definition: A mechanic whose occupation is to build mills, or to set uptheir machinery.
To run or pass under; especially (Naut.), to pass along andunder, as a cable, for the purpose of taking it in, or of examiningit.
The department of musical science which treats of the length ofsounds.
Pertaining to, or designating, a nitrogenous acid obtained as ayellow crystalline substance by the oxidation of quinine.
Pertaining to, or derived from, castor oil; formerly,designating an acid now called ricinoleic acid.
The quality or state of being other or different; alterity;oppositeness.
To utter as a rhapsody, or in the manner of a rhapsody Sterne.
With quick beating or palpitation; pitapat. Congreve.
That part of the breast of an animal which extends from thefore legs back beneath the ribs; also applied to the fore part of ahorse, from the shoulders to the bottom of the chest.
One of a group of nitrogenous phosphorized principles, supposedby Thudichum to exist in brain tissue.
According to measure or proportion; proportionable;proportionate. [Obs.]
A plane figure having four sides and angles; a quadrangle, as asquare, a rhombus, etc.
A writer of glosses or of a glossary; a commentator; ascholiast. Tyrwhitt.
One of a sect of ancient Christians, who, in supposed imitationof the first believers, renounced all their possessions.
A genus of plants, one species of which (A. Mexicanum) haslavender-blue flowers in dense clusters.
A nitrogenous substance, C8H7NO, isomeric with oxindol,obtained as an oily liquid.
A variety of bacterium; a microscopic, rod-shaped vegetableorganism.
A sigh or sobbing; also, a hiccough. [Obs.] Spenser. W. Browne.
Made by complete closure of the mouth organs; shut; -- said ofcertain consonants (p, b, t, d, etc.). H. Sweet.
The fold of skin which covers the glans of the penis; theprepuce.
Methyl alcohol, CH3OH; -- also, by extension, any one in thehomologous series of paraffine alcohols of which methyl alcohol isthe type.
One of the followers of Lucifer, bishop of Cagliari, in thefourth century, who separated from the orthodox churches because theywould not go as far as he did in opposing the Arians.
The reed bunting. It has a collar of white feathers. Calledalso ring bunting.
The state of being devoted, or set apart by a vow. [R.] Bp.Hurd.
A method of taking photographic pictures, on paper sensitizedwith iodide of silver; -- also called Talbotype, from the inventor,Mr. Fox. Talbot.
Two pieces of bread and butter with a thin slice of meat,cheese, or the like, between them.
The platform about the head of the mainmast in square-riggedvessels.

An instrument for recording, preserving, and reproducingsounds, the record being a tracing of a phonautograph etched in somesolid material. Reproduction  is accomplished by means of a systemattached to an elastic diaphragm.
The light elastic wood of the Aspidosperma excelsum, a tree ofGuiana having a fluted trunk readily split into planks.
A country seat; a country or suburban residence of somepretensions to elegance. Dryden. Cowper.
One who uses, or is skilled in the use of, an oar; a rower.
A genus of leguminous herbs with densely spiked flowers andusually trifoliate leaves; trefoil. There are many species, all ofwhich are called clover. See Clover.
A transparent or translucent variety of common feldspar, ororthoclase, which often shows pearly opalescent reflections; --called by lapidaries moonstone.

Primarily, liberty of converse; intercourse; hence, acertificate, given after compliance with quarantine regulations,permitting a ship to land passengers and crew; -- a term usedparticularly in the south of Europe.
One of the States of the United States of America.-- a.
A periodical work published once a quarter, or four times in ayear.
A sea god in the service of Neptune who assumed differentshapes at will. Hence, one who easily changes his appearance orprinciples.
The act or process of retenting; the state of having relented.Sir T. Browne.
The first word of any page of a book after the first, insertedat the right hand bottom corner of the preceding page for theassistance of the reader. It is seldom used in modern printing.
The epithelial lining of the ventricles of the brain and thecanal of the spinal cord; endyma; ependymis.
To deliver up by one government to another, as a fugitive fromjustice. See Extradition.
A blowing together, as of many instruments in a concert, or ofmany fires in a foundry. [R.]  Bacon.
A dry, cold, violent, northerly wind of the Adriatic.
After the manner of the Japanese; resembling japanned articles.Carlyle.
The glycerin salt of ricinoleic acid, occuring as acharacteristic constituent of castor oil; -- formerly called palmin.
A piece of canvas fastened by lacing to the bonnet of a sail,to give it a greater depth, or more drop.
A term formerly given to the salts supposed to be formedrespectively by neutralizing acids with certain peroxides. [Obsoles.]
To cover with shade; to render dark or gloomy; to overshadow.Shak.
A bitter, white, crystalline substance found in orange andlemon seeds.
A stock or handle for holding and rotating a bit; a brace.
The quality or state of being prefident. [Obs.] Baxter.
In an acute manner; sharply; keenly; with nice discrimination.
To tell, rehearse, or recite, as a story; to relate theparticulars of; to go through with in detail, as an incident ortransaction; to give an account of.
A kind of whip for flogging criminals, formerly much used inRussia. The last is a tapering bundle of leather thongs twisted withwire and hardened, so that it mangles the flesh.
A porridge or gruel of maize meal and water, milk, or the like.[Sp. Amer.]
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, the celandine. Cheidonicacid, a weak acid extracted fron the celandine (Chelidonium majus),as a white crystalline substance.
An earthen vessel wider at the top than at the bottom, -- usedfor holding milk and for various other purposes. [Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
A diseased condition produced by slow poisoning with arsenic.
Belonging to antipathy; opposite; contrary; allopathic.
A place or establishment where flax is retted. See Ret. Ure.
Sick at heart; extremely depressed in spirits; very despondent.
To become open, disclosed, or developed; to pass through aprocess of evolution. Prior.
A bird having small polygonal scales covering the tarsi.
One skilled in the knowledge of plants; a collector of, ordealer in, herbs, especially medicinal herbs.
An exclamation formerly used as an oath, and an expression ofanger or wonder.
A small worm or insect larva; also, a wormlike body. [R.]Derham.
The green woodpecker, or yaffle. See Yaffle. [Prov. Eng.]
Remorse; compunction; compassion. [Obs.] Killingbeck.

A series of antiphons and responses, expressing the sorrowfulremonstrance of our Lord with his people; -- sung on the morning ofthe Good Friday in place of the usual daily Mass of the Roman ritual.Grove.
The quality or state of being squalid; foulness; filthiness.
Having the anterior surface of the tarsus covered withscutella, or transverse scales, in the form of incomplete bandsterminating at a groove on each side; -- said of certain birds.
One skilled in pharmacy; a pharmaceutist; a druggist.
The figure, statue, or bust, on the prow of a ship.
A Roman governor of the fourth part of a province; hence, anysubordinate or dependent prince; also, a petty king or sovereign.
The burning of a wad of pease straw at the end of harvest.[Prov. Eng.]

A hut or small cottage in an expessed or a retired place (as ona mountain or at the seaside) such as is used by shepherds,fishermen, sportsmen, etc.; a summer cottage; also, a shed. [Writtenalso sheel, shealing, sheiling, etc.] [Scot.]

A curve invented by Diocles, for the purpose of solving twocelebrated problems of the higher geometry; viz., to trisect a planeangle, and to construct two geometrical means between two givenstraight lines.
Situated behind any transverse axis in the body of an animal;caudal; posterior; especially, behind, or on the caudal or posterior(that is, ulnar or fibular) side of, the axis of a vertebrate limb.
A female maker of, or dealer in, articles of fashion,especially of the fashionable dress of ladies; a woman who givesdirection to the style or mode of dress.
A fermented beverage made of honey and water; mead. Gay.
A judicial court of chancery, which in England and in theUnited States is distinctively a court with equity jurisdiction.
The middle segment of the thorax in insects. See Illust. ofColeoptera.
To take to graze or pasture, at a certain sum; -- usedoriginally of the feeding of cattle in the king's forests, andcollecting the money for the same. Blackstone.
To make fast, as a rope, by taking several turns with it rounda pin, cleat, or kevel. Totten.
In the manner of a child; in a trifling way; in a weak orfoolish manner.
Of or pertaining to Finland, to the Finns, or to theirlanguage.-- n.
Flexible; pliant; pliable; easily bent; plastic; tractable.Wordsworth.
Of or relating to worms, or Helminthes; expelling worms.-- n.
To exceed in the number of votes given; to defeat by votes.South.
Begone; depart; -- a word of contempt or abhorrence, equivalentto the phrase "Get thee gone."
A machine consisting of many pulleys; specifically, anapparatus formerly used for reducing luxations.
A colorless liquid, obtained from certain derivatives ofglycerin, and regarded as a partially dehydrated glycerin; -- calledalso glycidic alcohol.
A projecting mass of masonry, used for resisting the thrust ofan arch, or for ornament and symmetry.
An ancient anthem, -- usually known by its Latin nametersanctus.See Tersanctus.
Lasting six years, or happening once in six years.-- n.
A unit of electromotive force equal to one thousand volts.
To connect, in a series of links or ties; to chain. E. Darwin.
To form a key seat, as by cutting. See Key seat, under Key.
Want of surety; uncertainty; insecurity; doubt. [Obs.] Sir T.More.
An apparatus for conveying and distributing heat, especially bymeans of hot water circulating in tubes.
State of flowers; flowers, collectively or in general.Tennyson.
Of or pertaining to Galatia or its inhabitants.-- A native or inhabitant of Galatia, in Asia Minor; a descendant ofthe Gauls who settled in Asia Minor.
One of a series of anhydrides of an amido type, analogous tothe lactones, as oxindol.
To congeal; to change into a gelatinous mass. [R.] H. Spencer.
Work done by a cooper in making or repairing barrels, casks,etc.; the business of a cooper.
A bunch of hackled flax prepared for drawing into slivers.Knight.
Of or pertaining to catechu or its derivatives. See catechin.
A vase with a separate cover, the body usually rounded orpolygonal in plan with nearly vertical sides, a neck of smaller size,and a rounded shoulder.
Any one of several species of small arctic rodents of thegenera Myodes and Cuniculus, resembling the meadow mice in form. Theyare found in both hemispheres.
Capable of being decided by arbitration; determinable.[Archaic] Bp. Hall.
Of or pertaining to Bengal.-- n. sing. & pl. A native or natives of Bengal.
A box from which dice are thrown in gaming. Thackeray.
An infinitesimal change in a varying quantity; an increment ordecrement. [Obs.]

One of the forms which a verb takes by inflection or by addingauxiliary words, so as to indicate the time of the action or eventsignified; the modification which verbs undergo for the indication oftime.
An instrument for measuring minute quantities of radiant heat,especially in different parts of the spectrum; -- called also actinicbalance, thermic balance. S. P. Langley.
A slender prolongation of the receptacle as an axis between thecarpels, as in Geranium and many umbelliferous plants.
A boat with a flat bottom and square ends; -- used for thetransportation of bulky freight, especially in shallow waters.
A dark variety of sandstone, much used for building purposes.
Tending to render costive, or to diminish excretions ordischarges generally.-- n.
A genus of grasses including the various species of wheat.
A small-sized, well-proportioned, Spanish horse; a jennet.Shak.
A genus of bulbous-rooted plants found in many parts of Europe,including the meadow saffron.
A person who sells by auction; a person whose business it is todispose of goods or lands by public sale to the highest or bestbidder.
To exhaust or evaporate moisture from; to dry up. Sir T.Browne.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid, CH2O2(CO2H)2, obtainedfrom amido malonic acid.
A series of beds of clay and marl in the South of England,between the upper and lower greensand of the Cretaceous period.
The dowitcher or red-breasted snipe. See Dowitcher.
A hitch by which a rope may be temporarily shortened.
One of a class of temporal officers who originally representedthe bishops, but later erected their offices into fiefs, and becamefeudal nobles.
A hydrous silicate of alumina and baryta, occurring usually inwhite cruciform crystals; cross-stone.
Egg-bearing; -- applied particularly to certain receptacles, asin Crustacea, that retain the eggs after they have been excluded fromthe formative organs, until they are hatched.
An anarch; one who advocates anarchy of aims at the overthrowof civil government.
Of, pertaining to, or characterizing, the most recent divisionof the Tertiary age.
Flowing apart or off; dissolving; not fixed. [R.] Bailey.
A group of nomadic North American Indians including severaltribes native of Arizona, New Mexico, etc.
A nitrogenous compound, C7H6N2, analogous to indol, andproduced from a diazo derivative or cinnamic acid.
Inflammation of the spinal marrow or its membranes.
That which is within; the interior. [Poetic] Mrs. Browning.
The freezing, or effect of a freezing, of some part of thebody, as the ears or nose. Kane.
A harmless snake (Farancia abacura), found in the SouthernUnited States. The color is bluish black above, red below.
Containing directions; enjoining; instructing; directorial.
A small sturgeon (Acipenser ruthenus) found in the Caspian Seaand its rivers, and highly esteemed for its flavor. The finestcaviare is made from its roe.
A clumsy vessel that works its way from one anchorage toanother by means of the tides. Ham. Nav. Encyc.
A stanza of four lines rhyming alternately. Dryden.
The substances which inclose the ore on every side.
The act or practice of opening cysts; esp., the operation ofcutting into the bladder, as for the extraction of a calculus.
A writer of fables; a fabulist; a dealer in untruths orfalsehoods. Br. Hall.
A Russian river craft used for transporting freight.
A suburb of French city; also, a district now within a city,but formerly without its walls.
Appearing as if one side, or one half, were cut away;dimidiate.
A blue isometric mineral, characteristic of some volcani
A first view or glance, or the perception or estimation soobtained; an immediate apprehension or insight, appreciative ratherthan analytic.
Common or potash feldspar crystallizing in the monoclinicsystem and having two cleavages at right angles to each other. SeeFeldspar.
A glucoside found in species of the genus Pavia of the Horse-chestnut family.
One who, or that which, dibbles, or makes holes in the groundfor seed.
A handlelike process or part; esp., the anterior segment of thesternum, or presternum, and the handlelike process of the malleus.
One who repents, especially one who repents of sin; a penitent.
To drink deeply or freely in compliment; to take in a carousal;to engage in drunken revels.He had been aboard, carousing to his mates. Shak.
A summerhouse so situated as to command an extensive prospect.[Colloq.]
A sudden stroke or injury produced by some destructive cause.[Obs.] Shak.
An attachment to a millstone spindle for shaking the hoppe
The sacred books of the Buddhists in Burmah. Malcom.

The crested screamer of Brazil (Palamedea, or Chauna,chavaria), so called in imitation of its notes; -- called alsochauna, and faithful kamichi. It is often domesticated and is usefulin guarding other poultry. See Kamichi.
One who charters; esp. one who hires a ship for a voyage.
The views or teachings of Robert Brown of the Brownists.Milton.
The tendency or disposition to represent objects faithfully,without abstraction, conventionalities, or idealization.
In a primary manner; in the first place; in the first place; inthe first intention; originally.
Ornamental work with rambled lines. Especially: --(a) The decorative head of a Gothic window.
A literal adherent to, or a minute critic of, words; aliteralist.
The upper horizontal part of a step, on which the foot isplaced.
Emerging from the light of the sun, or passing into it; risingor setting at the same, or nearly the same, time as the sun. Sir T.Browne.
One of a negro tribe of Liberia and the adjacent coast, whosemembers are much employed on shipboard.
A kind of large rush, growing in wet land or in water.
Shield money; commutation of service for a sum of money. SeeEscuage.
To reduce to the smallest part or proportion possible; toreduce to a minimum. Bentham.
A leafstalk; the footstalk of a leaf, connecting the blade withthe stem. See Illust. of Leaf.
A ruffian; one who hounds, or spies upon, another; app. esp. tothe members of certain alleged societies among the Chinese. [U. S.]
A graduated scale for measuring the duration of sounds, anddetermining their different, and the relation of their intervals. J.J. Rousseau.
A panel deeply recessed in the ceiling of a vault, dome, orportico; a caisson.
An oily substance obtained by the distillation of castor oil,recognized as the aldehyde of oenanthylic acid, and hence called alsooenanthaldehyde.
To deprive of a tongue, or of voice. [Obs.] Fuller.
A genus consisting mostly of tropical perennial herbs(Commelina), having ephemeral flowers.

To convert into an emulsion; to form an emulsion; to reducefrom an oily substance to a milky fluid in which the fat globules arein a very finely divided state, giving it the semblance of solution;as, the pancreatic juice emulsifies the oily part of food.
, Consisting of quirks; resembling a quirk. Barrow.
An oily liquid alkaloid, C5H11N, having a hot, peppery,ammoniacal odor. It is related to pyridine, and is obtained by thedecomposition of piperine.
A bitter white crystalline substance obtained by thedecomposition of phlorizin, and formerly used to some extent as asubstitute for quinine.
A cone of paper which is placed in a vessel of lard or otherfat, and used as a taper. [Prov. Eng.]
To put an equal value upon; to put (something) on a par withanother thing. W. Taylor.
Earth or materials made into a bank after having beenexcavated.
A duty payable on commodities by the bushel. [Eng.]
Tonic spasm; -- applied generically to denote any diseasecharacterized by tonic spasms, as tetanus, trismus, etc.
Emptying; evacuative; purgative; cathartic.-- n. (Med.)
Potential energy; negative value of the force function.
One who opposes or attacks; that which opposes. Selden.
An unfermentable carbohydrate obtained by gently heatinglevulose.
To put, or go, on board a vessel again; to embark again.
An apparatus for passing air or gases through or over certainliquids or solids, or for exhausting a closed vessel, by means ofsuction.
A plant of the genus Geum, esp. Geum urbanum, or herb bennet.
A curve or arch in a bit to afford room for the tongue of thehorse.
In a manner not to be expressed in words; unspeakably. Milton.
To have a mistaken notion of or about. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
The locus described by any point attached to a curve that slipscontinuously on another fixed curve, the movable curve having norotation at any instant.
Passing through all its stages on one host, as certainparasitic fungi; -- contrasted with heterocious.
A Basque, Spanish, and Spanish-American game played in a court,in which a ball is struck with a wickerwork racket.
A large flat-bottomed trading boat peculiar to the riverGanges; -- called also puteli.
The snakebird, a water bird of the genus Plotus; -- so calledbecause it darts out its long, snakelike neck at its prey. SeeSnakebird.
To cover with a frieze, or as with a frieze. E. Hall.
That branch of science which treats of the laws and phenomenaof aqueous vapor. Whewell.
In a coarse manner; roughly; rudely; inelegantly; uncivilly;meanly.
The spotted flycatcher; -- so called from the white color ofthe under parts. [Prov. Eng.]
A mineral resin, of a blackish brown color, occurring in soft,flexible masses; -- called also mineral caoutchouc, and elasticbitumen.
In an artless manner; without art, skill, or guile;unaffectedly. Pope.
A case of strong paper filled with a composition of niter,sulphur, and mealed powder, -- used principally to ignite the primingin proving guns, and as an incendiary material in shells.
A growing together of parts; specifically, a morbid adhesion ofthe eyelids to each other or to the eyeball. Dunglison.
A superior lord, to whom fealty is due; a feudal lord; a lordparamount.
A colorless oily liquid, C4H3S.CH3, analogous to, andresembling, toluene; -- called also methyl thiophene.
A structure or frame of crossbarred work, or latticework, usedfor various purposes, as for screens or for supporting plants.
A rustic dance, so called in ridicule of the people of Bergamo,in Italy, once noted for their clownishness.
One who uses a sickle; a reaper.You sunburned sicklemen, of August weary. Shak.
A government by seven persons; also, a country under sevenrulers.
A place where the bones of the dead are deposited; a charnelhouse. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
a malvaceous plant (Hibiscus Sabdariffa) cultivated in the eastand West Indies for its fleshy calyxes, which are used for makingtarts and jelly and an acid drink.
To reply, as a plaintiff to a defendant's rebutter.
A liquor made of ale and honey fermented, with spices, etc.[Obs.] B. Jonson.
Not having the claws and balls of the forefeet cut off; -- saidof dogs.
To heave or lift up from beneath; to raise. Milton.
Pertaining to the care and medical treatment of children.[Webster 1913 Suppl.]
A light, smooth-bored gun, often double-barreled, especiallydesigned for firing small shot at short range, and killing smallgame.
Inclined to pester. Also, vexatious; encumbering; burdensome.[Obs.] Bacon.
A genus of birds, with a short, conical, pointed bill. Itformerly included all the sparrows and finches, but is now restrictedto certain European finches, like the chaffinch and brambling.
A genus of tropical and subtropical trees with pinnate leavesand panicled flowers. The fruits of some species are used instead ofsoap, and their round black seeds are made into necklaces.
To scramble or struggle; to wrangle; also, to be industrious.[Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a variety of the revivedclassic style of architecture, founded on the works of AndreaPalladio, an Italian architect of the 16th century.
A ship or seagoing vessel propelled by the power of steam; asteamer.
A paraffin obtained from petroleum from Rangoon in India, andpractically identical with ordinary paraffin.
A monster, in the shape, of a three-headed dog, guarding theentrance into the infernal regions, Hence: Any vigilant custodian orguardian, esp. if surly.
A bird belonging to the tribe of which the genus Tetrao is thetype, as the grouse, partridge, quail, and the like. Used alsoadjectively.
In a gradually diminishing manner; with abatement of tone;decrescendo; -- expressed on the staff by Dim., or Dimin., or thesign.
A more or less round gall resembling a nut, esp. one of thoseproduced on the oak and used in the arts. See Gall, Gallnut.
A very broad and heavy wooden collar which certain offenders inChina are compelled to wear as a punishment.
A Venetian vessel, with a square stern, having only a mainmast,jigger mast, and bowsprit; also a sloop of war ship-rigged.
A mass of large stones thrown into water at random to formbases of piers, breakwaters, etc.
Of or pertaining to a cobbler or cobblers; like a cobbler;hence, vulgar; low. [Obs.]
An Anabaptist or Baptist. [Contemptuous] B. Jonson.
A yellowish coloring matter found in plants grown in darkness,which is supposed to be an antecedent condition of chlorophyll.Encyc. Brit.
A white crystalline substance of a sweetish taste, resemblinginosite and metameric with dextrose. It is extracted from the kidneyof the dogfish (of the genus Scylium), the shark, and the skate.
In an integral manner; wholly; completely; also, byintegration.
The act or ceremony of depositing a dead body in the earth;burial; sepulture; inhumation. T. Warton.
The common mullein, the stalks of which, dipped in suet,anciently served for torches. Called also torch, and hig-taper.
The brans, stables, cattle-yards, etc., of a farm; -- calledalso onstead, farmstead, farm offices, or farmery. [Prov. Eng. &Scot.]
An application (a remedy, bandage, etc.) to a sore or wound.Wiseman.
A liquid hydrocarbon obtained by the decomposition of veratricacid, and constituting the dimethyl ether of pyrocatechin.
A book of reference, to be carried in the hand; a manual; aguidebook.
To lay out; to spread out; to display. [R.] Drayton.
Impossible to be searched; inscrutable; impenetrable.
A pin, usually forked, or of bent wire, for fastening the hairin place, -- used by women.
The captain, master, or commander of a ship. Jonah i. 6.
Electric potential or potential difference, expressed in volts.
To give the wrong meter to, as to a line of verse. [R.]Chaucer.
A significant shake of the head, commonly as a signal ofdenial. Shak.
An Asiatic deer (Rucervus Eldi) resembling the swamp deer; --called also Eld's deer.
The mistress of a house. [Archaic] Robynson (More's Utopia).
To convert into stone or stony material; to petrify.
One who topes, or drinks frequently or to excess; a drunkard; asot.
A woman who milks cows or is employed in the dairy.
A gill; a respiratory organ for breathing the air contained inwater, such as many aquatic and semiaquatic animals have.

A presbyter elder; a minister; specifically:(a) (R. C. Ch. & Gr. Ch.) One who is authorized to consecrate thehost and to say Mass; but especially, one of the lowest orderpossessing this power. Murdock. (b) (Ch. of Eng. & Prot. Epis. Ch.)
The act of whistling or hissing; a whistling sound; sibilation.[Obs.] A. Brewer.
The act of loosening or slackening, or the state of beingloosened or slackened.
A yellow, vegetable dyestuff, resembling quercitron.
The quality or state of being unreal; want of reality.
An old English gold coin, broader than a guinea, as a Carolusor Jacobus.
Bulged; bulging; bending, or tending to bend, outward.[Colloq.]
In a parallel manner; with parallelism. [R.] Dr. H. More.
A genus of ruminants, including the red deer and other alliedspecies.
An iodine compound obtained as a yellowish gray, odorless,tasteless powder by the action of iodine on phenolphthalein.
Relating to, or resulting from, experience, or experiment;following from empirical methods or data; -- opposed to nativistic.
A lilylike plant, of the genus Gladiolus; -- called also cornflag.
A note of reference or comment at the foot of a page.
The part of the epididymis; or the corresponding part of theexcretory duct of the testicle, which is derived from the Wolffianbody.
One who forsakes a duty, a cause or a party, a friend, or anyone to whom he owes service; especially, a soldier or a seaman whoabandons the service without leave; one guilty of desertion.
The six-shafted bird of paradise. See Paradise bird, underParadise.
A sedgelike plant (Cyperus esculentus) producing edible tubers,native about the Mediterranean, now cultivated in many regions; theearth almond.
A genus of plants, including the onion, garlic, leek, chive,etc.
A measure of electro-motive force; the millionth part of onevolt.
To squeeze, compress, crush, or bruise. [Obs. or Low] Spenser.
An old English game; -- called also lawn billiards.
One who has only a slight, superficial knowledge; a sciolist.
Relating to the deepest zone or region of the ocean.
To cause to have a wrong inclination or tendency; to affectwrongly.
A name applied loosely to several plants of different genera,esp. the comfrey.
Engaged in inspection; inspecting; involving inspection.
To dispose anew or again; to readjust; to rearrange. A. Baxter.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid, C5H6O4, which isobtained as a white crystalline substance by decomposing aconitic andother organic acids.
A division of phyllopod Crustacea, including those that areentirely covered by a bivalve shell.
One who believes in the existence of a God, but denies revealedreligion; a freethinker.
To give over; to surrender; to yield. [Obs.] Spenser.
The act or method of arranging in or by grade, or of bringing,as the surface of land or a road, to the desired level or grade.
A kind of biscuit or  rusk first baked in a loaf and afterwardscut and toasted.
The ascigerous fructification of lichens, forming masses ofvarious shapes.
One of a sect, chiefly in Syria and Egypt, which acknowledgesthe authority of the pope, but adheres to the liturgy and ceremoniesof the Eastern Church.
An inferior commercial variety of India rubber made up intoround masses.
A bluestocking; a literary woman. [Somewhat derisive]
(Bot.) A leguminous herb (Onobrychis Caput-galli), having smallspiny-crested pods.

An exhibition in which a series of views in various parts ofthe world is seen reflected by mirrors through a series of lenses,with such illumination, etc., as will make the views most closelyrepresent reality.
The higher order of clergy in Russia, including metropolitans,archbishops, and bishops. Pinkerton.
Something expressed verbally; a verbal remark or expression.
A small variety of the Lima bean (Phaseolus lunatus).
A disease, usually accompanied by colicky pains and diarrhea,caused by the presence of ascarids in the gastrointestinal canal.
Marriage only within the tribe; a custom restricting a man inhis choice of a wife to the tribe to which he belongs; -- opposed toexogamy.
Having a single, distinct, diagonal cleavage; -- said ofcrystals. Mohs.
To crowd together; to fill with obstructions; to block up.[Obs.] Cockeram.
A state which consists in total suspension of sensibility, ofvoluntary motion, and largely of mental power. The body is erect andinflexible; the pulsation and breathing are not affected. Mayne.
A condition of excessive redness. See Erythrochroism.
Bladdery; full of, or covered with, bladders; vesicular.
An alkaloid extracted from hops as a colorless volatile liquid.
One who sings the leading part; the director or leader. [Obs.]
One of an extinct genus of fossil cephalopods, allied to theAmmonites. The earliest forms are found in the Devonian formation,the latest, in the Triassic.
One who works for a certain portion of the ore, or its value.[Eng.]
An American ranunculaceous plant (Hidrastis Canadensis), havinga yellow tuberous root; -- also called yellowroot, golden seal, etc.
One of the segments of the abdomen or post-abdomen ofarthropods.
A sudden vertigo in a horse, succeeded sometimes byunconsciousness, produced by an excess of blood in the brain; a mildform of apoplexy. Youatt.
An East India muslin, formerly used for cravats, veils, etc.[Obs.]
A glutinous substance, insoluble in alcohol, resemblinglegumin; -- now called vegetable fibrin, vegetable albumin, or glutencasein.
A group of rodents, including the hares. They have fourincisors in the upper jaw. Called also Duplicidentata.
In England, the hawthorn; in New England, the trailing arbutus(see Arbutus); also, the blossom of these plants.
A Spanish title of courtesy given to a young lady; Miss; also,a young lady.
An ancient geometrical method in which an exhaustive processwas employed. It was nearly equivalent to the modern method oflimits.
A soldier detailed or employed to form roads, dig trenches, andmake bridges, as an army advances.
A grallatorial bird of Europe (Cursorius cursor), remarkablefor its speed in running. Sometimes, in a wider sense, applied torunning birds of the Ostrich family.
Of the nature of, or pertaining to, chorea; convulsive.
A kind of incubus which occurs during wakefulness, attended bythe peculiar pressure on the chest which characterizes nightmare.Dunglison.
A small pattern; a small quantity. [Obs.] Sir M. Hale.
An old theory of generation similar to emboOvulist.
The pied antelope of South Africa (Alcelaphus pygarga). Itsface and rump are white. Called also nunni.
Capable of being forgiven; pardonable; venial. Sherwood.
The top, platform, or horizontal surface, of a rampart, onwhich the cannon are placed. See Illust. of Casemate.
A very small figure, whether human or of an animal; especially,one in terra cotta or the like; -- distinguished from statuette,which is applied to small figures in bronze, marble, etc.
A genus of plants including the cashew tree. See Cashew.
The soil beneath the surface; understratum; subsoil.
Given to, or characterized by, vagaries; capricious; whimsical;crochety.
A strong black chewing tobacco, usually in twisted plug form;negro head.
To make actual; to realize in action. [R.] Coleridge.
In Spain and countries colonized by Spain, a village, ward, ordistrict outside a town or city to whose jurisdiction it belongs.
One who, or that which, aromatizes or renders aromatic. Evelyn.
Increasing strength, or the tone of the animal system;obviating the effects of debility, and restoring heatly functions.Tononic spasm. (Med.) See the Note under Spasm.
Having discomfort or misery; troubled. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who performs a public religious rite; -- appliedparticularly to an officiating priest in the Roman Catholic Church,as distinguished from his assistants.
An instrument by which the power of hearing can be gauged andrecorded on a scale.
A compound of the radical amyl with oxygen and a positive atomor radical.
The lower, or bottom, pipe in a lift of pumps in a mine.Ansted.
A book of directions and information for travelers, tourists,etc.
A small West Indian tree (Trophis Americana) of the Mulberryfamily, whose leaves and twigs are used as fodder for cattle.
A body or collection of cousins; the whole number of personswho stand in the relation of cousins to a given person or persons.
A south American fresh water fish of the genus Serrasalmo ofmany species, remakable for its voracity. When numerous they attackman or beast, often with fatal results.
One of several species of East Indian birds of the generaOrtygis and Hemipodius. They resemble quails, but lack the hind toe.See Turnix.
A dyestuff consisting of the dried bodies of females of theCoccus cacti, an insect native in Mexico, Central America, etc., andfound on several species of cactus, esp. Opuntia cochinellifera.
To cause to turn across; to transverse. [Obs.] Craft of Lovers(1448).
Not sternal; -- said of ribs which do not join the sternum.
To throw out or reject as false or ungrounded; -- said of abill rejected by a grand jury for want of evidence. See Ignoramus.
A native, or one of the Scandinavian people, of Iceland.
A ketone of valeric acid obtained as an oily liquid.
A large flying squirrel (Pteromys petuarista). Its body becomestwo feet long, with a large bushy tail nearly as long.
A foul vein, like chalcedony, in some precious stones.
One who steals and drives away cattle or beasts by herds ordroves. [Obs.]
The department of knowledge relative to the care and culture ofthe people; sociology in its broadest sense; -- in librarycataloguing.
A room for cookery; a kitchen; the galley or caboose of a ship.Sir W. Raleigh.
The state of being far off; distance; remoteness. [R.] Grew.
A long, straightnecked, glass vessel for chemicaldistillations; -- called also a matrass or receiver.
A vat or tub in which the mash is made; a mash tub. Ure.
A tablet; a register; hence, a list or scheme inscribed on atablet. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
An inward stroke; specif., in a steam or other engine, a strokein which the piston is moving away from the crank shaft; -- opposedto outstroke.
Of or pertaining to pitch; resembling pitch in color orquality; pitchy.
Pertaining to, or derived from, the juice of the Lactucavirosa; -- said of certain acids.
One of several species of California market fishes, of thegenus Sebastichthys; -- called also rockfish. See Rockfish.
A small gable, or gable-shaped canopy, formed over atabernacle, niche, etc.

One of the maidens of Odin, represented as awful and beautiful,who presided over battle and marked out those who were to be slain,and who also ministered at the feasts of heroes in Valhalla. [Writtenalso Valkyr, and Walkyr.]
A lot consisting of sixty pieces; -- a term applied in someBaltic ports to loose goods.
Any one of numerous species of reptiles of the orderTestudinata.
A South African carnivore (Cynictis penicillata), allied to theichneumons.
The act of omitting, or the state of being omitted;forbearance; neglect. Shak.

The art of working metals, comprehending the whole process ofseparating them from other matters in the ore, smelting, refining,and parting them; sometimes, in a narrower sense, only the process ofextracting metals from their ores.
A small oval plum of a blue color, the fruit of a variety ofthe Prunus domestica; -- called also damask plum.
By way of derision; in a contemptuous or mocking manner.
To wrest or force from the natural or proper position. Shak.
To freeze together again; to undergo regelation, as ice.
An old measure of length in France, containing six French feet,or about 6.3946 French feet.
A place where cloth is printed; print works; also, a printingoffice. [R.]
A class of plants in the Linnaean system, whose stamens growout of, or are united with, the pistil.
Tending to seclude; keeping in seclusion; secluding;sequestering.
Situated around bone; of or pertaining to the periosteum.
A ring of rope used as a wad to hold a cannon ball in place.
One belonging to, or living in, a cloister; a recluse.
To sink or lay, as in a bed; to deposit in a partly inclosingmass, as of clay or mortar; to cover, as with earth, sand, etc.
One who borrows personal chattels which are to be consumed byhim, and which he is to return or repay in kind. Bouvier.
An apparatus designed to close an unnatural opening, as afissure of the palate.
A long plain double-breasted outside coat for women.
A board, as upon a guidepost having upon it directions orinformation as to the road. Lowell.
Queer, and fitted to provoke laughter; ludicrous from oddity;amusing and strange.
Clouded with indistinct color markings, as an animal.
The office, duty, or care of a tutor; guardianship; tutelage.Hooker.
A dry, indehiscent, usually one-seeded, winged fruit, as thatof the ash, maple, and elm; a key or key fruit.
A custom of tenants to grind corn at the lord's mill. Cowell.
An English silver coin of the value of six pennies; half ashilling, or about twelve cents.
The quality or state of being tamable; tamableness.
A fisherman who used unlawful arts and engines to catch fish.[Obs.] Cowell.
A brittle mineral of a steel-gray color and metallic luster,containing antimony, arsenic, sulphur, and nickel.
Placed so as to face one another; -- said of animals.
A forest composed of stunted trees and thorny bushes, found inareas of small rainfall in Brazil.

A figure in which a word is separated or repeated by way ofemphasis, so as not only to signify the individual thing denoted byit, but also its peculiar attribute or quality; as, "His wife's awife indeed." Bailey.
One of the natives of France who were opposed to the firstRevolution, and who left their country in consequence.
Of, pertaining to, resembling, or derived from, pectose;specifically, designating an acid supposed to constitute largelyordinary pectin or vegetable jelly.
A deposit of superficial loam, sand, gravel, stones, etc.,caused by former action of flowing waters, or the melting of glacialice.
The branch of science which treats of fossil footprints.
Of pertaining to the Plotinists or their doctrines.
One of those, in the 4th century, who accepted the Nicenecreed, and maintained that the Son had the same essence or substancewith the Father; -- opposed to homoiousian.
Pertaining to, or evincing, orthodoxy; orthodox. [R.] Milton.
A Bible consisting of four different Greek versions arranged infour columns by Origen; hence, any version in four languages or fourcolumns.
A plant (Centaurea cyanus) which grows in grain fields. Itreceives its name from its blue bottle-shaped flowers.
An extractive matter contained in the juice of the green shucksof the walnut (Juglans regia). It is used medicinally as analterative, and also as a black hair dye.
A magistrate; one of a body of five magistrates chosen by thepeople of ancient Sparta. They exercised control even over the king.
A round-bottomed glass flask having a long neck; a bolthead.
A horseman armed with a lance, who in a bullfight receives thefirst attack of the bull, and excites him by picking him withoutattempting to kill him.
The day after or following to-morrow. [Obs.] Bible (1551).
The state of being exotic; also, anything foreign, as a word oridiom; an exotic.
Given to laughter; inclined to foolish or incessant merriment.
The first stomach of ruminants; the paunch; the fardingbag. SeeIllust. below.
A white amorphous or crystalline substance, obtained bydehydration of mannite, and distinct from, but convertible into,mannitan.
A name sometimes given to the nitro group or radical.

A bluish black, amorphous substance containing iron andobtained from blood. It exists the red blood corpuscles united withglobulin, and the form of hemoglobin or oxyhemoglobin gives to theblood its red color.
A kind of eruption upon the skin; lentigo; freckle.
To lay up, as in a treasury; to hoard. [Obs.] Shak.
A short passage connecting two sections, but not forming partof either; a short coda.
A divinity worshiped by the ancient Peruvians as the creator ofthe universe.
A genus of fossil corals abundant in the Silurian and Devonianrocks, having polygonal cells with perforated walls.
Inducing to vomit; exciting the stomach to discharge itscontents by the mouth.-- n.
To unite to, or form into, a canton or separate community.Addison.
To draw or delineate rapidly and by way of a first sketch.
A mark indicating a question; a note of interrogation.
The worn side of the bank of a river. See 4th Fret, n., 4.
A copy or exemplification of a record. [Obs.] Lord Herbert.
Relating to that kind of homology or symmetry, the mathematicalconception of organic form, in which all axes are equal. See underPromorphology.
A wooden instrument like a large knife, about two feet long,with one thin edge, used for beating and cleaning flax; a scutcher; -- called also swingling knife, swingling staff, and swingling wand.
The art of dressing up; artifice; stratagem; fraud; imposture.
A plant coif or skullcap. Same as Calotte. B. Jonson.
The ring-necked scaup duck; -- called also ring-billedblackhead. See Scaup.
A former gold coin of Germany worth nearly five dollars; also,a gold coin of Sweden worth nearly five dollars.
One of the opium alkaloids; a white crystalline substance,C18H21NO3, similar to and regarded as a derivative of morphine, butmuch feebler in its action; -- called also codeia.
A pungent colorless explosive liquid, CNO2Br3, analogous to andresembling chlorpicrin. [Spelt also brompikrin.]
That which tends to produce torsion; a couple of forces. J.Thomson.
A genus of mosses having white leaves slightly tinged with redor green and found growing in marshy places; bog moss; peat moss.
The Muse who presided over lyric and amatory poetry.
Of or pertaining to the medulla oblongata; medullar.
That part of the starch granule or granulose which is solublein water.
A nest: a repository for the eggs of birds, insects, etc.; abreeding place; esp., the place or substance where parasites or thegerms of a disease effect lodgment or are developed.
Like a friar; pertaining to friars or to a convent. [Obs.]Camden.
A half column; a column bisected longitudinally, or along itsaxis.
American genus of herbaceous plants with very handsome bell-shaped blossoms; -- named after B. P. Gloxin, a German botanist.
A certain rate per cent; the allowance, duty, rate of interest,discount, or commission, on a hundred.
To go, or move (in a certain manner); -- usually with out, off,along, etc. [Colloq.]  E. N. Wescott.
A running knot, or loop, which binds the closer the more it isdrawn.
Forgetfulness; also, a defect of speech, from cerebral disease,in which the patient substitutes wrong words or names in the place ofthose he wishes to employ. Quian.
The quality or state of being petty or paltry; littleness;meanness.
One who dances, walks, or performs acrobatic feats, on a ropeextended through the air at some height.-- Rope"dan`cing, n.
One who immigrates; one who comes to a country for the purposeof permanent residence; -- correlative of emigrant.
The pupa of insects which undergo only a slight change inpassing to the imago state.
A condition in which uric (lithic) acid is present in theblood.
An opening at either end of the embryonic neural canal.
Not tied up in tresses; unarranged; -- said of the hair.Chaucer.
Leather prepared from the skin of young or small cattle,intermediate in grade between calfskin and cowhide.
The mark, or stamp, of a post office on a letter, giving theplace and date of mailing or of arrival.
One who, or that which, scales; specifically, a dentist'sinstrument for removing tartar from the teeth.
An eruptive rock characterized by the presence of chrysolite(peridot). It also usually contains pyroxene, enstatite, chromite,etc. It is often altered to serpentine.
A complex, hypothetical radical, composed of two parts ofcarbon to three of hydrogen and one of oxygen. Its hydroxide isacetic acid.
A few silk threads or horsehairs, or a strip of linen or thelike, introduced beneath the skin by a knife or needle, so as to forman issue; also, the issue so formed.
A game at dice, properly called novem quinque (L., nine five),the two principal throws being nine and five. [Obs.] Shak.
A white amorphous or crystalline substance obtained by thepartial dehydration of mannite.
To spring upward; to rise. [R.] Davies (Microcosmos).
Bluish green granules which occur in certain lichens, asCollema, Peltigera, etc., and which replace the more usual gonidia.
An ornament, composed of vine leaves and bunches of grapes,used for decorating spiral columns.
Full of teen; harmful; grievous; grieving; afflicted. [Obs.]Piers Plowman.
The funnel part of the apparatus for solution by displacement.
Implying or imputing evil; depreciatory; disparaging;unfavorable.
To pass the summer in a state of torpor. [Spelt also estivate.]
To clear from spots or stains, or from any imperfection. [Obs.]Hales.
A license formerly required for the making over a bill ofexchange to another over sea. Cowell.
A division of nematoid worms, including the hairworms or haireels (Gordius and Mermis). See Gordius, and Illustration in Appendix.
A ball or globe on the top of a pillar, church, etc., as at St.Paul's, in London. [R.]
One to whom goods are bailed, to be kept for the bailor withouta recompense. Kent.
Conferring honor; tending to honor. London. Spectator.
To boil up; to swell and rage; to be agitated. Bacon.
To kiss; especially, to kiss repeatedly or fondly. [Obs.]
One who keeps or tends a bar for the sale of liquors.
The theory, held by Euhemerus, that the gods of mythology werebut deified mortals, and their deeds only the amplification inimagination of human acts.
A genus of grasses, including several hundred species, some ofwhich are valuable; panic grass.
A flat file having the handle at one side, so as to be usedlike a plane.
The poisoning of the system by the introduction of putrescentmaterial into the blood.
To cry out with vehemence; to exclaim; to bawl; to clamor.Cowper.
A sluiceway or passage for superfluous water in a reservoir, toprevent too great pressure on the dam.
A place artificially arranged for keeping or raising livinganimals, as a park, a pond, an aquarium, a warren, etc.
One who pumps; the instrument or machine used in pumping.Boyle.
Any ruminant having horns composed of a bony axis covered witha horny sheath; a hollow-horned ruminant.
Master; sir; -- a title of the Middle Ages, given to a personin authority, or to one having a license from a university to teachphilosophy and the liberal arts.
That which serves to guard from falling water; a drip ordripstone.
To throw together, or to throw. [Obs.] Bp. Montagu.
High boots or buskins; in Scotland, short spatterdashes orriding trousers, worn over the other clothing.
Rough dressing by knocking off knobs or projections.
In an especial manner; chiefly; particularly; peculiarly; in anuncommon degree.
The Florida and West Indian red snapper (Lutianus aya); also,sometimes, one of certain other allied species, as L. caxis.
Tin ore scarcely perceptible in the stone; tin ore stamped veryfine. Pryce.
Of or pertaining to the noumenon; real; -- opposed tophenomenal. G. H. Lewes.
One who actuates, or puts into action. [R.] Melville.
A division into fingers or fingerlike processes; also, afingerlike process.
An instrument for removing small rough portions of bone.
A genus of fishes, having the head prolonged into a tube, withthe mouth at the extremity.
A deep bright red tinged with orange or yellow, -- of manytints and shades; a vivid or bright red color.
One who deals in sundries, or a variety of articles.
The quality or state of being plangent; a beating sound. [R.]
A division of Lepidoptera, including the butterflies; -- socalled because they fly only in the daytime.
One who works a mine with means provided by another. [Sp. Amer.& Southwestern U. S.]
Of or pertaining to an asteroid, or to the asteroids.
One of the larger measures of electro-motive force, amountingto one million volts.
A heater; one who, or that which, makes hot, as a stove, etc.
Of or pertaining to Xanthus, an ancient town on Asia Minor; --applied especially to certain marbles found near that place, and nowin the British Museum.
The insertion of one or more clauses between the subject andthe verb, in a way that involves or complicates the construction.
Composed of, or having, tufted or matted filaments like tow;stupeous.
An upper skirt, shorter than the dress, and usually draped.
The great world; that part of the universe which is exterior toman; -- contrasted with microcosm, or man. See Microcosm.
A fortune teller; an astrologer; -- used in contempt. B.Jonson.
An ornamental appendage of wood at the ship's stern, usuallyspreading like a fan and curved like a bird's feather. Audsley.
One who, or that which, blanches or whitens; esp., one whoanneals and cleanses money; also, a chemical preparation for thispurpose.
A rebate or chase in masonry left to receive a permanent slabor other filling.
A book in which are described the sufferings of saints andmartyrs. T. Warton.
Bad legislation; the enactment of bad laws. Cockeram.
A nickname for auricular confession; shrift. [Obs.] Cartwright.
A white amorphous substance, the insoluble part of cherry gum;-- called also meta-arabinic acid.
The grasshopper warbler; -- so called from its note. [Prov.Eng.]
A small yellow-headed bird (Auriparus flaviceps) of LowerCalifornia, allied to the titmice; -- called also goldtit.
Any part of a rampart or parapet which deviates from thegeneral direction.
The Baltic or variable cod (Gadus callarias), by some believedto be the young of the common codfish.
A burning or searing, as of morbid flesh, with a hot iron, orby application of a caustic that will burn, corrode, or destroyanimal tissue.
To ordain or appoint beforehand; to preordain; to predestinate;to predetermine. Hooker.
The man who occupies a central position in a file of soldiers.
To lay or put to sleep; to stupefy. [Obs.] Cudworth.
An unorganized ferment or enzyme present in pancreatic juice.It decomposes neutral fats into glycerin and fatty acids.
One who decorates, adorns, or embellishes; specifically, anartisan whose business is the decoration of houses, esp. theirinterior decoration.
The process of forming hummocks in the collision of Arctic ice.Kane.
A combination of a stop, or explosive, with an immediatelyfollowing fricative or spirant of corresponding organic position, aspf in german Pfeffer, pepper, z (= ts) in German Zeit, time.
An under dean; the deputy or substitute of a dean. Ayliffe.
A notice or notion which precedes something else in time;previous notion or thought; foreknowledge. Bacon.
Extreme hatred or detestation; the feeling of utter dislike.
One who pushes a principle or measure to extremes; anextremist; a radical; an ultra.
a flat heap of moist, crushed silver ore, prepared for thepatio process.
To take from the tomb; to exhume; to disinter. Fuller.
A set or squad of ten men under a decurion. Sir W. Raleigh.
A small New Zealand owl (Sceloglaux albifacies). It has shortwings and long legs, and lives chiefly on the ground.
Act of enwrapping; a wrapping or an envelope. Shuckford.
Like a giant; mighty; gigantic. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
An ornament in the form of a rose or roundel, -much used indecoration.
Without error, mistake, or deviation; unerringly. Glanvill.
The wedging, as of a horse or car, against the top of anunderground passage. Raymond.
Opened; in blossom or having blossomed, as a flower. Shak.
The slope or angle to which the cutting edge of a tool, as aplane, is ground. Grier.
Of or pertaining to ambrein; -- said of a certain acid producedby digesting ambrein in nitric acid.
A machine for cropping, as for shearing off bolts or rod iron,or for facing cloth.
Round and without a cella; consisting of a single ring ofcolumns supporting a roof; -- said esp. of a temple.
A variety of sugar isomeric with sucrose, extracted from cottonseeds and from the so-called Australian manna (a secretion of certainspecies of Eucalyptus).
A kind of amulet or magical charm. [Obs.] J. Gregory.
Of or pertaining to glosses or to a glossary; containing aglossary.
Of or pertaining to pleas or pleading, in courts of law. [Obs.]Clayton.
A pointed projection, like a four-sided pyramid, used forornament in lines or groups.
An extensive tribe of bivalve mollusks of which the genus Venusis the type. The shells are usually oval, or somewhat heartshaped,with a conspicuous lunule. See Venus.
An idle, worthless fellow, who is without any visible means ofsupport; a dissipated sponger. [Slang, U.S.]
To make the noise, or utter the call, of a brooding hen. Ray.
Either one of two handles on the back of a piece of ordnance.
A genus of large and voracious two-winged flies, including thebee killer and robber fly.
To cause to resemble porphyry; to make spotted in composition,like porphyry.
On, or toward, the dorsum, or back; on the dorsal side of;dorsad.
To wish mutually in regarded to each other. [Obs.] Donne.
A palace; a seraglio; also, in the East, a place for theaccommodation of travelers; a caravansary, or rest house.
To divide or distribute proportionally; to assess pro rata.[U.S.]
A genus of extinct herbivorous mammals, abundant in theTertiary formation of the Rocky Mountains. It is more or less relatedto the camel, hog, and deer.
A general or commander of land forces in the Turkish empire;especially, the commander-in-chief of minister of war.
A genus of cephalopods, including numerous species of squids,common on the coasts of America and Europe. They are much used forfish bait.
Having the quality of drying up; causing a drying up.-- n. (Med.)
The lower reef of fore and aft sails; also, the upper reef oftopsails. Ham. Nav. Encyc.
The replacement of an edge or solid angle by a plane,especially when the plane is equally inclined to the adjoining faces.
A small wheel formerly fixed to the pan of firelocks fordischarging them. Crabb.
A cannon capable of being trained at very high angles for useagainst aircraft.
An officer in London whose duty was to weigh wool. [Obs.]
One of the numerous small spinning tubes on the spinnerets ofspiders.
A glassy colorless mineral occurring in rhombohedral crystals,sometimes used as a gem. It is a silicate of glucina, and receivesits name from its deceptive similarity to quartz.

An officer or magistrate chosen by the people, to protect themfrom the oppression of the patricians, or nobles, and to defend theirliberties against any attempts that might be made upon them by thesenate and consuls.
Pine wood abounding in pitch, used for torches in the SouthernUnited States; pine knots, dry sticks, and the like, for kindling afire quickly or making a blaze.
The condition of being mendicant; beggary; begging. Burke.
The art of memory; a system of precepts and rules intended toassist the memory; artificial memory.
A marked prominence or process on any part of a bone.
A chirping or creaking, as of a cricket. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Cherry-colored; a light bright red; --- applied to textilefabrics, especially silk.
The Spanish dollar; -- called also patacoon. [Obs.]
Of, pertaining to, or designating, the Jews (the Sephardim,also called Spanish or Portuguese Jews) descended from Jewishfamilies driven from Spain by the Inquisition.
A game at cards in which the object is to make fifteen points.
Good of its kind; -- variously used as implying substantial,real, fixed, sure, etc., and specif., of buildings, made of brick andmortar. [India]
The act or process of irrigating, or the state of beingirrigated; especially, the operation of causing water to flow overlands, for nourishing plants.
Of or pertaining to cork; specifically, designating an acid, C
A hypothetical land, or continent, supposed by some to haveexisted formerly in the Indian Ocean, of which Madagascar is aremnant. Herschel.

A short glass jar fitted with an air-tight cover, andcontaining some desiccating agent, as sulphuric acid or calciumchloride, above which is suspended the material to be dried, orpreserved from moisture.
The technical name of the form by which either party, inpleading, accepts the issue tendered by his opponent; -- calledsometimes a joinder in issue.
One of a breed of fancy frilled pigeons allied to the owls andturbits, having the body white, the shoulders tricolored, and thetail bluish black with a large white spot on each feather.
Having a head; -- applied chiefly to the Cephalata, a divisionof mollusks.
To move quickly, but with great effort; to gallop. [Prov. Eng.& Scot.]
A bay of a barn; also, a slight addition to a cottage. [Prov.Eng.]
A bulbous iridaceous plant (Crocus sativus) having blue flowerswith large yellow stigmas. See Crocus.
The reply of a plaintiff to a defendant's rebutter.
Thin; lean; meager; scrawny; scrannel. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
A part of a book or literary composition printed and deliveredby itself; a number; a part.
That branch of physics which treats of heat and electricity. R.Park.
The soft tissue, or substance, which, in developing bone,ultimately undergoes ossification.
The central column of parenchyma in a growing stem or root.
To put into the gut; to swallow greedily; to gorge; togormandize. [Obs.] L'Estrange. Dryden.
An unidentified plant mentioned by Shakespeare, perhapsequivalent to burdock.
Cloth or flax dipped in warm water or medicaments and appliedto a hurt or sore.
To unyoke or disengage, as oxen from a wagon. [S. Africa]
A name given to a free-booting, unenlisted, armed man orguerrilla.
The edges or lower borders of the roof of a building, whichoverhang the walls, and cast off the water that falls on the roof.
To make malign or malignant. [R.] "A strong faith malignified."Southey.
The fit, attack, or exacerbation, of a disease that occurs atintervals, or has decided remissions or intermissions. Arbuthnot.
A colorless viscous substance having a bitter-sweet taste.
To turn into a star; to cause to appear like a star; to placeamong the stars, or in heaven. [Obs. or R.] B. Jonson.
That branch of physics which relates to the determination ofthe humidity of bodies, particularly of the atmosphere, with thetheory and use of the instruments constructed for this purpose.
The anemone; -- so called because formerly supposed to openonly when the wind was blowing. See Anemone.

A gentlewoman; -- an appellation or courteous form of addressgiven to a lady, especially an elderly or a married lady; -- muchused in the address, at the beginning of a letter, to a woman. Thecorresponding word in addressing a man is Sir.
Zinc; -- especially so called in commerce and arts.
A brown, bitter substance found in some of the cells ofhoneycomb. It is made chiefly from the pollen of flowers, which iscollected by bees as food for their young.
A stick or device for removing the hook from a fish's gullet.
The hole in the deck through which the rudderpost passes.

A sharp, shrill, disagreeable sound suddenly utered, either ofthe human voice or of any animal or instrument, such as is made bycarriage wheels when dry, by the soles of leather shoes, or by a pipeor reed.
An exact enunciation of the constituents which make up thelogical essence.
The state of being surety; the obligation of a person to answerfor the debt, default, or miscarriage of another. Bouvier.
One who holds the opinion that all events are ordered for thebest.
A digesting furnace, formerly used by alchemists. It was soconstructed as to maintain uniform and durable heat. Chambers.
To fray; to wear or pull into tatters or tag ends; to tatter; --used literally and figuratively. [Prov. Eng. & U. S.]
A musical stringed instrument, similar in form to a guitar; apandore.
Seasonable; timely; sufficiently early. [Obs.] Sir W. Raleigh.
A white waxy solid obtained from Chinese wax, and by thedistillation of cerotin.
Of or pertaining to ancient Scandinavia, or to the languagespoken by its inhabitants.
The American red squirrel (Sciurus Hudsonius); -- so calledfrom its cry.
The title of the native sovereigns of Hyderabad, in India,since 1719.
A thin membrane existing in the pollen grains of some plants,and situated between the extine and the intine, as in .
Zinc sulphide; -- called also blende, black-jack, false galena,etc. See Blende (a).

An instrument for measuring the quantity of dew on the surfaceof a body in the open air. It consists of a balance, having a plateat one end to receive the dew, and at the other a weight protectedfrom the deposit of dew.
In the manner of a kitchen; in connection with a kitchen orcooking.
A measure by the ell; formerly a sworn officer in England,whose duty was to inspect act measure woolen cloth, and fix upon it aseal.
A small flat bastion, raised in the middle of an overlongcurtain.
To gargle; to rinse or wash, as the mouth and throat. [Obs.]Bacon.
Containing larval tapeworms; -- said of pork and beef.
An elector or chooser; one of two persons appointed by a courtto return a jury or serve a writ when the sheriff and the coronersare disqualified.
An East Indian insectivorous mammal (Gymnura Rafflesii),somewhat like a rat in appearance, but allied to the hedgehog.
A rock trout (Pleurogrammus monopterygius) found on the coastof Alaska; -- called also striped fish, and Atka mackerel.
Of or pertaining to Tiro, or a system of shorthand said to havebeen introduced by him into ancient Rome.
Characterized by cunning or shrewdness; crafty. [R.]
the act or process of diminishing the quantity of fluid in thevessels by bloodletting or otherwise; also excessive evacuation, asin severe diarrhea.
A strongly alkaline base, CN3H5, formed by the oxidation ofguanin, and also obtained combined with methyl in the decompositionof creatin. Boiled with dilute sulphuric acid, it yields urea andammonia.
A series of strata, of the Middle Tertiary period, of France,abounding in shells, and used by Lyell as the type of his Miocenesubdivision.
One of a breed of small dogs with short crooked legs, and longbody; -- called also badger dog. There are two kinds, the rough-haired and the smooth-haired.
To turn, or to be turned, over; to be upset. Mortimer.
A small compartment in a desk or case for the keeping ofletters, documents, etc.; -- so called from the resemblance of a rowof them to the compartments in a dovecote. Burke.
A cordial made of the kernels of apricots, nectarines, etc.,with refined spirit.
Mutually assisting or operating; helping. J. Philips.
Not aneled; not having received extreme unction. Shak.
Any aquatic animal whose external covering consists of a shell,either testaceous, as in oysters, clams, and other mollusks, orcrustaceous, as in lobsters and crabs.
An engine of war used for throwing viretons, large stones, andother missiles; a springal.
The aggregate of risks covered by the terms of a contract ofinsurance.
A frame of adjustable boards erected on a post, and havingholes through which the head and hands of an offender were thrust soas to be exposed in front of it. Shak.
To form or tell stories of; to narrate or describe in a story.[Obs.]
Inscribed with a posy.In poised lockets bribe the fair. Gay.
Pertaining to Argolis, a district in the Peloponnesus.
The state of being gibbous or gibbose; gibbousness.
The inferior vena cava.-- Post"ca`val, a. B. G. Wilder.
A very venomous viper (Daboia Russellii), native of Ceylon andIndia; -- called also cobra monil.
An aboriginal weapon consisting of a stone or piece of antlerfastened to the end of a slender wooden handle, used by AmericanIndians from the Great Plains to the Mackenzie River.
A division of Coleoptera including those which have but threejoints in the tarsi.
An acetate containing an excess of the basic constituent.
The connective tissue framework and sheath of a nerve whichbind together the nerve bundles, each of which has its own specialsheath, or perineurium.
A soluble product (proteose) formed in the gastric andpancreatic digestion of casein and caseinogen.
A large, coarse herb (Inula Helenium), with composite yellowflowers. The root, which has a pungent taste, is used as a tonic, andwas formerly of much repute as a stomachic.
Having the nature, qualities, taste, form, consistency, orappearance of cheese.
An instrument having two handles and two grasping jaws workingon a pivot; -- used for griping things to be held fast, drawingnails, etc.
A wide mouth; a mouth stretched in derision. Dryden.
A knot in which a portion of the string is drawn through in theform of a loop or bow, so as to be readily untied.
The European green woodpecker; -- also called ecall, eaquall,yaffle. [Prov. Eng.]
The act of reducing to any state, as of mixing two bodiescombletely. [Obs.] Bacon.
A long-tailed monkey of Borneo (Semnopithecus rubicundus). Ithas a tuft of long hair on the head.
An extensive artificial group of birds including the wading,swimming, and cursorial birds.
An apparatus for testing or proving the strength of gunpowder.
The timber forming the ridge of a roof, into which the raftersare secured.
The back, or posterior, part of the head or skull; the regionof the occipital bone.
A low stool to support the feet of one when sitting.
A kind of boat or junk used in the seas of the MalayArchipelago.
A vitreous form of basalt; -- so called because decompposableby acids and readily fusible.
An idol or symbolical figure which the Templars were accused ofusing in their mysterious rites.
Without ears; hence, deaf or unwilling to hear. Pope.
A gambling game in vogue in the eighteenth century. Thackeray.
The quality or state of being vacillant, or wavering. [R.] Dr.H. More.
A name of Allium Scorodoprasum and A. Ascalonium, two kinds ofgarlic, the latter of which is also called shallot.
The relation of freedom from the interventionof a medium;immediateness. Shak.
A staith or framework from which coal is discharged from carsinto vessels.
To hide; to skulk. [Scot.]He at length escaped them by derning himself in a foxearth. H.Miller.
A collection of sashes; ornamentation by means of sashes. [R.]Distinguished by their sasheries and insignia. Carlyle.

A leguminous plant of the genus Lupinus, especially L. albus,the seeds of which have been used for food from ancient times. Thecommon species of the Eastern United States is L. perennis. There aremany species in California.
Of or pertaining to tabes; of the nature of tabes; affectedwith tabes; tabid. -- n.
The act of developing a new coat of hair, a new set offeathers, scales, etc.; -- opposed to ecdysis.
The holding or occupation of an inheritable estate whichdescends from the ancestor to two or more persons; coheirship.
A kind of pudding or sausage made of liver or pork. [Obs.]Chapman.
A name given to several species of stonecrop, used asingredients of vermifuge medicines. See Stonecrop.
Doubled and twisted thread, made of coarse silk, and used fortassels, fringes, etc. McElrath.
A genus of spreading shrubs with many stems, from one speciesof which (K. triandra), found in Peru, rhatany root, used as amedicine, is obtained.
Having many poles; -- applied especially to those ganglionicnerve cells which have several radiating processes.
A defensive work of moderate height, hastily thrown up, ofearth or other material.
A yellowish red crystalline substance related to anthracene,and obtained from opianic acid.

An extinct tribe of fossil corals, including numerous species,many of them of large size. They are characteristic of the Paleozoicformations. The radiating septs, when present, are usually inmultiples of four. See Cyathophylloid.
Causing a discharge of water or phlegm.-- n. (Med.)
One who, or that which, bisects; esp. (Geom.) a straight linewhich bisects an angle.
A name of certain curious orchids which bear three kinds offlowers formerly referred to three genera, but now ascertained to besexually different forms of the same genus (Catasetum tridentatum,etc.).
One who kicks up the dust; a streetwalker; a low manner. [Obs.]Beau. & Fl.
One who soliloquizes; esp., one who monopolizes conversation incompany. De Quincey.
A nitrogenous substance closely resembling diastase, obtainedfrom bran, and possessing the power of converting starch intodextrin, sugar, and lactic acid. Watts.
A south African proteaceous tree (Protea grandiflora); also,its tough wood, used for making wagon wheels.
A political union, confederation, or league. [R.] Burke.
A raised shelf or stand on the back of an altar, on whichdifferent objects can be placed; a predella or gradino.
The wood of several West Indian trees, mostly of the genusCitharexylum.
A native or inhabitant of the Lowlands, especially of theLowlands of Scotland, as distinguished from Highlander.
The quality or state of being pilose; hairiness. Bacon.
In an apt or suitable manner; fitly; properly; pertinently;appropriately; readily.
That which serves to set or fix colors or drawings, as amordant.
One who makes known or proclaims; that which exhibits. Udall.
The son or husband of Gaia (Earth), and father of Chronos(Time) and the Titans.
A woman whose occupation is to sell goods or merchandise.
The state or quality of being jocund; gayety; sportiveness.
A cock or faucet having a bent down nozzle. Knight.
That which comes forth or results; effect; yield; issue;product; sum accruing from a sale, etc.
A game resembling ninepins, but played with ten pins. SeeNinepins. [U. S.]
By day, or every day; in the daytime. [Obs.] Fielding.
The state of being puzzled; perplexity. Miss Mitford.
One who makes a tour, or performs a journey in a circuit.
The chief police officer of a large city. [East Indies]
A colorless, crystalline hydrocarbon, C20H14, obtained fromnaphthylene, and consisting of a doubled naphthylene radical.
Any coarse seaweed growing on sea-washed rocks, especiallyFucus.
An instrument formerly used at sea for taking the altitudes ofheavenly bodies, now superseded by the sextant; -- called also cross-staff. Brande & C.
An instrument used, especially in trigonometrical surveying,for the accurate measurement of horizontal angles, and also usuallyof vertical angles. It is variously constructed.
An inclosure where the tanning of leather is carried on; atannery.
The quality or state of being soft; -- opposed to Ant:hardness, and used in the various specific senses of the adjective.
The external or outermost layer of a fructified or ripenedovary. See Illust. under Endocarp.
That branch of agriculture dealing with the methods ofconversion of agricultural products into manufactured articles;agricultural technology.
A small cannon supported by a swiveled rest on the back of acamel, whence it is fired, -- used in the East.
A body of cavarly comparising two companies or troops, andaverging from one hundred and twenty to two hundred men.
A small inclosed area; esp. one of the small spaces on thewings of insects, circumscribed by the veins.
The act or process of paging a book; also, the characters usedin numbering the pages; page number. Lowndes.
The motion of a small stream running among obstructions; also,the murmur it makes in so doing.
A part of a French newspaper (usually the bottom of the page),devoted to light literature, criticism, etc.; also, the article ortale itself, thus printed.
Silver, pounded into ingots of the shape of a shoe, and used ascurrency. The most common weight is about one pound troy. [China]McElrath.
Reflexive; -- applied to pronouns and verbs, but sometimeslimited to such pronouns as express mutual action.
One who makes or uses needles; also, a dealer in needles. PiersPlowman.

The science of life; that branch of knowledge which treats ofliving matter as distinct from matter which is not living; the studyof living tissue. It has to do with the origin, structure,development, function, and distribution of animals and plants.
Of or pertaining to a pipe (flute) or piper. [R.] Ash.
Contamination by illegality, as in cases of contraband goods;implication.
The American larch (Larix Americana), a coniferous tree withslender deciduous leaves; also, its heavy, close-grained timber.Called also tamarack.
Pertaining to, or corresponding with, the palm of the hand.
A lunch, or slight repast between breakfast and dinner; --originally, a Provincial English word, but introduced into India, andbrought back to England in a special sense.
A genus of plectognath fishes having the body covered withsolid, immovable, bony plates. It includes the trunkfishes.
Related to or resembling the marsupials; furnished with a pouchfor the young, as the marsupials, and also some fishes and Crustacea.
To give a feud, or right in land, to; to invest with a fief orfee; to invest (any one) with a freehold estate by the process offeoffment. Mozley & W.
A company or troop, especially the company pf performers in aplay or an opera.
One of a breed of small dogs having long and thick hair andlarge drooping ears. The legs are usually strongly feathered, and thetail bushy. See Illust. under Clumber, and Cocker.
A postponement of the decision of a cause, for furtherconsideration or re-argument.
In a pale manner; dimly; wanly; not freshly or ruddily.Thackeray.
To smirch or soil; to discolor; to obscure. Hence: To dishonor;to sully. Shak.
The act of equalizing; act or result of making adequate; anequivalent. [Obs.] Bp. Barlow.
A wooden lining or boarding of the walls of apartments, usuallymade in panels.
Having the leaves or petals arranged in the form of a cross;cruciform.
Pertaining to, or derived from, hydantoin. See Glycoluric.
A poisonous narcotic alkaloid extracted from the leaves ofIndian tobacco (Lobelia inflata) as a yellow oil, having atobaccolike taste and odor.
Resembling the smell or taste of roast meat, or of corruptanimal matter. [R.]
A trailing plant (Lysimachia Nummularia), with rounded oppositeleaves and solitary yellow flowers in their axils.
A slave warehouse, or an inclosure where slaves are quarteredtemporarily. Du Chaillu.
The pupa state of certain insects, esp. of butterflies, fromwhich the perfect insect emerges. See Pupa, and Aurelia (a).
Manner of linking or of being linked; -- said of the union ofatoms or radicals in the molecule.
Adhering closely; embracing; -- applied to certain creepinganimals, as caterpillars.
That may be kneaded; capable of being worked into a mass.
Erroneous thought; mistaken opinion; error. [Obs.] Spenser.
Pertaining to Mons Aventinus, one of the seven hills on whichRome stood. Bryant.
The small pyramid which crowns or completes an obelisk.
A deadly alkaloid extracted from the curare poison and from theStrychnos toxifera. It is obtained in crystalline colorless salts.
Distorted vision, in which straight lines appear bent.
The state or quality of being feudal; feudal form orconstitution. Burke.
To tie with a ligature; to bind around; to bandage.
In Cuba, Mexico, etc., a booth, stall, or shop wheremerchandise is sold.
Sought out with care; choice. Hence: of rare quality, elegance,or attractiveness; peculiar and refined in kind.
A place where bricks are made, especially an inclosed place.
Worthy of rebuke or reprehension; reprehensible. Shak.
To hasten away or along; to move rapidly; to hurry; as, therabbit scurried away.
Standing, but with the wings spread, as if about to fly; --said of a bird borne as a charge on an escutcheon.
A genus of small, hardy trees, including the hawthorn, muchused for ornamental purposes.
A genus of small insectivores including the common Europeanmole.
The order of Crustacea which includes the shrimps, lobsters,crabs, etc.
Any one of numerous species of small insectivorous singingbirds belonging to Parus and allied genera; -- called also tit, andtomtit.
The lining of the mantle borne about the shield or escutcheon.
Barium sulphate, generally called heavy spar or barite. SeeBarite.
A crystalline substance (C5H5N5O) contained in guano. It isalso a constituent of the liver, pancreas, and other glands inmammals.
A hypothetical radical constituting the characteristic residueof tartronic acid and certain of its derivatives.
Of or pertaining to lice; having the lousy distemper(phthiriasis); lousy. Southey.
A prolate spheroid; a figure described by the revolution of anellipse about its greater axis. Cf. Oblatum, and see Ellipsoid ofrevolution, under Ellipsoid.
An earth of a white color resembling lime in appearance, andbaryta in many of its properties. It is an oxide of the metalstrontium.
One who summons; one who cites by authority; specifically, apetty officer formerly employed to summon persons to appear in court;an apparitor.
An oppressive, relaxing wind from the Libyan deserts, chieflyexperienced in Italy, Malta, and Sicily.
The method of laying on different tints so that they may mingletogether while wet, and shade into each other insensibly. Weale.
The produce of animals yielding milk; milk and that which ismade from it.

An apparatus consisting of a slowly revolving disk, usuallyregulated by  clockwork, by means of wich the action of externalagents, as light and gravity, on growing plants may be regulated oreliminated.
A natural or artificial purgation of any passage, as of themouth, bowels, etc.
A kind of helmet worn in the 14th, 15th, and 16th centuries.
Having the surface covered with a fine yellow dust, likepollen.
The salt of wisdom of the alchemists, a double salt composed ofthe chlorides of ammonium and mercury. It was formerly used as astimulant. Brande & C.
To turn form the original or plain meaning; to pervert; towrest. Hammond.
A shovel with a turned-up edge, for frit, sand, etc. [Writtenalso strocal, strocle, strokal.]
The black currant; also, the wild plum. [Prov. Eng.]
To wander as a pilgrim; to go on a pilgrimage. [Obs.] B.Jonson.
A discharge pipe with a valve and spout at which water may bedrawn from the mains of waterworks; a water plug.
To feel or express undue care and anxiety; to manifestdisquietude or pain; to be fretful; to chafe; as, the child worries;the horse worries.
A pack sack to be swung on either side of a packsaddle.[Western U. S.]
Relating to exogamy; marrying outside of the limits of one'sown tribe; -- opposed to endogenous.
Unsuitableness; unaptness; unfitness; inability. [Obs.] Barrow.
A colorless oily hydrocarbon, C6H5.C3H7, obtained by thedistillation of cuminic acid; -- called also cumol.
A game at cards, called "High, Low, Jack, and the Game."
Timorous; feeble-minded. [Obs.] "A fainting, silly creature."Arbuthnot.
