Of or pertaining to a division of the Silurian formation,corresponding in general to the Lower Silurian of most authors,exclusive of the Cambrian.-- n.
A stringed instrument of music resembling the lute or theviolin, but larger, and having six strings, three of silk coveredwith silver wire, and three of catgut, -- played upon with thefingers.
The science which treats of the nose, and its diseases.
A pisonous resin extracted from hemp (Cannabis sativa, varietyIndica). The narcotic effects of hasheesh are due to this resin.
An extinct Quaternary marsupial from Australia, about as largeas the hippopotamus; -- so named because of its two large frontteeth. See Illustration in Appendix.
A short, straight, horizontal mark [-], placed over vowels todenote that they are to be pronounced with a long sound; as, a, indame; e, in seam, etc.
The birds, or all the kinds of birds, inhabiting a region.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, lichens; abounding inlichens; covered with lichens. G. Eliot.
A Brazilian name for the lofty myrtaceous tree (Bertholetiaexcelsa) which produces the large seeds known as Brazil nuts.
A word formerly used (as finis is now) at the conclusion of abook to indicate the end.
Act of making hollow; also, a hollow; an exvation; adepression.
The European greater weever fish (Trachinus draco), which iscapable of inflicting severe wounds with the spinous rays of itsdorsal fin. See Weever.
Capable of uniting with five molecules of a monacid base;having five acid hydrogen atoms capable of substitution by a basicradical; -- said of certain acids.
A small lemuroid mammal (Arctocebus Calabarensis) of Africa. Ithas only a rudimentary tail.

A contract or obligation under seal; a contract by deed; awriting, under seal, given as security for a debt particularlyspecified. Chitty. Bouvier. Wharton (Law Dict.).Let specialties be therefore drawn between us. Shak.
A name given in contempt to strict Calvinists in Switzerland,France, and some parts of Germany, in the early part of the 19thcentury.
The doctrines of the Academic philosophy. [Obs.] Baxter.
A horse, not of pure breed, but having only one eighth or onesixteenth impure blood in his veins. Darwin.
Any moth of the genus Nonagria and allied genera, as thespindleworm and stalk borer.
A chronic abscess, or fistula of the coronet, in a horse'sfoot, resulting from inflammation of the tissues investing the coffinbone.
To make a shop, sharp, cheerful, as of small birds or crickets.
A man's own act and deed; particularly:(a) (Civil Law) Anything stated and made certain.(b) (Testamentary Law) The due execution of a will, includingeverything necessary to its validity.
The shoulder of a bastion, or the place where its face andflank meet and form the angle, called the angle of the shoulder.
Resemblance between different plants or animals, in externalshape, in general habit, or in organs, which is not due to descentfrom a common ancestor, but to similar surrounding circumstances.
A tithing consisting of ten neighboring families. Burrill.
A knot of ribbons worn by a guest at a wedding; a weddingfavor. [Obs.]
A condition of impoverishment of the blood; a morbid state inwhich the red corpuscles, or other important elements of the blood,are deficient.

Any plant of the genera Asclepias and Acerates, abounding in amilky juice, and having its seed attached to a long silky down;silkweed. The name is also applied to several other plants with amilky juice, as to several kinds of spurge.
The quality of being audible; power of being heard; audiblecapacity.
That part of medicine which treats of urine. Dunglison.
Early ripe; ripe before others, or before the usual season.
A small nodule or cystic tumor, common on the nose, etc., whichon pressure allows the escape of a yellow wormlike mass of retainedoily secretion, with a black head (dirt).
The right of pasturing on a common; the right of using anythingin common with others.The claim of comonage . . . in most of the forests. Burke.
Charged with leaves, fruits, flowers, etc.; -- said of aborder.
A roof having a rounded form, hemispherical or nearly so; also,a celing having the same form. When on a large scale it is usuallycalled dome.
A complex, nitrogenous phosphorized substance widelydistributed through the animal body, and especially conspicuous inthe brain and nerve tissue, in yolk of eggs, and in the white bloodcorpuscles.
A genus of plants, the type of which is mignonette.
Hematite or specular iron ore; -- prob. so called in allusionto its feeble magnetism, as compared with magnetite.
A variety of quartz, of a color between grass green and leekgreen, which is found associated with common chalcedony. It was muchesteemed by the ancients for making engraved ornaments.
An order of elasmobranchs including the sharks and rays; thePlagiostomi. Called also Selacha, Selache, and Selachoidei.
To make a cripple of; to cripple; to lame. [R.] Dr. H. More.
The person who institutes and carries on a criminal suitagainst another in the name of the government. Blackstone.
The berries of a species of cypress in the East Indies.
The quality of being brief; brevity; conciseness in discourseor writing.
The quality which constitutes an alkali; alkaline property.Thomson.
A plant (Campanula Trachelium) formerly considered a remedy forsore throats because of its throat-shaped corolla.
Having transparent spots, as the wings of certain butterflies.
Having the teeth differentiated into incisors, canines, andmolars, as in man; -- opposed to homodont.
The convexity of a ship behind, under the stern. Mar. Dict.
To rebaptize; to rechristen; also, to rename. [R.] Whitlock.
A disease of horses, on which the mouth is so furred that theafflicted animal can not eat.
Having the dorsal fin spines symmetrical, and in the same line;-- said of certain fishes.
A division of ciliated Infusoria having a circle of ciliaaround the oral disk and sometimes another around the body. Itincludes the vorticellas. See Vorticella.
A tribe of Indians formerly inhabiting what is now a part ofthe State of New York. They were the central or head tribe of theFive Nations.
One who, or that which, fattens; that which gives fatness orfertility.
A kind of cutting weapon with a thick back and thin razorlikeedge, used by the Moros of the Philippine Islands.
One who assaults, or violently attacks; an assailant. E. Hall.
To say in too many words; to express verbosely. Hales.
The deviation of a shot or ball from its true course.
A yellow oil liquid, extracted from the shell of the cashewnut.
An amphibian of the salamander tribe found in the elevatedlakes of Mexico; the siredon.
A child's gun; a tube and rammer for shooting pellets, with apopping noise, by compression of air.
Worn out or subdued by toil; worn out so as to be trite.
A rural custom in England, of visiting one's parents on MidlentSunday, -- supposed to have been originally visiting the motherchurch to make offerings at the high altar.

A bird of the genus Anastomus, allied to the stork; -- socalled because the two parts of the bill touch only at the base andtip. One species inhabits India, another Africa. Called also open-beak. See Illust. (m), under Beak.
The act of running about the rigging of a vessel in sport;hence, frolicking; scuffing; sporting; carousing. [Colloq.]
One of a sect of visionaries, who, professing to imitate thestate of Adam, discarded the use of dress in their assemblies.
Rendered electro-polar by induction, or brought into theopposite electrical state by the influence of inductive bodies.
A bar or set of bars with skewers for holding paying-offbobbins, as in the roving machine, throstle, and mule.
An instrument for ascertaining the susceptibility of a personto hypnotic influences.
Matter excreted and ejected; that which is excreted or cast outof the animal body by any of the natural emunctories; especially,alvine, discharges; dung; ordure.
Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acid,isomeric with uric acid.
One who assists in saving a ship or goods at sea, without beingunder special obligation to do so. Wheaton.
One who steals purses, or money from purses. Latimer. Shak.
The gape of the mouth, as of birds; -- often resricted to thecorners of the mouth.
An order of fishes including the gray mullets (Mugil), thebarracudas, the silversides, and other related fishes. So called fromtheir relation both to perches and to pikes.
Having no savor; destitute of smell or of taste; insipid.
To draw the screws from; to loose from screws; to loosen orwithdraw (anything, as a screw) by turning it.
A rubbing or chafing of the skin; especially, an abrasion orexcoriation of the skin between folds, as in fat or neglectedchildren.
Any one of the several complex ethers of ethyl and glycerin.
The lowest deck of a vessel, esp. of a ship of war, consistingof a platform laid over the beams in the hold, on which the cablesare coiled.
A kind of spider. See Hunting spider, under Hunting.
A West African arboreal monkey (Cercopithecus cynosurus).
A white crystalline hydrocarbon, polymeric with benzene. It isextracted from pine tar, and is also found in certain fossil resins.
To make a false profession; to make pretensions to skill whichis not possessed.
A faculty in animals of developing and preserving the heatnesessary to life, that is, the animal heat.
The space between two triglyphs of the Doric frieze, which,among the ancients, was often adorned with carved work. See Illust.of Entablature.
Having branches in pairs, decussated, all nearly horizontal,and each pair at right angles with the next, as in the maple andlilac.

An affection of one or both eyes, in which the optic axes cannot be directed to the same object, -- a defect due either to unduecontraction or to undue relaxation of one or more of the muscleswhich move the eyeball; squinting; cross-eye.
Prevented from growing, by having the bark too firm or close.
The highest order of mammals. It includes man, together withthe apes and monkeys. Cf. Pitheci.
One who squabbles; a contentious person; a brawler.
Any one of several species of large sparoid food fishes of thegenus Lutjanus, abundant on the southern coasts of the United Statesand on both coasts of tropical America.
A short poem or stanza of eight lines, in which the first lineis repeated as the fourth and again as the seventh line, the secondbeing, repeated as the eighth. Brande & C.
To render divine; to deify. [Obs.] "Blessed and divinifiedsoul." Parth. Sacra (1633).
An addition to a coat of arms to distinguish the bearings oftwo persons, which would otherwise be the same. See Augmentation, andMarks of cadency, under Cadency.

A piece of apparatus used for reversing the direction of anelectrical current; an attachment to certain electrical machines, bymeans of which alternating currents are made to be continuous or tohave the same direction.
A pendulous branching lichen (Usnea barbata); -- so called fromits resemblance to hair.
A mucilaginous plant of the genus Borago (B. officinalis),which is used, esp. in France, as a demulcent and diaphoretic.
To treat or prepare with a chloride, as a plate with chlorideof silver, for the purposes of photography. R. Hunt.

A train or series of kites on one string and flying tandem,used for attaining great heights and for sending up instruments formeteorological observations or a man for military reconnoissance;also, a kite of such a train.
One of a mystical sect of the Greek Church in the fourteenthcentury; a quietist. Brande & C.
Any one of numerous species of hemipterous insects belonging toGerris, Pyrrhocoris, Prostemma, and allied genera. They have longlegs, and run rapidly over the surface of the water, as if skating.
One who lies with another in the same bed; a person who sharesone's couch.
A stone marked with dendrites and black lines, and so disposedas to represent rivers, marshes, etc.
To convert into a stony substance; to petrity. [R.] Bacon.
Violation of allegiance or of faith and confidence; treasonableor perfidious conduct; perfidy; treason.
Worthy of regard or notice; to be regarded; observable. [R.]Sir T. Browne.
Consisting of, or resembling, steam; full of steam; vaporous;misty. Cowper.
A person in a state of slavery; one whose person and libertyare subjected to the authority of a master.
A British trout usually regarded as a variety (var. Cambricus)of the salmon trout.
An extinct genus of horses from the Pliocene deposits. Eachfoot had a single toe (or hoof), as in the common horse.
The wing coverts of a bird. See Covert, and Illust. of Bird.
A nitrogenous base, C4H7N, obtained as a colorless liquid bythe reduction of pyrrol.
A slow rising of the floor of a gallery, occasioned by thepressure of incumbent strata upon the pillars or sides; a gradualmovement of mining ground.
A name for several plants with golden yellow blossoms,especially the Calendula officinalis (see Calendula), and thecultivated species of Tagetes.
According to chemical principles; by chemical process oroperation.
A mythical person who makes children sleepy, so that they rubtheir eyes as if there were sand in them.
An oversounding, or a misuse, of the letter r; specifically(Phylol.), the tendency, exhibited in the Indo-European languages, tochange s to r, as wese to were.
To die, or cause to die; to perish. See Starve. [Obs.] Chaucer.Spenser.
The separation of a leaf or floral organ into two more parts.
An instrument for measuring and recording the direction andforce of the wind. Knight.
The act of oppugning; opposition; resistance. Shak.
To perform by algebra; to reduce to algebraic form.
Impatience under affliction; morbid restlessness;dissatisfaction; the fidgets.
The difference between the cost and the selling price of anarticle.
The lower house of the Danish Rigsdag, or Parliament. SeeLegislature, below.
The wife of a peer; a woman ennobled in her own right, or byright of marriage.
One of several species of pheasants of the genus Euplocamus,having the lower back a bright, fiery red. They inhabit Southern Asiaand the East Indies.

A parasitic nematoid worm, espec. the roundworm, Ascarislumbricoides, often occurring in the human intestine and alliedspecies found in domestic animals; also commonly applied to thepinworm (Oxyuris), often troublesome to children and aged persons.
A ferment resembling diastase, found in bitter almonds. Cf.Amygdalin, and Emulsin.
To rake over, or sweep across, from end to end, as waves thatbreak over a vessel anchored with head to the sea.
Thin canvas glued on the inside of panels to prevent shrinking,checking, etc.
An officer, or ward, having the care of the streets. [Obs.]Cowell.
A mill for grinding grain; especially, a mill for grindinggrists, or portions of grain brought by different customers; a custommill.
The quality or state of being wry, or distorted. W. Montagu.

One who, or that which, crimps; as: (a) A curved board or frameover which the upper of a boot or shoe is stretched to the requiredshape. (b) A device for giving hair a wavy apperance. (c) A machinefor crimping or ruffling textile fabrics.
Magistrates in Sparta, who with the ephori and kings,constituted the supreme civil authority.
The act of shaking; a shake; esp. (Med.), a shaking of the bodyto ascertain if there be a liquid in the thorax.
Having the lower incisor teeth projecting beyond the upperones, as in the bulldog.
The act of raising one extremity of a spar higher than theother.
A brewhouse; the building and apparatus where brewing iscarried on.
A freckle. [Obs.]A few fraknes in his face. Chaucer.

A sect of dissenters from the ecclesiastical system of theRoman Catholic Church, who in the 13th century were driven bypersecution to the valleys of Piedmont, where the sect survives. Theyprofess substantially Protestant principles.
To apply thinly a transparent or semitransparent color to(another color), to modify the effect.
A lease granted by a tenant or lessee; especially, a leasegranted by one who is himself a lessee for years, for any fewer orless number of years than he himself holds; a sublease. Burrill.
A genus of small spiral fresh-water gastropods having anoperculum.
A variety of apatite from Wheal Franco in Devonshire.
A white or gray crystalline mineral consisting of the acidphosphate of calcium.
Made less harsh or burdensome; alleviated. [Obs.] Sir. T.Elyot.
Having the leaves so placed that the upper part of each onecovers the base of the leaf next above it, as in hepatic mosses ofthe genus Frullania. See Succubous.
A form of clouds in which they are arranged in a horizontalband or layer. See Cloud.
A yellow dyestuff obtained from the foliage of the dyer's broom(Reseda luteola).
One who, or which, parts or separates. Sir P. Sidney.
The act of stuffing or filling; an overloading and obstructionof any organ or vessel of the body; constipation.
A bone in the base of the lower jaw of many birds, reptiles,and fishes.

Formerly an allowance of two pounds in every three hundredweight after the tare and tret are subtracted; now used only in ageneral sense, of small deductions from the original weight. [Writtenalso clough.] McCulloch.
Protected or covered by bony or horny plates, or large scales.
One living in a dale; -- a term applied particularly to theinhabitants of the valleys in the north of England, Norway, etc.Macaulay.
A scale cast off from the skin; a thin dry shred consisting ofepithelium.
To fertilize by the impregnation of one species or variety byanother; to impregnate by a different species or variety.
One of the plates on the under side of the tail of a serpent.
Originally, cambric or lawn of fine linen; now applied also tocloth of similar texture made of cotton.
Wandering; -- applied especially to the pneumogastric nerve.-- n.
An oily hydrocarbon, C16H32, of the ethylene series, obtainedfrom spermaceti.

An extensive class of Protozoa, including those which havepseudopodia, by means of which they move about and take their food.The principal groups are Lobosa (or Amoebea), Helizoa, Radiolaria,and Foraminifera (or Reticularia). See Protozoa.
A movement in dancing, as across or to the right or left.
The Marxian socialism and programme of reform throughrevolution as advocated by the French political leader Jules BasileGuesde (pron. ged) (1845- ). -- Guesd"ist (#), n. & a.
Persons supported by alms; almsmen. [Archaic] Holinshed.
The lowest and supporting part or member of a wall, includingthe base course (see Base course (a), under Base, n.) and footingcourses; in a frame house, the whole substructure of masonry.
Having one oblique inclination; -- applied to strata that dipin only one direction from the axis of elevation.
A playful, humorous movement, commonly in 3-4 measure, whichoften takes the place of the old minuet and trio in a sonata or asymphony.
To give meaning to; to explain the meaning of; to interpret.[Obs.] Wyclif.
An old name of sandalwood, now applied only to the redsandalwood. See under Sandalwood.
That part of theological science directly preliminary to actualexegesis, or interpretation of the Scriptures.
To admit to the privileges of a denizen; to naturalize. [Obs.]B. Jonson.
A strong inclined frame, usually of wrought-iron bars, in frontof a locomotive engine, for catching or throwing off obstructions ona railway, as cattle; the pilot. [U.S.]
One who is given to intemperance or bacchanalian excesses; aman habitually lewd; a libertine.
The European hake; -- called also herring hake and sea pike.
Protected by a coat of mail; clad in armor. Sir W. Scott.
Of or pertaining to the inhabitants of a town; like the town.[R.] Turbervile.
In the broadest sense, a process or series of processes bywhich the living organism as a whole (or its component parts ororgans) is maintained in its normal condition of life and growth.
A stake or pole projecting from, or set up before, an alehouse,as a sign; an alepole. At the end was commonly suspended a garland, abunch of leaves, or a "bush." [Obs.] Chaucer.
To brace, fasten, or bind underneath or below. Cowper.
The European perch when two years old. [Prov. Eng.]
Any one of three species of Australian burrowing marsupials ofthe genus Phascolomys, especially the common species (P. ursinus).They are nocturnal in their habits, and feed mostly on roots.
A disk which surrounds the mouth and bears the tentacles of theBryozoa. See Phylactolemata.
An instrument for measuring the rise of water in the Nileduring its periodical flood.
Formerly a large vessel, now a small vessel of glass or othermaterial, used for holding salt on the table.
Descent from parents of recognized breed; excellence or purityof breed.
A day on which work is performed, as distinguished from Sunday,festivals, etc., a working day.
A Japanese game, played on a checkerboard, in which the objectof the game is to be the first in placing five pieces, or men, in arow in any direction.
A beverage made of wine, ale (or milk), sugar, etc. [Obs.]Blount.
An order of gastropods, including the true limpets, and havingthe teeth on the odontophore or lingual ribbon.
Of or pertaining to yesterday; relating to the day last past.
A kind of carriage like a gig, orig. of wicker-work.
A glass vessel or bottle with a large body and small neck,inclosed in wickerwork.
Of or pertaining to stamens or stamina; consisting in stamens.
The state or quality of being impervious to light; opacity. Dr.H. More.
A lode; a limited mass of rock bearing valuable mineral.
One of the orthodox Mohammedans who receive the Sunna as ofequal importance with the Koran.
One who composes, delivers, or utters, a threnode, or threnody.
A telescope arranged and used to determine errors ofcollimation, both vertical and horizontal. Nichol.
An extinct genus of artiodactylous mammals found in theEuropean Tertiary formations. It had slender legs, didactylous feet,and small canine teeth.
Human exertion of any kind employed for the creation of value,and regarded by some as a species of capital or wealth; labor.
A thing which is to be changed; something which must bealtered; -- used chiefly in the plural.
One of the pieces of sod used to line or cover parapets and thefaces of earthworks.
The worship of the dead; manes worship. H. Spenser.

To render unsatisfied or discontented; to excite uneasiness inby frustrating wishes or expectations; to displease by the want ofsomething requisite; as, to be dissatisfied with one's fortune.The dissatisfied factions of the autocracy. Bancroft.

A large galley, having some features of the galleon, asbroadside guns; esp., such a vessel used by the southern nations ofEurope in the 16th and 17th centuries. See Galleon, and Galley.[Written variously galeas, gallias, etc.]
One of the huge multinucleated cells found in the marrow ofbone and occasionally in other parts; a giant cell. See Osteoclast.
A humming bird (Docimastes ensiferus) having a very long,slender bill, exceeding the length of the body of the bird.
A rod which unites the drawgear at opposite ends of the car,and bears the pull required to draw the train.
Capable of being planted; fit to be planted. B. Edwards.
A genus of marine bivalve mollusks having thin, delicate, andoften handsomely colored shells.
The whole arrangement, or one range, of the keys of an organ,typewriter, etc.
The right of demanding a duty or toll for a ship entering aport; also, the duty or toll. Bouvier. Wharton.
The little finger; the fifth digit, or that corresponding toit, in either the manus or pes.
Sprouting or coming up freely and regularly. [Prev. Eng.]Grose.
A narrow shelf or path between the bottom of a parapet and theditch.
One who observes or considers; an observer. [R.] Goldsmith.
One who spends; esp., one who spends lavishly; a prodigal; aspendthrift.
To form or utter a prediction; -- sometimes used with of.Dryden.
An Australian plant (Atriplex nummularia) of the Goosefootfamily.
A platform in a shaft, especially one of those between theseries of ladders in a shaft.

A strong metallic vessel, usually of wrought iron platesriveted together, or a composite structure variously formed, in whichsteam is generated for driving engines, or for heating, cooking, orother purposes.
To take out the folds or twists of, as something previouslyplatted; to unfold; to unwreathe.
The hypothetical radical VO, regarded as a characterizedresidue of certain vanadium compounds.
A meteorite, or similar rude stone artificially shaped, heldsacred or worshiped as of divine origin.
A broad, thin plank, fixed along the gunwale of boat to keepthe sea from breaking inboard; also, a plank on the sill of a lowerdeck port, for the same purpose; -- called also wasteboard. Mar. Di
A genus of diminutive Shrubs, mostly evergreen, and withfragrant blossoms.
Of or performance to roots, or the root of a plant.
Turned round, as a wheel; also, wheel-shaped; rotate.
Act of making a knot, or state of being knotted. [R.]
Full of knots; hard; tough; hence, capable of enduring orresisting much.
Soft, like fruit that is too ripe; quashy; swash. [Prov. Eng.]
An image of external objects fixed on the retina by thephotochemical action of light on the visual purple. See Optography.
One of several species of pygmy geese, of the genus Nettepus.They are about the size of a teal, and inhabit Africa, India, andAustralia.
A large, Old World, ground cuckoo of the genus Centropus, ofseveral species.
That which is used for steadying anything; ballast.
The palma Christi. (Jonah iv. 6, margin, and Douay version,note.)
The anterior, and in man the larger, division of the brain; theseat of the reasoning faculties and the will. See Brain.
As much as a yard will contain; enough to fill a yard.
A species of remora (Echeneis naucrates). See Remora.
A small North American fresh-water cyprinoid fish (NotropisWhipplei).
A young tree, especially one reserved when others are cut.[Obs.] Fuller.
The inflammable wood of certain trees (Amyris balsamifera, A.Floridana, etc.); also, the trees themselves.
A gentle slope, or a smooth, gently sloping bank; especially(Fort.), that slope of earth which inclines from the covered waytoward the exterior ground or country (see Illust. of Ravelin).

A small statue; -- usually applied to a figure much less thanlife size, especially when of marble or bronze, or of plaster or clayas a preparation for the marble or bronze, as distinguished from afigure in terra cotta or the like. Cf. Figurine.
To wish; to desire. [Obs.] "He willneth no destruction."Chaucer.
A man who has lost his wife by death, and has not marriedagain. Shak.
An instrument for drawing a circular arc without the use of acentral point; a cyclograph.
A member of one of the religious orders called after St.Augustine; an Austin friar.
One who lives in the interior of a country, or at a distancefrom the sea. Sir T. Browne.
The quotient of a unit divided by eighty; one of eighty equalparts.

The principal garment of a Hindoo woman. It consists of a longpiece of cloth, which is wrapped round the middle of the body, aportion being arranged to hang down in front, and the remainderpassed across the bosom over the left shoulder.
The government or jurisdiction of a sachem. Dr. T. Dwight.
A large and thick pancake, with slices of bacon in it. [Obs.]Johnson.

An instrument for including the number of steps in walking, andso ascertaining the distance passed over. It is usually in the formof a watch; an oscillating weight by the motion of the body causesthe index to advance a certain distance at each step.
A species of inflorescence; a dense panicle, as in the lilacand horse-chestnut.
A dor, or a breed of dogs, chiefly employed to retrieve, or tofind and recover game birds that have been killed or wounded.
Ravenous; voracious.Cormorant, devouring time. Shak.
An ornament consisting of a ring passed through the lobe of theear, with or without a pendant.
To run in dept by getting goods made up in a way unsuitable forthe use of others, and then threatening not to take them except oncredit. [R.] Goldsmith.
A name given to many different kinds of apples, mostly ofFrench origin.
To clear from mist, clouds, or obscurity. [R.] Bailey.
Liable to be mistaken; capable of being misconceived. Sir T.Browne.
A compound having a relatively large percentage of oxygen; aperoxide. [Obs.]
A branch of algebra which relates to the direct search forunknown quantities. [R.]
The difference between the diameter of the bore of a gun andthat of the shot fired from it.
A hypothetical radical characteristic of succinic acid andcertain of its derivatives.
A dictionary of a peculiar dialect, or of the words and phrasespeculiar to one part of a country; a glossary.
Excess of urea or other nitrogenous substances in the urine.
The state of being dirty; filthiness; foulness; nastiness;baseness; sordidness.
An epidemic affection characterized by acute nasal catarrh, orby inflammation of the throat or the bronchi, and usually accompaniedby fever.
That portion of a group of moldings which projects beyond thegeneral surface of a panel; a bolection.
One who admits the existence of material beings only; amaterialist. Glanvill.
A genus of climbing leguminous plants bearing long, pendulousclusters of pale bluish flowers.
A boat designed to be propelled by oars instead of sails.
To constrain; to put under obligation. [R.] Bp. Gardiner.
The vent of a cannot or other firearm, by which fire iscommunicateed to the powder of the charge.
A member of a religious order, named from St. Barnabas.
In the manner or condition of a mulier; in wedlock;legitimately. [Obs.]
A piece of greased cloth or leather used as wrapping for arifle ball, to make it fit the bore.
Having a peduncle; supported on a peduncle; pedunculate.
A triplet; three lines, or three lines rhyming together.
To sting with, or as with, nettles; to irritate; to annoy. G.A. Sala.
The art or process of examining by means of the endoscope.
Having a bore of perfectly smooth surface; -- distinguishedfrom rifled.-- n.
To free from company; to dissociate. [R.]It she be alone now, and discompanied. B. Jonson.
Of or pertaining to Thuringia, a country in Germany, or itspeople.-- n.
A coming together; sexual intercourse; copulation. Grew.
A treasury or storehouse; hence, a repository, especially ofknowledge; -- often applied to a comprehensive work, like adictionary or cyclopedia.
The description of muscles, including the study of muscularcontraction by the aid of registering apparatus, as by some form ofmyograph; myology.
Leather softened by boiling so as to take any required shape.Upon drying, it becomes exceedingly hard, and hence was formerly usedfor armor. [Obs.] "His jambeux were of quyrboilly." Chaucer.
A curassow of the genus Ortalida, allied to the guan.
The half channel or groove in the edge of the triglyph in theDoric order.
An endogenous plant having simple leaves, a stem generallyjointed and tubular, the husks or glumes in pairs, and the seedsingle.
In a near manner; not remotely; closely; intimately; almost.
A form of seacoast cannon; a long, chambered gun designed forthrowing shot or shells with heavy charges of powder, at high anglesof elevation.
A structure of posts and boards for supporting workmen, etc.,as in building.
; sing. Mandingo. (Ethnol.) An extensive and powerful tribe ofWest African negroes.
One of a family of bats, including those which have thickexternal ears.
Of or pertaining to the genus Allium, or garlic, onions, leeks,etc.; having the smell or taste of garlic or onions.
Of or pertaining to the Pyrenees, a range of mountainsseparating France and Spain.-- n.
An order of court by which a proceeding is set aside orannulled.
The seven daughters of Atlas and the nymph Pleione, fabled tohave been made by Jupiter a constellation in the sky.
One of the incumbents of a benefice which has two or morerectors or vicars.
A number or company of ten householders who, dwelling near eachother, were sureties or frankpledges to the king for the goodbehavior of each other; a decennary. Blackstone.
Having a distinct cleavage in a single direction only.
Destitute of streams, or of a stream, as a region of country,or a dry channel.
Liberal principles; the principles and methods of the liberalsin politics or religion; specifically, the principles of the Liberalparty.
In a general sense, any bird of the order Psittaci.
A votary of the turf, or race course; hence, sometimes, ablackleg. [Colloq.] Thackeray.
The art of moving the hands in oratory or in pantomime; gesture[Obs.]
The wheather; -- so called from its cry. [Prov. Eng.]
A deep blue pigment or coloring material used in various arts.It is a vitreous substance made of cobalt, potash, and calcinedquartz fused, and reduced to a powder.
One of the two or three delicate membranous scales which arenext to the stamens in grasses.
In fives; consisting of five in one; five repeated; quintuple.
Tending to prevent, destroy, or expel, worms or vermin;anthelmintic.
Unsteadiness; levity; lightness. [Obs.] Bp. Hopkins.
A hot and destructive wind that sometimes blows, in Turkey,from the desert. It is identical with the simoom of Arabia and thekamsin of Syria.
To release from a cloister, or from confinement or seclusion;to set free; to liberate.
The written characters used in the common method of writing; --opposed to shorthand.
Having two tongues, or speaking two languages. [Obs.]
Having the power or quality of shaking or agitating. Johnson.
A plate of cartilage, or a series of bony or cartilaginousplates or segments, in the median line of the pectoral skeleton ofmost vertebrates above fishes; the breastbone.
The settlings of oil, molasses, etc., at the bottom of a barrelor hogshead. Simmonds.

A plant of the genus Dipsacus, of which one species (D.fullonum) bears a large flower head covered with stiff, prickly,hooked bracts. This flower head, when dried, is used for raising anap on woolen cloth.
Of or pertaining to the Latin poet Ovid; resembling the styleof Ovid.
A place where the bodies of persons found dead are exposed,that they may be identified, or claimed by their friends; adeadhouse.
A waterproof outer garment; -- so called from the name of theinventor.
The act of striking the heel of the fore foot with the toe ofthe hind foot; -- said of horses.
The most powerful, and except the king the most important,piece in a set of chessmen.
A measure of area, the hundredth part of an are; one squaremeter, or about 1
Having the basal part produced around the stem; -- said ofleaves which the stem apparently passes directory through.
The forehead; the part of the cranium between the orbits andthe vertex.
A species of the feldspar group containing barium. SeeFeldspar.
The doctrine of a modern religious sect, which originated inPersia in 1843, being a mixture of Mohammedan, Christian, Jewish andParsee elements.
To raise or remove from the grave; to disinter; to untomb; toexhume. [Obs.] Fuller.
The Greek major third, which comprehend two major tones (themodern major third contains one major and one minor whole tone).
The classification of living organisms according to theirstructural character; taxonomy.
A genus of plants including the common broom of Western Europe.
A mixed or compound stop in an organ; -- sometimes calledmixture.
Like glair, or partaking of its qualities; covered with glair;viscous and transparent; slimy. Wiseman.
That department of medical science which treats of miasma.
A genus of cephalopods having a multilocular, internal,siphunculated shell in the form of a flat spiral, the coils of whichare not in contact.
A suborder of struthious birds including the rheas.
A dilation or enlargement of a canal or other organ.
A Latin epic poem by Statius about Thebes in Boeotia.
Of or pertaining to Tycho Brahe, or his system of astronomy.
Passing or held by collation; -- said of livings of which thebishop and the patron are the same person.
The state of being on an equality, as in rank or power.
One who has a legal settlement in a town, city, or parish; apermanent resident.
A hard or thickened spot or protuberance; a hardening andthickening of the skin or bark of a part, eps. as a result ofcontinued pressure or friction.
Any elevated object on land which serves as a guide tomariners; a beacon; a landmark visible from the sea, as a hill, atree, a steeple, or the like. Shak.
The act, practice, or art of catching turtles. Marryat.
An order of Brachiopoda; the Lyopomata. See Brachiopoda.
To prohibit; to forbid; to avert. [Archaic]Which peril heaven forefend! Shak.
A liquid hydrocarbon, C20H38, of the acetylene series, obtainedfrom brown coal.

A picture produced by superposing a very light print, renderedtranslucent by varnish, and tinted upon the back, upon a strongerprint, so as to give the effect of a photograph in natural colors; --called also hellenotype. Knight.
A glairy viscous substance, which forms on the surface ofcertain mineral waters, or covers the sides of their inclosures; --called also baregin.
A salt spring; a place where salt water is collected in theearth.
Wood to which a tenant is entitled for making and repairingcarts and other instruments of husbandry.
An ointment composed of wax, pitch, resin, and olive oil, lard,or other fatty substance.
A large herbaceos plant (Cynara Cardunculus) related to theartichoke; -- used in cookery and as a sald.
The point of an orbit, as of the moon or a planet, at which itis in conjunction or opposition; -- commonly used in the plural.
A signer; one who signs or subscribes; as, a conference ofsignatories.
An apparatus for depositing and consolidating concrete underwater, essentially a tube of wood or sheet metal with a hooperliketop. It is usually handled by a crane.
A long, thin, marine fish of Europe (Trichiurus lepturus); theribbon fish.
A garden plant (Chrysanthemum Balsamita) having a strongbalsamic smell, and nearly allied to tansy. It is used as a pot herband salad plant and in flavoring ale and beer. Called also alecost.
The theory, early advanced in geology, that the successiverocks of the earth''s crust were formed by igneous fusion; -- opposedto the Neptunian theory.

A conveyance of property, upon condition, as security for thepayment of a debt or the preformance of a duty, and to become voidupon payment or performance according to the stipulated terms; also,the written instrument by which the conveyance is made.
To give or dedicate in token of thanks. [Obs. or R.] Mede.
To subject (wood, fabrics, etc.) to a process of saturation ina solution of chloride of zinc, to prevent decay; -- a processinvented by Sir William Burnett.
A stitch made by setting the needle back of the end of the laststitch, and bringing it out in front of the end.
In an easy, gliding manner, as if swimming; smoothly;successfully; prosperously.
An implement of steel, bone, ivory, etc., with a sharp point,for making holes by piercing; a
A borosilicate of iron and lime, near datolite in form andcomposition.
That branch of science which relates to the mind; mentalphilosophy. [R.]
A special breed of the dromedary used for rapid traveling; theswift camel; -- called also herire, and maharik.
Seasickness; hence, any similar sickness of the stomachaccompanied with a propensity to vomit; qualm; squeamishness of thestomach; loathing.
A process of bone formation in which ossification takes placein the perichondrium and either surrounds or gradually replaces thecartilage.
The complex radical, CO.OH, regarded as the essential andcharacteristic constituent which all oxygen acids of carbon (asformic, acetic, benzoic acids, etc.) have in common; -- called alsooxatyl.
A small maul with a short handle, -- used esp. for driving atool, as a chisel or the like; also, a light beetle with a longhandle, -- used in playing croquet.
To subject to scorching heat, so as to drive off volatileingredients; to roast, as ores.
In a supercilious, disdainful, or haughty manner; arroganty.Junius.
Prussian; -- applied to certain astronomical tables publishedin the sixteenth century, founded on the principles of Copernicus, aPrussian.
To grind with the teeth, and with a crackling sound; tocraunch. [Prov. Eng. & Colloq. U.S.]
From the beginning; a direction to return to, and end with, thefirst strain; -- indicated by the letters D. C. Also, the strain sorepeated.
A nerve, or string, that is imagined to be essential to life.Daniel.
The act or offense of grubbing up trees and bushes, and thusdestroying the tickets or coverts of a forest. Spelman. Cowell.
A division of cirripeds including those which have six thoracicsegments, usually bearing six pairs of cirri. The common barnaclesare examples.
To give a crimson or red color to; to crimson. Shak.
Formerly, in Ireland, a kind of servile tenure which subjectedthe tenant to maintain his chieftain gratuitously whenever he wishedto indulge in a revel. Spenser.
The common wild gray goose (Anser anser) of Europe, believed tobe the wild form of the domestic goose. See Illust. of Goose.
To bind or hold by, or as if by, a spell or charm; tofascinate, esp. by eloquence of speech, as in a political campaign. -- Spell"bind`er (#), n.
Having but one cell, or cavity; not divided by a septum orpartition.
The science of improving stock, whether human or animal. F.Galton.
The act or process of completing or perfecting; the final workupon or ornamentation of a thing.
A verse or line consisting of four measures, that is, iniambic, trochaic, and anapestic verse, of eight feet; in other kindsof verse, of four feet.
The mahoganylike wood of the Australian Eucalyptus marginata.See Eucalyptus.
Having a valence of eight; capable of being combined with,exchanged for, or compared with, eight atoms of hydrogen; -- said ofcertain atoms or radicals.
Imploying tort, or privat injury for which the law givesdamages; involing tort.
Thin shreds of leather shaved off in dressing skins. Simmonds.
Marked with spots or lines, which are often colored. Henslow.
Substance; subsistence; essence; person; personality; -- usedby the early theologians to denote any one of the three subdivisionsof the Godhead, the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.
Of or pertaining to the nobility or aristocracy. [R.] -- n.
A rare element of the boron group, sometimes associated withyttrium or other related elements, as in euxenite and gadolinite.Symbol Yb; provisional atomic weight 173.2. Cf. Yttrium.
A borosilicate of lime, first found at Danbury, Conn. It isnear the topaz in form. Dana.
One of the small divisions of a decompound frond or leaf. SeeIllust. of Bipinnate leaf, under Bipinnate.
a thin plate or scale of anything, as a thin scale growing fromthe petals of certain flowers; or one of the thin plates or scales ofwhich certain shells are composed.
Any fabric having a thick soft shag, like the fur of a mole;esp., a kind of strong twilled fustian.
A space left unroofed over the court of a Roman dwelling,through which the rain fell into the impluvium or cistern.
Jews who are descendants of the former Jews of Spain andPortugal. They are as a rule darker than the northern Jews, and havemore delicate features.
An international, interdenominational organization of Bibleclasses of young men; -- so named in allusion to the Hebrew wordBerachah (Meaning blessing) occurring in 2 Chron. xx. 26 and 1 Chron.xii.
The act of taking hold, seizing, or grasping, as with the handor other member.
The tendency to separate readily into parts by spuriousarticulations, as the pods of tick trefoil.
The peculiar bitter substance, soft or liquid, and of a yellowcolor, produced when meat, bread, gum, sugar, starch, and the like,are roasted till they turn brown.
A red wood of a leguminous tree (Baphia nitida), from Angolaand the Gaboon in Africa. It is used as a dyewood, and also forramrods, violin bows and turner's work.
The science which relates to the structure and habits ofmollusks.
A chank shell (Turbinella pyrum); also, a shell bracelet ornecklace made in India from the chank shell.
Out of; without; foreign to; out of the agreement, record,will, or other instrument.
A high, bleak plateau or district, with stunted trees, andcold, damp atmosphere, as in the Andes, in South America.
One who, or that which, fortifies, strengthens, supports, orupholds.
A smooth, white, marine, gastropod shell of the genus Ovulum,resembling an egg in form.
To fail to follow suit when holding a card of the suit led, inviolation of the rule of the game; to renege. Hoyle.
Occurring before the symptom ataxia has developed; -- appliedto the early symptoms of locomotor ataxia.
A salt formed by the combination of boric acid with a base orpositive radical.
A small loop or bow of ribbon used in making hats, boas, etc.
The lowest degree of desire; imperfect or incomplete volition.Locke.

A genus of iridaceous plants, with pretty blossoms risingseparately from the bulb or corm. C. vernus is one of the earliest ofspring-blooming flowers; C. sativus produces the saffron, andblossoms in the autumn.
Rebellowing; resounding loudly. [R.] Mrs. Browning.
To stretch; also, to lay out, as a dead body. See Streak. [Obs.or Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
A genus of liguliflorous composite plants, including the falldandelion (L. autumnale), and formerly the true dandelion; -- calledalso lion's tooth.
Larger than royal; -- said of a particular size of printing andwriting paper. See the Note under Paper, n.
Of or pertaining to the island, kingdom, or people of Sardinia.-- n.
Any one of the three hypothetical radicals corresponding to thethree toluic acids.
One who is impaneled on a jury, or who serves as a juror.
One of the Plymouth Brethren, or of a sect among them; -- socalled from John N. Darby, one of the leaders of the Brethren.
A rude balance for weighing, and a kind of weight, formerlyused in England. Halliwell.
A large fish pound used for the capture of the tunny in theMediterranean; also applied to the seines used for the same purpose.
One who tills; a husbandman; a cultivator; a plowman.
A disease characterized by severe nervous symptoms, dependentupon the presence of the constituents of the bile in the blood.
A small South American opossum (Didelphys opossum), having fourwhite spots on the face.
The wolverence; -- also applied, but erroneously, to the Canadalynx, and sometimes to the American badger. See Wolverene.
A narrow path or way for pedestrains only; a footway.
Nonsecretion or defective secretion of urine; ischury.
Having a fin, or fins, or anything resembling a fin. Mortimer.
The primary growth from the spore of a moss, usually consistingof branching confervoid filaments, on any part of which stem and leafbuds may be developed.
A member of the highest rank of nobility in Germany andAustria, corresponding to the British duke.
A castle and domain conferred on a nobleman for life. [Poland]Brande & C.
A yellow flowered evening primrose (Taraxia, syn. Onothera,ovata) native of California.
A piece of ground terminating in a point or acute angle. [Obs.]
A voracious, toothed whale of the genus Orca, of which severalspecies are known.
A large, square, woolen cloak which enveloped the whole person,worn by the Greeks and by certain Romans. It is the Roman name of aGreek garment.
Any of a group of sugars of the formula C5H10O5, as arabinose;-- so called from the five carbon atoms in the molecule. They are notfermented by yeast.
The fluid which surrounds the membranous labyrinth of theinternal ear, and separates it from the walls of the chambers inwhich the labyrinth lies.
A sculpin. [Local cant] Johny Crapaud (, a jocose designationof a Frenchman, or of the French people, collectively.
To change, as an algebraic expression or geometrical figure,into another from without altering its value.
A concise or abridged statement or view; an abstract; asummary.
One of a series of complex nitrogenous substances regarded ascontaining two molecules of urea or their radicals, as uric acid orallantoin. Cf. Ureide.
One of the free, or nearly free, segments of a tapeworm. Itcontains both male and female reproductive organs, and is capable ofa brief independent existence.
That which is permanent, or is supposed to be given, and in orupon which changes are effected by psychological or physicalprocesses and relations; -- opposed to form. Mansel.
A mark of ownership cut on the bill or swan. [Eng.] Encyc.Brit.
Somewhat mucky; soft, sticky, and dirty; muxy. [Prov. Eng.] R.D. Blackmore.
A flaming torch, esp. one made by combining together a numberof thick wicks invested with a quick-burning substance (anciently,perhaps, wax; in modern times, pitch or the like); hence, any torch.
One who has lost his hair by disease; a sneaking fellow, or onewho is hardly used.
The fold of peritoneum which suspends the ovary from the dorsalwall of the body cavity.
A hypothetical radical of selenium, analogous to sulphonium.[R.]
Polishing rouge; a reddish brown oxide of iron, used inpolishing glass, and also as a pigment; -- called also crocus Martis.
To wander away; to go astray; to wander far and to weariness.[Obs.]
The European throstle or song thrush (Turdus musicus).
To go out of the track; to deviate. [Obs.] Bentley.
The keel or lower outline of a bird's bill, so far as themandibular rami are united.
One portion of a fruit that spontaneously divides into halves.
An imaginary good-natured spirit, who was supposed often toperform important services around the house by night, such asthrashing, churning, sweeping. [Scot.]
In an absolute, independent, or unconditional manner; wholly;positively.
The systematic use of antiseptics in the performance ofoperations and the treatment of wounds; -- so called from JosephLister, an English surgeon.

One of a sect of heretics, in the first centuries of thechurch, whose doctrine was a mixture of Judaism and Christianity.They denied the divinity of Christ, regarding him as an inspiredmessenger, and rejected much of the New Testament.
The doctrine, as formulated by Luther, that Christ's glorifiedbody is omnipresent.
Resembling, or covered with, pustules; pustulate; pustular.
The use or application of a caustic; cautery. Ferrand.
One engaged in logging. See Log, v. i. [U.S.] Lowell.
To make immovable; in surgery, to make immovable (a naturallymobile part, as a joint) by the use of splints, or stiffenedbandages.
A step or raised shelf, as above a sideboard or altar. Cf.Superaltar, and Gradin.

The doctrine of the sphere; the science of the properties andrelations of the circles, figures, and other magnitudes of a sphere,produced by planes intersecting it; spherical geometry andtrigonometry.
The rising of the moon above the horizon; also, the time of itsrising.

A genus of huge, carnivorous, dinosaurian reptiles from theCretaceous formation of the United States. They had very large hindlegs and tail, and are supposed to have been bipedal. Some of thespecies were about eighteen feet high.

A web-footed bird, of the genus Diomedea, of which there areseveral species. They are the largest of sea birds, capable of long-continued flight, and are often seen at great distances from theland. They are found chiefly in the southern hemisphere.
The act of impugning, or the state of being impugned. Ed. Rev.
An order of worms parasitic in cephalopods. They are remarkablefor the extreme simplicity of their structure. The embryo exists intwo forms.
A haddock or other small fish split open and dried in the sun;-- called also speldron. [Scot.]
Of or pertaining to sculpture or carving of any sort, esp. toglyphs.
Having the power of contracting into wrinkles. Johnson.
The act of taking vengeance; revenge. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Pertaining to, or obtained from, anil; indigotic; -- applied toan acid formed by the action of nitric acid on indigo. [R.]
A gold coin of Bavaria, of the value of about 13s. 6d.sterling, or about three dollars and a quarter.
Rounded; especially, rounded at the end or ends, or at thecorners.
A deformity in which the foot is turned inward. See Talipes.
To dismiss from service on board ship. [Obs.] Hakluyt.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, palladium; -- usedspecifically to designate those compounds in which the element has ahigher valence as contrasted with palladious compounds.
An argillaceous sandstone, of a red color, and much seamed; --found in India.
The full profits or products which ground or land yields, asthe hay of the meadows, the feed of the pasture, the grain of arablefields, the rents, services, and the like. Cowell.
One of the two dorsal tubular organs on the hinder part of theabdomen of aphids. They give exit to the honeydew. See Illust. underAphis.
A functional nervous affection or disease, that is, a diseaseof the nerves without any appreciable change of nerve structure.
Shrubs, small trees, and the like, in a wood or forest, growingbeneath large trees; undergrowth.
A moat with water in it; also, a small stream; a runlet. [Prov.Eng.] Halliwell.
An order of Annelida, including the leeches; -- called alsoHirudinei.
Cleft in a pedate manner, but having the lobes distinctlyconnected at the base; -- said of a leaf.
Pertaining to, derived from, or resembling, octane; -- usedspecifically, to designate any one of a group of acids, the mostimportant of which is called caprylic acid.
Of or pertaining to Immanuel Kant, the German philosopher;conformed or relating to any or all of the philosophical doctrines ofImmanuel Kant.
One who seizes a person by the throat from behind, with a viewto strangle and rob him.
Small, little; of a woman or girl, of small size and trimfigure.
A hydrocarbon of the aromatic series obtained as a colorlessliquid by the distillation of camphor with zinc chloride. It is oneof the three metamers of xylene. Cf. Metamer, and Xylene.
That form of homology due to common ancestry (phylogenetichomology), in opposition to homomorphy, to which genealogic basis iswanting. Haeckel.
The private orchestra or band of a prince or of a church.

An apparatus for the determination of the amount of urea inurine, in which the nitrogen evolved by the action of certainreagents, on a given volume of urine, is collected and measured, andthe urea calculated accordingly.
A bard among the Highlanders of Scotland, who preserved andrepeated the traditions of the tribes; also, a genealogist. [Writtenalso senachy.] [Scot.]
An artificer whose occupation is to make or mend locks.
A division of Bryozoa, in which the cells have circularapertures.
The water course of a street; a little canal or channel; agutter; also, a puddle. Bp. Hall.
Having water within; containing fluid drops; -- said of certaincrystals.
A small Europen flounder (Rhoumbus punctatus). The name is alsoapplied to allied species.
Transportation, as of petroleum oil, by means of a pipeconduit; also, the charge for such transportation.
An unorganized ferment which causes cane sugar to take up amolecule of water and be converted into invert sugar.
A small cooper coin formerly current in the Roman States, worthabout a cent and a half.
A theory of the origin of ideas which derives them exclusivelyfrom sensation.
Having power to enact or establish as a law. Abp. Bramhall.
To prefigure; to exhibit previously in a type. Bp. Pearson.
A large mass of ice, generally floating in the ocean.
Of, pertaining to, or obtained from, sandalwood (Santalum); --used specifically to designate an acid obtained as a resinous or redcrystalline dyestuff, which is called also santalin.
A fancied perception of flashes of light, a symptom ofepilepsy; hence, epilepsy itself; convulsions.
One who frequents; one who often visits, or resorts tocustomarily.
A complaint to a court. See Audita Querela. [Obs.] Ayliffe.
Act or process of expelling the exhaust gases from the cylinderby some special means, as, in many four-cycle engines, by utilizingthe momentum of the exhaust gases in a long exhaust pipe.
An African sheeplike quadruped (the Ammotragus tragelaphus)having a long mane on the breast and fore legs. It is, perhaps, thechamois of the Old Testament.
The armpit, or the cavity beneath the junction of the arm andshoulder.
Having one oblique intersection; -- said of that system ofcrystallization in which the vertical axis is inclined to one, but atright angles to the other, lateral axis. See Crystallization.
A plan proposed; a draft of a proposed measure; a project.
Of or pertaining to building or construction; architectural.
Floating in water, as the leaves of water lilies, or submersed,as those of many aquatic plants.
The pelvic arch, or the pelvic arch together with the sacrum.See Pelvic arch, under Pelvic, and Sacrum.
A slender, nearly leafless, American herb (Polygonumarticulatum), with jointed spikes of small flowers.
Forming or producing an oil; specifically, designating acolorless gaseous hydrocarbon called ethylene. [Archaic]
A massive variety of talc, of a grayish green or brown color.It forms extensive beds, and is quarried for fireplaces and forcoarse utensils. Called also potstone, lard stone, and soapstone.
To be careless, negligent, or aswkward, esp. with regard todress and neatness; to be wasteful. Ray.
An oblong rectangular piece of cloth, worn by Roman ladies, andfastened with brooches.
An insect that turns about nimbly; the mole cricket; -- calledalso fan cricket. Johnson.
The herb wolfsbane, or monkshood; -- applied to any plant ofthe genus Aconitum (tribe Hellebore), all the species of which arepoisonous.
A country or region, more or less remote from the city of Rome,brought under the Roman government; a conquered country beyond thelimits of Italy. Wyclif (Acts xiii. 34). Milton.
An inhabitant, or, collectively, inhabitants, of the Faroeislands.
A branching perennial plant (Cichorium Intybus) with brightblue flowers, growing wild in Europe, Asia, and America; alsocultivated for its roots and as a salad plant; succory; wild endive.See Endive.
An American genus of plants, containing but a single species(E. repens), the trailing arbutus.
A bar of iron sharpened at one end, and used as a lever.
A naval vessel having the parts above water covered andprotected by iron or steel usually in large plates closely joined andmade sufficiently thick and strong to resist heavy shot.
To cease to hold; to unhand; to release. [Obs.] Otway.
A European flounder (Hippoglossoides limandoides); -- calledalso rough dab, long fluke, sand fluke, and sand sucker.
The peculiar fruit of fennel, carrott, parsnip, and the like,consisting of a pair of carpels pendent from a supporting axis.
One who furthers. or helps to advance; a promoter. Shak.
Covered with hairs or pubescence so platted together andinterwoven as to form a mass easily removed.
The Cornish chough. See under Chough. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
A stick three feet, or a yard, in length, used as a measure ofcloth, etc.
A loop or eye formed on the head rope of a bonnet, by which itis attached to the foot of a sail; -- called also latch and lasket.[Usually in pl.]
A member of the sanhedrin. Schaeffer (Lange's Com. ).
A sum paid to a lord as a pecuniary compensation for killinghis man (that is, his vassal, servant, or tenant). Spelman.
One who produces or creates original works of art ordecoration.
The sense by which the impressions made on the olfactory organsby the odorous particles in the atmosphere are perceived.

The matins and lauds for the last three days of Holy Week,commemorating the sufferings and death of Christ, -- usually sung onthe afternoon or evening of Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday, insteadof on the following days.
A ditch on the outside of the counterscarp, usually full ofwater.
Neglect or omission to use an easement or franchise or toassert a right. Kent.
The envelope or coat of certain fungi, such as the puffballsand earthstars.
A person of a dull, grave, gloomy temperament. W. browne.
The union of three persons (the Father, the Son, and the HolyGhost) in one Godhead, so that all the three are one God as tosubstance, but three persons as to individuality.
In a mincing manner; not fully; with affected nicety.
One to whom something is presented; also, one who is presented;specifically (Eccl.), one presented to benefice. Ayliffe.
A piece for one or more solo instruments with orchestra; --more concise than the concerto.
Immaterial; incorporeal; spiritual. [Obs.] Sir W. Raleigh.
An ornament much used in Egyptian architecture, generallyasserted to have been suggested by the Egyptian water lily.
A sliding, as down a snow slope in the Alps. Tyndall.
Loaded dice so contrived as to turn up high numbers. [Obs] SirJ. Harrington.
An instrument formerly used for taking the altitude of theheavenly bodies, but now superseded by the quadrant and sextant; --so called because the observer turned his back to the body observed.
A bitter principle obtained from the root of the bryony(Bryonia alba and B. dioica). It is a white, or slightly colored,substance, and is emetic and cathartic.
To edify anew; to build again after destruction. [R.] Milton.
Want of confidence or trust; suspicion; distrust. Milton.
One of the rings on the top of the saddle of a harness, throughwhich the reins pass.
A dwelling for a number of paupers maintained at publicexpense; an almshouse; a workhouse.
A bolt which a looped head, or an opening in the head.
Pertaining to, having the nature of, or resembling, an insect.Howell.
The song of Zacharias at the birth of John the Baptist (Luke i.68); -- so named from the first word of the Latin version.
A long-continued or excessive dilatation of the pupil of theeye.
An unmarried person; also, one opposed to marriage. Foxe.
To cover or saturate with albumen; to coat or treat with analbuminous solution; as, to albuminize paper.
Deprived or destitute of natural feelings; unnatural. [Obs.]Shak.
A theoretical aggregation of molecules constituting astructural particle of protoplasm, capable of increase or diminutionwithout change in chemical nature.
To face, as an embankment, with masonry, wood, or othermaterial.
A divalent, compound radical, CO.CH2, regarded as the essentialradical of glycolic acid, and a large series of related compounds.
in laundry work, to dry without smoothing or ironing.
A green or blue pigment produced by Peziza in certain kinds ofdecayed wood, as the beech, oak, birch, etc., and extracted as anamorphous powder resembling indigo.
A sort of pear, called also the red butter pear, from itssmooth, delicious, soft pulp.
An effusion of blood into the cavity of the pleura.
One who cultivates or keeps a nursery, or place for rearingtrees, etc.
The wiew or doctrins of the ultramontane party in the LatinChurch. Gladstone.
A dwarf tree, one in size between a shrub and a tree; atreelike shrub. Bradley.
A stone laid over, or erected near, a grave, usually with aninscription, to preserve the memory of the dead; a tombstone.
One of the starch group (C6H10O5)n of the carbohydrates; as,starch, arabin, dextrin, cellulose, etc.
Of or pertaining to Mars, the Roman god of war, or to theplanet bearing his name; martial.
One who pretends to be wise; a wiseacre; a witling. Donne.
A horizontal graduated bar mounted on a staff, used as astadium, or telemeter, for measuring distances.
A man who violates his religious covenant. Jer. ix. 2.
To make drafts upon or against, in excess of the proper amountor limit.
Of or pertaining to prosthesis; prefixed, as a letter orletters to a word.
A contrivance, turning on a vertical axis by a handle or winch,and giving a circular motion to the ore to be washed; a stirrer.
A patch; an addition; a piece put on. [Obs.] John Lewis (1731).
A carved ornament on the stern of a vessel, containing a windowor the representation of one.
Situated in front of the nose, or in front of the nasalchambers.
To deprive (a bencher) of his privileges. Mozley & W.
To bend or bow over; to bend in a contrary direction. [Obs.]Fuller.
That which goes out, or is paid out; outlay; expenditure; --the opposite of Ant: income. Lowell.
To act more than is necessary; to go to excess in action. B.Jonson.
A yellow powder, C6H3N9, obtained from certain sulphocyanates.It has acid properties and forms compounds called mellonides.
A little or insignificant dandy; a contemptible fop.
A colonnade or covered ambulatory, especially in classicalstyles of architecture; usually, a colonnade at the entrance of abuilding.
To imitate the manner of the Laconians, especially in brief,pithy speech, or in frugality and austerity.
An upholder of kingly authority; a royalist. [Obs.] Fuller.
A Mohammedan saint; especially, one who claims to work curessupernaturally.
A morbid condition of the system resulting from excessive useof chloral.
The fruit of the Corylus Avellana or hazel. It is an oval nut,containing a kernel that has a mild, farinaceous, oily taste,agreeable to the palate.
A grayish white mineral occuring in tetragonal crystals and incleavable masses. It is esentially a silicate of aluminia and soda.
A goatsucker; -- so called from the peculiar noise it makeswhen darting through the air.
Course of life; means of support; livelihood. [Obs.]
A cover; a shelter; a protection. [Archaic] Carew. C. Kingsley.
To forage for booty; to plunder. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
A Jacobite who favored the restoration of James II, oncondition of a general amnesty and of guarantees for the security ofthe civil and ecclesiastical constitution of the realm.
A medicine serving to mitigate or remove fever.-- a.

One of the stages in the life history of certain rusts(Uredinales), regarded at one time as a distinct genus. It is asummer stage preceding the teleutospore, or winter stage. SeeUredinales, in the Supplement.
Covered; -- applied to seeds which have the usual integumentarycovering.
A salt of a diamino phenol, C6H3(OH)(NH2)2, used as adeveloper.
A small European shrub (Daphne Mezereum), whose acrid bark isused in medicine.
An alloy of copper and zinc, resembling brass, but of a goldencolor. Ure.
The science which treats of the bones of the vertebrateskeleton.
To deprive of an endowment, as a church. Gladstone.
A genus of large malacopterygious fishes of the orderSiluroidei. They inhabit the inland waters of Europe and Asia.
One who performs or carries into effect. See Executor.
An amorphous mineral of apple-green color; a hydrous silicateof nickel and magnesia. It is an important ore of nickel.
A process which, among some of the lower forms of life,precedes reproduction by budding, fission, spore formation, etc.
A distance lime brawn across the rink or course between themiddle line and the tee. [Scot.]
Originally, one appointed to the command of a burg (fortress orcastle); but the title afterward became hereditary, with a domainattached.
Snobs, collectively. [Hybrid & Recent] C. Kingsley.

Any one of several species of long-legged sandpipers of thegenus Totanus, in which the legs are bright yellow; -- called alsostone snipe, tattler, telltale, yellowshanks; and yellowshins. SeeTattler, 2.
A slight gleam or glimmer; a glimpse. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acid,obtained by the action of acetic acid and potassium nitrite on uricacid, as a yellow crystalline substance, with a bitter, astringenttaste.
A perforated steel die through which wires or tubes are drawnto form them.
Three metrical feet taken together, or included in one measure.
In a chary manner; carefully; cautiously; frugally.

A radiotelegraphic station serving solely for determining theposition of ships. The radius of operation of such stations wasrestricted by the International Radiotelegraphic Convention (1912) to30 nautical miles.
A kind of pseudomorph, in which there has been a change ofphysical characters without alteration of chemical composition, asthe change of aragonite to calcite.
A green poisonous substance used as a pigment and drug,obtained by the action of acetic acid on copper, and consistingessentially of a complex mixture of several basic copper acetates.
Ready to obey; reverent; differential; also, servilelysubmissive.
One of the specially large spores of certain flowerless plants,as Selaginella, etc.
The state or practice of an athlete; the characteristics of anathlete.
Consisting of, or resembling, fat or oil; oily; unctuous;oleaginous.
A captain, leader, or commander; a chief; the head of a troop,army, or clan.

A complex nitrogenous substance obtained from murexide,alloxantin, and other ureids, as a white, or yellowish, crystallinewhich turns red on exposure to the air; -- called also uramil,dialuramide, and formerly purpuric acid.
A festival commemorative of the founding of a city or theconsecration of a church; also, the ceremonies (as at Oxford andCambridge, England) commemorative of founders or benefactors.
A plant from which layers are propagated by bending itsbranches into the soil. P. Henderson.
A disease in hawks, characterized by the presence of smallthreadlike worms, also of filaments of coagulated blood, from therupture of a vein; -- called also backworm. Sir T. Browne.
A Mexican shrub (Euphorbia pulcherrima) with very large andconspicuous vermilion bracts below the yellowish flowers.
An apparatus for determining the amount of nitrogen or some ofits compounds in any substance subjected to analysis; an azotometer.
Combined, or impregnated, with nitric acid, or some of itscompounds.
Having a hard albumen penetrated by irregular channels filledwith softer matter, as the nutmeg and the seeds of the North Americanpapaw.
The fore part of the night last past; the previous evening.[R.] Shak.
An extinct genus of brachiopods, very characteristic of theCarboniferous rocks.
A district from which a Zaim draws his revenue. Smart.
Crystallized cawk, in which the crystals are small.
A word letter; a phonogram, that, for the sake of brevity,represents a word; as, |, i. e., t, for it. Cf. Grammalogue.
A textile fabric with a nap or shag on one side, longer andsofter than the nap of velvet. Cowper.
State of being aseptic; the methods or processes ofasepticizing.
Any plant of the labiate genus Scutellaria, the calyx of whoseflower appears, when inverted, like a helmet with the visor raised.
Compression, especially constriction of vessels by an externalcause.
One who dives under water in search of something, as forpearls; a diver. [R.] Ray.
To expel from the bar, or the legal profession; to deprive (anattorney, barrister, or counselor) of his status and privileges assuch. Abbott.
A vinegar cup; socket of the hip bone; a measure of about oneeighth of a pint, etc.
Full of humps or bunches; covered with protuberances; humped.
The work of the painter; also, any work of art in which objectsare represented in color on a flat surface; a colored representationof any object or scene; a picture.
Of or pertaining to Thalia; hence, of or pertaining to comedy;comic.
A genus of shrubs or perennial herbs including the meadowsweetand the hardhack.
The pagan lands; pagans, collectively; paganism. [R.]
One versed in the niceties of academical disputation or ofschool divinity.
In a nominal manner; by name; in name only; not in reality.Burke.
One who appraises; esp., a person appointed and sworn toestimate and fix the value of goods or estates.
A minute particular; a small or minor detail; -- used chieflyin the plural.
A green foliated kind of amphibole, observed in eclogite andsome varietis of gabbro.
Tending to pull asunder, tear, or rend; distracting.
A prickly, climbing shrub of the genus Pisonia. The fruit is akind of berry.
A kind of boat of various forms, used in the IndianArchipelago.
The first university examination; -- called also little go. Seeunder Little, a.
Lint; esp., lint made into a tent for insertion into wounds orulcers.
Corn of grain of which bread is made, as wheat, rye, etc.
A colorless oil obtained from hemp dy distillation, andpossessing its intoxicating properties.
A carpentry obstruction, stockade, or other obstacle made in apassage in order to stop an enemy.
A silver coin of Portugal, worth about sixpence sterling, orabout eleven cents. Homans.
Diminished in value; dishonored; degraded. [R.] Shak.
A genus of climbing orchidaceous plants natives of tropicalAmerica.
A jet of steam issuing from a fissure in the earth.
Calcium oxalate, occurring in colorless or white monocliniccrystals.
The stoker or fireman of a furnace, as in glass works.Tomlinson.
To cover, as a corpse, with a mound or tomb; to bury. [Obs.]
One who overlays; that with which anything is overlaid.
To mingle; to mix; to unite; to blend. [R.] Thomson.
Capable of being cut smoothly; scissible. [R.] Arbuthnot.
A sulphide of antimony and silver of an iron-black color andmetallic luster; called also black silver, and brittle silver ore.
A pupil; especially, a graduate of a college or other seminaryof learning.
The person to whom another is bound, or the person to whom abond is given. Blackstone.
A bract on the stalk of a single flower, which is itself on amain stalk that support several flowers. Gray.
A California fish (Hemilepidotus spinosus), allied to thesculpin.
A method or practice of the administration of the sacrament bydipping the bread or wafer in the wine and administering bothtogether.
An orthographic projection of the sphere on the plane of themeridian, the eye being supposed at an infinite distance, and in theeast or west point of the horizon.
An armed constable; also, a government servant or courier.[Turkey]
Composed of solitary parts, as a flower with one sepal, onepetal, one stamen, and one pistil.
The position of a candidate; state of being a candidate;candidateship.
Working smoothly, or without splitting; -- said of timber.
An alloy resembling silver, and consisting chiefly of copper,zinc, and nickel, with small proportions of tin, aluminium, andbismuth. Ure.
An image or representation; a form; a phantom; an apparition.Sir W. Scott.
A name given by miners to George Stephenson's safety lamp.Raymond.
The property of radiant energy (found chiefly in solar orelectric light) by which chemical changes are produced, as inphotography.
Of, pertaining to, or denoting, those rays of light whichproduce chemical effects; actinic. [R.]
A supposed element, afterward found to be a mixture of severalmetals, as copper, iron, lead, nickel, etc.
A wheel-like joint of the stem of a fossil crinoid.
An instrument for exhibiting the repulsive action produced bylight or heat in an exhausted vessel; a modification of theradoimeter. W. Crookes.
Having all the flowers of a plant alike in respect to thestamens and pistils.
The division of mankind which embraces the smooth-haired races.
A sea view; -- distinguished from landscape. [Jocose] Fairholt.
To consider by a separate act of attention or analysis. Sir W.Hamilton.
The doctrine that the universe, taken or conceived of as awhole, is God; the doctrine that there is no God but the combinedforce and laws which are manifested in the existing universe;cosmotheism.
People of rank and fashion; the class of swells, collectively.[Jocose]
A variety of enstatite, often having a bronzelike luster. It isa silicate of magnesia and iron, of the pyroxene family.
To exceed in duration; to survive; to endure longer than.Milton.
One who skulks, or keeps out of sight; hence, a truant; anidler; a thief, etc. [Obs.] Shak.
A Turkish official; one of the dominant tribe of Turks;loosely, any Turk.
The title of an incarnation of self-abnegation, virtue, andwisdom, or a deified religious teacher of the Buddhists, esp. GautamaSiddartha or Sakya Sinha (or Muni), the founder of Buddhism.
The adaptation or adjustment of parts to each other, as of abroken bone or dislocated joint.
Of or pertaining to the setting sun; falling; descending;western.
A flowing; also, a hostile incursion. [Obs.] Sir M. Hale.
A little Greek, or one of small esteem or pretensions. B.Jonson.
Unarmed; destitute of prickles or thorns, as a leaf. Gray.
An enlargement or protrusion of the mucous membrane of thelachrymal passages, or dropsy of the lachrymal sac, dependent uponcatarrhal inflammation of the latter. Dunglison.
A small tube, usually curved, applied to a trumpet, horn, etc.,to change its pitch or key.
To give by will; -- used of real estate; formerly, also, ofchattels.
A short, upright piece of timber in framing; a short post; anintermediate stud. Oxf. Gloss.
A viverrine mammal of Madagascar (Eupleres Goudotii), allied tothe civet; -- called also Falanouc.
To wander in a wrong path; to stray; to go astray. [Obs.]Chaucer.
The arrangement of a body of troops, as in a square, column,etc. Farrow.

The quality or state of being seedy, shabby, or worn out; astate of wretchedness or exhaustion. [Colloq.] G. Eliot.What is called seedness, after a debauch, is a plain proof thatnature has been outraged. J. S. Blackie.
An alkaloid obtained from the leaves of an Australian tree(Duboisia myoporoides), and regarded as identical with hyoscyamine.It produces dilation of the pupil of the eye.
One who, or that which, heartens, animates, or stirs up. W.Browne.
The transmission of a disease from one person to another, bydirect or indirect contact.
The navigable part of a river, bay, etc., through which vesselsenter or depart; the part of a harbor or channel ehich is kept openand unobstructed for the passage of vessels. Totten. the rough.
One of the French Protestant insurgents who rebelled againstLouis XIV, after the revocation of the edict of Nates; -- so calledfrom the peasant's smock (camise) which they wore.
A nitrogenous organic base from coal tar, and identical withquinoline. Cf. Quinoline.
To render insecure; to put in danger. [Obs.] Fanshawe.
The state of being a boy; the time during which one is a boy.Hood.
To induce hypnotism in; to place in a state of hypnotism.
Giving a name; naming; designating; -- said of that case orform of a noun which stands as the subject of a finite verb.-- n.
One who is rigorous; -- sometimes applied to an extremeJansenist.
To ween amiss; to misjudge; to distrust; to be mistaken. [Obs.]Spenser.
Inserted below the pistil or pistils; -- said of sepals,petals, and stamens; having the sepals, petals, and stamens insertedbelow the pistil; -- said of a flower or a plant. Gray.
An itinerant licensed dealer in commodities used for food; ahawker; a huckster; -- formerly applied especially to one who boughtgrain in one place and sold it in another. [Now dialectic, Eng.]
Fixed position; stable condition; firmness. [Obs.] Shak.

A formal allegation or charge against a party made or presentedto the appropriate court or officer, as for a wrong done or a crimecommitted (in the latter case, generally under oath); an information;accusation; the initial bill in proceedings in equity.
A strong or sweet scent. [Obs. & Illegitimate.] Sir T. Herbert.
Inferior ore, separated from the better by cobbing. Raymond.
To go into or reside in the country; to ruralize. Pope.
To card coarsely; to run through the scribling machine.
A genus of plant-eating beetles, including the potato beetle.See Potato beetle.
One of the radial segments composing the body of one of theCoelenterata.
The substance which, added to the material of a cell wall,makes it waterproof, as in cork.
The act of eloping; secret departure; -- said of a woman and aman, one or both, who run away from their homes for marriage or forcohabitation.
That with which one dabs; hence, a pad or other device used byprinters, engravers, etc., as for dabbing type or engraved plateswith ink.
Anything alleged in pleading which is impertinent, and isreproachful to any person, or which derogates from the dignity of thecourt, or is contrary to good manners. Daniell.
Something to preserve memory; a reminder; a monument; hence, amark; an image; a superscription; a record. [Obs.] Spenser.
An instrument for examining the capillary vessels of animalsand plants. Morin.
A house appropriated for the use of the poor; a poorhouse.
The celebration of the hundredth anniversary of any event; acentenary. [U. S.]
Any bird that frequents the water, or lives about rivers,lakes, etc., or on or near the sea; an aquatic fowl; -- used alsocollectively.
A scallion; a leek or small onion. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
Wattles, or hurdles, made with stakes interwoven with osiers,to cover lodgments. [Obs.]
Grass and sprigs beaten or trampled down by a stag passingthrough them. Crabb.
