A carnivore (Viverricula Mallaccensis) allied to the civet butsmaller, native of China and the East Indies. It furnishes a perfumeresembling that of the civet, which is highly prized by the Javanese.Called also Malacca weasel, and lesser civet.
One who emigrates, or quits one country or region to settle inanother.
A hood-shaped bandage for the head, the shoulder, or the stumpof an amputated limb.
The demand, by the consuls or tribunes, of a law to be passedby the people; a proposed law or decree.
The quality or state of being porous; -- opposed to density.
The peculiar free swimming larva of Balanoglossus. See Illust.in Append.
Of or pertaining to Servia, a kingdom of Southern Europe.-- n.
The nickname of a crackbrained Italian who fancied himself anemperor. [Obs.] Shak.
Implying an admission; tending to admit. [R.] Lamb.
One of the higher hydrocarbons, C10H20, of the ethylene series.
A binary compound of carbon with some other element or radical,in which the carbon plays the part of a negative; -- formerly termedcarburet.
To exceed in measure or extent; to measure more than. Sir T.Browne.
To make or place an arch over; to hang over like an arch."Brown with o'erarching shades." Pope.
A rubber of hard wood used in smoothing marble to be polished.Knight.
Equality; -- sometimes written ovelty and ovealty. Burrill.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained by theoxidation of convolvulin (obtained from jalap, the tubers of Ipomoeapurga), and identical in most of its properties with sebacic acid.
Of the delicate purplish pink color likened to that of peachblooms; -- applied esp. to a Chinese porcelain, small specimens ofwhich bring great prices in the Western countries.
A cutaneous disease occurring under two distinct forms.
A Mexican prickly poppy (Argemone platyceras), which hasmigrated into California.
The state of being a pauper; the state of indigent personsrequiring support from the community. Whatly.
Possession of lands or tenements in, or conveyance to, deadhands, or hands that cannot alienate.
A piece of wood or sheet metal fitted into a ditch to dam upthe water so as to overflow a field. [U. S.]
A mouse (Arvicala agrestis), called also meadow mouse, whichoften does great damage in fields and gardens, by feeding on rootsand seeds.

A division of annelids including those which construct, andhabitually live in, tubes. The head or anterior segments usually beargills and cirri. Called also Sedentaria, and Capitibranchiata. SeeSerpula, and Sabella.
Of or pertaining to the kitchen, or the servants' quarters;hence, subordinate; menial. [Obs.]
One of the small bones in the tympanum of the ear; the anvilbone. See Ear.
A daughter of Cadmus, and by Zeus mother of Bacchus.
An African genus of ganoid fishes including the bichir.
A genus of corals with meandering grooves and ridges, includingthe brain corals.
Being the last one of a million of units or objects counted inregular order from the first of a series or succession; being one ofa million.
The natural abode, locality or region of an animal or plant.
To make an ambitious display of; to show or exhibit boastingly.[R.] Jer. Taylor.
Confusing; having a tendency to confusion.  Bp. Hall.
That which saponifies; any reagent used to causesaponification.
The doctrine of mutual dependence as the condition ofindividual and social welfare. F. Harrison. H. Spencer. Mallock.
Producing or bearing a great number; bringing forth many.
Matter in pleading which is not necessary or relevant to thecase, and which may be rejected.
To sley, or prepare for use in the weaver's sley, or slaie.Shak.
A short narrative or tale, esp. one dealing with surprising ormarvelous events.
The act, process, or result of saturating a substance, or ofcombining it to its fullest extent.
Before that time; beforehand. [Obs.]Many a winter therebiforn. Chaucer.
A Japanese musical instrument with three strings, resembling aguitar or banjo.
Those fortuitous effects produced by luminous rays falling oncertain objects so that some parts stand forth in abnormal brightnessand other parts are cast into a deep shadow.
One who makes or writes comments; a commentator; an annotator.
The goddess of beauty and love, that is, beauty or lovedeified.
Strict adherence to the forms or principles of some churchorganization; sectarianism.
Violation of chastity by force; rape. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
One of the movable peduncles which, in the decapod Crustacea,bear the eyes at the tip.
A colorless stone of high luster, made of paste. It is muchused as an inexpensive ornament.
A stiff compact pasteboard of various qualities, for makingcards, etc., often having a polished surface.
A fine smooth-faced woolen cloth for men's garments, usually ofdouble width (i.e., a yard and a half); -- so called in distinctionfrom woolens three quarters of a yard wide.
A place for raising oranges; a plantation of orange trees.
Relating to Draco, the Athenian lawgiver; or to theconstellation Draco; or to dragon's blood.
A coarse, composite weed, having a rough or prickly fruit; oneof several species of the genus Xanthium; -- called also clotbur.
Feudal tenure; the feudal system. See Feudality. Burke.
A province or territorial division of a kingdom, under the ruleof a nomarch, as in modern Greece; a nome.
The sixth day of the week, following Thursday and precedingSaturday.
The doctrine of papal supremacy; extreme views in support ofthe authority of the pope; ultramontanism; -- a term used only bypersons who are not Roman Catholics.

A custom, formerly practiced by the scholars at Eton school,England, of giing every third year, on Whittuesday, to a hillock nearthe Bath road, and exacting money from all passers-by, to support atthe university the senior scholar of the school.

An appendage to the shield, placed above it, and supporting thecrest (see Illust. of Crest). It generally represents a twist of twocords of silk, one tinctured like the principal metal, the other likethe principal color in the arms.
A Mohammedan rosary, consisting of ninety-nine beads. Byron.
A secretary or notary under the Roman empire; also, a similarofficer in France during the old monarchy.
Abstruseness; that which is abstruse. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
To shoot forth, as rays of light; to beam; to radiate. Dr. H.More.
Too frequent use of the letter m, or of the sound representedby it.
The terminal part of the oviduct in insects and various otherinvertebrates. See Illust., of Spermatheca.
To steal or purloin from the writings of another; toappropriate without due acknowledgement (the ideas or expressions ofanother).
A nitro derivative of methane, analogous to chloroform,obtained as a colorless oily or crystalline substance, CH.(NO2)3,quite explosive, and having well-defined acid properties.
A tool used by turners in metal, having a bend forming a heelnear the cutting end.
One of many textile fabrics having a pile like that of velvet.
A messenger or officer who serves the process of anecclesiastical court. Bouvier.
To prophesy; to foretell; to practice prediction; to utterprophecies.
A person in disguise; a masker; a mummer. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
A Venetian coin, worth about three English farthings, or oneand a half cents. [Obs.]
A compound radical, C6H13, regarded as the essential residue ofhexane, and a related series of compounds.
The morbid condition produced by the excessive use of tobacco.
A genus of fishes, remarkable for their power of living longout of water, and of making their way on land for considerabledistances, and for climbing trees; the climbing fishes.
An electro-negative element, or the element which, in electro-chemical decompositions, is evolved at the anode; -- opposed tocation. Faraday.
The quality or state of being simple; simplicity. Shak.
A double iambus; a foot consisting of two iambuses (
A species of civet (Viverra fossa) resembling the genet.
The wryneck; -- so called from its note. [Prov. Eng.]

The faculty of seeing; sight; one of the five senses, by whichcolors and the physical qualities of external objects are appreciatedas a result of the stimulating action of light on the sensitiveretina, an expansion of the optic nerve.
One who dwells in the same house with another. R. Browning.
Having small pits or depression, as the receptacle in somecomposite flowers.
A toll duty formerly exacted of merchant strangers by mayors,sheriffs, etc., for goods shown or offered for sale within theirprecincts. Cowell.
A beverage consisting of lemon juice mixed with water andsweetened.
A portion of land nearly surrounded by water, and connectedwith a larger body by a neck, or isthmus.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid of the formic acidseries, found in the tar, wax, or paraffine obtained by distillingcertain kinds of wood, as the beech.
The number three; three things together; a ternary. Bp. Hall.
A cord; specifically, the umbilical cord or navel string.
A sweetheart, of either sex; a gallant, or a mistress; --usually in a bad sense. [Archaic] Chaucer. Spenser. Shak.
The office, disposition, or act of a pedant; pedantry. [Obs.]
Growing upon flowers; -- said of certain species of fungi.
To fasten or bind, as with a knot; to knot together. Fuller.
In the greater part of Russia, a division for local governmentconsisting of a group of mirs, or village communities; a canton.
A permitted choice; a rhetorical figure in which a thing iscommitted to the decision of one's opponent. [Obs.] Milton.
A solemn or formal observance; proceeding according to dueform; the formality which is necessary to render a thing done valid.
Shifting the sword from one side of an adversary's sword to theother.
the material of which wicks are made; esp., a loosely braidedor twisted cord or tape of cotton.
Having elevations or depressions in form like one half of abivalve shell; -- applied principally to a surface produced byfracture.
Belonging to the Gephyrea.-- n. One of the Gerphyrea.
Pertaining to, or having the nature of, insects. Bacon.
The true, or six-legged, insects; insects other than myriapodsand arachnids.
The mineral or earthy substance associated with metallic ore.
A mania for, or an inordinate attachment to, foreign customs,institutions, manners, fashions, etc. [R.] Saintsbury.
Furnished with, or having the form of, a steeple; adorned withsteeples. Fairfax.
A large rope to fasten the midship part of a ship to a wharf,or to another vessel.
A kind of mantilla worn by women over the head and shoulders,and sometimes over part of the face. [Mexico & Sp. Amer.]
A group of suctorial Infusoria, which in the adult stage arestationary. See Suctoria.
A yellow crystalline substance produced artificially. It isisomeric with alizarin.
Consisting of hail; abounding in hail. [R.] Bailey.
To clear of outlawry or attainder; to place under theprotection of the law. Burrill.
A genus of marine fishes, including the wrasses of Europe. SeeWrasse.
Any one of a group of thick oily hydrocarbons, C12H26, of theparaffin series.
Agreement of words with one another, in gender, number, person,or case.
One who obtrudes himself on another for bed and board. [Scot.]De Quncey.
A grooved director for a probe or knife.(c) (Printing) A strip or device to direct the compositor's eye tothe line of copy he is setting.
Ability; aptitude. [Obs.] Robynson. (More's Utopia).
A simple gland, glandular cavity, or tube; a follicle; as, thecryps of Lieberk.
A blending of one color into another; the spreading of onecolor over another, as on the feathers of birds.
A bituminous mineral resembling asphaltum, found in the countyof A.
To make stony or calcareous by the deposit or secretion ofsalts of lime.
A rope or chain to confine the bowsprit of a ship downward tothe stem or cutwater; -- usually in the pl.
A rare metallic element found in platinum ore. It is a whitemalleable substance. Symbol Da. Atomic weight 154.
A pretty or dear little bird; -- a pet name. Tennyson.
A light, with a powerful reflector, placed at the head of alocomotive, or in front of it, to throw light on the track at night,or in going through a dark tunnel.
The acid amide derivative of valeric acid, obtained as a whitecrystalline substance.
The state of being a father; the character or authority of afather; paternity.
A name given to several resinous-glandular composite plants ofCalifornia, esp. to the species of Grindelia, Hemizonia, and Madia.
An arsenide of platinum occuring in grains and minute isometriccrystals of tin-white color. It is found near Sudbury, OntarioCanada, and is the only known compound of platinum occuring innature.
A picture produced by a process in which development afterexposure may be deferred indefinitely, so as to permit transportationof exposed plates; also, the process itself.
An American sole (Achirus lineatus, or A. achirus), related tothe European sole, but of no market value.
A silver coin of several countries of Europe, and of differentvalues.
Not erratic or wandering; fixed; settled; established.
To carry improperly; to carry (one's self) wrongly; tomisbehave. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who is skilled; a master of his business; a proficient; anadept. [Colloq.]
An extinct marine reptile from the coal measures of NovaScotia; -- so named because supposed to be of the earliest knownreptiles.
A rover in quest of booty or plunder; a plunderer; one whopillages. De Quincey.
To excite; to irritate; especially, to excite the activity of(a nerve or an irritable muscle), as by electricity.
Having the form of a funnel, or tunnel; that is, expandinggradually from the bottom upward, as the corolla of some flowers;infundibuliform.
Boiled or stewed meat; beef boiled with vegetables in waterfrom which its gravy is to be made; beef from which bouillon or souphas been made.
The buds or branches produced from underground stems.
An oval or pearshaped diamond having its entire surface cut intriangular facets.
The blade of a leaf; the broad, expanded portion of a petal orsepal of a flower. Gray.
An animal of the seal tribe, moving by short feet that serve aspaddles.
Relating to homodermy; originating from the same germ layer.
A variety of sugar, found in certain plants. It is opticallyinactive.
A hook fastened to pole, by which shepherds lay hold on thelegs or necks of their sheep; a shepherd's crook. Dryden.
One who administered the Eucharist with unleavened bread; -- aname of reproach given by those of the Greek church to the Latins.
The track or tread a horseman makes upon the ground he goesover. Johnson.
The principles and rules of the art of poetry. J. Warton.
The cowslip (Primula veris); -- so called from its supposedremedial powers. Dr. Prior.
One of an important religious sect in India which regards Sivawith peculiar veneration.
A division of annelids including the common earthworms andallied species.
Containing the combustible principle of coal. Kirwan.
A genus of plants related to the banana, found at the Cape ofGood Hope. They have rigid glaucous distichous leaves, and peculiarrichly colored flowers.
A person in whose favor a power of appointment is executed.Kent. Wharton.
A brief written acknowledgment of a debt, not made payable toorder, like a promissory note. Burrill.
A tract of land or a territory inclosed within anotherterritory of which it is independent. See Exclave. [Recent]
The state or quality of being null and void; invalidity;forfeiture. Burrill.
To jolt; to shake, especially by rough riding or by drivingover obstructions.
Something taught; precepts; schooling. [Obs.] penser.
A short rope grafted on a harpoon, to which a longer linTotten.
To be intewoven or entwined; to twine together; as, a bower ofwreathing trees. Dryden.
One whose occupation is to tan hides, or convert them intoleather by the use of tan.
Of or pertaining to Pegasus, or, figuratively, to poetry.
A robber; a pirate; hence, loosely, a rogue or rascal.
Quiet; peaceable; harmless; innocent. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
One who, or that which, roots; one that tears up by the roots.
A student of biology; one versed in the science of biology.
A massive mineral, greenish in color, and opal-like inappearance. It is essentially a hydrous silicate of iron.

A West African anthropoid ape allied to the gorilla andchimpanzee, and by some considered only a variety of the chimpanzee.It is noted for building large, umbrella-shaped nests in trees.Called also tscheigo, tschiego, nschego, nscheigo.
A division of Arachnida, including the whip scorpions(Thelyphonus) and allied forms. Sometimes used in a wider sense toinclude also the true scorpions.
A beast that has died of disease or by mischance. [Obs.] Bp.Hall.
The glowing effect which arises from the use of warm colors;hence, any similar appearance or effect in a painting, or work ofcolor.
The fragrant gum resin of various species of Boswellia;Oriental frankincense.
The material of the outside or front side, as of a wall orbuilding; facing.
The crested curassow; -- called also royal pheasant. SeeCurassow.
Of or pertaining to the Osci, a primitive people of Campania, aprovince of ancient Italy.-- n.
The theory or practice of Marconi's wireless telegraph system.
That which prevents, hinders, or obstructs; that whichintercepts access; in medicine, something to prevent disease; aprophylactic.
Having three ribs or nerves extending unbranched from the baseto the apex; -- said of a leaf. Gray.
Of or pertaining to Trent, or the general church council heldin that city.
A register or roll showing the order in which officers,enlisted men, companies, or regiments are called on to serve.
A sudden, violent check of a horse by drawing or twitching thereins on a sudden and with one pull.
.The act of drawing or laying over, as a covering. [Obs.]
A bracket to support a balcony, a cornice, or the like.
Having no granules, as chlorophyll in certain conditions. R.Brown.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, copper; containing copper;-- said of those compounds of copper in which this element is presentin its highest proportion.
To call together; to summon to meet; to assemble by summons.There remained no resource but the dreadful one of convoking aparliament. palfrey.
A red clay from the Upper Missouri region, used by the Indiansfor their pipes.
Butyl; -- so called from the four carbon atoms in the molecule.
The mother and ruler of a family or of her descendants; a rulerby maternal right.
A curved plank, placed edgewise, to work in the bows of avessel. R. H. Dana, Jr.
To drive from a house or habitation; to dislodge; hence, todeprive of shelter.
A framework moving on casters, designed to support childrenwhile learning to walk.
A small bar, rod, bundle of fibers, or septal membrane, in theframework of an organ part.
To produce inanition in; to exhaust for want of nourishment.[R.]
Description or definition by denial, exclusion, or exception;statement of what a thing is not, or has not, from which may beinferred what it is or has.
A lage molding used in the bases of columns. Its profile issemicircular. See Illust. of Molding. Brande&C.
The common qua(Colinus, or Ortyx, Virginianus); -- so calledfrom its note.
A round gall produced on the leaves and shoots of variousspecies of the oak tree. See Gall, and Nutgall.
To prevent or hinder oxidation, rust, or decay; as, inoxidizingoils or varnishes.
To designate with an obelus; to mark as doubtful or spirituous.[R.]
A basin, or bowl, to hold water for washing one's hands, face,etc.
One who favors the practice of fallowing land. [R.] Sinclair.
Exercise of authority; control; government; arrangement.Chaucer. J. H. Newman.
The flanged outer end of a drawbar; also, a name applied to thedrawgear.
Pertaining to, or designating, certain compounds of oxygen andbromine.
A boast or boasting; a vaunt; a bravado; a bragging;braggodocio. Swift.
Of or pertaining to the machinery of a poem; acting or used asa machine.[Obs.] Dryden.
Not tamed; untamed; savage; wild. [Obs.] J. Salkeld.
Things belonging to the sheriff; especially, farms (called alsovicontiel rents) for which the sheriff used to pay rent to the king.
A small vessel of iron, copper, or other metal, with a handle,used for culinary purpose, as for stewing meat.
A gold coin of Zealand [Netherlands] equal to 14 florins, about$ 5.60.
A hybrid whose parents differ by three pairs of contrastingMendelian characters.
The second, or true, muscular stomach of birds, in which thefood is crushed and ground, after being softened in the glandularstomach (crop), or lower part of the esophagus; the gigerium.
A work raised in the middle of a wide ditch, to defend it.Crabb.
A short sleep taken about the middle of the day, or afterdinner; a midday nap.
A colorless, mobile, and very volatile liquid obtained fromalcohol by certain of oxidation.
Sung or addressed to one departing; valedictory; as, apoplecticsongs or hymns.
A small piece or silver of skin which hangs loose, near theroot of finger nail. Holloway.
A genus of parrots with gray heads. of New Zeland and papua,allied to the cockatoos. See Kaka.
A trible of North American Indians (Southern Appalachian)allied to the Choctaws. They formerly occupied the northern part ofAlabama and Mississippi, but now live in the Indian Territory.
Hard rubber produced by vulcanizing with a large proportion ofsulphur.
To germinate; to bud; to multiply abundantly. Warburton.

To use the hands in dexterous operations; to do hand work;specifically, to manage the apparatus or instruments used inscientific work, or in artistic or mechanical processes; also,specifically, to use the hand in mesmeric operations.
A passage for wind or air; a passage or pipe for ventilatingapartments. Gwilt.
The morbid phenomena produced by dwelling among marshes;malarial disease or disposition.
The postero-lateral ossification in the sternum of birds; also,the part resulting from such ossification.
One who tramps; a stroller; a vagrant or vagabond; a tramp.Dickens.
A sunken compartment with raised margins, molded or otherwise,as in ceilings, wainscotings, etc.
A name given to several species of crowfoot (Ranunculus) whichhave spear-shaped leaves.
An order of fishes, formerly proposed by Agassiz, for thosewith thin, smooth scales, destitute of marginal spines, as theherring and salmon. The group is now regarded as artificial.
To enslave; to bind; to restrict. [Obs.] Sir M. Hale.
Making undue claims and pretension; prone to arrogance. [R.]Dr. H. More.
To remove from a class; to separate or degrade from one'sclass.  North Am. Rev.
Having six columns in front; -- said of a portico or temple.-- n.
The horizontal line which measures the distance to which aprojectile is thrown; the range.
One of a series of flat, fringed, and usually bilobed,appendages, of which several pairs occur on the abdominal somites ofmany crustaceans. They are used as fins in swimming.

An instrument formed by combining prisms so as to correct thechromatic aberration of the light while linear dimensions of objectsseen through the prisms are increased or diminished; -- called alsoprism telescope. Sir D. Brewster.
To drive on rashly; to go to excess; hence, to exaggerate; toboast. [Obs.] Barrow.
The intersection of two surface forming a salient angle,especially the angle at the top between the opposite slopes or sidesof a roof or a vault.
Liquefying by heat after having been frozen; thawing; melting.
A genus of extinct Tertiary Foraminifera, having a thin, flat,round shell, containing a large number of small chambers arrangedspirally.
A flattened concretionary nodule, usually of limestone,intersected within by cracks which are often filled with calcite,barite, or other minerals.
A piece of furniture having a number of uninclosed shelves orstages, one above another, for receiving articles of elegance or use.Fairholt.
The true meaning, understanding, or intention of a law, or ofany legal instrument.
One of the larger measures of electrical resistance, amountingto one million ohms.
A surplice, in England and America usually one shorter and lessfull than the ordinary surplice and with short sleeves, or sometimesnone.
A foot consisting of four syllables, of which the first andlast are long, and the other short (- ~ ~ -); that is, a choreus, ortrochee, and an iambus united.
A division of swimming birds including those that havetotipalmate feet.
Stirring; in a state of activity or motion; out of bed.
The contact of one curve with another, when the number ofconsecutive points of the latter through which the former passessuffices for the complete determination of the former curve. Brande &C.
Affecting a whole people or a number of countries; everywhereepidemic.-- n.
One of the royalist insurgents in western France (Brittany,etc.), during and after the French revolution.
Vigorous; energetic; with energy; -- a direction to perform apassage with energy and force.
A kind of canoe used in Central and South America; also, a kindof boat used in the Southern United States. Bartlett.
A word coined by Lewis Carroll (Charles L. Dodgson), andusually explained as a combination of chuckle and snort. [Humorous]
One who assesses, or sets a value on, anything; an appraiser.Swift.
A local tax paid by a ship for the ground or space it occupieswhile in port. Bouvier.
Causing dilation; tending to dilate, on enlarge; expansive.Coleridge.
The quality or state of being rancid; a rancid scent or flavor,as of old oil. Ure.
The act of disheriting, or debarring from inheritance;disinhersion. Bp. Hall.
Covered with gyrons, or divided so as to form several gyrons; -- said of an escutcheon.
Any plant of the genus Pilularia; minute aquatic cryptograms,with small pill-shaped fruit; -- sometimes called peppergrass.
A circular hole formed in the rocky beds of rivers by thegrinding action of stones or gravel whirled round by the water inwhat was at first a natural depression of the rock.
A variety of steatite sometimes manufactured into culinaryvessels.
Work performed, or results obtained, by guess; conjecture.
A line connecting places on the earth having the same meanwinter temperature. Cf. Isothere.
A West African antelope (Damalis Senegalensis), allied to thesassaby. It is reddish gray, with a black face, and a black stripe onthe outside of the legs above the knees.
To make resemble. [Obs.]If I was a philosopher, says Montaigne, I would naturalize artinstead of artilizing nature. Bolingbroke.
A musician who plays on the harp or lyre; a composer of lyricalpoetry. Shelley.
Rubbish; refuse; dirt. [Obs.]All this mullok [was] in a sieve ythrowe. Chaucer.
That part of the eye of an invertebrate which corresponds infunction with the retina of a vertebrate.

Divination by the assistance, or supposed assistance, of evilspirits, or the power of commanding evil spirits; magic; necromancy;witchcraft; enchantment.Adder's wisdom I have learned, To fence my ear against thy sorceries.Milton.
A short, light musket or rifle, esp. one used by mountedsoldiers or cavalry.
An apparatus for condensing vegetable juices, or for dryingfruit by heat.
An imagined space having more than three dimensions.
A cement or paste (as of plaster and freestone, or of sawdustand glue or lime) used by sculptors, builders, and workers in wood orstone, to fill holes, cover defects, or finish a surface.
A talmudic exposition of the Hebrew law, or of some part of it.
A genus of plants of the order Filices or ferns. Thefructifications are in uncovered roundish points, called sori,scattered over the inferior surface of the frond or leaf. There arenumerous species.
A Russian measure of length equal to about seven English feet.
A capping or crowning molding in classic architecture.
The maiming of a person by depriving him of the use of any ofhis members which are necessary for defense or protection. See Maim.
Hollow and distended, as a perianth, corolla, nectary, orpericarp. Martyn.

Originally, in classical architecture, the triangular spaceforming the gable of a simple roof; hence, a similar form used as adecoration over porticoes, doors, windows, etc.; also, a rounded orbroken frontal having a similar position and use. See Temple.
To meet a wager on, as on the taking of a trick, with a higherwager. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A hard, compact variety of serpentine found in Rhode Island. Itis of a light green color and resembles jade.
A metallic handle with a clasp for holding a crayon.
A member of a reserve force of soldiers or militia. [Eng.]
Divisible by six; having six beats; as, sixtuple measure.
A loin of beef, or the upper part of the loin. See Sirloin, themore usual, but not etymologically preferable, orthography.
A earthworm of the genus Lumbricus, frequently used by anglersfor bait. See Earthworm.
A reddish brown or violet crystalline substance, C16H12O6, gotfrom hematoxylin by partial oxidation, and regarded as analogous tothe phthaleins.
To exceed in generalship; to gain advantage over by superiormilitary skill or executive ability; to outmaneuver. Chesterfield.
A genus of cruciferous plants (Alyssum) with white or yellowflowers and rounded pods. A. maritimum is the commonly cultivatedsweet alyssum, a fragrant white-flowered annual.
Caontaining cant or affectation; whining; singing. [R.]

Sweeping; grazing; -- applied to a style of fortification inwhich the command of the works over each other, and over the country,is kept very low, in order that the shot may more effectually sweepor graze the ground before them. H. L. Scott.
A callous tumor on the leg of a horse, below the hock.
A small yellow singing bird, with an ash-colored head; theEuropean siskin. Called also tarin.
The person to whom money is to be, or has been, paid; theperson named in a bill or note, to whom, or to whose order, theamount is promised or directed to be paid. See Bill of exchange,under Bill.
Belief in the coming of the Mahdi; fanatical devotion to thecause of the Mahdi or a pretender to that title. -- Mah"dist (#), n.
A thing of brass; -- the name under which the Israelitesworshiped the brazen serpent made by Moses. 2 Kings xviii. 4.
To spread or scatter. See Strew, and Strow. Chaucer.
The vicegerent of a prior; a claustral officer who assists theprior.
The diagnosis of diseases by inspection of urine. Sir T.Browne.
The stone at the foot of a grave; -- opposed to headstone.
Whispering; rustling; full of whispering sounds. [R.]
The quality or state of being sleek; smoothness and glossinessof surface.
Having the nature of chitin; consisting of, or containing,chitin.
A pungent kind of snuff made from the darker and ranker kindsof tobacco leaves.
The good principle, or being, of the ancient Persian religion.See Ahriman.
A piece of thick plank, armed with iron plates, and fixed onthe bow or fore channels of a vessel, for the bill or fluke of theanchor to rest on. Totten.
The science which treats of the general properties of matter;somatology.
Subterranean; -- applied to sources supplying wells.

In military language, a strict disciplinarian; in general, onewho lays stress on a rigid adherence to the details of discipline, orto forms and fixed methods. [Hence, the word is commonly employed ina depreciatory sense.]
Courtship; gallantry; love; an object of love. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who believes that life can be produced independently ofantecedent. Huxley.
Of the nature or color of verdigris, or the rust of copper.
A kind of rack, shaped like a double St. Andrew's cross, onwhich sticks of wood are laid for sawing by hand; -- called alsobuck, and sawbuck.
Having little crossings or openings like the sashes of awindow. [R.] Donne.
In mining, a rich mine or vein of silver or gold; hence,anything which is a mine of wealth or yields a large income. [Colloq.U. S.]
Fine clay or ocher made up into balls, used for marking sheep.[Eng.] Woodsward.
Of or pertaining to metamorphosis; pertaining to, or involving,change.
Applied to a line or verse in which each successive word hasone more syllable than the preceding.
Any structure or contrivance, as a mole, or a wall at the mouthof a harbor, to break the force of waves, and afford protection fromtheir violence.
A mischance causing a person's death without felony, as bydrowning, or falling into the fire.
The variation or change which words undergo to mark case,gender, number, comparison, tense, person, mood, voice, etc.
The arrangement or distribution of nerves, as in the leaves ofa plant or the wings of an insect; nervation.
Any fossil coral of the genus Syringopora consisting of acluster of upright tubes united together by small transverse tubules.
Embodied in, or changed into, water. [Obs.] Cranmer.
The condition or quality of being broad; breadth; coarseness;grossness.
A goblin, in the shape of a large dog, portending misfortune.[Also written barguest.]
The designation of position and direction. B. G. Wilder.
A vessel of Anam, with two or three masts, lofty triangularsails, and in construction somewhat resembling a Chinese junk.
A stone in a building, left rough and projecting, to beafterward carved into shape. Gwilt.
A bird (Crex crex or C. pratensis) which frequents grainfields; the European crake or land rail; -- called also corn bird.
A kind of long-winged hawk; -- called also bockerel, andbockeret. [Obs.]
The chief man of a tithing; a headborough; one elected topreside over the tithing.
A deity corresponding to Odin, the supreme deity of theScandinavians. Wednesday is named for him. See Odin.
One who, or that which, perturbs, or cause perturbation.
Destitute of acid properties; hence, basic; metallic; positive;-- said of certain atoms and radicals.
A veteran partisan; one who is so conservative in opinion thathe may be likened to a stone or old tree covered with moss.[Political Slang, U.S.]
A division of pectinibranchiate gastropods, having the headprolonged into a snout which is not retractile.
Having no rival; without a competitor; peerless. [Spelt alsounrivalled.] Pope.
One who wishes another well; one who is benevolently orfriendlily inclined.
A genus of delicate branching corals, made up of minute cells,belonging to the Bryozoa.
An application made to a court or judge orally in open court.Its object is to obtain an order or rule directing some act to bedone in favor of the applicant. Mozley & W.
Furnished with, or guarded by, forts; strengthened or defended,as by forts. [R.] Shak.
A genus of nut-bearing trees or shrubs including the chestnutand chinquapin.
A body identical with indigo blue, occasionally found in theurine in degeneration of the kidneys. It is readily formed byoxidation or decomposition of indican.
One employed to procure supplies, as for an army, a steamer,etc.; a purveyor; one who provides for another. Jer. Taylor.
The derivation of the name of a race, tribe, etc., from that ofa fabulous hero, progenitor, etc.
One who idolizes or loves to the point of reverence; anidolater.
A group of ungulate mammals including the hog and thehippopotamus. The term is also sometimes applied to the bears, and tocertain passerine birds.
To march too far, or too much; to exhaust by marching. Baker.
1. To repair; to prepare; to put in order. [Prov. Eng.]Carlyle.
That which is hard to hear, as toil, privation, injury,injustice, etc. Swift.
The petrified fruit of the Chara hispida, a species ofstonewort. See Stonewort. Lyell.
A genus of malvaceous plants of many species, found in thetorrid and temperate zones of both continents; -- called also Indianmallow.
A mineral, commonly of a yellowish green (pistachio) color,occurring granular, massive, columnar, and in monoclinic crystals. Itis a silicate of alumina, lime, and oxide of iron, or manganese.
An extinct genus of Brachiopoda, abundant in the Paleozoicrocks.
Writing in which letters are joined in words; -- distinguishedfrom writing in single letters. Addison.
An actuality; a conception completely actualized, indistinction from mere potential existence.

Variation in arrangement from that existing in a normal form;heterogenous arrangement or structure, as, in botany, the deviationin position of the organs of a plant, from the ordinary or typicalarrangement.
The slender recoil spring which regulates the motion of thebalance in a timepiece.
Near; near at hand; closely. [Obs. or Scot.] Bacon.
An attorney who sufficiently excuses the absence of another.
The receiving of a man's goods again from a thief, or acompensation for them, by way of composition, with the intent thatthe thief shall escape punishment.
A modified form of Buddhism which prevails in Thibet, Mongolia,and some adjacent parts of Asia; -- so called from the name of itspriests. See 2d Lama.
The area in the central part of an amphitheater, in which thegladiators fought and other shows were exhibited; -- so calledbecause it was covered with sand.
One who drinks much wine. Prov. xxiii. 20.-- Wine"bib`bing, n.
To free from clouds; to unvail; to clear from obscurity, gloom,sorrow, or the like. Beau. & Fl.
A room or rooms under a building, and usually below the surfaceof the ground, where provisions and other stores are kept.
A heart-shaped cherry with a very dark-colored skin.
The tenure by which a drench held land. [Obs.] Burrill.
A kind of divination anciently practiced by means of markedarrows drawn at random from a bag or quiver, the marks on the arrowsdrawn being supposed to foreshow the future. Encyc. Brit.
The quality or state of being sage; wisdom; sagacity; prudence;gravity. Ascham.
Any butterfly of the genus Pieris and related genera. SeeCabbage butterfly, under Cabbage.
A weapon with a scythe-shaped blade, and a separate long sharppoint, mounted on a long staff and carried by foot soldiers.
Interest in excess of a legal rate charged to a borrower forthe use of money.
Containing, or resembling, lard; of the character orconsistency of lard.
A false or artificial voice; that voice in a man which liesabove his natural voice; the male counter tenor or alto voice. SeeHead voice, under Voice.
A liquor consisting of honey diluted in water, and afterfermentation called mead.
Charged with another bearing of the same figure, and of thecolor of the field, so large that only a narrow border of the firstbearing remains visible; -- said of any heraldic bearing. CompareVoided.
A sort of hand cannon, or portable firearm, used in France inthe 15th century.
The shape and size of a book; hence, its external form.
Grass of the genus Cenchrus, growing in sand, and having bursfor fruit.
An alkaloid found in the plant Peganum harmala. It formsbitter, yellow salts.
The science which treats of the division of mankind into races,their origin, distribution, and relations, and the peculiaritieswhich characterize them.
To undo, as something sewn, or something inclosed by sewing; torip apart; to take out the stitches of.
The science which treats of the viscera of the body.
A picture, or combination of pictures, consisting of acenterpiece and double folding doors or wings, as for an altarpiece.
India silk brocaded with flowers in silver or gold.-- a.
A small triangular flag, esp. one attached to a knight's lance;a pennon.
A herdsman; a ranchman; one owning, or having charge of, herdsof live stock. [Australia & U.S.] W. Howitt.
Of or pertaining to the dioptre, or to the metric system ofnumbering glasses.-- n.
A neck guard of chain mall, hanging from the bascinet or otherheadpiece.
To cleanse; to purge away, as foul or offending matter from thebody, or from an ulcer.
A prefix of one or two unaccented syllables to a verse properlybeginning with an accented syllable.
To employ or place so as to make alliteration. Skeat.
The act or posture of reclining on a couch, as practiced by theancients at meals.

One who serves a cause or a party for a share of the spoils; inUnited States politics, one who makes or recognizes a demand forpublic office on the ground of partisan service; also, one whosanctions such a policy in appointments to the public service.
An instrument for autographically recording the wave forms ofvarying currents, esp. rapidly varying alternating currents.
Servants of the priests and Levites in the menial servicesabout the tabernacle and temple.
The termination of a right or privilege through neglect toexercise it within the limited time, or through failure of somecontingency; hence, the devolution of a right or privilege.
A spore borne at the extremity of the cells of fructificationin fungi.
A collection of words; a vocabulary; a dictionary; a lexicon.
To overwhelm by argument; to refute conclusively; to prove orshow to be false or defective; to overcome; to silence.
A dish of veal, chickens, or other white meat, freed frombones, tied up, boiled, and served cold. Smart.
Boring, or hollowing out, rocks; -- said of certain molluskswhich live in holes which they burrow in rocks. See Illust. ofLithodomus.
Butane, each molecule of which has four carbon atoms.
The quality or state of being toxic or poisonous;poisonousness.
The curve whose ordinates are proportional to the sines of theabscissas, the equation of the curve being y = a sin x. It is alsocalled the curve of sines.

A writ or process, granted by a court of equity, and, insomecases, under statutes, by a court of law,whereby a party is requiredto do or to refrain from doing certain acts, according to theexigency of the writ.
A partner; a confederate; an accomplice. [Obs.] hak.
A part of a rock or stratum lying without, or beyond, the mainbody, from which it has been separated by denudation.
A small sail immediately above the topgallant sail. Totten.
One of certain narrow, crooked valleys seen, by aid of thetelescope, on the surface of the moon.
A sack or bag of wool; specifically, the seat of the lordchancellor of England in the House of Lords, being a large, squaresack of wool resembling a divan in form.
Work wrought by blacksmiths; -- so called in distinction fromthat wrought by whitesmiths. Knight.
The orange-colored pulp covering the seeds of the tropicalplant Bixa Orellana, from which annotto is prepared. See Annoto.
Pertaining to derived from, or designating, an acid, H2B4O7(called also tetraboric acid), which is the acid ingredient ofordinary borax, and is obtained by heating boric acid.
Happening at, or belonging to, the same time; synchronous;simultaneous. Dr. H. More.
The title by which the shogun, or former commander in chief ofthe Japanese army, was known to foreigners.
Pertaining to the gyroscope; resembling the motion of thegyroscope.
The curve formed by a rope or chain of uniform density andperfect flexibility, hanging freely between two points of suspension,not in the same vertical line.
Incapable of being divided by cutting; indivisible.
A table of syllables; more especially, a table of theindivisible syllabic symbols used in certain languages, as theJapanese and Cherokee, instead of letters. S. W. Williams.
A disease in sheep, indicated by shaking, trembling, orconvulsive motions.
A felling by a knock, as of a combatant, or of an animal.
A subordinate word that is never inflected (a preposition,conjunction, interjection); or a word that can not be used except incompositions; as, ward in backward, ly in lovely.
An apparatus employed to indicate the presence, or the amount,of ozone.
The act of setting aside, or of giving up. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.
In root construction, a horizontal member supported on theprincipals and supporting the common rafters.
A tribe of Indians that formerly occupied the country betweenthe Wabash and Maumee rivers.
One who deals in drugs; especially, one who buys and sellsdrugs without compounding them; also, a pharmaceutist or apothecary.
For nothing; without fee or recompense; freely; gratuitously.
A tumor developed on, or connected with, a nerve, esp. oneconsisting of new-formed nerve fibers.
A great act or event; a great attainment. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A fetid gum resin obtained from a species of Ferula. It hasbeen used in hysteria, etc., but is now seldom met with. U. S. Disp.
A genus of flowering plants, of many species, mostly climbers,having feathery styles, which greatly enlarge in the fruit; -- calledalso virgin's bower.
A composition made from blood, mixed with mineral or vegetablesubstances, used for making buttons, door knobs, etc.
To burn. [Obs.] Chaucer.Consuming fire brent his shearing house or stall. W. Browne.
A loose and flowing outer garment, worn by the ancient Greeks;a kind of cloak.
The division of a shield palewise, or by a vertical line, esp.for the purpose of putting side by side the arms of husband and wife.See Impale, 3.
A kind of domestic spirit in German mythology, corresponding tothe Scottish brownie and the English Robin Goodfellow.
A coarse stuff, usually of cotton, originally made in India.Also, an imitation of this fabric made for export.
To form like a bowl; to give a globular shape to. [Obs.] Sir P.Sidney.
Murmuring; grumbling; -- sometimes applied to the rumblingproduced by a slight attack of the gripes. [Scot.] Burns.
The condition of a woman during marriage, because she isconsidered under the cover, influence, power, and protection of herhusband, and therefore called a feme covert, or femme couverte.
A setting free, or deliverance from the charge of an offense,by verdict of a jury or sentence of a court. Bouvier.
A point halfway between the fess point and the middle basepoint of an escutcheon; -- called also navel point. See Escutcheon.
The adducing of particular examples so as to lead to auniversal conclusion; the argument by induction.
One of a press gang, who aids in forcing men into the navalservice; also, one forced into the service.
A keyed stringed instrument, now superseded by the pianoforte.See Clarichord.
With a green color; newly; freshly, immaturely.-- a.
Capable of producing bone; having the power to change cartilageor other tissue into bone.
Resembling a puppet in appearance or action; of the nature of apuppet.
A passage into a field or yard, closed by bars made to take outof the posts.
A long, stout fishing line to which many hooks are attached.
A vitrified sand tube produced by the striking of lightning onsand; a lightning tube; also, the portion of rock surface fused by alightning discharge.
The quality or state of being showy; pompousness; great parade;ostentation.
Having a poison gland or glands for the secretion of venom, ascertain serpents and insects.
To goad, drive, hunt, throw, or pitch. [Slang, Eng.] Dickens.
The passage for the breath from the larynx to the lungs; thetrachea; the weasand. See Illust. under Lung.
A bastard; colloquially, a low, scurvy fellow; -- usedgenerally in contempt, or in coarse humor. Also used adjectively.[Archaic] Shak.
A common soldier; a soldier below the grade of anoncommissioned officer. Macaulay.
A collection of vedic hymns, songs, or verses, forming thefirst part of each Veda.
The property, quality, or state, of being magnetic; themanifestation of the force in nature which is seen in a magnet.
Any unbranched, slender, green plant of the fresh-water algae.The word is frequently used in a wider sense.

Any one of numerous small spring birds belonging to Anthus,Corydalla, and allied genera, which resemble the true larks in colorand in having a very long hind claw; especially, the European meadowpipit (Anthus pratensis).
An albuminous substance existing in the blood, and in otheranimal fluids, which either alone or with fibrinoplastin orparaglobulin forms fibrin, and thus causes coagulation.
A genus of solanaceous plants, with large funnel-shaped flowersand a four-celled, capsular fruit.
Notice or information of an event before it happens;forewarning. [R.] Rymer.
A sexual spore in which the sexes differ in size; -- opposed toisospore.
A forked piece of wood, or a small spring clamp, used forfastening clothes on a line.
Like or pertaining to the genus Mullus, which includes thesurmullet, or red mullet.
A colorless liquid base, C4H9NH2, of which there are fourisomeric varieties.
The occasional twisted growth of the parts of a flower.
A game played by four persons with forty cards, being theremainder of an ordinary pack after the tens, nines, and eights arediscarded. Hoyle.
A crystal of one species inclosed within one of another, as oneof rutile inclosed in quartz.
A cyst formed under the tongue by obstruction of the duct ofthe submaxillary gland.
A rush candle, or its light; hence, a small, feeble light.
A genus of ganoid fishes, found in strata of the new redsandetone, and the lias bone beds. Agassiz.
One of the masses of generative tissue primitively alike inboth sexes, but giving rise to either an ovary or a testis; agenerative gland; a germ gland. Wiedersheim.
Pertaining to, or resembling, the Hebrew language or idiom.
Producing, or produced by, the action of light; -- formerlyused specifically to designate a gas now called carbonyl chloride.See Carbonyl.
(Crystalloq.) A solid related to a tetrahedron, and containedunder twelve equal triangles.
If, pertaining to, or consisting of, three colors or colorsensations.
Any marine gastropod shell of the genus Apporhais having anelongated siphon. See Illust. under Rostrifera.

To enlarge by addition or discussion; to treat copiously byadding particulars, illustrations, etc.; to expand; to make much of.Troilus and Cressida was written by a Lombard author, but muchamplified by our English translator. Dryden.
A peaceful person; -- applied specif. by the Spaniards to thenatives in Cuba and the Philippine Islands who did not oppose theSpanish arms.
To fix and settle by long continuance. [Obs.] Bacon.
A kind of half-pike, or halberd, formerly borne by inferiorofficers of the British infantry, and used in giving signals to thesoldiers.
An inflammation in the foot of a horse, between the sole andthe bone. [Obs.]
A generic term, or a term applicable in the same sense to allthe species it embraces.
To remove from, or as from, a throne; to dethrone. Milton.
The entire cavity of the prosencephalon. B. G. Wilder.
A mania or infatuation for icons, whether as objects ofdevotion, bric-a-brac, or curios.
A short tubular opening at the top of a retort, or at the topor side of a bottle; a tubulation.
The representation of ideas independently of sounds, or in anideographic manner, as sometimes is done in shorthand writing, etc.
Noting the case of a noun which expresses the remoter object,and is generally indicated in English by to or for with theobjective.
As much as a tureen can hold; enough to fill a tureen.
A head or dense cluster of flowers, formed by condensation of acyme, as in the flowering dogwood.
A powder or other substance to be used in cleaning the teeth;tooth powder.
A person who follows an army, and sells to the troopsprovisions, liquors, and the like.
A female superior or governess of a nunnery, or convent ofnuns, having the same authority over the nuns which the abbots haveover the monks. See Abbey.
To set in order; to adorn; to deck, to embellish; to trim.Shak.
The space between two nodes or points of the stem from whichthe leaves properly arise. H. Spenser.
A musical instrument, formerly in use, in form of a spinet; --called also manichord and clavichord.
The embryo which has begun its development in the act ofgermination.
To remove a spike from, as from the vent of a cannon.
A person living in the marches between England and Scotland orWales.
One of the small hooklike processes on the barbules offeathers.
The mahogany-like wood of the South African tree Pteroxylonutile, the sawdust of which causes violent sneezing (whence thename). Also called sneezewood.
The male of the domestic fowl; a cock. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
A cultivator of saffron; a dealer in saffron. [Obs.] Holinshed.
A nocturnal South American monkey (Callithrix discolor), notedfor its agility; -- called also ventriloquist monkey.
Not capable of being sounded or fathomed; unfathomable. Shak.
A variety of allanite from Sweden supposed to contain wasium.
To make irregular; to disorder. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.

One who polls; specifically: (a) One who polls or lops trees.(b) One who polls or cuts hair; a barber. [R.] (c) One who extorts orplunders. [Obs.] Bacon. (d) One who registers voters, or one whoenters his name as a voter.
To propose or name as a candidate for admission to communionwith a church.
Ancient; pertaining to the earliest period in geologicalhistory.
An American tree of the genus Populus or polar, having theseeds covered with abundant cottonlike hairs; esp., the P. moniliferaand P. angustifolia of the Western United States.
A morbid condition in which pus is discharged in the urine.

One of a sect in the primitive church, who celebrated theLord's Supper with bread and cheese, alleging that the firstoblations of men not only of the fruit of the earth, but of theirflocks. [Gen. iv. 3, 4.]
In ancient Sparta, one of those Helots who were freed by thestate in reward for military service. Milford.
The science of, or a system of, weights and measures; also, atreatise on the subject.
A thick, viscid fluid; a clot, as of blood. Quincy.
A brilliant glass, used in the manufacture of artificial pastegems, which consists essentially of a complex borosilicate of leadand potassium. Cf. Glass.
A border of greensward left round the margin of a plowed field.Ray.
The torpedo, or electric ray, the touch of which gives anelectric shock. See Electric fish, and Torpedo.
A member of the scapolite, group, occuring in glassy crystalson Monte Somma, near Naples.
To thrust down or out; to push down with force. Locke.
resembling rustic work. See Rustic work (a), under Rustic.
In or to some other place, or places; elsewhere. Milton.Tennyson.
A compound of arsenic and hydrogen, AsH3, a colorless andexceedingly poisonous gas, having and odor like garlic; arseniuretedhydrogen.
The offspring of the union of two distinct species; an animalor plant produced from the mixture of two species. See Mongrel.
The calf of the leg. [Obs.] Wyclif (Deut. xxviii. 35).
A genus of pearly bivalve shells, numerous extinct species ofwhich are characteristic of the Mesozoic rocks. A few living speciesexist on the coast of Australia.
Pertaining to, or consisting of, entrochites, or the joints ofencrinites; -- used of a kind of stone or marble.
An instrument for determining the strength or purity of wine bymeasuring its density.
The act of smearing or covering with wax. B. Jonson.
One of a tribe of crabs which live in holes in the sand alongthe seashore, and run very rapidly, -- whence the name.
One who takes again what has been taken; a recaptor. Kent.

One of several species of East Indian and Asiatic fresh-waterfishes of the genus Ophiocephalus, remarkable for their power ofliving out of water, and for their tenacity of life; -- called alsowalking fishes.

Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an acid,HO.C2H4.SO3H, obtained as an oily or crystalline substance, by theaction of sulphur trioxide on alcohol or ether. It is derivative ofsulphuric acid.

One of thirty regions or zones, parallel to the equator, intowhich the surface of the earth from the equator to the pole wasdivided, according to the successive increase of the length of themidsummer day.
The lordship of a castle; the extent of land and jurisdictionappertaining to a castle.
The reverse, or left-hand, page of a book or a folded sheet ofpaper; -- opposed to recto.
A genus of bivalve mollusks, common on the coasts of Americaand Europe.
A genus of leeches, including the common medicinal leech. SeeLeech.
The branch of medical science which teaches the method ofacquiring a good habit of body. [Obs.]
One who presumes; also, an arrogant person. Sir H. Wotton.
The skin of a seal; the pelt of a seal prepared for use, esp.of the fur seal; also, a garment made of this material.
A division of ciliated Infusoria in which the cilia cover onlythe under side of the body.
One who patrols; a watchman; especially, a policeman whopatrols a particular precinct of a town or city.
With the flat side, as of a sword; flatlong; in a prostrateposition. [Obs.] Spenser.
Incapable of error in defining doctrines touching faith ormorals. See Papal infallibility, under Infallibility.
Either land held by a bordar, or the land which a lord kept forthe maintenance of his board, or table. Spelman.
A book of dramatic compositions; a book of the play. Swift.
A formal recital or exposition of facts; exposure, orrevelation, of something which some one wished to keep concealed.
Growing on the angles of a stem, as the leaves in some speciesof Selaginella.
A genus including numerous species of shells resembling Neritain form. They mostly inhabit brackish water, and are often delicatelytinted.
To speak or write in commendation of (another); to extol inspeech or writing; to praise.
A hypothetical radical found in certain derivatives ofstyrolene and cinnamic acid; -- called also cinnyl, or cinnamyl.
Effort to overcome in contest; struggle; endeavor. [R.]Farindon.
The act of defining; definition; description. [Obs.] Shak.
A small tile of glass, marble, or other substance, of variouscolors, used in making ornamental patterns in mosaic pavements.Fairholt.
Among the primitive Christians, the living on a diet of dryfood in Lent and on other fasts.
Having the power of self-government; autonomous. Hickok.
Originally, a gondola race in Venice; now, a rowing or sailingrace, or a series of such races.
A genus of lizards, one of the few which feed upon vegetablesubstances; also, one of these lizards.
Departure; decrease; -- opposed to accesion. [Obs.] Jer.Taylor.
A writ to commission private persons to do some act in place ofa judge, as to examine a witness, etc. Bouvier.
To lay asleep; to put to sleep; to quiet. [Obs.]The king's declaration for the sopiting of all Arminian heresies.Fuller.
Relating to, or resembling, gneiss; consisting of gneiss.
The description or natural history of cetaceous animals.
The opinion or doctrine that everything in nature, being thework of God, is ordered for the best, or that the ordering of thingsin the universe is such as to produce the highest good.
Order of rhizopods, usually having a siliceous skeleton, orshell, and sometimes radiating spicules. The pseudopodia project fromthe body like rays. It includes the polycystines. See Polycystina.
Capable of being healed or cured; susceptible of remedy.
A ravine. See Gill a woody glen. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]Wordsworth.
The maws, or stomachs, of young calves, used a rennet forcurdling milk. [Scot.]
A glucoside extracted from the cambium layer of coniferoustrees as a white crystalline substance.
The hindmost mast of a three-masted vessel, or of a yawl-riggedvessel.
In a handfast or publicly pledged manner. [Obs.] Holinshed.
One who mines by contract, at so much per ton of coal or ore.
The act of driving a chariot or a carriage. [R.] De Quincey.
The quality or state of being sandy, or of being of a sandycolor.
The standard unit of electrical quantity, and also of current.See Coulomb, and Amp. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to a weald, esp. to the weald in the county ofKent, England. [Obs.] Fuller.
An order of amphibians having the tail well developed and oftenlong. It comprises the salamanders, tritons, and allied animals.
To allege or prove to be of unsound mind, so that theperformance of some act may be avoided.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid found in the lichenParmelia parietina, and called also chrysophanic acid.
The refinement or subtilization of a body, or the increasing ofits virtue or principal property.
Resembling Christ in character, actions, etc.-- Christ"like`ness, n.
A genus of Hymenoptera including the common wasps and hornets.
A pinnacle of ice among the crevasses of a glacier; also, oneof the blocks into which a glacier breaks on a steep grade.
A cloth with a cotton wart, and a woof of very fine wool, orwool and silk.
A deliverer; -- a name of infamy given to Christians whodelivered the Scriptures, or the goods of the church, to theirpersecutors to save their lives. Milner.
An instrument with a hinged claw, -- used for extracting teethwith a twist.
the fleshy part of a stone fruit, situated between the skin, orepicarp, and the stone, or endocarp, as in a peach. See Illust. ofEndocarp.
A genus of plants including the glasswort. See Glasswort.
A picture printed from a kind of gelatine plate produced bymeans of a photographic negative.
The relation of a son to a father; sonship; -- the correlativeof paternity. J. S. Mill.
One who sacks; one who takes part in the storm and pillage of atown.
Either of two compounds, a chlorine derivative and brominederivative, of hydroquinone, used as developers.
Cut into distinct parts, by incisions which reach the midrib; -- said of a leaf.
The servant or officer, in a great family, who has charge ofthe bread and the pantry. [Obs.] Shak.
A plant of the genus Ranunculus, or crowfoot, particularly R.bulbosus, with bright yellow flowers; -- called also butterflower,golden cup, and kingcup. It is the cuckoobud of Shakespeare.

A compound obtained as a yellowish gray powder by the action ofacetyl chloride or acetic anhydride or ordinary tannic acid. It isused as an intestinal astringent, and locally in rhinitis andpharyngitis.
Containing, or consisting of, dew; dewy. [R.] Bacon.
Full of chinks or fissures; gaping; opening in narrow clefts.Dryden.
A mineral consisting principally of sulphate of iron; whitecopperas; -- so called because found in the province of Coquimbo,Chili.
To use the enticements of a siren; to act as a siren; tofascinate.
The state or quality of being alive; possession of energy orvigor; animation; quickening.
A punting pole with a broad flange near the end to prevent itfrom sinking into the mud; a setting pole.
A book containing annual reports of cases adjudged in thecourts of England.
The articles or goods supplied by upholsterers; the business orwork of an upholsterer.
A plane figure having four angles, and consequently four sides;any figure having four angles.
Of or pertaining to passion or the passions; exciting,influenced by, or ministering to, the passions.-- n.
Furring done with small pieces nailed directly upon the wall.
A choriambic verse, first used by the Greek poet Asclepias,consisting of four feet, viz., a spondee, two choriambi, and aniambus.
A moth of the genus Lithophane, as L. antennata, whose larvabores large holes in young peaches and apples.
Same as Almug (and etymologically preferable). 2 Chron. ii. 8.
To examine, as the thickness of the metal at the muzzle of agun; or, in general, to examine the thickness of, as ordnance, inorder to ascertain its strength.
Pertaining to, derived from, or related to, xylene;specifically, designating any one of several metameric acids producedby the partial oxidation of mesitylene and pseudo-cumene.
The operation of cutting or removing the tarsal cartilages.
The outer part of the west end of a collegiate or other chapel.Shipley.
One or two whom a pledge is delivered as security; one whotakes anything in pawn.
The searching of a ship for unentered goods. [Eng.] [Writtenalso jerguer.]
A division of Diptera in which the young are born in a stagelike the pupa. It includes the sheep tick, horse tick, and otherparasites. Called also Homaloptera.
A bellowing, as of a deer in rutting time. Johnson.
The opinion or doctrine that everything in nature is orderedfor or tends to the worst, or that the world is wholly evil; --opposed to Ant: optimism.
A vessel to carry liquid metal from the furnace to the mold.
A coral, or corallum; also, one of the coral-like structuremade by bryozoans and hydroids.
Having particles which easily move and change their relativeposition without a separation of the mass, and which easily yield topressure; capable of flowing; liquid or gaseous.

One of the principal means of securing unity and consistency inpolyphonic composition; the repetition of essentially the samemelodic theme, phrase, or motive, on different degrees of pitch, byone or more of the other parts of voises. Cf. Canon.
Bridgework; structure or edifice of a bridge. [R.] Milton.
Having the edge worn away so as to be jagged or irregularlytoothed.
An ovum, as that of a mammal, only partially composed ofgerminal matter, that is, consisting of both a germinal portion andan albuminous or nutritive one; -- opposed to holoblast.
A legislative assembly or parliament of any one of severalcountries colonized by the Dutch, esp. that of the South AfricanRepublic, or the Transvaal, and that of the Orange Free State.
One skilled in the knowledge of the Bible; a demonstrator ofreligious truth by the Scriptures.
To put in a state of readiness for active service in war, as anarmy corps.
A flatulent distention of the belly; tympanites. Fuller.
An uncrystallizable alkaloid obtained by the action of heatfrom quinine, with which it is isomeric.
To communicative ideas by the fingers; to show or compute bythe fingers. [Obs.]
The man who manages the movable scenes in a theater.
A peculiar substance obtained from the wool of sheep,consisting largely of potash mixed with fatty and earthy matters. Itis used as a source of potash and also for the manufacture of gas.
One who assays. Specifically: One who examines metallic ores orcompounds, for the purpose of determining the amount of anyparticular metal in the same, especially of gold or silver.
A minute, thin-walled vessel; particularly one of the smallestblood vessels connecting arteries and veins, but used also for thesmallest lymphatic and biliary vessels.
The machinery of a clock, or machinary resembling that of aclock; machinery which produced regularity of movement.
Able or tending to discuss or disperse tumors or coagulatedmatter.
An overflowing with water; also, the water which thusoverflows.
To commit the first act of hostility or offense; to begin aquarrel or controversy; to make an attack; -- with on.
A large drinking vessel; also, its contents. [Colloq. Eng.]Forby.
One who belong to a council; one who gives an opinion. [Obs.]I will in three months be an expert counsilist. Milton.
A whitish marble, from Rome, containiing pale greenish zones.It consists of calcium carbonate, with zones and cloudings of talc.
A hollow organ or tube attached to the head, or connected withthe mouth, of various animals, and generally used in taking food ordrink; a snout; a trunk.
One who has sinned; especially, one who has sinned withoutrepenting; hence, a persistent and incorrigible transgressor; onecondemned by the law of God.
Of or pertaining to the clergy; clerical; clerkily; learned.[Obs.] Milton.
Divination by means of water, -- practiced by the ancients.
To stammer; to speak unintelligibly; to prevaricate.[Prov.Eng.] Halliwell.
To restore from a warped state; to cause to be linger warped.
A preparation of antimony with which Mohammedan men anointtheir eyelids.
A mixture of white lead and lime, with which the bright partsof machines, such as the connecting rods of steamboats, are paintedto be preserved from oxidation.
To make clear; to clear up what is obscure or not understood;to explain.
Any court or vestibule before a building or leading into anyinclosure.
A genus of plants (Polygala) of many species. The commonEuropean P. vulgaris was supposed to have the power of producing aflow of milk in nurses.
A board set up to windward in a boat, to keep out water. Ham.Nav. Encyc.
Government by new or inexperienced hands; upstart rule; raw oruntried officials.
The lowest relief, -- often used in Italian sculpture of the15th and 16th centuries.
Either one of two species of South African wild horsesremarkable for having the body white or yellowish white, andconspicuously marked with dark brown or brackish bands.
One of several species of sea birds of the genus Sula, alliedto the pelicans.
Varied with irregular markings, or witch a confused blending ofirregular spots and streaks.
To use the Greek language; to play the Greek; to Grecize.
A nematode worm (Trichocephalus dispar) often found parasiticin the human intestine. Its body is thickened posteriorly, but isvery long and threadlike anteriorly.
The act of shutting up or confining; confinement. [R.] Geddes.
A complex bitter gum, found on the leaves of the olive tree; --called also olivite.
Not made by brewing; unmixed; pure; genuine. [R.] Young.
An easy, unceremonious attire; undress; also, a kind of easyrobe or dressing gown worn by women.
One who lacquers, especially one who makes a business oflacquering.
A complete course or vibration; time of vibration, as of apendulum. [Obs.] Locke.
The state or quality of being juicy; succulence plants.
Pertaining to, or consisting of, images, pictures, orrepresentations of any kind.
A principle or mixture of principles derived from Euonymusatropurpureus, or spindle tree.
To overpower by disdain; to outface. [Obs.] Marston.
An outwork of a strong, high wall, with turrets, in frontgateway (as of an old castle), for defending the entrance.
Quicker than andante, but not so quick as allegro.-- n.
Having stamens and pistil in the same head, or, in mosses,having antheridia and archegonia on the same receptacle.
Pertaining to the science or doctrine of refracted sounds.
Having the qualities of a cuckold; mean-spirited; sneaking.Shak.
The alderman or chief officer of an ancient guild. [Obs.]
The examination of the ear; the art of using the otoscope.
A yellow dyestuff extracted from the root bark of an EastIndian plant (Morinda citrifolia).
One of the fine lines of a letter, esp. one of the fine crossstrokes at the top and bottom of letters. [Spelt also seriph.]Savage.
Attracting the humors to the skin; exciting action in the skin;blistering.

A providing necessaries for the sovereign by buying them at anappraised value in preference to all others, and oven without theowner's consent. This was formerly a royal prerogative, but has longbeen abolished. Wharton.
An igneous rock consisting essentially of plagioclase andeither leucite or nephelite, or both.
A genus of small, bivalve, freshwater Crustacea, belonging tothe Ostracoda; also, a member of this genus.
A cycadaceous plant of Florida and the West Indies, the Zamiaintegrifolia, from the stems of which a kind of sago is prepared.
A group of soft-bodied Alcyonaria, of which Alcyonium is thetype. See Illust. under Alcyonaria.
An instrument for writing in the dark, or without seeing.Maunder.
Like, or covered with, slabber or slab; slippery; sloppy.
One of a class of organic bases, C8H11N, usually pungent oilyliquids, belonging to the pyridine series, and obtained from boneoil, coal tar, naphtha, and certain alkaloids.
A genus of fleshy Alcyonaria, its polyps somewhat resemblingflowers with eight fringed rays. The term was also formerly used forcertain species of sponges.
The person to whom a lease is given, or who takes an estate bylease. Blackstone.
In a sufficient degree; fully; amply; plentifully; in largemeasure.
Having the capacity of becoming organizable in a high degree,as the matter forming the false membranes which sometimes result fromacute inflammation in a healthy person. Dunglison.
A carrying forward, as of a final letter, to a following word;as, for example, a nickname for an ekename.
To boil; to seethe; hence, to extract by boiling or seething.[Obs.] Cockeram.
A coherent mass of pollen, as in the milkweed and most orchids.

A genus of small schizopod shrimps found both in fresh and saltwater; the opossum shrimps. One species inhabits the Great Lakes ofNorth America, and is largely eaten by the whitefish. The marinespecies form part of the food of right whales.
An underground way or gallery; especially, a passage under astreet, in which water mains, gas mains, telegraph wires, etc., areconducted.

A solid mass of cellular tissue, consisting of one or morelayers, usually in the form of a flat stratum or expansion, butsometimes erect or pendulous, and elongated and branching, andforming the substance of the thallogens.
A nitrogenous body, related to cerebrin, supposed to exist inthe brain.
Of or performance to trap; resembling trap, or partaking of itsform or qualities; trappy.
The elementary and indestructible units which were conceived ofas endowed with the power to produce all the changes they undergo,and thus determine all physical and spiritual phenomena.
A staging for supporting a stack of hay or grain; a rickstand.
An apparatus for drying substances or preserving them frommoisture; a desiccator; also, less frequently, an agent employed toabsorb moisture, as calcium chloride, or concentrated sulphuric acid.
In a dismal manner; gloomily; sorrowfully; uncomfortably.
Among Mohammedans, a warrior champion or veteran, esp. in thedestruction of infidels.
The pedicel raising the pistil or ovary above the stamens, asin the passion flower. Lindley.
An iodide containing a higher proportion of iodine than anyother iodide of the same substance or series.
The sapphirine gurnard (Trigla hirundo). See Illust. underGurnard. [Prov. Eng.]
A sharp-pointed tool, used by joiners for drawing lines onstuff; a marking awl.
A small book or case for carrying papers, money, etc., in thepocket; also, a notebook for the pocket.
The skin of a pig, -- used chiefly for making saddles; hence, acolloquial or slang term for a saddle.
To turn to another course or use. [Obs.] Sir H. Wotton.
A wether sheep between one and two years old. [Scot.]
The act of one who spells; formation of words by letters;orthography.
The sacred shield of the Romans, said to have-fallen fromheaven in the reign of Numa. It was the palladium of Rome.
The condition, practice, or mode of life, of ascetics.
The signs, abbreviations, letters, or characters standing forwords, shorthand, etc., in ancient manuscripts, or on coins, medals,etc. W. Savage.
To sluice; to open the sluice or sluices of; to let flow; todischarge. Dryden.

That part of a blossom which secretes nectar, usually the baseof the corolla or petals; also, the spur of such flowers as thelarkspur and columbine, whether nectariferous or not. See theIllustration of Nasturtium.
The quality or state of being sonorous; sonorousness.
A property attached to a word, but not essential to it, asgender, number, case.

An American clupeoid fish (Clupea mediocris), similar to theshad in habits and appearance, but smaller and less esteemed forfood; -- called also hickory shad, tailor shad, fall herring, andshad herring.
Any carnivore of the genus Mellivora, allied to the weasels andthe skunks; -- called also honey badger.
Room in a storehouse or repository; a room in which articlesare stored.
The process of giving a dull or ground surface to glass by acidor by mechanical means. Knight.
An extinct group of fishes, supposed to be ganoids. The bodyand head were covered with large bony plates. See Illust. underPterichthys, and Coccosteus.
Containing years; having existed or continued many years; aged.[Obs.] B. Jonson.
A language used by German and other Jews, being a Middle Germandialect developed under Hebrew and Slavic influence. It is written inHebrew characters.
A subordinate cliff on a shore, consisting of material that hasfallen from the higher cliff above.

Any substance or medium that transmits the electric force by aprocess different from conduction, as in the phenomena of induction;a nonconductor. separating a body electrified by induction, from theelectrifying body.
A present of books given to a meritorious undergraduate studentas a prize. [Harvard Univ., U. S.]
A bar or timber connecting two knightheads or two bitts.
A body of about five or six hundred soldiers; the tenth part ofa legion.
A woman's loose dressing sack; hence, a loose morning gown orwrapper.
The charasteristics, manners, or dialect, of a cockney.

A phenol derivative of cymene, C10H13.OH, isomeric withcarvacrol, found in oil of thyme, and extracted as a whitecrystalline substance of a pleasant aromatic odor and strongantiseptic properties; -- called also hydroxy cymene.
A native or inhabitant of Lapland; -- called also Lapp.
An officer who had the charge of showing hospitality to thosewho came from a friendly city or state.
An Asiatic wild dog (Canis procyonoides), native of Japan andadjacent countries. It has a short, bushy tail. Called also raccoondog.
Ornamentation on the border of a thing; specifically, theinlaid border of a musical instrument, as a violin.
The more ancient of the two great epic poems in Sanskrit. Thehero and heroine are Rama and his wife Sita.
A state of being united togheter as in a clan; an associationunder a chieftain.
The myristate of glycerin, -- found as a vegetable fat innutmeg butter, etc.
A native of either ancient or modern Greece; a Greek. Brewer.
The state of healty tension or partial contraction of musclefibers while at rest; tone; tonus.
The act of taking or carrying away; removal. [R.] Bp. Hall.
A quantity of corn formerly given by the lord to his customarytenants, as an encouragement to, or reward for, labor and faithfulservice.
One who simply repeats what he has heard. [R.] J. S. Mill.

Formerly, a member of an independent body of marksmen in theFrench army. They were used sometimes in front of the army to annoythe enemy, sometimes in the rear to check his pursuit. The term isnow applied to all troops acting as skirmishers.
To discourse in the manner of a preacher. [Colloq.] Thackeray.
In a sober manner; temperately; cooly; calmly; gravely;seriously.
Of or pertaining to a canton or cantons; of the nature of acanton.

An amorphous variety of manna obtained from the nests andcocoons of a Syrian coleopterous insect (Larinus maculatus, L.nidificans, etc.) which feeds on the foliage of a variety of thistle.It is used as an article of food, and is called also nest sugar.
A horse imported from New South Wales; also, any Australianhorse. [Colloq.]  Kipling.
One skilled in the theory or use of torpedoes; also, one whofavors the use of torpedoes.
To remove a cloak or cover from; to deprive of a cloak orcover; to unmask; to reveal.
A name given to each of three compromises made by the emperorCharles V. of Germany for the sake of harmonizing the connectingopinions of Protestants and Catholics.
A small cake (usually sweetened) fried in a kettle of boilinglard.
A pyramidal form of inflorescence, in which the cluster isloosely branched below and gradually simpler toward the end.
The doctrine of signs as the expression of thought orreasoning; the science of indicating thought by signs. Smart.
Harshness or roughness of voice or sound, due to mucuscollected on the vocal cords, or to swelling or looseness of thecords.
An Italian marble of which the principal varieties occur in theneighborhood of Carrara and in Corsica. It commonly shows a dark grayor bluish ground traversed by veins.
The exterior wall; the outside surface, or appearance. Shak.
A kind of small, prickly cucumber, much used for pickles.

Of or pertaining to a revelation, or, specifically, to theRevelation of St. John; containing, or of the nature of, a propheticrevelation. Apocolyptic number, the number 666, mentioned in Rev.xiii. 18. It has been variously interpreted.
A gallfly which deposits its eggs in galls formed by otherinsects.

One of a Teutonic race, formerly dwelling on the south shore ofthe Baltic, the most barbarous and fierce of the northern nationsthat plundered Rome in the 5th century, notorious for destroying themonuments of art and literature.
Of or pertaining to Russia, its inhabitants, or language.-- n.
A theory of generation in which each germ is supposed tocontain the germs of all subsequent generations; -- the opposite ofepigenesis.
A cord or band of fibrous tissue extending from the bladder tothe umbilicus.
That part of the baths and gymnasia in which bathers andwrestlers anointed themselves.
One who engages or undertakes; a promiser. Burrill.
An assaulter whose weapon is a sand bag. See Sand bag, underSand.
A very small frond, or distinct portion of a compound frond.
A weed that binds stalks of corn, as Convolvulus arvensis,Polygonum Convolvulus. [Prov. Eng.]
Formed unnaturally or illegitimately; deformed. Spenser.Milton.
The distance measured toward the east between two meridiansdrawn through the extremities of a course; distance of departureeastward made by a vessel.
