A tenure of lands by knight's service; that is, by thecondition of a knight's performing service on horseback, or ofperforming some noble or military service to his lord.
To contend for; to defend; to vindicate. [Obs.] Hammond.
The point of junction of the coronal and sagittal sutures ofthe skull.
A projection in a building; also, a pier or mole; a jetty.Shak.

The flour of a hard and small-grained wheat made into dough,and forced through small cylinders or pipes till it takes a slender,wormlike form, whence the Italian name. When the paste is made inlarger tubes, it is called macaroni.
A peculiar glandlike but ductless organ found near the stomachor intestine of most vertebrates and connected with the vascularsystem; the milt. Its exact function in not known.
Fertilization of the pistil of a plant by pollen from anotherof the same species; cross-fertilization.
The open space between the inner and outer shells of a dome orcupola of masonry.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, maltose; specif.,designating an acid called also gluconic or dextronic acid. SeeGluconic.
One who wins, or gains by success in competition, contest, orgaming.
The wooden mold in which cheese is pressed. Simmonds.
Pertaining to seaweeds of the genus Laminaria, or to that zoneof the sea (from two to ten fathoms in depth) where the seaweeds ofthis genus grow.
Pertaining to, or partaking of, the nature of the gerund;gerundial.-- n. (Lat. Gram.)
A halter consisting of a long leather or rope strap andheadstall, -- used for leading or tieing a pack animal. [WesternU.S.]
A kind of sirup made by the Indians of Arizona from the fruitof some cactaceous plant (probably the Cereus giganteus).
Capable of being excited, or roused into action; susceptible ofexcitement; easily stirred up, or stimulated.
One who gives light with a torch, or as if with a torch. [Obs.]Shak.
A white, crystalline, aromatic substance resembling camphor,extracted from oil of peppermint (Mentha); -- called also mintcamphor or peppermint camphor.
A subterranean room of any kind; esp., one under a church (seeCrypt), or one used as a chapel or for any sacred purpose.
The division of a thing into three parts, Specifically: (Geom.)the division of an angle into three equal parts.
Any fish of the family Silurid or of the order Siluroidei.
A leap of a horse, as between two pillars, or upon a straightline, so that when his four feet are in the air, he shows only theshoes of his hind feet, without jerking out.
On board; into or within a ship or boat; hence, into or withina railway car.
An inflammation of the large intestine, esp. of its mucousmembrane; colonitis.
A dark brown or black mineral, occurring in prismatic crystalsimbedded in limestone near Warwick, New York. It consists of theborate and titanate of magnesia and iron.
One who has an estate for a term of years or for life.
A belt or girdle which the Christians and Jews of the Levantwere obliged to wear to distinguish them from Mohammedans. [Writtenalso zonnar.]
The description of a particular place, town, manor, parish, ortract of land; especially, the exact and scientific delineation anddescription in minute detail of any place or region.
One skilled to technics or in one or more of the practicalarts.
In the construction of fieldworks, the erection at properintervals of wooden profiles, to show to the workmen the sectionalform of the parapets at those points.
A fish of the genus Priacanthus, remarkable for the large sizeof the eye.
To deprive of the claim of a pauper to public support; todeprive of the privilege of suing in forma pauperis.
That which makes smooth or sleek. Specifically:(a) A kind of burnisher for leather.(b) (Founding) A curved tool for smoothing the surfaces of a moldafter the withdrawal of the pattern.
, In a muddy manner; turbidly; without mixture; cloudily;obscurely; confusedly.
A Russian liquid measure, equal to 3.249 gallons of U.S.standard measure, or 2.706 imperial gallons. McElrath.
A term variously employed by early writers on art, thoughcommonly designating the yellow oxide of lead, or massicot. Fairholt.
A fief held of a superior feudatory; a fief held by an undertenant. Blackstone.
A little sac, or bag; a utricle; especially, a part of themembranous labyrinth of the ear. See the Note under Ear.
Probably, the baked berry of the hawthorn tree, that is, coarsefare. See 1st Haw, 2. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The interlacing osseous plates constituting the elastic poroustissue of certain parts of the bones, esp. in their articularextremities.
The lintel of a fireplace when of wood, as frequently in earlyhouses.
Long, narrow slips of canvas daubed with tar and wound about arope like a bandage, before it is served; used, also, in mousing onthe stayes, etc.
A tribe of Indians of the Dakota stock, living in Montana; --also called Upsarokas.
To broil; to grill; hence, To harass. [Obs.] Hudibras.
Pertaining to, or designating, a set of astronomical tablescomputed by Kepler, and founded on the observations of Tycho Brahe; -- so named from Rudolph II., emperor of Germany.
A pale sea-green color; also, porcelain or fine pottery of thistint.
One of the ordinaries, much like the flanch, but less roundedand therefore smaller.
Anything which causes expansion esp. (Mech.) a tool forstretching open or expanding a tube, etc.

A person who represents a parish in its ecclesiastical andcorporate capacities; hence, the rector or incumbent of a parochialchurch, who has full possession of all the rights thereof, with thecure of souls.
The Mohammedan Scriptures. Same as Alcoran and Koran.
To slide back; to fall away; esp. to abandon gradually thefaith and practice of a religion that has been professed.
To exceed in building, or in durability of building.
One of the bones of the tarsus which in man, forms the greatbone of the heel; -- called also fibulare.
An artificial group of stony corals including those which havetransverse septa in the calicles. The genera Pocillopora andFavosites are examples.
The European redstart; -- called also fireflirt. [prov. Eng.]
A draught or model from which to build; especially, one of thefull size of the work to be done; a detailed drawing.
Tending to excite or provoke; inflammatory. Barrow.
An expression consisting of two terms connected by the signplus (+) or minus (-); as, a+b, or 7-3.
A perennial, cruciferous plant (Cheiranthus Cheiri), withsweet-scented flowers varying in color from yellow to orange and deepred. In Europe it very common on old walls.
A nitrogenous base C10H9N, extracted from coal-tar naphtha, asan oily liquid. It is a member of the quinoline series, and isprobably identical with lepidine.
Of or pertaining to the Hebrews, or to the language of theHebrews.
An extensive group of mammals including all those that havehoofs. It comprises the Artiodactyla and Perissodactyla.
A hammer with a head formed of a bundle of square bars, withpyramidal points, arranged in rows, or a solid head with a face cutinto a number of rows of such points; -- used for dressing stone.
A mass or lump of fat rolled up by the butcher. [Obs.] Shak.
Any one of certain plants whose soft, downy leaves have beenused for dressing wounds, as the kidney vetch, and several species ofthe labiate genus Stachys.
One who officiously concerns himself with the affairs ofothers; a meddling person.And not only idle, but tattlers also and busybodies, speaking thingswhich they ought not. 1 Tim. v. 13.
Having the surface covered with irregular, impressed lines.
The European ringdove (Columba palumbus); the cushat. [Writtenalso quist, queeze, quice, queece.] See Ringdove.
A small sloop-rigged racing yacht carrying about six hundredsquare feet of sail, distinguished from a knockabout by having ashort bowsprit.
A genus of trilobites characteristic of the Silurian age.
To render Italian, or conformable to Italian customs; toItalianize. [R.] Ascham.
Orig., a printing-out process using paper coated with silverchloride in gelatin; now, any such process using silver salts ineither collodion or gelatin; also, a print so made.
The first name of a person, by which individuals of the samefamily were distinguished, answering to our Christian name, as Caius,Lucius, Marcus, etc.
The substance of apples, or of similar fruit, crushed bygrinding.
That which has one or more of the three dimensions, length,breadth, and thickness.
The dressing of the hair by crisping or curling. Smollett.
The olfactory organ of some Mollusca. It is connected with theorgan of respiration.
A fluoride of sodium and aluminum, found in Greenland, in whitecleavable masses; -- used as a source of soda and alumina.
Gentleness; courtesy; kindness; nobility. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The part of a plow, or other implement, that turns over theearth; the moldboard.
Formed or consisting of straw. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
To form into a genus; to view objects in their relations to agenus or class; to take general or comprehensive views.
One who makes peace by reconciling parties that are atvariance. Matt. v. 9. --Peace"mak`ing, n.
Capable of, or admitting of, being resumed. Sir M. HAle.
One who makes, or is authorized to make, an excuse; anapologist. [Obs.] Hume.
Pertaining to the Pactolus, a river in ancient Lydia famous forits golden sands.
A compound radical, C7H15, regarded as the essential radical ofheptane and a related series of compounds.
Belonging or relating to winter; wintry; winterish. Sir T.Browne.
A perennial alliaceous plant (Allium fistulosum), sometimescalled Welsh onion. Its fistular leaves areused in cookery.
A kind of small umbrella used by women as a protection from thesun.
Any serranoid fish of the genus Rhypticus; -- so called fromthe soapy feeling of its skin.
Curved and sharppointed, like a falcula, or claw of a falcon.

A nonphosphorized, nitrogenous substance, obtained from brainand nerve tissue by extraction with boiling alcohol. It is uncertainwhether it exists as such in nerve tissue, or is a product of thedecomposition of some more complex substance.
A four-wheeled carriage, with a falling top, a seat on theoutside for the driver, and two double seats on the inside arrangedso that the sitters on the front seat face those on the back seat.
A prefix signifying out of, outside; as in exocarp, exogen,exoskeleton.
A group of Mammalia in which a decidua is thrown off with, orafter, the fetus, as in the human species.
The chemical basis of sponge tissue, a nitrogenous, hornlikesubstance which on decomposition with sulphuric acid yields leucinand glycocoll.
A public shed, or portico, for travelers, worshipers, etc.[Burmah]
One who frisks; one who leaps of dances in gayety; a wanton; aninconstant or unsettled person. Camden.
The craft of kings; the art of governing as a sovereign; royalpolicy. Prescott.
Originating in the character of the germ, or at the firstcommencement of an individual; -- said of peculiarities of structure,character, etc.
One who disparages or dishonors; one who vilifies or disgraces.
The consecrated wafer; the host. [Obs.] Bp. Burnet.
A hydrous arseniate of copper, of an emerald-green color; -- socalled from Erin, or Ireland, where it occurs.
A judgment by which one is deprived or put of a right or thingin question.
A play of children, in swinging on ropes, or the like, tillthey are dizzy.
A small shaft sunk from one level to another, as for thepurpose of ventilation.
An opacity of the crystalline lens, or of its capsule, whichprevents the passage of the rays of light and impairs or destroys thesight.
A body of men, either horse, foot, or artillery, commanded by acolonel, and consisting of a number of companies, usually ten.
A form of micrococcus, found in putrid meat infusions,occurring in peculiar masses, each of which is inclosed in a hyalinecapsule and contains a large number of spherical micrococci.
A foot of two syllables, the first long and the second short,as in the Latin word ante, or the first accented and the secondunaccented, as in the English word motion; a choreus.
A man who washes clothes, esp. for hire, or for others.
Heating; burning. [Obs.]The wicked enchaufing or ardure of this sin [lust]. Chaucer.
Iolite; -- so called from its presenting two different colorswhen viewed in two different directions. See Iolite.
Straight threads obtained by unraveling old linen cloth; --used for surgical dressings.
A genus of mytraceous plants, mostly of tropical countries, andincluding several aromatic trees and shrubs, among which are thetrees which produce allspice and cloves of commerce.
A printed form, used by merchants in making out bills orrendering accounts.
The act of deposing from office; a removal from the throne.Fox.
A microscopic, bacterial organism (Bacillus anthracis),resembling transparent rods. [See Illust. under Bacillus.]
A genus of large marine gastropods having the outer border ofthe lip divided into lobes; -- called also scorpion shell.
A lamb reared without the aid of the dam. Hence: A pet, ingeneral.
A wild goat (Capra Jemlaica) which inhabits the loftiestmountains of India. It has long, coarse hair, forming a thick mane onits head and neck.
A substance resembling indigo blue, obtained artificially fromcertain isatogen compounds.
A thin, oblong turf used for covering cottages, and also forfuel. [Scot.] Simmonds.
That which obtunds or blunts; especially, that which bluntssensibility.
A place where rabbits are kept; especially, a collection ofhutches for tame rabbits.
A large and valuable food fish (Polyprion prognathus) of NewZealand. It sometimes weighs one hundred pounds or more.
The state of being irreligious; want of religion; impiety.
In a skillful or dexterous manner; adroitly; with readiness andaccuracy.
A genus of slender, transparent holothurians which havedelicate calcareous anchors attached to the dermal plates. SeeIllustration in Appendix.
A word of doubtful meaning used once by Shakespeare.This [gold] is itThat makes the wappen'd widow wed again.
To be or become unwound; to be capable of being unwound oruntwisted.
Having the appearance of bran; consisting of or containingbran. Wiseman.
A water nymph; one of the lower female divinities, fabled topreside over some body of fresh water, as a lake, river, brook, orfountain.
Ropes or cords, collectively; hence, anything made of rope orcord, as those parts of the rigging of a ship which consist of ropes.
According to, in harmony with, moral principles or character.
The act of refusing a judge or challenging that he shall nottry the cause, on account of his supposed partiality. Blackstone.
Growth from within; multiplication of cells by endogenousdivision, as in the development of one or more cells in the interiorof a parent cell.
Dissection of the blood vessels and lymphatics of the body.Dunglison.
That which is evidently false; an assertion or statement thefalsity of which is plainly apparent; -- opposed to truism.
An English game resembling ninepins, but played by throwingwooden disks, instead of rolling balls, at the pins.
A removable upper part of a hive. The word is sometimescontracted to super.
The policy of the Jingoes, so called. See Jingo, 2. [Cant,Eng.]
To remove the epidermis of (a skin) with a concave knife, bluntin its middle part, -- as in making chamois leather.
A species of inferior carpet imported from the Levant.McElrath.
The pollock, or coalfish; -- called also sillock. [Scot.]
That branch of science which treats of moving machines.
An illuminator of manuscripts and books; a limner. [Obs.]Cowell.
To remove from a charnel house; to raise from the grave; toexhume. Byron.
The protuberance through which milk is drawn from the breast ormamma; the mammilla; a teat; a pap.

A dramatic work, partly in dialogue and partly in song, of akind popular in Germany in the latter part of the 18th century. Itwas often comic, had modern characters, and patterned its music onfolk song with strictly subordinated accompaniment.
One that sprays; any instrument for vaporizing and sprayingliquids.
A part of a turtle which is next to the upper shell. Itcontains a fatty and gelatinous substance of a dull greenish tinge,much esteemed as a delicacy in preparations of turtle.
A sand bath; application of hot sand to the body. Dunglison.
Chamomile; a genus of composite, herbaceous plants.
A fastness; a fort or fortress; fortfield place; a place ofsecurity.
To waste by little and little; to fritter away. [Obs.]
A band which goes around the neck; often, the part at the topof a garment.
One of the ropes toggled to the footrope of a sail, used tohaul up to the yard the body of the sail when taking it in. Totten.
The principal star in Scorpio: -- called also the Scorpion'sHeart.
A small, flat fillet, encircling a column, etc., used byitself, or with other moldings. It is used, several times repeated,under the Doric capital.
A genus of plants having bulbous roots and gladiate leaves, andincluding many species, some of which are cultivated and valued forthe beauty of their flowers; the corn flag; the sword lily.
A frozen waterfall, or mass of ice resembling a frozenwaterfall. Coleridge.
A silk yarn or fabric made out of carded spun silk.
One who, or that which, causes an extension in time or space.
Worsted yarn,, slackly twisted, used for embroidery.

An auditory cyst or vesicle; one of the simple auditory organsof many invertebrates, containing a fluid and otoliths; also, theembryonic vesicle from which the parts of the internal ear ofvertebrates are developed.

A cyst in which some unicellular organisms temporarily inclosethemselves, from which they emerge unchanged, after a period ofdrought or deficiency of food. In some instances, a process of sporeformation seems to occur within such cysts.
The state or quality of being oily or fat; fatness. [R.] B.Jonson.
To sprinkle; to scatter. [Obs.] Wyclif (1 Pet. i. 2).
To be inconsistent with, or act contrary to, the precepts ofthe gospel; to pervert the gospel. [Obs.] Milton.
A small cushion, in which pins may be stuck for use.
One of a body of men appointed by the army, in Cromwell's time,to look after their interests; -- called also adjutators. Clarendon.
Some time ago; formerly. [Scot.] Sir W. Scott.-- a.
One of the needlelike or bristlelike spines or prickles of someanimals and plants; also, a needlelike crystal.

A Jewish cabalistic book attributed by tradition to Rabbi Simonben Yochi, who lived about the end of the 1st century, a. d. Moderncritics believe it to be a compilation of the 13th century. Encyc.Brit.
Inlaid work; work inlaid with pieces of wood, shells, ivory,and the like, of several colors.
A genus of carnivorous mammals, including the domestic cat, thelion, tiger, panther, and similar animals.
A continuation of the petiole, extending from the base to theapex of the lamina of a leaf.
Any ornamental vessel used as a spittoon; hence, to avoid thecommon term, a spittoon of any sort.
Speaking reproachfully; slanderous. [Obs.] Sir E. Sandys.
Pertaining to, or derived from, Friedrich Froebel, or thekindergarten system of education, which he organized. -- n.
The colorless porous framework, or stroma, of red bloodcorpuscles from which the zooid, or hemoglobin and other substancesof the corpuscles, may be dissolved out.
Originally, a wig; afterwards, a mop for cleaning cannon.
A genus of large univalve mollusks, including the partridgeshell and tun shells.
To fill underneath; to stuff. [Obs.]He drank and well his girdle underpight. Chaucer.
Any tube or canal in which the blood or other fluids arecontained, secreted, or circulated, as the arteries, veins,lymphatics, etc.
Any sculptured, chased, or embossed ornament worked in lowrelief, as a cameo.
The ermine in its summer pelage, when it is reddish brown, butwith a black tip to the tail. The name is sometimes applied also toother brown weasels.
In the Levant, a small coffee cup without a handle, such as isheld in a cup or stand called a zarf.
Relating to, or affecting the lungs; pulmonary.-- n.
To stew, as flounders, eels, etc., with just enough or liquidto cover them. Smart.
A cant word for anything petty or small. It is used by Draytonas the name of a fairy.
The toes or feet of a pig, -- often used as food; sometimes, incontempt, the human feet. Shak.
Partaking of the nature of two bodies; producing twosubstances. Wright.

A rare element of the light platinum group, found associatedwith platinum ores, and isolated as a hard, brittle steel-gray metalwhich is very infusible. Symbol Ru. Atomic weight 103.5. Specificgravity 12.26. See Platinum metals, under Platinum.
An extensive genus of fossil ferns; -- so named from theregular comblike arrangement of the leaflets.
A metal urn used in Russia for making tea. It is filled withwater, which is heated by charcoal placed in a pipe, with chimneyattached, which passes through the urn.
A genus (Lemna) of small plants, seen floating in greatquantity on the surface of stagnant pools fresh water, and supposedto furnish food for ducks; -- called also duckmeat.
A thin slip of wood used to justify a page. [Obs.] Crabb.

One of the subclasses of fishes. They have an arterial cone andbulb, spiral intestinal valve, and the optic nerves united by achiasma. Many of the species are covered with bony plates, or withganoid scales; others have cycloid scales.

A special form of rotary converter with stationary commutatorand rotating brushes, in which the exciting field is induced by thealternating current in a short-circuited magnetic core instead ofbeing produced by an external magnet.
One of the larger measures of electrical capacity, amounting toone million farads; a macrofarad.
Of or pertaining to the Didynamia; containing four stamensdisposed in pairs of unequal length.
Nevertheless. [Archaic] Chaucer. Milton. E. Arnold.
A crystalline nitrogenous substance, formed in thedecomposition of creatin (one of the constituents of muscle tissue).Chemically, it is methyl glycocoll.
A substance isomeric with starch, extracted from severalspecies of moss and lichen, esp. from Iceland moss.
The Lake herring (Coregonus Artedi), valuable food fish of theGreat Lakes of North America. The name is also applied to C. Hoyi, arelated species of Lake Michigan.
To hold or advocate the doctrine of pessimism. London Sat. Rev.
A comprehensive division of the Vertebrata, including all thosethat have a skull.
A mass of interwoven brush, poles, etc., to protect a bank frombeing worn away by currents or waves.
A claylike mineral, occurring in soft, smooth, amorphousmasses, of a whitish color.
Having towns; containing many towns. [Obs.] Hakluyt.
The act of ingulfing, or the state of being ingulfed.
A slender elastic rod, as of whalebone, with a sponge on theend, for removing obstructions from the esophagus, etc.
A dissecting instrument for opening the spinal canal. [Writtenalso rachiotome.]
A son's or daughter's child; a child in the second degree ofdescent.
A kind of linen cloth made in Egypt, and so named from itsresemblance to cambric.
A small Italian coin worth a sou or a cent; the twentieth partof a lira.
A species of time; -- so called from its resemblance in form toa trefoil.
Pertaining to, or designating, the highest oxygen acid, HBrO4,of bromine.
One of the second pair of mouth organs of arachnids. In somethey are leglike, but in others, as the scorpion, they terminate in aclaw.
A narcotic alkaloid extracted from the tops of the common broom(Cytisus scoparius, formerly Spartium scoparium), as a colorless oilyliquid of aniline-like odor and very bitter taste.
Turnip-rooted celery, a from of celery with a large globularroot, which is used for food.
The reciprocal of the focal distance of a lens, used as measureof the divergence or convergence of a pencil of rays. [R.] HumphreyLloyd.
In a septic manner; in a manner tending to promoteputrefaction.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid, CH3C6H3(CO2H)2,obtained as a white crystalline substance by the partial oxidation ofmesitylene; -- called also mesitic acid.
To play the pedant; to use pedantic expressions. [R.]
A descendant of Cush, the son of Ham and grandson of Noah.
To trace out, as a line, figure, or solid, by the motion of apoint or a magnitude of inferior order.
A substance obtained from, and resembling, pectin, andoccurring in overripe fruits.
A buffoon in the Middle Ages, who attended rich men's tables tomake sport for the guests by ribald stories and songs.

A yellow crystalline substance, occurring quite widelydistributed in the vegetable kingdom, as is apple-tree bark, horse-chestnut leaves, etc., but originally obtained by the decompositionof quercitrin. Called also meletin.
The answer of a defendant in matter of fact to a plaintiff'ssurrejoinder.
A small branch, or branchlet, of corals, hydroids, and similarorganisms.
A personage in the old Italian comedy (derived from Spain)characterized by great boastfulness and poltroonery; hence, a personof like characteristics; a buffoon.
Cylindrical and slightly tapering; columnar, as some stems ofplants.
Pertaining to a thin membrane of the brain and spinal cord,between the dura mater and pia mater.
A dynamometer for ascertaining the power required to drawcarriages over roads.
A characteristic crystalline substance, obtained from oil ofbitter almonds.
Having the bark so close and constricting that it impedes thegrowth; -- said of trees. Bacon.
Acid; producing acid; -applied especially to certain glands andcells in the stomach.
The property of presenting different colors by transmittedlight, when viewed in two different directions, the colors beingunlike in the direction of unlike or unequal axes.
A waxy substance extracted by alcohol or ether from cork;sometimes applied also to the portion of beeswax which is soluble inalcohol. Watts.

The science, or the art, by which implements, vessels,dwellings, or other edifices, are constructed, both agreeably to theend for which they are designed, and in conformity with artisticsentiments and ideas.
Being without mixture or adulteration; hence, strong; racy.[Obs.]
Pertaining to, or designating, certain acids analogous to thephosphonic acids, but containing two hydrocarbon radicals, andderived from the secondary phosphines by oxidation.
An artifical division of vertebrates, including those that layeggs; -opposed to Vivipara.
An American fresh-water food fish (Stizostedion Canadense); --called also gray pike, blue pike, hornfish, land pike, sand pike,pickering, and pickerel.
To gaze beyond; to exceed in sharpness or persistence of seeingor of looking; hence, to stare out of countenance.
The sacrament of the Lord's Supper; the solemn act of ceremonyof commemorating the death of Christ, in the use of bread and wine,as the appointed emblems; the communion.-- See Sacrament.
In relation to, or in a line with, an axis; in the axial(magnetic) line.

The giant armadillo (Priodontes gigas) of tropical SouthAmerica. It becomes nearly five feet long including the tail. It isnoted for its burrowing powers, feeds largely upon dead animals, andsometimes invades human graves.
A mineral occurring in pale yellow or brownish hexagonalcrystals. It is an arseniate of lead.
A genus of leguminous plants growing in the tropics; coraltree; -- so called from its red flowers.
The central keel-bearing part of the sternum in birds.
Facing three ways; arranged in three vertical ranks, as theleaves of veratrum.
To design or purpose beforehand; to predetermine. Mitford.
A light fabric of wool, worn on the head by women; a cloud.
Of or pertaining to, or of the nature of, a lientery.-- n. (Med.)
To have in wrong estimation; to repute or estimate erroneously.
The tumid upper lip of certain mammals, as of a camel.

A soft, unctuous, or waxy substance, of a light brown color,into which the fat and muscle tissue of dead bodies sometimes areconverted, by long immersion in water or by burial in moist places.It is a result of fatty degeneration.
A writing or signature made by some person other than any ofthe parties thereto; -- opposed to autograph.
To lift or push from behind (one who is endeavoring to climb);to push up; hence, to assist in overcoming obstacles, or in makingadvancement. [Colloq. U. S.]
The state of being an accomplice; participation in guilt.

A white concretionary form of calcium carbonate, usually hardand semicrystalline. It is deposited from the water of springs orstreams holding lime in solution. Extensive deposits exist at Tivoli,near Rome.
One who has charge of money; a cash keeper; the officer who hascharge of the payments and receipts (moneys, checks, notes), of abank or a mercantile company.
To set aside or reject as spurious, as by marking with anobelus.
To repeat wrongly; to give a wrong version of. Gov. Winthrop.
An interval of a fifth; also, a part sung with such intervals.[Obs.] "He sang . . . a loud quynyble." Chaucer.
Performance to, or obtained from, valerian root; specifically,designating an acid which is usually called valeric acid.
The art of printing from the surface of type, plates, orengravings in relief, by means of a press; the work so done.MacKellar.
That variety of xylene, or dimethyl benzene, in which the twomethyl groups occupy the meta position with reference to each other.It is a colorless inf
A mineral related to the micas, but low in silica and yieldingbrittle folia with pearly luster.
To cause to be no longer deceived; to free from deception,fraud, fallacy, or mistake. South.
A hollow cylinder to contain air. It is closed above and openbelow, and has its open end plunged into water.
Being without gifts, especially native gifts or endowments.Cowper.
An apron or covering for the front of the person. [Obs.] Beau.& Fl.
A large and powerful hound formerly used in hunting the stag,the wolf, and other large animals. The breed is nearly extinct.
A woven silk stuff with transparent and colored figures; diaperwork.
The genus Ranunculus, of many species; some are common weeds,others are flowering plants of considerable beauty.
A fold of muscous membrane often found at the orifice of thevagina; the vaginal membrane.
The lower throat, or that part of the neck just above thebreast.
To present and institute in a benefice, when the personpresenting is both the patron and the ordinary; -- followed by to.
A former name for a euphorbiaceous genus (Hevea) of SouthAmerican trees, the principal source of caoutchouc.
In a ruminant manner; by ruminating, or chewing the cud.
A solid figure or body inclosed by ten plane surfaces. [Writtenalso, less correctly, decaedron.]
Pertaining to, obtained from, or containing, fluorine.
A comprehensive group of mankind, including those that haveprognathous jaws.
Characterized by short wings covered with feathers resemblingscales, as the penguins.-- n.
A valatile alkaloid extracted from Capsicum annuum or fromcapsicin.
One who maintains that points of the Hebrew word translated"Jehovah" are really the vowel points of the word "Adonai." SeeJehovist.
In old English law, a court, or mote, held in a port town.[Obs.] Blackstone.
To augment gradually in force or loudness, as the sound of anote.
A variety of anhydrite composed of contorted plates fancied toresemble pieces of tripe.
Of or pertaining to lines connecting places on the earth'ssurface which have a mean annual rainfall.-- n.
The young of a canine animal, esp. of the common dog; a whelp.
The property of a woman which, on her marriage, was not made apart of her dower, but remained her own.
The pistils of a flower, taken collectively. See Illust. ofCarpophore.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained fromatropine and certain other alkaloids, as a white crystallinesubstance slightly soluble in water.
Raised into a pile; collected into a crowd; heaped. [R.] Bacon.
To encircle with a garland, or with garlands. Sir P. Sidney.
The quality of being asinine; stupidity combined withobstinacy.
The science of the distribution and management of land.
To deprive of lead, as of a leaden coffin. [R.] Burke.
A cutting into, or opening of, the abdomen or the stomach.
In a virtual manner; in efficacy or effect only, and notactually; to all intents and purposes; practically.
Having a valence of one; capable of combining with, or of beingsubstituted for, one atom of hydrogen; monovalent; -- said of certainatoms and radicals.
An East Indian resin, of a pellucid white color, from whichsmall ornaments and toys are sometimes made.
Groats; coarse flour or meal. [Obs.] Sir. H. Wotton.
Strong, stiff, or hard, like a horn; resembling horn.Up stood the cornu reed. Milton.
Beneath or forward of the umbos of a bivalve shell.
A sulphur hydrocarbon, C4H4S, analogous to furfuran andbenzene, and acting as the base of a large number of substances whichclosely resemble the corresponding aromatic derivatives.
An enemy in war.And the stern joy which warriors feel In foemen worthy of theirsteel. Sir W. Scott
An extra exercise enjoined on students as a punishment. T.Warton.
A group of seven notes to be played in the time of four or six.
The act of enabling, or the state of being enabled; ability.Bacon.
Any plant of the genus Lechea, low North American herbs withbranching stems, and very small and abundant leaves and flowers.
One who conjures; one who calls, entreats, or charges in asolemn manner.
A thing to be noted or observed; a notable fact; -- chieflyused in the plural.
One of the wedgelike stones of which an arch is composed.
Of or pertaining to Tripoli or its inhabitants; Tripoline.-- n.
One of the two main arteries of the neck, by which blood isconveyed from the aorta to the head.
A large South American goatsucker (Nyctibius grandis).
Applied to a signature when the body of the instrument is inanother's handwriting. Burrill.
The process of bringing, or of coming, to maturity; hence,specifically, the process of suppurating perfectly; the formation ofpus or matter.
A genus of seals. It includes the common harbor seal and alliedspecies. See Seal.
Making a right angle; perpendicular, as two lines or two sidesof a triangle, which include a right angle.
Having no disk; appearing as a point and not expanded into adisk, as the image of a faint star in a telescope.
To declare or announce beforehand; to preannounce. Milman.
A mineral of a greenish yellow color; it is a silicate ofglucina, lime, and soda with fluorine. Called also leucophanite.
Suitable for membership in a club; sociable. [Humorous.] G. W.Curtis.
To inform, fill, or animate, excessively. [R.] Johnson.
Destitude of branches or shoots; without any valuable product;barren; naked.
The foot joint; in birds, the joint between the metatarsus andthe toes.
To relate as history; to chronicle; to historicize. [R.]Evelyn.
A disease of the eye, in which the eyelashes, being turned inupon the eyeball, produce constant irritation by the motion of thelids.
A connected series of military operations forming a distinctstage in a war; the time during which an army keeps the field.Wilhelm.
The quality or state of being angular; angularness.
A coral island or islands, consisting of a belt of coral reef,partly submerged, surrounding a central lagoon or depression; alagoon island.
Among Mohammedans, the last imam or leader of the faithful. TheSunni, the largest sect of the Mohammedans, believe that he is yet toappear.
One of the bifurcations of the brachial plates of a crinoid.
Persistent portions of a calyx or corolla; also, leaves whichdo not disarticulate from the stem, and hence remain for a long time.
Nascent epidermis, or external cuticle of plants in a formingcondition.
A hard chitinous or calcareous process or corpuscle, especiallya spicule of the Alcyonaria.
A kind of war hatchet used by the American Indians. It wasoriginally made of stone, but afterwards of iron.
One who fires or sets fire to anything; an incendiary. [R.] R.Carew.
Easily startled; apt to start; startish; skittish; -- saidespecially of a hourse. [Colloq.]
The fold of peritoneum which attaches the testis to the dorsalwall of the body cavity or scrotal sac.
An inferior tenant; one who rents a pendicle or croft. [Scot.]Jamieson.
In an excessive manner; excessively. [Obs.] Wiclif.
The art or act of varnishing in the Japanese manner.
The quality or condition of being a duke; also, the personalityof a duke. Massinger.
In a definite manner; with precision; precisely; determinately.

Any one of several small, fresh-water, cyprinoid fishes of thegenera Cobitis, Nemachilus, and allied genera, having six or morebarbules around the mouth. They are found in Europe and Asia. Thecommon European species (N. barbatulus) is used as a food fish.
A South African monkey (Cercopithecus pygerythrus, orLelandii). The upper parts are grayish green, finely specked withblack. The cheeks and belly are reddish white.
The office, position, or jurisdiction of a prefect; also, hisofficial residence.
A blackish lead-gray mineral, closely related to tetrahedrite.It is essentially a sulphide of arsenic and copper.
An electro-positive substance, which in electro-decompositionis evolved at the cathode; -- opposed to anion. Faraday.
To initiate the doctrines or principles of the Illuminati.
Quality or state of being sequacious; sequaciousness. Bacon.
An apparatus for measuring or determining the proportion ofnitrogen; a nitrometer.
Deductions and duties paid yearly out of a manor and lands, asrent charge, rent seck, pensions, annuities, and the like. [Writtenalso reprizes.] Burrill.
A quantity consisting of three terms, connected by the sign +or -; as, x + y + z, or ax + 2b - c2.
One of the casks stowed in the wings of a vessel's hold, beingsmaller than such as are stowed more amidships. Totten.
A name given to various lichens gathered for dyeing. [Scot.]
A scale series of four sounds, of which the extremes, or firstand last, constituted a fourth. These extremes were immutable; thetwo middle sounds were changeable.
To keep under, or in subjection; to suppress. [Obs.] Spenser.
The hall where a guild or corporation usually assembles; atownhall.
Capable of being corroded; corrosible. Sir T. Browne.
An instrument for examining the interior of the rectum, theurethra, and the bladder.
An Indian monkey (Macacus Rhesus), protected by the Hindoos assacred. See Rhesus.
A communication of news; an announcement. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A form of cymose inflorescence with all the flowers on one sideof the rachis, usually causing it to curl; -- called also a uniparoushelicoid cyme.
Any one of numerous species of Asiatic finches of the generaCarpodacus, and Propasser, and allied genera, in which the male ismore or less colored with rose red.
The external organs of generation, especially of the female;the vulva.
An instrument for observing the clouds and their velocity.
A mat or screen of fibers, as of the kuskus grass, hung at adoor or window and kept wet to moisten and cool the air as it enters.[India]
Herring taken and cured or smoked near Quoddy Head, Maine, ornear the entrance of Passamaquoddy Ray.
The doctrine that there is a tendency throughout nature towardimprovement. J. Sully.
A shelly plate found in the terminal chambers of ammoniteshells. Some authors consider them to be jaws; others, opercula.
A garment for women, consisting of chemise and drawers unitedin one. [U. S.]
The common newt; -- called also asker, eft, evat, and ewt.
To declare war with certain ceremonies. [Obs.] Holland.
The supposed faculty of perceiving subterraneous springs andcurrents by sensation; -- so called from one Bleton, of France.
Any coral of the genus Millepora, having the surface nearlysmooth, and perforated with very minute unequal pores, or cells. Theanimals are hydroids, not Anthozoa. See Hydrocorallia.
A cutaneous eruption, consisting of large, round pustules, uponan indurated and inflamed base. Dunglison.
To daub, smear, or spread, as with mud, etc. [Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
A tree (Citrus decumana) and its fruit, which is a largespecies of orange; -- called also forbidden fruit, and pompelmous.
A crystallizable, sugarlike substance, with a slightly sweetishtaste, obtained from the gentian.
A coarse kind of linen; -- called also harden. [Prov. Eng.]
Characteristic quality of a woman, such as softness,luxuriousness, delicacy, or weakness, which is unbecoming a man;womanish delicacy or softness; -- used reproachfully of men. Milton.
A composite plant (Erigeron Canadensis), which is a commonweed.
Having the edge broken like battlements; -- said of a bearingsuch as a fess, bend, or the like.
A clamorous, quarrelsome, noisy fellow; a wrangler. [R] Shak.
The quality or state of being prosaic; a prosaic manner orstyle. [R.] Poe.
The kestrel; -- called also windbibber, windcuffer, windfanner.[Prov. Eng.]
Dimness or obscurity of sight, dependent upon a speck on thecornea; also, the speck itself.
The state of a pluralist; the holding of more than oneecclesiastical living at a time. [Eng.]
Tired out with excessive waking or watching. [Obs.] Chaucer.
In an artful manner; with art or cunning; skillfully;dexterously; craftily.
The process of determining the solid or cubic contents of abody.
Given to light, familiar talk; talkative. Lady M. W. Montagu.
A variety of cryptocrystalline of a leek-green color.
A measure of area, or superficies, containing a hundred ares,or 10,000 square meters, and equivalent to 2.471 acres.
A composition in a soft, rural style, generally in 6-8 or 12-8time.
Any violent catastrophe, involving sudden and extensive changesof the earth's surface.
An element that in combination produces amphid salt; -- appliedby Berzelius to oxygen, sulphur, selenium, and tellurium. [R.]
Any imperfect development of the body, or any anomaly oforganization.
A pursuer; a persecutor; a censorious critic. [Obs.] Bailey.
A disease of the teeth, which causes them to loosen and fallout of their sockets.
A round-toed, armed covering for the feet, worn during a partof the sixteenth century in both military and civil dress.
The quality or state of being negligent; lack of due diligenceor care; omission of duty; habitual neglect; heedlessness.
That branch of philosophy which treats of the constitution,phenomena, and development of human society; social science. H.Spencer.

A genus of edentates, covered with large, hard, triangularscales, with sharp edges that overlap each other like tiles on aroof. They inhabit the warmest parts of Asia and Africa, and feed onants. Called also Scaly anteater. See Pangolin.
The state or quality of being immane; barbarity. [R.] Shak.
An order of mandibulate insects including grasshoppers,locusts, cockroaches, etc. See Illust. under Insect.
Pertaining to the upper portion of the Laurentian rocks. T. S.Hunt.
One who commits a tort or trespass; a trespasser; a tortfeasor. Ayliffe.
A light, loose over-garment, like a smock frock, wornespecially by workingmen in France; also, a loose coat of anymaterial, as the undress uniform coat of the United States army.
One of the two double-pointed teeth which intervene between thecanines (cuspids) and the molars, on each side of each jaw. SeeTooth, n.
A neutral; one who professes or practices neutrality. Milman.
An artificial red or violet dyestuff consisting of a complexsulphur derivative of certain aromatic diamines, and obtained as adark crystalline powder; -- called also phenylene violet.
A grantitoid variety of rhyolite, common in Nevada.
The state of a woman bringing forth a child, or being in labor;parturition.
A vessel with a sharp bow, built and rigged for fast sailing.-- Clip"per-built` (, a.
A microscopic cell in the structure of an egg, animal, orplant.
To transfer (as sheets of partly dried pulp) from the wireclotch mold to a felt blanket, for further drying.
pres. indic. 1st & 3d pers. sing. of Forwete. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The longest note formerly used, equal to two longs, or fourbreves; a large.
A denial of the existence of the universe as distinct from God.
The tongue, or lingua, of an insect. See Hymenoptera.
The Roman personification of the dawn of day; the goddess ofthe morning. The poets represented her a rising out of the ocean, ina chariot, with rosy fingers dropping gentle dew.
A kind of French stewpan with a steamtight lid. Knight.
Having the form of a gland or nut; resembling a gland.
Bringing forth, or about to bring forth, young; fruitful. Jer.Tailor.
To furnish (a vessel) with too long or too heavy a mast ormasts.
Having the uterus double; of or pertaining to the Didelphia.
The pastoral staff of a bishop (also of an archbishop, beingthe symbol of his office as a shepherd of the flock of God.
To adhere to, advocate, or inculcate, the doctrine ofpolytheism. Milman.
A camp, esp. one with an inclosure of travelers' wagons fortemporary defense. [South Africa]
A modification of the kaleidoscope; -- used to reflect imagesso as to form beautiful designs.
A process for checking the fermentation of the must of grapes.
A monument consisting of three stones; especially, such amonument forming a kind of doorway, as among the ancient Celts.
I have sinned; -- used colloquially to express confession oracknowledgment of an offense. Aubrey.
A genus of bulbous plants, of the order Amaryllidace,cultivated as greenhouse plants on account of their beauty.
A halfpenny. [Spelt also baubee.] [Scot. & Prov. Eng.]
Having a tendency to prevent the development of anything,especially of a disease.
Boring, or adapted for boring; -- said of certain Hymenoptera,as the sawflies.
Of or pertaining to the continents of Europe and Asia combined.
A hydrous arsenite of cobalt, occuring in small red crystals,allied to erythrite.
A Russian and German liqueur, consisting of a sweetened spiritflavored with caraway seeds.
A spectro-electric tube in which the decomposition of a liquidby the passage of an electric spark is observed. Knight.
The angular distance of a celestial object below the horizon.
A white crystallized substance, C12H8NH, derived from anilineand other amines.
Having a small, distinct point; apiculate. Henslow.
Inducing or stimulating the secretion of mucus; blennogenous.
A small job; in the pl., the regular or daily light work of ahousehold or farm, either within or without doors. [U. S.]
A hill of compact, unstratified, glacial drift or till, usuallyelongate or oval, with the larger axis parallel to the former localglacial motion.
A spot or fleck on the sun brighter than the surroundingsurface.
A compound radical, C3H5, regarded as the essential radical ofglycerin. It is metameric with allyl. Called also propenyl.

A name of several plants having red roots, as the New Jerseytea (see under Tea), the gromwell, the bloodroot, and the Lachnanthestinctoria, an endogenous plant found in sandy swamps from RhodeIsland to Florida.

A male of the human species castrated; commonly, one of a classof such persons, in Oriental countries, having charge of the women'sapartments. Some of them, in former times, gained high official rank.
To cause to hang down; to depress at the side; as, to slouththe hat.
The inner or lower layer of the blastoderm; -- called alsoendoderm, entoderm, and sometimes hypoderm. See Illust. ofBlastoderm, Delamination, and Ectoderm.
A punch-cutting tool, or machine for deepening and enlargingthe spaces between the teeth of a worn saw.
An instrument for measuring the limits of distincts vision indifferent individuals, and thus determiming the proper focal lengthof a lens for correcting imperfect sight. Brande & C.
Of, pertaining to, or in the form of, a nodule or knot.
The way in which a leaf is sometimes folded in the bud.
A shield of basket work formerly used by archers as a shelterfrom the enemy's missiles.
Puppets caused to perform evolutions or dramatic scenes bymeans of machinery; also, the representations in which they are used.
An alkaloid extracted from the shoots of the vetch, red clover,etc., as a white crystalline substance.
Coarse and ruddy-faced; fat and ruddy; high colored; frowzy.
Similarity of form; resemblance in external characters, whilewidely different in fundamental structure; resemblance in geometricground form. See Homophyly, Promorphology.
A white crystalline glucoside extracted from the bastard hemp(Datisca cannabina).
That may expire; capable of being brought to an end.
A toll paid for the privilege of taking up ballast in a port orharbor.
A vessel, commonly or earthenware, for earth in which plantsare grown.
To turn away from the cast; to confuse as to which way is east;to cause to lose one's bearings. [R.] Bp. Warburton.
Of the nature and consistence of gelatin or the jelly;resembling jelly; viscous.
Conveying impressions from the surface of the body to thespinal cord; -- said of certain nerves. Opposed to exodic.
Possessing the property of touching at two points.-- n.
One who harangues, or is fond of haranguing; a declaimer.With them join'd all th' harangues of the throng, That thought to getpreferment by the tongue. Dryden.
To cover with snow, or as with snow. [Poetic] Shak. Dryden.
The thick shell or sheild which cover the back of the tortoise,or turtle, the crab, and other crustaceous animals.
The common marmoset (Hapale vulgaris). Formerly, the name wasalso applied to other species of the same genus.
Having the form of a petal; petaloid; petal-shaped.
The inflorescence of a compound flower in which many floretsare gathered into a involucrate head.
To remove, or take away, from a stack; to remove, as somethingconstituting a stack.
To deal or distribute wrongly, as cards; to make a wrongdistribution.
A genus of bivalve Mollusca which includes the true oysters.
To sew up; to inclose by a seam; hence, to include; to contain.Camden.
An olive-green mineral, a hydrous arseniate of copper; oliveore.
An organic radical, C3H5, existing especially in oils of garlicand mustard.
To dig Horizontally; to cut a horizontal gallery or tunnel.Tomlinson.
Furnished with talents; possessing skill or talent; mentallygifted. Abp. Abbot (1663).
Covered with scum; of the nature of scum. Sir P. Sidney.
To divest of human qualities, such as pity, tenderness, etc.;as, dehumanizing influences.
The act or result of dispersing or scattering; dispersion.Darwin.
One of the larger measures of work, amounting to one millionergs; -- called also megalerg.
To toddle; to walk unsteadily, like a child or an old man;hence, to do anything slowly or feebly.
One employed to steer a vessel; a helmsman; a steersman.Dryden.
In the direction of the sun's apparent motion, or from the eastsouthward and westward, and so around the circle; also, in the samedirection as the movement of the hands of a watch lying face upward.
A customhouse officer who watches the landing of goods frommerchant vessels, in order to secure payment of duties. Swift.
An apple-green mineral, a hydrous arseniate of nickel, cobalt,and magnesia; -- so named from the Sierra Cabrera, Spain.
One who follows the sea as a business; a mariner; a sailor.
Worthy of being wished for; desirable. [Obs.] Puller.
Pertaining to, or resembling, Briareus, a giant fabled to havea hundred hands; hence, hundred-handed or many-handed.
A genus of tough, leathery seaweeds, usually of a dull brownishgreen color; rockweed.
A kind of dock (Rumex Patientia), less common in America thanin Europe; monk's rhubarb.
A place for dregs and dirt; a sink; a sewer. [Obs.] Latimer.
The business or the work of a tailor or a tailoress.
Pertaining to an embryo, or the initial state of any organ;embryonic.
An ornamental finish on the top of a wall or ridge of a roof.
A bundle containing the papers in reference to some matter.
Pertaining to, or contained in, archives or records. Tooke.
The dignity or jurisdiction of a viscount. Sir B. Burke.
A nitrogenous organic base obtained by the oxidation ofamarine, and regarded as a derivative of benzoic aldehyde. It isobtained in long white crystalline tufts, -- whence its name.
Literally, those who are enlightened; -- variously applied asfollows: -
A watchword given only to officers of guards; -- distinguishedfrom countersign, which is given to all guards.

A Scripture name of the Supreme Being, by which he was revealedto the Jews as their covenant God or Sovereign of the theocracy; the"ineffable name" of the Supreme Being, which was not pronounced bythe Jews.
One who exhibits; one who presents a petition, charge or bill.Shak.

Of, pertaining to, or designating, a condition assumed by theimago of certain Neuroptera, after exclusion from the pupa. In thisstate the insect is soft, and has not fully attained its maturecoloring.
To deliver from the state of a fool; to awaken the mind of; toundeceive.
Of or pertaining to asbestus, or partaking of its nature;incombustible; asbestic.
The act of thinking worthy; honor. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.
In relief; pertaining to sculpture in relief, especially ofmetal; also, pertaining to chasing such as surface ornamentation inmetal.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, pegmatite; as, the pegmaticstructure of certain rocks resembling graphic granite.
A youth beloved by Venus for his beauty. He was killed in thechase by a wild boar.
To tread down; to trample upon. [Obs.]In hell shall they be all fortroden of devils. Chaucer.
One who practices simony, or who buys or sells preferment inthe church. Ayliffe.
Made of silk; having a silky or flaxlike appearance. Coles.
A sycophant; a fawner; a toady. Cf. Bootlick. Shak.
Pertaining to the Franks, or their language; Frankish.
An African antelope (Hippotragus Bakeri). Its face is stripedwith black and white.
The active young larva of any oil beetle. It has feet armedwith three claws, and is parasitic on bees. See Illust. of Oilbeetle, under Oil.
Any one of several small German and Dutch coins, worth fromabout one and a half cents to about five cents.
The state of a cuckold; cuckolds, collectively. Addison.
The qualities and practices of a slut; sluttishness;slatternlines. Drayton.
A colorless oil (quickly becoming brown), with a pleasant odor,obtained by the decomposition of ericolin.
A penalty or fine for neglect. [Local, New England]
A rounded mass or irregular shape; a little knot or lump.
An explosive consisting of a mixture of powdered aluminium andnitrate of ammonium.
An instrument used for smoothing the surface of a core.
One of a peculiar kind of internal buds, or germs, produced inthe interior of certain Bryozoa and sponges, especially in the fresh-water species; -- also called winter buds.
A summary, plan, or scheme of something proposed, affording aprospect of its nature; especially, an exposition of the scheme of anunpublished literary work.
An animal one year old, or in the second year of its age; --applied chiefly to cattle, sheep, and horses.
Capable of being designated or distinctly marked out;distinguishable. Boyle.
The outer boundary of a body or figure, or the sum of all thesides.
A large South American bird (Dicholophus, or Cariama cristata)related to the cranes. It is often domesticated. Called also cariama.
A long, flat-bottomed canoe, used for the navigation of riversand lagoons in Central America. Squier.
A cake made of the meal of Indian corn, wrapped in a coveringof husks or paper, and baked under the embers. [U.S.] Bartlett.
A kind of large ship formerly used by the Spaniards andPortuguese in the East India trade; a galleon. [Spelt also carrack.]The bigger whale like some huge carrack law. Waller.
To bring to a certain degree of consistency, by evaporation, asa fluid. Graduating engine, a dividing engine. See Dividing engine,under Dividing.
The process or act of baffling, or of being baffled;frustration; check.
A grayish or greenish compact rock, composed of feldspar andaugite, and allied to basalt.
The acts, arts, or boastful pretensions of a quack; falsepretensions to any art; empiricism. Carlyle.
A kind of dress goods made of cotton or woolen, with a glossysurface resembling satin.
The officer in a religious house who had the care of theinfirmary. [Obs.]

A class of objects divided into several subordinate species; aclass more extensive than a species; a precisely defined and exactlydivided class; one of the five predicable conceptions, or sorts ofterms.
In an atomic manner; in accordance with the atomic philosophy.
Work done by a team, as distinguished from that done bypersonal labor.
The state or quality of being slick; smoothness; sleekness.
A part of mechanics which treats of the motion, range, time offlight, etc., of bodies thrown or driven through the air by animpelling force.
To conform, or cause to conform, to the religion of Islam.
Said before, or in a preceding part; already described oridentified.
An imperfection on the inside of the hind leg in horses,different from a curb, but at the same height, and frequentlyinjuring the sale of the animal by growing to an unsightly size.Craig.
One of the nine honorable ordinaries, consisting of two broadbands of the width of the bar, issuing, respectively from the dexterand sinister bases of the field and conjoined at its center.
Work aside from regular work; subordinate or secondarybusiness.
Pertaining to, or situated near, the calcar of the brain.
Elevated, -- as a toe, when raised so high that the tip doesnot touch the ground.
A classic idiom or expression; a classicalism. C. Kingsley.
The quality or tenure of the fee held by a vavasor; also, thelands held by a vavasor.
Gentle heat; moderate warmth; tepidness. Arbuthnot.
According to desert (whether good or evil); justly.
Sitting, as a lion or other beast. Sejant rampant, sitting withthe forefeet lifted up. Wright.
A South American bird of the flycatcher family. (Tityrainquisetor).
A rope applied to the fore yardarm, to change the position ofthe foresail.
The highest or utmost degree; the best of anything. [Colloq.]
Any written or other legal evidence of the conveyance ofproperty; a conveyance; a deed.
A perennial herb (Phryma Leptostachya), having slender seedlikefruits.
The state of abounding, or being covered, with hair. Johnson.
One who is engaged in lumbering as a business or employment.[U.S.]

A double star; -- applied to the nucleus of a cell, when,during cell division, the loops of the nuclear network separate intotwo groups, preparatory to the formation of two daughter nuclei. SeeKaryokinesis.
One who violates; an infringer; a profaner; a ravisher.
Purulent inflammation of the cellular or areolar tissue.
A subclass of fishes including all the ordinary bony fishes asdistinguished from the ganoids.
A narrow circle of persons associated by common interests orfor the accomplishment of a common purpose; -- generally used in abad sense.
The state of an heir; succession by inheritance. Burke.
Capable of being obtained or moved by petition. [Obs.] Bailey.
An herb (Pilea pumila) of the Nettle family, having a smooth,juicy, pellucid stem; -- called also clearweed.
Pertaining to, or designating, any one of three acids obtainedby the distillation of citric acid, and called respectivelycitraconic, itaconic, and mesaconic acid.
A minute spherical or rounded structure; as blood, lymph, andpus corpuscles, minute fungi, spores, etc.
Partaking of the qualities of a bear; resembling a bear intemper or manners. Harris.
To stand apart from; top leave off; to desist. [Obs.] Raleigh.
One who toots; one who plays upon a pipe or horn. B. Jonson.
A genus of intestinal worms which includes the common tapewormsof man. See Tapeworm.
Two-nerved; -- applied to leaves which have two longitudinalribs or nerves.
A medicine adapted to relieve or cure disease of the kidneys.
One of the subdivisions of the trachea or windpipe; esp. one ofthe two primary divisions.
To split into scales, especially to become converted intoscales at the result of heat or decomposition.
A combination of wheels, and their connection, in a machine ormechanism.
The act of borrowing or exchanging. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Characterized by waving or flamelike curves, as in the traceryof windows, etc.; -- said of the later (15th century) French Gothicstyle.
A Turkish saint; a kind of dervish, regarded by the people as asaint: also, a hermit.
To practice an exercise or exercises; to train one's self.
A salmon returning from the sea the second time. [Prov. Eng.]
Divination by means of the ascent or motion of smoke.
The red oxide of copper; red copper; an important ore ofcopper, occurring massive and in isometric crystals.
A glass used in subliming camphor. [Spelled also bombolo andbumbolo.]
An insoluble albuminous body formed from casein and otherproteid substances by the action of gastric juice. Meissner.

Pertaining to, or derived from, linoleum, or linseed oil;specifically (Chem.), designating an organic acid, a thin yellow oil,found combined as a salt of glycerin in oils of linseed, poppy, hemp,and certain nuts.
The quality or condition of being bunchy; knobbiness.
Pertaining to the catamenia, or menstrual discharges.
Of or pertaining to the external organs of generation.
A formulary or prescription for making some combination,mixture, or preparation of materials; a receipt; especially, aprescription for medicine.
A pneumatic or hydraulic cushion for a falling weight, as inthe valve gear of a steam engine, to prevent shock.
An old name for the judges of the higher English courts.
To draw towards a common center or a middle line. Huxley.
Brightness or strength of color. [R.] E. Waterhouse.
Opposition of action; counteraction or contrariety of things orprinciples.
A state of difficulty or perplexity; doubt; uncertainty.
Amphibole resulting from the alternation of pyroxene byparamorphism. It is not uncommon in massive eruptive rocks.
A lens convex on one side and concave on the other.
The hipped part of a roof which is hipped only for a part ofits height, leaving a truncated gable.
To sit badly or imperfectly upon; to misbecome. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A liquid hydrocarbon, C10H20, of the ethylene series, regardedas a polymeric form of amylene.
Overalls of sheepskin or leather, usually open at the back,worn, esp. by cowboys, to protect the legs from thorny bushes, as inthe chaparral; -- called also chapareras or colloq. chaps. [Sp.Amer.]
Devotion to the pursuit of wealth; worldliness. Carlyle.
One skilled in the art or science of music; esp., a skilledsinger, or performer on a musical instrument.
Reduced to ashes by burning; thoroughly consumed. [Obs.] Bacon.
A bed of earth heated by fermenting manure or other substances,and covered with glass, intended for raising early plants, or fornourishing exotics.
To insure; to covenant to indemnify for loss, or to pay aspecified sum at death. See Insure.
An epidemic disease of the silkworm, characterized by thepresence of minute vibratory corpuscles in the blood.
The horizontal thrust or pressure of an arch or vault upon theabutments. [R.] Knight.
One who, or that which, inclines; specifically, an inclineddial.
The vessel which carries the commanding officer of a fleet orsquadron and flies his distinctive flag or pennant.
The art or practice of disputation or controversy, especiallyon religious subjects; that branch of theological science whichpertains to the history or conduct of ecclesiastical controversy.
Pure silica, like quartz, but crystallizing in hexagonaltables. It is found in trachyte and similar rocks.
A vessel with a spout, in which tea is made, and from which itis poured into teacups.
A boxlike structure with funnel-shaped traps for catching eels;an eelbuck.
One instructed in the mysteries of a secret system. Carlyle.
A tavern; a house where liquors are retailed. [Obs. as anEnglish word.]

A warning or citation to appear in court; a writtennotification signed by the proper officer, to be served on a person,warning him to appear in court at a day specified, to answer to theplaintiff, testify as a witness, or the like.
A thin stuff made of the finest wool or silk, or of wool andsilk.
In a dry manner; not succulently; without interest; withoutsympathy; coldly.

A telescope with a diagonal eyepiece, suspended vertically ingimbals by the object end beneath a fixed diagonal plane mirror. Itis used for delineating landscapes, by means of a pencil at the eyeend which leaves the delineation on paper.
A piece of metal in the form of a coin, struck with a device,and intended to preserve the remembrance of a notable event or anillustrious person, or to serve as a reward.

A large brass wind instrument, formerly used in the orchestraand in military bands, having a loud tone, deep pitch, and a compassof three octaves; -- now generally supplanted by bass and contrabasstubas. Moore (Encyc. of Music).
The food supplied to the Israelites in their journey throughthe wilderness of Arabia; hence, divinely supplied food. Ex. xvi. 15.
Having the ends terminating in rounded protuberances or singleballs; -- said of a cross.
A town or village, or part of a town or village, assigned to abody of troops for quarters; temporary shelter or place of rest foran army; quarters.
The crime of buying or selling ecclesiastical preferment; thecorrupt presentation of any one to an ecclesiastical benefice formoney or reward. Piers Plowman.
Of or pertaining to Libya, the ancient name of that part ofAfrica between Egypt and the Atlantic Ocean, or of Africa as a whole.
The arrangement of flowers in a cluster; the science of therelative position of flowers; inflorescence.
An assumed name; a fanciful epithet or appellation; a nickname.[Sometimes less correctly written soubriquet.]
Masonry constructed of unsquared stones that are irregular insize and shape.
A watchman; an officer of customs or police. [India]
One who sets right; one who does justice or redresses wrong.Shelton.

A diminution or softening of statement for the sake of avoidingcensure or increasing the effect by contrast with the moderationshown in the form of expression; as, " a citizen of no mean city,"that is, of an illustrious city.

Sound of the kind or quality heard in speech or song in theconsonants b, v, d, etc., and in the vowels; sonant, or intonated,utterance; tone; -- distinguished from mere breath sound as heard inf, s, sh, etc., and also whisper.

One who pays; one who compensates, rewards, or requites;specifically, an officer or agent of a government, a corporation, oran employer, whose duty it is to pay salaries, wages, etc., and keepaccount of the same.
The tops or heads of stream-work which lie over the stream oftin.
A privy, or water-closet, esp. in a camp, hospital, etc.

A musical instrument, of unknown character, supposed by some tohave been used by the people of Gath, and thence obtained by David.It is mentioned in the title of Psalms viii., lxxxi., and lxxxiv. Dr.W. Smith.
That part of grammar which treats of the quantity of syllables,of accent, and of the laws of versification or metrical composition.
A variety of jade or nephrite, -- used in New Zealand for themanufacture of axes and weapons.
Lamentation; threnody; a dirge. Shak.The threns . . . of the prophet Jeremiah. Jer. Taylor.
Pertaining to endosmose; of the nature endosmose; osmotic.Carpenter.
The ankle bone, or hock bone; the bone of the tarsus whicharticulates with the tibia at the ankle.
The act or habit of eating earth. See Dirt eating, under Dirt.Dunglison.
A genus of large sea birds, including the albatross. SeeAlbatross.
Appropriate to, or like, a parson; -- used in disparagement.[Colloq.]
Money paid for the maintenance of a beacon; also, beacons,collectively.
The track of man or beast as followed by the scent. [Scot.]Halliwell.
To rise, or cause to rise, in a swarm or swarms. [R.] Shak.Cowper.
A remedy which has an action similar to that of another remedy,and hence increases the efficiency of that remedy when combined withit.
A piece of malleable iron, wrought into the shape of a bar inthe middle, but unwrought at the ends.
One who makes his mark, instead of writing his name, in signingdocuments. Burrill.
The large process at the proximal end of the ulna whichprojects behind the articulation with the humerus and forms the bonyprominence of the elbow.
A kind of diorite or diabase containing imbedded whitishspherules, which give the rock a spotted appearance.
A compound of the so-called margaric acid with a base.
To remain sitting, or in session, longer than, or beyond thetime of; to outstay.
To set in, or punish with, the pillory; to pillory. [R.]
A small column or pillar, used as a monument, milestone, etc.

A small fish, about three inches in length, of the Herringfamily (Engraulis encrasicholus), caught in vast numbers in theMediterranean, and pickled for exportation. The name is also appliedto several allied species.
To baptize; -- used in contempt by the Reformers. [Obs.]Tyndale.
Pertaining to, or of the nature of, a falcon or hawk; hawklike.Lowell.
One who treks before or first; a pioneer. [South Africa]
A block of wood, usually fastened to some spar, and shaped toreceive the end of another spar.
A genus of shrubs growing in Australia, having beautiful, hard,dry, evergreen leaves.
A word which is joined to another so closely as to lose itsproper accent, as the pronoun thee in prithee (pray thee).
The Australian white-quilled honey eater (Entomyza albipennis).
A white crystalline solid, from ammonia by replacement of anequivalent of hydrogen by acetyl.
To reduce to a lower rating or rank; to degrade. Marryat.
Gout in the joints of the foot; -- applied also to gout inother parts of body.
To become putrid; to decay offensively; to rot. Isa. 1. 6.
Of or pertaining to the palm of the hand or the sole of thefoot.
The dorsal lobe or branch of a parapodium. See Parapodium.
The upper and outer element of periotic bone, -- in man forminga part of the temporal bone.
The radical UO2, conveniently regarded as a residue of manyuranium compounds.
As much as will fill a book; a book full. Shak.-- a.
A genus of terrestrial gastropods, having transparent, verythin, and delicate shells, -- whence the name.
The portion of movable estate to which the children areentitled upon the death of the father.
Of or pertaining to pectin; specifically, designating an acidobtained from ordinary vegetable jelly (pectin) as an amorphoussubstance, tough and horny when dry, but gelatinous when moist.
To make hostile; to cause to become an enemy. [Obs.] A. Seward.
A white metallic alloy; which is made into spoons, forks,teapots, etc. British plate or German silver. See German silver,under German.
A system of apparatus for electric signals providing forautomatic transmission of a definite number of different signals orcalls, as in connection with hotel annunciators.
Of or pertaining to the Avesta or the language of the Avesta. --n.
Having, or characterized by, three unequal axes intersecting atoblique angles. See the Note under crystallization.
A heap or pile of hay, usually covered with thatch forpreservation in the open air.
The process of forming an ulcer, or of becoming ulcerous; thestate of being ulcerated; also, an ulcer.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid amide derivative ofsuccinic acid, obtained as a white crystalline substance, and forminga series of salts.
A small, two-wheeled, hooded vehicle drawn by one more men.[Japan]
The state or dignity of a thane; thanehood; also, theseignioralty of a thane.
An assistant editor, as of a periodical or journal.
A cup or bowl; especially, the cup used in the sacrament of theLord's Supper.
A leader of the rabble; one who attempts to control themultitude by specious or deceitful arts; an unprincipled and factiousmob orator or political leader.
The person to whom a note or bill is indorsed, or assigned byindorsement.
A genus of singing birds including the true thrushes.
One who nurses; a nurse; one who cherishes or encouragesgrowth.
Ornamentation by means of lacquer painted or carved, or simplycolored, sprinkled with gold or the like; -- said especially ofOriental work of this kind.
A small, African, foxlike animal (Vulpes zerda) of a pale fawncolor, remarkable for the large size of its ears.
Swarming and devastating like locusts. [R.] Tennyson.
To overwhelm with water; to drench; to drown. [Obs.] Shak.
The act or process of carding coarsely. Scribbing machine, themachine used for the first carding of wool or other fiber; -- calledalso scribbler.
A personification, in German and Scandinavian mythology, of aspirit natural power supposed to work mischief and ruin, esp. tochildren.
A chinese reed instrument, with tubes, blown by the mouth.
A kind of masonry in which the outer faces of the wall areashlar, the space between being filled with broken stone and mortar.Cross layers of stone are interlaid as binders. [R.] Weale.
Olefiant gas, or ethylene; hence, by extension, any one of theseries of unsaturated hydrocarbons of which ethylene is a type. SeeEthylene.
One who is versed in ethics, or has written on ethics.
A division of Artiodactyla having four stomachs. This divisionincludes the camels, deer, antelopes, goats, sheep, neat cattle, andallies.
A metameric segment of the cerebro-spinal nervous system.
A beverage of molasses and water, seasoned with vinegar andginger. [U. S.]
Rising to a point or head; conical; pointed; crested. Wiseman.
A swivel at one end of a ropewalk, used in laying the strands.
A wastebook, in which entries of transactions are made as theytake place.

The second month in the year, said to have been introduced intothe Roman calendar by Numa. In common years this month containstwenty-eight days; in the bissextile, or leap year, it has twenty-nine days.
A radical, of the aromatic series, regarded as an essentialingredient of certain compounds found in the waxy resin of anAustralian species of fig.
A tailor's assistant for repairing garments; -- called alsobusheler. [Local, U.S.]
To concert or arrange beforehand; to settle by previousagreement.
Eatable growth of grass for horses and cattle, esp. that ofaftermath.
Carried; conveyed; supported; defrayed. See Bear, v. t.
The edible nut of a forest tree (Castanea vesce) of Europe andAmerica. Commonly two or more of the nuts grow in a prickly bur.
A soft, effeminate person; a voluptuary. [R.] Bp. Woolton. .
The expectoration of blood, due usually to hemorrhage from themucous membrane of the lungs.
From head to foot; at all points. "He was armed cap-a-pie."Prescott.
A small piece of inclosed ground. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
A tendency in the end of a magnetic needle to point to thenorth. Faraday.
Causing the ejection of matter from the stomach; emetic.
A body of troops, whether cavalry, artillery, infantry, ormixed, consisting of two or more regiments, under the command of abrigadier general.
A wheel with cogs or teeth; a gear wheel. See Illust. ofGearing.
To become loose; to become less tight, firm, or compact. S.Sharp.
Having the form of tussocks; full of, or covered with,tussocks, or tufts.
A stone composed of sand or grit; -- so called because it iseasily cut or wrought.
A Spanish dance, or the lively music which accompanies it.
That class of Mollusca which includes the bivalve shells; theLamellibranchiata. See Mollusca.

A form of sentence among the ancient Syracusans by which theybanished for five years a citizen suspected of having dangerousinfluence or ambition. It was similar to the ostracism in Athens; butolive leaves were used instead of shells for ballots.
A poisonous alkaloid resembling veratrine, and found with it inwhite hellebore (Veratrum album); -- called also jervina.
A genus of small rubiaceous herbs, having tetramerous salveformblue or white flower. There are about twenty species, natives ofNorth America. Also, a plant of this genus.
A surety, under the old writ of mainprise, for a prisoner'sappearance in court at a day.
A one-horse carriage with two seats and a calash top.
The period of natural cessation of menstruation. See Change oflife, under Change.
Of or pertaining to accent; characterized or formed by accent.
The state of a part which, from having been soft, has becomehard and swollen by the accumulation of blood in the erectile tissue.
A lighthouse, or the apparatus placed in it for giving light.
A tool employed by blacksmiths for punching or enlarging thenail holes in a horseshoe.
A grove of shrubs or low trees under taller ones. Wordsworth.
A strip of tender flesh on either side of the vertebral columnunder the short ribs, in the hind quarter of beef and pork. Itconsists of the psoas muscles.
A woman's light scarflike head covering, usually knit orcrocheted of wool.
To convey by means of a vehicle; to ride in a vehicle. Carlyle.

A slackening or arrest of the blood current in the vessels, duenot to a lessening of the heart's beat, but presumably to someabnormal resistance of the capillary walls. It is one of thephenomena observed in the capillaries in inflammation.

One who dances at the opera, not singly, but in groups orfigures; an accessory character on the stage, who figures in itsscenes, but has nothing to say; hence, one who figures in any scene,without taking a prominent part.
In a saucy manner; impudently; with impertinent boldness.Addison.

An inversion of the order of words or phrases, when repeated orsubsequently referred to in a sentence; thus,If e'er to bless thy sons My voice or hands deny, These hands letuseful skill forsake, This voice in silence die. Dwight.
The art or practice of defining words; definition of words.
A female slave, or one bound to service without wages, asdistinguished from a hired servant.
One who enacts a law; one who decrees or establishes as a law.Atterbury.
The doctrine and ceremonies of the Church of Rome; popery. [R.]Whitgift.
The practice or faculty of subsisting on many kinds of food.
Like a carrot in color or in taste; -- an epithet given toreddish yellow hair, etc.
A steward or butler of a monastery or chapter; one who hascharge of procuring and keeping the provisions.
A shrike or butcher bird; -- written also matagasse. [Prov.Eng.]
Any one of three metameric radicals which are characteristicrespectively of the three xylenes.
A hive for a swarm of bees. Also used figuratively.
The science which relates to mammals or the Mammalia. SeeMammalia.
A dry, scaly eruption on the skin; especially, a ringworm.
An alkaloid extracted from the root of the pellitory of Spain(Anacyclus pyrethrum).
The system and influences of a monastic life; monasticism.
The concurrence of two vowels in two successive words orsyllables. Pope.
The hollow beneath the junction of the arm and shoulder; theaxilla.
The layer of vascular connective tissue lining the medullarycavities of bone.
Painting in shades of one color; monochrome. Mollett.
Large; strong; -- from the gigantic bones shown atRoncesvalles, and alleged to be those of old heroes. [Obs.]
A North American rodent, so named because it is said to make abooming noise. See Sewellel.
A chicken; -- used as a diminutive or pet name, especially incalling fowls.
A muscle of the cheek; -- so called from its use in blowingwind instruments.
The least quantity assignable, admissible, or possible, in agiven case; hence, a thing of small consequence; -- opposed to Ant:maximum.
A substance composed of ground bone, mineral matters, etc.,hardened by pressure, and used for making billiard balls, boxes, etc.
Capable of being inspired or drawn into the lungs; inhalable;respirable; admitting inspiration. Harvey.
The bittersweet nightshade (Solanum Dulcamara). SeeBittersweet.
To reply, as a plaintiff to a defendant's rejoinder.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, any one of three isomericcrystalline acids, C9H10ON.CO2H, which are toluyl derivatives ofglycocoll.
To render urban, or urbane; to refine; to polish. Howell.
A surety; one who is bound, or who gives security, for another.
A projection on the inner side of the distal end of thenumerus; the internal condyle.
The part of a harness which passes over the saddle, andsupports the shafts of a cart; -- called also ridgerope, and ridger.Halliwell.

That branch of science, or of engineering, which treats offluids in motion, especially of water, its action in rivers andcanals, the works and machinery for conducting or raising it, its useas a prime mover, and the like.
The period of a synodic revolution of the moon, or the timefrom one new moon to the next; varying in length, at different times,from about 29
Relating to, or affected with, hiccough. Dunglison.
