One who describes the fauna of country; a naturalist. GilbertWhite.
That part of the headstall of a bridle which passes over ahorse's nose.
A mineral found usually in thin, wedge-shaped crystals of ayellow or green to black color. It is a silicate of titanium andcalcium; titanite.
One who holds or occupies a place; one who has office undergovernment. Sir W. Scott.
To make froward, perverse, or ungovernable. [Obs.] Sir E.Sandys.
One of numerous species of birds that feed upon insects, whichthey take on the wing.
To delay; to hinder; to neglect; to put off. [Obs.] Bacon.
A sentry who guards the entrance or approach to a place; anoutguard.
The Mohammedan tribes of the southern Philippine Islands, saidto have formerly migrated from Borneo. Some of them are warlike andaddicted to piracy.
An invariable quantity; specifically, a function of thecoefficients of one or more forms, which remains unaltered, whenthese undergo suitable linear transformations. J. J. Sylvester.
The girdle of a cassock, by which it is fastened round thewaist.
A tubular structure found in Potsdam sandstone, and believed tobe the fossil burrow of a marine worm.
The name firat given in England to the red wines of M
To make lethargic.All bitters are poison, and act by stilling, and depressing, andlethargizing the irritability. Coleridge.
A word, verse, or sentence, that is the same when read backwardor forward; as, madam; Hannah; or Lewd did I live, & evil I did dwel.
A tall, coarse grass (Imperata arundinacea) of the PhilippineIslands and adjacent countries, used for thatching.
The American woodcock; -- so called from its feeding among thebogs.
The state of being a laird; an estate; landed property. [Scot.]Ramsay.

The doctrine of Quesne, that there is a fluid universallydiffused, end equally animating all living beings, the difference intheir actions being due to the difference of the individualorganizations. Fleming.
The Gorgon; or one of the Gorgons whose hair was changed intoserpents, after which all who looked upon her were turned into stone.
A design or draught which has been divided into squares, inorder to reproduce it in other dimensions.
The quality or state of being viewy, or of having unpracticalviews.
An order of fishes in which the air bladder is provided with aduct, and the ventral fins, when present, are abdominal. It includesthe salmons, herrings, carps, catfishes, and others.
A chiton, or loose, ungirded tunic, falling in straight folds.
The tree (Dipteryx odorata) which bears the tonka bean; also,the bean itself.
A book in which is kept a register of money received or paidout.

A substance found in great abundance on some coasts or islandsfrequented by sea fowls, and composed chiefly of their excrement. Itis rich in phosphates and ammonia, and is used as a powerfulfertilizer.

One of the mineral concretions about the joints, and in othersituations, occurring chiefly in gouty persons. They consist usuallyof urate of sodium; when occurring in the internal organs they arealso composed of phosphate of calcium.
A small rent paid to the lord paramount. [Obs.] Swift.
A type or block containing a facsimile of an autograph. Knight.

A citrous fruit produced by a cross between the sweet orangeand the trifoliate orange (Citrus trifoliata). It is more acid andhas a more pronounced aroma than the orange; the tree is hardier.There are several varieties.
A yellow urinary pigment, considered by Thudichum as the onlypigment present in normal urine. It is regarded by Maly as identicalwith urobilin.

A white, semisolid, spermaceti-like hydrocarbon, C16H34, of theparaffin series, found dissolved as an important ingredient ofkerosene, and so called because each molecule has sixteen atoms ofcarbon; -- called also hexadecane.
To make fine; to dress finically. [Obs.]Hath so pared and finified them [his feet.] B. Jonson.
To oppress by bulk; to overtower. [Obs. & R.] Shak.
One of certain Bohemian reformers who suffered persecution inthe fifteenth century; -- so called from Tabor, a hill or fortresswhere they encamped during a part of their struggles.
One of the classes of Protozoa, including a large number ofspecies, all of minute size.
Of or pertaining to nard; having the qualities of nard.
The cutting a fetus into pieces within the womb, so as toeffect its removal.
To do injury to; to hurt. [Archaic]Other might be determined thereby. Fuller.
To deprive of sinfulness, as a sin; to make sinless. [Obs.]Feltham.
Want of exertion; want of effort; defect of action; indolence;laziness.
Being in unison; having the same degree of gravity oracuteness; sounded alike in pitch.
Smoky; hence, fond of smoking; addicted to smoking tobacco.
A red crystallizable tasteless substance, extracted from thecarrot.
A picture printed from two half-tone plates made with thescreen set at different angles, and usually printed in two shades ofthe same color or in black and one tint.
A genus of deciduous forest trees, found in the north temperatezone, and including the true ash trees.
A solid preparation obtained by evaporating a solution of adrug, etc., or the fresh juice of a plant; -- distinguished from anabstract. See Abstract, n., 4.
A plasterer's float, having two handles; -- used in smoothingceilings, etc.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, an extinct genus of sharks(Hybodus), especially in the form of the teeth, which consist of aprincipal median cone with smaller lateral ones.
The part of the carapace of a crustacean situated behind thecervical groove.
A baker; originally, a female baker. [Old Eng. & Scotch]
To ascend in vapors; to take the form of a meteor. Evelyn.
The water cure; a mode of treating diseases by the copious andfrequent use of pure water, both internally and externally.
A horizontal working forming one of a series, the working facesof which present the appearance of a flight of steps.
To utter in a shrill tone; to scream. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
Furnished with a virole or viroles; -- said of a horn or abugle when the rings are of different tincture from the rest of thehorn.
A tool used by coopers for smoothing and chamfering rheir work,especially the inside of casks.
Of or pert. to, or characterized by, mania, or excitement.
Simulated, or capable of being simulated. Bp. Hall.
Weak, poor, or flat liquor; weak, profitless discourse orwriting.
A comprehensive group equivalent to the true Coelenterata,i.e., exclusive of the sponges. They are so named from presence ofstinging cells (cnidae) in the tissues. See Coelenterata.
A division of insects nearly equivalent to the true Orthoptera.

The part of the alimentary canal between the cavity of themouth and the esophagus. It has one or two external openings throughthe nose in the higher vertebrates, and lateral branchial openings infishes and some amphibias.
A yellow crystalline substance found in the root of yellow dock(Rumex crispus) and identical with chrysophanic acid.
A minute abrupt point, as of a leaf; any small, sharp point orprocess, terminating a larger part or organ.
One who, or that which, detects or brings to light; one whofinds out what another attempts to conceal; a detector.
That by which a lever is sustained, or about which it turns inlifting or moving a body.
The quality or state of being luminous; luminousness.
A keeper or a frequenter of a brothel. [Obs.] Gower.
A stone that is placed on the top, or which forms the top.
Futility; trifling talk or behavior; drollery. [R.] Dr. H.More.
Rare or subtile; tenuous; -- opposed to dense. [Obs.] Glanvill.
The doctrine or the practices of the Essenes. De Quincey.
In a civil manner; as regards civil rights and privileges;politely; courteously; in a well bred manner.
A large, globular glass bottle, esp. one of green glass,inclosed in basket work or in a box, for protection; -- used commonlyfor carrying corrosive liquids; as sulphuric acid, etc.
Of or pertaining to Vesuvius, a volcano near Naples.
That portion of the axis which bears the nectocalyces in theSiphonophora.
A division of Hydroidea including the hydra. See Hydra.
The quality of being nimble; lightness and quickness in motion;agility; swiftness.
A stick or small wooden cylinder used for tightening a bandage,in order to compress the arteries of a limb.
A bright-colored European actinian (Anemonia, or Anthea,sulcata); -- so called because it does not retract its tentacles.
An instrument for intensifying sounds produced by percussion ofthe thorax. Knight.
The crest or line in which strata slope or dip in oppositedirections.
A book in which a tradesman keeps his accounts. Locke.
The name of several caryophyllaseous weeds, especiallyStellaria media, the seeds and flower buds of which are a favoritefood of small birds.
A tool of which the hemp for lines and twines, used bysailmakers, is finished.
The physical phenomena of organized bodies, in opposition totheir organic or vital phenomena.
Under the board, or table; hence, secretly; unfairly;underhand. See the Note under Aboveboard.
Leave of abserice; especially, leave given to an offcer orsoldier to be absent from service for a certain time; also, thedocument granting leave of absence.
Attractive power; attractiveness. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.

Any one of three isometric bases (C6H7N) related to pyridine,and obtained from bone oil, acrolein ammonia, and coal-tar naphtha,as colorless mobile liquids of strong odor; -- called also methylpyridine.
Left-handed on both sides; clumsy; -- opposed to ambidexter.[R.] Sir T. Browne.
A kind of coarse punch with a rasplike face, used for making arough surface on etching ground, or on the naked copper, the effectafter biting being very similar to stippled lines.
To stare or stand upward; hence, to be uplifted or conspicuous."Rearing fiercely their upstaring crests." Spenser.
One from whom a race, tribe, city, or the like, took its name;an eponym.
That branch of physical science which treats of the nature andproperties of light, the laws of its modification by opaque andtransparent bodies, and the phenomena of vision.
A kind of candy or sweetneat made up in small balls or disks.
To ramble over in order to clear; to scour. [Archaic] Shak.
An upright piece of round timber, in a whaleboat, over which aturn of the line is taken when it is running out too fast. Ham. Nav.Encyc.
A nearly opaque white mineral, in part identical with titanite,observed in some igneous rocks as the result of the alteration oftitanic iron.
Of or pertaining to cork; of the nature of cork; suberose.
The quality or state of being wild; an uncultivated or untamedstate; disposition to rove or go unrestrained; rudeness; savageness;irregularity; distraction.
To trail along; to saunter or be drawn along, carelessly,swaying in a kind of zigzag motion. [Colloq.] Thackeray.
Wherever; -- a contracted and poetical form. Cowper.
To dye with excess of color; to put one color over (another).Shak.
An electric telegraph which prints the messages in letters andnot in signs.
The last stone in a horizontal course, if of a less size thanthe others, or a piece of brick finishing a course. Gwilt.
Giving light; affording light or means of discovery. Boyle.
The Numidian crane (Antropoides virgo); -- so called on accountof the grace and symmetry of its form and movements.
One of the pads on the under surface of the toes of birds.
To crow, exult, or boast, over; to overpower. Spenser. Shak.
An anglo-Saxon copper coin of the lowest value, being worthhalf a farthing. S. M. Leake.
A piece of armor formerly worn to guard the things; a tasse.
Mortification or gangrene of bone, or the death of a bone orportion of a bone in mass, as opposed to its death by moleculardisintegration. See Caries.
A slender tactile organ on the lips of certain fished.
The middle part of the main or sea. [Poetic] Chapman.
A variety of orthoclase feldspar common in certain eruptiverocks, as trachyte; -- called also glassy feldspar.
An algebraic curve, so called from its resemblance to a heart.
To transport with delight; to enrapture; to fascinate. Spenser.
A prop or support; a piece of timber in the form of a stake orpost, used for a support or stay.
A light, open, two-wheeled carriage for one horse; a kind ofgig. ("The term and vehicle common about 1825." Latham.)
Furnished with hoofs. See the Note under Nail, n., 1.
To utter the ordinary call or cry of a horse; to neigh.

Freehold estate; land which is the absolute property of theowner; real estate held in absolute independence, without beingsubject to any rent, service, or acknowledgment to a superior. It isthus opposed to feud. Blackstone. Bouvier.
A trivial mechanism; a device; a toy; a pretty thing.Arbuthnot.
A form of melody in which a phrase or passage is successivelyrepeated, each time a step or half step higher; a melodic sequence.
A clergyman of a superior order, as an archbishop or a bishop,having authority over the lower clergy; a dignitary of the church.
A contrivance for removing the pits from peaches, plums, andother stone fruit.
Festival games celebrated once in three years. [R.] May.
A small opening; esp., one of the apertures, closed bymembranes, between the tympanum and internal ear.
One who denies the existence of the universe, or of a universeas distinct from God. G. H. Lewes.
A slight sound such as that made by pressing the tongue againstthe roof of the mouth and explosively sucking out the air at oneside, as in urging on a horse. -- v. i.
The fibrin ferment which produces the formation of fibrin fromfibrinogen.
A small hydrometer for determining the specific gravity ofurine.
The quality of being formed by the aid of the teeth.
A constellation of the southern hemisphere, near the southpole.
One of forty equal parts into which one whole is divided; thequotient of a unit divided by forty; one next in order after thethirty-ninth.
Of or pertaining to Temple, a valley in Thessaly, celebrated byGreek poets on account of its beautiful scenery; resembling Temple;hence, beautiful; delightful; charming.
The central column in the osseous cochlea of the ear.
A genus of aquatic plants having showy flowers (white, blue,pink, or yellow, often fragrant), including the white water lily andthe Egyptia lotus.
In the Anglo-Indian army, a native commander of a ressala.
The return of the judge before whom a cause was tried, after averdict, of what was done in the cause, which is indorsed on the nisiprius record. Wharton.
A yellow crystalline substance of acid properties extractedfrom fustic (Maclura tinctoria, formerly called Morus tinctoria); --called also moric acid.
A genus of shrubby plants bearing opposite leaves and largeheads of showy flowers, white, or of various colors. H. hortensis,the common garden species, is a native of China or Japan.
A small pan with a handle, in which sauce is prepared over afire; a stewpan.
Domestic fowls reared for the table, or for their eggs orfeathers, such as cocks and hens, capons, turkeys, ducks, and geese.
The science of midwifery; the art of assisting women inparturition, or in the trouble incident to childbirth.
A verse which has a redundant syllable or foot; ahypercatalectic verse.
A woman who feeds and cherishes; a nurse. B. Jonson.
A species of joinery or cabinet-work consisting of an inlay ofgeometric or other patterns, generally of different colors, -- usedespecially for floors.
A cured olive which has spoiled or is on the verge ofdecomposition; loosely, an olive defective because of bruises,wormholes, or the like.
To incline from the vertical; to hade; -- said of a vein,fault, or lode.
A toll or duty paid for weighing wool; also, the act ofweighing wool. [Obs.] Nares.
A plant of several species of the genus Chrysocoma; -- socalled from the tufts of yellow flowers which terminate the stems;also, the Ranunculus auricomus, a kind of buttercup.
A member of the trecento, or an imitator of itscharacteristics.
Uniting the chemical rays of light into one focus, as a certainkind of lens; amacratic.
An extra first toe, or rudiment of a toe, on the preaxial sideof the hallux.
A genus of poisonous African serpents, with a horny scale overeach eye; the horned viper.
A subdivision of Cetacea, including the sperm whale, dolphins,etc.; the toothed whales.
The terminal part of the cochlea in birds and most reptiles; anappendage of the sacculus, corresponding to the cochlea, in fishesand amphibians.
An apple-green mineral occurring in reniform masses. It is ahydrous phosphate of alumina.
A large and commodious, but generally cumbrous and sluggishboat, used for journeys on the Ganges.
Regard for others, both natural and moral; devotion to theinterests of others; brotherly kindness; -- opposed to egoism orselfishness. [Recent] J. S. Mill.
Having to do with inlaid work; -- especially used withreference to work of the ancient Greeks.
A rattling sound in the throat arising from difficulty ofbreathing; a rattle. [Obs.]
The Dutch equivalent of Mr. or Sir; hence, a Dutchman.
A small instrument of ivory, wood, metal, or quill, used inplaying upon the lyre and other stringed instruments.
A plant of the genus Mitella; miterwort. Longfellow.
A print made from two half-tone plates made from the samenegative, but etched differently.
A small plaque, esp., in modern medal engraving, a small anddelicate bas-relief, whether cast or struck from a die, or of formother than circular.
Below; beneath; under; after; -- often used as a prefix.
Pertaining to, or desingating, an acid (called also valericacid) derived from pentane.
That branch of systemized knowledge which treats of theChinese, their language, literature, etc.
Wrinkled; crumpled; furrowed; contracted into ridges andfurrows.
The coarse-grained brownish yellow wood of a small tree(Pisonia obtusata) of Florida and the West Indies. Also called pigeonwood, beefwood, and corkwood.
Moving in the air with, or as with, wings; moving lightly orrapidly; intended for rapid movement.
One who serves on board of the same ship with another; a fellowsailor.
Producing myosis, or contraction of the pupil of the eye, asopium, calabar bean, etc.-- n.
The state of being demure; gravity; the show of gravity ormodesty.
To emasculate; to dispossess of manhood. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Of or pertaining to the language or people of the of Man.-- n.
Profound sleep from which a person can be roused only withdifficulty.
A fortified place; a large and permanent fortification,sometimes including a town; a fort; a castle; a stronghold; a placeof defense or security.
A kind of scepter or spear with three prongs, -- the commonattribute of Neptune.
A flowing or entering in; -- opposed to emanation. [R.] Good.
Curling or tending to curl; having curls; full of ripples;crinkled.
The act of casting off the skin or shell, as do insects andcrustaceans; ecdysis.
A plant of various species, chiefly cruciferous. The leaveshave a moderately pungent taste, and are used as a salad andantiscorbutic.
A genus of perennial, composite herbs including hemp agrimony,boneset, throughwort, etc.
A covering of canvas or tarpaulin for the hammocks, stowed onthe nettings, between the quarterdeck and the forecastle.
Applied to one of the cases of the noun in Latin and some otherlanguages, -- the fundamental meaning of the case being removal,separation, or taking away.
An East Indian insectivorous mammal of the genus Tupaia.
An instrument for taking altitudes, as a quadrant, sextant,etc. Knight.
One who, or that which, feeds on or destroys wit. [Obs.] B.Jonson.
A word to be given before a person is allowed to pass; awatchword; a countersign. Macaulay.
A letter or writing, usually under seal, conferring someprivilege, honor, or power; a document bearing record of a degreeconferred by a literary society or educational institution.
A muscle which contracts the skin of the forehead intowrinkles.
Represented as enraged, as any wild creature depicted with fireissuing from mouth and eyes.
A charitable gift or contribution; a gift; an alms; a dole; alargess; a sportula. [Obs.] Ayliffe.
An implement for braying and spreading ink in hand printing.
An alkaloid obtained from the yellow jasmine (Gelsemiumsempervirens), as a bitter white semicrystalline substance; -- calledalso gelsemia.
Capable of being, or liable to be, delineated. Feltham.
Having only one form of pistils; -- said of the flowers of someplants. Darwin.
One of the component segments of the body of an animal.
Soreness of eyes; the state of being blear-eyes; blearedness.
The jurisdiction or office of an alcalde; also, the building orchamber in which he conducts the business of his office.
A resinoid coloring matter obtained from alkanet root.
A sacrifice, or ceremony, by which cities, fields, armies, orpeople, defiled by crimes, pestilence, or other cause of uncleanness,were purified.
Decorative painting in gray monochrome; -- used in Englishespecially for painted glass.
A young eel; a young conger or sea eel; -- called also elvene.
That which is held of another by service; property which oneholds of a lord or proprietor in consideration of some military orpecuniary service; fief; fee.
A small farm; -- so called as requiring but one yoke of oxen totill it. [Prov. Eng.]
One who follows the dietetic system of Graham. [U. S.]
A crystalline substance said to be found in the root of acertain plant of the Leadwort (Plumbago) family.
To make or take auguries; to augur; to predict. [Obs.] C.Middleton.
To make mad; to drive to madness; to craze; to excite violentlywith passion; to make very angry; to enrage.
A post sunk in the ground to receive the bars closing a passageinto a field.

A fine white claylike mineral, soft, and light enough when indry masses to float in water. It is a hydrous silicate of magnesia,and is obtained chiefly in Asia Minor. It is manufacturd into tobaccopipes, cigar holders, etc. Also called sepiolite.
One of the class of diviners among the Etruscans and Romans,who foretold events by the inspection of the entrails of victimsoffered on the altars of the gods.
A division of Mollusca remarkable for the bilateral symmetry ofthe organs and the arrangement of the nerves.
The Richardson's skua (Stercorarius parasiticus);- so calledfrom its cry. [Prov. Eng.]
At a small price; at a low value; in a common or inferiormanner.
In a lowering manner; with cloudiness or threatening gloom.
A provisional name for a plant which has not had its flowersbotanically examined, and therefore has not been referred to itsproper genus.
The rice bunting or bobolink; -- so called in the island ofJamaica.
Given to sensual indulgence; gluttonous. [Obs.] Joye.
A viverrine animal of Madagascar (Cryptoprocta ferox). Itresembles a cat in size and form, and has retractile claws.
A city of the dead; a name given by the ancients to theircemeteries, and sometimes applied to modern burial places; agraveyard.
A woman's under-garment; a smock. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Johnson.
One of the naked, inflatable air sacs on the neck of theprairie chicken and other species of grouse.
The act or practice of opening a vein for letting blood, in thetreatment of disease; venesection; bloodletting.
Work formed of clay in whole or in part, and baked; as, vases,urns, etc. Knight.
Of or pertaining to, or of the nature of, the Sauria.-- n.
One of several species of sea birds of the generaSynthliboramphus and Brachyramphus, inhabiting the North Pacific.They are closely related to the murres.
That which forms the foundation or support of anything; thebasis; the essential or fundamental part; first principle. Dryden.
To mutually agree to meet at a certain place. [Scot.]
A woman supposed to be endowed with a spirit of prophecy.
To cause to shake; to tremble; to move tremulously, as fromweakness; to totter. [Obs.]
To receive or entertain hospitably. [Obs.] Sylvester.
The crab-eating seal (Lobodon carcinophaga) of the AntarcticOcean.
Any plant of the genus Veronica, mostly low herbs with paleblue corollas, which quickly fall off.
To embark; to go or put into a barge. [Obs.] Drayton.
A vessel used to carry naval stores for a fleet, garrison, orthe like.
To fashion anew; to form or mold into shape a second time.MacKnight.
A weight of one hundred pounds avoirdupois; -- called in manyparts of the United States a Hundredweight.
To revert, or become forfeited, to the lord, the crown, or theState, as lands by the failure of persons entitled to hold the same,or by forfeiture.
The unlawful permission, by a jailer or other custodian, of aprisoner's departure from custody.
A long, narrow foot, carried (that is, produced or extending)forward; -- said of dogs.
Not questioned or doubtful; evident; certain. [Obs.] Bacon.
A girdle; particularly that of Aphrodite (or Venus) which gavethe wearer the power of exciting love.
A foot of four syllables, the first and fourth short, and thesecond and third long.
A machine, resembling a well sweep, used in Egypt for raisingwater from the Nile for irrigation.
Concentration of one's interests on one's self; self-love;selfishness. Emerson.
The quality or state of being equal in weight, especially inatmospheric pressure. Also, the theory, method, or application ofisobaric science.
Pertaining to, or derived from, cyanic and uric acids.
An unnatural deviation of shape or position of any part of thebody producing visible deformity.
The art or practice of applying tests to ascertain the nature,quality, etc., of objects, as of metals or ores, of medicines, or offacts pertaining to physiology.
One of the functionaries who light and trim the tapers.
A weed with a sterm of many joints (Illecebrum verticillatum);also, the Polygonum aviculare or knotgrass.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid which is the primaryacid amide derivative of tartaric acid.
Capable of being converted into vapor by the agency of heat;vaporizable.
Cleaving in more directions than one, parallel to the axis.
To ascertain and declare, by a public process and decree, thata deceased person is one of "the blessed" and is to be reverenced assuch, though not canonized.
The anterior of the three principal divisions of the brain,including the prosencephalon and thalamencephalon. Sometimesrestricted to the prosencephalon only. See Brain.
A frame of wood, bent into the shape of the letter U, andembracing an ox's neck as a kind of collar, the upper ends passingthrough the bar of the yoke; also, anything so shaped, as a bend in ariver.
Vaulted work; also, a vaulted place; an arched cellar. [Obs.]Shak.
To beat with a stick or cudgel, especially on the soles of thefeet.
Capable of being tempted; liable to be tempted. Cudworth.
In a labial manner; with, or by means of, the lips.
An instrument for ascertaining the strength of acids. Ure.
Pertaining to the measles; partaking of the nature of measels,or resembling the eruptions of that disease; measly.
Moved or worked by the action of the foot or feet on a pedal ortreadle.
The retiring room of actors and actresses in a theater.
A native or inhabitant of Zante, one of the Ionian Islands.
Of or pertaining to, or in the manner or style of, the Moors;Moorish.-- n.

A contrivance for effecting ventilation; especially, acontrivance or machine for drawing off or expelling foul or stagnantair from any place or apartment, or for introducing that which isfresh and pure.
A widely distributed genus of fragrant herbs, including thepeppermint, spearmint, etc. The plants have small flowers, usuallyarranged in dense axillary clusters.
Tending to reduce; having the power or effect of reducing.-- n.
A congregation; also, formerly, the Lord's Supper. Jer. Taylor.
A genus including several species of large marine gastropodshaving massive pyriform shells, with conspicuous folds on thecolumella.
That which grows out of, or proceeds from, anything; anexcrescence; an offshoot; hence, a result or consequence.
The bleak, a small European fish having scales of a peculiarlysilvery color which are used in making artificial pearls.
Not producing gain; unprofitable. Hammond.-- Gain"less/ness, n.
A hole or space covered by a movable piece of board, as in afloor, boxing, partitions, or the like.
A feeder; an eater; also, one who provides viands, or food; ahost. [Obs.] Holinshed.
A painful affection of the spine; especially, Pott's disease;also, formerly, lead colic.
A tuft of hair turned up or awry (usually over the forehead),as if licked by a cow.
One who strikes heavy blows; hence, a boxer; a prize fighter.[Cant or Slang]
A case with shelves for holding books, esp. one with glazeddoors.
To inosculate; to intercommunicate by anastomosis, as thearteries and veins.The ribbing of the leaf, and the anastomosing network of its vessels.I. Taylor.
A sweating; a profuse or morbid sweating, often succeeded by aneruption of small pimples.
In an insipid manner; without taste, life, or spirit; flatly.Locke. Sharp.
A projection on the bolt, which passes through the tumblergates in locking and unlocking.
The center of mass, inertia, or gravity of a body or system ofbodies.
The external smooth horny layer of the hoof of the horse andallied animals.
A fold or pen for sheep; a place where sheep are collected orconfined.
One who makes an appointment, or tryst; one who meets withanother.
An under-garment worn by the ancient Romans of both sexes. Itwas made with or without sleeves, reached to or below the knees, andwas confined at the waist by a girdle.
Building up; constructive; -- opposed to destructive. [Obs.]
Avenger. [Obs.]The stork, the wrekere of avouterye [adultery]. Chaucer.
A flat-floored fishing boat with a lug sail, and a drop rudderextending from two to four feet below the keel. It was originallyused on the stormy coast of Yorkshire, England.
Earnest and active in matters of no moment; bustling. [Colloq.Eng.] Dickens.
The aperture in a mold for pouring in the metal; the gate.Simmonds.
A rough-barked species of hickory (Carya alba), its nut. Calledalso shellbark. See Hickory.(b) The West Indian Pithecolobium micradenium, a legiminous tree witha red coiled-up pod.
To maneuver; to move hither and thither. [Colloq.]Wooden arms with elbow joints jerking and fugling in the air.Carlyle.
A native oxide of manganese, of dark brownish black color. Itwas named from a Mr. Braun of Gotha.
Measured; -- a direction to perform a passage in strict ormeasured time.
A large, deep, hollow place in the earth; a large cave.
A small tumor upon the eyelid, resembling a grain of barley; asty.
In a cogent manner; forcibly; convincigly; conclusively. Locke.
To institute and prosecute a suit against, in court; to sue orprosecute at law; hence, to accuse; to impeach.
A pedestal of small size, used to support small objects, asbusts, vases, and the like.
An herbaceous plant of the Barberry family (Epimedium alpinum),having leaves that are bitter and said to be sudorific.
Resembling sagenite; -- applied to quartz when containingacicular crystals of other minerals, most commonly rutile, alsotourmaline, actinolite, and the like.
To make a hissing sound; to fry, or to dry and shrivel up, witha hissing sound. [Prov. Eng. & Colloq. U. S.] Forby.
The work belonging to housekeeping; especially, kitchen work,sweeping, scrubbing, bed making, and the like.
A tumor springing from the neuroglia or connective tissue ofthe brain, spinal cord, or other portions of the nervous system.

The act of anointing, or the state of being anointed; unction;specifically (Med.), the rubbing of ointments into the pores of theskin, by which medicinal agents contained in them, such as mercury,iodide of potash, etc., are absorbed.
A mineral consisting of both the chloride and the bromide ofsilver.
Situated under the dura mater, or between the dura mater andthe arachnoid membrane.
The coloring principle of turmeric, or curcuma root, extractedas an orange yellow crystalline substance, C14H14O4, with a greenfluorescence.
An umbelliferous plant (Sium, or Pimpinella, Sisarum). It is anative of Asia, but has been long cultivated in Europe for its edibleclustered tuberous roots, which are very sweet.
A crestlike excrescence about the hilum of certain seeds; acaruncle.
The act of going off, or the state of being off, the rails of arailroad.
One of several upright slender calcareous processes whichsurround the central part of the calicle of certain corals.
A silver coin, and money of account, in the East Indies.
A plant used as a remedy for tetter, -- in England thecalendine, in America the bloodroot.
Of or pertaining to a sinecure; being in the nature of asinecure.
Pertaining to a bone of the shoulder girdle in most birds,reptiles, and amphibians, which is reduced to a process of thescapula in most mammals.
Conducing to ripeness or maturity; hence, conducing tosuppuration.
A panorama of the interior of a building, seen from within.
An extensive artificial group of invertebrates, having all theparts arranged radially around the vertical axis of the body, and thevarious organs repeated symmetrically in each ray or spheromere.
One who abnegates, denies, or rejects anything. [R.]
A spontaneously inflammable liquid, having a repulsive odor,and consisting of cacodyl and its oxidation products; -- called alsoCadel's fuming liquid.
A small narrow opening or window in a tower or fortified wall;a loophole.
An inflammable gaseous hydrocarbon, C4H10, of the marsh gas, orparaffin, series.
The heavy interior portion of the earth, within thelithosphere.
A seigniory or lordship held of the king, on which otherlordships and manors depended. Cowell.
Upright, or straight and narrow; -- said of the shape of theplants or their flower clusters.
In the manner of a reform; for the purpose of reform. [Obs.]Milton.
A genus of extinct Cretaceous fishes; -- so named from theirspear-shaped teeth. They were allied to the pike (Esox).
Joining; having the quality of joining; forming an adjunct.
A male attendant of a bridegroom at his wedding; -- thecorrelative of bridesmaid.
The enrichment of an opening by means of foils, arranged intrefoils, quatrefoils, etc.; also, one of the ornaments. See Tracery.
To invest with dignity or honor; to make illustrious; to givedistinction to; to exalt in rank; to honor.Your worth will dignity our feast. B. Jonson.
A lever mounted on a tripod for lifting stones, leveling uprailroad ties, etc. Knight.
An instrument for comparing magnetic forces, esp. in theearth's magnetic field.
A female governor; a woman invested with authority to controland direct; especially, one intrusted with the care and instructionof children, -- usually in their homes.
A piece of furniture used as a writing table, commonly withdrawers, pigeonholes, and the like; a secretary or writing desk.

A poisonous, white, crystallizable alkaloid, extracted from theAtropa belladonna, or deadly nightshade, and the Datura Stramonium,or thorn apple. It is remarkable for its power in dilating the pupilof the eye. Called also daturine.
Above the angular bone; supra-angular; -- applied to a bone ofthe lower jaw in many reptiles and birds.-- n.
One of the bones or cartilages of the tarsus; esp., one of theseries articulating with the metatarsals.
A granular mineral of a grayish or yellowish color, found inBolton, Massachusetts. It is a silicate of magnesium, belonging tothe chrysolite family.
A vibrant or whirring noise such as that made by some insects,as the cockchafer, or by some birds, as the nightjar, the partridge,etc.
A soft and flexible fabric for men's wear, made wholly of woolexcept in some inferior kinds, the wool being dyed, usually in twocolors, before weaving.
To pull; to haul; to tear; to worry. [Prov. Eng.] Shak.As a bear, whom angry curs have touzed. Spenser.
Of or pertaining to an umbel; having the form of an umbel.
An Australian name for Marsilea Drummondii, a four-leavedcryptogamous plant, sometimes used for food.
That which serves to anoint; any soft unctuous substance usedfor smearing or anointing; an unguent.
A green compound used as a dyestuff, produced from aniline bluewhen acted upon by acid.
With sounds like singing; with a kind of tune; in a singingtone. G. North (1575).
The act of opening; an opening; an aperture. [Archaic] Wiseman.
The bright reflection of the moon's light on an expanse ofwater. [Poetic]
The trapezohedron or tetragonal trisoctahedron; -- so called asbeing the form of the mineral leucite.
One born in a country; an aboriginal animal or plant; anautochthon. Evelyn. Tylor.

The character, sentiment, or disposition of a community orpeople, considered as a natural endowment; the spirit which actuatesmanners and customs; also, the characteristic tone or genius of aninstitution or social organization.
A mode of speaking peculiar to the Irish; an Hibernicism.
A colorless oily liquid, C4H3O.CHO, of a pleasant odor,obtained by the distillation of bran, sugar, etc., and regarded as analdehyde derivative of furfuran; -- called also furfural.
An artificial alkaloid, believed to be efficient in abatingfever.
Capable of being thrust out or protruded. J. Fleming.
A privilege of setting up, and moving about, folds for sheep,in any fields within manors, in order to manure them; -- oftenreserved to himself by the lord of the manor. Spelman.
Of or pertaining to Athens, the metropolis of Greece.-- n. A native or citizen of Athens.
A union of securities given at different times, all of whichmust be redeemed before an intermediate purchaser can interpose hisclaim. Bouvier.
To disclaim and expel from the family, as a father his child;to disown; to disinherit.
A sharp or uneven edge on a board that is cut from a log notperfectly squared, or that is made in the process of squaring. SeeWany, a.
A human head represented sidewise, or in a side view; the sideface or half face.
The lash of a whip, -- usually made of thongs of leather, or ofcords, braided or twisted.
A genus of coarse liliaceous herbs having very poisonousqualities.
The eleventh month of the ancient Hebrew year, approximatelycorresponding with February. W. Smith (Bibl. Dict. ).
Burnt sugar; a brown or black porous substance obtained byheating sugar. It is soluble in water, and is used for coloringspirits, gravies, etc.
The white and softer part of wood, between the inner bark andthe hard wood or duramen; sapwood.
A shoot or secondary stem growing from the main stem, or from aprincipal limb or bough of a tree or other plant.
Reach of the ear; distance at which words may be heard. Dryden.
A beetle of the genus Melolontha (esp. M. vulgaris) and alliedgenera; -- called also May bug, chafer, or dorbeetle.
To aggravate; to make worse; to lie heavy on. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To refuse to confirm; to annul, as a judicial decision, by acontrary judgment of a superior tribunal.
The quality or condition of being steamy; vaporousness;mistness.
Having the same tint or color throughout; uniformly or evenlycolored.
The science of measuring time, or the principles and art ofconstructing instruments for measuring and indicating portions oftime, as clocks, watches, dials, etc.
Affectation of a pretty style, manner, etc. [R.] Ed. Rev.
One of a species of coccoliths, having an oval discoidal body,with a thick strongly refracting rim, and a thinner central portion.One of them measures about
Any plant of the genera Asclepias and Acerates whose seedvessels contain a long, silky down; milkweed.
An inflated ball to be kicked in sport, usually made in Indiarubber, or a bladder incased in Leather. Waller.
An unorganized amylolytic ferment, on enzyme, present in humanmixed saliva and in the saliva of some animals.
A dish made of fresh fish or clams, biscuit, onions, etc.,stewed together.
To make search after; to investigate or examine; to ensearch.[Obs.]

A large class of Echinodermata, including numerous extinctfamilies and genera, but comparatively few living ones. Most of thefossil species, like some that are recent, were attached by a jointedstem. See Blastoidea, Cystoidea, Comatula.
An annual composite plant of the Mississippi valley (Seneciolobatus).
A time note, with a stem, having one fourth the value of asemibreve, one half that of a minim, and twice that of a quaver; aquarter note.
The note next above the keynote; the second of the scale.Busby.
An explanation or exposition of the principles of some opinion,action, hypothesis, phenomenon, or like; also, the principlesthemselves.
To recall or take back, as something thought. Shak.
A radical, C16H33, not yet isolated, but supposed to exist in aseries of compounds homologous with the ethyl compounds, and derivedfrom spermaceti.
The quality or state of being orient or bright; splendor.[Obs.] Fuller.
To throw in between; to insert; to interpose. Sir H. Wotton.
The quality or state of being smudged, soiled, or blurred. C.A. Young.
Having in a capitulum large ray florets which are unlike thedisk florets, as in the aster, daisy, etc.
One who edits; esp., a person who prepares, superintends,revises, and corrects a book, magazine, or newspaper, etc., forpublication.
A sort of second plinth or block, below the bases of Ionic andCorinthian columns, generally without moldings, and of smaller sizehorizontally than the pedestal.
One who engages in rows, or noisy quarrels; a ruffianly fellow.M. Arnold.
To make Aryan (a language, or in language). K. Johnston.
Displayed with the back toward the spectator; -- saidespecially of an eagle.
A genus of trees (Celtis) related to the elm, but bearingdrupes with scanty, but often edible, pulp. C. occidentalis is commonin the Eastern United States. Gray.
A foot of three syllables, the middle one long, the first andlast short (as, h. In modern prosody the accented syllable takes theplace of the long and the unaccented of the short; as, pro-phet''ic.
The dropping of a letter or syllable from the beginning of aword; e. g., cute for acute.
A southern constellation, within which is the south pole of theecliptic; -- called also sometimes Xiphias, or the Swordfish.
A form of machine for exhibiting animated pictures.
A rare earth, regarded by some as an oxide of the supposedelement gadolinium, by others as only a mixture of the oxides ofyttrium, erbium, ytterbium, etc.
A record of the lineage or strain of an animal, as of a horse.
One who makes objection; an objector. [R.] Cardinal Wiseman.
Waste and knots of wool removed by the comb; combings.
The yellow discoloration often observed in cancerous tumors.
A dreamer; an absent-minded person. [Obs.] Rom. of R.
One who cultivates land for a share (usually one half) of itsyield, receiving stock, tools, and seed from the landlord. [France &Italy] Milman.
To cover with dung, as for manuring; to bedaub or defile,literally or figuratively. Bp. Hall.
A highly volatile liquid, condensed by cold and pressure fromthe first products of the distillation of petroleum; -- used forproducing low temperatures.
An instrument for measuring the water that percolates through acertain depth of soil. Knight.
One who reasons from analogy, or represent, by analogy. Cheyne.
An oblong shield made of boards or wickerwork covered withleather, with sometimes an iron rim; -- carried chiefly by the heavy-armed infantry.
To walk quickly with the head bent forward; -- often withalong. [Prov. Eng.]
any one of a series of nitrogenous bases, certain of which areused as antipyretics.
An animal, particularly a log, having an uncut tail. Cf.Curtail. Dog.
To presage; to foreshow; to foretoken. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.

Any one of numerous species of ten-armed cephalopods having along, tapered body, and a caudal fin on each side; especially, anyspecies of Loligo, Ommastrephes, and related genera. See Calamary,Decacerata, Dibranchiata.
One who, or that which, convinces; one who wins over by proof.
Being without order or regularity; disorderly; out of rule.
That science, or branch of applied mathematics, which treats ofthe action of forces on bodies.
Toward the north; nearer to the north than to the east or westpoint.
To beg; to pilfer; to skelder. [Prov. Eng.& Scot.] Sir W.Scott.
East men; Danish settlers in Ireland, formerly so called.Lyttelton.
To disarm and disband, as a body of soldiers,-Wilhelm.
A small ulcerous swelling, coming suddenly; also, a whitlow.[Obs.] Boucher.
An optical instrument used in viewing distant objects, as theheavenly bodies.
A parchment which has been written upon twice, the firstwriting having been erased to make place for the second. Longfellow.
Native magnesium carbonate occurring in white compact orgranular masses, and also in rhombohedral crystals.
A plant with checkered petals, of the genus Fritillaria: theGuinea-hen flower. See Fritillaria.
Any species of Dentalium and allied genera having a tooth-shaped shell. See Dentalium.
The science of inscriptions; the art of engraving inscriptionsor of deciphering them.
A title borne by the princes or governors of Moldavia andWallachia before those countries were united as Roumania.
To follow a matter judicially, as a complaining party; to actas a prosecutor. Burrill.

a systematic course of diet, etc., pursed with a view toimproving or preserving the health, or for the purpose of attainingsome particular effect, as a reduction of flesh; -- sometimes usedsynonymously with hygiene.
To form with the manners or character of a cockney. [Colloq.]
, An extreme member or part of a thing; a limb. [Obs.] Fuller.
Stars not included in any constellation; -- called alsoinformed, or unformed, stars.
A heavy mineral of an iron-black color and submetallic luster.It is essentially a tantalate of iron.

A fir pole of from four to seven inches diameter, and twenty toforty feet long, sometimes roughly hewn, used for scaffoldings, andsometimes for slight and common roofs, for which use it is split.[Spelt also ufer.] [Eng.] Gwilt.
In a bloody manner; cruelly; with a disposition to shed blood.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid of the aromaticseries obtained from opianic acid.
A floor or pavement supposed to rest upon the earth.
To cause to feel horror; to strike or impress with horror; as,the sight horrified the beholders. E. Irving.
The art of making edged tools or cutlery. [Obs.] Milton.
The thick, curdy precipitate formed by the coagulation ofalbuminous matter; any mass of coagulated matter, as a clot of bloot.
To mingle or infuse with nectar; to sweeten. [Obs.] Cockeram.
Of or pertaining to a prelude; of the nature of a prelude;introductory. [R.]
Pleasantness; agreeableness. See Jocundity. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
A day given to play or diversion; a holiday. Swift.
An officer who has the care or inspection of weights andmeasures, etc.
Behavior or manners of a clown; clownery. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
One who rents a tenement, or land, etc., of one who is also atenant; an undertenant.
A little cigar; a little fine tobacco rolled in paper forsmoking.
One whose occupation is to load and unload vessels in port; onewho stows a cargo in a hold.
Pertaining to, or designating, a dibasic acid of the oxalicseries found in archil (Roccella tinctoria, etc.), and other lichens,and extracted as a white crystalline substance C17H32O4.
In Continental armies, especially in the French army, a womanaccompanying a regiment, who sells provisions and liquor to thesoldiers; a female sutler.
The refuse whale blubber, used as a manure, and in themanufacture of Prussian blue. Ure.
Pertaining to sleep or dreams; somnial. [Obs. or R.] Urquhart.
One who awards, or assigns by sentence or judicialdetermination; a judge.
A teller of news; especially, one who spreads false reports.Shak.
A churl; a boor; a peasant or countryman. [Obs.] Shak.
The action of a horse, when he throws himself on his haunchestwo or three times, bending himself, as it were, in very quickcurvets. Harris.
To untwist, uncoil, or untwine, as anything wreathed.
An hypothesis of animal magnetism propounded by Dr. Keiser, inGermany, in which the phenomena are ascribed to the agency of atelluric spirit or influence. [R.] S. Thompson.
A genus of coleopterous insects, including the glowworms.
The quality of being august; dignity of mien; grandeur;magnificence.
A genus of liliaceous plants; the three-leaved nightshade; --so called because all the parts of the plant are in threes.

A small quantity of wine and water, which is used to wash thepriest's thumb and index finger after the communion, and which then,as perhaps containing portions of the consecrated elements, is drunkby the priest.
A variety of sugar obtained by the partial oxidation ofmannite, and closely resembling levulose.
An entertainment at which a medley of dishes is set on at thesame time.

A large water wheel, turned by the action of a stream againstits floats, and carrying at its circumference buckets, by which wateris raised and discharged into a trough; used in Arabia, China, andelsewhere for irrigating land; a Persian wheel.
An athletic contest involving both boxing and wrestling.
The head of a monastery, convent, abbey, or the like.
Industrial science; the science of systematic knowledge of theindustrial arts, especially of the more important manufactures, asspinning, weaving, metallurgy, etc.
One of the divisions of a compound leaf; a foliole.
Crude tartar; an acidulous salt from which cream of tartar isprepared. It exists in the juice of grapes, and is deposited fromwines on the sides of the casks. Ure.
Shaped like spatula, or like a battledoor, being roundish, witha long, narrow, linear base. [Also written spathulate.]
A general name for coloring matter of plants other thanchlorophyll, especially that of petals.
A picture, example, or illustration, often taken from sensibleobjects, and used to illustrate a subject; usually, an extendedmetaphor. Brande & C.
Play; sport; pastime; diversion; playfulness. Milton.
One who plays a merely nominal part in any action; a shamcharacter.
To speak hastily and confusedly; to sputter. [Colloq.]Carleton.
Overexertion; excessive tension; strain. [Obs.] Spenser.

A large genus of American, mostly tropical, climbing shrubs,having compound leaves and showy somewhat tubular flowers. B.capreolata is the cross vine of the Southern United States. Thetrumpet creeper was formerly considered to be of this genus.
Capable of being uttered or explained; utterable. Barrow.
A thin film formed on the surface of an evaporating solution.
The process of building up, heating, and working, fagots, orpiles, to form bars, etc.
A vessel of light draught, carrying one or more guns.
The fore part of the deck, having a bulkhead athwart ships highenough to prevent water which enters the hawse holes from runningover it.
A cloth, or other material, for wiping off or cleaning ink froma pen.
A valuable kind of wood obtained on the shores of the DemeraraRiver in South America, much used for timbers, rails, naves andfellies of wheels, and the like.
A short anthem sung at intervals during the reading of achapter.
A post, or one of a series of posts, set up to indicate spacesof a mile each or the distance in miles from a given place.
The striped mullet of California (Mugil cephalus, orMexicanus).
To cover over with, or as with, a mantle; to put about as aprotection. [Obs.] Holland.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid, C5H8N4O6, which isobtained, as a white crystalline substance, by the slow oxidation ofuric acid in alkaline solution.
A light box of pasteboard or thin wood, usually cylindrical,for holding ruffs (the bands of the 17th century), collars, caps,bonnets, etc.
Master; sir; -- a title of respect formerly applied to a knightor a clergyman, and sometimes to the lord of a manor. Cowell.
Bearing hair; covered with hair or down; piliferous.
The first period, or increase, of a disease; augmentation.[Obs.]
Starch made from Indian corn, esp. a fine white flour used forpuddings, etc.
A compound containing in the molecule two atoms of oxygenunited with some other element or radical; -- usually called dioxide,or less frequently, binoxide.
To make into a snarl or knot; to entangle; to snarl. [Obs.]Cotgrave.
The front or the back part of the frame of a bedstead. [Obs. orDial. Eng.]
To form or constitute the essence or being of. [Obs.] Boyle.
An implement for cutting, trimming, or ornamenting the rim ofanything, as the edges of pies, etc.; also, a reamer. Knight.
Spurious; fictitious; sham; -- a cant term originally appliedto counterfeit coin, and hence denoting anything counterfeit.[Colloq. U. S.]
A remedy which promotes discharges, as an emetic, or acathartic.
Tungstate of iron and manganese, generally of a brownish orgrayish black color, submetallic luster, and high specific gravity.It occurs in cleavable masses, and also crystallized. Called alsowolfram.
A caul. See Caul, n., 3. [Obs. or Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
A member of the Ribbon Society. See Ribbon Society, underRibbon.
One of the incomplete rings of the upper part of the bronchialtubes of most birds. The semerings form an essential part of thesyrinx, or musical organ, of singing birds.
To search for gold by picking at stone or earth or among rootsin isolated spots, picking over abandoned workings, etc.; hence, tosteal gold or auriferous matter from another's claim. [Australia]
An extinct genus of saber-toothed tigers. See Mach.
A complete or ridiculous failure, esp. of a musicalperformance, or of any pretentious undertaking.
A false stroke with a billiard cue, the cue slipping from theball struck without impelling it as desired.
One in a flight of steps which are parallel to each other(as inordinary stairs), as distinguished from a winder.
The aquatic larva of a large neuropterous insect (Corydaluscornutus), used as bait in angling. See Hellgamite.
That part of a ship's hull or bottom which is broadest and mostnearly flat, and on which she would rest if aground.

Raised; lifted up; -- a term applied to what is also called theabsolute superlative, denoting a high or intense degree of a quality,but not excluding the idea that an equal degree may exist in othercases.
A genus of hemipterous insects of which the bedbug is the bestknown example. See Bedbug.
A genus of dipterous insects, including the common house fly,and numerous allied species.

An extensive division of Mammalia. It formerly included theProboscidea, Hyracoidea, Perissodactyla, and Artiodactyla, but bylater writers it is generally restricted to the two latter groups(Ungulata). They feed almost exclusively upon vegetation.
A cubic measure containing 1000 cubic meters, and equivalent to35,315 cubic feet.
A colloquial name for the Southern portion of the UnitedStates, esp. during the Civil War. [U.S.]
A small knife with a thin, keen blade, -- used by surgeons, andin dissecting.
A kind of double thrown silk of very fine texture, that is,silk twisted like a rope with different strands, so as to increaseits strength.
Any butterfly of the tribe Nymphalidi, or genus Basilarchia, asthe ursula and the viceroy.
An order, or suborder, of birds, including more that half ofall the known species. It embraces all singing birds (Oscines),together with many other small perching birds.
To excel or surpass in reasoning; to reason better than. South.
An instrument for measuring the compressibility of liquids.
A cylindrical projection on each side of a piece, whether gun,mortar, or howitzer, serving to support it on the cheeks of thecarriage. See Illust. of Cannon.
A coarse leaden shot, larger than swan shot, used in huntingdeer and large game.
The line by which a fowling net was pulled over so as toinclose the birds.
To have inherent; to contain in itself; to possess. [Obs.] SirW. Raleigh.
A slope or inclination of the earth, as the side of a hill,considered as ascending, in opposition to declivity, or descending;an upward slope; ascent.
To twang.While the twangling violin Struck up with Soldier-laddie. Tennyson.
A fork, or farming utensil, used in pitching hay, sheaves ofgrain, or the like.
A coronet or little crown of a seed; the downy tuft on seeds.See Pappus. Martyn.
A genus of small European and American trees; the spindle tree.The bark is used as a cathartic.
One who pretends to, or is addicted to, theurgy. Hallywell.
A nunnery; -- a term still applied to the ruins of certainnunneries in England.
A white crystalline substance extracted from the fruit of thebay (Laurus nobilis), and consisting of a complex mixture of glycerinethers of several organic acids.
The quality or state of being sooty; fuliginousness. Johnson.
The condition of being abnormally small in stature;dwarfishness; -- opposed to gigantism.
The second day of the week; the day following Sunday.
Any shellfish which casts its shell, as a lobster. [Prov. Eng.]
A man whose occupation is to cover buildings with tiles.Bancroft.
The lower or under side of a sirloin of beef; the fillet.
The act of cutting off from the church; excommunication.
A yellow crystalline substance resembling quinone, extractedfrom green shucks of the walnut (Juglans regia); -- called alsonucin.
Any member like a step, as the raised back of an altar or thelike; a set raised over another. "The gradines of the amphitheeater."Layard.
Having a single rib or strong nerve running upward from thebase; -- said of a leaf.
The act of expelling or ejecting a fetus or an egg from thewomb.
A confused noise; uproar; tumult. [Colloq.] Thackeray.
A probable chemical element discovered by Sir William Crookesin 1898. Its nitrate is obtained byy practical decomposition andcrystallization of yttrium nitrate. At. wt., about 117.
Want of sobriety, moderation, or calmness; intemperance;drunkenness.
Consisting of, containing, or resembling, mother (in vinegar).
An expression composed of two or more terms, connected by thesigns plus or minus; as, a2 - 2ab + b2.
To mar or destroy the perfection of. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
A tribe of Ophiuroidea, including the genera Euryale,Astrophyton, etc. They generally have the arms branched. SeeAstrophyton.
A hardening of the heart; hardness of heart. [Obs.]
A circular saw; -- so called from the buzzing it makes whenrunning at full speed.
The right to take fish at a certain place, or in particularwaters. Abbott.

An American feline carnivore (Felis pardalis). It ranges fromthe Southwestern United States to Patagonia. It is covered withblackish ocellated spots and blotches, which are variously arranged.The ground color varies from reddish gray to tawny yellow.
A group of fishes, established by Agassiz, characterized byhaving scales with a pectinated margin, as in the perch. The group isnow generally regarded as artificial.
Having a shaft; -- applied to a spear when the head and theshaft are of different tinctures.

A wild duck (Aythya, or Fuligula, marila), which appears inlarge numbers on the eastern coast of the United States, in autumn; -- called also bluebill, blackhead, raft duck, and scaup duck. SeeScaup duck.
A genus of raptorial birds, including the European kite.
The constructive metabolism of the body, as distinguished fromkatabolism.
A military engine formerly used for throwing stones andjavelins.
A hollow cylindrical piece carried by a revolving shaft, onwhich it may, however, revolve independently.
One of the Northmen who founded a dynasty in Russia in the 9thcentury; also, one of the Northmen composing, at a later date, theimperial bodyguard at Constantinople.
A small silver coin. [Obs.]A thousand vines at a thousand silverings. Isa. vii. 23.
One of the several species of howling monkeys of South America.See Howler, 2.
The act of harvesting; also, that which is harvested.Swinburne.
Having a medium orbital index; having orbits neither broad nornarrow; between megaseme and microseme.
To vary, as a noun or a verb in its terminations; to decline,as a noun or adjective, or to conjugate, as a verb.
One of a sect of freethinkers among the Mohammedans.
A kind of sweet cake cut in strips and curled or twisted, andfried crisp in boiling fat. [Also written kruller.]
The doctrine, system, and practices of the Mormons.
The vital principle or force which (according to theParacelsians) presides over the growth and continuation of livingbeings; the anima mundi or plastic power of the old philosophers.[Obs.] Johnson.
The lowest sill of a structure, usually embedded in the soil;the lowest timber of a house; also, that sill or timber of a bridgewhich is laid at the bottom of the water. See Sill.
To search or prowl after; to rob; to plunder. [Obs.] Barrow.
A genus of minute fungi. The plants consist of slender threadswith terminal globular sporangia; mold.
One who, or that which, purifies or cleanses; a cleanser; arefiner.
A buttress of an arch; the supporter, or that part which joinsit to the upright pier.
A race or strain differing in certain characters from theparent breed; an incipient breed.
The watery fluid contained in the membranous labyrinth of theinternal ear.
Pertaining to a petal; attached to, or resembling, a petal.
To make solid or compact.Every machine is a solidified mechanical theorem. H. Spencer.
A hole near the bottom, through which the sediment iswithdrawn.
The hypothetical radical, (C6H5.C2H2)2C, of cinnamic compounds.[Formerly written also cinnamule.]
The top or head of a mast; the part of a mast above the hounds.
Anything made so as to form alternate squares lke those of acheckerboard.
The red or cuckoo gurnard (Trigla pini.) [Prov. Eng.]
The doctrine taught by Schelling, that matter and mind, andsubject and object, are identical in the Absolute; -- called also thesystem or doctrine of identity.
A new metallic element, of doubtful genuineness and uncertainindentification, said to exist in certain minerals, as columbite.Hermann.
A genus of Cephalopoda. The shell is called paper nautilus orpaper sailor.
Encompassed with a coma, or bushy appearance, like hair; hairy.
An order of ganoid fishes of which Amis is type. See Bowfin andGanoidei.
A record of what passes in the night; a nightly journal; --distinguished from diary. [R.] Addison.
A dullard, or dull person; a blockhead; a numskull. Entick.

One of successive or homodynamous parts in animals and plants;one of a series of similar parts that follow one another in avertebrate or articulate animal, as in an earthworm; a segment; asomite. See Illust. of Loeven's larva.
An admirer or lover of the fine arts; popularly, an amateur;especially, one who follows an art or a branch of knowledge,desultorily, or for amusement only.

A genus of leafles trees or shrubs, with drooping branchlets ofa rushlike appearance, mostly natives of Australia. Some of them arelarge, producing hard and heavy timber of excellent quality, calledbeefwood from its color.
The ruins of the fallen roof resulting from the removal of thepillars and stalls. Raymond.
A side dish; a dainty or relishing dish usually eaten after thejoints or principal dish; also, a sweetmeat, served with a dinner.
The motion of a horse when, raising his fore quarters, he keepshis hind feet on the ground without advancing; rearing.
The terminal lamina, or thin ventral part, of the anterior wallof the third ventricle of the brain. B. G. Wilder.
A graceless, unprincipled person; one who is wild and reckless.Beaconsfield.
The horoscope, or that degree of the ecliptic which rises abovethe horizon at the moment of one's birth; supposed to have acommanding influence on a person's life and fortune.
Having two legs or sides that are equal; -- said of a triangle.
A term of contempt for an Irish Methodist. Shipley.
A German silver coin worth about three shillings sterling, orabout 73 cents.
A ribbon or string used to draw clothes closer. [Obs.]
A slender trailing branch which takes root at the joints or endand there forms new plants, as in the strawberry and the commoncinquefoil.
A genus of hydroids having large, naked, flowerlike hydranthsat the summits of long, slender, usually simple, stems. Thegonophores are small, and form clusters at the bases of the outertentacles.
A poison separable from decomposed meat infusions, and supposedto be formed from albuminous matter through the agency of bacteria.
A hawk gradually changing the color of its feathers, commonlyin the second year.
One of the timbers which tail into a header, in floor framing.See Illust. of Header.
An instrument for measuring the distance of distinct vision,mainly for the selection of eveglasses.
A bar or lever, generally of wood, used in a windlass orcapstan, for heaving anchor, and, in modified forms, for variouspurposes.
Passing through several distinct larval forms; -- havingseveral distinct kinds of young.
Of or pertaining to a virago; having the qualities of a virago.Milton.
A kind of stereotype plate made by lithotypy; also, that whichin printed from it. See Lithotypy.
A hawser passed round the capstan, and having its two endslashed together to form an endless rope or chain; -- formerly usedfor heaving in the cable.
A little septum; a division between small cavities or parts.
A piece of armor covering the shoulder at the junction of thebody piece and arm piece.
To cut off, as a vowel or a syllable, usually the final one; tosubject to elision.
A rolling, marshy, mossy plain of Northern Siberia.
One of the legs of the loose drawers worn by children andwomen; particularly, the lower part of such a garment, coming belowthe knee, often made in a separate piece; -- chiefly in the plural.
To play the beau; to wait upon the ladies; also, to roam aboutfor pleasure without any definite plan. [Slang] Dickens.
To tear; to lacerate; to pierce or stab. De Quincey.

Any one of several species of American musteline carnivores ofthe genus Mephitis and allied genera. They have two glands near theanus, secreting an extremely fetid liquid, which the animal ejects atpleasure as a means of defense.
An attendant; a servant; a follower. Now chiefly used as apolitical cant term.
A speech, or figure of speech, designed to move the passion.Smart.
Material for studs, or joists; studs, or joists, collectively;studs.
A cassing or lining of staves; especially, one encircling awater wheel.
A tincture, rarely employed, which is considered as an orangecolor or bright brown. It is represented by diagonal lines fromsinister to dexter, crossed by vertical lines.
A proposition adopted by a majority of votes; especially, oneadopted by vote of the Athenian people; a statute. J. P. Mahaffy.
On deck; and hence, like aboveboard, without artifice. Smart.
A small, swift-sailing vessel, propelled by oars and lateensails, -- once common in the Mediterranean.
A group which includes the typical copepods and the lerneans.
An alkaloid found in opium. It has a weaker therapeutic actionthan morphine.
Marked or measured by crotchets; having musical notation.Harmar (1587).
To make a sound as if moving heavily or clumsily; to rumble.Cowper.
One of the lateral pieces next to the sternum in the thorax ofinsects.
One who had charge of the wall of a town, or its repairs.
Affected with the disease called grease; as, the heels of ahorse. See Grease, n., 2.
A goat upon whose head were symbolically placed the sins of thepeople, after which he was suffered to escape into the wilderness.Lev. xvi. 10.
An artificial pond, or a globe or tank (usually with glasssides), in which living specimens of aquatic animals or plants arekept.
A civil officer charged with the duty of impounding hogsrunning at large. [New Eng.] Bartlett.
Deprived of wits or understanding; distracted. [Obs.] Drayton.
An alkaloid, , prepared from codeine. In its effects itresembles apomorphine.
An artist who models or forms statues and reliefs in anyplastic material. [R.] Elmes.
Significant; ominous; serving as a warning of danger; --appliedesp. to the warning colors or forms of certain animals.
Of or pertaining to vanadium; obtained from vanadium; -- saidof an acid containing one equivalent of vanadium and two of oxygen.
One who contends for the prize in public games. [R.]
To wrong; to do injury to. [Obs.]Who hath you misboden or offended Chaucer.
Delicacy or softness in the representation of flesh.
Endowed with irritability; susceptible of irritation; capableof being excited to action by the application of certain stimuli.
That may be sqyared, or reduced to an equivalent square; --said of a surface when the area limited by a curve can be exactlyfound, and expressed in a finite number of algebraic terms.
The Destroyer; -- a name used (Rev. ix. 11) for the angel ofthe bottomless pit, answering to the Hebrew Abaddon.
The stamping of pigs of tin, by the proper officer, with thearms of the duchy of Cornwall.
One who rails; one who scoffs, insults, censures, or reproacheswith opprobrious language.
A leader in heresy; the chief of a sect of heretics. Bp.Stillingfleet.
A yellow-flowered composite herb (Lampsana communis), formerlyused as an external application to the nipples of women; -- calledalso dock-cress.
To beseech; to supplicate; to implore. [R.]. Cockerman.
A large bivalve shell of the East Indies (Hippopus maculatus),often used as an ornament.
One who, or that which, pares; an instrument for paring.
A compound of salicylal; -- named after the analogy of a salt.
A scamp; a scapegrace. [Spelt also scallawag.] [Slang, U.S.]Bartlett.
A cell or mass of protoplasm devoid of an envelope, as a whiteblood corpuscle.
Bread cut in various forms, and fried lightly in butter or oil,to garnish hashes, etc.
A rubbing or kneading of the body, especially when performed asa hygienic or remedial measure.
A diminutive of the bar, having one fourth its width.
To recant or recall, as an oath; to recall after having sworn;to abjure. J. Fletcher.
A hydrocarbon, C6H10, of the acetylene series, obtainedartificially as a colorless, volatile, pungent liquid; -- called alsohexoylene.
Equal law, or a well-adjusted constitution of government. [R.]Mitford.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, certain strata which occupyan intermediate position between the Eocene and Miocene periods.-- n.
The outer branch of the legs in certain Crustacea. SeeMaxilliped.
A division of Pseudoneuroptera including the species which havefour broad, flat wings, as the termites, or white-ants, and the stoneflies (Perla).
Pertaining to, containing, or resembling, zinc; zincous.
A machine for stirring and spreading hay, to expedite itsdrying.
In a decided manner; indisputably; clearly; thoroughly.
Priests, collectively; the priesthood; -- so called incontempt. [R.] Milton.
A substance produced by acting upon uric with warm and verydilute nitric acid.
A vessel built or fitted for the conveyance of troops; atransport. [Eng.]
An ancient military engine for casting stones and arrows bymeans of a spring.
A glen; a ravine closed at its upper end. [South Africa]
Frosty; covered with fine scales, hairs, dust, bloom, or thelike, so as to give the appearance of frost.
A single algebraic expression; that is, an expressionunconnected with any other by the sign of addition, substraction,equality, or inequality.
To free from that which cumbers or impedes; to disencumber.[Archaic] Pope.
a star of the first magnitude in the constellation Canis Minor,or the Little Dog.
A genus of slender, nematode worms of many species, parasiticin various animals. See Guinea worm.
A South American aquatic bird; the horned screamer or kamichi(Palamedea cornuta). See Kamichi.
One of the order of the Religious Servants of the Holy Virgin,founded in Florence in 1223.
The play in whist where partners trump each a different suit,and lead to each other for that purpose; -- called also seesaw.
A compound radical, C6H5.CO; the base of benzoic acid, of theoil of bitter almonds, and of an extensive series of compounds.[Formerly written also benzule.]
A little valve; a valvule; especially, one of the pieces whichcompose the outer covering of a pericarp.
The science or art of teaching; the principles and rules ofteaching; pedagogy.
In an acceptable manner; in a manner to please or givesatisfaction.
The after sail of a ship or bark, being a fore-and-aft sailattached to a boom and gaff; -- sometimes called driver. See Illust.under Sail. Totten.
To deprive of that principal quality of gavelkind tenure bywhich lands descend equally among all the sons of the tenant; -- saidof lands. Burrill.
Oral declaration; word of mouth; also, a writing not underseal. Blackstone.
A figure of speech by which what is to be understoodaffirmatively is stated negatively, and the contrary; affirmation bycontraries.
An inhabitant of the earth; a mortal.Earthings oft her deemed a deity. Drummond.
A post-mortem examination or inspection; an autopsy. SeeAutopsy.
That part of anatomy which treats of the soft parts. Itincludes myology, angiology, neurology, and splanchnology.
The osier willow (Salix viminalis). See Osier, n. (a).
Any plant of the American genus Hydrophyllum, herbs havingwhite or pale blue bell-shaped flowers. Gray.
A short aria, or air. "A military ariette." Sir W. Scott.
A small drum, especially a shallow drum with only one skin,played on with the hand, and having bells at the sides; a timbrel.
The planet which is lord of the sign where another planet is.[Obs.] Crabb.
Barium carbonate occurring in white or gray six-sided twincrystals, and also in columnar or granular masses.
A gummy substance of the pentosan class, present in woodytissue, and yielding xylose on hydrolysis; wood gum.
Egyptian dancing girls, of a lower sort than the almeh.

One of the anterior pair of mouth organs, terminated by apincherlike claw, in scorpions and allied Arachnida. They arehomologous with the falcers of spiders, and probably with themandibles of insects.
The offspring of a negress by a white man, or of a white womanby a negro, -- usually of a brownish yellow complexion.
One of a sect of Anabaptists who maintain that the demons ordevils will finally be saved.
One who pursues the sports of the field; one who hunts, fishes,etc.
The nucleus of a cell; the germinal or active spot of acellule, through or in which cell development takes place.
To be taken away, lost, or alienated, as a title or an estate.
An instrument used for cutting the bladder in operations forthe stone.
A brown, amorphous, bitter substance having a strong emeticaction, extracted from the root of the mudar.
Having the lower chap or jaw drooping, -- an indication ofhumiliation and dejection; crestfallen; discouraged. See Chopfallen.
A ball of minced meat, fowl, rice, or other ingredients, highlyseasoned, and fried.
Situated upon or above an artery; -- applied esp. to thebranches of the bronchi given off above the point where the pulmonaryartery crosses the bronchus.
Permitting liquids to pass by percolation; not capable ofretaining water; porous; pervious; -- said of gravelly or sandysoils, and the like.
To solve, as a problem, by enumerating the several things to bedone, in order to obtain what is required; to find the answer to, orthe result of. Hutton.
To trade beyond one's capital; to buy goods beyond the means ofpaying for or seleng them; to overstock the market.
A preacher; a sermonizer. [Derogative or Jocose.] Thackeray.

A piece of soft iron used to connect the two poles of a magnet,or electro-magnet, in order to complete the circuit, or to receiveand apply the magnetic force. In the ordinary horseshoe magnet, itserves to prevent the dissipation of the magnetic force.
A sirup in which, formerly, a decoction of barley entered, butwhich is now prepared with an emulsion of almonds, -- used to flavorbeverages or edibles.

A custom or right, analogous to borough-English in England,formerly existing in various parts of Europe, and surviving in partsof Germany and Austria, by which certain entailed estates, as ahomestead and adjacent land, descend to the youngest male heir.
A small or secondary spike; especially, one of the ultimateparts of the in florescence of grasses. See Illust. of Quaking grass.
The discharge from the womb and vagina which followschildbirth.
The state of being a cuckold; the practice of making cuckolds.
The lesser spotted woodpecker (Dryobates minor). [Prov. Eng.]
A physiological organ; a living organ; an organ endowed withfunction; -- distinguished from idorgan.
The public executioner at Rome, who executed persons of thelowest rank; hence, an executioner or hangman.
A female deacon; as:(a) (Primitive Ch.) One of an order of women whose duties resembledthose of deacons. (b) (Ch. of Eng. and Prot. Epis. Ch.)
The form or figure assumed by a drop of oil when placed uponwater or some other liquid with which it does not mix.
A white crystalline tasteless substance extracted from gumstorax, and consisting of a salt of cinnamic acid with cinnamicalcohol.
To take out the entrails of; to disembowel; to gut.
A variety of starch extracted from the dahlia; -- called alsoinulin. See Inulin.
The addition to the human body of some artificial part, toreplace one that is wanting, as a log or an eye; -- called alsoprothesis.
Suspicious; captious; disposed to take umbrage. [Obs. & R.] SirH. Wotton.
A poisonous umbelliferous plant; in England, the Cicuta virosa;in the United States, the Cicuta maculata and the Archemora rigida.See Water hemlock.
Having no sinews; hence, having no strength or vigor.

A yellow, crystalline, volatile substance, CI3H, having anoffensive odor and sweetish taste, and analogous to chloroform. It isused in medicine as a healing and antiseptic dressing for wounds andsores.
The process of soaking through anything. [Obs.] Bacon.
Full of pocks; affected with smallpox or other eruptivedisease. Bp. Hall.
A pungent oily substance obtained by redistilling bone oil.[Obs.]
One who has commited a crime; especially, one who is foundguilty by verdict, confession, or proof; a malefactor; a felon.
To cover or overspread with, or as with, leaves. [R.] Howell.
Pertaining to exile or banishment, esp. to that of the Jews inBabylon. Encyc. Dict.
The quality of being fickle; instability; inconsonancy. Shak.
To deprive of bones; to take out the bones of; to bone. [Obs.]Bailey.
The most popular of the Hindoo divinities, usually held to bethe eighth incarnation of the god Vishnu.
Like or pertaining to the genus Haliotis; ear-shaped.
A lady superior of a priory of nuns, and next in dignity to anabbess.

A genus of plants including the plants called mugwort,southernwood, and wormwood. Of these A. absinthium, or commonwormwood, is well known, and A. tridentata is the sage brush of theRocky Mountain region.
The means or parts by which cars are connected to be drawn.
To get under or beneath; also, to understand. [Obs.] R. ofGloucester.
A receiver; the person or thing that receives; one to whom, orthat to which, anything is given or communicated; specifically, thereceiver of a still.
A vocal or instrumental composition of a soft tranquilcharacter, having a lulling effect; a cradle song.
Chaffy; like chaff; paleaceous. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
To make eternal. [Obs.]Fame . . . eternifies the name. Mir. for Mag.
One who neglects, for two years, to perform the service bywhich he holds lands, so that he incurs the danger of the writ ofcessavit. See Cessavit. Cowell.
To render dainty, delicate, or fastidious. "Daintifiedemotion." Sat. rev.
A temporary fort or parallel where siege guns are mounted.
Incapable of being penetrated by balls from firearms.
An obsequious follower of the modes and fashions. [R.] Fuller.
A kind of lyric poetry in honor of Bacchus, usually sung by aband of revelers to a flute accompaniment; hence, in general, a poemwritten in a wild irregular strain. Bentley.
The resolution or favorable termination of a disease, coming ongradually and not marked by abrupt change.
To amalgamate and blend; to beat up or mix in water, as clay.
An organ in which the ova are developed in certain Turbellaria.
A man who assists women in childbirth; a man midwife; anobstetrician.
A modification of the stethoscope, for directly auscultatingthe uterus from the vagina.
A right of digging turf on another man's land; also, the groundwhere turf is dug.
Arched like the roof of the mouth, as the upper lip of manyringent flowers.
A blain, sore, or inflammatory swelling, produced by exposureof the feet or hands to cold, and attended by itching, pain, andsometimes ulceration.
A small sack or case, usually of leather, but sometimes ofother material, for containing the clothes, toilet articles, etc., ofa traveler; a traveling bag; a portmanteau.
