An instrument for measuring the diameters of minute particlesor fibers, from the size of the colored rings produced by thediffraction of the light in which the objects are viewed.
Of or pertaining to Jutland, or to the people of Jutland.
To answer, as the defendant to the plaintiff's replication.
A leap in which the horse pulls up his hind legs toward hisbelly.
Being without a soul, or without greatness or nobleness ofmind; mean; spiritless.Slave, souless villain, dog! Shak.
Of or pertaining to the pharynx; in the region of the pharynx.
A strong, offensive smell; stench; fetidness. Arbuthnot.
One who makes or mends hedges; also, one who hedges, as, inbetting.
An exchange for the transaction of business. [Sp. Amer. & Phil.Islands]
That which naturally invests or covers another thing, as thetesta or the tegmen of a seed; specifically (Anat.), a covering whichinvests the body, as the skin, or a membrane that invests aparticular.
Incomprehensibility of things; the doctrine held by the ancientSkeptic philosophers, that human knowledge never amounts tocertainty, but only to probability.
Situated in the region of the rump, or posterior end of thebackbone; -- applied especially to the posterior median plates in thecarapace of chelonians.
A treatise on beasts; esp., one of the moralizing orallegorical beast tales written in the Middle Ages.
A worshiper of the god Vishnu in any of his incarnations.
A manumitted slave; a freedman; also, the son of a freedman.
To dry in, or to expose to, the sun's rays; to ripen or prepareby such exposure. Johnson.
The decay and dissolution of the organic tissues and of theblood.
One who infracts or infringes; a violator; a breaker.
One who commences a personal action or suit to obtain a remedyfor an injury to his rights; -- opposed to Ant: defendant.
Abounding in cobwebs, or any fine web; resembling a cobweb.
A tribe of Indians who, when first known, lived on the OttawaRiver. Most of them subsequently migrated to the southwestern shoreof Lake Superior.
A valuable ore of copper, containing copper, iron, and sulphur;-- also called purple copper ore (or erubescite), in allusion to thecolors shown upon the slightly tarnished surface.
Pertaining to abortion; miscarrying; abortive. Carlyle.
A player in the ripieno portion of an orchestra. See Ripieno.
A braided cord or fabric formed by plaiting together rope yarnsor other small stuff.
An instrument for measuring the area of any plane figure,however irregular, by passing a tracer around the bounding line; aplatometer.
A diseased state; unhealthiness. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
A heap of ore; a mass undergoing the process of amalgamation.
An element possessing metallic properties in an inferior degreeand not malleable, as arsenic, antimony, bismuth, molybdenum,uranium, etc. [Obs.]
Pertaining to, derived from, or resembling, the dogwood (Cornusflorida).
A prayer; an invocation; a religious formula; a charm. [India]
The iterative sound of beating a drum, or of a galloping horse.
A movable tower erected by besiegers for purposes of attack anddefense.
A label, placed upon or in a book, showing its ownership or itsposition in a library.
An owner or occupant of, or laborer on, a ranch; a herdsman.[Western U. S.]
A delicate bar of cartilage connecting the dorsal and ventralextremities of the first pair of bronchial cartilages in the syrinxof birds.
The clear, viscid fluid secreted by the poison glands ofcertain serpents; also, a nitrogenous base contained in this, andsupposed to be the active poisonous principle of the virus. Brande &C.
The act of editing, or writing for, a magazine. [Colloq.]Byron.
To have the axes of the eyes not coincident; -- to be cross-eyed.
A small rag or pledget introduced into the hole in the craniummade by a trephine. Dunglison.
An outer garment worn in the 18th century; esp., a woman'sriding habit, buttoned down the front. Fairholt.
Just or harmonious proportion or movement, as in thecomposition of a poem, an edifice, a painting, or a statue.
To throw onto confusion or disorder; to render maudlin. [Obs.]
A mineral of a white a slightly bluish color, usually massive.It is anhydrous sulphate of lime, and differs from gypsum in notcontaining water (whence the name).
To treat as a lout; to talk abusively to. [Obs.] Camden.
Folded together, or upon itself, with the fold runninglengthwise.
A worthless, base, degenerate person or animal. [Obs.]Callander.
An officer of the king's stables whose duty it was to provideoats for the horses. [Obs.]
A cotton fabric, figured in the loom, -- used as a dress goodsfor women and children, and for vestings, etc.
To envelop as in clouds; to darken; to obscure. Milton.
To form or deposit in strata, or layers, as substances in theearth; to arrange in strata.
A fold of the endoderm, which projects into the blood cavity ofascidians. See Tunicata.
A Mexican spinous lizard (Phrynosoma orbiculare) having a headsomewhat like that of a toad; -- called also horned toad.
A false wall; a work raised in front of the main wall. [Writtenalso vaimure, and vamure.] Camden.
A white crystalline powder used as an intestinal antiseptic;beta-naphthol benzoate.
Consanguinity by a line of males only, as distinguished fromcognation. Bouvier.
Pertaining to the part of a radiate animal which contains themouth. L. Agassiz.
A running ornament consisting of leaves and tendrils, used inGothic architecture.
Animals without a mouth or regular internal organs, as thesponges.
Like, or pertaining to, the goby, or the genus Gobius.-- n.
The division of the terms of an equation by a known quantitythat is involved in the first term. [Obs.]
A muscle having two heads or origins; -- applied particularlyto a flexor in the arm, and to another in the thigh.
The right of using and enjoying the profits of an estate orother thing belonging to another, without impairing the substance.Burrill.
Pertaining to nativities; calculated by astrologers; showingposition of stars at one's birth. Howell.
Pertaining to, or divided into, centuries or hundreds. [R.]Holland.
Having a very flat or snub nose, with the end turned up.
A fruit bat (Pteropus medius) native of India. It is similar tothe flying fox, but smaller.
An emerald-green variety of spodumene found in North Carolina;lithia emerald, -- used as a gem.
Pertaining to a poem, or to poetry; poetical. [R.] Coleridge.
A roll of hair, silk, etc., passed through the flesh of horses,answering to a seton in human surgery.
A salt formed by the union of arsenious acid with a base.
The act or process of ascertaining the proportion of aparticular metal in an ore or alloy; especially, the determination ofthe proportion of gold or silver in bullion or coin.
A yellow or brown amorphous substance obtained as a sublimationproduct in the flues of smelting furnaces of zinc, and consisting ofa crude zinc oxide.
A swindler; one who deceives by trickery. [Colloq.] Arbuthnot.
A sweating bath or place for sweating. Sir T. Herbert.
A European siluroid fish (Silurus glanis) allied to the cat-fishes. It is the largest fresh-water fish of Europe, sometimesbecoming six feet or more in length. See Siluroid.
Articles for the table, as china or silverware, that are moreor less flat, as distinguished from hollow ware.
A strong, closely woven linen or cotton fabric, of which ticksfor beds are made. It is usually twilled, and woven in stripes ofdifferent colors, as white and blue; -- called also ticken.
An olive stuffed with a kind of sweet red pepper, or pimiento.

One of an ancient and secret association or fraternity, said tohave been at first composed of masons or builders in stone, but nowconsisting of persons who are united for social enjoyment and mutualassistance.
Want of vigilance; neglect of watching; carelessness.
To reduce to thralldom; to inthrall. [Obs.] Spenser.
A pipe with a long, flexible stem, so arranged that the smokeis cooled by being made to pass through water.
One who, or that which, subdues; a conqueror. Spenser.
Belonging to the front part; being in front; esp. (Anat.),

That form of delusion which leads to extravagant and absurdundertakings or sacrifices in obedience to a morbidly romantic idealof duty or honor, as illustrated by the exploits of Don Quixote inknight-errantry.
A glucoside extracted from the root of the white swallowwort(Vincetoxicum officinale, a plant of the Asclepias family) as abitter yellow amorphous substance; -- called also asclepiadin, andcynanchin.
Pertaining to a rector or a rectory; rectoral. Shipley.
The main substance of the muscular wall of the heart inclosedbetween the epicardium and endocardium.
The rejecting or casting off of some part, more particularly,the outer cuticular layer, as the shells of crustaceans, skins ofsnakes, etc.; molting; ecdysis.
One addicted to mannerism; a person who, in action, bearing, ortreatment, carries characteristic peculiarities to excess. Seecitation under Mannerism.
Of or pertaining to the New World, or Western Hemisphere.
A somewhat rare skin disease, characterized by the developmentof blebs upon different part of the body. Quain.
A rope of hair or of maguey fiber, for tying horses, etc.[Southwestern U. S.]
A subordinate portion or a subdivision of a sentence containinga subject and its predicate.
The principal female divinity of the Phoenicians, as Baal wasthe principal male divinity. W. Smith.
A tribe of warlike Indians formerly inhabiting NorthernCalifornia. They are nearly extinct.
A plane figure bounded by four right lines, of which no two areparallel.
One whose occupation is to make utensils of pewter; apewtersmith. Shak.
A figure of speech whereby the mental habitude of an adversaryor opponent is feigned for the purpose of arguing against him. Crabb.
Valuable beyond estimation; inestimable; priceless; precious.
An outwork in the main ditch, in front of the curtain, betweentwo bastions. See Illust. of Ravelin.
The act of making one a denizen or adopted citizen;naturalization. Hallam.
Strong aversion; intense dislike; hate; an affection of themind awakened by something regarded as evil.
To strip of gear; to unharness; to throw out of gear.
A genus of plants of many species, producing capsules or dryberries of various forms, which have an exceedingly pungent, bitingtaste, and when ground form the red of Cayenne pepper of commerce.
A lead ore found in Cornwall, England, and used by potters togive a green glaze to their wares; potter's ore.

One of a body of mounted soldiers recruited from slavesconverted to Mohammedanism, who, during several centuries, had moreor less control of the government of Egypt, until exterminated ordispersed by Mehemet Ali in 1811.
A fat, ungainly, stupid person; an awkward bungler. [Law.]
Pertaining to, or containing, ruthenium; designating thosecompounds in which it has a lower valence as contrasted with rutheniccompounds.
A fourth part of the coin called an as. See 3d As, 2.
A toxic substance contained in the venom of poisonous snakes;also, a (supposedly identical) toxic substance obtained by thecleavage of an albumose.
One of the Catarrhina, a division of Quadrumana, including theOld World monkeys and apes which have the nostrils close together andturned downward. See Monkey.
A bushing for expanding the end of a flue to fasten it tightlyin the tube plate, or for partly filling up its mouth.
Good or established order or arrangement. [R.] E. Waterhouse.
In mammals, a fluid excretion from the kidneys; in birds andreptiles, a solid or semisolid excretion.
A follower of Jean de Labadie, a religious teacher of the 17thcentury, who left the Roman Catholic Church and taught a kind ofmysticism, and the obligation of community of property amongChristians.
A kind of notary public, or attorney, in the Levant.

An artificial channel into which water is let by a sluice;specifically, a trough constructed over the bed of a stream, so thatlogs, lumber, or rubbish can be floated down to some convenient placeof delivery.
An insect in the larval state; a caterpillar; a larva.
A kind of soft tumor, usually of syphilitic origin.
The act of commiting, or the state of being committed;commitment.
A large, white, South American duck, of the genus Cascoroba,resembling a swan.
A week; any period of seven consecutive days and nights. SeeSennight.
A kind of sweet wine from Crete, the Canary Islands, etc. Shak.
That which tightens; specifically (Mach.), a tightening pulley.
The external parts of the female genital organs; sometimes, theopening between the projecting parts of the external organs.
To deprive of a guard; to leave unprotected. [R.] Sterne.
The Arabian camel (Camelus dromedarius), having one hump orprotuberance on the back, in distinction from the Bactrian camel,which has two humps.
Absence of reverse; frankness; freedom of communication. T.Warton.
A white crystalline, sugary substance obtained from an Africancaotchouc.
Containing seeds or stones of grapes, or grains like them.
A roofing tile, of peculiar form, having a transverse sectionresembling an elongated S laid on its side (
Uniformly or evenly distributed or spread; even; smooth. SeeSuant. Thoreau.
Pertaining to, or designating, a complex acid obtained, as ayellow crystalline substance, from certain genera of lichens (Usnea,Parmelia, etc.).
Having tubercles or grainlike processes, as the petals orsepals of some flowers.
A change of apparel; a second or different suit. [Obs.] Beau &Fl.
The ratio of mass, or quantity of matter, to bulk or volume,esp. as compared with the mass and volume of a portion of somesubstance used as a standard.
An assessment equal to a fourth part of the revenue. [India] J.Mill.
Admitted to a state of paradisaic happiness. [R.] Davies (Wit'sPilgr. ).
A granular variety of pyroxene, green or white in color.
Abounding in scrog; also, twisted; stunted. [Prov. Eng. &Scot.] Halliwell.
A genus of Cetacea, including the dolphin. See Dolphin,
A Berserker, or Norse warrior who fought without armor, orshirt of mail. Hence, adverbially: Without shirt of mail or armor.
The elongation, or angular distance from the sun; -- saidchiefly of the inferior planets. [R.]
A genus of venomous snakes found both in America and the OldWorld. Many species are known. See Coral snake, under Coral.

A small American ericaceous shrub (Kalmia angustifolia); --called also calfkill, sheepkill, sheep laurel, etc. It is supposed topoison sheep and other animals that eat it at times when the snow isdeep and they cannot find other food.
A certain surface of the third degree, described by a movingstraight line; -- used to illustrate the motions of a rigid body andalso the forces acting on the body.
To admit or accept the tenets of the Arians; to become anArian.
One of the Gorgoniacea; -- so called because the fleshy partsurrounds a solid axis, like a bark.
To sprinkle flour and salt and drip butter or fat on, as onmeat in roasting.
An officer who commanded a company; a captain. Mitford.
An apparatus for detecting the presence of any dangerous gas,from a gas leak in a coal mine or a dwelling house.
A taking or reception, as the receiving of rents or tithes inkind, the receiving of profits. Blackstone.
An animal base or alkaloid, appearing in the tissue duringlife; hence, a vital alkaloid, as distinguished from a ptomaine orcadaveric poison.
Happening independently of human will or means of foresight;resulting from unavoidable physical causes. Abbott.
An oily liquid, Cl3.CHO, analogous to chloral and bromal.
Depressed; flattened. [Obs.]Though my nose be cammoused. B. Jonson
The art or practice of punning; paronomasia. [R.] Pope.
To surpass in marching; to march faster than, or so as to leavebehind.
A Whig; -- a cant term applied in contempt to ScotchPresbyterians. [Scot.] Sir W. Scott.
A tree nymph whose life ended with that of the particular tree,usually an oak, which had been her abode.

A seashore plant of the Spinach family (Salicornia herbacea),with succulent jointed stems; also, a prickly plant of the samefamily (Salsola Kali), both formerly burned for the sake of theashes, which yield soda for making glass and soap.
A genus of herbaceous plants, with racemes of two-spurred orheart-shaped flowers, including the Dutchman's breeches, and the moreshowy Bleeding heart (D. spectabilis). [Corruptly written dielytra.]
Mournful; -- said of a species of music among the ancientGreeks. Busby.
A division of the Crinoidea, including those furnished withlong jointed arms. See Crinoidea.

A trope in which one word is put for another that suggests it;as, we say, a man keeps a good table instead of good provisions; weread Virgil, that is, his poems; a man has a warm heart, that is,warm affections.
Having the form or appearance of glass; resembling glass;glasslike.
A newly formed shoot, or the annually produced addition to thestems of many mosses.
One to whom a thing is referred; a person to whom a matter indispute has been referred, in order that he may settle it.
Slow or slowly; -- more so than adagio; next in slowness tograve, which is also weighty and solemn.-- n.
One who makes a blustering show of valor or force of arms.Shak.
A suffrutescent, D. Fraxinella (the only species), with strongperfume and showy flowers. The volatile oil of the leaves is highlyinflammable.
A symbol of the solar deity, found on monuments exhumed inBabylon, Nineveh, etc.
A small white-flowered herb (Samolus Valerandi) found usuallyin wet places; water pimpernel.
Sugar confectionery; a sugarplum; hence, any dainty.
To recover health; to regain strength; to convalesce.
One who receives the eucharist in both kinds; esp., one of abody of Hussites who in the 15th century fought for the right to dothis. Called also Calixtines.
An officer in the Court of King's Bench and Common Pleas whoseduty it was make out exigents. The office in now abolished. Cowell.
One who, or that which, suspends; esp., one of a pair of strapsor braces worn over the shoulders, for holding up the trousers.
A colorless oily liquid, CCl3.CHO, of a pungent odor and harshtaste, obtained by the action of chlorine upon ordinary or ethylalcohol.
The knot or bunch of foliage, or foliated ornament, that formsthe upper extremity of a pinnacle in Gothic architecture; sometimes,the pinnacle itself.
A term supposed to mean, perforated wind instruments of music,as pipes or flutes. Ps. v. (heading).
A shoot from the roots or lower part of the stem of a plant; --so called, perhaps, from diverting nourishment from the body of theplant.
A base, C10H19N, produced by heating valeric aldehyde withammonia. It is probably related to the conine alkaloids.
Existence as a separate self, or independent person; consciouspersonality; individuality. Bib. Sacra.
A magnificent and imposing ceremonial performed in honor of ageneral who had gained a decisive victory over a foreign enemy.
Purifying the blood or the humors; depuratory.-- n.
A dainty morsel; a Welsh rabbit. See Welsh rabbit, underRabbit.
A plant which produces only that kind of reproductive organswhich are capable of developing into fruit after impregnation orfertilization; a pistillate plant.
One of a proposed class of flowering plants growning on theroots of other plants and destitute of green foliage.
One of the somites (arthromeres) that make up the thorax ofArthropods. Packard.
One of the seeds or large beans of a tropical vine (Entadascandens) used for making purses, scent bottles, etc.
Any species of marine fishes of the genus Trichiurus; esp., T.lepterus of Europe and America. They are long and like a band, with aslender, pointed tail. Called also bladefish.
Sweepings; refuse; the lowest order of society. Beau & Fl.
A measure of energy or work done; the power exerted in raisingone gram through the distance of one meter against gravitation.
To load with too great weight or too much care, etc. Sir P.Sidney.

A bitter American herb of the Bloodwort family, with the leavesall radical, and the small yellow or white flowers in a long spike(Aletris farinosa and A. aurea). Called sometimes star grass,blackroot, blazing star, and unicorn root.
One of a group of gigantic, horned beetles, including DynastusNeptunus, and the Hercules beetle (D. Hercules) of tropical America,which grow to be six inches in length.
The art of uttering words corectly; a correct pronunciation ofwords; also, mode of pronunciation.
To put in between other things; to insert. [Obs.] Brerewood.
The second coat, or integument, of an ovule, lying within theprimine.
A kind of Persian wine; -- so called from the place whence itis brought.
Inclined to tolerate; favoring toleration; forbearing;ingulgent.
The act of drawing after, or pursuing, deer with a dog. Cowell.

A structure of considerable magnitude, usually with arches orsupported on trestles, for carrying a road, as a railroad, high abovethe ground or water; a bridge; especially, one for crossing a valleyor a gorge. Cf. Trestlework.
A civil officer or magistrate among the ancient Romans.
A malvaceous tree (Hoheria populnea) of New Zealand, the barkof which is used for cordage.
A drink made of orange juice and water, corresponding tolemonade; orange sherbet.
One of a mongrel breed of dogs said to have been a crossbetween the sheep dog, greyhound, and spaniel. It hunts gamesilently, by scent, and is often used by poachers.
In lichens, a Hardened cup or disk surrounded by a rim andcontaining the fructification, or asci.
Like or pertaining to the genus Didus, or the dodo.
An ornamental case of hold the corporal when not in use.Shipley.
A white, crystalline substance, having a bitter taste and aneutral reaction, and forming one of the essential ingredients oflactucarium.
To sew up, so nicely that the seam is not perceived; to renter.Marryat.
A hydrous phosphate of zinc in transparent prismatic crystals.
The process of putting a book into its cover, and making itready for the finisher.
Lit., given; hence, in a literary work, as a drama or tale,that which is assumed as to characters, situation, etc., as a basisfor the plot or story.  W. E. Henley.

A photograph printed by a process in which a strip or roll ofsensitized paper is automatically fed over the negative so that aseries of prints are made, and are then developed, fixed, cut apart,and washed at a very rapid rate.
A military punishment formerly practiced, which consisted indrawing an offender to the top of a beam and letting him fall to thelength of the rope, by which means a limb was often dislocated. Shak.
Any one of the several symmetrical segments arranged around thecentral axis and composing the body of a radiate anmal.
The chief officer of a shire or county, to whom is intrustedthe execution of the laws, the serving of judicial writs andprocesses, and the preservation of the peace.
The desertion by a party to any pleading of the ground taken byhim in his last antecedent pleading, and the adoption of another.Bouvier.
A talking in sleep; the talking of one in a state ofsomnipathy. [R.] Coleridge.
A horn, or anything shaped like or resembling a horn.
A keeper of stock or cattle; a herdsman. [Southwestern U. S.]Bartlett.
St. Vitus's dance; a disease attended with convulsivetwitchings and other involuntary movements of the muscles or limbs.
To cause to become an object; to cause to assume the characterof an object; to render objective. J. D. Morell.
One who converts cast iron into wrought iron by the process ofpuddling.
Properly, a short hauberk, but often used loosely for thehauberk. Chaucer.
Any myriapod of the genus Iulus and allied genera which rollsup spirally; a galleyworm. See Illust. under Myriapod.
A white, crystalline substance having a sweetish taste,obtained by the decomposition of hesperidin, and regarded as acomplex derivative of caffeic acid.
To take off the slings of, as a yard, a cask, or the like; torelease from the slings. Totten.
The hoary, or northern, marmot (Arctomys pruinosus).

The cow blackbird (Molothrus ater), an American starling. Likethe European cuckoo, it builds no nest, but lays its eggs in thenests of other birds; -- so called because frequently associated withcattle.
An umbelliferous plant (Foeniculum dulce) having a somewhattuberous stem; sweet fennel. The blanched stems are used in Franceand Italy as a culinary vegetable.
One who believes in, or maintains the doctrine of, a pluralityof gods.
The art of carving statues or images as representatives of realpersons or things; a branch of sculpture. Sir W. Temple.
One who wanders; a rambler; one who roves; hence, one whodeviates from duty.
One who plunders or pillages without the authority of nationalwarfare; a member of a predatory band; a pillager; a buccaneer; a searobber. Bacon.
Sensitive or responsive to moral excellence. Dr. H. More.
A political party in France, during the minority of Louis XIV.,who opposed the government, and made war upon the court party.
The last stage or consequence; finality. [Obs.] Bacon.
A method of painting with opaque colors, which have been groundin water and mingled with a preparation of gum; also, a picture thuspainted.
Having no excuse; not admitting of excuse or apology. Whillock.
A remedy for acidity of the stomach, as an alkali or absorbent.-- a.
Critically discerning; sagacious; shrewd; subtle; crafty.
One who gripes; an oppressor; an extortioner. Burton.

A knob or ball; an object resembling a ball in form; as:(a) The knob on the hilt of a sword. Macaulay.(b) The knob or protuberant part of a saddlebow.(c) The top (of the head). Chaucer.(d) A knob forming the finial of a turret or pavilion.
Having the color spots, or structural parts, arranged spirally.
A branch vein which drops off from, or leaves, the main lode.
A registrar or recorder; a notary. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
One who, or that which, weeds, or frees from anything noxious.
A lamellibranch which has three muscular scars on each valve.
The twisting of an artery with a needle to arrest hemorrhage.
Of or pertaining to a pupa, or the condition of a pupa.
Of, pertaining to, or obtained from, sweet clover or meliot;specifically, designating an acid of the aromatic series, obtainedfrom melilot as a white crystalline substance.
Want of vision or of the power of seeing. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
The skull of an animal; especially, that part of the skull,either cartilaginous or bony, which immediately incloses the brain;the brain case or brainpan. See Skull.
The naming or publishing of the current price of stocks, bonds,or any commodity; also the price named.
A peculiar fatlike body, made up of cholesterin and certainfatty acids, found in feathers, hair, wool, and keratin tissuesgenerally.
Pertaining to, or designating, a fatty acid analogous to oleicacid, obtained from castor oil as an oily substance, Cricinolic.
The ethyl ether of phenol, obtained as an aromatic liquid,C6H5.O.C2H5.
A genus of longeared South American monkeys, including numerousspecies of marmosets. See Marmoset.
The theory of generation which holds that the germ is createdentirely new, not merely expanded, by the procreative power of theparents. It is opposed to the theory of evolution, also tosyngenesis.
Situated in front of any transverse axis in the body of ananimal; anterior; cephalic; esp., in front, or on the anterior, orcephalic (that is, radial or tibial) side of the axis of a limb.
To come out finally or in conclusion; to result; to come topass.
Resembling an acorn; -- applied to a group of barnacles havingshells shaped like acorns. See Acornshell, and Barnacle.
A clock, watch, or other instrument, to measure or show theprogress of time; a chronometer.
A copy of a print, writing, etc., made by placing it upon achemically prepared paper which is acted upon by a gas whichpermeates the paper of the print, writing, etc.

Formerly, defamation generally, whether oral or written; inmodern usage, defamation by words spoken; utterance of false,malicious, and defamatory words, tending to the damage and derogationof another; calumny. See the Note under Defamation. Burril.
The quality or state of being neutral. See Neutral, a., 4.
The quality or state of being tactile; perceptibility by touch;tangibleness.
To daub or catch with glue or birdlime; to entangle withglutinous matter. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
A kind of plastic cement, or artificial stone, consistingchiefly of magnesia and silica; -- called also albolite.
Somewhat worn or damaged by having been kept for a time in ashop.
A kind of glass produced by volcanoes. It is usually of a blackcolor, and opaque, except in thin splinters.
The protection of the interior walls of a fortification from anenfilading fire, as by covering them, or by a high parapet on theexposed side.

A device for restoring a coherer to its normal condition afterit has been affected by an electric wave, a process usuallyaccomplished by some method of tapping or shaking, or by rotation ofthe coherer.
A person who adheres to his sovereign or to the lawfulauthority; especially, one who maintains his allegiance to his princeor government, and defends his cause in times of revolt orrevolution.
An alloy of gold, silver, and copper, of which an inferiorquality of jewerly is made.
The hundredth part of a stere, equal to .353 cubic feet.
One who contrives, makes, or arranges for, anything, as a book,a machine, etc. [Colloq.]A diligent getter-up of miscellaneous works. W. Irving.
A tendency in the end of a magnetic needle to point toward thesouth pole. Faraday.
A nest, or habitation, of insects of the wasp kind.
One of the earths, consisting of two parts of aluminium andthree of oxygen, Al2O3.
An old money of account in Bombay, equal to three fifths of arupee.
The soft, spongy, or cancellated substance between the platesof the skull.
Inclined to bluster; given to blustering; blustering. Motley.
An organ which produces both ova and spermatozoids; anhermaphrodite gland.
An ancient galley or vessel with tree banks, or tiers, of oars.
A term applied to the bark obtained from young oak trees.McElrath.
A machine for throwing water by hand power, as a garden engine,a fire extinguisher, etc.

A compound radical, NH2, not yet obtained in a separate state,which may be regarded as ammonia from the molecule of which one ofits hydrogen atoms has been removed; -- called also the amido group,and in composition represented by the form amido.
A small mound of earth; ground slightly elevated; a smallridge.
An instrument for studying the mechanism of accommodation.
A fivefold athletic performance peculiar to the great nationalgames of the Greeks, including leaping, foot racing, wrestling,throwing the discus, and throwing the spear.
A man given to lewdness; one addicted, in an excessive degree,to the indulgence of sexual desire, or to illicit commerce withwomen.
A beach; a strand; in the plains and deserts of Texas, NewMexico, and Arizona, a broad, level spot, on which subsequentlybecomes dry by evaporation. Bartlett.
The quality or state of being timid; timorousness; timidness.
Applied to those ova which segment uniformly, and which havelittle or no food yelk embedded in their protoplasm. Balfour.
A name for the one of the fancy sails alleged to have beensometimes set above the skysail. [Obs.](b) A very tall building.(c) Hence, anything usually large, high, or excessive. [Slang orColloq.]
One who prepares and sells drugs or compounds for medicinalpurposes.
Having the arms growing broader and floriated toward the end; -- said of a cross. See Illust. 9 of Cross.
A large, long-legged South American bird (Dicholophuscristatus) which preys upon snakes, etc. See Seriema.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid (called alsohydroxy malonic acid) obtained, by reducing mesoxalic acid, as awhite crystalline substance.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid NH2.C2O2.HO obtained asa fine crystalline powder, intermediate between oxalic acid andoxamide. Its ammonium salt is obtained by boiling oxamide withammonia.
The grievance complained of; the substantial cause of theaction; also, in general, the ground or essence of a complaint.Bouvier.
; sing. Dyak. (Ethnol.) The aboriginal and most numerousinhabitants of Borneo. They are partially civilized, but retain manybarbarous practices.
Methyl phenyl ether, C6H5OCH3, got by distilling anisic acid orby the action of methide on potassium phenolate.
A mineral occurring as an aggregation of minute scales havingan olive-green color and pearly luster. It is a hydrous silicate ofaluminia and iron.
Cleared and ready for engagement, as a ship. Smart.
Of the age of the Lias; pertaining to the Lias Formation.-- n.
The hide or skin of a calf; or leather made of the skin.
To garrison; to put in garrison, or to protect by a garrison.Bp. Hall.
Defensive armor used for the whole body and often for thehorse, also, esp. the linked mail or scale armor of some easternnations.
An order of birds which formerly included all the waders. Bylater writers it is usually restricted to the sandpipers, plovers,and allied forms; -- called also Grallatores.
Amber; also, the alloy of gold and silver, called electrum.
The person to whom goods are committed in trust, and who has atemporary possession and a qualified property in them, for thepurposes of the trust. Blackstone.
Sworn brotherhood; a society in ancient Greece nearlyresembling a modern political club.
A governor or prefect appointed by the Spartans in the citiessubjugated by them.
A passage cut through the glacis to facilitate sallies by thebesieged. Wilhelm.
The union, or binding together, of adjacent parts or tissues.
To beat back; to offer sudden resistance to; to check; to repelor repulse violently, harshly, or uncourteously.
To delight one's self; to indulge in feasting; to revel. [Obs.]
The quality or state of being wily; craftiness; cunning; guile.
Direct; proving directly; -- applied to reasoning, and opposedto elenchtic or refutative.
Like a medusa; having the fundamental structure of a medusa,but without a locomotive disk; -- said of the sessile gonophores ofhydroids.-- n.
A small marine Asiatic fish (Saurus ophidon) used in India as arelish; -- called also Bombay duck.
To cut deeper, as engraved lines on a plate of metal, when theengraving has not been deep enough, or the plate has become worn inprinting.
A reagent by the action of which the latent image upon aphotographic plate, after exposure in the camera, or otherwise, isdeveloped and visible.
The science of measuring the air, including the doctrine of itspressure, elasticity, rarefaction, and condensation; pneumatics.
To frame; to devise; to disguise or excuse; hence, to pretend;to declare falsely. [Obs.]
An Australian lorikeet (Ptilosclera versicolor) noted for thevariety of its colors; -- called also varied lorikeet.
The art or science of good eating; epicurism; the art of goodcheer.
A part which acts by falling, as a stamp in a fulling mill, orthe device in a spinning machine to arrest motion when a threadbreaks.
The process of mixing clay in potteries with a blunger.Tomlinson.
The act of carrying; conveyance; carriage. [Obs.] Bacon.
A wheedling to delude; words used in cajoling; flattery."Infamous cajoleries." Evelyn.
An American animal allied to the weasel. [Obs.] Goldsmith.
The progeny resulting from a cross between two breeds, as ofdomestic animals; anything of mixed breed. Drayton.
A disease of the eye, in which the iris adheres to the corneaor to the capsule of the crystalline lens.
One of the great divinities of the ancient Romans, identicalwith the Greek Hestia. She was a virgin, and the goddess of thehearth; hence, also, of the fire on it, and the family round it.
The country inhabited by the Mormons; the Mormon people.
Containing a third, or one part to three. Bp. Wilkins.
One who has the care of the spence, or buttery. [Obs.]Promptorium Parvulorum.
Having short, stiff hairs, often barbed at the point. Gray.
The exterior portion of the earth, formerly universallysupposed to inclose a molten interior.
Any pheasant of the genus Pucrasia. The birds of this genusinhabit India and China, and are distinguished by having a longcentral and two lateral crests on the head. Called also pucras.
Partiality; specifically (Theol.), the doctrine of thePartialists.
A pouring or streaming downwards; esp., a heavy or continuousshower.
A compound of a binary type containing two cyanogen groups orradicals; -- called also bicyanide.
That side of a vessel which is one of the right hand of aperson who stands on board facing the bow; -- opposed to Ant:larboard, or Ant: port.
One of a group of perching birds, having the middle toe more orless united to the outer and inner ones.
A body of followers; -- applied to the lawless or brigand bandsin Italy and Sicily.
Any workman engaged in work involved in putting the track inplace. [U. S. & Canada] -- Track"lay`ing, n.
A mode of catching birds at night, by holding a torch or otherlight, and beating the bush or perch where they roost. The birds,flying to the light, are caught with nets or otherwise.
Beneath the stars or heavens; terrestrial. Bp. Warburton.
Funnel-shaped; -- applied particularly to a hollow muscleattached to the ball of the eye in many reptiles and mammals.
A sudden springing or leaping out. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
To pamper excessively; to feed or dress too much. Dryton.
Pertaining to a rude kind of hieroglyphics, in which a thing isrepresented by its picture instead of by a symbol.
A boarding house or boarding school in France, Belgium,Switzerland, etc.

A composition (usually in symphonic form with three movements)in which one instrument (or two or three) stands out in bold reliefagainst the orchestra, or accompaniment, so as to display itsqualities or the performer's skill.
An upper loft; a garret; the highest room in a building.Dryden. Swift.
One who abstractedly wanders or gazes about, as if moonstruck.[R.] Dickens.
The gossamer-winged butterflies; a family of small butterflies,including the hairstreaks, violets, and theclas.
Bordered, as when one color is surrounded by an edging ofanother.
A zitherlike musical instrument, provided with dampers which,when depressed, deaden some strings, leaving free others that form achord.
The loss of a short unaccented vowel at the beginning of aword; -- the result of a phonetic process; as, squire for esquire.New Eng. Dict.
Pertaining to, or derived from, oxalic acid and aniline; --used to designate an acid obtained in white crystalline scales byheating these substances together.
The priestess who gave oracular answers at Delphi in Greece.
A hook with a pendant, to the end of which the fish-tackle ishooked. Dana.
(F., prop. good woman.) A female servant charged with the careof a young child.
The doctrine of those who maintain the existence of two gods orof two original principles (as in Manicheism), one good and one evil;dualism.
Of or pertaining to an hyperbaton; transposed; inverted.
One of the superior men, distinguished from a pawn.
A pimple; a small, usually conical, elevation of the cuticle,produced by congestion, accumulated secretion, or hypertrophy oftissue; a papule. Quain.
An attachment to a surveyor's compass for keeping tally inchaining.
Spirited; spiritedly; -- a direction to perform a passage in ananimated, lively manner.
Existing in the mind, but below the surface or threshold ofconsciousness; that is, existing as feeling rather than as clearideas.

The main constituent of the starch grain or granule, indistinction from the framework of cellulose. Unlike cellulose, it iscolored blue by iodine, and is converted into dextrin and sugar byboiling acids and amylolytic ferments.
An annular molding whose section is concave, like the edge of apulley; -- called also scotia.
The internal shell, or pen, of cephalopods like the squids.
Any toxic agent whose action is mainly directed to the greatnerve centers.
The ninth month of the French Republican calendar, which datedfrom September 22, 1792. It began May, 20, and ended June 18. SeeVendemiaire.
An invocation of, or address to, the Supreme Being.
The condition or quality of being idle (in the various sensesof that word); uselessness; fruitlessness; triviality; inactivity;laziness.

A chief bishop; a church dignitary of the first class (oftencalled a metropolitan or primate) who superintends the conduct of thesuffragan bishops in his province, and also exercises episcopalauthority in his own diocese.
A piece, as a ring or hook, attached to another piece by a pin,in such a manner as to permit rotation about the pin as an axis.
One to whom a grant is made, or a privilege secured, by patent.Bacon.
The quality of being putrid; putrefaction; rottenness.
According to desire; longingly; with wishes. [Obs. or Prov.Eng.] Chapman.
A positive or nonacid constituent of compound, eitherelementary, or, if compound, performing the functions of an element.
A thin membrane surrounding the embryos of mammals, birds, andreptiles.
The player stationed in the field bewtween the second and thirdbases.
A Greek version of the Old Testament; -- so called because itwas believed to be the work of seventy (or rather of seventy-two)translators.
A transparent, pale green variety of beryl, used as a gem. SeeBeryl.
The oxide of tungsten, a yellow mineral occurring in apulverulent form. It is often associated with wolfram.
Of, pertaining to, or discovered by, Filippo Pacini, an Italianphysician of the 19th century.
An East Indian barbet (Megalaima faber), inhabiting the Islandof Hainan. The name alludes to its note, which resembles the soundsmade by a smith.
A person who operates a typewriting machine; a typewriter.
To remove the paint from; to efface, as a painting. Parnell.
An inclosure or yard for grapevines; a plantation of vinesproducing grapes.
An allowance made to a wife out of her husband's estate orincome for her support, upon her divorce or legal separation fromhim, or during a suit for the same. Wharton. Burrill.
The great titmouse; -- so called from its harsh call notes.[Prov. Eng.]
A frame mounted on the running gear of a wagon, and used inhauling hay, straw, sheaves, etc.; -- called also hay rigging.
The operation of finding, by means of a mine dial, the placewhere to sink an air shaft, or to bring an adit to the work, or tofind which way the lode inclines.
The power or right of taking a thing before it is offered.Burrill.
A thin board; a billet of wood; a splinter. [Prov. Eng.]
An apparatus for the determination of colors by comparison witharbitrary standards; a colorimeter.
the practice of doing things with undiscriminating, mechanicalregularity.
Offal, as the bowels of an animal or fish; refuse animal orvegetable matter from a kitchen; hence, anything worthless,disgusting, or loathsome. Grainger.
To find fault; to be peevish. [Prov. Eng. or Scot.]
The state of an albino, or of a white child of black parents.
Represented with wings expanded; -- applied to doves and otherbirds not of prey. Cussans.
Any of the live stock found in a region, as distinguished fromsuch as belong to pure and distinct imported breeds. [U.S.]
A form of government in which the supreme power is placed inthe hands of a few persons; also, those who form the ruling few.All oligarchies, wherein a few men domineer, do what they list.Burton.

Any device for producing electric oscillations; esp., anapparatus for generating electric waves in a system of wirelesstelegraphy.(b) (Mech.) An instrument for measuring rigidity by the torsionaloscillations of a weighted wire.
A peculiar insectivore (Ptilocercus Lowii) of Borneo; -- socalled from its very long, quill-shaped tail, which is scaly at thebase and plumose at the tip.
A genus of bivalve shells, allied to the oyster, so called fromtheir unequal valves, of which the lower is perforated forattachment.
In a medical manner; with reference to healing, or to theprinciples of the healing art.
A decision or rule of a judge or a court, especially an oraldecision, as in excluding evidence.
The response which one side of the choir makes to the other ina chant; alternate chanting or signing.
Conveyance by means of a wagon or wagons. [Obs.] Milton.
The board which receives the ends of the steps in a staircase.
That part of blastoderm where the hypoblast appears like asmall disk on the inner face of the epibladst.
To arm or prepare for attack or resistance before the time ofneed. South.
An anomalous state of refraction caused by the absence of thecrystalline lens, as after operations for cataract. The remedy is theuse of powerful convex lenses. Dunglison.
A building behind the main building. Specifically: A privy; anecessary.
Capable of being impeded or hindered. [R.] Jer. Taylor.
To convert into English; to anglicize. Franklin. Darwin.
The larva of any geometrid moth, which drops from trees bymeans of a thread of silk, as the cankerworm.
A charter or warrant; also, a deed of gift. [India]
Of or pertaining to truisms; consisting of truisms. [R.]
Serving or tending to form an eschar;; producing a scar;caustic.
A thin layer or fold of tissue, usually supported by a fibrousnetwork, serving to cover or line some part or organ, and oftensecreting or absorbing certain fluids.
To smooth over; to palliate.By glozing the evil that is in the world. I. Taylor.
One who as has charge of the work of a companionship.
A small party of men assembled for drill, inspection, or otherpurposes.
The worship of saints or sacred things. [R.] Coleridge.
To call forth or increase the vital activity of an organism, orany of its parts.
As much as a trowel will hold; enough to fill a trowel.
The state or quality of being laic; the state or condition of alayman.
The delicate connective tissue framework which supports thenervous matter and blood vessels of the brain and spinal cord.
Resembling a bladder; swollen like a bladder; inflated;utricular. Dana.
The style or pin, which by its shadow, shows the hour of theday. It is usually set parallel to the earth's axis.
A Jewish festival, called also the Feast of Lots, instituted tocommemorate the deliverance of the Jews from the machinations ofHaman. Esther ix. 26.
Pain in the muscles; muscular rheumatism or neuralgia.
Springing up or emerging; -- said of a plant or animal.
A stroller; a loiterer; esp., an idle, untidy woman; aslattern; a slut; a whore.
One of the tiles or squares of a tessellated pavement; anabaculus.
A box with holes in its lid; -- used for sprinkling flour, ason meat or a breadboard; -- called also dredging box, drudger, anddrudging box.
To crush; to quash; to squash. [Colloq. or Slang, Scot.] Sir W.Scott.
A spear with barbed prongs used for harpooning fish. Knight.
A fibrous and muscular band lying within the longitudinal axisof the tongue in many mammals, as the dog.
The bolt of the cap-square over the trunnion of a cannon.Knight.
A standing without moving forward or backward; a stop; a stateor rest.
To prize beyong value, or in excess; to exceed in value. [Obs.]Shak.
Rough dressing by knocking off knobs or projections; knobbing.
With wings expanded; -- said of a bird of pray, esp. an eagle.
A quartet; -- applied chiefly to instrumental compositions.
A small bird, the blackcap titmouse (Parus atricapillus), ofNorth America; -- named from its note.
The name of a hypothetical element predicted and afterwardsdiscovered and named germanium; -- so called because it was a missinganalogue of the silicon group. See Germanium, and cf. Ekkabor.
The class of Vertebrata that includes the fishes. The principaldivisions are Elasmobranchii, Ganoidei, and Teleostei.
The bone, or principal bone, of the lower jaw; the inferiormaxilla; -- also applied to either the upper or the lower jaw in thebeak of birds.
Admitting of repudiation; fit or proper to be put away.
Cheerful or mirthful, as after good eating or drinking; also,wanton. [Scot. & Prov. Eng.]
Pertaining to, derived from, designating, certain amidocompounds obtained by reducing certain nitro derivatives of diphenyl.

To pay out; to expend; -- usually from a public fund ortreasury.The duty of collecting and disbursing his revenues. Macaulay.Disbursing officer, an officer in any department of the publicservice who is charged with the duty of paying out public money.

A peculiar bitter orange-brown substance, with strong,penetrating odor, found in two sacs between the anus and externalgenitals of the beaver; castor; -- used in medicine as anantispasmodic, and by perfumers.
A residence at a particular place accompanied with an intentionto remain there for an unlimited time; a residence accepted as afinal abode. Wharton.
, a. Having the head covered with a wig; wearing a wig.
Time during which one is awake. [R.] Mrs. Browning.
A wolf (Canis pallipes), found in India, allied to the jackal.
To spurt or shoot in a scattering manner. [Obs.] Drayton.
A broad stripe of purple on the fore part of the tunic, worn bysenators in ancient Rome as an emblem of office.
Constituting, or containing, the essence of a thing;quidditative.
An instrument for testing the density of gases, consisting of athin glass globe, which is weighed in the gas or gases, and then inan atmosphere of known density.
A group of Turbellaria in which there is no anal aperture.
The upper petal of a papilionaceous flower; the standard.
Having no limits; unbounded; boundless. Davies (Wit's Pilgr.).
One belonging to the second of the four classes in an Americancollege, or one next above a freshman. [Formerly written alsosophimore.]
The dominion of an ethnarch; principality and rule. Wright.
A canvas screen, formerly sometimes extended along the side ofa vessel in a naval engagement, to conceal from the enemy theoperations on board.
The treatment of deformities in the human body by mechanicalappliances.
The quality or state of being viscid; also, that which isviscid; glutinous concretion; stickiness.
Of or pertaining to prose; prosaic. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
A turbulent surface of water, caused by strong currents settingover submerged ridges; also, a dangerous submerged ridge or shoal.
Having no mirth; not festive or merry; dull; cheerless; gloomy;forlorn. [R.]
One who, or that which, folds; esp., a flat, knifelikeinstrument used for folding paper.
One who studies, or professes the knowledge of, the decretals.
To go beyond, or be superior to, on the flank; to pass aroundor turn the flank or flanks of.
Comrade; boon companion; good fellow; -- a term of familiaraddress and fellowship among sailors. Dickens.
To convert again into the forest, as a region of country.
Presented, instituted, and inducted into a rectory, and in fullpossession.-- n.
The suborder of elasmobranch fishes which comprises the sharks.
Formed into a legion or legions; legionary. Shelley.
An acrid plant of the genus Polygonum (P. Hydropiper), whichproduces smarting if applied where the skin is tender.
Not appalled; not frightened; dauntless; undaunted. Milton.
One who overweens. [R.]The conceits of warmed or overweening brain. Locke.
Disposed to embrace; fond of caressing. [R.] Thackeray.
A square or oblong opening in a deck or floor, affordingpassage from one deck or story to another; the entrance to a cellar.
A bar attached to the tiller, for convenience in steering.
A series of six notes, with a semitone between the third andfourth, the other intervals being whole tones.
One of the jointed antenniform appendage of the posteriorsomites of cartain insects. Packard.
An instrument for ligating, or for placing and fastening aligature.
In the form of a cross; across; transversely. Longfellow.
An international, interdenominational organization of Bibleclasses of young women.
The act or method of ascertaining the strength of vinegar, orthe proportion of acetic acid contained in it. Ure.
A tailor; -- so called in contempt. [Old slang] L'Estrange.
The quality or state of being public, or open to the knowledgeof a community; notoriety; publicness.

A small herbivorous mammal of the genus Hyrax. The speciesfound in Palestine and Syria is Hyrax Syriacus; that of NorthernAfrica is H. Brucei; -- called also ashkoko, dassy, and rock rabbit.See Cony, and Hyrax.
One who writers marginal notes; one who illustrates the text ofa book by notes in the margin. Sir T. Browne.
A gibbon (Hylobates syndactylus), native of Sumatra. It has thesecond and third toes partially united by a web.
, and Gray.] (Bot.) A genus of twining plants with showymonopetalous flowers, including the morning-glory, the sweet potato,and the cypress vine.
A one-seeded, one-called, indehiscent fruit; an achene with thecalyx tube adherent.

One of the notes, bills, or bonds, issued as currency by therevolutionary government of France (1790-1796), and based on thesecurity of the lands of the church and of nobles which had beenappropriated by the state.
A measure of capacity, containing four quarts; -- used, for themost part, in liquid measure, but sometimes in dry measure.
The sudden drop or depression of the strata of rocks on oneside of a fault. See Throw, n.
To demise back; to convey or transfer back, as an estate.
A large genus of plants belonging to the Sedge family, andincluding the species called galingale, several bulrushes, and theEgyptian papyrus.
A genus of shrubs having opposite, petiolate leaves and cymoseflowers, several species of which are cultivated as ornamental, asthe laurestine and the guelder-rose.
Having two principal ribs running longitudinally, as a leaf.
A strap for tightening a saddle girth. [Western U. S. & Sp.Amer.]
Arranged in little roselike clusters; -- said of leaves andbracts.
To judge beforehand, or before hearing the facts and proof; toprejudge.
A bench on which work is performed, as in a carpenter's shop.
A young buck in the third year. See the Note under Buck. Shak.
The conduct of a truant; neglect of employment; idleness;truancy. Ascham.
A council; a convention; a tribunal; an assembly; esp., thegrand council of state in Spain.
Born in a low condition or rank; -- opposed to highborn.
A message sent by telegraph; a telegraphic dispatch.
A fibrous material obtained by deviling rags or the remnants ofwoolen goods.
To turn inside out, or with the leg part back over the foot, asa stocking in pulling off or for putting on. [Scot.]
Any picture printed in two shades of the same color, asduotypes and duographs are usually printed.

The principles of a political party in England (1838-48), whichcontended for universal suffrage, the vote by ballot, annualparliaments, equal electoral districts, and other radical reforms, asset forth in a document called the People's Charter.
To involve in a quarrel or dispute; to embroil. [R.] Bp.Sanderson.
The price or fare to be paid for passage at a ferry.
Articles made of iron, as household utensils, tools, and thelike.
A vulgar person; one who has vulgar ideas. Used alsoadjectively.
One who receipts; specifically (Law), one who receipts forproperty which has been taken by the sheriff.
Pertaining to Sigault, a French physician. See Symphyseotomy.
One of the great military roads constructed by the Romans inEngland and other parts of Europe; -- so called from the fosse orditch on each side for keeping it dry.
The first public examinations for degrees at the University ofOxford; -- usually contracted to mods.
A crystal of one species inclosing one of another species. SeeEndomorph.
A mineral of a blackish green color, commonly massive or innodules. It is a hydrous phosphate of iron.
Of or pertaining to the protasis of an ancient play;introductory.
The quality or condition of being sharp; keenness; acuteness.
A charcoal hearth or furnace for the conversion of cast ironinto wrought iron, or into iron suitable for puddling.
Relating to trypsin or to its action; produced by trypsin; as,trypsin digestion.
Having a tendency to purify or to sweeten by removing orcorrecting acidity and acrimony.
A customhouse officer who goes on board of a merchant ship tosecure payment of the duties; a tidewaiter.
The act of drawing the warp threads through the heddle-eyes ofa weaver's harness; the harness itself. Knight.
A preparation from acorns used by the Arabs as a substitute forchocolate, and also as a beverage for invalids.
An American wild cat (Felis tigrina), ranging from Mexico toBrazil. It is spotted with black. Called also long-tailed cat.
One of certain corrupt persons in the early church at Ephesus,who are censured in rev. ii. 6, 15.
The eye of a bean or other seed; the mark or scar at the pointof attachment of an ovule or seed to its base or support; -- calledalso hile.
A form of capsule for inclosing a dose of medicine that isoffensive, caustic, or the like.
The act or process of testing, esp. of analyzing or examiningmetals and ores, to determine the proportion of pure metal.
The peptone formed by pancreatic digestion; -- so calledbecause it is formed through the agency of the ferment trypsin.
A government by many persons, of whatever order or class.Cudworth.
Consisting chiefly of aloes; of the nature of aloes.
A plantation of pine trees; esp., a collection of living pinetrees made for ornamental or scientific purposes.
That part of a bird, or the feathers, surrounding the cloacalopening; the under tail coverts.
Lime in the lump after it is burned; quicklime. [Eng.]
A large boom or spar, which projects over the stem of a ship orother vessel, to carry sail forward.
A kind of muslin of a texture between nainsook and mull.

One who, or that which, scorifies; specifically, a small flatbowl-shaped cup used in the first heating in assaying, to remove theearth and gangue, and to concentrate the gold and silver in a leadbutton.
A species of agate, sprinkled with spots of red jasper.
A genus of fresh-water Pulmonifera, having reversed spiralshells. See Pond snail, under Pond.
Without regular form; shapeless; ugly; deformed. Cotton.
The line bisecting the angle between the optic axes of abiaxial crystal.
A coarse linen cloth made in the north of England and inScotland, now nearly replaced by calico. Shak.
Any one of the spaces in the Milky Way which are very black,owing to the nearly complete absence of stars; esp., the large spacenear the Southern Cross sometimes called the Black Magellanic Cloud.
The bones of the cranium; more especially, the bones of thedomelike upper portion.
A hydrocarbon, C14H12, produced artificially in large, finecrystals; -- called also diphenyl ethylene, toluylene, etc.
To vibrate as a balance does before resting in equilibrium;hence, to be poised.Their parts all liberate on too nice a beam. Clifton.
A rare fluophosphate of glucina, in small white crystals.
An instrument of punishment or torture resembling the knout,used in Russia.
The act of loricating; the protecting substance put on; acovering of scales or plates.
Full of rushes: resembling rushes; juncaceous. [R.] Johnson.
Having protuberances resembling the teat of an animal.
One who wrestles; one who is skillful in wrestling.
A curve of the third order, consisting of two infinitebranches, which have a common asymptote. The curve has a doublepoint, and a leaf-shaped loop; whence the name. Its equation is x3 +y3 = axy.
Either one of two asclepiadaceous shrubs (Calotropis gigantea,and C. procera), which furnish a strong and valuable fiber. The acridmilky juice is used medicinally.
Nice or keen appreciation or enjoyment; relish; taste; fancy.Dryden.
The more liquid or volatile portion of certain oily substance,as distinguished from stearoptene, the more solid parts. [Writtenalso elaoptene.]
A wise man; a physician, esp. a Mohammedan. [India]
An officer in attendance upon a hospital, but not residing init; esp., one who cares for the out-patients.
An instrument designed to show the condition of the superficialportions of the eye.
The continuation of a trope in one word through a succession ofsignifications, or the union of two or more tropes of a differentkind in one word.
In a dirty manner; foully; nastily; filthily; meanly; sordidly.
A sensation originated by some external object, but so modifiedas in any way to lead to an erroneous perception; as when the rollingof a wagon is mistaken for thunder.
A grotesque mask, representing a person chewing or grimacing,worn in processions and by comic actors on the stage.
A portable bag for travelers; -- so called because originallymade of carpet.
The act of soaking, or the state of being soaked; also, thequantity that enters or issues by soaking.
A group of birds including the woodpeckers, toucans, barbets,colies, kingfishes, hornbills, and some other related groups.
A sugarlike body obtained by the decomposition of thenitrogenous non-phosphorized principles of the brain.
A fossil resin, so called from its strong, peculiar, pleasantodor.
The division of birds which includes the gulls and terns.
The act or method of grouping the notes so as to form distinctmusical phrases.
A cloth for covering a table, especially one with which a tableis covered before the dishes, etc., are set on for meals.
A flat muscle on either side of the tongue, connecting it withthe hyoid bone.
That which jets out or projects from anything. [R.] H. Miller.
Faultless; blameless; innocent. South.An innocent and incupable piece of ignorance. Killingbeck.
The part of a church, theater, or other public building,assigned to the audience.
A stick, cane, or cudgel, made of the wood of the carb tree.
A flake; also, a lock, as of wool. [Obs.] J. Martin.
A little, perennial, white, woolly plant (Leontopodiumalpinum), growing at high elevations in the Alps.
The male of the European black grouse (Tetrao tetrix, Linn.); -- so called by sportsmen. The female is called gray hen. See Heathgrouse.
One of a religious order founded by Ignatius Loyola, andapproved in 1540, under the title of The Society of Jesus.
One of the small chips or slices into which beets are cut insugar making.
The son of Saturn and Ops, the god of the waters, especially ofthe sea. He is represented as bearing a trident for a scepter.

A rare metallic element. It occurs quite widely, but in smallquantities, and always combined. It is isolated as a soft yellowishwhite metal, analogous to potassium in most of its properties. SymbolRb. Atomic weight, 85.2.
The author of a dramatic composition; a writer of plays.
The quality or state of being sanable; sanableness;curableness.
Consisting of a spondee, a choriamb, and a pyrrhic; -- appliedto a kind of verse in Greek and Latin poetry.-- n. (Pros.)
Fidelity to nature or to real life; representation withoutidealization, and making no appeal to the imagination; adherence tothe actual fact.
The act of keeping holiday; cessation from work. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
To beat or flog soundly. [Prov. Eng. & Colloq. U.S.] Forby.
A preparation from the seeds of Paullinia sorbilis, a woodyclimber of Brazil, used in making an astringent drink, and also inthe cure of headache.

An African freshwater fish (Protopterus annectens), belongingto the Dipnoi. It can breathe air by means of its lungs, and whenwaters dry up, it encases itself in a nest of hard mud, where itremains till the rainy season. It is used as food.
That which cleanses or purifies; esp., an apparatus forremoving the feculencies of juices and sirups. Knight.
A double spondee; a foot consisting of four long syllables.
A rare skin disease consisting in the development of smooth,milk-white spots upon various parts of the body.
Round, water-worn, and loose gravel and pebbles, or acollection of roundish stones, such as are common on the seashore andelsewhere.
A cunette. 3. (Spectrometry) (Analytical chemistry)
A seed vessel resembling a silique, but about as broad as it islong. See Silique.
A plant (Sarracenia flava) with long, hollow leaves.
One of the symmetrical halves of any one of the radii, orspheromeres, of a radiate animal, as a starfish.
One of the adherents of Charles Stewart Parnell (1846-91) inhis advocacy of home rule for Ireland.
A short mortar used formerly for throwing stone shot. Hakluyt.
One versed in tactics; hence, a skillful maneuverer; an adroitmanager.
The offspring of a quadroon and a white person; a mestee.
Of or pertaining to Portugal; Portuguese. [Obs.] -- n.
One of numerous species of Heliconius, a genus of tropicalAmerican butterflies. The wings are usually black, marked with green,crimson, and white.
Any substance (but especially sodium hyposulphite) used inremoving the excess of chlorine left in paper pulp or stuffs afterbleaching.
Of or pertaining to St. Bernard of Clairvaux, or to theCistercian monks.-- n.
The belief or doctrine that attributes everything to nature asa sanative agent.
A condition of endemic or inherited idiocy, accompanied byphysical degeneracy and deformity (usually with goiter), frequent incertain mountain valleys, esp. of the Alps.
A gold coin of Portugal, valued at about 27s. sterling.
A kind of griddlecake of unleavened bread, used among thenatives of India. [Anglo-Indian]
A small European rodent (Eliomys nitela), allied to thedormouse.
Noting two small bones, forming the body of the inverted hyoidarch.

A nitrogenous base, C5H11NO2, produced artificially, and alsooccurring naturally in beetroot molasses and its residues, from whichit is extracted as a white crystalline substance; -- called alsolycine and oxyneurine. It has a sweetish taste.
Of a red color with a slight mixture of gray. Dana.
One who brings meat to the table; hence, in some countries, theofficial title of the grand master or steward of the king's or anobleman's household.
To unite again; to join after separation or variance. Shak.
In an answerable manner; in due proportion or correspondence;suitably.
The title of the ruling Prince of Baroda, in Gujarat, inBombay, India.
Of or pertaining to the real or to the mystical Babylon, or tothe ancient kingdom of Babylonia; Chaldean.
Of or pertaining to a penumbra; resembling a penumbra;partially illuminated.
A concealed hiding place; a burrow; a lair; a hole.
The act or habit of talking idly or rapidly, or of makinginarticulate sounds; the sounds so made; noise made by the collisionof the teeth; chatter.
A genus of rapacious birds; one of the Accipitres or Raptores.
Pertaining to, or derived from, ytterbium; containingytterbium.
Want or absence of divine power or of divinity. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
A chapel; hence, the choir or orchestra of a prince's chapel;now, a musical establishment, usually orchestral. Grove.
The margin of the head, behind the bill of birds, often bearingrigid bristles.
Dewrotting; the process of decomposing the gummy matter of flaxand hemp and setting the fibrous part, by exposure on a sward to dew,rain, and sunshine.
To unite, embrace, communicate with, or flow into, one another;to be connected in one system; to lock into one another; to interlacefirmly.

The opinions of Origen of Alexandria, who lived in the 3dcentury, one of the most learned of the Greek Fathers. Prominent inhis teaching was the doctrine that all created beings, includingSatan, will ultimately be saved.
To cover with a screen, or as with a screen; to shelter; toconceal. Shak.
An instrument formerly used in extracting foreign or offensivematter from a wound.
A small round dish with a handle, usually of porcelain.
A rope or chain fitted around the masthead to hold hangingblocks for jibs and stays.
A list of drams, operas, pieces, parts, etc., which a companyor a person has rehearsed and is prepared to perform.
The quality or state of being thin (in any of the senses of theword).
One who will never cease to be; one exempt from death, decay,or annihilation. Bunyan.
Not plumed; without plumes or feathers; featherless. [R.]Drayton.
Made convex; protuberant in a spherical form. Sir T. Browne.
An instrument for determining the specific gravities ofliquids, and thence the strength spirituous liquors, salinesolutions, etc.
A local name for the partridge berry; also, for the deerberry.[U. S.]
A thousand millions; -- called also billion. See Billion.
The state of being a pagan; paganism. [R.] Cudworth.
The constitution, or fundamental law, of the French monarchy,as established on the restoration of Louis XVIII., in 1814.
By stealing, or as by stealing, furtively, or by an invisiblemotion. Sir P. Sidney.
A translucent variety of serpentine, of a honey yellow orgreenish yellow color, having a waxy resinlike luster.
One whose occupation is to make or repair small firearms; anarmorer.
Pestering; vexatious; troublesome. Used also as an intensive.[Colloq. & Low, U.S.] Judd.
A dog kept to watch and guard premises or property, and to givenotice of the approach of intruders.
A genus of vascular, cryptogamic, herbaceous plants; -- alsocalled horsetails.
A low, oven-shaped mound, common in volcanic regions, andemitting smoke and vapors from its sides and summit. Humboldt.

An instrument for transmission of auditory vibrations throughthe bones of the head, so as to be appreciated as sounds by personsdeaf from causes other than those affecting the nervous apparatus ofhearing.
A maker of catalogues; esp. one skilled in the making ofcatalogues.
A rocket that ascends high and burns as it flies; a species offireworks.
To stop or close, as an opening; specif., (Ordnance),
Having the form of, or resembling, sawdust or raspings.
To shorten by omitting a letter or letters or by reducing twoor more vowels or syllables to one.
The tendency of an organism to respond, during its growth, tothe force of gravitation.
A variety of onyx consisting of sard and white chalcedony inalternate layers.
A small, shrill flute, the pitch of which is an octave higherthan the ordinary flute; an octave flute.
A colorless or white crystalline compound, (CH2)6N4C2H5Br, usedas a sedative in epilepsy.
To call by the wrong name; to give a wrong or inappropriatename to.
A division of boring Hymenoptera, including Tremex and alliedgenera. See Illust. of Horntail.
One who conforms; one who complies with established forms ordoctrines.
The sanderling; -- so called from its cry. [Prov. Eng.]
The pivoted or swinging bar to which the traces of a harnessedhorse are fixed; a whiffletree.
To become corporeal; to assume the qualities of a materialbody. See Embody.The soul grows clotted by contagion, Imbodies, and imbrutes. Milton.
To take long, loose stitches over (the raw edges of a seam) toprevent raveling.
A place where animals are slaughtered for their hides andtallow. [Western U. S.]
A small instrument with four strings, played with a bow; afiddle.
Any one of several umbelliferous plants, of the genera Myrrhis,Osmorrhiza, etc.
The child of a mulatto and a negro; also, the child of anIndian and a negro; colloquially or humorously, a negro; a sambo.
A gephyrean worm of the genus Thalassema, having a spoonlikeprobiscis.
Constipation; also, constriction of the vessels or ducts.
The grasscloth plant (Boehmeria nivea); also, its fiber, whichis very fine and exceedingly strong; -- called also China grass, andrhea. See Grass-cloth plant, under Grass.
Within the range of hpe; proper to be hoped for. [Obs.] Bacon.
The quality or characteristics of a gem or jewel. [Obs.]Bailey.
One who scrutinizes; a close examiner or inquirer. Ayliffe.
The symmetry of a metameric structure; serial symmetry; thestate of being made up of metameres.
To send on from an intermediate station by means of a repeater.
The ventral and anterior of the three principal bones composingeither half of the pelvis; sharebone; pubic bone.
To roll or wallow; to welter. [Obs. or Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
Any slender, marine fish of the genus Hemirhamphus, having theupper jaw much shorter than the lower; -- called also balahoo.
In Spanish countries, a court or trial held, sometimes as longas six months, by a newly elected official, as the governor of aprovince, to examine into the conduct of a predecessor.
One who ordains or establishes; a director. [R.] T. Adams.
A doctor of the Sorbonne, or theological college, in theUniversity of Paris, founded by Robert de Sorbon, a. d. 1252. It wassuppressed in the Revolution of 1789.
The third division of the stomach of ruminants. See Manyplies,and Illust. under Ruminant.
A Celtic divinity, regarded as the evil principle, butconfounded by the Romans with Jupiter.
A basic substance, C7H17NO2, formed from the growth of thetyphoid bacillus on meat pulp. It induces in small animals lethargicconditions with liquid dejecta.
One who explains; an expounder or expositor; a commentator; aninterpreter.
Of or pertaining to the Crustacea; crustaceous.-- n.
Divided into an even number of bends; -- said of a shield orits charge. Cussans.
A parent stock or race of people, not yet divided into separatebranches or tribes.
A salt derived from a sesquioxide base, or made up on theproportions of a sesqui compound.
To refuse to worship; to treat as unworthy. [Obs.] Sir T. More.
A member of the lowest class in the military academy at WestPoint. [Cant, U.S.]
An inhabitant or native of the south, esp. of the SouthernStates of North America; opposed to Northerner.
The practice of meanly fawning on another; base sycophancy;servile adulation.
A large, handsome squirrel (Sciurus Javensis), native of Javaand Southern Asia; -- called also Java squirrel.
An inflammable, volatile, oily, liquid hydrocarbon, obtained bythe destructive distillation of caoutchouc.
A study; an exercise; a piece for practice of some specialpoint of technical execution.
Tending to prevent the formation of urinary calculi, or todestroy them when formed.-- n.
A piece of wood, shell, stone, or other substance, worn in aperforation of the lip or cheek by many savages.
A regulus consisting essentially of nickel, obtained as aresidue in fusing cobalt and nickel ores with silica and sodiumcarbonate to make smalt.
A genus of evergreen tropical shrubs; -- so called from theblack berries of some species, which stain the mouth.
One who, or that which, erases; esp., a sharp instrument or apiece of rubber used to erase writings, drawings, etc.
The state of being negligent; negligence. [Obs.] Shak.
To lash with stripes; to wale; to thrash; to drub. [Prov. Eng.& Colloq. U. S.] Halliwell. Bartlett.
A hornlike tuft of feathers on the head of some birds.
The science which treats of poisons, their effects, antidotes,and recignition; also, a discourse or treatise on the science.
A very vascular superficial opacity of the cornea, usuallycaused by granulation of the eyelids. Foster.
To go or come after; -- used in the various senses of thetransitive verb: To pursue; to attend; to accompany; to be a result;to imitate.
A mode of facing sea walls and embankments with planks drivenas piles and secured by ties. Knight.
One who adopts the geological theory of igneous fusion; aPlutonian. See Plutonism.
A pustular eruption upon the scalp, or the beared part of theface, whether due to ringworm, acne, or impetigo.
A verbal imitation of a musical sound, as of the note of a larkor a horn.The lark, that tirra lyra chants. Shak."Tirralira, " by the river, Sang Sir Lancelot. Tennyson.
The daughter of Saturn and Ops or Rhea, the goddess of corn andtillage.
Near or beside the ethmoid bone or cartilage; -- appliedespecially to a pair of bones in the nasal region of some fishes, andto the ethmoturbinals in some higher animals.-- n.
A compound radical, NH4, having the chemical relations of astrongly basic element like the alkali metals.
The replacement of an edge by two similar planes, equallyinclined to the including faces or adjacent planes.
Any coral of the genus Madrepora; formerly, often applied toany stony coral.
Making a promise; implying a promise; promising. [R.]
The lowest of the grand divisions of the animal kingdom.

The cohesion of the particles on the surface of a body,determined by its capacity to scratch another, or be itselfscratched;-measured among minerals on a scale of which diamond andtalc form the extremes.
A boat or raft used in the East Indies in the landing ofpassengers and goods.

The cutting off or suppression of a vowel or syllable, for thesake of meter or euphony; esp., in poetry, the dropping of a finalvowel standing before an initial vowel in the following word, whenthe two words are drawn together.
A special oblong or pyriform cell, with slender branches, whichbears the spores in that division of fungi called Basidiomycetes, ofwhich the common mushroom is an example.
Pertaining to, or furnishing, a diagnosis; indicating thenature of a disease.
A place where eggs are deposited (as by sea birds) or kept; anest of eggs. [R.]
A water clock; a contrivance for measuring time by thegraduated flow of a liquid, as of water, through a small aperture.See Illust. in Appendix.
The art or science of sounding, or measuring depths in the sea.
Of or pertaining to the diameter of the cranium, from oneparietal fossa to the other.

One of a class of religious reformers in Germany in the 17thcentury who sought to revive declining piety in the Protestantchurches; -- often applied as a term of reproach to those who make adisplay of religious feeling. Also used adjectively.
A young male of the ox kind; especially, a common ox; acastrated taurine male from two to four years old. See the Note underOx.
The Baltimore oriole (Icterus galbula); -- so called becauseits nest is suspended from the limb of a tree. See Baltimore oriole.
A small warbler (Pratincola rubetra) common in Europe; --called also whinchacker, whincheck, whin-clocharet.
An order of fresh-water rhizopods having a more or lessglobular form, with slender radiating pseudopodia; the sunanimalcule.
To behave or move in a lively or restless manner, as animpatient horse; to caper; to prance; to frisk.  Kipling.
A common name of the yellowish green mineral chrysolite, esp.the variety found in eruptive rocks.
To divest of scales; to remove scales from.[An eagle] purging and unscaling her long-abused sight at thefountain itself of heavenly radiance. Milton.
A white, crystalline hydrocarbon, regarded as a polymericvariety of ethylene, obtained in heavy oil of wine, the residue leftafter making ether; -- formerly called also concrete oil of wine.
A composition sung to the sound of seven chords or tones. Moore(Encyc. of Music).
Making inquiry; inquiring; questioning. [Obs.] Shenstone.
A genus of land snails having an elongated spiral shell, oftenof large size. The species are numerous ingabundant in tropicalAmerica.
A point where one branch of a curve crosses another branch. SeeDouble point, under Double, a.
To practice psalmody. " The psalmodizing art." J. G. Cooper.
One of the specialized or tactile hairs which grow about thenostrils, or on other parts of the face, in many animals, as the so-called whiskers of the cat, and the hairs of the nostrils of man.
One who wavers; one who is unsettled in doctrine, faith,opinion, or the like. Shak.
A magazine or other publication which appears at stated orregular intervals.
A word used to define or limit the extent of the significationof a common noun, such as the definite article, and some pronouns.

Any small marine gastropod shell of the genus Littorina. Thecommon European species (Littorina littorea), in Europe extensivelyused as food, has recently become naturalized abundantly on theAmerican coast. See Littorina.
A figure of speech by which a word is used in a literal andmetaphorical sense at the same time.
A verse containing eight feet; as, --Deep'' in|to'' the | dark''ness | peer''ing, | long'' I | stood''there | wond'''ring, | fear''ing. Poe.

A substance obtained from the residues of the distillation ofpetroleum, essentially the same as vaseline, but of somewhat stifferconsistency, and consisting of a mixture of the higher paraffines; akind of petroleum jelly.
A rope used for tying or hobbling the legs of a horse or cow.[Prov. Eng. & Local, U.S.] Grose.
Paving or flooring made of small squares or lozenges setdiagonally. [Formerly written pointal.]

A beautiful Australian parrakeet (Platycercus eximius) oftenkept as a cage bird. The head and back of the neck are scarlet, thethroat is white, the back dark green varied with lighter green, andthe breast yellow.
One who prepares homilies; one who preaches to a congregation.
A Portuguese money of account rated in the treasury departmentof the United States at one dollar and eight cents; also, a Brazilianmoney of account rated at fifty-four cents and six mills.
