An umbelliferous plant (Pimpinella anisum) growing naturally inEgypt, and cultivated in Spain, Malta, etc., for its carminative andaromatic seeds.
More recent than the Paleozoic, -- that is, including theMesozoic and Cenozoic.
To derive or deduce; also, to transmit; to transfer. [Obs.]Fotherby.
A shell or tube formed by an annelid, as a serpula.
The quality or state of being supple; flexibility; pliableness;pliancy.
In the West Indies and Guiana, a fugitive slave, or a freenegro, living in the mountains.
A hypothetical radical of glycerin. [Obs.] Berzelius.
Inclined to swag; sinking, hanging, or leaning by its weight.Sir T. Browne.
The act or process of litigating; a suit at law; a judicialcontest.
To retract or falsify a previous prediction. Milton.
A violent and cold northwest wind experienced in theMediterranean provinces of France, etc.
To yield seed; to emit seed, or sperm. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A centaur; a fabulous being, half man, half horse, armed with abow and quiver. Shak.
A measure of length; the distance from the elbow to the end ofthe middle finger; a cubit.
The addition of a letter or syllable to the end of a word, aswithouten for without.
The part of a chimney between the gathering, or portion of thefunnel which contracts in ascending, and the flue. Gwilt.
A principal enemy. Specifically, Satan, the grand adversary ofmankind. Milton.
A genus of trees or shrubs, one species of which (F. Carica)produces the figs of commerce; the fig tree.
The condition or quality of being sane; soundness of health ofbody or mind, especially of the mind; saneness.
Act of benumbing, or state of being benumbed; torpor. Kirby.
A species of sunfish (Lepomis pallidus), common in the UnitedStates; -- called also blue sunfish, and copper-nosed bream.

A genus of leguminous trees of tropical America, the differentspecies of which yield balsamic products, among which are balsam ofPeru, and balsam of Tolu. The species were formerly referred toMyrospermum.
A kind of gimlet for making vents in casks; -- called alsopiercer.
Small articles of virtu, as jewelry, trinkets, etc.
Bearing ships; capable of floating vessels. [R.] Blount.
Having or containing bulbs, or a bulb; growing from bulbs;bulblike in shape or structure.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, the mulberry; moric.
An ancient Roman liquid and dry measure, about equal to anEnglish pint.
Uniting and blending together different systems, as ofphilosophy, morals, or religion. Smart.
The external angle of knee timber, the inside of which iscalled the throat.

It seems; -- chiefly used impersonally in reports and judgmentsto express an opinion in reference to the law on some point notnecessary to be decided, and not intended to be definitely settled inthe cause.
A large South American monkey (Lagothrix Humboldtii), withprehensile tail.
A hypothetical radical, C5H4N, regarded as the essentialresidue of pyridine, and analogous to phenyl.
The song of the Virgin Mary, Luke i. 46; -- so called becauseit commences with this word in the Vulgate.
The discussion or description of portraiture or ofrepresentative images. Cf. Iconography.
A yellowish white, translucent mineral, consisting of thecarbonates of lime and soda, with water.
The highest kind of worship, or that paid to God; --distinguished by the Roman Catholics from dulia, or the inferiorworship paid to saints.
A steel-gray metallic mineral, a sulphide of antimony and lead.
To scrape (the club) on the ground, in a stroke, before hittingthe ball; also, to make (a stroke) in that way.
The horse which goes between the thills, or shafts, andsupports them; also, the last horse in a team; -- called also thillhorse.
In a feeling manner; pathetically; sympathetically.
A nitrogenous substance resembling vitellin, present in the eggyolk of cartilaginous fishes.
A pustular eruptive disease of the cow, which, whencommunicated to the human system, as by vaccination, protects fromthe smallpox; vaccinia; -- called also kinepox, cowpock, andkinepock. Dunglison.
A term sometimes applied to the decomposition of organicsubstance into more simple bodies, by the use of chemical agentsalone. Thudichum.
A quorum, or number necessary, for conducting public worship.
In a winking manner; with the eye almost closed. Peacham.
The work of a coal miner who is paid by a share of his product.
A writing composed of words not having a certain letters; -- asin the Odyssey of Tryphiodorus there was no A in the first book, no Bin the second, and so on.
Belonging to rivers or streams; fluviatile. Johnson.
A native sailor, employed in European vessels; also, a menialemployed about arsenals, camps, camps, etc.; a camp follower. [EastIndies]
One who sells unguents or perfumery. [Obs.] Jonhson.
A little cable less than ten inches in circumference.
The art of mangonizing, or setting off to advantage. [Obs.]
A book containing stories, or short narratives, either true orfalse.
An alloy of nicked with copper and zinc; German silver.
A manure made from night soil, dried and mixed with charcoal,gypsum, etc.
A morbid condition produced by the excessive or prolonged useof morphine.
An individual of one of the races of aboriginal inhabitantswhich survive in Hindostan.-- a.
The achromatic figure, formed in mitotic cell-division,consisting of two asters connected by a spindle-shaped bundle ofrodlike fibers diverging from each aster, and called the spindle.
Unskillfully painted, so that the painter's method of work istoo obvious; also, having too much pigment applied to the surface.[Cant]
To feed with too little food; to supply with an insufficientquantity of food.
resembling a rose in smell or color. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
Having the lower chop or jaw depressed; hence, crestfallen;dejected; dispirited;downcast. See Chapfallen.
A duty paid to the crown for the passage of vessels on certainrivers.
A plane four-sided figure, having two sides parallel to eachother.
A flat batter cake cooked on a griddle; a flapjack; agriddlecake. [Local, U.S.]
Not to be depended on; weak; unstable. [Prov. Eng.] Grose.
The art or occupation of a smith; smithing. [R.] Sir W.Raleigh.
The two projecting feathered angles of the forehead of somebirds; the frontal points.
One of a celebrated breed of American trotting horses; -- socalled from the name of the stud from which the breed originated inVermont.
The indian cane, a plant of the Palm family. It furnishes thecommon rattan. See Rattan, and Dragon's blood.
One who, or that which, bewrays; a revealer. [Obs. or Archaic]Addison.
The vessel in which incense is burned and offered; a censer; athurible. [R.] Evelyn.
An exclamatory sentence, or striking reflection, which sums upor concludes a discourse.
One of three hydroxy derivatives of toluene, called thecresols. See Cresol.
A minute inclosed crystal, often observed when minerals orrocks are examined in thin sections under the microscope.
A game for two, played with 40 cards, in which each playertries to form three or four of a kind or sequences.
A note of half the time or duration of the breve; -- nowusually called a whole note. It is the longest note in general use.
To inclose, as a body of troops, between hostile forces, so asto cut off means of communication or retreat; to invest, as a city.
That point in the orbit of a double star where the smaller staris farthest from its primary.
A contrivance for holding and turning a drill. Knight.
Published under the name of some one other than the author.
A genus of coniferous trees, properly called Fir, as the balsamfir and the silver fir. The spruces are sometimes also referred tothis genus.
A house on deck, where the cooking is done; -- commonly calledthe galley.
An astringent and narcotic drug made from the dried leaves andseed capsules of wild hemp (Cannabis Indica), and chewed or smoked inthe East as a means of intoxication. See Hasheesh.
A process of printing, ornamenting, or carving, by burning withheated instruments.
A jocosely depreciative name for a vehicle. [Ireland]
The condition of being mazed; confusion; astonishment. [Obs.]Chaucer.
Want of strength; weakness; feebleness. [Obs.] Wyclif.
A right whereby one thing is subject to another thing or personfor use or convenience, contrary to the common right.
A figure by which synonymous words are used to amplify adiscourse.
A special branch, resembling a leaf, as in the apparent foliageof the broom (Ruscus) and of the common cultivated smilax(Myrsiphillum).
The addition of a letter at the end of a word, without changingits sense; as, numb for num, whilst for whiles.
Figuratively [Obs.]; by way of allusion; by implication,suggestion, or insinuation.
A musical istrument of percussion, consisting of bars yieldingmusical tones when struck. Knight.
A cylindrical pipe fitting, having a number of lateral outlets,for connecting one pipe with several others.
To recall something by means of memory; to remember. [Obs.]Bryskett.
A photographic picture obtained by the use of a cyanide.
A short, thick piece of anything. [Colloq. U. S. & Prov. Eng.]
One of several large wading birds of the genera Mycteria andXenorhynchus, allied to the storks in form and habits.
One of certain upright timbers on the bilge ways, used tosupport a vessel in launching. Totten.
The mucilaginous drupaceous fruit of two East Indian trees(Cordia Myxa, and C. latifolia), sometimes used medicinally inpectoral diseases.
The tendency of a mass of matter toward a center of attraction;esp., the tendency of a body toward the center of the earth;terrestrial gravitation.
To embarrass with difficulties; to make a bungle or botch of.[Local, U. S.]
An embryo or certain invertebrates in the stage when theprimitive band is first developed.
A metallic substance, resembling gold in color, but inferior invalue; a mixed metal of the ancients, resembling brass; -- calledalso aurichalcum, orichalcum, etc.
A ship or vessel employed in the business of taking fish, as inthe cod fishery.
One who collects illustrations from various books for thedecoration of one book.
An acute infectious febrile disease, resembling typhoid fever,with muscular pains, disturbance of the digestive organs, jaundice,etc.
An instrument attached to the wheel of a vehicle, to measurethe distance traversed; also, a wheel used by surveyors, whichregisters the miles and rods traversed.
To strip of a mask or disguise; to lay open; to expose.
A liqueur distilled from fermented cherry juice, and flavoredwith the pit of a variety of cherry which grows in Dalmatia.
An animated picture machine for screen projection; acinematograph.
The Anglicized form of the French arpenteur, a land surveyor.[R.]

A group of acalephs of which Lucernaria is the type. The bodyis cup-shaped with eight marginal lobes bearing clavate tentacles. Anaboral sucker serves for attachment. The interior is divided intofour large compartments. See Lucernarida.
One who forges, makes, of forms; a fabricator; a falsifier.
A contractile striated layer found in the bodies and stems ofcertain Infusoria.
A mock moon; an image of the moon which sometimes appears atthe point of intersection of two lunar halos. Cf. Parhelion.
The larva of a small tortricid moth which eats the leaves ofthe cranberry, so that the vines look as if burned; -- called alsocranberry worm.
Relating to the correcting or straightening out of something;corrective.
Like a huswife; capable; economical; prudent.-- adv.
Quality or state of being ventose; windiness; hence, vainglory;pride. Bacon.
A genus of composite plants with white or colored dry andpersistent involucres; a kind of everlasting.
Fated or decreed with something else. [R.] A. Tucker.
One of a sect among the Jews in the time of our Savior,remarkable for their strictness and abstinence.
A waxlike mineral resin; -- sometimes called native paraffin,and mineral wax.
A beverage, formerly made by boiling ale with spice, sugar, andsops of bread.Their aleberries, caudles, possets. Beau. & Fl.
To force (a person) to do something, or give up something, byintimidation; to coerce. Wharton.
To saw again; specifically, to saw a balk, or a timber, whichhas already been squared, into dimension lumber, as joists, boards,etc.
The part of the small intestines between the stomach and thejejunum. See Illust. of Digestive apparatus, under Digestive.

An unaccompanied polyphonic song, in four, five, or more parts,set to secular words, but full of counterpoint and imitation, andadhering to the old church modes. Unlike the freer glee, it is bestsung with several voices on a part. See Glee.
To shake and wash a fluid about in the mouth with the lipsclosed. [Prov. Eng.] Forby.
The state or quality of being briny; saltness; brinishness.

Of or pertaining to delay; esp., designating a law passed, asin a time of financial panic, to postpone or delay for a period thetime at which notes, bills of exchange, and other obligations, shallmature or become due.
A coarse umbelliferous plant of Europe (Tordylium maximum).
A wheel turned by persons or animals, by treading, climbing, orpushing with the feet, upon its periphery or face. See Treadmill.
Having power or a tendency to exert; using exertion.
An auscultatory process, which consists in noting the tone ofthe observer's own voice, while he speaks, holding his head close tothe patient's chest. Dunglison.

A poisonous alkaloid glucoside extracted from the berries ofcommon nightshade (Solanum nigrum), and of bittersweet, and frompotato sprouts, as a white crystalline substance having an acrid,burning taste; -- called also solonia, and solanina.
Primitive religion in which each of several divinities isregarded as independent, and is worshiped without reference to therest. [R.]
Of or pertaining to the Kurile Islands, a chain of islands inthe Pacific ocean, extending from the southern extremity ofKamschatka to Yesso.-- n.
To throw out of the proper orbit; to unsphere. Shak.
The place of departed spirits; Hades; also, the grave.For thou wilt not leave my soul to sheel. Ps. xvi. 10. (Rev. Ver.)
A hypothetical hydrocarbon radical, C3H5, isomeric with allyland glyceryl, and regarded as the essential residue of glycerin. Cf.Allyl, and Glyceryl.
The art of making roads or ways for traveling, including theconstruction of bridges, canals, viaducts, etc. [R.] R. Park.
One of the minute cushions on the feet of certain insects.
A member of a secret organization, consisting mainly ofIrishment, having for its aim the overthrow of English rule inireland.
An idiom of the Greek language; a Hellenism. Addison.
Dissection of, or incision into, a gland or glands.
Ware made of metal, as cutlery, kitchen utensils, and the like;ironmongery.
A black, greenish, or brownish mineral of the chrysolite group.It is a silicate of iron.
Any one of several species of small wrenlike Asiatic birdshaving short wings and a short tail. They belong to Brachypterix,Callene, and allied genera.
That division of the natural sciences which treats of theclassification of animals and plants; the laws or principles ofclassification.
Tending to become liquid; inclined to melt to melt; melting.
Inclined to remit punishment; lenient; clement. Drayton.
A smokeless powder containing equal parts of solublenitrocellulose and nitroglycerin.

Of or pertaining to a sulphamide; derived from, or related to,a sulphamide; specifically, designating an amido acid derivative,NH2.SO2.OH, of sulphuric acid (analogous to sulphonic acid) which isnot known in the free state, but is known in its salts.
A small species of antelope (Rupicapra tragus), living on theloftiest mountain ridges of Europe, as the Alps, Pyrenees, etc. Itpossesses remarkable agility, and is a favorite object of chase.
One of the followers of Simon Magus; also, an adherent ofcertain heretical sects in the early Christian church.
Native zinc oxide; a brittle, translucent mineral, of anorange-red color; -- called also red zinc ore, and red oxide of zinc.
One of the followers of Noetus, who lived in the third century.He denied the distinct personality of the Father, Son, and HolyGhost.
A person subjected to mesmeric influence; one who ismesmerized. [R.]
A precious stone of a rich green color, a variety of beryl. SeeBeryl.
A fixed star of the second magnitude, in the constellationGemini. Cf. 3d Castor.
One who makes or deals in costumes, as for theaters, fancyballs, etc.
An appendage at the base of petioles or leaves, usuallysomewhat resembling a small leaf in texture and appearance.
Any species of bee which has on the hind legs a brush of hairsused for collecting pollen, as the hive bees and bumblebees.
An evergreen shrub, of the genus Laurus (L. nobilis), havingaromatic leaves of a lanceolate shape, with clusters of small,yellowish white flowers in their axils; -- called also sweet bay.
The timbers, etc., which form a truss, taken collectively.Weale.
A rule relating to the solution of questions concerning thecompounding or mixing of different ingredients, or ingredients ofdifferent qualities or values.
Seizure by, or grasp of, the hand; also, close quarters infighting. Hudibras.

Mineral coal retaining the texture of the wood from which itwas formed, and burning with an empyreumatic odor. It is of morerecent origin than the anthracite and bituminous coal of the propercoal series. Called also brown coal, wood coal.
In an infallible manner; certainly; unfailingly; unerringly.Blair.
The act of pouring upon, or sprinkling with a liquid, as waterupon a child in baptism. Specifically: (Med)
Having mettle; high-spirited; ardent; full of fire. Addison.
A small, narrow flag or streamer borne at the top of a lance; -- called also pennoncel. [Obs.] Piers Plowman. Chaucer.
A note of half the duration of the quaver; -- now usuallycalled a sixsteenth note.
The calculation and explanation of a nativity. [Obs.] Bailey.
Work composed of shells, or adorned with them. Cotgrave.
Veneration or worship given to the Virgin Mary as the mostexalted of mere creatures; higher veneration than dulia. Addis &Arnold.

A genus of small, slender fishes, remarkable for their habit ofliving as commensals in other animals. One species inhabits the gillcavity of the pearl oyster near Panama; another lives within an EastIndian holothurian.
A king of parrot, of a beautiful green color, found in thePhilippine Islands.
In an indigent, mean, or despicable manner; in the manner of abeggar.
A bitter compound used in adulterating beer; bittern.
The state of rising above others; a projection. Evelyn. Boyle.
A design or painting in thin transparent water colors; also,the mode of painting in such colors.

An instrument intended to replace the knife in many operations,the parts operated on being severed by the crushing effect producedby the gradual tightening of a steel chain, so that hemorrhage rarelyfollows.
To strike and dash about water, mud, etc.; to dash in such away as to spatter.
A member or a supporter of the Rump Parliament. I. Disraeli.
The nature or characteristic qualities or actions of a brute;extreme stupidity, or beastly vulgarity.
To make to understand; to instruct. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
The act or the process of putting anything into bottles (asbeer, mineral water, etc.) and corking the bottles.
To praise highly; to extol in a public speech; to write ordeliver a panegyric upon; to eulogize.
A contrivance or apparatus to prevent the explosion of steamboilers.
A stall or a crib for an ox, cow, or other animal. [Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
A young hawk when it begins to leave the nest and take to thebranches.
A genus of herbs (Chenopodium) mostly annual weeds; pigweed.
A writ of prohibition against proceeding in the spiritual courtin certain cases, when the suit belongs to the common-law courts.Wharton (Law Dict. ).
Seats in the chancel of a church near the altar for theofficiating clergy during intervals of service. Hook.
That department of musical science which relates to, or treatsof, the power of tones.
A genus of tall tropical grasses including the sugar cane.
An officer who ranks next below a captain, -- ranking with alieutenant colonel in the army.
The quotient of two vectors, or of two directed right lines inspace, considered as depending on four geometrical elements, and asexpressible by an algebraic symbol of quadrinomial form.
A genus of large eocene birds from the Paris basin.
A substance resembling starch, found in the green frothy scumformed on the surface of stagnant water.
Not deplored or bewailed; unlamented. [Obs.] Spenser.
A hydrated arseniate of copper, occurring in obtuse pyramidalcrystals of a sky-blue or verdigris-green color.
A person cited to answer, or defend against, a petition.

To take or get back, by a writ for that purpose (goods andchattels wrongfuly taken or detained), upon giving security to trythe right to them in a suit at law, and, if that should be determinedagainst the plaintiff, to return the property replevied.
Inward sense; mind; understanding; conscience. [Obs.] Wyclif.
The quality or state of being modern; recentness; novelty. M.Arnold.
To cause to fester; to make sore; to inflame. [R.] Beau. & Fl.
Having the testicles naturally concealed, as in the case of thecetaceans.
A collection of persons employed to applaud at a theatricalexhibition.
Consisting of loam; partaking of the nature of loam; resemblingloam. Bacon.
An engraved tablet, usually of brass, set up in a public place.
A tribe belonging to the Finnic race, and inhabiting a portionof Russia.
The person who weighs and proportions the materials to be madeinto glass, and who works and tempers them.
Having the power to produce the sensation of taste; producingtaste, flavor, or relish.
A cord or rope interwoven in a bedstead so as to support thebed.
A chief judge in the Turkish empire, so named originallybecause his jurisdiction extended to the cases of soldiers, who arenow tried only by their own officers.
A modification of the quadrant, for measuring small angles.[Obs.]
A pencil of black or red lead; -- called also keelyvine pen.[Scot.] Sir W. Scott.
A Hebrew name for God, usually translated in the Old Testamentby the word "Lord".
A colorless, crystalline hydrocarbon, C13H10 having a beautifulviolet fluorescence; whence its name. It occurs in the higher boilingproducts of coal tar, and is obtained artificially.
Of or pertaining to a stoma; of the nature of a stoma.
Pertaining to, or having the nature of, a basyle; electro-positive; basic; -- opposed to chlorous. Graham.
The quality or state of being rubescent; a reddening; a flush.
Mystery; esoterics; -- opposed to exotery. A. Tucker.
An early coin struck by the dukes of Milan, and bearing thefigure of St. Ambrose on horseback.
A rope stitched to the edges of a sail to strengthen the sail.
A metallic wire used for regulating the resistance of acircuit, or varying the strength of an electric current, by insertinga greater or less length of it in the circuit.

A name suggested by Dr. Beale for the germinal matter supposedto be essential to the functions of all living beings; the materialthrough which every form of life manifests itself; unalteredprotoplasm.
The lowest group of vertebrates; -- so called from the cirriaround the mouth; the Leptocardia. See Amphioxus.
The button, globule, or mass of metal, in a more or less impurestate, which forms in the bottom of the crucible in smelting andreduction of ores.
The division of mankind which embraces the races having woollyor crispy hair. Cf. Leiotrichi.
The outer and usually the smaller of the two bones of the leg,or hind limb, below the knee.
Laid down; absolute or positive, as a law. Dr. H. More.
The art or process of exhibiting luminous images, especiallythose of external objects, in a darkened room, by arrangements oflenses or mirrors.
A small owl (Glaucidium gnoma) of the Western United States.
One who confesses a crime and accuses another. See 1stApprovement, 2.
A head covering of various kinds; a hood; a coif; a cap. [Obs.]Chaucer.
One versed in the Talmud; one who adheres to the teachings ofthe Talmud.
Pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid obtained by apartial decomposition of orsellic acid as a white crystallinesubstance, and related to protocatechuic acid.
Not open to a free current of air; wanting fresh air, orcommunication with the open air.
A solid bounded by twenty-four similar quadrilateral faces. Itis a hemihedral form of the hexoctahedron.
A plowland; as much land as one team can plow in a year and aday; -- by some said to be about 100 acres. Burrill.
An officer of the French customs. [Anglicized form douaneer.]
A genus of trees with entire opposite leaves and smallapetalous flowers. There are less than a dozen species, occuring fromIndia to Australia and the Pacific Islands. See Sandalwood.
An instrument devised by Hermann, for regulating and measuringthe thickness of a layer of blood for spectroscopic examination.
The horselouse; an insect that deposits nits on horses.
Ground situated at a distance from the house; outlying land.
A trinket; a jewel; -- a word applied to anything small and ofelegant workmanship.
A piece of leather crossing the breast, used by the men whodrag sledges in coal mines.
Clothed or adorned with the fur of the ermine. Pope.
The art or process of determining he constituents of a gaseousmixture by means of the eudiometer, or for ascertaining the purity ofthe air or the amount of oxygen in it.
A revolving cylinder, or a vibrating bar with teeth, in acarding machine, which doffs, or strips off, the cotton from thecards. Ure.
A steel-gray mineral, of metallic luster, commonly fibrousmassive. It is a sulphide of antimony and lead, with a little iron.
Any marked prominence or projecting part, especially of a bone;anapophysis.
A native phosphate of yttrium occurring in yellowish-browntetragonal crystals.
To render modern; to adapt to modern person or things; to causeto conform to recent or present usage or taste. Percy.
An incision into the rectum, as for the division of astricture.
A threemasted vessel, having the foremast square-rigged, andthe others schooner-rigged. [Spelled also barquentine, barkantine,etc.] See Illust. in Append.
Being in the state, or the position, of one who, or that which,sits.
A name given by Lestiboudois to dicotyledons; -- so calledbecause the plumule is naked.

Among furriers, any of several Asiatic minks; esp., Putoriussibiricus, the yellowish brown pelt of which is valued, esp. for thetail, used for making artists' brushes. Trade names for the fur arered sable and Tatar sable.
The act of burying vessels in warm earth in order to exposetheir contents to a steady moderate heat; the state of being thusexposed.
The term in a fraction which indicates the number of fractionalunits that are taken.
A structure on the hurricane deck of a steamer, containing thepilot house, officers' cabins, etc. [Western U.S.] Knight.
Of or pertaining to the United States, or to America.
A note at the head of a page or chapter; in law reports, anabstract of a case, showing the principles involved and the opinionof the court.
Pertaining to eczema; having the characteristic of eczema.

A large marine annelid (Arenicola marina) having a row oftufted gills along each side of the back. It is found burrowing insandy beaches, both in America and Europe, and is used for bait byEuropean fishermen. Called also lobworm, and baitworm.
Capable of communicating color or tint to other bodies.
An instrument to thrash with; a flail. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.

A hurt; an injury. Specifically:(a) (Civil Law) Loss sustained from failure to fulfill a bargain orcontract. Burrill.(b) (Med.) Any morbid change in the exercise of functions or thetexture of organs. Dunglison.
Any one of a group of fishes having the dorsal and anal finspartially covered with scales.
To deprive of saintship; to deny sanctity to. [R.] South.
A half chorus; a passage to be sung by a selected portion ofthe voices, as the female voices only, in contrast with the fullchoir.
A West Indian lizard (Celestus occiduus), about a foot long,imagined by the natives to be venomous.
A thick liquid residuum obtained in the distillation of Russianpetroleum, much used as fuel.
The principal sound or sounds by which others are produced; thefundamental note or root of the common chord; -- called alsogenerating tone.
A genus of marine gastropods in which the shell has the outerlip dilated into a broad wing. It includes many large and handsomespecies commonly called conch shells, or conchs. See Conch.

A genus of large hymenopterous insects allied to the sawflies.The female lays her eggs in holes which she bores in the trunks oftrees with her large and long ovipositor, and the larva bores in thewood. See Illust. of Horntail.
An order of myriapods having two pairs of legs on each segment;the Chilognatha.
A suit or action in court; any legal process by which a partyendeavors to obtain his claim, or what he regards as his right; case;ground of action.

The name given to a revolt of French peasants against thenobles in 1358, the leader assuming the contemptuous title, JacquesBonhomme, given by the nobles to the peasantry. Hence, any revolt ofpeasants.
A composition of substances which in combustion emit asuffocating odor; -- used formerly in naval warfare.
Of or pertaining to santonin; -- used specifically to designatean acid not known in the free state, but obtained in its salts.
The great gray crane of India (Grus cinerea). [Also writtencoolen and cullum.]
A peculiar small siliceous spicule having a denticulated wheelat each end; -- found in freshwater sponges.
A substitution of a new debt for an old one; also, theremodeling of an old obligation.
Anything done deceitfully, and which could not be properlydesignated by any special name, whether belonging to contracts ornot. Burrill.
In a submissive manner; with a submission. [Archaic] Jer.Taylor.
To judge erroneously or unjustly; to err in judgment; tomisconstrue.
To become checked in normal development, so as either to remainrudimentary or shrink away wholly; to become sterile.
A mineral of a lead-gray color and brilliant metallic luster,occurring in prismatic crystals; sulphide of antimony; -- called alsoantimony glance, and gray antimony.
The process or art of fixing coloring matters permanently anduniformly in the fibers of wool, cotton, etc.
Greediness; voracity; ravenousness; rapacity. Bacon.
With the sails furled, and the helm lashed alee; -- applied toships in a storm. See Hull, n.
A drink consisting of eggs beaten up with sugar, milk, and(usually) wine or spirits.
A beginning or first attempt; hence, a first appearance beforethe public, as of an actor or public speaker.
A white crystalline nitrogenous substance obtained by theaction of dilute sulphuric acid on silk gelatin.
One who emblazons; also, one who publishes and displaysanything with pomp.
One of two or more species of European labroid fishes(Crenilabrus melops, and Ctenolabrus rupestris); -- called alsogoldsinny, and goldney.
A right line drawn or extending from the center of a circle tothe periphery; the semidiameter of a circle or sphere.
Queasy; nice; squeamish; fastidious; scrupulous. [Obs.] Bp.Earle.
A map showing geographically, by shades or curves, statisticsof various kinds; a statistical map.
In a corrupt manner; by means of corruption or corruptinginfluences; wronfully.
Lady; a lady; -- a title formerly given to noble ladies whoheld a barony in their own right. Burrill.
An hypothesis advanced by Darwin in explanation of heredity.
To shiver; to have chills. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Ray.
A long pole on two wheels, used in hauling logs. [Scot.]Jamieson.
A female servant whose business is the care of the dairy.
A white crystalline substance, C6H7(OH)5, found in acorns, thefruit of the oak (Quercus). It has a sweet taste, and is regarded asa pentacid alcohol.
A greenish, oily, nitrogenous hydrocarbon, C12H19N7, obtainedfrom coal tar, and probably consisting of a mixture of severalmetameric compounds which are higher derivatives of the basepyridine.
A gale of piercingly cold wind, usually accompanied with fineand blinding snow; a furious blast. [U. S.]
Of, pertaining to, or obtained from, saccharine substances;specifically, designating an acid obtained, as a white amorphousgummy mass, by the oxidation of mannite, glucose, sucrose, etc.
The trace or record made by means of a thermograph.
Having the radicle of the embryo lying against the back of oneof the cotyledons; incumbent.
A light fabric of cotton and worsted, resembling bombazine ormerino. Beck (Draper's Dict.)
One who, or that which, civilizes or tends to civilize.

Any one of numerous species of tropical American birds of thegenus Galbula and allied genera. They are allied to the kingfishers,but climb on tree trunks like nuthatches, and feed upon insects.Their colors are often brilliant.
To touch closely, so as to have a common curvature at the pointof contact. See Osculation, 2.
A board, placed on or before a shop, office, etc., on whichssome notice is given, as the name of a firm, of a business, or thelike.
Insanity; madness; esp. that form which consists in weakness ortotal loss of thought and reason; mental imbecility; idiocy.
A kind of dry fruit, consisting of three or more cells, eachwhich at length breaks open at the inner angle.
That service which a tenant owed his lord, to be done by thework beasts of the tenant, as the carriage of wheat, turf, etc.
A peculiar hydrocarbon occuring as an ingredient of Caucasianpetroleum.
A genus of fossil corals, common in the lower Silurianlimestones.
Having the toes bordered by membranes; fin-footed, as certainbirds.
To neglect by idleness; to delay or to waste by sloth. [Obs.]Spenser.
A picture representing a scene at sea; a marine picture.Addison.
A shop or barroom where spirits are sold by the dram.
The act of one who angles; the art of fishing with rod andline. Walton.
The employment, arts, or practices of a pander. Bp. Hall.
The fringe of teeth around the orifice of the capsule ofmosses. It consists of 4, 8, 16, 32, or 64 teeth, and may be eithersingle or double.
A dark yellow, crystalline substance, obtained by the action ofammonia on isatin.
According to wish; conformably to desire. [Obs.] Chapman.
To cry as a cat; to mew; to caterwaul. Sir W. Scott.
A member of a secret political association in Italy, organizedin the early part of the nineteenth centry for the purpose ofchanging the government into a republic.
One who makes and tends a garden; a horticulturist.
The quality or state of being perverse; perverseness.
The process of passing cotton goods between two rollers andexposing them to numerous minute jets of gas to burn off the smallfibers; any similar process of singeing.
An order of mammals including the armadillos, sloths, andanteaters; -- called also Bruta. The incisor teeth are rarelydeveloped, and in some groups all the teeth are lacking.
One who has money invested in the public funds. J. S. Mill.
To wash, as tin ore, with a shovel in a frame fitted for thepurpose. Smart.
One of a race or tribe that has no fixed location, but wandersfrom place to place in search of pasture or game.
The annular molding or group of moldings dividing a long shaftor clustered column into two or more parts.
One of the subdivisions, of more importance than genus, intowhich certain families are divided.
One who receives or collects toll; a toll gatherer. Cowper.
The state of being a deacon; office of a deacon; deaconship.
A kind of basketwork wear in a river, for catching fish.[Improperly spelled kittle.]
A salt or carbonic acid, as in limestone, some forms of leadore, etc.
A tracing (with the sphygmograph) of the movements of a vein,or of the venous pulse.
An instrument for scraping the periosteum from bones; araspatory.
Thunderous; sonorous. "Scraps of thunderous epic." Tennyson.
A barbarous word used by the old chemists to designate variousmedical remedies. [Obs.]
A celebrated Athenian lawmaker, born about 638 b. c.; hence, alegislator; a publicist; -- often used ironically.
Of a light color, or white, mottled with black or brown;grizzled or grizzly. Maunder.
To believe erroneously, or in a false religion. "Thatmisbelieving Moor." Shak.
A handsome tropical American wood, much used for making flutesand other wind instruments; -- called also Grenada cocos, or cocus,and red ebony.
Likely or inclined to roll or pitch, as a ship in a heavy sea;having a tendency to labor.
To point out as with the finger. [R.] Robinson (Eudoxa).
Empty oyster shells and other substances laid down on oystergrounds to furnish points for the attachment of the spawn of theoyster. [Also written cutch.]
A genus of leguminous plants (herbs, shrubs, or trees) of manyspecies, most of which have purgative qualities. The leaves ofseveral species furnish the senna used in medicine.

A hydrocarbon, C6H5.CH3, of the aromatic series, homologouswith benzene, and obtained as a light mobile colorless liquid, bydistilling tolu balsam, coal tar, etc.; -- called also methylbenzene, phenyl methane, etc.
Formerly, a housing or caparison for a horse. Sir W. Scott.
The state of being colored, as in the case of images formed bya lens.
, Of or relating to a pander; characterizing a pander.
A long movable shed used by besiegers in ancient times inattacking the walls of a fortified town.
Of or pertaining to the theme of a word. See Theme, n., 4.
To sprout, as seed in the ground; to vegetate. Chalmers.
To handle, or use, too much; to mention too often. Shak.
A line connecting places on the earth's surface at which thereis the same mean frequency of auroras.
The barn owl; -- called also pudge, and pudge owl. [Prov. Eng.]
A little roll; a roll of coins put up in paper, or somethingresembling such a roll.
An instrument for cropping and holding the snuff of a candle.
A genealogical register of a particular breed or stud ofhorses, esp. thoroughbreds.
A measure of solidity, containing one hundred cubic meters, andequivalent to 3531.66 English or 3531.05 United States cubic feet.
The epidermal cells of rootlets, specially adapted to absorbliquids. Goodale.
To sweeten; to free from acidity, saltness, or acrimony.Wiseman.
One who produces, or offers to notice. [Obs.] Ayliffe.
A plane or arched surface for sustaining bodies by its movementthrough the air; a spread wing, as of a bird.
A yard or inclosure for stacks of hay or grain. A. Smith.
The act of making compact, or the state of being compact.[Obs.] Bacon.
A kind of delicate confectionery or cake, perhaps made from thepulp of fruit. [Obs.] Nares.
Government by three persons; a triumvirate; also, a countryunder three rulers. Holland.
A stick used in playing the game of trapball; hence, fig., aslender leg. Addison.
The upper rail of any parapet of ordinary height, as of abalcony; the railing of a quarter-deck, etc.
A genus of fishes comprising the hairtails. See Hairtail.
A kind of traces with hooks and rings, with which men drag andmaneuver guns where horses can not be used.
Chief physician; -- a term applied, on the continent of Europe,to the first or body physician of princes and to the first physicianof some cities. P. Cyc.
A colorless crystalline substance, C9H6O4, extracted fromdaphnin.
To unfold; to lay open; to explain. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The stress of voice laid upon accented syllable of a word. Cf.Arsis.
To raise, as a rampart, so as to shelter interior workscommanded from some higher point.
Handy; reat; handsome; notable. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
An instrument for measuring power in watts, -- much used inmeasuring the energy of an electric current.
A short cope, or an inferier kind of cope. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A white crystalline nitrogenous substance, found in extract ofmeat, and related to xanthin.
Having a fringe of feathers, as the legs of certian birds; orof hairs, as the legs of a setter dog.
The bearded loach (Nemachilus barbatus) of Europe. [Scot.]
Skill in all kinds of work or business; craft. [R.] Bailey.
The avocet; -- so called because it scoops up the mud to obtainfood.
Capable of being inoculated; capable of communicating disease,or of being communicated, by inoculation.
That which supplies with air; esp. an apparatus used forcharging mineral waters with gas and in making soda water.
A tailless marsupial (Phascolarctos cinereus), found inAustralia. The female carries her young on the back of her neck.Called also Australian bear, native bear, and native sloth.
The darker portion of a picture; a less illuminated part. SeeDef. 1, above.
The case, or impermeable apparel, in which a diver can workwhile under water.
The exhibition or production of a record or paper in opencourt, or an allegation that it is in court.
One of the vessels or tubes which carry either venous orarterial blood from the heart. They have tricker and more muscularwalls than veins, and are connected with them by capillaries.
Anything kept, or given to be kept, for the sake of the giver;a token of friendship.
To hire, as a ship, for the transportation of goods or freight.
A test by which the fitness of a player or contestant to remainin a certain class is determined.
A name of a place; more broadly, a name, as in the binomialname of a plant, based on, or derived from, a place name, or based onthe location of the thing named.
A coarse kind of woolen cloth, used for wrapping, blanketing,etc.
A miraculously given power, as of healing, speaking foreignlanguages without instruction, etc., attributed to some of the earlyChristians.
A painting or drawing in a single color; a picture made with asingle color.

A small, low pillar, square or round, commonly having aninscription, used by the ancients for various purposes, as forindicating the distances of places, for a landmark, for sepulchralinscriptions, etc. Gwilt.
Without punishment; with impunity. [Obs.] J. Ellis.
The plain surface between the channels of a triglyph. [Writtenalso merus.] Weale.
To place under the lee, or unfavorably to the wind. Shak.
Action carried on aside, and commonly in dumb show, while themain action proceeds.
A glucoside found in the stems of the jalap plant and scammony.It is a strong purgative.
A measure of land of uncertain quantity, varying from fifteento forty acres; a virgate. [Obs.]
A stream or river flowing into a larger river or into a lake; atributary stream.
One who advocates or practices the doctrines of socialism.
A crystalline substance (chemically, tribromophenol,C6H2Br3OH), used as an antiseptic and disinfectant.
A scholar appointed to inspect other scholars; a monitor. Todd.
The rehearsal of a lesson by pupils before their instructor.
The song of a minstrel; hence, any song. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Originally, the place of a king; but afterward, an apartmentprovided in the houses of persons of importance, where assemblieswere held for dispensing justice; and hence, any large hall used forthis purpose.
An under reader in the inns of court, who reads the texts oflaw the reader is to discourse upon. [Eng.] Crabb.
A carriage or cart used in India, esp. one drawn by bullocks.
A small circumscribed tumor of the eyelid caused by retentionof secretion, and by inflammation of the Melbomian glands.
A bending or sinking between the ends of a thing, inconsequence of its own, or an imposed, weight; an arching downward inthe middle, as of a ship after straining. Cf. Hogging.
A winged animal; wild fowl; game. [Obs.] Chaucer. Sir T.Browne.
An organic residue or radical derived from lactic acid.
A mixture of two or more sorts of grain; -- now called maslinand meslin. Bacon.
Pertaining to Lusitania, the ancient name of the region almostcoinciding with Portugal.-- n.
To inter with funeral rites; to bury. [Obs.] G. Fletcher.
A short piece of rope having a knot at one or both ends, with alanyard under the knot, -- used to secure something. Totten.
The light frame which holds the sheet of paper to the tympan inprinting.
A small ball of clay, baked hard and oiled, used as a marble byboys in playing. [Prov. Eng. & U. S.] Halliwell. Bartlett.
Pertaining to or designating a rock or peak of the Capitolinehill, Rome, from which condemned criminals were hurled.
A soluble ferment occurring in the animal body, to the presenceof which many normal decompositions and synthetical processes aresupposed to be due.
To grow exuberantly; to produce fleshy or warty outgrowths; as,a vegetating papule.
A reservior in which water accumulates at the bottom of a mine.
The celebrated work of Ptolemy of Alexandria, which containsnearly all that is known of the astronomical observations andtheories of the ancients. The name was extended to other similarworks.
The highest class of Vertebrata. The young are nourished for atime by milk, or an analogous fluid, secreted by the mammary glandsof the mother.
A draught; a dose; usually, a draught or dose of a liquidmedicine. Shak.
One who works as a mason without having served a regularapprenticeship. [Scot.]
Land granted by the crown to a thane or lord. Burrill.
Pertaining to, or resembling, the electro-negative character ofchlorine; hence, electro-negative; -- opposed to basylous or zincous.[Obs.]
An instrument for measuring the degree of hardness; especially,an instrument for testing the relative hardness of steel rails andthe like.
A popular Italian dance in quick 3-4 or 6-8 time, runningmostly in triplets, but with a hop step at the beginning of eachmeasure. See Tarantella.
A medicine composed of powders, or other ingredients,incorporated with some convserve, honey, or sirup; a confection. Seethe note under Confection.
To fail, as on a lesson; to back out, as from an undertaking,through fear.
Inability to utter articulate sounds, due either to paralysisof the larynx or to that form of aphasia, called motor, or ataxis,aphasia, due to loss of control of the muscles of speech.
A spirituous liquor or drink distilled from potatoes; -- usedin the Barbadoes.
The branches of polite or elegant learning; as language,rhetoric, poetry, and the ancient classics; belles-letters.
Any plant of the umbelliferous genus Laserpitium, of severalspecies (as L. glabrum, and L. siler), the root of which yields aresinous substance of a bitter taste. The genus is mostly European.
A stout pole for use in making a rick, or for a spar to a boat.
A clamp on a flexible pipe to regulate the flow of a fluidthrough the pipe.
One of five commissioners appointed for some special object.
A going round in a circle; a course not direct; a roundaboutway of proceeding.
The hypothetical radical of picric acid, analogous to phenyl.
Indian corn parched, and beaten to powder, -- used for food bythe Northern American Indians.
An air plant which grows on other plants, but does not deriveits nourishment from them. See Air plant.
A wide-mouthed bottle with glass stopper for holding chemicals,especially crystallized salts.
Turning or facing inward, or toward the axis of the part towhich it belongs. Gray.
The bag or pouch which contains the testicles; the cod.
The doctrine that all our ideas, or the operations of theunderstanding, not only originate in sensation, but are transformedsensations, copies or relics of sensations; sensationalism; sensism.

One of a class eligible to the office of senator, but not yetchosen, who could sit and speak in the senate, but could not vote; --so called because he might indicate his opinion by walking over tothe side of the party he favored when a vote was taken.

A class of air-breathing oviparous vertebrates, usually coveredwith scales or bony plates. The heart generally has two auricles andone ventricle. The development of the young is the same as that ofbirds.
A dark brown resinous substance obtained from indican.
Of or pertaining to Portugal, or its inhabitants.-- n. sing. & pl.
Like or pertaining to the nautilus; shaped like a nautilusshell.-- n.
A carbohydrate of the glucose group found in the thickenedendosperm of certain seeds, and extracted as yellow sirup having asweetish-bitter taste.
A pecuniary compensation for an injury, of eight times thevalue of the thing.
To put inconvenience; to incommode; to trouble. [R.]
The last milk drawn in milking; strokings. [Obs.] Grose.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid (called also pyroracemicacid) obtained, as a liquid having a pungent odor, by thedistillation of racemic acid.
A confection made of nut kernels, usually of almonds, roastedin boiling sugar until brown and crisp.
Having a dense covering of long hair, like the foot of a hare.
The yellowish, fragrant balsam yielded by the sweet gum; also,the tree itself.
A flat-bottomed river barge or coasting vessel. [Eng.]
The shedding or spilling of blood; slaughter; the act ofshedding human blood, or taking life, as in war, riot, or murder.
To plait, crimp, or flute; to goffer, as lace. See Goffer.
To eat to excess; to eat voraciously; to gormandize. Hallywell.
The act or process of separating the finer parts of drugs fromthe coarser by sifting.
To water, as land, by causing a stream to flow upon, over, orthrough it, as in artificial channels.
Resembling a Mongol or the Mongols; having racecharacteristics, such as color, hair, and features, like those of theMongols. Huxley.
A compressed portion of one or more drugs or chemicals, or offood, etc.
Resembling tow; having long, loose scales, or matted filaments,like tow; stupose.
To restore from folly, or from being a fool. [Obs.] Shak.
Containing, or intended to contain, tears; lachrymal. Addison.
A substance added to a medicine to mollify or modify itsaction. Dunglison.
Habitual lewdness or prostitution of a woman; harlotry.
Of or pertaining to twigs; consisting of twigs; producingtwigs.
A division of a tribe; a group of genera of a little lower rankthan a tribe.
An aqueous medicine, containing little, if any, medicinalagent; a tea or tisane.
Movement in musical time, with periodical recurrence of accent;the measured beat or pulse which marks the character and expressionof the music; symmetry of movement and accent. Moore (Encyc. )
A division of Orthoptera including grasshoppers, locusts, andcrickets.
Pertaining to, or derived from, vanilla or vanillin; resemblingvanillin; specifically, designating an alcohol and an acidrespectively, vanillin being the intermediate aldehyde.
Foil or wire made of gold, silver, or brass. De Colange.
The ancient Latin name of Wales. It is used by modern poets.

A plug of some substance lodged in a blood vessel, beingbrought thither by the blood current. It consists most frequently ofa clot of fibrin, a detached shred of a morbid growth, a globule offat, or a microscopic organism.
A supposed spongelike expansion of the tip of a rootlet forabsorbing water; -- called also spongelet.
A ragout or partky roasted game stewed with sauce, wine, bread,and condiments suited to provoke appetite.
One of the divisions or parties of charioteers (distinguishedby their colors) in the games of the circus.
Wine and water sweetened and spiced, -- a favorite West Indiandrink.
A turfite; a votary of the turf, or race course. [Colloq.]
To uncover; to unfold or unroll; to disentangle. [R.] Dr. H.More.
An officer in the pope's court, having charge of the Dataria.
Any machine or vehicle that does not run smoothly. [Colloq.] A.Trollope.
One who, or that which, impels; an inciter. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
One of a board of seven men associated in some office.
To deceive or lead astray with a false light. Herrick.
Any large Old World lizard of the genus Varanus; esp., theEgyptian species (V. Niloticus), which is useful because it devoursthe eggs and young of the crocodile. It is sometimes five or six feetlong.
Of or pertaining to the pulpit; like preaching. Chalmers.
The shank of a rudder, having the blade at one end and theattachments for operating it at the other.
To tear or separate into minute shreds, as with needles orsimilar instruments.
To revoke, as a legacy, grant, etc., or to satisfy it by someother gift.
Pertaining to, or resembling, a decoction. [Obs.] J. Whitaker.
Capable of being converted into vapor, or dissipated byevaporation.
A fish of the genus Leuciscus; the blue chub of the Danube.

A kind of missile weapon consisting of one, two, or more ballsof stone, iron, or other material, attached to the ends of a leathercord; -- used by the Gauchos of South America, and others, forhurling at and entangling an animal.
Born anew; become Christian; renovated in heart; changed from anatural to a spiritual state.
To cover, as with a mask; to disguise or conceal. [R.] Shak.
The quality or state of being watery; moisture; humidity.
Modern practice; a thing of recent date; esp., a modern usageor mode of expression.
The quality or condition of being spumy; spumescence.
An American grape, with compact bunches of small, amber-coloredberries, sweet and of a good flavor.
The act or operation of smearing the body with mud, especiallywith the sediment from mineral springs; a mud bath.
A rare white earthy substance, consisting of the oxide ofthorium; -- formerly called also thorina.
Chainlike; -- said both or color marks and of indentations whenarranged like the links of a chain, as on shells, etc.
Disturbance of the stomach; a feeling of nausea. Holland.

A modification of the gyroscope, consisting essentially of afly wheel fixed inside a rigid case to which is attached a thinflange of metal for supporting the instrument. It is used in studyingthe dynamics of rotating bodies.
A salt of tartaric acid in which the base replaces but half theacid hydrogen; an acid tartrate, as cream of tartar.
The state, office, or dignity of a king; royalty. Landor.
To move with a lever; to force up or open; to pry. [Writtenalso prise.]
A mass of iron or lead hung from the yardarm, in readiness tobe dropped on the deck of an enemy's vessel.
An unusual or unexpected thing; a wonder. See Fearly. [Obs. orProv. Eng.] Drayton.
One of the principal rivers of Hades, in the channel of whichfire flowed instead of water.
A group of simple marine organisms, usually classed as thelowest of the sponges. They have inflated hollow bodies.
The part of the scapula in front of, or above, the spine, ormesoscapula.
A variety of altered iolite of a green color and greasy luster.
One of the minute papillary processes on certain vascularmembranes; a villosity; as, villi cover the lining of the smallintestines of many animals and serve to increase the absorbingsurface.
A transfer of title, or a legal conveyance of property toanother.
Having or exercising delegated power; acting by substitution,or in the place of another. Milton.
The system of a decimal currency, decimal weights, measures,etc.
One who attributes the phenomena of the drift, in geology, toglaciers.
The quality or state of being triune; trinity. Dr. H. More.
An apparatus, especially an inclined trough or vat, in whichstamped ore is concentrated by subjecting it to the action of rynningwater so as to wash out the lighter and less valuable portions.
To change the position of; -- said of tones which form a chord,or parts which compose harmony.
A metallic element of the alkaline group, occurring in severalminerals, as petalite, spodumene, lepidolite, triphylite, etc., andotherwise widely disseminated, though in small quantities.
Having an acute sound; (Gr. Gram.), having an acute accent onthe last syllable.
To annoy; to trouble; to worry; to perplex. See Pother.
An uproar; a quarrel; a noisy outbreak. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
To combine with arsenic; to treat or impregnate with arsenic.
Of or pertaining to Austria, or to its inhabitants.-- n.
A female founder; a woman who founds or establishes, or whoendows with a fund.
A small vane of bunting, feathers, or any other light material,carried at the masthead to indicate the direction of the wind.Totten.
The person who is vouched, or called into court to support ormake good his warranty of title in the process of common recovery.Blackstone.
Among Spanish, a religious festival; a saint's day or holiday;also, a holiday or festivity.
The act of washing with salt water. [R. & Obs..] Greenhill.
The act of stealing; specifically, the felonious taking andremoving of personal property, with an intent to deprive the rightfulowner of the same; larceny.
Petty rapine; trick; also, seeking a livelihood by shifts anddishonest devices.
A hydrous silicate of copper, occurring in emerald-greencrystals.
Given to tittuping; gay; lively; prancing; also, shaky;unsteady.
The having, holding, or detention of property in one's power orcommand; actual seizin or occupancy; ownership, whether rightful orwrongful.
Humbleness; abasement; low obeisance. [Obs.] Chaucer. Spenser.
To weary or tire out; to fatigue. [R.] Sir T. Herbert.
A genus of plants embracing a large number of species,including bistort, knotweed, smartweed, etc.
A cake, thinner than a bannock, made of wheat or barley or oatmeal. [Written variously, scon, skone, skon, etc.] [Scot.] Burns.
The servance of common or undivided interests, particularly inreal estate. It may be effected by consent of parties, or bycompulsion of law.
To go before in time or place; to precede; to surpass. Sir M.Hale.
Possessing, or characterized by, a crunode; -- used of curves.
The office or charge of an editor; care and superintendence ofa publication.
Information without oath; an entry of a material fact orcircumstance on the record for the information of the court, at thedeath or insolvency of a party.

One of the short pieces of timber on which the planks formingthe floor of a scaffold are laid, -- one end resting on the ledger ofthe scaffold, and the other in a hole left in the wall temporarilyfor the purpose. Oxf. Gloss.
A small sloop or shallop, or a large boat with sails.
Having the nature and qualities of glass; glasslike; --distinguished from ceramic.
Scotland; esp. the Highlands of Scotland. T. Cambell.
The condition or quality of being regnant; sovereignty; rule.Coleridge.
The technical name of the element tungsten. See Tungsten.
To cut off, as a mortar joint, even with the face of the wall,or inward at a slight angle.
A picture taken on a place of prepared glass, in which thelights are represented in silver, and the shades are produced by adark background visible through the unsilvered portions of the glass.
The positive electrode of an electrolytic cell; anode. [R.]Miller.
A branch of the Mongolian race, now living in the northernparts of Norway, Sweden, and the adjacent parts of Russia.
One who performs some act upon the human body by means of thehand, or with instruments.
Having power, or a tendency, to enervate; weakening. [R.]
A process of sorting ore by washing in a hand sieve. [Writtenalso deluing.]
A writ issued by a superior court and directed to some inferiortribunal, or to some corporation or person exercising authority,commanding the performance of some specified duty.
Of a different tincture from the animal itself; -- said of theeyes of a rapacious animal. Brande & C.
A pickax with one sharp point and one cutting edge. Knight.
To cause to shine with abundance of light; to radiate; to beam.[R.]His eyes effulging a peculiar fire. Thomson.
Having a border or outline composed of semicircles with theconvexity outward; -- the opposite of engrailed.
Like the teeth off a saw; jagged. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
An extinct genus of tree ferns with large, two-ranked leaves,or fronds.
A conglomerate or grit rock, consisting of rounded pebbles sandfirmly united together.
A clock that is designed to keep very accurate time.
The state of being as a thing ought to be; rightness. [R.] N.W. Taylor.
To loosen the reins of; to remove restraint from. Addison.
A trader who sells goods in a shop, or by retail; -- indistinction from one who sells by wholesale. Addison.
The Australian pied crow shrike (Strepera graculina). It isglossy bluish black, with the under tail coverts and the tips andbases of the tail feathers white.
A pair of grappling dogs for hoisting logs and timber.
A popular or jocular name for a drinking vessel. [Obs.]
Animating spirit; intention; temper. nimus furandi Etym: [L.](Law), intention of stealing.
A human being that eats human flesh; hence, any that devoursits own kind. Darwin.
The more granular cells, which finally become internal, in manysegmenting ova, as those of mammals.
Having a knack; cunning; crafty; trickish. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]Halliwell.
One who associates with drabs; a wencher. Massinger.
Foplike; characteristic of a top in dress or manners; making anostentatious display of gay clothing; affected in manners.
The quality or state of being prosy; tediousness; tiresomeness.
To mingle together; to mix in one mass, or intimately; toblend. Bacon.
To excel in volume of ringing sound; to ring louder than.
The state or quality of being obese; incumbrance of flesh.
Any agent capable of causing nervimotion. Dunglison.
A philosophical toy for exhibiting the prismatic tints by meansof thin films.
To deprive of its natural qualities; change the nature of.

One of a group of extinct reptiles having the jaws armed with ahorny beak, as in turtles, and in the genus Dicynodon, supportingalso a pair of powerful tusks. Their remains are found in triassicstrata of South Africa and India.
To cover or overspread with clouds; to becloud; to overcast.
To pull or haul strongly and all together, as upon a rope,without the assistance of mechanical appliances.
A tribe of Indians native of Arizona and the adjacent parts ofMexico and California. They are agricultural, and cultivate corn,wheat, barley, melons, etc.
Having the form or nature of air, or of an elastic fluid;gaseous. Hence fig.: Unreal.
Somewhat shrubby in character; imperfectly shrubby, as theAmerican species of Wistaria.
A massive piece of stone or wood laid immediately on the abacusof the capital of a column or pillar; -- now called architrave.
One who maintains that animals of the same species have sprungfrom more than one original pair; -- opposed to monogenist.
The corner where the upper and under eyelids meet on each sideof the eye.
Consisting of, or containing, gristle; like gristle;cartilaginous.
Minute vesicles surrounded by an area of reddened skin,produced by excessive sweating.
A rupture or hernia in the scrotum; scrotal hernia.
An error in regard to the place of an event or a thing; areferring something to a wrong place. [R.]
Harsh and offensive, as a color; tawdry or in bad taste, as acombination of colors, or any design or work of art.
Trembling or vaccilating, as if about to fall; unsteady;shaking. Johnson.
Wood of the jack (Artocarpus integrifolia), used incabinetwork.
In the direction toward which stars appear to move. SeeFollowing, 2.
A compound of a binary type containing two atoms of iodine; --called also biniodide.
Belonging to, or designating, the modern revival of classical,esp. Greco-Roman, taste and manner of work in architecture, etc.
The art or process of converting skins into leather. See Tan,v. t., 1.
To heal or induce the formation of a cicatrix in, as in woundedor ulcerated flesh. Wiseman.
Any proposition which is subject to the process of conversion;-- so called in its relation to itself as converted, after whichprocess it is termed the conversae. See Converse, n. (Logic).
The state of a communty which permits promiseuous sexualintercourse among its members, as in certain societies practicingcommunism.
A species of hickory (Carya alba) whose outer bark is loose andpeeling; a shagbark; also, its nut.
A certain game at cards in which, if no player wins three ofthe five tricks possible on any deal, the game is said to be spoiled.
That which is part fable and part truth; a mixture of truth andfable. De Quincey.
Measured by sixty degrees; fixed or indicated by a distance ofsixty degrees. Glanvill.
To modify or qualify with respect to quantity; to fix orexpress the quantity of; to rate.
To become publicly known. [R.] "To keep it from divulging."Shak.
An action at law; a suit in equity or admiralty; any legalproceeding before a court for the enforcement of a claim.
One who, or that which, matches; a matching machine. See under3d Match.
Having one of the two florets in the same spikelet neuter, andthe other unisexual, whether male or female; -- said of grasses.
Of or pertaining to the Struthiones, or Ostrich tribe.
The division of fishes which includes the rays and skates.
Any one of several species of large, elongated, marine fishesof the genus Cryptacanthodes, especially C. maculatus of the Americancoast. A whitish variety is called ghostfish.
A continuous and, usually, structureless layer which coversmore or less of the exterior of many corals.
A gelatin dynamite in which the dope is composed largely ofsodium nitrate.
The famous mythic Thracian poet, son of the Muse Calliope, andhusband of Eurydice. He is reputed to have had power to entrancebeasts and inanimate objects by the music of his lyre.
A cloth, the weft of which is of woolen yarn, and the warp ofcotton and silk, -- used for w
A genus of climbing plants, native of Mexico and South America.C. scandens is a consrvatory climber with large bell-shaped flowers.
A building or apartment for silkworms, when feeding and formingcocoons.
A mode of propagating trees by bending branches to the ground,and covering the small shoots with earth; layering. Chambers.
Characterized by dimorphism; occurring under two distinctforms, not dependent on sex; dimorphic.
An instrument for measuring time by the running of sand. SeeHourglass.
Having three furrows, forks, or prongs; having three grooves orsulci; three-grooved.
The bathing of the feet, a bath for the feet. [Obs.]
The book containing the service of the Mass for the entireyear; a Mass book.

To reduce to scoria or slag; specifically, in assaying, to fuseso as to separate the gangue and earthy material, with borax, lead,soda, etc., thus leaving the gold and silver in a lead button; hence,to separate from, or by means of, a slag.
Borne in the escutcheon with his tail doubled between his legs;-- said of a lion.
In general, any piece of a frame which resists thrust orpressure in the direction of its own length. See Brace, and Illust.of Frame, and Roof.
The literary style of Dr. Samuel Johnson, or one formed inimitation of it; an inflated, stilted, or pompous style, affectingclassical words. E. Everett.
To act as a bishop; to fill the office of a prelate. [Obs.]Feeding the flock episcopating. Milton.
Short curls dangling over the temples; -- fashionable in thereign of Charles II. [Obs.] Farquhar.
The carrion crow; -- called also gercrow. [Prov. Eng.]
The doctrine of Jansen regarding free will and divine grace.
A curious American mole (Condylura cristata) having the noseexpanded at the end into a stellate disk; -- called also star-nosedmole.
Conforming to the principles of the Jesuits. Milton.
Between rami or branches; esp., between the mandibles, or ramiof the lower jaw; intermandibular.
A name applied by Dujardin in 1835 to the gelatinous materialforming the bodies of the lowest animals; protoplasm.
To cause to become like the Scotch; to make Scottish. [R.]
Of or pertaining to a tutor; belonging to, or exercised by, atutor.
A fragrant substance which is the chief constituent ofambergris.
To bluster; to swagger; to bully; to be bold, noisy, vaunting,or turbulent.I have a roisting challenge sent amongst The dull and factious noblesof the Greeks. Shak.
The watery eye; a disease in which the tears accumulate in theeye, and trickle over the cheek.
An explosive mixture, consisting of sawdust, charcoal, niter,and ferrocyanide of potassium, used as a substitute for gunpowder.
To drive about; to drive here and there. [Obs.] Rom. of R.
Resting on a track at the bottom, instead of being suspended; -- said of a sliding door. Forney.
A written account or description of a single thing, or class ofthings; a special treatise on a particular subject of limited range.
One of those who commenced the reformation of religion in thesixteenth century, as Luther, Melanchthon, Zwingli, and Calvin.
An herbaceous plant (Trillium erectum), and its astringentrootstock, which is said to have medicinal properties.
A writing signed by both or all the parties to a contract orbond.
A popular name given to a few species of the genus Careopsis,especially to C. tinctoria of Arkansas.
A form of fruit in the cycle of development of the Rusts orBrands, an order of fungi, formerly considered independent plants.
The branch of science which treats of the formation of theearth.
Having ten columns in front; -- said of a portico, temple, etc.-- n.
One of no merit; one who is nor deserving or worthy. [Obs.]Shak.
Argumentative; discursive; reasoning. [R.] Bp. Hall.
Making or doing throughly; efficient; effectual. [R.]Blackstone.
One of the abdominal legs of a crustacean. See Illust. underCrustacea.
To play the politician; to dispute as politicians do. [Obs.]Milton.
A literary or a musical composition formed by selections fromdifferent authors disposed in a new order.
The science of fruits; a treatise on fruits; the cultivation offruits and fruit trees.
A chief butler; -- an officer of the German empire.
Pertaining to, affected with, or of the nature of, epilepsy.
Capable of being thought or conceived; cogitable. Sir W.Hamilton.
To underlet a proportion of, for a single crop; -- said of afarm. [Ireland]
Coated with icing; iced; glazed; -- said of fruits, sweetmeats,cake, etc.
Relating to, or containing, Jehovah, as a name of God; -- saidof certain parts of the Old Testament, especially of the Pentateuch,in which Jehovah appears as the name of the Deity. See Elohistic.
One of a sect of philosophers in the Middle Ages, who adoptedthe opinion of Roscelin, that general conceptions, or universals,exist in name only. Reid.
An inferior kind of vanilla, the pods of Vanilla Pompona.
Occurring or appearing once every two weeks; fortnightly.-- n.
One of the substances of which vegetable tissue is composed,differing from cellulose in its solubility in certain media.
Congenitally united with an organ of another kind, as calyxwith ovary, or stamens with petals.
A sulphide of lead and antimony, of a blackish lead-gray colorand metallic luster.
A species of mixed action, which lies for the recovery ofpossession of real property, and damages and costs for the wrongfulwithholding of it. Wharton.
The state of being savage; the state of rude, uncivilized men,or of men in their native wildness and rudeness.

A univalve mollusk of the genus Haliotis. The shell is linedwith mother-of-pearl, and used for ornamental purposes; the sea-ear.Several large species are found on the coast of California, clingingclosely to the rocks.
To represent by an image, form, model, or resemblance.Our Savior was typified, indeed, by the goat that was slain, and thescapegoat in the wilderness. Sir T. Browne.
The hooded crow; also, in Scotland, the hooded gull.
The chitinous ribbon bearing the teeth of mollusks; -- calledalso lingual ribbon, and tongue. See Odontophore.
The act of refunding; also, that which is refunded. [R.] Lamb.
A slope or declivity in a manege ground down which a horse ismade to gallop, to give suppleness to his haunches.
A tubelike marking, occuring in sandstone and other strata.
An ornamental foliation consisting of more than five divisionsor foils. [R.] See Foil.
Any inflammation of the joints, particularly the gout.
To retard; to repel; to do damage to. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Shot or bits of iron used sometimes in loading cannon.
The stay extending from the foot of the foremast to themaintop.
The act of kindling, or the state of being kindled or on fire.Bacon.
One who, or that which, hacks. Specifically: A cuttinginstrument for making notches; esp., one used for notching pine treesin collecting turpentine; a hack.
Of or pertaining to the north; toward the north, or from thenorth; northern.
Represented as running; -- said of a beast borne in a coat ofarms.
An intentional perversion of truth for the purpose of obtainingsome valuable thing or promise from another.
An officer who has charge of the boats, sails, rigging, colors,anchors, cables, cordage, etc., of a ship, and who also summons thecrew, and performs other duties.
Of or pertaining to glanders; of the nature of glanders.Youatt.
An itinerant player on the musette, an instrument formerlycommon in Europe.
An Algonquin tribe of Indians who formerly inhabited a part ofIllinois.
Slightly increasing an insensible perspiration; mildlydiaphoretic.-- n.
An image or effigy; -- used rather in an abstract sense, andrarely for a work of art.

A common large North American marmot (Arctomys monax). It isusually reddish brown, more or less grizzled with gray. It makesextensive burrows, and is often injurious to growing crops. Calledalso ground hog.
A region infested by rebels; rebels, considered collectively;also, conduct o Thackeray.
Any one of several metameric unsaturated hydrocarbons (C9H14)of the valylene series.
To tend or care for, or to curry or clean, as a, horse.
Too odious to be expressed or mentioned. [Obs.] Howell.
A Sicilian dance, resembling the pastorale, set to a ratherslow and graceful melody in 12-8 or 6-8 measure; also, the music tothe dance.
Attachment to the principles of the society of Orangemen; thetenets or practices of the Orangemen.
Pertaining to, made of, or resembling, floss; hence, light;downy.
A person who has the care of neat cattle; a cowherd. Dryden.
An interval comprising two octaves and a second. Moore (Encyc.of Music.)
A composition for eight parts, usually for eight soloinstruments or voices.
A white, sugarlike substance, C6H8.(OH)2, occurring naturallyin a manna from Madagascar, and in certain plants, and producedartificially by the reduction of galactose and lactose or milk sugar.
The first or chief man; as:(a) The chief man of a jury, who acts as their speaker.(b) The chief of a set of hands employed in a shop, or on works ofany kind, who superintends the rest; an overseer.
Of or pertaining to Anam, to southeastern Asia.-- n.
Any one of several plants yielding a red pigment which is usedby the North American Indians, as the bloodroot and two species ofLithospermum (L. hirtum, and L. canescens); also, the pigment itself.
That part of anatomy which treats of blood vessels andlymphatics.
To remove grease or fatty matter from, as wool or silk.

The science or doctrine of the elementary sounds uttered by thehuman voice in speech, including the various distinctions,modifications, and combinations of tones; phonetics. Also, a treatiseon sounds.
To separate or undo, as links; to uncoil; to unfasten. Shak.
The system of religion, philosophy, and instruction, receivedand taught by the Druids; the rites and ceremonies of the Druids.
Extending over all the zones, from the tropics to the polarzones inclusive.
A vessel employed to attend other vessels, to supply them withprovisions and other stores, to convey intelligence, or the like.
The class of the Coelenterata which includes the corals and seaanemones. The three principal groups or orders are Acyonaria,Actinaria, and Madreporaria.
Capable of being written, or of being written upon. [R.]
A beating or throbbing, especially of the heart or of anartery, or in an inflamed part; a beat of the pulse.
Payment of toll; also, the amount or quantity paid as toll.Drayton.
Of a coarse texture; -- applied to silk with a heavy threadrunning crosswise.
An Australian lorikeet (Trichoglossus multicolor) remarkablefor the variety and brilliancy of its colors; -- called also blue-bellied lorikeet, and blue-bellied parrot.
Having hollow teeth; -- said of a group lizards.-- n.
Of or pertaining to Ahura-Mazda, or Ormuzd, the beneficentdeity in the Zoroastrian dualistic system; hence, Zoroastrian.
To steal in small quantities, or articles of small value; topractice petty theft.
Anything which brings misfortune upon one, or causes failure inan effort or enterprise; a reverse. [Scot.]
A warlike tribe of indians, related to the blackfeet, formerlyinhabiting the region of Wyoming, but now mostly on reservations inthe Indian Territory. They are noted for their horsemanship.
An oxide of zinc which collects on the sides of furnaces wherezinc is sublimed. Formerly applied to the mineral calamine.
A Dominican friar; -- so named because, before the FrenchRevolution, that order had a convent in the Rue St. Jacques, Paris.
Uttered by the aid of the palate; -- said of certain sounds, asthe sound of k in kirk.
Continuing for two years, and then perishing, as plants whichform roots and leaves the first year, and produce fruit the second.
A cuirass, originally of leather, afterward of plates of metalor horn sewed on linen or the like.
Incommensurable; also, unsymmetrical. [Obs.] D. H. More.
The use of a word in a figurative or extended sense; ametaphor;a trope. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
To make a dwarf of; to stunt or hinder the growth of; to dwarf.Donne.
In a heady or rash manner; hastily; rashly; obstinately.
A cake of Indian meal, water, and salt, baked before the fireor in the ashes; -- so called because often cooked on a hoe.[Southern U.S.]
The act of one who weeps; lamentation with tears; shedding oftears.
A reader of lectures or discourses; a lecturer. Sheldon.
An address or public prayer read from the steps of the pulpitin Mohammedan mosques, offering glory to God, praising Mohammed andhis descendants, and the ruling princes.
The American hop hornbeam (Ostrya Virginica), a small tree withvery tough wood.
The entire lower surface of the foot;-said of birds, ect.
To call or set as a prisoner at the bar of a court to answer tothe matter charged in an indictment or complaint. Blackstone.
Notice of a proposed marriage, proclaimed in a church, or otherplace prescribed by law, in order that any person may object, if heknows of just cause why the marriage should not take place.
White; -- applied to albinos, from the whiteness of their skinand hair.
Liability to be overset; -- said of a ship or other vessel.
One who capers, leaps, and skips about, or dances.The nimble capperer on the cord. Dryden.
A trailing branch which is disposed to take root at the end orat the joints; a stole.
A service book containing a selection of pieces for thefestival services.
A deep pie or pudding made of baked apples, or of sliced breadand apples baked together, with no bottom crust.
A genus of fungi having the under surface full of minute pores;also, any fungus of this genus.
One who swears to another's credibility. W. Wotton.
An uncouth or disagreable sound of words, owing to theconcurrence of harsh letters or syllables. "Cacophonies of allkinds." Pope.

The platforms, consisting of two or more planks doweledtogether, for the flooring of a temporary military bridge. Wilhelm.A singular, chess, is sometimes used. "Each chess consists of threeplanks." Farrow.
One of a fabulous race of dwarfs who waged war with the cranes,and were destroyed.
One who, or that which, hardens; specif., one who temperstools.
A glass of fishes having a suckerlike mouth, without jaws, asthe lamprey; the Marsipobranchii.
A blue coloring matter supposed by some to be one of thecomponent parts ofchlorophyll.
Am Austrian silver coin equivalent to 20 kreutzers, or about 10cents.
To pour (something) over or on something else. [Obs.] Evelyn.
A merman; the male of the mermaid. [R.] "Not to mentionmermaids or seamen." Locke.
The top member of a pillar, pier, wall, etc., upon which theweight of an arch rests.
The distal segment of the fore limb, including the carpus andfore foot or hand.
A duty or toil paid for weighing merchandise. Bouvier.
One of tow equal parts of a line, or other magnitude.
The act or condition of holding chattels; the state of being achattel.
A white crystalline substance derived from urethane, used inmedicine as an antipyretic, etc.
An intimate union of the soul with God in contemplation, -- anideal of the Neoplatonists and of some Oriental mystics.
The long flower stems of the ribwort plantain (PlantagoLanceolata). Dr. Prior.
Of the nature of melody; relating to, containing, or made upof, melody; melodious.
The upper faceted portion of a brilliant-cut diamond, whichprojects from the setting and occupies the zone between the girdleand the table. See Brilliant, n.
