Capable of being sued; subject by law to be called to answer incourt. Story.
One of a tribe of beetles, having long maxillary palpi.
The native name of a South American rutaceous shrub (Pilocarpuspennatifolius). The leaves are used in medicine as an diaphoretic andsialogogue.
A shelf behind the altar, for display of lights, vases ofwlowers, etc.
Solemnness.Some think he wanted solemnes. Sir H. Wotton.
A direct descending blow with the edge of a sword. [Obs.] B.Jonson.
Dividing the partitions; -- said of a method of dehiscence inwhich a pod splits through the partitions and is divided into itscomponent carpels.
A small, graceful, and swift African antelope, allied to theklipspringer.
A white person; -- an appellation supposed to have been appliedto the whites by the American Indians. J. F. Cooper.
Pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid (called alsononoic acid) found in the leaves of the geranium (Pelargonium) andallied plants.
Relating to that tribe of ruminant mammals of which the genusBos is the type.
One who is half squire and half farmer; -- used humorously.[Eng.] C. Kingsley.
A person called to make up a deficiency in the number of jurorswhen a tales is awarded. Wharton.
The wood of the Rhus Cptinus or Venice sumach, a shrub ofSouthern Europe, which yields a fine orange color, which, however, isnot durable without a mordant. Ure.
A treatise on teaching or education. [Obs.] Milton.
The dorsal plate of the prothorax in insects. See Illust. ofColeoptera.
A vacant space, or gap, esp. between teeth in a jaw.
A system of bracing bars, not crossing each other in themiddle, connecting the channel bars of a compound strut. Waddell.
A device with fingers or jaws for seizing an object and holdingor conveying it; as, in a printing press, a clasp for catching asheet and conveying it to the form.
A composition irregular in form, like an improvisation; as,Liszt's "Hungarian Rhapsodies."
Matter stated by way of explanatory preamble or introduction tothe main allegations of a pleading; a leading to.
The branch of science which treats of the ear and its diseases.
A lateral half of the heart, either the right or left. B. G.Wilder.
One who affects excessive refinement and elegance of language;-- applied esp. to a class of writers, in the age of Elizabeth, whoseproductions are marked by affected conceits and high-flown diction.
To interpret (mythology) on the theory of euhemerism.
A weight by which lead and some other metals were formerlysold, in England, varying from 19 [Obs.]
Having the form of a cucumber; having the form of a cylindertapered and rounded at the ends, and either straight or curved.
A grayish green antiseptic powder, consisting of a basic iodideand gallate of bismuth, sometimes used in place of iodoform. [ATrademark]
Commonly used as an auxiliary verb, either in the past tense orin the conditional or optative present. See 2d & 3d Will.
An explosive containing nitroglycerin. It is used in blasting.

An immense leguminous tree (Pithecolobium Saman) of Venezuela.Its branches form a hemispherical mass, often one hundred and eightyfeet across. The sweet pulpy pods are used commonly for feedingcattle. Also called rain tree. J. Smith (Dict. Econ. Plants).
A block of type metal lower than the letters, -- used inspacing and in blank lines. [Abbrev. quad.]
An optical property of some crystals which exhibit a star-shaped by reflected light, as star sapphire, or by transmitted light,as some mica.
A sulphide having two atoms of sulphur in the molecule; adisulphide, as in iron pyrites, FeS2; -- less frequently calledbisulphuret.
The science which treats of rays of light, especially of theactinic or chemical rays.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a subdivision of the TrentonPeriod of the Lower Silurian, characterized in the State of New Yorkby beds of shale.
Of or pertaining to Horace, the Latin poet, or resembling hisstyle.
A local division of the people in ancient Athens; a clan; atribe.
A variety of datolite, usually having a botryoidal structure.
A small wooden pail or tub with an upright stave for a handle,-- often used as a dipper.
The elevation of the hand, or that part of the bar at which itis raised, in beating time; the weak or unaccented part of the bar; -- opposed to thesis. Moore.
The front piece of a cap; -- now more commonly called visor.
An affectation of excessive elegance and refinement oflanguage; high-flown diction.
A large North American aquatic salamander (Protonopsis horridaor Menopoma Alleghaniensis). It is very voracious and very tenaciousof life. Also called alligator, and water dog.
The premium or interest paid by the buyer to the seller, to beallowed to defer paying for the stock purchased until the nextfortnightly settlement day. [Eng.]
Large lumps picked out of the sieve, in dressing ore.
The secant of the complement of an arc or angle. See Illust. ofFunctions.
The imaginary milk-white animal on which Mohammed was said tohave been carried up to heaven; a white mule.
The movement which separates a limb or other part from theaxis, or middle line, of the body.
In the Corinthian capital, one of the eight stalks rising outof the lower leafage and terminating in leaves which seem to suportthe volutes. See Illust. of Corinthian order, under Corinthian.
The first of the four pieces composing the dorsal part, ortergum, of a thoracic segment of an insect. It is usually small andinconspicuous.
A whitish soluble powder used as a developer in photography.Chemically, it is the sulphate of methyl-p-amino-m-cresol.
Anhydrous sodium sulphate, a mineral of a white or brown colorand vitreous luster.
Toward the higher part of a stream; against the current.
To find fault with; to scold; to overwhelm with wordy abuse; tocensure severely or abusively; to rate.
Leaning forward; -- said of certain monosyllabic words whichare so closely attached to the following word as not to have aseparate accent.
The female of the bullfinch; -- called also tonyhoop. [Prov.Eng.]

One of the higher aromatic hydrocarbons of coal tar, allied tonapthalene and anthracene. It is a white crystalline substance,C18H12, of strong blue fluorescence, but generally colored yellow byimpurities.
Specifically, ill from menstruation; affected with, or having,catamenial; menstruant.
A deformity in which the urethra opens upon the top of thepenis, instead of at its extremity.
Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acidobtained by decomposition of melam, or of urea, as a whitecrystalline powder; -- called also melanurenic acid.
A blue coloring matter found in the pus from old sores,supposed to be formed through the agency of a species of bacterium(Bacillus pyocyaneus).C13H10N2O
A composition for infernal purposes; a magical preparation.Shak.
Above, or on the dorsal side of, the axis of the skeleton;episkeletal.
The person to whom property is mortgaged, or to whom a mortgageis made or given.
A yellow crystalline dyestuff, regarded as a glucoside,extracted from a species (Rhamnus Frangula) of the buckthorn; --called also rhamnoxanthin.
An agent of a corporation, or of any body of men engaged in abusiness enterprise; an advocate or patron; an assignee.

One who, or that which, hems with a needle. Specifically:(a) An attachment to a sewing machine, for turning under the edge ofa piece of fabric, preparatory to stitching it down.(b) A tool for turning over the edge of sheet metal to make a hem.
An iron club used in lofting the ball; -- called also loftingiron.
One of two Roman officers or magistrates united in the samepublic functions.
Earthenware; vessels formed of baked clay, especially thecoarser kinds.
Of or pertaining to King Arthur or his knights.  J. R. Symonds.
A volcanic area or vent which yields only sulphur vapors,steam, and the like. It represents the stages of the volcanicactivity.
A set or prescribed model; a formula. [Obs.] Johnson.
A special involucre formed of one leaf and inclosing a spadix,as in aroid plants and palms. See the Note under Bract, and Illust.of Spadix.
A kind of mixed dish, as of cooked vegetables with white sauce,sweet jelly with whole fruit, etc. Also, fig., a medley.
One who leases; the person who lets to farm, or gives a lease.Blackstone.
The person who binds himself, or gives his bond to another.Blackstone.
A bitter white crystalline glucoside extracted from the rootbark of the apple, pear, cherry, plum, etc. [Formerly also writtenphloridzin.]
A form of government by the multitude; a mobocracy. Hare.
A man whose employment is to drive, or to convey goods in, acar or car.
Introductory; prefatory; preliminary. [R.] Hammond.
A nutlet resembling a seed, or the kernel of a drupe. Gray.
To cheat by boasting and false pretenses; to gull. [R.] Shak.
Those who lived in former ages, as opposed to the moderns.
An instrument for measuring liquids. It consists of a pistonmoving in a tube in which is contained the liquid, the quantityexpelled being indicated by the graduation upon the piston rod.
Of or pertaining to Genoa, a city of Italy.-- n. sing. & pl.
Capable of being broken; brittle; fragile; easily broken.
A name given to several species of Sagina, low andinconspicuous herbs of the Chickweed family.
Of, pertaining to, resembling, or containing, a sulphate orsulphates.
Stylish; modish; elegant; showy; aristocratic; fashionable.[Slang]
A medicine supposed to promote the formation of callus.
A quality analogous to that of a viscous fluid, supposed to becaused by internal friction, especially in the case of gases.
The morbid deposition of black matter, often of a malignantcharacter, causing pigmented tumors.
(Arch.) A draped female figure supporting an entablature, inthe place of a column or pilaster.
Costing or worth three pence; hence, worth but little; poor;mean.
Having an odor of musk, or somewhat the like. Milton.
One who watches shoals of fish; a balker. See Balker.
To expel air, or obstructing or irritating matter, from thelungs or air passages, in a noisy and violent manner.
A fund for the support of a priest, without the title of abenefice. The patron in the collator.

An instrument made like large lute, but having two necks, withtwo sets of pegs, the lower set holding the strings governed byfrets, while to the upper set were attached the long bass stringsused as open notes.
Composed of several carpels consolidated into one ovary.
A title given to every one of sons of the kings of Spain andPortugal, except the eldest or heir apparent.
A genus of heart-shaped sea urchins belonging to theSpatangoidea.
Destitute of a tail, as the frogs and toads. [Also writtenanourous.]
Drooping of the upper eyelid, produced by paralysis of itslevator muscle.
An anthem or psalm sung before the Communion service.
The operation for the removal of squinting by the division ofsuch muscles as distort the eyeball.
A genus of exinct marine reptiles, allied to the Mosasaurus.See Illust. in Appendix.
Making erect or upright; raising; tending to erect.
To wound by clandestine detraction; to censure meanly orspitefully (as absent person); to slander or speak evil of (oneabsent). Spenser.
One of the minute bodies into which the chromatin of thenucleus is resolved during mitotic cell division; the idant ofWeismann.
To cheat; to deceive.She has bubbled him out of his youth. Addison.The great Locke, who was seldom outwitted by false sounds, wasnevertheless bubbled here. Sterne.
A kind of injector for forcing water by steam. See Injector,n., 2.
The quality of being paronymous; also, the use of paronymouswords.
The part a chimney appropriated to the fire; a hearth; --usually an open recess in a wall, in which a fire may be built.
One who redacts; one who prepares matter for publication; aneditor. Carlyle.
One who, or that which, enlivens, animates, or invigorates.
The parliament of Austria (exclusive of Hungary, which has itsown diet, or parliament). It consists of an Upper and a Lower House,or a House of Lords and a House of Representatives.
A extinct genus of Branchiopoda, very common in Silurianlimestones.
A slight hit or tip of the ball, often unintentional.
An exact copy of a writing, set forth in the words and figuresof it. It differs from purport, which is only the substance orgeneral import of the instrument. Bouvier.
An ornamental and diversified arrangement of beds or plots, inwhich flowers are cultivated, with intervening spaces of gravel orturf for walking on.
A bird fabled to exist single, to be consumed by fire by itsown act, and to rise again from its ashes. Hence, an emblem ofimmortality.
A truss, framed with a king-post; -- used in roofs, bridges,etc.
A vessel, vat, or cistern, in which things are steeped.
A Saxon; an Englishman; a Lowlander. [Celtic] Sir W. Scott.
One who prates much in his own favor, and makes unwarrantablepretensions; a quack; an impostor; an empiric; a mountebank.
A star of the first magnitude in the southern constellationArgo.
Originally, a melody of simpler form than the aria; a songwithout a second part and a da capo; -- a term now variously andvaguely used.
A perennial plant (Pyrethrum, or Chrysanthemum, Parthenium)allied to camomile, having finely divided leaves and white blossoms;-- so named from its supposed febrifugal qualities.
The intensity of a magnetic field expressed in C.G.S. units, orgausses.
A mineral having a glassy fracture, occurring in translucenttrapezohedral crystals. It is a silicate of alumina and potash. It isfound in the volcanic rocks of Italy, especially at Vesuvius.
A kind of nearly black cherry with dark red flesh and juice, --used chiefly for preserving.
A red consisting of silica, borax, and soda, fused with oxideof copper and iron, and used in enamels, mosaics, etc.
One who prohibits or forbids; a forbidder; an interdicter.

The theory that structural variations, characteristic ofspecies and genera, are produced in animals and plants by the directinfluence of physical environments, and esp., in the case of animals,by effort, or by use or disuse of certain organs.
Any one of several species of small, brilliantly coloredAmerican birds of the genus Rhamphomicron. They have a long, slender,sharp bill, and feed upon honey, insects, and the juice of the sugarcane.

In the Middle Ages, one of an order of men who subsisted by thearts of poetry and music, and sang verses to the accompaniment of aharp or other instrument; in modern times, a poet; a bard; a singerand harper; a musician. Chaucer.
A small marmoset (Midas rosalia); the silky tamarin.
Quality of being profluent; course. [R.] Sir H. Wotton.
A vessel for perfumes; esp. one in which incense is burned.
A lesser third, having its terms as 6 to 5; a hemiditone. [R.]
To loosen, unfix, or separate, as things mortised together.Tennyson.
Pertaining to, or resembling, the bracts of a calycle.
A defense for the shoulder, composed of flexible overlappingplates of metal, used in the 15th century; -- the origin of themodern epaulette. Fairholt.
A boiling spring which throws forth at frequent intervals jetsof water, mud, etc., driven up by the expansive power of steam.
Turned into, or reduced to, a village. [Obs.] W. Browne.
A kind of coarse, woolen cloth, usually ribbed, woven from woolof long staple.
Distinguishing mark; diagnostic. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
An apartment on the after end of the lower gun deck of a shipof war, usually occupied as a messroom by the commissioned officers,except the captain; -- called wardroom in the United States navy.
A quarter; esp., a quarter of a pound, or a quarter of ahundred. Piers Plowman.
To cause (a ship taken aback in a light breeze) so to turn ormake a circuit as to recover, without bracing the yards, the sametack on which she had been sailing.
An interior corner; a nook; hence, an angular recess or hollowbend in a mountain, river, cliff, or the like. [Western & Southern U.S.] D. S. Jordan.
A feather not fully developed; esp., a rudimentary feather justemerging through the skin.
The hypothetical radical characteristic of vanillic alcohol.
Of the nature of a polypus; having many feet or roots, like thepolypus; affected with polypus.
A short lyric tale set to music; a song or short instrumentalpiece in ballad style; a romanza.
In the proper position of an altar, that is, at the east of achurch with its ends towards the north and south. Shipley.
The faith, doctrines, or religious system of the Mohammedans;Mohammedanism; Islam.
Pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid obtained as adeliquescent white crystalline substance, and isomeric with itaconic,citraconic, and mesaconic acids.
Life and practice of brigands; highway robbery; plunder.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid, C3H3.CO2H, of theacetylene series, homologous with propiolic acid, obtained as a whitecrystalline substance.
A white crystalline substance having a sweet taste and ahyacinthlike odor, obtained by the decomposition of styracin; --properly called cinnamic, or styryl, alcohol.
A morbid degree of excitement or irritation in an organ.Hoblyn.
Prostitution or fornication on the part of a woman.
One who appoints, or executes a power of appointment. Kent.
Wine with a mixture of honey and species. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A band, plate, or loop of metal for clasping and holdingtimbers or parts of a machine. (b) (Naut.)
A form of Ambry, a closet; but confused with Almonry, as if aplace for alms.
To part, as an alliance; to sunder. [R.] "Disallied theirnuptials." Milton.
One who makes, inscribes, or engraves, alphabetical letters.
A white tablet on which anything was inscribed, as a list ofnames, etc.
The figures of two heads on a medal or coin, either side byside or joined.

A marine gadoid fish (Pollachius carbonarius), native both ofthe European and American coasts. It is allied to the cod, and likeit is salted and dried. In England it is called coalfish, lob,podley, podling, pollack, etc.
In a primeval manner; in or from the earliest times;originally. Darwin.
One who, or that which, fumigates; an apparattus forfumigating.
A member of The Institute of the Missionary Priests of St. Paulthe Apostle, founded in 1858 by the Rev. I. T. Hecker of New York.The majority of the members were formerly Protestants.
Not cyclic; not disposed in cycles or whorls; as: (a) (Bot.)

An extensive division of marine Annelida, including those thatare without oral tentacles or cirri, and have the gills, whenpresent, mostly arranged along the sides of the body. They generallylive in burrows or tubes.
A plant (Agathotes Chirayta) found in Northern India, havingmedicinal properties to the gentian, and esteemed as a tonic andfebrifuge.
One of a series of isonitroso derivatives obtained by theaction of hydroxylamine on aldehydes or ketones.
A pullet from which the ovaries have been removed to producefattening; hence, a fat pullet.
The pointless sword carried before English monarchs at theircoronation, and emblematically considered as the sword of mercy; --also called the sword of Edward the Confessor.
Fear of one's self; fear of being egotistical. [R.] Hare.
Dissection of a dead body, for the purpose of ascertaining thecause, seat, or nature of a disease; a post-mortem examination.
In the quaternion analysis, a quantity that has magnitude, butnot direction; -- distinguished from a vector, which has bothmagnitude and direction.
The canal by which the urine is conducted from the bladder anddischarged.
A thread or threadlike object or appendage; a fiber; esp.(Bot.), the threadlike part of the stamen supporting the anther.
The inner layer of the coating of a seed, usually thin anddelicate; the endopleura.
The larva of a moth (Heliothis armigera) which devours thebolls or unripe pods of the cotton plant, often doing great damage tothe crops.
A public nursery, where the young children of poor women arecared for during the day, while their mothers are at work.
The cold-blooded vertebrates, that is, all but the mammals andbirds; -- the antithesis to Hematotherma.
A very dangerous contagious disease in which the air passages,and especially the throat, become coated with a false membrane,produced by the solidification of an inflammatory exudation. Cf.Group.
A long-tailed, crested Javan monkey (Semnopithecus mitratus).The head, the crest, and the upper surface of the tail, are black.
A South American tinamou (Rhynchotus rufescens); -- called alsoperdiz grande, and rufous tinamou. See Illust. of Tinamou.
A mineral usually of a reddish brown color, and brilliantmetallic adamantine luster, occurring in tetragonal crystals. Incomposition it is titanium dioxide, like octahedrite and brooklite.
To save; to be parsimonious or niggardly. [Prov. Eng. & Colloq.U.S.]
A token, mark, or explanation. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
Breathing with difficulty and with a wheeze; wheezing. Usedalso figuratively.
Having a small or narrow mouth; -- said of certain small groundsnakes (Opoterodonta), which are unable to dilate their jaws.
An order of holothurians in which the internal respiratoryorgans are wanting; -- called also Apoda or Apodes.
A nervous disease in which the patient involuntarily imitatesthe words or action of another.
A minute thread of fiber, as one of the fibrous elements of amuscular fiber; a fibril.
Having the form of a crown or coronet; resembling a crown.
An order of holothurians mostly found in the deep sea. They areremarkable for their bilateral symmetry and curious forms. [Writtenalso Elasmopoda.]
A jellylike mass of free protoplasm, without any union ofamoeboid cells, and endowed with life and power of motion.
An American genus of sapotaceous trees bearing sweet and ediblefruits.
One who, or that which, endures or lasts; one who bears,suffers, or sustains.

Containing or expressing salutations; speaking a welcome;greeting; -- applied especially to the oration which introduces theexercises of the Commencements, or similar public exhibitions, inAmerican colleges.
One who truckles, or yields servilely to the will of another.
A tollbooth; also, a merchants' meeting place, or exchange.[Obs.] Halliwell.
Marked with a slur; performed in a smooth, gliding style, likenotes marked with a slur.
A weed of the genus Melampyrum, with black seeds, found onEuropean wheatfields.
The ethical theory which excludes all relations between virtueand happiness; the science of virtue; -- contrasted with eudemonics.J. Grote.
Inclined to, or engaged in, rumination or meditation.
A feast of the Romans in honor of Lupercus, or Pan.
A small hole, as the stop in a flute; a vent. Shak.
Unprovided with a diocese; having no diocese. Milton.
The substitution of one root vowel for another, thus indicatinga corresponding modification of use or meaning; vowel permutation;as, get, gat, got; sing, song; hang, hung. Earle.
To carry, as a firearm, with the breech near the ground and theupper part inclined forward, the piece being held by the right handnear the middle.
An uneasy, burning sensation in the stomach, often attendedwith an inclination to vomit. It is sometimes idiopathic, but isoften a symptom of often complaints.
Incision of the intestines, especially in reducing certaincases of hernia.

A succulent plant of the genus Sempervivum (S. tectorum),originally a native of subalpine Europe, but now found very generallyon old walls and roofs. It is very tenacious of life under droughtand heat; -- called also ayegreen.
The act or process of covering with laths; laths, collectively;a covering of laths.
To deprive of the tongue. [Obs.] Davies (Holy Roode).
A name sometimes applied to the process of annealing metals.
One's native land; the native land of one's fathers orancestors.
An herb of the Mint family (Sideritis), supposed to heal swordcuts; also, a species of Galeopsis.
Consisting in a heap; formed or being in a heap or hillock.Pinkerton.
The act of softening or relaxing; relaxation. Bacon.
A kind of large steelyard for weighing merchandise; -- alsocalled weighmaster's beam.
The popular designation of the hereditary sovereign of Japan.
One who forms or divides words into syllables, or is skilled indoing this.
A genus of plants comprehending the potato (S. tuberosum), theeggplant (S. melongena, and several hundred other species;nightshade.
A large building in which tobacco is stemmed. [U. S.] Bartlett.
One who, or that which, blends; an instrument, as a brush, usedin blending.
The native black race of Papua or New Guinea, and the adjacentislands.
A sum formerly levied to pay the expense of coinage; -- nowcalled seigniorage.
Resembling a ring; -- said esp. of the cartilage at the larynx,and the adjoining parts.
An exhibition of wax figures, or the place of exhibition.
A steward; a purveyor, particularly of a college or Inn ofCourt. Chaucer.
A licensed lighter employed in the transportation of goods toand from vessels. [China] S. W. Williams.
A Linnean genus of mollusks having a conical shell. See Cone,n., 4.
Rather quicker than andante; between that allegretto.
To insinuate; to offer indirectly. [Obs.] Sir E. Dering.

The tassels of twisted cords or threads on the corners of theupper garment worn by strict Jews. The Hebrew for this word istranslated in both the Authorized and Revised Versions (Deut. xxii.12) by the word "fringes."
The piping frog (Hyla Pickeringii), a small American tree frog,which in early spring, while breeding in swamps and ditches, singswith high, shrill, but musical, notes.
The all-containing soul. [R.]That unity, that oversout, within which every man's particular beingis contained and made one with all other. Emerson.
One who estimates or values; a valuer. Jer. Taylor.
To wind about; to encircle.In the circle of his arms Enwound us both. Tennyson.
The state or quality of being needy; want; poverty; indigence.
The chaffinch, whose cry is thought to foretell rain. [Prov.Eng.]
The quality or state of being musky; the scent of musk.
To prevent the transfer o Insulating stool (Elec.), a stoolwith legs of glass or some other nonconductor of electricity, usedfor insulating a person or any object placed upon it.
Of an even, composed frame of mind; of a steady temper; noteasily elated or depressed. Bp. Gauden.
A term applied derisively to any literary or artistic work, andesp. a painting, done simply for money and the means of living.[Cant]
A condition produced by the excessive or long-continued use ofquinine, and marked by deafness, roaring in the ears, vertigo, etc.
a mineral, consisting chiefly of the silicate of bismuth, foundat Freiberg; -- called also culytine.
The quality or state of being prudish; excessive or affectedscrupulousness in speech or conduct; stiffness; coyness. Cowper.
To deprive of temper, or of the proper degree of temper; tomake soft.
One taken at random rather than by selection; anybody.
A house where glass is made; a commercial house that deals inglassware.
To climb up; to ascend.Upclomb the shadowy pine above the woven copse. Tennyson.
To carry too far; to carry beyond the proper point. Hayward.
A morbid condition characterized by automatic and purposelessrepetition of words or imitation of actions.
The science of tongues or languages; comparative philology;glossology.
Forming, or separating into, scales or thin layers.
In a sprunt manner; smartly; vigorously; youthfully. [Obs.] B.Jonson.
To cast or throw out; to void, as excrement; to excrete, as theindigestible matter of the food; in an extended sense, to excrete bythe lungs, skin, or kidneys.
A tribe of spiders, comprising some of those which take theirprey in a web, but which also frequently run with agility, and chaseand seize their prey.
To free from a dam, mound, or other obstruction. Dryden.
Actuated or prompted by a devotion to money getting or theservice of Mammon. Carlyle.
To raise little bladders or blisters upon; to inflame andseparate the cuticle of; to blister. Wiseman.
A small fishing vessel met with in the Persian Gulf.
A degraded Papuan race, inhabiting Luzon and some of the othereast Indian Islands. They resemble negroes, but are smaller in size.They are mostly nomads.
To doubt. [R.]If he . . . were to loiter dubitating, and not come. Carlyle.
One who lives by shifts and tricks; one who avoids theperformance of duty or labor.
Sufficiency; plenty; abundance; contentment. [Obs.]He could in little thing have suffisaunce. Chaucer.
A disease in wheat, in which the blackened and contractedgrain, or ear, is filled with minute worms.
The humbling of a person by act or words, especially by aretort or a reproof; the retort or the reproof which has such effect.
A liquid, C3H7.C6H4.CHO, obtained from oil of caraway; --called also cuminic aldehyde.
A red coloring matter obtained from the safflower, or Carthamustinctorius.
A very large genus of composite plants including the groundseland the golden ragwort.
Pertaining to an annotator; containing annotations. [R.]
Embodied in bread, esp. in the bread of the eucharist. [Obs.]Cranmer.
Consisting of the pulverized or fragmentary material of rock,as conglomerate, shale, etc.
An East India herring (Clupea toli) which is extensively caughtfor the sake of its roe and for its flesh.
An onyx, part or all of whose layers consist of jasper.
A plain cap or headdress for women or girls; especially, onetying under the chin by a very broad band, generally of the samematerial as the cap itself. Thackeray.
The state or condition of being an albino; albinism.
To adorn by illuminating or ornamenting with colored anddecorated letters and figures, as a book or manuscript. [R.]Palsgrave.

An instrument which shows the direction of the wind; a windvane; a weathercock; -- usually applied to a contrivance consistingof a vane above, connected in the building with a dial or index withpointers to show the changes of the wind.
Decomposed rock, usually reddish or ferruginous (owing tooxidized pyrites), forming the upper part of a metallic vein.
Argumentation; ratiocination; discursive reasoning.
Gumminess; a viscous or adhesive quality or nature. [R.]Floyer.
One who, or that which, stupefies; a stupefying agent.
Property, landed or funded, so attached to a title of honor asto descend with it.

The art or act of determining the directions and heights of thelines of rampart with reference to the protection of the interiorfrom exposure to an enemy's fire from any point within range, or fromany works which may be erected. Farrow.
A basket for holding materials for needlework, or the like.
A glass water bottle for the table or toilet; -- called alsocroft.
It does not appear; it is not plain or clear; it does notfollow.
The practice of attracting the males of Lepidoptera or otherinsects by exposing the female confined in a cage.
Of or pertaining to a manubrium; shaped like a manubrium;handlelike.
That branch of the military art which embraces the details ofmoving and supplying armies. The meaning of the word is by somewriters extended to include strategy. H. L. Scott.
A division of Hydroidea in which the zooids are naked, or notinclosed in a capsule. See Tubularian.
A Hebrew weight for gold or silver, being one hundred shekelsof gold and sixty shekels of silver. Ezek. xlv. 12.
A brickred ferruginous clay used by the ancients for red paint.
The quality or state of being accustomed. [R.] Eikon Basilike.
A duck of the genus Fuligula. Two American species (F. marilaand F. affinis) are common. See Scaup duck.
Pertaining to a small Wormian bone sometimes present in thehuman skull between the parietal and the great wing of the sphenoid.-- n.
To take off a cloak from; to uncloak. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A child's game, in which a player, hopping on one foot, drivesa stone from one compartment to another of a figure traced orscotched on the ground; -- called also hoppers.
The division of cestode worms which comprises the tapeworms.See Tapeworm.
To cut through, as a partition between one working and another.
The covering of the outside wall of a frame house, whether madeof weatherboards, vertical boarding with cleats, shingles, or thelike.
To let the foot slip from a ball, when attempting to give atight croquet.

The richest kind of stuff used in garments in the Middle Ages,the web being gold, and the woof silk, with embroidery : -- madeoriginally at Bagdad. [Spelt also baudkin, baudkyn, bawdekin, andbaldakin.] Nares.
A small South African antelope (Neotragus melanotis). It isspeckled with gray and chestnut, above; the under parts are reddishfawn.

Of or pertaining to the lowest beds of the Silurian age,corresponding to the Acadian and Potsdam periods in American geology.It is called also Cambrian, and by many geologists is separated fromthe Silurian.
In a digested or well-arranged manner; methodically.

One who is receiving rudimentary instruction in the doctrinesof Christianity; a neophyte; in the primitive church, one officiallyrecognized as a Christian, and admitted to instruction preliminary toadmission to full membership in the church.

A rare metallic element, occurring in the minerals cerite,allanite, monazite, etc. Symbol Ce. Atomic weight 141.5. It resemblesiron in color and luster, but is soft, and both malleable andductile. It tarnishes readily in the air.
Somewhat slow or slowly, but not so slowly as largo, and rathermore so than andante.
A genus of herbs growing in wet places, and having whiteflowers; grass of Parnassus.
Of or pertaining to the fibula; in the region of the fibula.
A sandy calcareous straum, containing, or impregnated with,iron, and lying between the upper and lower Lias of England.
A vessel in which milk or cream is stirred, beaten, orotherwise agitated (as by a plunging or revolving dasher) in order toseparete the oily globules from the other parts, and obtain butter.
A genus of parasitic, trematode worms, having two suckers forattaching themselves to the part they infest. See 1st Fluke,
The act of selecting or detaching soldiers; a draft (see Draft,n., 2)(g) The act of drawing up, marking out, or delineating;representation. Dryden.
Pierced with small holes; worked in eyelets; scalloped on theedge. Shak.
An ointment or pomatum made of black poplar buds. [Obs.]Cotgrave.
The stone or plank forming a step before an outer door.
A shield or protective armor; -- applied in mythology to theshield of Jupiter which he gave to Minerva. Also fig.: A shield; aprotection.
To make or enact a law or laws.Solon, in legislating for the Athenians, had an idea of a moreperfect constitution than he gave them. Bp. Watson (1805).
A long, narrow boat, sharp at both ends, used by whalemen.
A raw, inexperienced person; one easily imposed upon. W.Irving.
To perform some manual act upon a human body in a methodicalmanner, and usually with instruments, with a view to restoresoundness or health, as in amputation, lithotomy, etc.
The power of moving, or being managed, at sea; -- said withreference to a ship. Sir T. North.

The act or process by which a body (whether solid, liquid, orgaseous) is absorbed into a liquid, and, remaining or becoming fluid,is diffused throughout the solvent; also, the product reulting fromsuch absorption.
To smother; to suffocate; to choke. [Obs.] Holinshed.Palsgrave.
A boy who operates the harness cords of a hand loom; also, apart of power loom that performs the same office.
A carnivorous marsupial quadruped of Australia, belonging tothe genus Dasyurus. There are several species.
The act or practice of playing games for stakes or wagers;gambling.
A kind of tobacco for smoking, made of the dried leaves,coarsely broken; -- so called from the rush baskets in which it ispacked in South America. McElrath.
One who, or that which, vulcanizes; esp., an apparatus forvulcanizing caoutchouc.
A blustering demonstration, or great effort; a great display.[Slang, U.S.] Bartlett.
The marking off or separation of anything. Hammond.
To set with diamonds; to adorn; to enrich. [R.]Diamondizing of your subject. B. Jonson.
Resembling vermin; in the manner of vermin. [Obs.] Gauden.
A taste which remains in the mouth after eating or drinking.
One who withdraws; one who takes back, or retracts.

A modern transliteration of the Hebrew word translated Jehovahin the Bible; -- used by some critics to discriminate the tribal godof the ancient Hebrews from the Christian Jehovah. Yahweh or Yahwe isthe spelling now generally adopted by scholars.
Exciting; producing irritation; irritating. [R.] Hales.
The special properties and functions of the nerves; thatcapacity for transmitting a stimulus which belongs to nerves. G. H.Lewes.
The state or quality of being free; freedom; liberty; openness;liberality; gratuitousness.
A contorted knot in wood; a crossgrained protuberance; anodule; a boss or projection.
A white, crystalline, aromatic hydrocarbon, C14H14, consistingof two radicals or residues of toluene.
A kind of hammer having a head formed of a group of pointedsteel bars, used for dressing ashlar, etc. -- v. t.
A flesh-eating animal, especially any one of the carnivorousmarsupials.
A flourish made with the pen at the end of a signature. In theMiddle Ages, this formed a sort of rude safeguard against forgery.Brande & C.
A rock occurring in the Alps, consisting of saussurite andsmaragdite; -- sometimes called gabbro.
A genus of trilobites found in the Lower Silurian formation.See Illust. in Append.
A small European bat (Vesperugo pipistrellus); -- called alsoflittermouse.
To treat with cruel playfulness, as a cat treats a mouse; toabuse. [Obs.] Birch.
Burning; ardent. [R.]Lo! further on, Where flames the arduous Spirit of Isidore. Cary.
One of the internal thoracic processes of the sternum of aninsect.
A passage or way along or through which a carriage may bedriven.
The district in which a thane anciently had jurisdiction;thanedom.
Any plant of the genus Chara; -- so called because they areoften incrusted with carbonate of lime. See Chara.
To draw a mark or line under; to underline. J. Tucker.
A kind of ball-shaped fungus (Lycoperdon giganteum, and otherspecies of the same genus) full of dustlike spores when ripe; --called also bullfist, bullfice, puckfist, puff, and puffin.
A hemispherical or rounded head to a rivet or bolt; also, aswaging tool with a cavity in its face for forming such a roundedhead.
The person to whom a thing is vended, or sold; -- thecorrelative of vendor.

Pertaining to, or derived from, gums and micilaginoussubstances; specif., denoting an acid obtained by the oxidation ofgums, dulcite, etc., as a white crystalline substance isomeric withsaccharic acid.
Any plant growing on dacayed animal or vegetable matter, asmost fungi and some flowering plants with no green color, as theIndian pipe.
The song or shout of praise, of battle, or of triumph. [R.]
The act of depositing; deposition. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.

A mineral, composed of silica, magnesia, and iron, of a yellowto green color. It is common in certain volcanic rocks; -- calledalso olivine and peridot. Sometimes used as a gem. The name was alsoearly used for yellow varieties of tourmaline and topaz.
The quality of being alert or on the alert; briskness;nimbleness; activity.
Interrupted by unproductive spots; -- said of a flied ofturnips or grain. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
Capable of radiating; acting by radiation. Tyndall.
A drain trench, in a ditch or moat; -- called also cuvette.
An examination of catechumens, in the last week of Lent, whowere to receive baptism on Easter Day.
A pickle of various vegetables with pungent species, --originally made in the East Indies.
pertaining to, or derived from, rubian; specifically,designating an acid called also ruberythrinic acid. [Obs.]
A tough old goose; hence, coarse, bad food of any kind. [Prov.Eng.] Halliwell.
A colorless liquid prepared from herring brine and containingamines, used as a local antiseptic.
A fruit consisting in large part of a receptacle, enlargedbelow the calyx, as in the alycanthus, the rose hip, and the pear.
A yellow oil having a geraniumlike odor, produced as a sideproduct in making phorone; -- called also xylite oil.
A kind of bandage passing, by successive turns and crosses,from an extremity to the trunk; -- so called from its resemblance toa spike of a barley.
To lean; to recline; to repose. [Obs.] J. Allen (1761).
Inflammation of the lining membrane of the middle ear.
An argument, or apparent argument, which professes to bedecisive of the matter at issue, while in reality it is not; asophism.
A species of Vaccinium (V. Vitis-id), which bears acid redberries which are sometimes used in cookery; -- locally calledmountain cranberry.
The larva of certain starfishes as developed in the free-swimming stage.
Of or pertaining to tantalum; derived from, or containing,tantalum; specifically, designating any one of a series of acidsanalogous to nitric acid and the polyacid compounds of phosphorus.
A game at cards in which various combinations of cards in thehand, when declared, score points.
The science or art of hurling missile weapons by the use of anengine. Whewell.

The long, branching filaments of which the mycelium (and thegreater part of the plant) of a fungus is formed. They are also foundenveloping the gonidia of lichens, making up a large part of theirstructure.
The tenth month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year, answering toa part of December with a part of January. Esther ii. 16.
An optical instrument consisting of two lenses set in a lightframe, and worn to assist sight, to obviate some defect in the organsof vision, or to shield the eyes from bright light.
In a frigid manner; coldly; dully; without affection.
To become squeamish; to feel nausea; to turn away with disgust.
A betting man who "makes a book." See To make a book, underBook, n.
A denial, disavowal, or renunciation, as of a title, claim,interest, estate, or trust; relinquishment or waiver of an interestor estate. Burrill.
Of or characterized by antiquity or archaism; antiquated;obsolescent.
To dress; to prink; -used humorously or in contempt. Dryden.
To revile or abuse in scurrilous language. Southey.
A mineral of a transparent vitreous brown color, found in theejected masses of Vesuvius. It is a silicate of iron and magnesia,containing fluorine.
An instrument used for measuring the expansion of solid bodiesby heat.
A license to print or publish a book, paper, etc.; also, incountries subjected to the censorship of the press, approval of thatwhich is published.
Situated under, or at the bases of, the lobules of the liver.
The formation of frit or slag by heat with but incipientfusion.
Gathered or formed into a ball or round mass. [Obs.] Blount.
The quality or state of being shaggy; roughness; shaggedness.
A shrub (Viburnum dentatum) growing in damp woods and thickets;-- so called from the long, straight, slender shoots.
One of the prominent embedded crystals of a porphyry.
To put in the place of another; to substitute. [R.] Dr. H.More.
The state, conditions, or quality of being brassy. [Colloq.]
A fixed star, in Medusa's head, in the constellation Perseus,remarkable for its periodic variation in brightness.
To pay; to satisfy or appease. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
To retire again to a couch; to lie down again. [Obs.] Sir H.Wotton.
Not daunted; not subdued or depressed by fear. Shak.
The last or posterior segment of the thorax in insects. SeeIllust. of Coleoptera.
Dowry brought by a bride to her husband. [Scot.] Burns.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid which occurs in opium,and which may be obtained by oxidizing narcotine.
A kind of hard-twisted or braided cord, sometimes used formaking whiplashes.
The Brazilian porcupine (Cercolades, or Sphingurus,prehensiles), remarkable for its prehensile tail.
Any bird of certain genera, as Urinator (formerly Colymbus), orthe allied genus Colymbus, or Podiceps, remarkable for their agilityin diving.
A west Indian climbing shrub (Combretum Jacquini) with slenderreddish branchlets.
Literally, a fly swallower; hence, once who keeps his mouthopen; a boor; a silly and credulous person.
One who invents or finds out something new; a contriver;especially, one who invents mechanical devices.
One of the quinine group of alkaloids isomeric with andresembling cinchonidine; -- called also cinchonia.
One to whom a devise is made, or real estate given by will.
Pertaining to expansions of the nasal bone or cartilage.
State of being deceived; hallucination. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A segment next above the ceratohyal in the hyoidean arch.
A light horseman. See 2d Hobbler. [Obs.] Brande & C.
To inhere or exist together, as in one substance. Sir W.Hamilton.
To punish or beat severely; to whip smartly; to flog; tocastigate. [Colloq.]
Depurating; tending to depurate or cleanse; depurative.
An injection, or clyster, thrown into the rectum as a medicine,or to impart nourishment. Hoblyn.
One who, not being interested, maintains a cause dependingbetween others, by furnishing money, etc., to either party. Bouvier.Wharton.
The unicameral national assembly of Bulgaria, elected for aterm of five years by universal suffrage of adult males.
Applied to a line which is the sum of two lines commensurableonly in power (as the side and diagonal of a square).
Affected with shortness of breath; relating to dyspn
The albumen of a seed; -- limited by recent writers to thatformed within the embryo sac.
The state of oscillating; a seesaw kind of motion. [R.]
A little bud or knob at the top of a deer's antler.
The common herring, esp. when of large size, smoked, and halfdried; -- called also bloat herring.
A borosilicate of alumina, iron, and lime, commonly found inglassy, brown crystals with acute edges.
A body of foot soldiers and cavalry consisting of differentnumbers at different periods, -- from about four thousand to aboutsix thousand men, -- the cavalry being about one tenth.
The contend in words; to dispute with zeal, heat, or anger; towrangle.
A three-wheeled velocipede. See Illust. under Velocipede. Cf.Bicycle.
A thin, laminated variety of serpentine, usually of a palegreen color.
A man employed in placing supports of timber in a mine. Weale.
A member of one of the ten sections into which the Atheniansenate of five hundred was divided, and to each of which belonged thepresidency of the senate for about one tenth of the year.
Privation of sense or consciousness, due to a narcotic.
The fieldfare; -- so called from its harsh cry before rain.[Prov. Eng.]
Indemnification for injury; satisfaction. [Chiefly in Scotslaw]
Painting executed in size or distemper, on canvas or walls, --formerly, frequently taking the place of tapestry. Shak. Fairholt.
To deny the right of the plaintiff in regard to (the suit, orthe wrong charged); to oppose or resist, as a claim at law; tocontest, as a suit. Burrill.
A vault or crypt in connection with a church, used as arepository for human bones disintered from their original burialplaces; a charnel house.
The act of enlacing, or state of being enlaced; a surroundingas with a lace.

One who contracts; one of the parties to a bargain; one whocovenants to do anything for another; specifically, one who contractsto perform work on a rather large scale, at a certain price or rate,as in building houses or making a railroad.
A copy of a work of art, as of a picture or satue, made by themaker of the original.
Containing or producing pap; like pap. [R.] Arbuthnot.
A driving wind; a wind that drives snow, sand, etc., intoheaps. Beau. & Fl.
Pertaining, or belonging, to the episperm, or covering of aseed.
Of or pertaining to the island Scio (Chio or Chios).-- n.
Growing or covering over; -- said of a kind of invagination.See under Invagination.
A band for the breast. Specifically: (Naut.) A band of canvas,or a rope, fastened at both ends to the rigging, to support the manwho heaves the lead in sounding.
Similarly in arrangement of parts; -- the opposite ofheterotaxy.
Bearing or bringing forth a god; -- said of the Virgin Mary.[Obs.] Bailey.
An animal, invisible, or nearly so, to the naked eye. SeeInfusoria.
A bandage or apparatus used in cases of hernia, to keep up thereduced parts and hinder further protrusion, and for other purposes.
A cap of cells which covers the growing extremity of a root; arootcap.
The circuit or extent of a bishop's jurisdiction; the districtin which a bishop exercises his ecclesiastical authority.[Frequently, but improperly, spelt diocess.]
One who is guilty of perjury; one who perjures or forswears, inany sense.
In the organ, a light strip of wood connecting (in path) a keyand a pallet, to communicate motion by pulling.
A division of Trematoda in which alternate generations occur,the immediate young not resembling their parents.
Capable of being cut or divided by a sharp instrument. [R.]con.
Having feet resembling hands, or with the first toe opposable,as the opossums and monkeys.
A European wild pigeon (Columba palumbus) having a whitecrescent on each side of the neck, whence the name. Called also woodpigeon, and cushat.
One of the outer pinions or feathers of the wing of a bird,esp. of a hawk.
A metallic element of the rare-earth group, discoveredspectroscopically by Demarcay in 1896. Symbol, Eu; at. wt., 152.0.
The projecting part of a Classic cornice, the under side ofwhich is cut with a recess or channel so as to form a drip. SeeIllust. of Column.
A tough, lustrous, reddish white metal of the iron group, noteasily fusible, and somewhat magnetic. Atomic weight 59.1. Symbol Co.
An instrument for augmenting a very small quantity ofelectricity, so as to render it manifest by sparks or theelectroscope.
A hydrocarbon radical, C10H21, never existing alone, butregarded as the characteristic constituent of a number of compoundsof the paraffin series.
A dry slough, crust, or scab, which separates from the healthypart of the body, as that produced by a burn, or the application ofcaustics.
One of several northern sea birds, allied to the auks. Theyhave short legs, placed far back, and are expert divers and swimmers.
A written or printed scroll or sheet of paper; a document;especially, a formal list or inventory; a list or catalogue annexedto a larger document, as to a will, a lease, a statute, etc.
A Syrian idiom, or a peculiarity of the Syrian language; aSyriacism. Paley.
A gummy or mucilaginous tasteless substance obtained from themarigold or calendula, and analogous to bassorin.
A genus of transparent, tubular, free-swimming oceanictunicates found abundantly in all the warmer latitudes. SeeIllustration in Appendix.
A chest of drawers not more than four feet high; -- appliedcommonly to the lower half of a tallboy from which the upper half hasbeen removed. [U. S.]
One who is elected, or claims to be, pope in opposition to thepope canonically chosen; esp. applied to those popes who resided atAvignon during the Great Schism.
Established or accepted religious rites or usages of worship;state of religious development. Cf.Cult, 2.
A bombproof chamber, usually of masonry, in which cannon may beplaced, to be fired through embrasures; or one capable of being usedas a magazine, or for quartering troops.
An indulgence of forty days, corresponding to the forty days ofancient canonical penance.
To practice polygamy; to marry several wives. Sylvester.Coleridge.
A tribe of bivalve mollusks, characterized by the closed stateof the mantle which envelops the body. The ship borer (Teredonavalis) is an example.
A long seat with a back, -- made to accommodate several personsat once.
A musical instrument formerly in use, consisting of severalsticks bound together, but separated by beads, and played with astick with a ball at its end. Moore (Encyc. of Music. ).
The little stalk that attaches a seed to the placenta.
To take another turn with, as a cable around a windlass.Totten.
To make rattle; to scold vociferously; to cry down. [Obs.]Shak.
To divest of a branch or branches; to tear off. Shak.
A kind of short chemisette, worn with a low-necked dress.
Rising and falling in waves toward the margin, as a leaf;waved.
The art of occupation of laying out and cultivating gardens;horticulture.
An oxide of barium (or barytum); a heavy earth with a specificgravity above 4.
A fellow rival; a competitor; a rival; also, a companion. [R.]Shak.
A dark blue dyestuff, of the induline group; -- called alsoazodiphenyl blue.
The planking outside of a vessel, above the sheer strake.Smyth.
The edible viscera of animals, as the heart, liver, etc.
Crushing sorrow or grief; a yielding to such grief. Shak.
To range or place in a line; to bring into line; to align.Evelyn.
A thin muscle which serves to draw up the testicle.
Consisting of copper or resembling copper; coppery.
A brown amorphous substance resembling humin, and obtained fromindican.
One of the tribe of Judah; a member of the kingdom of Judah; aJew. Kitto.
The top of the head; the head or noll. [Obs.] Spenser.
A Spartan institution which prohibited strangers from residingin Sparta without permission, its object probably being to preservethe national simplicity of manners.
A cuban trogon (Priotelus temnurus) having a serrated bill anda tail concave at the end.
A long gown or surcoat (cut off in front), worn in the MiddleAges. It was sometimes embroidered or interwoven with gold. Also, arich stuff from which the gown was made.
One of a body of nominal Christians, who speak the Arabiclanguage, and reside on Mount Lebanon and in different parts ofSyria. They take their name from one Maron of the 6th century.
The present or the coming night; the night after the presentday.
To be incapable of combining; to disagree; to differ. [Obs.]Milton.
That state in which every part of space is supposed to be fullof matter; -- opposed to vacuum. G. Francis.
An instrument which, placed against the teeth, conveys sound tothe auditory nerve and enables the deaf to hear more or lessdistinctly; a dentiphone.
One who has the power of choosing; an elector. [R.]
Properly, printed calico, whether Oriental or of fancifuldesign with flowers, etc., in Western work. Hence, as extended inEnglish, material of a similar character.
Pertaining to, or produced by, fermentation; -- formerly, byconfusion, used to designate lactic acid.
The act of anticipating another's wishes, desires, etc., in theway of favor or courtesy; hence, civility; obligingness. [Obs.]Sterne.
Leaning or resting; -- said of anthers when lying on the innerside of the filament, or of cotyledons when the radicle lies againstthe back of one of them. Gray.
A singer, or vocal musician, as opposed to an instrumentalist.
A class of air-breathing Arthropoda; -- called alsoProtracheata, and Onychophora.
A kind of small turnip, a variety of Brassica campestris. SeeBrassica. [Writen also naphew.]
A support for the spear when couched for the attack. [Obs.]Chaucer.
Capable of being avowed, or openly acknowledged, withconfidence. Donne.
Capable of worthy of being tasted; savory; relishing.
The art of predicting events after the manner of the priestessof Apollo at Delphi; equivocal prophesying.
A peculiar toothlike fossil of many forms, found especially incarboniferous rocks. Such fossils are supposed by some to be theteeth of marsipobranch fishes, but they are probably the jaws ofannelids.
An artificial hillock, especially one raised over a grave,particularly over the graves of persons buried in ancient times; abarrow.
An imaginary line, or a line on a chart, marking thesimultaneous development of a thunderstorm, as noted by observing thetime when the thunder is heard at different places.
A name given to a number of metallic minerals, sulphides ofiron, copper, cobalt, nickel, and tin, of a white or yellowish color.
Capable of being discharged by spitting. [Obs.] Swift.
To start back; to recoil; to recede from a purpose. J. Ellis.
Self-importance; loftiness of carriage. [Cant, Eng.Universities]
Bad speaking; bad choice or use of words. Buchanan.
A short piece of timber, iron, or stone, placed in a wall undera girder or other beam, to distribute the weight or pressure.
Of or pertaining to an agent or an agency. Fitzed. Hall.
To rain in very fine drops, like a thick mist; to mizzle.
To become separated, broken up, dissolved, or scattered;especially, to quit military service by breaking up organization.
A platform of a staircase where the stair turns back in exactlythe reverse direction of the lower flight. See Quarterpace.
Havingthree principal operative parts or motions, so as toproduce a three-fold effect.
Polite and attentive to ladies; courteous to women; chivalrous.
An atheist or unbeliever; -- name given in the East to thosecharged with disbelief of any revealed religion, or accused ofmagical heresies.
A vapid or meaningless remark; a commonplace; nonsense.
The act of adjudging; judicial decision; adjudication. Sir W.Temple.
To exceed in reckoning or computation. Bp. Pearson.
To throw or cast, as a dart; to throw out; to emit.
The doctrine of royal prerogative or supremacy. [R.] CardinalManning.
A dry fruit which splits at maturity into several closed one-seeded portions.
One of the dominant people of Hungary, allied to the Finns; aHungarian.
An instrument of the ancients for finding two meanproportionals between two given lines, required in solving theproblem of the duplication of the cube. Brande & C.
An action or engagement not of sufficient magnitude to becalled a battle.
The religion of Mohammed; also, idolatry. See Mawmet. [Obs.]Chaucer.

Persons added to a jury, commonly from those in or about thecourthouse, to make up any deficiency in the number of jurorsregularly summoned, being like, or such as, the latter. Blount.Blackstone. (b) syntactically sing.
A mullet (Mugil capito) found in the rivers of Southern Europeand in Africa.
An extinct eocene bird from New Mexico, larger than theostrich.
A small furnace or iron cage to hold fire for charring theinside of a cask, and making the staves flexible. Knight.
Window blinds having movable slats, similar to Venetian blinds.
In France, a second ballot taken after an indecisive firstballot to decide between two or several candidates.
A kind of coarse bagging, -- used for coal sacks. Weale.
An apple-green mineral having a greasy feel. It is a hydroussilicate of nickel, magnesia, aluminia, and iron.
The planking from the waterways up to the port sills. Totten.
A witness by means of his ears; one who is within hearing anddoes hear; a hearer. Fuller.
A blank book in which extracts cut from books and papers may bepasted and kept.
An instrument with a revolving wheel for measuring a curvedline, as on a map.
Inclined to revolve things in the mind; meditative. [Obs.]Feltham.
Full of dirty water; wet and muddy, so as be easily splashedabout; slushy.

A small insectivore (Centetes ecaudatus), native of Madagascar,but introduced also into the islands of Bourbon and Mauritius; --called also tanrec. The name is applied to other allied genera. SeeTendrac.
The province or seigniory of a palatine; the dignity of apalatine. Howell.
Having an involucre, as umbels, heads, etc. Martyn.
A traveler; -- applied in Canada to a man employed by the furcompanies in transporting goods by the rivers and across the land, toand from the remote stations in the Northwest.
The quality or state of being thick (in any of the senses ofthe adjective).
An ancient stringed instrument used by the Greeks, theparticular construction of which is unknown.
A salt formed by the union of croconic acid with a base.
A fruit tree (D. zibethinus, the only species known) of theIndian Archipelago. It bears the durian.
A kiln or furnace in which limestone or shells are burned andreduced to lime.
A plant (Zostera marina), with very long and narrow leaves,growing abundantly in shallow bays along the North Atlantic coast.
That which generates; the point, or the mathematical magnitude,which, by its motion, generates another magnitude, as a line,surface, or solid; -- called also describent.
A hydrous phosphate of alumina, occurring usually inhemispherical radiated forms varying in color from white to yellow,green, or black.
To make moral reflections; to regard acts and events asinvolving a moral.
The quality or state of being tangent; a contact or touching.
The quality or state of being tepid; moderate warmth;lukewarmness; tepidness. Jer. Taylor.
A plundering and destructive incursion; a foray; a rai
Suited for, or capable of, extension; extensible. Owen.
A disease occurring in Bengal and other parts of the EastIndies, in which the tongue chaps and cleaves.
One of the principal names by which God is designated in theHebrew Scriptures.
Capable of being offered; suitable or worthy to be offered.
To aid secretly; to assist in a private manner, or indirectly.[R.] Daniel.
One of the half ribs against the walls in a ceiling vaultedwith ribs.
To intertwine; to weave or bind together. [Obs.] B. Jonson.

Any flat, thin piece of metal, clay, ivory, or the like, usedfor ornament, or for painting pictures upon, as a slab, plate, dish,or the like, hung upon a wall; also, a smaller decoration worn on theperson, as a brooch.
A kiln, or furnace, in which bricks are baked or burnt; or apile of green bricks, laid loose, with arches underneath to receivethe wood or fuel for burning them.
A valley or low place; a tract of low, and usually wet, land; amoor; a fen. [Prov. Eng. & Local, U.S.]
One whose thoughts take the form of mental sounds or ofinternal discourse rather than of visual or motor images.
Resembling man; -- applied especially to certain apes, as theourang or gorilla.-- n.
A constellation of the zodiac, containing the two bright starsCastor and Pollux; also, the third sign of the zodiac, which the sunenters about May 20th.
Palmately branched, with the branches again palmated.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an anhydride, C4H4O5, oftartaric acid, obtained as a white crystalline deliquescentsubstance.
A headdress, or manner of dressing the hair. Addison.
Deprived of quiet; impatient; restless; uneasy. [R.] Shak.
Capable of being washed without damage to fabric or color.
Triple; treble; threefold. [Prov. Eng. or Colloq.] Halliwell.
The quality or state of being lithe; flexibility; limberness.
A hardened steel plate having a hole, or a gradation of conicalholes, through which wires are drawn to be reduced and elongated.
In some provinces of Russia, one who farms the rents orrevenues.
The art and science of predicting in medicine. Laycock.
A circular temple consisting of a roof supported on columns,without a cella.
A French coin, the tenth part of a franc, equal to about twocents.
Yellow; specifically (Ethnol.), of or pertaining to those racesof man which have yellowish, red, auburn, or brown hair.
Capable of being medicated; admitting of being cured or healed.
Without fever; -- applied to days when there is an intermissionof fever. Dunglison.
An elision or retrenchment of one or more letters or syllablesfrom the middle of a word; as, ne'er for never, ev'ry for every.
A mineral occurring in emerald-green tabular crystals having amicaceous structure. It is a hydrous phosphate of uranium and copper.Called also copper uranite, and chalcolite.
The amount or degree of energy with which a force operates or acause acts; effectiveness, as estimated by results produced.
Covered, or bound round, with a kercher. [Obs.] G. Fletcher.
The European red gurnard (Trigla cuculus). [Prov. Eng.]
Scolding; clamorous or abusive talk. [Slang] H. Kingsley.
A technicist; esp., one skilled particularly in the technicaldetails of his work.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid of the acrylicseries, obtained by the distillation of terpenylic acid, as an onlysubstance having a peculiar cheesy odor.
A beat of the drum or sound of the bugle as a signal to troopsto assemble.
An apartment or closet in which bread and other provisions arekept.
The act of removing, or the state of being removed.
Anciently, a snake, called dart snake; now, one of a genus ofreptiles closely allied to the lizards.
That part of the pistil which contains the seed, and in mostflowering plants develops into the fruit. See Illust. of Flower.
A bone or cartilage, of some animals, situated in the middleline in front of the pubic bones.
Pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid metameric withmalic acid.
The act of killing the fetus in the womb; the offense ofprocuring an abortion.

A nitrogenous substance, somewhat resembling albumin, whichforms the chemical basis of elastic tissue. It is very insoluble inmost fluids, but is gradually dissolved when digested with eitherpepsin or trypsin.
Having two wings only; belonging to the order Diptera.
A genus of marine gastropods having a long, tapering spire.They belong to the Toxoglossa. Called also auger shell.
A genus of simple, stony corals; -- so called because they areusually flat and circular, with radiating plates, like the gills of amushroom. Some of them are eighteen inches in diameter.
The opinion or doctrine that the Father, Son, and Holy Spiritare three distinct Gods.
A morbid condition in which the blood is deficient in qualityor in quantity.
As much as is taken up between the thumb and two first fingers.[Obs.] Bacon.
A woman who performs any work; especially, a woman skilled inneedlework.
Any fish of the genus Fistularia; -- called also tobaccopipefish. See Fistularia.
A sacred government; by holy orders of men. Southey.
An American parrakeet of the genus Conurus. Many species areknown. See Parrakeet.
A deciduous plant; -- opposed to Ant: evergreen. J. Barton.
A mounted peddler of fish; -- called also jouster. [Obs.]Carew.
In a heating manner; so as to make or become hot or heated.
Capable of exceeding or surpassing. [Obs.] Sherwood.
One who negotiates; a person who treats with others, either asprincipal or agent, in respect to purchase and sale, or publiccompacts.

A Species of duck (Aythya vallisneria), esteemed for thedelicacy of its flesh. It visits the United States in autumn;particularly Chesapeake Bay and adjoining waters; -- so named fromthe markings of the plumage on its back.
A kind of boat used in Canton. It is about 25 feet long and isoften rowed by women. Called also tankia. S. W. Williams.
A double ear trumpet for estimating the direction from whichsounds proceed, esp. for the use of navigators.
The laying bare of rocks by the washing away of the overlyingearth, etc.; or the excavation and removal of them by the action ofrunning water.
Like a lizard; of or pertaining to the Lacertilia.-- n.
A white crystalline substance obtained from castoreum.
A genus of climbing plants with very showy lilylike blossoms,natives of India.
Vocal music colored, as it were, by florid ornaments, runs, orrapid passages.
A small poisonous snake of North America (Elaps fulvius),banded with yellow, red, and black.
The snaffle and rein of a military bridle, which actsindependently of the bit, at the pleasure of the rider. It is used inconnection with a curb bit, which has its own rein. Campbell.
The quality or state of being rich (in any sense of theadjective).
An eruption upon the skin, consisting of vesicles with inflamedbase and filled with serous, purulent, or bloody fluid, which driesup, forming a blackish crust.
A consort, husband or wife; a companion; a fere. [Obs.]
A complex nitrogenous hydrocarbon obtained artificially (as bythe action of cyanogen chloride on aniline) as a white, crystallinesubstance; -- called also diphenyl guanidin.
The product of a second sifting of meal; the finest part of thebran. [Prov. Eng.]
; sing. Iowa. (Ethnol.) A tribe of Indians which formerlyoccupied the region now included in the State of Iowa.
To gain the superiority; to be victorious. Rev. iii. 21.
A carnivorous animal (Canis latrans), allied to the dog, foundin the western part of North America; -- called also prairie wolf.Its voice is a snapping bark, followed by a prolonged, shrill howl.
A half turn which a horseman makes, either to the right or theleft.
A zeolitic mineral occuring in delicate radiating groups ofwhite crystals. It is a hydrous silicate of aluminia and lime. Calledalso lime mesotype.
By inference; as an illative; in an illative manner.
A soluble, nitrogenous ferment, capable of converting starchand dextrin into sugar.
A note of half the length of the quaver; a semiquaver. [R.]

A celestial body which revolves about the sun in an orbit of amoderate degree of eccentricity. It is distinguished from a comet bythe absence of a coma, and by having a less eccentric orbit. SeeSolar system.
A road; especially, the part traveled by carriages. Shak.
A Chaldean astronomical period or cycle, the length of whichhas been variously estimated from 3,600 years to 3,600 days, or alittle short of 10 years. Brande & C.
A person who does not think, or does not think wisely.
Of, pertaining to, or fit for, pabulum or food; affording food.
One who recites; also, a book of extracts for recitation.
An instrument for recording the height of the liquid in anendosmometer or for registering osmotic pressures.
A bearing worn, not upon the shield, but usually above it, orseparately as an ornament for plate, liveries, and the like. It is arelic of the ancient cognizance. See Cognizance, 4.
A poisonous alkaloid of bitter taste extracted from the leavesand seeds of the European yew (Taxus baccata). Called alsotaxia.C35H47NO10
Capable of being formed or shaped by a hammer. Sherwood.
A professional mourner who wails at a funeral. [Ireland]
A body of Hindoo literature containing aphorisms on grammar,meter, law, and philosophy, and forming a connecting link between theVedic and later Sanscrit literature. Balfour (Cyc. of India).
Of or pertaining to Friesland, a province of the Netherlands;Friesic.
A kind of stout woolen cloth with unfinished face and withoutraised nap. A commoner variety has a cotton warp.
Not capable of making a will; not legally qualified orcompetent to make a testament. Blackstone.
A burn, or injury to the skin or flesh, by some hot liquid, orby steam.
Any one of a group of bombycid moths of which the genus Zeuzerais the type. Some of these moths are of large size. The goat moth isan example.
The wintergreern. (Gaultheria procumbens). [Local, U.S.]
The act of fleshing, or the excitement attending a successfulbeginning. [R.] Shak.
Lifeless matter deposited in the form of minute granules withinthe protoplasm of living cells.
Meeting and intersecting, as lines; not parallel; -- opposed toparallel. [Obs.] Ash.
A coach that runs regularly from one stage, station, or placeto another, for the conveyance of passengers.
A white crystalline waxy substance extracted from the root ofthe leguminous plant Ononis spinosa.
The buttock or tight of a hog, salted and smoked or dried; thelower end of a flitch. Goldsmith.
To enter or insert wrongly, as a charge in an account.
An ichneumon (Herpestes galera) native of Southern Africa andMadagascar. It is reddish brown or dark brown, grizzled with white.Called also vondsira, and marsh ichneumon.
Lying or being at a distance from the central part, or the mainbody; being on, or beyond, the frontier; exterior; remote; detached.
On the hither side of the Alps with reference to Rome, that is,on the south side of the Alps; -- opposed to transalpine.
A duty of two shillings on every tun of wine imported intoEngland by merchant strangers; -- so called because paid to theking's butler for the king. Blackstone.
A freeman of the lowest class; one not a thane or of theservile classes; a churl.
One of the fruit dots, or small clusters of sporangia, on theback of the fronds of ferns.
To remove the shot from, as from a shotted gun; to unload.
A salt of the class formed by the combination of an acid and abase, or by the union of two oxides, two sulphides, selenides, ortellurides, as distinguished from a haloid compound. [R.] Berzelius.
One of a class of robbers, in India, who act in gangs.
Violence of a disease, which brings it speedily to a crisis.
The embryological history of groups or families of individuals.
Something used for taking hold or holding; a catch; a loop; abutton. [Obs.] Ex. xxvi. 6.
In a dying manner; as if at the point of death. Beau. & Fl.
The property of remaining invariable under prescribed orimplied conditions. J. J. Sylvester.
Surface decoration of any sort which consists of the constantrepetition of one or more simple figures or units of design evenlyspaced.
A proposition affirming the possibility of finding suchconditions as will render a certain determinate problem indeterminateor capable of innumerable solutions. Playfair.
In ancient architecture, an inclosed court, esp., onesurrounding a temple.
An instrument designed for transmitting pictures by telegraph.Fallows.
The name of several kinds of grass having a soft dense head offlowers, mostly the species of Alopecurus and Setaria.
A systematic view of all branches of human knowledge; a work ofuniversal information.
A Roman silver coin of the value of about fourteen cents; the"penny" of the New Testament; -- so called from being worthoriginally ten of the pieces called as.
The time from dusk to dawn; -- opposed to Ant: daytime.
The proximal segment of the hind limb between the knee and thetrunk. See Femur.
To plait or fold again; to fold, as one part over another,again and again.
A writer of plays; a dramatist; a playwright. Lecky.

An old French silver coin, originally of the value of abouteighteen pence, subsequently reduced to ninepence, and later tosixpence, sterling. Hence, in modern English slang, a sixpence; --often contracted to tizzy. Called also teston. Shak.
Resembling or containing gypsum; partaking of the qualities ofgypsum.
The pronghorn antelope. [Also written cabrit, cabret.]
A bearing consisting of a segment of a circle encroaching onthe field from the side.
To ornament with figured work, as the side of a stocking.
A disease of the scalp, produced by a vegetable parasite.
All the cannon and small arms collectively, with theirequipments, belonging to a ship or a fortification.
To pace again; to walk over again in a contrary direction.
An Arabian tree (Trichilia emetica). The fruit, which isemetic, is sometimes employed in the composition of an ointment forthe cure of the itch.

A religious as well as a secular designation applied to rulersof some of the city states of ancient Chaldea, as Lagash orShirpurla, who were conceived to be direct representatives of thetutelary god of the place.
A peculiar strong soup or broth, made in Scotland. [Writtenalso imrich.]
Pieces of timber bolted to certain parts of a mast tp supportthe trestletrees.
Of or pertaining to paresis; affected with paresis.
The solid generated by the rotation of a parabola about itsaxis; any surface of the second order whose sections by planesparallel to a given line are parabolas.
The second Sunday before Lent; -- so called as being about thesixtieth day before Easter.
A cruciferrous plant (Hesperis matronalis), remarkable for itsfragrance, especially toward the close of the day; -- called alsorocket and dame's violet. Loudon.
Of or pertaining to the thyroid cartilage of the larynx and thehyoid arch.
A superficial excoriation, with loss of substance under theform of small shreds. Dunglison.
Fatigued; worn with labor or hardship. [Obs. or Local] Mir. forMag.
Inflammation, acute or chronic, of the bronchial tubes or anypart of them.
An acrid, poisonous, crystallizable substance, obtained fromsome species of anemone.
Of or pertaining to nostalgia; affected with nostalgia.
Turned round like a crook, or bent to and fro. Loudon.
The pendulous or overhanging lateral parts of the upper lip ofdogs, especially prominent in hounds; -- called also chaps. SeeIllust. of Bloodhound.
Pertaining to the antipodes, or the opposite side of the world;antipodal.
A gaping or opening; state of being chinky, or havingapertures. Kirwan.
The erosion of the bed of a stream by running water,principally by attrition of the detritus carried along by the stream,but also by the solvent action of the water.
A plate or block with a printing surface (usually in relief)obtained from a photograph; also, any one of the many methods ofprocesses by which such a printing surface is obtained.
A piece of armor for the thighs, forming an appendage to theancient corselet.
An under-garment, worn by women, usually covering the neck,shoulders, and breast.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid which is obtained as awhite crystalline substance by the action of ammonia on pyrotartaricacid.
To pack or stow, as cargo in a ship's hold. See Steeve.
Havig a moist and adhesive or sticky surface, as a leaf orgland.
Curd produced from milk by adding acetic acid, after rennet hasceased to cause coagulation. Brande & C.
In a correct manner; exactly; acurately; without fault orerror.
Pudding made of Indian meal; also, porridge made of chestnutmeal. [Italy]
Of recent origin or introduction; not ancient; new; hence, outof the ordinary course; unusual; strange; surprising.
A chief broken or opening like a carpenter's bevel. Encyc.Brit.
An inferior kind of veneration or worship, given to the angelsand saints as the servants of God.
The cord which suspends the embryo; and which is attached tothe radicle in the young state; the proembryo.
To subject to the influence of letheon. [R. or Obs.]
One of the large beads in the rosary at which the paternosteris recited. [Obs.] Gower.
The ketone of stearic acid, obtained as a white crystallinesubstance, (C17H35)2.CO, by the distillation of calcium stearate.
The three anterior ambulacra of echinoderms, collectively.
A genus of beautiful South American passerine birds, includingthe cock of the rock.
A fish that keeps at the bottom of the water, as the loach.
To add a piece of leather to the heel of (a shoe, boot, etc.)
The domain of puzzles; puzzles, collectively. C. Kingsley.
To split (as an eel) lengthwise, and broil it, or fry it in hotfat.
Hernia in which the urinary bladder protrudes; vesical hernia.
A pavement or sidewalk of flagstones; flagstones, collectively.
Producing heat; -- said of substances, as septic poisons, whichelevate the temperature of the body and cause fever.
To pass a rope round, as a cask, gun, etc., preparatory toattaching a hoisting or lowering tackle.
Approaching the nature of sand; loose; not compact. [Obs.]Evelyn.
A periodical sale of ore in the English mining districts; -- socalled from the tickets upon which are written the bids of thebuyers.
A poisonous alkaloid extracted from the stavesacre (Delphiniumstaphisagria), as a colorless amorphous powder.
Evil intent, embracing both malice and fraud. See Culpa.Wharton.
The space which is behind and subordinate to a portrait orgroup of figures.
An agreement; a compact; a bargain. [R.] Sir W. Scott.
An instrument which, in conjunction with another making anabsolute disposition, constitutes a trust.
The dissection, or that part of anatomy which treats of thedissection, of muscles.
A son of one's husband or wife by a former marriage.
A meteoric stone characterized by the presence of chondrules.
A babe or young child of Indian parentage in North America.

A name formerly given to various fevers occuring in tropics;esp. to a form of furious delirium accompanied by fever, amongsailors, which sometimes led the affected person to imagine the seato be a green field, and to throw himself into it.
A channel of curved section; -- usually applied to one of avertical series of such channels used to decorate columns andpilasters in classical architecture. See Illust. under Base, n.
A genus of extinct Merostomata, found in Silurian rocks. Someof the species are more than three feet long.
The act of stumbling, rocking, or rolling; a reeling. Quain.
A young rowdy; a rough, lawless fellow. [Colloq. U.S.]
One who locates, or is entitled to locate, land or a miningclaim. [U.S.]
An engraving or other picture or illustration for a book.
Having the power or quality of purging; cathartic.-- n. (Med.)
The act of touching the football down by a player behind hisown goal line when it received its last impulse from an opponent; --distinguished from safety touchdown.
One of the pear-shaped pots open at both ends, and so formed asto be fitted together, the neck of one into the bottom of another insuccession; -- used in the process of sublimation. Ure.
