One who imports; the merchant who brings goods into a countryor state; -- opposed to exporter.
Want of intelligence; stupidity; folly. [R.] Blount.
The creation or evolution of the stars or the heavens. H.Spencer.
One who narrates; one who relates a series of events ortransactions.
Pretentious; taking much upon one's self; presumptuous. Burke.
A halo opposite the sun, consisting of a colored ring or ringsaround the shadow of the spectator's own head, as projected on acloud or on an opposite fog bank.
An officer who inspects and rates articles liable to exciseduty. Macaulay.
A basket made of rushes, used chiefly for containing figs andraisins.
A silky wool derived from the seeds of Ceiba pentandra (syn.Eriodendron anfractuosum), a bombaceous tree of the East and WestIndies.
One who registers; esp., one who , by virtue of securing anofficial registration, obtains a certain right or title ofpossession, as to a trade-mark.
An apparatus for receiving and condensing the volatile productsof distillation to a liquid or solid form, by cooling.
A leaving dry; a recession of the sea or other water, leavingdry land; land left uncovered by such recession. Burrill.
To strike, beat, or bang; to break; to destroy. [Scot. & Prov.Eng.]
A trade name for a brown dyestuff obtained from certain basicazo compounds of benzene; -- called also Bismarck brown, Manchesterbrown, etc.
An instrument for the volumetric measurement of gases; -- sonamed because frequently used to determine the purity of the air.
Of or pertaining to Sumatra or its inhabitants.-- n.

Nourishing matter stored up within the integuments of the seedin many plants, but not incorporated in the embryo. It is the flourypart in corn, wheat, and like grains, the oily part in poppy seeds,the fleshy part in the cocoanut, etc.
A genus of fishes, common on the Atlantic coast, including theyellow or goldon mackerel.
The seventh month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year, answeringto a part of September with a part of October.
A collective term for cravats, collars, etc. [Colloq. or tradename]
A person appointed to inspect highways, fences, or the like,and to report upon the same.
Of irregular form; shapeless. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
To soothe; to mollify; to pacify; to soften. [R.] Sir T. Elyot.
The steersman of a boat; a petty officer who has charge of aboat and its crew.
A head or chief over ten; especially, an officer who commandeda division of ten soldiers.
Fernlike, either in form or in the nature of the method ofreproduction.
An elongated pod, consisting, like the legume, of two valves,but divided transversely into small cells, each containing a singleseed.
One of the nine Muses, daughter of Zeus by Mnemosyne, andpatron of astronomy.
To struggle against anything; to resist; to oppose. [Obs.] "Todelude their reluctating consciences." Dr. H. More.
The nest of a bird of prey, as of an eagle or hawk; also abrood of such birds; eyrie. Shak. Also fig.: A human residence orresting place perched like an eagle's nest.
A South American carnivore of the genus Conepatus, allied tothe skunk, but larger, and having a longer snout. The tail is notbushy.
In a weak manner; with little strength or vigor; feebly.
A bone of the carpus at the base of the third metacarpal bone.
The relationship between a person and his sponsors. [Obs.]
A ball which has passed through all the hoops and would go outif it hit the stake but is continued in play; also, the player ofsuch a ball.
Any oil substance having a hyacinthine odor, obtained by theaction of acids on terpin, and regarded as a related hydrate.
A saltish concretion on reeds and grass in marshy grounds inGalatia. It is soft and porous, and was formerly used for cleansingthe skin from freckles and tetters, and also in leprosy. Dana.
A dish of food that has been warmed again, hence, fig.,something made up from old material; a rehash.
A dance in moderate twofold time, invented by the French in thereign of Louis XIV.; -- now mostly found in suites of pieces, likethose of Bach and Handel.
A hydrous chloride of potassium and magnesium, sometimes foundassociated with deposits of rock salt.

A muscle of the thigh, called the tailor's muscle, which arisesfrom the hip bone and is inserted just below the knee. So namedbecause its contraction was supposed to produce the position of thelegs assumed by the tailor in sitting.
An obstruction, or indigestible mass, found in the intestine ofbears and other animals during hibernation.
Manganese spar, or silicate of manganese, a mineral occuringcrystallised and in rose-red masses. It is often used as anornamental stone.
Having alternate ridges and depressions; wrinkled. Dana.
The language of ancient Ethiopia; the language of the ancientAbyssinian empire (in Ethiopia), now used only in the Abyssinianchurch. It is of Semitic origin, and is also called Geez.
A fish having spines in, or in front of, the dorsal fins.
The purslane tree of South Africa, -- said to be the favoritefood of elephants. Balfour (Cyc. of India).
An orthopterous insect of the genus Gryllus, and allied genera.The males make chirping, musical notes by rubbing together the basalparts of the veins of the front wings.
A plant described by Milton as "of sovereign use against allenchantments."
Being under the apex; of or pertaining to the part just belowthe apex.
The crash or concussion attending the breaking up of masses ofice, -- often due to contraction from extreme cold.
A cartilaginous fish with a mouth adapted for suction, as thelampery.
Pertaining to, resembling, or characteristic of, the stag, orCervus elaphus.
Anything that binds and makes fast, as a lock, catch, bolt,bar, buckle, etc.
One of a sect of Judaizing Christians in the first and secondcenturies, who observed the laws of Moses, and held to certainheresies.
The armed or feruled end of a staff; in a sheephook, the end ofthe staff to which the hook is attached. Sir P. Sidney.
That which is expectorated; a salival discharge; spittle;saliva.
One who takes or receives; one who catches or apprehended.
To haul under the keel of a ship, by ropes attached to theyardarms on each side. It was formerly practiced as a punishment inthe Dutch and English navies. Totten.
The reproductive zooids of a hydroid colony, collectively.
Something new-fashioned; a foolish innovation; a gewgaw; atrifling ornament.
Either entirely of partially separate, as the carpels of acompound pistil; -- opposed to syncarpous. Lindley.
To distribute into classes; to arrange according to a system;to arrnge in sets according to some method founded on commonproperties or characters.
Any plant which habitually breaks away from its roots in theautumn, and is driven by the wind, as a light, rolling mass, over thefields and prairies; as witch grass, wild indigo, Amarantus albus,etc.
A creditor for whom an appraisal is made. Sir W. Scott.
Want of action or activity; forbearance from labor; idleness;rest; inertness. Berkeley.
A small gray and brown sandpiper (Calidris arenaria) verycommon on sandy beaches in America, Europe, and Asia. Called alsocurwillet, sand lark, stint, and ruddy plover.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid, C11H18O2, of thepropiolic acid series, obtained indirectly from undecylenic acid as awhite crystalline substance.
A copper coin, used in the Ionian Islands, about one cent invalue.
A condition in which the circulation is retarded, and theentire mass of blood is less oxygenated than it normally is.
To make to foam at the mouth, like a hunted animal. [Obs.]
A genus of blood sucking flies, including the horseflies.
One who believes the prophecies of the Apocalypse to have beenalready fulfilled. Farrar.
To issue, as breath; to be breathed out; to exhale. Beau. & Fl.
Of or pertaining to the middle division of the Tertiary.-- n.
To wind too tightly, as a spring, or too far, as a hoistingrope on a drum.
The state of being an owner; the right to own; exclusive rightof possession; legal or just claim or title; proprietorship.
The household gods of the ancient Romans. They presided overthe home and the family hearth. See Lar.
A unit of cubic measure in the metric system, being a cubicmeter, or kiloliter, and equal to 35.3 cubic feet, or nearly 1
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the stern old Roman, Cato theCensor; severe; inflexible.
The lifeless food matter in the cytoplasm of an ovum or a cell,as distinguished from the active or true protoplasm; yolk substance;yolk.
One who tunes; especially, one whose occupation is to tunemusical instruments.
Of or pertaining to a particular region; sectional.
A large division of gastropod molluske, including thePulmonifera and Opisthobranchiata.
To cut; to separate and remove; to resolve or break up, as bymedicines. [Obs.] Arbuthnot.
Witty or humorous writings or saying; witticisms; merryconceits.
A piece of furniture holding the ewer or pitcher, basin, andother requisites for washing the person.
Having, or relating to, sepals; -- used mostly in composition.See under Sepal.
Government of the church by bishops; church government by threedistinct orders of ministers -- bishops, priests, and deacons -- ofwhom the bishops have an authority superior and of a different kind.
Making a clangor; having a ringing, metallic sound.
A bird, especially a pheasant, which, being flushed, risesstraight in the air like a rocket. [Eng.]
The representation or image of a fowl made by fowlers to shootat. Johnson.
A cushion for terminating or softening a note made by astringed instrument with a keyboard.
A nickname for a policeman; -- from Sir Robert Peel, whoremodeled the police force. See Peeler. [Slang, Eng.] Dickens.
Excessive appetite; greediness; voracity. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
A hypothetical component of a chemical atom, on the theory thatthe elements themselves are complex substances; -- called alsoatomicule.
The act or process of ascertaining the force or velocity of thewind.
An instrument for ascertaining the specific gravity or densityof a substance.
Money paid by a tenant in lieu of the service of average.
Any one of several species of sparoid fishes belonging toSargus, Pomodasys, and related genera; -- called also sar, andsaragu.
Relating to the blood or blood vessels; pertaining to, situatedin the region of, or on the side with, the heart and great bloodvessels; -- opposed to neural.
Situated in front; opposite; hence, opposing; adverse;antagonistic. Pope.
A supposed element claimed to have been discovered byR.Harmann.
Situated under, or on the ventral side of, the liver; --applied to the interlobular branches of the portal vein.
Any plant of the genus Lithospermum, herbs having a fruitcomposed of four stony nutlets.
Act or process of egesting; a voiding. Sir M. Hale.
In the foremost place or order; among the foremost. J. Webster.
A body of coal left to sustain an overhanding mass.
Of or pertaining to incubation, or to the period of incubation.
A nitrogenous phosphorized principle found in brain tissue. Bydecomposition it yields neurine, fatty acids, and other bodies.
An issue or artificial ulcer for the discharge of humors fromthe body.[Obs.] Wiseman.
The side of the ditch next the parapet; -- same as scarp, andopposed to counterscarp.
A carbohydrate isomeric with dextrin, obtained from quitchgrass (Agropyrum, formerly Triticum, repens) as a white amorphoussubstance.
A hypothetical radical, SH3, regarded as the type and nucleusof the sulphines.
A general sketch or outline of a subject; a synopsis; anepitome.
Civered with a sort of white, mealy powder, as the leaves ofsome poplars, and the body of certain insects; mealy.
Resembling the tail of a squirrel; -- generally said ofbranches which are close and dense, or of spikes of grass likebarley.
An alkaloid, C8H13N, obtained by the chemical dehydration oftropine, as an oily liquid having a coninelike odor.
One line or radius falling perpendicularly on another; as, thecatheti of a right-angled triangle, that is, the two sides thatinclude the right angle. Barlow.
A part of a turtle which is attached to the lower shell. Itcontains a fatty and gelatinous substance of a light yellowish color,much esteemed as a delicacy. Thackeray.
To deprive of commonable quality, as lands, by inclosing orappropriating. Burrill.
The doctrine that all things are subject to fate, or that theytake place by inevitable necessity.
A portable ornamental column, formerly carried before acardinal, as emblematic of his support to the church. [Obs.] Skelton.
Like a Tarquin, a king of ancient Rome; proud; haughty;overbearing.
A layer of tissue beneath the epidermis in plants, andperforming the physiological function of strengthening the epidermaltissue. In phanerogamous plants it is developed as collenchyma.
A piece of curved timber bolted to the stem, keelson, and apronin a ship's frame near the bow.
A species of bindweed or Convolvulus (C. Scammonia).
A bitter white crystalline alkaloid found in opium, possessingstrong narcotic properties, and much used as an anodyne; -- calledalso morphia, and morphina.
A cumbrous two-wheeled pleasure carriage used in Cuba.
Capable of being inflamed or kindled; combustible; inflammable.Ure.
Any one of several plants with yellow roots. Specifically:(a) See Xanthorhiza.(b) Same as Orangeroot.
In the form of a hexahedron; having six sides or faces.
A wind attending or presaged by the cloud called helm. [Prov.Eng.]
An invitation of friends to drink ale at some poor man's house,and there to contribute in charity for his relief. [Prov. Eng.]
An igneous rock of feldspathic composition, lamellar instructure, and clinking under the hammer. See Phonolite.
Having a rounded form resembling that of a globe; globular, ornearly so; spherical. Milton.
, to rely for authority. [Obs.]Authorizing himself, for the most part, upon other histories. Sir P.Sidney.
Something not true; a false statement. [Recent & R.] A.Trollope.
The quality of being chatty, or of talking easily andpleasantly.
A white amorphous horny substance forming the harder part ofthe outer integument of insects, crustacea, and various otherinvertebrates; entomolin.
Affected with amaurosis; having the characteristics ofamaurosis.
Producing only asexual individuals, as the eggs of certainannelids.
A door-keeper; a porter; one who has the care of a publicbuilding, or a building occupied for offices, suites of rooms, etc.
The history or description of the sacred writings or of sacredpersons; a narrative of the lives of the saints; a catalogue ofsaints. J. H. Newman.
Consisting of enamel; resembling enamel; smooth; glossy. [R.]Craig.
A jack in which a screw is used for lifting, or exertingpressure. See Illust. of 2d Jack, n., 5.
One of the definite areas of the skin of a bird on whichfeathers grow; -- contrasted with apteria.
The act or business of putting on lacquer; also, the coat oflacquer put on.
A priming tube connecting the charge chamber with the gallery,or place where the slow match is applied. Knight.
A kind of quadrangular piece of cloth put on by the Jews whenrepeating prayers in the synagogues. Crabb.
In a steep manner; with steepness; with precipitous declivity.
An inguinal hernia; esp. that incomplete variety in which thehernial pouch descends only as far as the groin, forming a swellingthere like a bubo.
The Pawnees, a tribe of North American Indians whose principaltotem was the wolf.
The penetrating of one rock, while in a plastic or metal state,into the cavities of another.
The act or process of beating into a plate, sheet, or leaf, asa metal; extension by beating.
To run out; to flow forth; to pass away. [Obs.] Boyle.
To reduce (as a liquid) to a fine spray or vapor; to atomize.
A kind of cotton or linen cloth, usually in stripes or checks,the yarn of which is dyed before it is woven; -- distinguished fromprinted cotton or prints.
An outer, or exterior. wall. See Vauntmure. [Obs.] Hakluyt.
A semicircular hollow or opening among trees or hills.Wordsworth.
The grass that grows after the first crop has been mown;aftermath.
Changeableness of color, as in a mineral; play of colors.Cleaceland.
A net for catching the larger sorts of birds; also, a dragnet.Crabb.
To release from espousal or plighted faith. [Poetic] Milton.
Situated in front of the notochord; -- applied especially toparts of the cartilaginous rudiments in the base of the skull.
A species of large South African antelope (Oreas canna). It isvalued both for its hide and flesh, and is rapidly disappearing inthe settled districts; -- called also Cape elk.
To recall, as former laughter. [Obs. & R.] Sir T. More.
A variety of calcite, or calcium carbonate, consisting ofaggregated globular concretions about the size of a pea; -- calledalso peastone, peagrit.
A tick or bag made of cloth, used for inclosing the materialsof a bed.
A kind of motor speed controller permitting of very gradualvariation in speed and of reverse. It is especially suitable for usewith motor driven machine tools.
To pour out; to give or spend liberally; to lavish; tosquander. [Obs.] Chapman.
As a lobe; so as to make a lobe; in a lobate manner.
A combination of acetic acid with glycerin. Brande & C.
Want of tone; weakness of the system, or of any organ,especially of such as are contractile.
A disease in cattle consisting in inflammation of the stomachby gas, ordinarily caused by eating too much green food; tympany;bloating.
One who, after having received sacred orders, renounces hisclerical profession.
To make over again; to restore to freshness or vigor; to renew.All nature feels the reniovating force Of winter. Thomson.
Relating to, or existing by, the union of divine and humanoperation in Christ, or the joint agency of the divine and humannature. Murdock.
In a nimble manner; with agility; with light, quick motion.
The Indian antelope (Antilope bezoartica, or cervicapra), notedfor its beauty and swiftness. It has long, spiral, divergent horns.
To thrust one's self upon a company or upon attention; tointrude.
A genus of extinct Eocene whales, remains of which have beenfound in the Gulf States. The species had very long and slenderbodies and broad serrated teeth. See Phocodontia.
A small Abyssinian antelope (Neotragus Saltiana), about thesize of a hare.
To subject to a washing process for the purpose of separatingsoluble material from that which is insoluble; to leach, as ashes,for the purpose of extracting the alkaline substances.
To give the quality, sound, or office of a vowel to.
A hollow way, adapted to cover troops, and facilitate theiraproach to a place. Farrow.
A morphological unit, consisting of two or more plastids, whichdoes not possess the positive character of the person or stock, indistinction from the physiological organ or biorgan. See Morphon.
Composed of small plates, as of horn or metal, overlapping liketiles; -- said of a kind of ancient armor. Fairholt.

A manner of engraving on copper or steel by drawing upon asurface previously roughened, and then removing the roughness inplaces by scraping, burnishing, etc., so as to produce the requisitelight and shade. Also, an engraving so produced.
A form of woman's underwaist stiffened with whalebones, or thelike, and worn to support the breasts.
A hydrous silicate of alumina, of a greenish color, which, incertain states of humidity, appears transparent and almostgelatinous.
A genus of birds including the swallows and martins.
A reserve force in the Turkish army, or a soldier of thereserve. See Army organization, above.
An order of birds, including the common domestic fowls,pheasants, grouse, quails, and allied forms; -- sometimes calledRasores.
A greenish yellow or green mineral, consisting chiefly of thehydrous silicate of iron.
One who, or that which, disjoins or causes disunion.
An instrument for comparing the relative amount of the light ofstars.
The front part of the thoracic region; the epigastrium.
A tool for making the band impression distinct on the back.Knight.
A glucoside extracted from the bittersweet (Solanum Dulcamara),as a yellow amorphous substance. It probably occasions the compoundtaste. See Bittersweet, 3(a).
A compound salt consisting chiefly of potassium chloride andmagnesium sulphate, occurring at the Stassfurt salt mines in PrussianSaxony.
The roots of the Chilian plant Calceolaria arachnoidea, -- usedfor dyeing crimson.
A dry, hot wind, prevailing on the Atlantic coast of Africa, inDecember, January, and February, blowing from the interior or Sahara.It is usually accompanied by a haze which obscures the sun.
A euphorbiaceous shrub of the genus Pedilanthus (P.tithymaloides), found in the West Indies, and possessing powerfulemetic and drastic qualities.
A hole or spot in a volcanic or other region, from which fumesissue.
An agreement, manifesting itself in words or deeds, by whichtwo or more persons confederate to do an unlawful act, or to useunlawful to do an act which is lawful; confederacy.
Any siphonophore which has an air sac for a float, as thePhysalia.
To remove the nails from; to unfasten by removing nails.
The state or quality of being recidivous; relapse, specif.(Criminology),
The final judgment of the Court of Session, or of an inferiorcourt, by which the question at issue is decided.
The tube which runs through the partitions of chamberedcephalopod shells.
An order of birds in which the wings are small, rudimentary, orabsent, and the breastbone is destitute of a keel. The ostrich, emu,and apteryx are examples.

A luminous impression produced through excitation of the retinaby some cause other than the impingement upon it of rays of light, asby pressure upon the eyeball when the lids are closed. Cf. After-image.
A weight divisible first into a hundred parts, and then intosmaller parts.
A zeolitic mineral, occurring generally in masses of a radiatedstructure. It is a hydrous silicate of aluminia, lime, and soda.Called also mesole, and comptonite.
The office of the keeper of a forest or park. [Eng.]
A colorless crystalline substance extracted from the Capsicumannuum, and giving off vapors of intense acridity.
The black rattlesnake (Crotalus, or Caudisona, tergemina),found in the Mississippi Valley.
The system of doctrines, polity, and worship, of the sectcalled Methodists. Bp. Warburton.
A Roman catholic; one who adheres to the Church of Rome and theauthority of the pope; -- an offensive designation applied to RomanCatholics by their opponents.
The practice or employment of spies; the practice of watchingthe words and conduct of others, to make discoveries, as spies orsecret emissaries; secret watching.
Prognostication by inspection of the entrails of victims slainsacrifice.
The laying of floors in a building; also, a floor of boards orplanks.
One of the small particles or organic molecules of protoplasm.Haeckel.

A division of marine gastropod mollusks in which the radula areconverted into poison fangs. The cone shells (Conus), Pleurotoma, andTerebra, are examples. See Illust. of Cone, n., 4, Pleurotoma, andTerebra.
Of or pertaining to the rectum; in the region of the rectum.
Wanting wisdom; stupid; foolish. [R.] Clarendon.-- n.
In distillation of low wines, the first portion of spirit thatcomes over, being a fluid abounding in fusel oil. Knight.
A printed and stitched book containing only a few leaves; apamphlet.
Bearing fruit repeatedly, as most perennial plants; polycarpic.
Adhesive; -- said of a roof in a mine to which coal clings.
A South African plant (Prionium Palmita) of the Rush family,having long serrated leaves. The stems have been used for makingbrushes.
A framework of sleepers and crossbeams forming a foundation inmarshy or treacherous soil.
A match for firing a charge of powder, as in blasting; a fuse.
A large wild goat (Capra megaceros), having huge flattenedspiral horns. It inhabits the mountains of Northern India andCashmere.
The number by which another number is multiplied. See the Noteunder Multiplication.
A muscle that stretches a part, or renders it tense.
A mist, or very fine rain, which sometimes falls from a clearsky a few moments after sunset. Tyndall.
A beautiful fluorescent crystalline substance, intermediate incomposition between thionol and thionine.
In various parts of Asia, an open space, as for militaryexercises, or for a market place; an open grassy tract; an esplanade.
Any mollusk which has a shell composed of more than two pieces.
A citation from some author, or a sentence framed for thepurpose, placed at the beginning of a work or of its separatedivisions; a motto.

A graceful and swift South African antelope (Pelea capreola).The hair is woolly, and ash-gray on the back and sides. The horns areblack, long, slender, straight, nearly smooth, and very sharp. Calledalso rheeboc, and rehboc.
A hard hitter; a slugger. [Cant or Slang]  T. Hughes.
Cognizable; liable to be tried or judged. [Obs.] Bp. Barlow.
The quality or state of being shoaly; little depth of water;shallowness.
According to the French and American method of numeration, athousand millions, or 1,000,000,000; according to the English method,a million millions, or 1,000,000,000,000. See Numeration.
The condition of having two or more kinds of flowers, differentas to the length of their stamens and pistils.
A tracing, usually made by the barograph, showing graphicallythe variations of atmospheric pressure for a given time.
A follower of Cornelius Jansen, a Roman Catholic bishop ofYpres, in Flanders, in the 17th century, who taught certain doctrinesdenying free will and the possibility of resisting divine grace.
A division of struthious birds, including the tinamous.
A servant who attends faithfully to his duty only when watched.
Divination from the state of the air or from atmosphericsubstances; also, forecasting changes in the weather.
Sucked by cubs. [R.]This night, wherein the cub-drawn bear would couch. Shak.
In a lousy manner; in a mean, paltry manner; scurvily. [Vulgar]
To produce, or cause, by proximity without contact ortransmission, as a particular electric or magnetic condition in abody, by the approach of another body in an opposite electric ormagnetic state.
A writ based upon the presumption that the person summoned washiding. Blackstone.
A forest officer appointed to walk over a certain space forinspection; a forester.
One of a race of South African nomads, living principally inthe deserts, and not classified as allied in race or language to anyother people.
Blankets, sheets, coverlets, etc., for a bed. Shak.
A man of learning; one versed in literature or science; aperson eminent for acquirements.
A tract of ground laid out for the game of golf; a golfinggreen.
The fire god of the Ammonites in Canaan, to whom humansacrifices were offered; Molech. Also applied figuratively.
By stabbing; with intent to injure covertly. Bp. Parker.
Finished at the ends with fleurs-de-lis; -- said esp. a crossso decorated.
A supposed new element of the rare-earth group, accompanyinglutecium and scandium in the gadolinite earths. Symbol, Ct (noperiod).
Given to tricks; practicing deception; trickish; knavish.
One of a sect in the 2d century who abstained from marriage,wine, and animal food; -- called also Continent.
A low bush (Viburnum lantanoides) having long, stragglingbranches and handsome flowers. It is found in the Northern UnitedStates. Called also shinhopple.
A hydrocarbon radical regarded as the essential residue ofnaphthalene.
A woman who makes and leaves a will at death; a femaletestator.
Under the influence of Mars; courageous; bold. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who understands the principles of harmony or is skillful inapplying them in composition; a musical composer.
Having the color of the willow; resembling the willow; willowy.Walton.
The ponderousness or bulk of a folio; voluminousness. [R.] DeQuincey.
To bring out from concealment; to discover. [Obs.] P. Fletcher.
The lowest note but one in Guido Aretino's scale of music.
The deeper wisdom; knowledge of spiritual truth, such as wasclaimed by the Gnostics.
The quality or state of being liquid; liquidity; fluency.
In French usage, a dish served at the beginning of dinner togive zest to the appetite; in English usage, a side dish, served witha joint, or between the courses, as a cutlet, scalloped oysters, etc.
The process or operation of feeding the contents of thecrucilbe with fresh material. B. Jonson.
An orderly and ceremonial progress of persons, either from thesacristy to the choir, or from the choir around the church, within orwithout. Shipley.
One who weighs; specifically, an officer whose duty it is toweigh commodities.
A bird that feeds on wheat, especially the chaffinch.
To be formal or affected in dress or manners; -- often with up.[Prov. Eng. & Scot.] Halliwell.
Being vertical, or at the highest point of altitude; hence,predominant. [R.]
A thin silk fabric used for linings, etc., in ladies' dresses.
Of, pertaining to, concerned in, or occurring by, metalepsy.
A powerful astringent alkaloid extracted from ergot as a brown,amorphous, bitter substance. It is used to produce contraction of theuterus.
Changed to bone or something resembling bone; hardened bydeposits of mineral matter of any kind; -- said of tissues.
A stroke made with a downward motion of the pen or pencil.
Having the tail nearly or quite symmetrical, the vertebralcolumn terminating near its base; -- opposed to heterocercal.
One of the bones of the carpus; the cuneiform. See Cuneiform(b).
Frivolous or bantering talk; a frivolous manner of treating anysubject, whether serious or otherwise; light raillery. Hannah More.
Of or pertaining to Anjou in France.-- n. A native of Anjou.
To impart to (one) a manner or character like that whichdistinguishes Londoners.
A timekeeper; especially, a watch by which small intervals oftime can be measured; a kind of stop watch. It is used for timing thespeed of horses, machinery, etc.
In a swift manner; with quick motion or velocity; fleetly.Wyclif.
The sliding crosspiece, or vane, on a leveling staff.
A method of tripping by getting the leg back of the opponent'sheel on the outside and pulling forward while pushing his body back;a throw made in this way. -- v. t.
A ditch or drain for catching water. See Catchdrain.
In a dogged manner; sullenly; with obstinate resolution.
Arranged on one side only, as flowers or leaves on a stalk.Gray.
To convert into the Hebrew idiom; to make Hebrew or Hebraistic.J. R. Smith.
A printing process of engraving on a surface of wax spread on asteel plate, for electrotyping.
One who, or that which, reminds; that which serves to awakenremembrance.
A quire; a book. [Obs.] " The king's quhair." James I. (ofScotland).
The science which treats of the laws relating to organictissues, their formation, development, functions, etc.
A command in writing; a species of writ or process. Burrill.
Am eagle without beak or feet, with expanded wings. Burke.
An arrant coward; a dastard; a craven; a mean-spirited wretch.Shak.
A small stage hung over a vessel's side, for workmen to standon in calking, etc.

Of, pertaining to, or resembling, pine or its products;specifically, designating an acid called also abeitic acid, which isthe chief ingredient of common resin (obtained from Pinus sylvestris,and other species).
Converted into a mummy or a mummylike substance; having theappearance of a mummy; withered.

Green vitriol, or sulphate of iron; a green crystallinesubstance, of an astringent taste, used in making ink, in dyeingblack, as a tonic in medicine, etc. It is made on a large scale bythe oxidation of iron pyrites. Called also ferrous sulphate.
Separated from other bodies by means of nonconductors of heator electricity.
The inner or principal branch of the oral appendages ofCrustacea. See Maxilla.
Upon or above the notochord; -- applied esp. to a vertebralcolumn which develops upon the dorsal side of the notochord, asdistinguished from a perichordal column, which develops around it.
That excerpts, selects, or chooses. D. L. Mackenzie.
An attachment to a clock by which the quarter hours are struckupon bells of different tones.
A name given to several kinds of wood with an unpleasant smell,as that of the Foetidia Mauritiana of the Mauritius, and that of theSouth African Ocotea bullata.
The refuse of cattle taken from a drove. [Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
A tool with a semicircular edge, -- used by engravers to clearaway the spaces between the lines of an engraving. Fairholt.
The shore or border of the land adjacent to the sea or ocean.Also used adjectively.
A fastening, consisting of an iron ring around the wrist,usually connected by a chain with one on the other wrist; a manacle;-- usually in the plural.
One who, or that which, gives energy, or acts in producing aneffect.
The large muscle which raises the under jaw, and assists inmastication.
Measurement by a tachometer; the science or use of tachometers.
A stratum of clay lying beneath a coal bed, often containingthe roots of coal plants, especially the Stigmaria.

A trough or sluice having cleats, grooves, or steps across thebottom for holding quicksilver and catching particles of gold whenauriferous earth is washed; also, one of the cleats, grooves, orsteps in such a trough. Also called ripple.
Of or pertaining to Java, or to the people of Java.-- n. sing. & pl.
One who makes an apology; one who speaks or writes in defenseof a faith, a cause, or an institution; especially, one who argues indefense of Christianity.
A colorless, crystalline substance, C10H8O4, from furfurol.
The act or process of laying the ground in a painting. [R.]
A warlike, savage, and nomadic tribe of the Shoshone family ofIndians, inhabiting Mexico and the adjacent parts of the UnitedStates; -- called also Paducahs. They are noted for plundering andcruelty.
A spark; the least particle; an iota; a tittle. R. North.
Parings and refuse of hides, skins, etc., from which glue ismade.
In the form of a ply, fold, or doubling. [Obs.] Pennant.
A kind of ruff for the neck; a turned-down collar; a rebato.[Obs.] Shak.
A perennial herbaceous plant of almost treelike size (Musasapientum); also, its edible fruit. See Musa.
The national assembly or parliament of Iceland. See Thing, n.,8.
The sucking proboscis of various insects. See Lepidoptera, andDiptera.
A segment in the hyoidean arch between the epihyal andtympanohyal.
A nebulous arch, or bow, of white or yellowish light sometimesseen in fog, etc.
A constellation in the Northern Hemisphere, delineated as a manholding a serpent in his hands; -- called also Serpentarius.
One who, or that which, raises (in various senses of the verb).
Bearing fruit; -- said of a tree or plant so represented uponan escutcheon. Cussans.
Characteristic of Gargantua, a gigantic, wonderful personage;enormous; prodigious; inordinate.
A dangerous whirlpool on the coast of Sicily opposite Scylla onthe Italian coast. It is personified as a female monster. See Scylla.
A centerpiece for table decoration, usually consisting ofseveral dishes or receptacles of different sizes grouped together inan ornamental design.
Of or pertaining to the Himalayas, the great mountain chain inHindostan.
To take the tiles from; to uncover by removing the tiles.
Things which may be furnished or restored in kind, asdistinguished from specific things; -- called also fungible things.Burrill.
The interjunction, or joining, of words in uttering the clausesof sentences.
One whose occupation it is to make tents. Acts xviii. 3.
To date later than the true or proper period. Milton.
An old game, played by holding up the fingers. Herrick.
Writing prose; speaking or writing in a tedious or prosymanner. Sir W. Scott.
A kind of toy or rude musical instrument, as a tube inside ofwhich is a stretched string made to vibrate by singing or humminginto the tube.
An advocate or professional pleader; one who counted for hisclient, that is, orally pleaded his cause. [Obs.] Burrill.
An office or feast celebrated with less solemnity than thedouble ones. See Double, n., 8.
Literally, this-ness. A scholastic term to expressindividuality or singleness; as, this book.
The connecting rod in a sawmill; also, sometimes, a connectingrod in other machinery.
Applied to the examination of a witness, by the party callinghim, after the cross-examination.
A minute soft filamentary process springing from the surface ofcertain hydroids and sponges.
The designation or nomenclature of organs. B. G. Wilder.
An organic base, in the form of a white powder, obtained fromAconitum lycoctonum. Eng. Cyc.
A plant growing in a state of nature; especially, one which hasrun wild, or escaped from cultivation.
The number of simple elements which an abstract conception ornotion includes; the comprehension or content.
Consisting of, or including, two chambers, or legislativebranches. Bentham.
To repent; to displease; to disgust. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A plea of a defendant that he did not hold the land, asaffirmed.
To talk rapidly, indistinctly, or unintelligibly; to uttergibberish or nonsense; to chatter. Swift.
Producing mathematically perfect harmony or concord; sweetly orperfectly harmonious.
A kind of latticework formed of, or covered with, vines,branches of trees, or other plants, for shade; a bower. Sir P.Sidney.
The act of transposing, or the state of being transposed;transposition.
Of or pertaining to a trochoid; having the properties of atrochoid.
The first, or preaxial, digit of the hind limb, correspondingto the pollux in the fore limb; the great toe; the hind toe of birds.
A wild rush of sheep, cattle, horses, or camels (especially atthe smell or the sight of water); a stampede.
An instrument closely resembling the mandolin, but of largersize and tuned lower.
Free from color; transmitting light without decomposing it intoits primary colors.
A magistrate in ancient Rome, who had the superintendence ofpublic buildings, highways, shows, etc.; hence, a municipal officer.
The king of the fairies, and husband of Titania or Queen Mab.Shak.
Having one hydrogen atom replaceable by a negative or acid atomor radical; capable of neutralizing a monobasic acid; -- said ofbases, and of certain metals.
A spiral whose polar equation is r2th = a; that is, a curve thesquare of whose radius vector varies inversely as the angle which theradius vector makes with a given line.
Applied to a variety of tumor forming hard, flat, irregularexcrescences upon the skin.-- n.
A tuft or brush of hair on the knees of some species ofantelopes and other animals; -- chiefly used in the plural.
Of or pertaining to the feet; employing the foot or feet.
A kind of border similar to the orle, but of only half thebreadth of the latter.
Resembling gneiss; having some of the characteristics ofgneiss; -- applied to rocks of an intermediate character betweengranite and gneiss, or mica slate and gneiss.
A division of spiders, including those that make geometricalwebs, as the garden spider, or Epeira.
In a wrathy manner; very angrily; wrathfully. [Colloq.]
Having the mandibular arch articulated directly to the cranium,as in the skulls of the Amphibia.
One who undertakes to discharge a specific business commission;a mandatory. Wharton.
A work constructed on each side of the ravelins, to increasetheir strength, procure additional ground beyond the ditch, or coverthe shoulders of the bastions.
A genus of plants, mostly of tropical America, many species ofwhich are grown as ornamental plants. The leaves are curiously one-sided, and often exhibit brilliant colors.
,.A play performed by shaking money in a hat or cap. [R.]Arbuthnot.
Coming from a point well abaft the beam, but not directlyastern; -- said of waves or any moving object.
A writer and doctor of the law; one skilled in the law andtraditions; one who read and explained the law to the people.
To put in the place of another; to substitute. Barrow.
Singing birds; a group of the Passeres, having numeroussyringeal muscles, conferring musical ability.
The thirteenth, or intercalary, month of the Jewishecclesiastical calendar, which is added about every third year.
One who interrupts or incommodes another in the peaceableenjoyment of his right.
One of a picked company of irregular riflemen in each regimentof the French infantry.
A feeling of weariness and disgust; dullness and languor ofspirits, arising from satiety or want of interest; tedium. T. Gray.
The act of laying small gathers in cloth in regular order.
A citizen of the lowest class, who served the state, not withproperty, but only by having children; hence, a common person.

Originally, a shield-bearer or armor-bearer, an attendant on aknight; in modern times, a title of dignity next in degree belowknight and above gentleman; also, a title of office and courtesy; --often shortened to squire.
A chimney; esp., a pipe serving as a chimney, as the pipe whichcarries off the smoke of a locomotive, the funnel of a steam vessel,etc.
Increasing by internal growth and elongation at the summit,instead of externally, and having no distinction of pith, wood, andbark, as the rattan, the palm, the cornstalk.
A fertile or green spot in a waste or desert, esp. in a sandydesert.
A variety; -- used in giving scientific names, and oftenabbreviated to var.
An extinct order or suborder of bivalve mollusks characteristicof the Cretaceous period; -- called also Rudista. See Illust. underHippurite.
Like a young person or thing; young; youthful. [Obs.] Shak.
A fine, small line, fastened to a hawk's leash, when it isfirst lured.
A yard, staff, or rod, used as a measure. [Obs.] Shak.
Of or pertaining to internodes; intervening between nodes orjoints.
In the position of fighting; -- said of two lions set face toface, each rampant.
Any one of several dark-colored augitic, eruptive rocks alliedto basalt.
Small wings or winged shoes represented as fastened to theankles, -- chiefly used as an attribute of Mercury.
One who contests; an opponent; a litigant; a disputant; one whoclaims that which has been awarded to another.

The young aquatic larva of any amphibian. In this stage itbreathes by means of external or internal gills, is at firstdestitute of legs, and has a finlike tail. Called also polliwig,polliwog, porwiggle, or purwiggy.
In an anxious manner; with painful uncertainty; solicitously.
An imperfect enunciation of the letter r, in which it soundslike l.
To assay, or attempt, improperly or unsuccessfully. [Obs.] W.Browne.

Any one of a series of cyanogen compounds; particularly, one ofthose cyanides of alcohol radicals which, by boiling with acids oralkalies, produce a carboxyl acid, with the elimination of thenitrogen as ammonia.
Humped; protuberant; -- said of a surface which presents one ormore large elevations. Brande & C.
One of a secret association of Mormons, bound by an oath toobey the heads of the church in all things. [U. S.]

Miscellaneous curiosities and works of decorative art,considered collectively. A piece of bric-a-brac, any curious orantique article of virtu, as a piece of antiquated furniture or metalwork, or an odd knickknack.
A bolter from the Republican party in the national election of1884; an Independent. [Political Cant, U.S.]
A special groove or furrow at one or both angles of the mouthof many Anthozoa.
The stone roller. See Stone roller (a), under Stone.
A woman who officiated in sacred rites among pagans. Abp.Potter.
A machine for raising guns or mortar into their carriages.
Government by ecclesiastics; a hierarchy. Jefferson.
Manner of approaching or accosting; address. Chesterfield.
To deprive of the rank or position of a lord. Milton.
A very large bird of the Vulture family (Sarcorhamphusgryphus), found in the most elevated parts of the Andes.
Of, or containing, bismuth, when this element has its lowervalence.
To retire; to retreat; to quit a company or place; to go away;as, he withdrew from the company. "When the sea withdrew." King Horn.
Any one of numerous species of small East Indian and Asiaticswifts of the genus Collocalia. Some of the species are noted forfurnishing the edible bird's nest. See Illust. under Edible.

A European fish (Peristethus cataphractum), having the bodycovered with bony plates, and having three spines projecting in frontof the nose; -- called also noble, pluck, pogge, sea poacher, andarmed bullhead.
A vascular sac connected, beneath the brain, in many fishes,with the infundibulum.
The use of a bicycle; the act or practice of riding a bicycle.
A painted tape, marked with linear dimensions, as inches, feet,etc., and often inclosed in a case, -- used for measuring.
In a peculiar manner; particulary; in a rare and strikingdegree; unusually.
An ordained minister; a man regularly authorized to peach thegospel, and administer its ordinances; in England usually restrictedto a minister of the Established Church.
Capable of being judged; capable of being tried or decidedupon. Jer. Taylor.
The quality or state of being tense, or strained to stiffness;tension; tenseness.
Having the quality of closing the pores of the skin.
Having the quality of softening or mitigating, as pain oracrimony; assuasive; emollient.
A volatile oil distilled from the resin or balsam of the nutpine (Pinus sabiniana) of California.
The aquatic larva of a gnat; -- called also, colloquially,wiggler.
To surpass in flying; to fly beyond or faster than. Shak.Winged with fear outflies the wind. Waller.
An umbelliferous plant, the Coriandrum sativum, the fruit orseeds of which have a strong smell and a spicy taste, and in medicineare considered as stomachic and carminative.
An instrument for trepanning, being an improvement on thetrepan. It is a circular or cylindrical saw, with a handle like thatof a gimlet, and a little sharp perforator called the center pin.
To inlay into, as a piece of carving or other ornamentalobject.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid found in certainlichens, and called also lecanoric acid. [Formerly written alsoorseillic.]
In the metric system, one million meters, or one thousandkilometers.
One of the protoplasmic cells which occur in the osteogeneticlayer of the periosteum, and from or around which the matrix of thebone is developed; an osteoplast.
The doctrine of the localization of disease, or which refers italways to a material lesion of an organ. Dunglison.
The structureless, protoplasmic tissue of the embryo; theprimitive basis of an organ yet unformed, from which it grows.
A character [0] which, standing by itself, expresses nothing,but when placed at the right hand of a whole number, increases itsvalue tenfold.
A small wagon used for the underground work of a mine.Tomlison.
The euphonic modification of a root vowel sound by theinfluence of a, u, or especially i, in the syllable which formerlyfollowed.
The principal gaseous substance forming the solar corona,characterized by a green line in the coronal spectrum.
One dressed in blue, as a soldier, a sailor, a beadle, etc.
Belonging to winter; done in winter. Sir T. Browne.
That on which anything is mounted; a setting; hence, a saddlehorse. [Obs.] Spenser.
A flying machine, or a small plane for experiments on flying,which floats in the air only when propelled through it.
To strip of plumes or feathers; hence, to humiliate.
A soft-spoken, crafty hypocrite. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
The jamb or sidepiece of a door. Ex. xii. 22 (Douay version).
A people visited by Ulysses in his wanderings. They subsistedon the lotus. See Lotus (b), and Lotus-eater.
Either half of a square-rigged vessel's yard, from the centeror mast to the end.
One whose business is to free wool from its filth. [Prov. Eng.]
The character or person of a devil or the devil. Cowley.
Blended; passing into each other by subtle gradations; -- saidof colors or of the surface or material on which the colors are laid.
A small copper coin of Spain, equal to three mils Americanmoney, less than a farthing sterling. Also, an ancient Spanish goldcoin.
A red coloring matter derived from phenol; -- called also, incommerce, yellow coralin.
The covering, or coat, of a mammal, whether of wool, fur, orhair.

A dyestuff extracted from certain lichens (Roccella tinctoria,Lecanora tartarea, etc.), as a blue amorphous mass which consists ofa compound of the alkaline carbonates with certain coloring mattersrelated to orcin and orcein.
A throwing toy, or implement, of the Australian aborigines,consisting of a cigar-shaped stick fastened at one end to a flexibletwig. It weighs in all about two ounces, and is about two feet long.

Articles made of the blades or fiber of the Lygeum Spartum andStipa (or Macrochloa) tenacissima, kinds of grass used in Spain andother countries for making ropes, mats, baskets, nets, andmattresses. Loudon.
To draw within so as to meet yet not cut the boundaries.

An apparatus for holding and measuring of gas; in gas works, ahuge iron cylinder closed at one end and having the other endimmersed in water, in which it is made to rise or fall, according tothe volume of gas it contains, or the pressure required.
A leguminous tree (Eperua falcata) of Demerara, with pinnateleaves and clusters of red flowers. The reddish brown wood is usedfor palings and shingles. J. Smith (Dict. Econ. Plants).
A defect or malformation; esp., a fissure of the iris supposedto be a persistent embryonic cleft.
A disease of the eyelids, consisting in chronic inflammation ofthe margins, with a gummy secretion of sebaceous matter. Dunglison.

The god of eloquence and letters among the ancient Egyptians,and supposed to be the inventor of writing and philosophy. Hecorresponded to the Mercury of the Romans, and was usuallyrepresented as a human figure with the head of an ibis or a lamb.
A male horse not castrated; a male horse kept for breeding.
The involute of a curve. See Involute, and Evolute.

The most important tribe belonging to the Kaffir race. Theyinhabit a region on the southeast coast of Africa, but formerlyoccupied a much more extensive country. They are noted for theirwarlike disposition, courage, and military skill.
The assistant of a bishop or of a priest holding a benefice.
Branched, as the stem or root of a plant; having lateraldivisions; consisting of, or having, branches; full of branches;ramifying; branching; branchy.
The state of being fair, or free form spots or stains, as ofthe skin; honesty, as of dealing; candor, as of an argument, etc.
A disease in sheep and cattle, marked by great nervousness, orby dullness and stupor.
A scaly granular variety of anhydrite of a grayish white color,used for ornamental purposes.
One of the points sometimes drilled as guides for cutting awaysuperfluous stone.
To disarrange, so that the letters or lines stand awry or aremixed and need careful readjustment; -- said of type that has beenset up.
The perpendicular from the center to one of the sides of aregular polygon.
A word or words unintentionally doubled or set up a secondtime.
A scamp; an Irish term for a good-for-nothing fellow; -- oftenused in good-humored contempt or ridicule. [Colloq.]
Not agreeing with some artificial system of classification.
In Porto Rico, any of several araceous plants or their starchyedible roots, which are cooked and eaten like yams or potatoes, asthe taro.
Of or pertaining to Milan in Italy, or to its inhabitants.-- n. sing. & pl.
Of or pertaining to a hoof, claw, or talon; ungual.
To emit a strong, offensive smell; to send out a disgustingodor.
Pertaining to, produced by, or attending, catarrh; of thenature of catarrh.
Characterized by, or introducing, innovations. Fitzed. Hall.
A glucoside found in the seeds of several species of lupine,and extracted as a yellowish white crystalline substance.
Invertebrate animals covered with shells, especially mollusks;shellfish.
An armed ship having her upper deck cut away, and thus reducedto the next inferior rate, as a seventy-four cut down to a frigate.Totten.
A false spur or gaff, fitted on the heel of a gamecock. Wright.
To combine or impregnate with nitrogen; to convert, byoxidation, into nitrous or nitric acid; to subject to, or produce by,nitrification.
An act or engagement on behalf of a state, by an agent notspecially authorized for the purpose, or by one who exceeds thelimits of authority.
A white, crystalline, bitter substance. See Calumbin.
A star in the tail of the Great Bear, the one next the bowl inthe Dipper.
A chief magistrate of a free imperial city or canton ofSwitzerland. [Obs.]
A short act or piece between others, as in a play; aninterlude; hence, intermediate employment or time. Chesterfield.
Capable of being drawn out in length; ductile. Bacon.
Not torn, split, or parted; not torn to pieces. [Obs.] Bp.Hall.
An extinct genus of Devonian ganoid fishes, having the broadplates about the head studded with berrylike tubercles.
In an adverse manner; inimically; unfortunately; contrariwise.
A composite stone (quartz, schorl, and hornlende) in the wallsof tin and copper lodes.
The bearded tortoise (Chelys fimbriata) of South Americanrivers.
One who adjusts things to a line or lines or brings them intoline. Evelyn.
A hawk resembling the buzzard, but with legs relatively longer.
A yellow-flowered composite plant (Helenium autumnale) the odorof which is said to cause sneezing.
Relating to the common wormwood or to an acid obtained from it.
A contraction of the muscles of the jaw by which its motion issuspended; a variety of tetanus.
Mud or slime, such as that at the bottom of rivers. [Scot.]
One of the smaller cells, or blastomeres, resulting from thecomplete segmentation of a telolecithal ovum.
A treatise on, or the science of, the preservation of health.[R.]
A carangoid oceanic fish (Trachurops crumenophthalmus), havingvery large and prominent eyes; -- called also goggle-eye, big-eyedscad, and cicharra.
To avoid or defeat; to prove false, as a judgment. Blackstone.
Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of, Pompeii, an ancientcity of Italy, buried by an eruption of Vesuvius in 79 a. d., andpartly uncovered by modern excavations.
A square of white linen worn at first on the head, but nowabout the neck and shoulders, by priests of the Roman Catholic Churchwhile saying Mass.
A triacid alcohol, related to glycerin, and obtained fromcertain styryl derivatives as a yellow, gummy, amorphous substance; -- called also phenyl glycerin.
A kind of cigar, originally brought from Mania, in thePhilippine Islands; now often made of inferior or adulteratedtabacco.
Conclusive; decisive; definitive; final. [Obs.] Greene (1593).
Not near; not close to; at a distance from. [Obs.] Davies(Muse's Sacrifice).
Like a polyp; having the nature of a polyp, but lacking thetentacles or other parts.
To work in, as lace; to embellish with work resembling lace;also, to lace or enlace. P. Fletcher.
A red Madeira wine, wanting the high aroma of the white sorts,and, when old, resembling tawny port.
To relinquish all claim to; -- used when an insured persongives up to underwriters all claim to the property covered by apolicy, which may remain after loss or damage by a peril insuredagainst.
Distinct markings resembling the variegations of marble, as onbirds and insects.
Distance north or south of the equator, measured on a meridian.
The act of pleading for or supporting; work of advocating;intercession.
A loose outer garment worn the 16th and 17th centuries.
The system of drains and their operation, by which superfluouswater is removed from towns, railway beds, mines, and other works.
A composition resembling ivory in appearance and used as asubstitute for it.
A chair, litter, or other contrivance fitted to the back orpack saddle of a mule for carrying travelers in mountainousdistricts, or for the transportation of the sick and wounded of anarmy.
A dome parallel to the longer lateral axis of an orthorhombiccrystal. See Dome, n., 4.
To break into bends, turns, or angles; to crinkle.Old Veg's stream . . . drew her humid train aslope, Crankling herbanks. J. Philips.
A hydrous sulphate of lead and copper occurring in bright bluemonoclinic crystals.
A genus of American Eocene mammals allied to the horse, buthaving four toes in front and three behind.
A half wolf; a mongrel dog, between a dog and a wolf.
A bond or pledge for appearance before a judge on a certainday. [Obs.]
A case for trial which can not be tried during the term; apostponed case. [Eng.]
To divest of garniture; to disfurnish; to dismantle. Bp. Hall.
A kind of pillar; a cylindrical or polygonal support for aroof, ceiling, statue, etc., somewhat ornamented, and usuallycomposed of base, shaft, and capital. See Order.
A substance resembling pyroxylin, obtained by the action ofnitric acid on starch; -- called also nitramidin.
The pricking of a horse's foot in nailing on a shoe.
A diseased condition of the system, brought about by thecontinued use of alcoholic liquors.
A fabulous winged animal, half horse and half griffin. Milton.
Close-fitting garments, especially for the lower part of thebody and the legs.
Of or pertaining to Saint Vincent de Paul, or founded by him.[R.]
The inspissated juice of the Papaver somniferum, or whitepoppy.
A salt formed by the combination of ambreic acid with a base orpositive radical.
In a ropy manner; in a viscous or glutinous manner.
The American quail or bobwhite. The name is also applied toother related species. See Bobwhite.
A blur, or an appearance of a double impression, as when thepaper slips a little; a mackle.
A short, distorted hand; also, the deformity of having such ahand.
In a converse manner; with change of order or relation;reciprocally. J. S. Mill.
Over the rest in authority; above all others; highest. [Obs.]Fabyan.
A covering; -- applied especially to the bundles oflongitudinal fibers in the upper part of the crura of the cerebrum.
A liquid measure equal to four gills, or an imperial pint.[Scot.]
Anything added to raise the sides of a ship. Bailey.
One who receives baptism on a sick bed. [Obs.] Hook.
Giddiness; a whirling sensation in the head; vertigo.
The South American lapwing (Vanellus Cayennensis). Its wingsare furnished with short spurs. Called also Cayenne lapwing.
One who carries the cross before an archbishop. [Obs.]
A sort of fillet worn by dignitaries, priests, and others amongthe ancient Romans. It was generally white.
Of the nature of, or by means of, a paction. Bp. Sanderson.
A shirt worn next the skin, under another shirt; -- called alsoundervest.
The contents or substance of the ovum; egg yolk. See Illust. ofOvum.
A customhouse clearance for a coasting vessel; a permit.
A process of bone formation in which ossification takes placewithin the substance of the cartilage.
A spirituous liquor distilled by the Chinese from the yeastyliquor in which boiled rice has fermented under pressure. S. W.Williams.
The bending or twining of any part of a plant toward one sideor the other, or in any direction from the vertical.
A genus of valuable trees, including the true walnut of Europe,and the America black walnut, and butternut.
A light, covered, four-wheeled pleasure carriage with twoseats.
An instrument for measuring depths, esp. one for takingsoundings without a sounding line.
Antimonic; -- used with reference to certain compounds ofantimony.
A wooden flat-bottomed boat, a metallic cylinder, or a framecovered with canvas, India rubber, etc., forming a portable float,used in building bridges quickly for the passage of troops.
One who has been fondled to excess; one fond of ease andsensual delights; -- a term of contempt.
The hypothetical radical C4H3S, regarded as the essentialresidue of thiophene and certain of its derivatives.
Insurrection; commotion; disturbance. [Obs.] Sir J. Cheke.
A confidential officer employed in the service of the tribunal,especially in apprehending and imprisoning the accused.
An instrument for describing circles, measuring figures, etc.,consisting of two, or (rarely) more, pointed branches, or legs,usually joined at the top by a rivet on which they move.
An apparatus resembling a Jacquard for weaving small figures(usually about 12 - 16 threads, seldom more than 36 - 40 threads).
A bull issued by a pope in the period between his election andcoronation.
In a wild manner; without cultivation; with disorder; rudely;distractedly; extravagantly.
To examine or search thoroughly; to exhaust a remedy against,as against a principal debtor before proceeding against the surety.Burrill.
To rail in; to inclose or surround, as with rails. Hooker.
The quality or state of being puny; littleness; pettiness;feebleness.
A woman plaintiff, or complainant, in equity pleading. Burrill.
A note or memorandum, esp. one containing an enumeration ofdocuments.
A disease affecting grapes, esp. in California, manifested bythe premature dropping of the fruit.
One who rides over a post road to carry the mails. Bancroft.
A figure supposed to resemble an apple; a roundel, -- always ofa green color.
To walk with labor, or heavily; to tramp. [Law, U. S.]Bartlett.
One who makes trees his study, or who is versed in theknowledge of trees. Howell.
To declare elapsed, as the time allowed for introducingevidence. Sir W. Scott.
Mannite; -- so called because found in the pomegranate.
An animal (usually an old mare), wearing a bell and acting asthe leader of a troop of pack mules. [S. America]
Rising to a point; conical; copped. [Obs.] Woodward.
A tribe of Indians inhabiting New Mexico and Arizona, allied tothe Apaches. They are now largely engaged in agriculture.
The process of smooth filing by working the file sidewiseinstead of lengthwise.
A made-up story; stuff; nonsense; humbug; -- often anexclamation of contempt.
A living plant set to grow, esp. when set for a hedge;specifically, the hawthorn.
The day following Whitsunday; -- called also Whitsun Monday.
In a selfish manner; with regard to private interest only orchiefly.
The evening star; Hesper; Venus, when seen after sunset; hence,the evening. Shak.
Having two of the intersections between the three axes oblique.See Crystallization.
One of a court of about one hundred judges chosen to try civilsuits. Under the empire the court was increased to 180, and metusually in four sections.
A broken state; decrepitude; an impaired state of theintellect.
A morbid condition in which the blood contains black pigmenteither floating freely or imbedded in the white blood corpuscles.
A road prepared for easy transit of trams or wagons, by formingthe wheel tracks of smooth beams of wood, blocks of stone, or platesof iron.
A species of divination, by means of an ax or hatchet.
A substance resembling gutta-percha, and used to adulterate it,obtained from the East Indian tree Isonandra acuminata.
Small grains or dust of cochineal or the coccus insect.
One of the veins of the neck when swollen with anger or otherexcitement. [Obs.]
An alkaloid obtained from the Buxus sempervirens, or common boxtree. It is identical with bebeerine; -- called also buxina.
A stick or switch used among some American Indians in making orcounting a coup.
A cavity in the primary nectocalyx of certain Siphonophora. SeeIllust. under Nectocalyx.
One who has shaken off restraint; a prodigal. [Obs.] Cotgrave.
Of or pertaining to Acheron; infernal; hence, dismal, gloomy;moribund.
Such things, in respect to infants, lunatics, and marriedwomen, as are requisite for support suitable to station.
In the United States navy, a sick-bay nurse; -- now officiallydesignated as hospital apprentice.
Relating to the production of light by the lower animals.
A small British lake whitefish (Coregonus clupeoides, or C.ferus); -- called also gwyniad and lake herring.
That part of the army, in Germany and Austria, which hascompleted the usual military service and is exempt from duty in timeof peace, except that it is called out occasionally for drill.
Cotton cloth, printed with flowers and other devices, in anumber of different colors, and often glazed. Swift.
To inclose or defend with a bank or banks. See Embank.
A voracious ganoid fish (Amia calva) found in the fresh watersof the United States; the mudfish; -- called also Johnny Grindle, anddogfish.
A window placed in the roof of a building, in the ceiling of aroom, or in the deck of a ship, for the admission of light fromabove.
A California rosaceous shrub (Adenostoma fasciculatum) whichoften forms an impenetrable chaparral.
A compact granular cryptocrystalline mineral of a dull grayishor greenish white color. It is a hydrous alkaline silicate, and isderived from the alteration of other minerals, as iolite.

A spiral scroll which forms the chief feature of the Ioniccapital, and which, on a much smaller scale, is a feature in theCorinthian and Composite capitals. See Illust. of Capital, alsoHelix, and Stale.
that which gives a rotary or rolling motion, as a muscle whichpartially rotates or turns some part on its axis.
Something that whirls or turns about in a rapid manner; awhirligig.
A person devoted to worldly pleasure. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
To ordain or appoint for some purpose along with another.
In the university of Cambridge, England, one who pays for hisliving in commons; -- corresponding to commoner at Oxford. Ld.Lytton.
A roundish, flattened, sesamoid bone in the tendon in front ofthe knee joint; the patella; the kneecap.
The quality or state of being tall; height of stature.
To use persuasion; to plead; to prevail by persuasion. Shak.
An old Portuguese coin, worth about seventy cents. [Writtenalso cruade.] Shak.
One who propounds, proposes, or offers for consideration.Chillingworth.
Turbid; muddy. [Scot. & Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Wodroephe (1623).Burns.
A collection of small houses surrounded by a wall and occupiedby a community of Beguines.
Of or pertaining to, or designating, a certain thionic acid,H2S3O6 which is obtained as a colorless, odorless liquid.
A hypothetical radical of quinine and related alkaloids.
A large and valuable sparoid food fish (Archosargus, orDiplodus, probatocephalus) found on the Atlantic coast of the UnitedStates. It often weighs from ten to twelve pounds.
A proteid substance (acid albumin) formed from the albuminousmatter of muscle by the action of dilute acids; -- formerly calledmusculin. See Acid albumin, under Albumin.
The innermost sanctuary or shrine in ancient temples, whenceoracles were given. Hence: A private chamber; a sanctum.
A chief priest; also, a kind of vicar, or a rural dean.

A degraded form of superstition and sorcery, said to includehuman sacrifices and cannibalism in some of its rites. It isprevalent among the negroes of Hayti, and to some extent in theUnited States, and is regarded as a relic of African barbarism.
The joint or interstice between stones, to be filled withmortar. Gwilt.
A supposed new metallic element. It is said to have beendiscovered in pyrites, and some other minerals, and to be of asilver-white color, and malleable.
A play for representation or exhibition by moving pictures;also, the moving-picture representation of a play.
The hypothetical radical C3H7, regarded as the essentialresidue of propane and related compounds.
A body or space contained under a single surface, which inevery part is equally distant from a point within called its center.
The person to whom a guaranty is made; -- the correlative ofguarantor.
The lapse or interval of time between two events. [R.] Harvey.
A garment worn throughout the Levant, consisting of a long gownwith sleeves reaching below the hands. It is generally fastened by abelt or sash.
That part of the skeleton of the hind or lower limb between thetarsus and phalanges; metatarse. It consists, in the human foot, offive bones. See Illustration in Appendix.
Pertaining to the country, people, or language of Biscay;Basque [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Having the margins only a little curved; -- said of leaves.Henslow.
The posterior part of the alimentary canal, including therectum, and sometimes the large intestine also.
Originally, a dealer in any kind of goods or wares; nowrestricted to a dealer in textile fabrics, as silks or woolens.[Eng.]
The process of artificially repairing lesions by taking a pieceof healthy tissue, as from a neighboring part, to supply thedeficiency caused by disease or wounds.
The delicate bands of connective tissue interspersed amongmuscular fibers.
Having the quality of acting upon or affecting the nerves;quieting nervous excitement.-- n.
A part of the alimentary canal. See under Mesenteron.
A carbohydrate, isomeric with cane sugar, contained in gumarabic, from which it is extracted as a white, amorphous substance.
One of the common people; a low person; also, the common peopleas a class or estate in a country.
A second lending of the same thing; a renewal of a loan.
One aiming at or pretending to a greater purity of like thanothers about him; -- applied to persons of various sects. SeeAlbigenses.
A dwarf wall or partition carried up to a certain height forseparation and protection, as in a church, to separate the aisle fromthe choir, or the like.
The skin of a dog, or leather made of the skin. Also usedadjectively.
To become channeled, as a candle when the flame flares in thewind.
The name of several plants of the genera Spermacoce and Diodia,of the Madder family.
A discharge of fetid matter from the nostril, particularly ifassociated with ulceration of the soft parts and disease of the bonesof the nose.
an argument from the cause to the effect; an a priori argument.Johnson.
A solid of five sides, having a rectangular base, tworectangular or trapezoidal sides meeting in an edge, and twotriangular ends.
One of numerous species of long-winged, shrikelike birds ofAustralia and the East Indies, of the genus Artamus, and alliedgenera; called also wood swallow.
Sung or played in a restless, hurried, and spasmodic manner.
Containing or resembling brimstone; sulphurous. B. Jonson.
Pertaining to, or designating, an organic amido acid, which isregarded as a derivative of lactic acid and urea.
A genus of large extinct Eocene mammals from Wyoming; -- calledalso Uintatherium. See Illustration in Appendix.
Eager or immoderate excitement or action; the state ofturgescence of any organ; erethism; esp., the height of venerealexcitement in sexual intercourse.
The evil and malicious disposition of Satan; a diabolicalsprit. [R.]
A granary; a building or place where grain is stored forpreservation.
A substance obtained from euchroic acid. See Eychroic.
The European smooth blenny (Blennius pholis). It is olive-greenwith irregular black spots, and without appendages on the head.
An annual plant of the genus Iberis, cultivated in gardens. Thename was originally given to the I. umbellata, first, discovered inthe island of Candia.
To walk or run about in an idle or slatternly manner; totraipse. [Obs. or Colloq.]
The act of eating out or through. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Of or pertaining to uxoricide; tending to uxoricide.
The science or study of Egyptian antiquities, esp. thehieroglyphics.
A medicine which eats away extraneous growths; a caustic.
To forbid; to renounce; to forsake; to deny. [Obs.] Spenser.
Having the appearance of ruins, or of the ruins of houses; --said of certain minerals.
To convert into opal, or a substance like opal. Lyell.
The front median plate of the labium in insects. See Labium.
A regaining; recovery of something lost. [Obs.] Bacon.
A house where ale is retailed; hence, a tippling house.Macaulay.
A mineral, consisting of the sulphates of soda and lime.

One of a race of giants, sons of Neptune and Amphitrite, havingbut one eye, and that in the middle of the forehead. They were fabledto inhabit Sicily, and to assist in the workshops of Vulcan, underMt. Etna.

A genus of minute insects parasitic, in their larval state, onbees and wasps. It is the typical genus of the group Strepsiptera,formerly considered a distinct order, but now generally referred tothe Coleoptera. See Strepsiptera.
Of or pertaining to parricide; guilty of parricide.
A wooden rattle sometimes used as a substitute for a bell, inthe Roman Catholic church, during the latter part of Holy Week, orthe last week of Lent.
A short caulis or stem, esp. the rudimentary stem seen in theembryo of seed; -- otherwise called a radicle.
Of or pertaining to an orchestra; suitable for, or performed inor by, an orchestra.
A female servant or attendant; specifically, as a term of thetheater, a lady's maid, in comedies, who acts the part of anintrigante; a meddlesome, mischievous female servant or young woman.
A garment worn by men and boys, extending from the waist to theknee or to the ankle, and covering each leg separately. pants; usedattrib. in the singular, as a trouser leg; see pant
Any seasoning preparation used to stuff meat; especially, acomposition of bread, condiments, spices, etc.; forcemeat; dressing.
A place near the fire or hearth; home; domestic life orretirement.
The milk secreted just before, or directly after, the birth ofa child or of the young of an animal; colostrum.
An unnatural collection of serous fluid in any serous cavity ofthe body, or in the subcutaneous cellular tissue. Dunglison.
Pointing two ways, as leaves that grow only on opposite sidesof a branch; in two vertical rows.
A discharge or flowing of humors or fluid matter, as from thenose in catarrh; -- sometimes used synonymously with inflammation.Dunglison.
Invested by a sheath, or cylindrical membranaceous tube, whichis the base of the leaf, as the stalk or culm in grasses; vaginate.
The smaller of the two otoliths found in the inner ear of manyfishes.
A contriver; an inventor; a contriver of engines. [Obs.] Shak.
Unnatural softness of any organ or part. Dunglison.
A positive statement of facts; an allegation; an offer tojustify or prove what is alleged.
The four "liberal arts," arithmetic, music, geometry, andastronomy; -- so called by the schoolmen. See Trivium.
A colorless, crystalline, nitrogenous base, obtained by thedecomposition of cocaine.
Of or pertaining to prey; plundering; predatory. [R.] Boyse.
To pasture; to feed; to graze; also, to use for pasture. [R.]Cattle, to graze and departure in his grounds. Blackstone.A right to cut wood upon or departure land. Washburn.
To gaze; to overlook. [Poetic] "Earth's o'ergazing mountains."Byron.
A form of hygrometer having wet and dry bulb thermometers, withan adjustable index showing directly the percentage of moisture inthe air, etc.
A hot, oppressive wind which sometimes blows in theMediterranean, particularly on the eastern coast of Spain.
Like a companion; companionable; on equal terms; sympathetic.[Obs.] Udall.
A kind of linen cloth anciently used in England, originallyimported from Brittany. Shak.
A species of Magnolia (M. conspicua) with large white blossomsthat open before the leaves. See the Note under Magnolia.
A transparent mucous discharge from the membrane of theurethra, commonly an effect of gonorrhea. Hoblyn.
One of several American marine fishes. See Sea robin, andGrunt, n., 2.
An instrument for executing minute writing or engraving.
Collared; having a torques, or distinct colored ring around theneck.
Drawing together; contracting; -- said of the corrugator.[Obs.]
One who kills a human being; one who commits manslaughter.
Suitable for walking; -- said of the limbs of an animal whenadapted for walking on land.
An extinct genus of huge vertebrates, probably dinosaurs, knownonly from four-toed tracks in Triassic sandstones.
One of two or more words identical in orthography, but havingdifferent derivations and meanings; as, fair, n., a market, and fair,a., beautiful.
The drink of the gods (as ambrosia was their food); hence, anydelicious or inspiring beverage.
The seventh or last day of the week; the day following Fridayand preceding Sunday.
Plaited strips or bark, cane, straw, etc., used for making hatsor the like.
One of the steps in which a gable wall is often finished inplace of a continuous slope; -- also called crowstep.
Of or pertaining to a finger or toe, or to the claw of aninsect crustacean.
The state of having, or being full of, ears like corn. [R.]Bailey.
A fish of the genus Silurus, as the sheatfish; a siluroid.
The ramus of the lower jaw of a bird as far as it is naked; --commonly used in the plural.
The act of thrusting or pushing out; a driving out; expulsion.
Of, pertaining to, or containing, argument; argumentative.
Pertaining to the foot, or to any organ called a foot; pedal.Dana.
, One who, or that which, qualifies; that which modifies,reduces, tempers or restrains.
To greet again; to resalute; to return a salutation to; togreet. Shak.
One who regards Father, Son, and Spirit as modes of being, andnot as persons, thus denying personal distinction in the Trinity.Eadie.
An orange-red crystalline substance, C15H10O5, obtained fromthe buckthorn, rhubarb, etc., and regarded as a derivative ofanthraquinone; -- so called from a species of rhubarb (Rheum emodei).
A hydrous sulphate of iron of a deep red color. It often occursin botryoidal form.
Containing tartar; consisting of tartar, or partaking of itsqualities; tartareous.
Any ruminant of the genus Rangifer, of the Deer family, foundin the colder parts of both the Eastern and Western hemispheres, andhaving long irregularly branched antlers, with the brow tinespalmate.
Quicklime; also, plaster or mortar. [India] Whitworth.
Plain India muslin, of various qualities and widths.
A scheme or desire to unite all the Slavic races into oneconfederacy.
To convert into, or cause to resemble, glass or a glassysubstance, by heat and fusion.
To bite by little at a time; to seize gently with the mouth; toeat slowly or in small bits.Thy turfy mountains, where live nibbling sheep. Shak.
Somewhat resembling the Roman; -- applied sometimes to thedebased style of the later Roman empire, but esp. to the moredeveloped architecture prevailing from the 8th century to the 12th.
Having two balls or protuberances at each end; -- said of across.
Having a tendency by nature; prone; proclivous. [R.] Mrs.Browning.
A recessed portion of a room, or a small room opening into alarger one; especially, a recess to contain a bed; a lateral recessin a library.
Of or pertaining to breathing; suited to the inhaling of air
The act of burying with funeral rites. [Obs.] Knatchbull.
To insert, as one piece of timber into another, by alternatescores or projections from the middle, to prevent slipping; to scarf.
A young salmon after its first return from the sea.
In the mind; in thought or meditation; intellectually; in idea.
The flower of a rose before it opens, or when but partiallyopen.
The science which treats of the structure and functions of thestomach; a treatise of the stomach.
In the Ethiopic church, a small building attached to a churchedifice, in which the bread for the eucharist is made. Audsley.
Possessing only small coins; impoverished. [R.] Lamb.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a complex organic acidproduced as a white crystalline substance by the action of nitrousacid on hydroquinone.
A sheet of partially felted fur before it is united to the hatbody. Knight.
Descending from the same stock or ancestor, but not in the sameline or branch or one from the other; -- opposed to lineal.
Farthest toward the south; southernmost. [R.] Milton.
To renew or renovate; to instaurate. [Obs.] Marston.
A motion in dancing, when one leg is a little bent, and raisedfrom the floor, and with the other a forward motion is made.Chambers.
A colorless, oily liquid, formerly obtained by distillation ofcolophony. It is regarded as a polymeric form of terebenthene. Calledalso diterebene.
Either one of the three common American scaup ducks. See Scaupduck, under Scaup.
To compare (a proof) with a previous proof of the same matter,and mark again such errors as have not been corrected in the type.

A cutting or engraving; a figure cut into something, as a gem,so as to make a design depressed below the surface of the material;hence, anything so carved or impressed, as a gem, matrix, etc.; --opposed to cameo. Also used adjectively.
Capable of being gathered or collected; deducible frompremises. [R.] Godwin.

An Appalachian tribe of Indians, formerly inhabiting the regionabout the head waters of the Tennessee River. They are now mostlysettled in the Indian Territory, and have become one of the mostcivilized of the Indian Tribes.
