Hydrous sesquixoide of iron, an important ore of iron,occurring in stalactitic, mammillary, or earthy forms, of a darkbrown color, yellowish brown powder. It includes bog iron. Alsocalled brown hematite.
The name of several poisonous umbelliferous herbs having finelycut leaves and small white flowers, as the Cicuta maculata,bulbifera, and virosa, and the Conium maculatum. See Conium.
One who gets, gains, obtains, acquires, begets, or procreates.
Any extension of a church behind the higggggggh altar, as achapel; also, in an apsidal church, all the space beyond the line ofthe back or eastern face of the altar.
A short blunt arrow for killing birds without piercing them.Hence: Anything which smites without penetrating. Shak.
Wanting a distinct meaning; having no certain signification.[R.] Puller.
A present, as of corn, wine, or oil, made by a Roman emperor tothe soldiers or the people; -- so called because measured to each ina congius. Addison.
The theory or doctrine that the human races have a commonorigin, or constitute a single species.
Any organ of an animal having a structure adapted to produce aratting sound.
The quality or state of being produced by nature. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
A receding or giving up; a complete surrender. [Colloq.]
The sprout at the end of a seed when it begins to germinate;the plumule in germination; -- so called from its spiral form.
A throwing or tossing of the body; a shaking or agitation. Sir.W. Temple.
Pertaining to, or derived from, or designating, an organic acidobtained by the decomposition of phloretin.
Ossification which takes place in purely fibrous tracts; theformation of bone outside of the periosteum.
A minute smooth rodlike or fusiform structure found in thetissues of many Turbellaria.
A kind of worsted braid, about an inch broad. [Scot.] Jamieson.
A writ commanding the sheriff to distrain a person by his goodsor chattels, to compel a compliance with something required of him.
A plant (Eryngium foetidum) supposed to be a remedy for fits.
Living through the winter, or from year to year; perennial.[R.]
A soothsaying; a foretelling. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Pertaining to, or designating, one of several isomeric acidsobtained from citric acid.
A style of type having a narrow and heave face. It is made inall sizes.
A small European kinglet (Regulus ignicapillus), having abright red crest; -- called also fire-crested wren.
Mild as a dove; gentle; pure and lovable. Longfellow.
Resembling the capitulum of burdock; covered with forkedpoints.
An organic base, especially one of a class of substancesoccurring ready formed in the tissues of plants and the bodies ofanimals.
A bending downward; a sloping; incurvation downward; declivity.[R.] Davies (Wit's Pilgr.)
A receptacle, as in a dining room, for a few bottles of wine orliquor, made in the form of a chest or coffer, or a deep drawer in asideboard, and usually lined with metal.
Having the faculty of speech but imperfectly developed orpartially lost.
The inflicting of retributive punishment; satisfaction taken.[R.] Milton.
A small lobe in the under surface of the cerebellum, near themiddle peduncle; the subpeduncular lobe.
The space between the strands on the outside of a rope. Knight.
The citadel of a town or city; especially, the citadel ofMoscow, a large inclosure which contains imperial palaces,cathedrals, churches, an arsenal, etc. [Russia]
Waved obtusely up and down, near the margin, as a leaf orcorolla; wavy.
A bench or board on which work is performed; a workbench.South.

An order of Entomostraca including a large number of species,most of which live in fresh water. They have flattened or leaflikelegs, often very numerous, which they use in swimming. Called alsoBranchiopoda.
A pleasing or sweet sound; an easy, smooth enunciation ofsounds; a pronunciation of letters and syllables which is pleasing tothe ear.
A system of working in ore, etc., when it lies not in strata orveins, but in solid masses, so as to be worked in chambers orstories.
The cavity from which the earth for parapets, etc. (remblai),is taken.

A low four-wheeled carriage used in Russia. The carriage boxrests on two long, springy poles which run from the fore to the hindaxletree. When snow falls, the wheels are taken off, and the body ismounted on a sledge.
A glimpse or flash of the sun. [Scot.] Sir W. Scott.
An obligation by which property of a debtor was made over tohis creditor in security of his debt.
A group of rocks having a common age or origin; -- nearlyequivalent to formation, but used somewhat less comprehensively.
In an apish manner; with servile imitation; foppishly.
To reduce to a unit, or one whole; to form into a unit; tounify.
Capable of being succored or assisted; admitting of relief.
A European owl (Syrnium aluco) of a tawny color; -- called alsouluia.
To release, as one thing stuck to another. Richardson.
The adjustable socket, or step, of a millstone spindle. Knight.
A bare axis or cylinder with staves or levers in it to turn itround, but without any drum.

Of camel's hair. Camel's-hair pencil, a small brush used bypainters in water colors, made of camel's hair or similar materials.-- Camel's-hair shawl. A name often given to a cashmere shawl. SeeCashmere shawl under Cashmere.
The act or process of discharging anything from the body,particularly the excretions.
One of the rowers on the topmost of the three benches in atrireme.
A sacred or holy work or worship. [Obs.] Waterland.
To grow to an inferior, or less than the usual, size or height.Wyclif.
One who enters a religious house, whether of monks or nuns, asa probationist. Shipley.No poore cloisterer, nor no novys. Chaucer.
The second month of the calendar adopted by the first Frenchrepublic. It began thirty days after the autumnal equinox. SeeVendemiaire.
Inclined or able to range, or rove about, for considerabledistances; apt or suited for much roving, --chiefly used of cattle.
Diligence; care; persevering endeavor. [Obs.] Milton.
A tribe of North American Indians formerly inhabiting thecountry from the upper Missouri River to the Saskatchewan, but nowmuch reduced in numbers.
One of the peculiar minute chitinous hooks found in largenumbers in the tori of tubicolous annelids belonging to the Uncinata.
Any of two or more narrow paths, of steel, smooth stone, or thelike, laid in a public roadway otherwise formed of an inferiorpavement, as cobblestones, to provide an easy way for wheels.
The art of healing; skill of a physician. [Archaic] Chaucer.
A luminous image or appearance of a hallucinatory character.
Having four branches diverging at right angles; -- said ofcertain spicules of sponges.
So as to secure approbation; in an approved manner.
A chime of bells diatonically tuned, played by clockwork or byfinger keys.
A poisonous amido acid, C6H13NO2, separated by Brieger fromdecaying horseflesh. In physiological action, it is similar tocurare.
Capable of resisting bombs or other shells; bombproof.
The plural of himself, herself, and itself. See Himself,Herself, Itself.
Of or pertaining to the vagus, or pneumogastric nerves;pneumogastric.
The young of the great black-backed gull (Larus marinus),formerly considered a distinct species. [Prov. Eng.]
Tending or relating to a purpose or an end. [R.] Cudworth.
The act of selecting, or the state of being selected; choice,by preference.
A genus of Foraminifera, having a porcelanous shell withseveral longitudinal chambers.
Containing heresy; of the nature of, or characterized by,heresy.
The operation of expelling one substance from another by heat,as sulphur or arsenic from ores, in a muffle.
A comprehensive division of animals including all Vertebratatogether with the Tunicata, or all those having a dorsal nervouscord.
A degeneration of animal tissue into a cheesy or curdy mass.
The state or quality of being fishy or fishlike. Pennant.
The second lateral plate in the plastron of turtles; -- calledalso hyosternum.
The outer, hardened integument which covers most hydroids.
An oyster which has the gills tinged with a green pigment, saidto be due to an abnormal condition of the blood.
A species of poem of a mournful character, in which a singlemourner expresses lamentation; a song for one voice.
To hold or value too highly; to estimate at too dear a rate.[Obs.] Shak.
A heron. [Written variously hernshaw, harnsey, etc.]
The perceptive faculty concerned with the ability to rememberthe relative positions of places.
A substance analogous to chloranil but containing bromine inplace of chlorine.
The tissue which fills the cavities of most bones; the medulla.In the larger cavities it is commonly very fatty, but in the smallercavities it is much less fatty, and red or reddish in color.
Of or pertaining to Myrmica, a genus of ants including thesmall house ant (M. molesta), and many others.
An alkaloid extracted from fumitory, as a white crystallinesubstance.
In a puffing manner; with vehement breathing or shortness ofbreath; with exaggerated praise.
A small village containing a church. [Scot.] Sir W. ScottSitting at the clachon alehouse. R. L. Stevenson.
An aromatic composite herb, the costmary; also, the SouthEuropean Achillea Ageratum, a kind of yarrow.
The descent of the moon below the horizon; also, the time whenthe moon sets.
The introduction of a tube into an organ to keep it open, asinto the larynx in croup.
, adv. In a fell or cruel manner; fiercely; barbarously;savagely. Spenser.
A substance (C6H5.N2.C6H5) derived from nitrobenzene, formingorange red crystals which are easily fusible.
A North American plant (Collinsonia Canadensis) having a veryhard root; horse balm. See Horse balm, under Horse.
To act the part of a patron towards; to patronize. [Obs.] Shak.
A bamboo frame or trellis hung at a door or window of a house,over which water is suffered to trickle, in order to moisten and coolthe air as it enters. [India]
An aggregate or collection of rays of light, especially whendiverging from, or converging to, a point.
In the manner of a duke, or in a manner becoming the rank of aduke.
An East Indian plant of the genus Curcuma, of the Gingerfamily.
To reason falsely; to draw conclusions not warranted by thepremises. [R.]
A perennial rosaceous herb (Potentilla Anserina) having theleaves silvery white beneath.

A linguistic family or stock of North American Indians,comprising many tribes, which extends from Montana and Idaho intoMexico. In a restricted sense the name is applied especially to theSnakes, the most northern of the tribes.
A specied of wild sheep (Ovis Hodgsonii), native of Nepaul andThibet. It has a dorsal mane and a white ruff beneath the neck.
America; the United States; -- a poetical appellation given inhonor of Columbus, the discoverer. Dr. T. Dwight.
The place where an almoner resides, or where alms aredistributed.
One employed on work on the track; specif., a trackwalker.
The quality or state of being like a vulture; rapaciousness.
A lustration or purification, especially the purification ofthe whole Roman people, which was made by the censors once in fiveyears. Hence: A period of five years.
Capable of being employed; capable of being used; fit or properfor use. Boyle.
An underground drain or trench with openings through which thewater may percolate from the soil or ground above.
A defensive covering for the head. See Casque, Headpiece,Morion, Sallet, and Illust. of Beaver.
The quality or state of being grisly; horrid. Sir P. Sidney.
A white, amorphous, deliquescent powder, (CO.H)2, obtained bythe partial oxidation of glycol. It is a double aldehyde, betweenglycol and oxalic acid.
A thick gruel of oatmeal and milk or water; food of theporridge kind. [Scot.]
To take effect or vest again, as a title; to revert to formerowner; as, the title or right revels in A after alienation.
One who founds, establishes, and erects; one who lays afoundation; an author; one from whom anything originates; one whoendows.
Any one of numerous species of Bryozoa belonging to Tubuliporaand allied genera, having tubular calcareous calicles.
A species of mica, of a lilac or rose-violet color, containinglithia. It usually occurs in masses consisting of small scales. SeeMica.
The left-hand side of a ship to one on board facing toward thebow; port; -- opposed to Ant: starboard.
Pertaining to, or designating, a complex organic acid, obtainedas a yellowish white gum by the oxidation of croconic acid.
A flat or somewhat hollowed stone upon which grain or otherfood is ground, by means of a smaller stone or pestle. [SouthwesternU. S. & Sp. Amer.]
One of a peculiar kind of zooids situated on the polyp-stem ofcertain Siphonophora. They somewhat resemble the feeding zooids, butare destitute of mouths. See Siphonophora.
An extinct South American quaternary mammal, allied to thearmadillos. It was as large as an ox, was covered with tessellatedscales, and had fluted teeth. Owen.
A Mohammedan professor or teacher of language. [India]
The quality or state of being sweet (in any sense of theadjective); gratefulness to the taste or to the smell; agreeableness.

Sustained; -- applied to a movement or passage the sounds ofwhich are to sustained to the utmost of the nominal value of thetime; also, to a passage the tones of which are to be somewhatprolonged or protacted.
Each particular taken singly; distinction. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
A morbidly increased discharge of sebaceous matter upon theskin; stearrhea.
A buck in his second year. See Note under 3d Buck. Shak.
To subject to the operation of integration; to find theintegral of.
The punctuation mark [;] indicating a separation between partsor members of a sentence more distinct than that marked by a comma.
One who seeks or asks; a seeker; an applicant. [R.] Fuller.
The use of a picture symbol of an object to representphonetically the initial sound of the name of the object.
That part of military force which serves on horseback.
Of or pertaining to Geneva, in Switzerland; Genevese.
A kind of graduated breech sight for a small arm, or a cannon.
A plant growing on another, as the mistletoe; an epiphyte.[Obs.] Bacon.
To chirp or to make a mournful cry, as a bird. [Obs.] Huloet.
A glucoside found in ripe and unripe fruit (as the orange), andextracted as a white crystalline substance.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid now called maleic acid.
The art of dramatic composition and representation.
One of a group of crystalline bodies produced by the action ofammonia on certain aldehydes.
The act or process of gilding or covering with gold.
The viscid, tenacious substance which gives adhesiveness todough.
A sum of money, payable yearly, to continue for a given numberof years, for life, or forever; an annual allowance.
One who mangles or tears in cutting; one who mutilates any workin doing it.
Having to stomach, or distinct digestive canal, as thetapeworm.
One of the nobility; a noble; a peer; one who enjoys rank abovea commoner, either by virtue of birth, by office, or by patent.
The act of one who stutters; -- restricted by somephysiologists to defective speech due to inability to form the propersounds, the breathing being normal, as distinguished from stammering.
The complement of the latitude, or the difference between anylatitude and ninety degrees.
Having, in some respects, the nature of light; resemblinglight. Berkeley.
An oversight in pleading, or the acknowledgment of a mistake oroversight. Blackstone.
A portion of the Old Testament prepared by Origen in the 3dcentury, containing the Hebrew text and seven Greek versions of it,arranged in eight parallel columns.
Attack at once; -- a direction at the end of a movement to showthat the next is to follow immediately, without any pause.
One who takes pains; one careful and faithful in all work. Gay.
A shop or barroom where gin is sold as a beverage. [Colloq.]
Guaiacol benzoate, used as an intestinal antiseptic and as asubstitute for creosote in phthisis. It is a colorless crystallinepewder.
Not according to the forms of law; not judicial. [R.]
In an agreeing manner (to); correspondingly; agreeably. [Obs.]
To pass, or to draw off, (as steam) through narrow ports, orthe like, thus reducing its pressure or force by friction.
A daughter of one's stepfather or stepmother by a formermarriage.
The green mineral characteristic of the greensand of the chalkand other formations. It is a hydrous silicate of iron and potash.See Greensand.
A vessel with a perforated cover, for sprinkling with a liquid;a sprinkler.
A disease in which the body is colored blue in its surface,arising usually from a malformation of the heart, which causes animperfect arterialization of the blood; blue jaundice.
An order of Bryozoa in which the anus lies outside the circleof tentacles.
A colorless, oily substance, C4H4O, obtained by distillingcertain organic substances, as pine wood, salts of pyromucic acid,etc.; -- called also tetraphenol.
To unfold or undo, as a tuck; to release from a tuck or fold.

The principles of Dr. Pusey and others at Oxford, England, asexhibited in various publications, esp. in a series which appearedfrom 1833 to 1841, designated " Tracts for the Times;" tractarianism.See Tractarianism.
An Australian insessorial bird (Corcorax melanorhamphus) notedfor the curious actions of the male during the breeding season. It isblack with a white patch on each wing.
The quality or state of being tenable; tenableness.
On the day after the present day; on the next day; on themorrow.Summon him to-morrow to the Tower. Shak.
A small, strong-winged European falcon (Falco subbuteo),formerly trained for hawking.

One of a group of shooting stars which appear yearly about the10th of August, and cross the heavens in paths apparently radiatingfrom the constellation Perseus. They are beleived to be fragmentsonce connected with a comet visible in 1862.
A scarecrow, generally made of feathers tied to a string, hungup to prevent deer from breaking into a place. Halliwell.
Athwart; adversely; unfortunately; peevishly; fretfully; withill humor.
A white crystalline substance, C6H5.C6H5, obtained by leadingbenzene through a heated iron tube. It consists of two benzene orphenyl radicals united.
Inverted; having a position or mode of attachment the reverseof that which is usual.
Relating to Hygeia, the goddess of health; of or pertaining tohealth, or its preservation.
An indirect argument which proves a thing by showing theimpossibility or absurdity of the contrary.
The essential principle of cacao; -- now called theobromine.
Land adjoining a road or highway; the part of a road or highwaythat borders the traveled part. Also used ajectively.
An acquittal, or sentence of a judge declaring and accusedperson innocent. [Obs.]
A crested black monkey (Semnopithecus maurus) of Java.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid (called also lithicacid) found in certain red precipitates of urine. See Uric. [Obs.]
Pertaining to an advocate, or to the maintenance and defense ofsuits.
A room where news is collected and disseminated, or periodicalssold; a reading room supplied with newspapers, magazines, etc.

A French political group, also known as the ConstitutionalRight from its position in the Chambers, mainly monarchists whorallied to the support of the Republic in obedience to the encyclicalput forth by Pope Leo XIII. in Feb., 1892.

An unsymmetrical, divalent, hydrocarbon radical, C2H4 metamericwith ethylene but written thus, CH3.CH to distinguish it from thesymmetrical ethylene, CH2.CH2. Its compounds are derived fromaldehyde. Formerly called also ethidene.
A remedy which restores the natural order of the invertedirritative motions in the animal system. [Obs.] E. Darwin.
The number from which another number is to be subtracted.
A genus of parasitic Acarina, which includes various species ofticks. See Tick, the insect.
Pertaining to moss of the genus Sphagnum, or bog moss;abounding in peat or bog moss.
A Spanish gold coin, no longer issued, varying in value atdifferent times from over fifteen dollars to about five. See Doblonin Sup.
A kind of bellflower, Companula Trachelium, once called ViolaMariana; but it is not a violet.
A genus of beetles without wings, but having short oval elytra;the oil beetles. These beetles are sometimes used instead ofcantharides for raising blisters. See Oil beetle, under Oil.
An injury caused by violent strains or by overloading; -- saidof the backs of horses. Crabb.
A tribe of Pueblo Indians occupying a village in New Mexico, onthe Zuni River.
A person employed to do all kinds of work or business. B.Jonson.
A woman excelling both in beauty and goodness; a fair maid.[Obs.] Spenser.
The Chinese name for a highly prized variety of pale greenjade. See Jade.
Tending to add; making some addition. [R.] Arbuthnot.
The quality or state of being soggy; soddenness; wetness.
A platform; the bottom of a room; a floor; pavement. See Floor,n. Addison.
A medicine that strengthens the stomach and excites its action.
To remove a prop or props from; to deprive of support.
A plant which has no cotyledons, as the dodder and allflowerless plants.
To free from the body; to disembody.Her soul unbodied of the burdenous corse. Spenser.
A small line made of spun yarn, to bind or worm cables, seizetackles, etc.
A mean, worthless fellow; a rascal; a villain; a man withouthonor or virtue.Go, if your ancient, but ignoble bloodHas crept through soundrels ever since the flood. Pope.
Of or pertaining to a semivowel; half cocal; imperfectlysounding.
Of or pertaining to resin; derived from resin; specifically,designating an acid found in certain fossil resins and hydrocarbons.
To lease again; to grant a new lease of; to let back.
Intense fear or dread of the pope, or of the Roman CatholicChurch. [R.]

Of, pertaining to, or derived from, mutton suet; -- applied byChevreul to an oily acid which was obtained from mutton suet, and towhich he attributed the peculiar taste and smell of that substance.The substance has also been called hircin. Watts.
The dignity, office, or government, of a prior. T. Warton.
To mark with points; to separate into sentences, clauses, etc.,by points or stops which mark the proper pauses in expressing themeaning.
The setting of one above another; preference. [R.] Jer. Taylor.

A small North American dace (Minnilus cornutus, or Notropismegalops). The male, in the breeding season, has bright red fins.Called also red dace, and shiner. Applied also to Notropis ardens, ofthe Mississippi valley.
That part of natural history which treats of the ophidians, orserpents.
The edible drupaceous fruit of an Australian tree (Fusanusacuminatus) of the Sandalwood family; -- called also quandang.
A climbing plant (Ullucus officinalis) of the Andes, havingtuberous roots which are used as a substitute for potatoes.
In a leaping position; springing forward; -- applied especiallyto the squirrel, weasel, and rat, also to the cat, greyhound, monkey,etc.
Not moral nor immoral; having no connection with morals; not inthe sphere of morals or ethics; not ethical.
Subdivided into many distinct subordinate parts, which,however, not being jointed to the petiole, are not true leaflets; --said of leaves. Henslow.
The larva of the spiny lobsters (Palinurus and allied genera).Its body is remarkably thin, flat, and transparent; the legs are verylong. Called also glass-crab, and glass-shrimp.
To interweave or twist together.Raddling or working it up like basket work. De Foe.
Affected with ennui; weary in spirits; emotionally exhausted.
An alkaloid accompanying harmaline (in the Peganum harmala),and obtained from it by oxidation. It is a white crystallinesubstance.
The quality or condition of being two or twofold; dualcharacter or usage.
A piece of wood set between two studs, posts, etc., to stiffenand support them.
A gallery, drift, or adit in a mine; also, the end of a driftor gallery; the vein above a drift.
(adv. In a contrary manner; in opposition; on the other side;in opposite ways.
Tasting beforehand; having a foretaste. [R.] Ed. Rev.
A colorless liquid of an agreeable odor, C6H10O, obtained bydistilling a mixture of sugar and lime; -- so called because formerlyregarded as a polymeric modification of acetone.
A medicinal tablet or lozenge; strictly, one of circular form.
One who exlpains geological phenomena by the action of streams.[R.]
A syllogism with three conditional propositions, the majorpremises of which are disjunctively affirmed in the minor. SeeDilemma.
A kind of inferior cigar of a long slender shape, tapered atone end. [Local, U. S.]
A rebated cross, formerly used as a secret emblem, and a commonornament. It is also called gammadion, and swastika.
Work done at a desk, as by a clerk or writer. Tennyson.
A woman of doubtful reputation or suspected character; anadventuress. [Colloq.] De Quincey.
One who makes or favors a version; a translator. [R.]
Athletic or disciplinary exercises; the art of performinggymnastic exercises; also, disciplinary exercises for the intellector character.
One who devises, or gives real estate by will; a testator; --correlative to devisee.
The outer husk, pod, or shell, as of oats, pease, etc.; sheal;shell. [Obs. or Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
The art of making measurements among the stars, or ofdetermining their relative magnitudes.
Strictness, or the doctrine of strictness, in conforming tolaw.
To empty or unload, as the vessels of human system, bybloodletting or by medicine. Copland.
Manufacture of glass; articles or ornamentation made of glass.
One of the bishops of the Episcopal Church of Scotland, whopresides at the meetings of the bishops, and has certain privilegesbut no metropolitan authority. Internat. Cyc.
Direction; command; authoritative admonition. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
A palsy that affects one side only of the body.-- Hem`i"pleg"ic, a.

The C.G.S. unit of magnetic reluctance or resistance, equal tothe reluctance of a centimeter cube of air (or vacuum) betweenparallel faces. Also, a reluctance in which unit magnetomotive forcesets up unit flux.
A coat worn over the other clothing; a greatcoat; a topcoat.
A cotton fabric employed for hangings and furniture coverings,and formerly used for women's under-garments. It is of many patterns,both plain and twilled, and occasionally is printed in colors.
Composed of peat; abounding in peat; resembling peat.
The service formerly required of a tenant, to carry timber fromthe woods to the lord's house. Bailey. Mozley & W.
One who raises sheep for the production of wool.-- Wool"grow`ing, n.
To ply to excess; to exert with too much vigor; to overwork.Milton.
A binary compound of boron with a more positive or basicelement or radical; -- formerly called boruret.
A concretion, or calculus, formed in the gall bladder orbiliary passages. See Calculus, n., 1.
The doctrine of certain extreme adherents or disciples ofDescartes and Johann Gottlieb Fichte, which finds all the elements ofknowledge in the ego and the relations which it implies or providesfor.
A plane of fracture, or divisional plane, of a rock transverseto the stratification.
A figure in which the idea is expressed by two nouns connectedby and, instead of by a noun and limiting adjective; as, we drinkfrom cups and gold, for golden cups.
Not behooving or becoming; unseemly. [Obs. & R.] Gower.
A thin piece placed between two parts to hold or adjust them,fill a space, etc., ; a shim.
A dealer in cogware or coarse cloth. [Obs.] Wright.
One who claims; one who asserts a right or title; a claimer.
The art or act of recognizing the presence of disease from itssigns or symptoms, and deciding as to its character; also, thedecision arrived at.
The saving of a son or a slave with the father's or master'sconsent; a little property or stock of one's own; any exclusivepersonal or separate property. Burrill.
A niche near the altar in a church, containing a small basinfor rinsing altar vessels.
Without events; tame; monotomous; marked by nothing unusual;uneventful.
Any long, slender nematode worm, especially the pinworm andfilaria.

State of being adjusted to a certain wave length; agreement ortuning between the time period of an apparatus emitting electricoscillations and that of a receiving apparatus, esp. in wirelesstelegraphy.
One learned in science; a scientific investigator; one devotedto scientific study; a savant. [Recent]
Measurement of life; calculation of the probable duration ofhuman life.
Young cabbage, used as "greens"; esp. a kind cultivated forthat purpose; colewort. [Colloq. Souther U. S.]
To put money to usury; to lend on interest. [Obs.] Cockeram.
To think; to deliberate; to muse; -- usually followed by on orover. Longfellow.
To wind, or wrap; especially, to wind a rope round, as a mastor yard made of two or more pieces, at the place where it has beenfished or scarfed, in order to strengthen it.
A prostrate filiform stem or runner, as of the strawbwrry. SeeRunner.
A salt formed by the combination of azotous, or nitrous, acidwith a base; a nitrite. [R.]
A folded piece of cloth, pledget of lint, etc., used to coverthe dressing of wounds, and so placed as, by the aid of a bandage, tomake due pressure on any part.
Such as can be presented in opposition; that may be put forwardas an objection. [R.]
Hydrous sulphate of magnesia found at the salt mines ofStassfurt, Prussian Saxony.
Attached partly to an organ or limb and partly to some otherpartintrinsic.
To divide into plots or parts; to apportion. Milton.
That which is obvious, public, or common.Dealing out exoteries only to the vulgar. A. Tucker.
The Cornus, a genus of large shrubs or small trees, the wood ofwhich is exceedingly hard, and serviceable for many purposes.
A writing, as the means of giving formal expression to someact; a writing expressive of some act, contract, process, as a deed,contract, writ, etc. Burrill.
Varieties of kersey; also, trousers made of kersey.
A patrolman; also, a policeman who acts as an inspector overthe rounds of the patrolmen.

To hew less than is usual or proper; specifically, to hew, as apiece of timber which should be square, in such a manner that itappears to contain a greater number of cubic feet than it really doescontain. Haldeman.
An evergreen Chinese shrub of the Magnolia family (Illiciumanisatum), and its aromatic seeds; Chinese anise; star anise.
A zeolite occuring in groups of glassy acicular crystals, andin masses which often have a radiated structure. It is a hydroussilicate of alumina and soda.
An instrument for measuring the intensity of light, or, moreespecially, for comparing the relative intensities of differentlights, or their relative illuminating power.
A nearly pellucid variety of feldspar, showing pearly oropaline reflections from within. It is used as a gem. The bestspecimens come from Ceylon.
Belief in, or the practice of, the obi superstitions and rites.
Of or pertaining to a climate; depending on, or limited by, aclimate.
An upright or curved piece of timber connecting the plank sheerwith the gunwale; also, a scroll terminating a rail.
An oily substance, C8H14, obtained from several derivatives ofconine.
to assert or confirm, as a judgment, decree, or order, broughtbefore an appelate court for review.
An amorphous huminlike substance resembling sacchulmic acid,and produced together with it.
A disease of the skin, in which a diffused inflammation formsrose-colored patches of variable size.
A circle, or disk, or any indication of radiant light aroundthe heads of divinities, saints, and sovereigns, upon medals,pictures, etc.; a halo. See Aureola, and Glory, n., 5.
To wander without a settled habitation; to travel from place oron a circuit, particularly for the purpose of preaching, lecturing,etc.
The title of a heathen deity to whom the Jews ascribed thesovereignty of the evil spirits; hence, the Devil or a devil. SeeBaal.
To cause to fail in spirit or power; to quell; to crush; tosubdue. [Obs.] Spenser.
A genus of beautiful trees, natives of the East Indies. Thetree imperfectly di
One that sterilizes anything; specif., an apparatus forsterilizing an organic fluid or mixture.
One who dribs; one who shoots weakly or badly. [Obs.] Ascham.
To gain anew; to get again; to recover, as what has escaped orbeen lost; to reach again.
A commercial traveler; one employed to solicit orders formanufacturers and tradesmen. Thackeray.
A frame or barrow, without a wheel, carried by hand.
Snowy; resembling snow; partaking of the qualities of snow. SirT. Browne.
A wood cell with spiral or other markings and closedthroughout, as in pine wood.
To separate, as sisters; to disjoin. [Poetic & R.] Tennyson.
The business of felling trees, cutting them into logs, andtransporting the logs to sawmills or to market.
A compound formerly supposed to be modification of oxygen, butnow known to be hydrogen dioxide; -- so called because apparentlyantagonistic to ozone, converting it into ordinary oxygen.
One who writes an account or history of the life of aparticular person; a writer of lives, as Plutarch.
A mineral of a gray, red, brown, or green color, and glisteningluster. It is a silicate of iron and manganese.
A water course, esp. a dry one; a gully; a gorge; -- orig. anEast Indian term.  E. Arnold.
One who is acquainted with, or skilled in, anything bypractice; a practitioner.
A crisp, hard, thin paper, sometimes used for postage stamps.
A small European rodent of the genus Myoxus, of severalspecies. They live in trees and feed on nuts, acorns, etc.; -- socalled because they are usually torpid in winter.
A salt of chromic acid containing two equivalents of the acidradical to one of the base; -- called also bichromate.
An instrument for measuring the specific gravity of fluids; aform hydrometer.
Materia Medica; that branch of therapeutics which treats ofremedies.
A large European bat (Vespertilio, or Noctulina, altivolans).
The fitful naps taken when all hands are kept up by stress.
The manner of holding lands and tenements of a superior.
A condition of the system produced by long use of belladonna.
A saw for dividing timber lengthwise, usually set in a frame,and worked by two persons; also, a fret saw.
Any large ape; especially, the chimpanzee and the orang-outang.
The act of regaling; anything which regales; refreshment;entertainment.
The gate of a mold, through which the melted metal is poured;runner, geat.
A small nematoid worm (Oxyurus vermicularis), which isparasitic chiefly in the rectum of man. It is most common in childrenand aged persons.
Cited before; quoted in a foregoing part of the treatise oressay.

A divice of gauze or wire, covering the mouth or nose, toprevent the inhalation of noxious substances, as dust or smoke. Beingwarmed by the breath, it tempers cold air passing through it, and mayalso be used for the inhalation of medicated vapors.
The record of a single event or item. "In deathless annal."Young.
Of or pertaining to the region of lower Babylonia, which wasanciently called Sumer, or its inhabitants or their language.
The quality or characteristics of a flunky; readiness to cringeto those who are superior in wealth or position; toadyism. Thackeray.
A superior kind of earthenware into whose composition flintenters largely. Knight.
A hood-shaped organ, resembling a cowl or monk's hood, ascertain concave and arched sepals or petals.
A Flemish sloop with a castle at each end. Sir W. Raleigh.
Glazed earthenware; esp., that which is decorated in color.
A collection of tents; an encampment. [Obs.] Drayton.
Supported by a stipe; elevated on a stipe, as the fronds ofmost ferns, or the pod of certain cruciferous plants.
A genus of South American monkeys, including the howlers. SeeHowler, 2, and Illust.
Capable of being affiliated to or on, or connected with inorigin.
Capable of being eaten; fit to be eaten; proper for food;esculent; edible.-- n.
A projecting face like the triglyph, but having only twochannels or grooves sunk in it.
An extract or preparation of opium, used in China and India forsmoking. Balfour.
A flowerless plant which forms a true fruit as the result offertilization, as the red seaweeds, the Ascomycetes, etc.
A genus of limicoline birds including many species ofsandpipers. See Dunlin, Knot, and Sandpiper.
To combine with oxygen so as to form a suroxide or peroxide.[Obs.]
Of or pertaining to animals of the tortoise kind.-- n.
The inferior and posterior of the three elements forming theperiotic bone.
Having the leaves so placed that the upper part of each one iscovered by the base of the next higher leaf, as in hepatic mosses ofthe genus Plagiochila.
The interval of three tones and a semitone, embracing fivediatonic degrees of the scale; the dominant of any key.
The practice or habit of drinking too much; tippling. Blount.
A fermented liquor made from pears; pear cider. Mortimer.
One who, or that which, dilates, expands, o r enlarges.
A kind of drawing knife or planing tool for dressing the spokesof wheels, the shells of blocks, and other curved work.
A state of separation or disunion; want of unity. Dr. H. More.
To a vast extent or degree; very greatly; immensely. Jer.Taylor.
Purification by washing the hands before prayer; -- aMohammedan rite. Heyse.
Small pinchers used to pluck out hairs, and for other purposes.
A fabric resembling velvet, but having the nap flat and lessclose.
Having a sharp point; armed with prickles; prickly; aculeate.
One who indulges in persiflage; a banterer; a quiz. Carlyle.
Native iron protosulphide, FeS. It is known only in meteoricirons, and is usually in imbedded nodular masses of a bronze color.
Act of rejecting; matter rejected, or thrown away. Eaton.
One skilled in some trade or manual occupation; an artificer; amechanic.
A pastoral poem, in which shepherds are introduced conversingwith each other; a bucolic; an idyl; as, the Ecloques of Virgil, fromwhich the modern usage of the word has been established.
To free from deafness; to cause to hear. [Obs.] Shak.
Tending to mitigate; mitigating; lentitive. Johnson.
The condition of sleeping or becoming dormant by day, as is thecase of the bats.
A local name in parts of the Mississippi Valley for theAmerican lotus (Nelumbo lutea).
One who dedicates; more especially, one who inscribes a book tothe favor of a patron, or to one whom he desires to compliment.
The art or process of reproducing sounds at a distance, as withthe telephone.
Of or pertaining to Asia or to its inhabitants.-- n.
Of or pertaining to Caledonia or Scotland; Scottish; Scotch.-- n.
A genus of birds including the common European partridge.Formerly the word was used in a much wider sense to include manyallied genera.
Resembling aphanite; having a very fine-grained structure.
A credence table; -- so called by the Eastern or Greek Church.
To talk much and idly; to prate; hence, to talk lightly andartlessly, like a child; to utter child's talk.
In a topical manner; with application to, or limitation of, aparticular place or topic.
A form of prayer in which public confession of sins is made.
A sport piece of bar iron for rolling into a sheet; a smallbillet.
A group of butterflies which includes the satyrs. See Satyr, 2.
A red cap worn by Turks and other Eastern nations, sometimesalone and sometimes swathed with linen or other stuff to make aturban. See Fez.
The science of plants; a description of the kinds andproperties of plants; botany. Sir T. Browne.
An instrument for obtaining directly, without calculation, thetrue bearing of the sun, and thence the variation of the compass
A large sturgeon (Acipenser huso) from the region of the BlackSea. It is sometimes twelve feet long.
The act of filling or crowding together; a stopping byredundant matter; obstruction, particularly in the lower intestines.Jer. Taylor.
The organs of generation; the sexual organs; the private parts.
Having the nose of medium width; between leptorhine andplatyrhine.
Of or pertaining to the janizaries, or their government. Burke.
One of a middle or intermediate class in some schools andseminaries.
Of or pertaining to the epidermis; epidermic; cuticular.
An impure aqueous solution of chloride of aluminium, used as anantiseptic and disinfectant.
A light, volatile liquid, H2C(OCH3)2, regarded as a complexether, and having a pleasant ethereal odor. It is obtained by thepartial oxidation of methyl alcohol. Called also formal.
In an external manner; outwardly; on the outside; inappearance; visibly.
One of a group of univalve shells, having a large aperture ormouth.
Searching; exploring; investigating. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.
A hut or shelter for shepherds of fishers. See Sheeling.[Scot.]
A male friend who attends upon a bridegroom and bride at theirmarriage; the "best man." Sir W. Scott.
A word, phrase, or idiom peculiar to Great Britain; any mannerof using a word or words that is peculiar to Great Britain.
Of the color of lavender; pale blue with a slight mixture ofgray. Lindley.
A water wheel having a vertical axis, and an inner and outertapering shell, between which are vanes or floats attached usually toboth shells, but sometimes only to one.
A priest employed in saying annuals, or anniversary Masses.[Obs.] Chaucer.
Emitting a murmuring sound; droning; murmuring; buzzing.
A genus of herbaceous plants (Scrophularia), mostly found inthe north temperate zones. See Brownwort.
So tight as to prevent the passing through of wind. Bp. Hall.
To move forward; to advance; to promote. [Obs.] Bp. Fell.

The hard, central part of the trunk of a tree, consisting ofthe old and matured wood, and usually differing in color from theouter layers. It is technically known as duramen, and distinguishedfrom the softer sapwood or alburnum.
The pulverized matter from a quartz mill, or the lighter soilof hydraulic mines. [Local, U. S.]
A place, properly secured from the weather, for containingdung.
The quality or state of being timely; seasonableness;opportuneness.
An order of mammals having two (rarely four) large incisorteeth in each jaw, distant from the molar teeth. The rats, squirrels,rabbits, marmots, and beavers belong to this order.
The bones which inclose the brain; the skull; the cranium.
The same, or equal, in law or right; one in kind or origin;analogous; similar. Dana.

A concretion in the joints of the bamboo, which consistslargely or chiefly of pure silica. It is highly valued in the EastIndies as a medicine for the cure of bilious vomitings, bloody flux,piles, and various other diseases.

A metallic element found in certain rare minerals, as thorite,pyrochlore, monazite, etc., and isolated as an infusible graymetallic powder which burns in the air and forms thoria; -- formerlycalled also thorinum. Symbol Th. Atomic weight 232.0.

An extinct, hairy, maned elephant (Elephas primigenius), ofenormous size, remains of which are found in the northern parts ofboth continents. The last of the race, in Europe, were coeval withprehistoric man.
A medicine, or application, which promotes suppuration.
The act of unshipping, or the state of being unshipped;displacement.
A suborder of Cephalopoda including Octopus, Argonauta, andallied genera, having eight arms around the head; -- called alsoOctopoda.
Partial blindness, or a tendency to blindness. [R.] Sir T.Browne.
A complex mixture of several substances extracted from Irishmoss.
One skilled in strategy, or the science of directing greatmilitary movements.
A tribe or confederacy of North American Indians, including theMuskogees, Seminoles, Uchees, and other subordinate tribes. Theyformerly inhabited Georgia, Florida, and Alabama.

A tribe of North American Indians formerly living on the Neuseand Tar rivers in North Carolina. They were conquered in 1713, afterwhich the remnant of the tribe joined the Five Nations, thus formingthe Six Nations. See Six Nations, under Six.

Work composed of pieces sewed together, esp. pieces of variouscolors and figures; hence, anything put together of incongruous orill-adapted parts; something irregularly clumsily composed; a thingputched up. Swift.
The wishbone or merrythought of birds, formed by the unitedclavicles.
The state, personality, or character of a queen; queenliness.Tennyson.
The act of pervading, passing, or spreading through the wholeextent of a thing. Boyle.
A small visorless cap, worn by members of German student corps.It is made in the corps colors, and usually bears the insignia of thecorps.
A group which includes the bony ganoids, as the gar pikes.
A word of opposite meaning; a counterterm; -- used as acorrelative of synonym. [R.] C. J. Smith.
A guard or small body of troops at a distance from the mainbody of an army, to watch for the approach of an enemy; hence,anything for defense placed at a distance from the thing to bedefended.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a certain tribasic acid(called also trimellitic acid) metameric with trimesitic acid.
A figure of speech by which one form of a noun, verb, orpronoun, and the like, is used for another, as in the sentence: "Whatis life to such as me" Aytoun.
Positivism; the positive philosophy. See Positivism.
Doing mischief; causing harm or evil; nefarious; hurtful. [R.]Chaucer.
Pertaining to, or produced by, a lamp; -- formerly said of asupposed acid.
The system of bards; the learning and maxims of bards.
A persistently excessive flow of watery urine, with lowspecific gravity and without the presence of either albumin or sugar.It is generally accompanied with more or less thirst.
A mark cut into the ear of an animal to identify it; anearmark.
An old form of piece for the organ or harpsichord, somewhat inthe free and brilliant style of the prelude, fantasia, or capriccio.
To fill with artifice and duplicity; to complicate; toembarrass. [Obs.]How doth it [sin] perplex and intrique the whole course of yourlives! Dr. J. Scott.
The unwritten code of moral principles regulating the actionsof the Japanese knighthood, or Samurai; the chivalry of Japan.
A person engaged in illicit distilling; -- so called becausethe work is largely done at night. [Cant, U.S.]
A mystical word used as a charm and engraved on gems among theancients; also, a gem stone thus engraved.
A tabular statement of the dates of feasts, offices, saints'days, etc., esp. of those which are liable to change yearly accordingto the varying date of Easter.
Articles of home manufacture, especially cotton goods. [U. S.]
The state of being gradual; gradualness. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
One of those who attend the coffin at a funeral; -- so calledfrom the pall being formerly carried by them.
The ground-plan of a railway or other road, in distinction fromthe grades or profile.
An ancient galley or vessel with two banks or tiers of oars.
To share through sympathy; to participate in. [R.] D. Rodgers.
A marine fish having a very slender, flat, transparent body. Itis now generally believed to be the young of the conger eel or someallied fish.
A celebrated Sanskrit poem having for its subject the Raghudynasty.
A branch; a projecting part or prominent process; aramification.
A noisy, swaggering, or worthless fellow; a rowdy. [Slang, U.S.]
A small European duck (Anas querquedula); -- called alsocricket teal, and summer teal.
Any item of movable or immovable property except the freehold,or the things which are parcel of it. It is a more extensive termthan goods or effects.
an organ situated in the floor of the mouth of most vertebratesand connected with the hyoid arch.
Corrupted; decayed; moldy. See Vinnewed. [Obs.] Dr. Favour.
To loose, and take off, as a bonnet from a sail, or to castoff, as any lacing in any part of the rigging of a vessel. Totten.
A superintendent or keeper of a church's valuables; achurchwarden. [Obs.] Bailey.
To pass, or escape, while dreaming. "To oultdream dangers."Beau. & Fl.
The central part of the hilum of a seed, through which thenutrient vessels pass into the rhaphe or the chalaza; -- called alsoomphalodium.
Giving a faint shadow, or slight resemblance; shadowing forth.
One who whitens, or whose occupation is to whiten, bybleaching.
The terminal part of the large intestine; -- so named becausesupposed by the old anatomists to be straight. See Illust. underDigestive.
A mode of execution which produces the effect by dots or smallpoints instead of lines.
A tropical humming bird of the genus Lophornis, with veryelegant neck plumes. Several species are known. See Illustrationunder Spangle, v. t.
A person employed to shunt cars from one track to another.
To reject by judicial sentence; also, to abjudge. [Obs.] Ash.
Any substance, such as an iron salt or organic compoundcontaining iron, which when ingested tends to increase the hemoglobincontents of the blood.
One of the Ascidioidea, or in a more general sense, one of theTunicata. Also as an adj.
The written appointment of a proctor in suits in theecclesiastical courts. Burrill.
Situated under, or on the ventral side of, the sacrum.
Loss of power to express, or to understand, symbols or signs ofthought.
A form of action by which some right or interest is sought tobe judicially declared.
Full of gas; like gas. Hence: [Colloq.] Inflated; full ofboastful or insincere talk.
One engaged in the same work with another; a companion in work.
To lay color on canvas by uniting them skillfully together.[R.] Cf. Impasto.
A small vessel for holding ink, to dip the pen into; also, adevice for holding ink and writing materials.
An opening in the side of small vessels of war, near thesurface of the water, to facilitate rowing in calm weather.
An apparatus consisting essentially of a mirror moved byclockwork so as to throw the rays of the sun or a star in a fixeddirection; -- a more general term for heliostat.
Past; -- applied to a tense which expresses an action or stateas past.
One who welcomes; one who salutes, or receives kindly, anewcomer. Shak.
A sword, especially a broadsword, formerly used both to cut andthrust.
A livid or black and blue spot, produced by the extravasationor effusion of blood into the areolar tissue from a contusion.
A low rate or price; a price less than the real worth;undervaluation. Milton.
To project upward, or make an angle with the horizon or withthe line of a vessel's keel; -- said of the bowsprit, etc.
A fleshy excrescence; esp. a small excrescence or fungousgrowth. Wiseman.
A species of Galium (G. Aparine), having a fruit set withhooked bristles, which adhere to whatever they come in contact with;-- called also, goose grass, catchweed, etc.
The quality or state of being thwart; obliquity; perverseness.
A mark of reference; -- called also dagger [&dag;]. See Dagger,n., 2.
To adjudge; to try and determine, as a court; to settle byjudicial decree.
One of the motionless spermatozoids in the conceptacles ofcertain fungi. J. H. Balfour.
A halfround single-cut file or fioat, having one curved faceand one straight face, -- used by comb makers. Knight.
Of or pertaining to the captain of the vanguard of a Romanarmy. Barrow.
To score, not by skillful play but by some fortunate chance ofthe game. [Cant, U.S.]
One who holds a tack or lease from another; a tenant, orlessee. Sir W. Scott.The tacksmen, who formed what may be called the "peerage" of thelittle community, must be the captains. Macaulay.
Villenage; tenure of land on condition of doing the meanestservices for the owner.
A corruption of God yield, i. e., God reward or bless. Shak.
Capable of being repugned or resisted. [R.] Sir T. North.
A vote given to one candidate only, when two or more are to beelected, thus giving him the advantage over the others. A person whogives his vote thus is said to plump, or to plump his vote.
A cavity, or excavation, made in the snow by a seal, over itsbreathing hole in the ice.
The board at the rear end of a cart or wagon, which can beremoved or let down, for convenience in loading or unloading.
To compose; to settle; to arrange. [Obs.]A good pretense for componing peace. Strype.
A small passageway, as in a mine, that a man may pass through.Raymond.
One who sums up; one who forms an abridgment or summary. Sir E.Dering.
A vegetable parasite subsisting in the interior of the body.
The substance of the cells which inclose the white of birds'eggs.
A Romansch dialect spoken in some parts of Switzerland and theTyrol.
To cause to be like the Mexicans, or their country, esp. inrespect of frequent revolutions of government.
A term of reproach for a low or vulgar labor person. [Slang]
In railroads, the bed or foundation on which the superstructure(ties, rails, etc.) rests; in common roads, the whole material laidin place and ready for travel.
The use of light, frivolous language by way of fun or ridicule;raillery; banter.
A figure bounded by three lines, and containing three angles.
To appoint as one's deputy; to empower to act in one's stead;to depute.
To make great; to enlarge; to magnify. [Obs.] Fotherby.
A cervical ring of hair or feathers, distinguished by its coloror structure; a collar.
Having tthe character of a child; belonging, or appropriate, toa child. Gower.
Of or pertaining to Ephesus, an ancient city of Ionia, in AsiaMinor.
A conventional comment or saying, such as those characteristicof bromides. [Slang]
To reduce to form, as literary matter; to digest and put inshape (matter for publication); to edit.
To strip the shell from; to take out of the shell; to hatch.
In France, interest payable by government on indebtedness; thebonds, shares, stocks, etc.,, which represent governmentindebtedness.
A glucoside found in the poisonous berries of a species ofhoneysuckle (Lonicera xylosteum), and extracted as a bitter, white,crystalline substance.
A secret language or conventional slang peculiar to thieves,tramps, and vagabonds; flash.
A kind of broad-brimmed hat, worn in Spain and in SpanishAmerica. Marryat.
A wet meter used to determine the breathing capacity of thelungs.
Rotten from being too ripe; overripe. [Obs.] Blount.
One of a peculiar kind of spines covering the surface ofcertain starfishes. They are pillarlike, with a flattened summitwhich is covered with minute spinules or granules. See Illustrationin Appendix.
Resembling, or composed of, cinders; full of cinders.
An instrument which, placed against the teeth, conveys sound tothe auditory nerve; an audiphone. Knight.
; 115), adv. With the flat side downward; not edgewise. Shak.
The forward extension of the hearth of a blast furnace underthe tymp.
A stratum in crystalline rock, containing metallic sulphides.Raymond.
To skip or leap over; to treat with indifference. Shak.

A person on shipboard whose business was to take charge ofstowing the cargo; -- formerly written roomager, and romager. [Obs.]The master must provide a perfect mariner, called a romager, to rangeand bestow all merchandise. Hakluyt.
To reduce from civilization to a savage state. [R.] Blackwood'sMag.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitroso derivativeof barbituric acid. It is obtained as a white or yellow crystallinesubstance, and forms characteristic yellow, blue, and violet salts.
The upward direction of a vein in a mine; the emergence of astratum at the surface.
A long-horned animal, as a cow, goat, or beetle. See Long-horned.
One of a pair of shelly plates found in some cephalopods, asthe ammonites.
A spot or stain; also, a trick. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
Pertaining to, or resulting from, sexual connection; formed bythe union of the male and female elements.
To lay a stock or branch of a vine in the ground forpropagation. [Obs.] Johnson.
A small square block or projection in cornices, a number ofwhich are ranged in an ornamental band; -- used particularly in theIonic, Corinthian, and Composite orders.
The edible fruit of a small North American tree of the genusViburnum (V. Lentago), having white flowers in flat cymes; also, thetree itself. Called also nannyberry.

An extinct genus of Tertiary mammals allied to the horse, butthree-toed, having on each foot a small lateral hoof on each side ofthe main central one. It is believed to be one of the ancestralgenera of the Horse family.
A prolific sort of apple, good for cider. [Obs.] Mortimer.
Parental affection; the instinctive affection which animalshave for their young.
The European bar-tailed godwit; -- called also yardkeep, andyarwhelp. See Godwit. [Prov. Eng.]
A glass vessel, usually cylindrical, filled with a solutionwhich is sensitive to atmospheric changes, indicating by a cloudedappearance, rain, snow, etc., and by clearness, fair weather.
Ancient heretics who held that Christ's body was merely aphantom or appearance.
A comprehensive group of vertebrates, comprising the reptilesand birds.
Pertaining to, or of the nature of, edema; affected with edema.
An accountant; under Constantine, an officer of the empire; areceiver of revenue; an administrator of a department.
To exercise authority; to rule; to lord it. [R.] Fairfax.
The exterior curve of an arch; esp., the upper curved face ofthe whole body of voussoirs. See Intrados.
Agency in common; joint agency or agent. Coleridge.
An instrument which periodically or otherwise interrupts anelectric current. Wheatstone.
Held to service as attached to the soil; -- said of feudalserfs.

A figure of speech in which the parts of a sentence or clauseare repeated in inverse order, as in the following: --O more exceeding love, or law more just Just law, indeed, but moreexceeding love! Milton.
The uninterrupted and continuous flat band, coping, or pavementupon which the bases of a row of columns are supported. See Sub-base.
The quality or state of being tender (in any sense of theadjective).
The quality or state of being trim; orderliness; compactness;snugness; neatness.
A flat piece of wood, used for striking, children, esp. on thehand, in punishment.
A piece of tallow placed in a cavity at the lower end of asounding lead, to bring up the sand, shells, etc., of the sea bottom.Totten.
A traverse made with gabions between guns or on their flanks,protecting them from enfilading fire.
An unsweetened breakfast cake shortened with butter or lard,rolled thin, and baked.
Having two keel-like projections, as the upper palea ofgrasses.
a professional female dancer; a woman who dances at a publicexhibition as in a ballet.
Iron pyrites, or arsenical pyrites; -- so called by the Cornishminers.
A serpent, or serpent's head and neck, represented on the frontof the headdresses of divinities and sovereigns as an emblem ofsupreme power.
The trace or record of an earth tremor, made by means of aseismograph.
To free from chains or slavery; to let loose. Prior.
A play among boys, in which one stoops down and another leapsover him by placing his hands on the shoulders of the former.
An ecclesiastical who holds but one benefice; -- distinguishedfrom pluralist. [Eng.] V. Knox.
Rather fast; also, somewhat dissipated. [Colloq.] Thackeray.
One who deals in tropes; specifically, one who avoids theliteral sense of the language of Scripture by explaining it as meretropes and figures of speech.
An extensive division of parasitic Protozoa, which increase bysporulation. It includes the Gregarinida.
Serving to palliate; serving to extenuate or mitigate.
A story or relation of fictitious events, intended to conveysome moral truth; a moral fable.
One who, or that which, shores or props; a prop; a shore.
One of the nutritive zooids of a hydroid colony. Also appliedto the proboscis or manubrium of a hydroid medusa. See Illust. ofHydroidea.
The brainpan, or skull; hence, the crest. [Obs.] Spenser.
Pertaining to or designating an organic acid of the tartaricacid series, distinct from lithofellic acid, but, like it, obtainedfrom certain bile products, as bezoar stones.
Standing before; -- applied to a gland which is found in themales of most mammals, and is situated at the neck of the bladderwhere this joins the urethra.-- n.

In Christian worship: A hymn expressing praise and honor toGod; a form of praise to God designed to be sung or chanted by thechoir or the congregation.David breaks forth into these triumphant praises and doxologies.South.
To move or conduct to or toward. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Moving moderately slow, but distinct and flowing; quicker thanlarghetto, and slower than allegretto.-- n.
Excessive conservatism; hostility to progress. [Political Cant,U.S.]
Unawares; unexpectedly; -- sometimes preceded by at. [Obs.]Holinshed.
One who contended for a prize in the public games of ancientGreece or Rome.
A dry measure in Spain and Spanish America, varying from 1 DeColange.
Tin ore freed from earthy matter by stamping. Knight.
A kind of clay slate, carved by the Indians into tobacco pipes.Cf. Catlinite.
Moving in a hobbling manner, owing to ten der feet; -- said ofa horse. Youatt.
Of or pertaining to a segment sometimes present at the proximalend of the hyoidean arch.-- n.
To dissipate by heat the volatile parts of, as ores.
One who holds lands or tenements by socage; a socager. Cowell.
A growth of minute powdery or webby fungi, whitish or ofdifferent colors, found on various diseased or decaying substances.
To change the form of, as of an algebraic expression, byexecuting certain indicated operations without changing the value.
Adnate to the surface of the ovary, so as to be apparentlyinserted upon the top of it; -- said of stamens, petals, sepals, andalso of the disk.

To wink; to nictate. Nictitating membrance (Anat.), a thinmembrance, found in many animals at the inner angle, or beneath thelower lid, of the eye, and capable of being drawn across the eyeball;the third eyelid; the haw.
The three membranes that envelop the brain and spinal cord; thepia mater, dura mater, and arachnoid membrane.
The whole body of soldiers; soldiery; militia; troops; thearmy.
A manufacturer of tin vessels; a dealer in tinware.
A book containing the list and pedigrees of one or more herdsof choice breeds of cattle; -- also called herd record, or herdregister.
An alkaloid found in opium in small quantities, and extractedas a white crystalline substance.
The part of the mesoblast which gives rise to the connectivetissues and blood.
To cause to cease being weary; to refresh. [Obs.] Dryden.
The body of the Jewish civil and canonical law not comprised inthe Pentateuch.
Capable of being apposed, or applied one to another, as thethumb to the fingers of the hand.
Long poles, topped with wisps of straw, used as landmarks andsignals. Farrow.
Having the appearance or qualities of a shopkeeper, or shopman.
A poisonous alkaloid found in the unripe seeds of the laburnum.
To weigh or consider beforehand; to premeditate. [Obs.]Spenser. Sir T. Elyot.
To give a name to; to characterize by an epithet; to entitle;to name; to designate.Passions commonly denominating selfish. Hume.
Any external application intended to beautify and improve thecomplexion.
A knitted worsted jacket, worn over the waist of a woman'sdress.
An unmarried person, male or female, who has criminalintercourse with the other sex; one guilty of fornication.
One of the body segments of Arthropods. See Arthrostraca.Packard.
An arrangement of lenses and mirrors which enables a person tosee an object in spite of intervening objects.
A name given in contempt, derision, or sportive familiarity; afamiliar or an opprobrious appellation.
He who, or that which, deodorizes; esp., an agent that destroysoffensive odors.
A dirty or clotted lock of wool on a sheep; a taglock.
Of or pertaining to David, the king and psalmist of Israel, orto his family.
To agree; to be in accordance; to be adapted; to suit; to fallinto a class or place. Mitford.
Capable of being bowed or bent; flexible; easily influenced;yielding. [Obs.]
A young salmon or parr, in the stage in which it has transverseblack bands, as if burned by a gridiron.
To color with, or as with, vermilion; to dye red. [Obs.]Milton.
Expressing denial; belonging to negation; negative. Carlyle.
An extinct genus of sharks having conical, compressed teeth.
A name given to several plants of different genera, butparticularly to Celosia cristata, or garden cockscomb. Same asCockscomb.
A bed of earth or rock of one kind, formed by natural causes,and consisting usually of a series of layers, which form a rock as itlies between beds of other kinds. Also used figuratively.
Of the color of the hazelnut; of a light brown. Mortimer.
As much as a teacup can hold; enough to fill a teacup.
A certain function relating to a system of forces and theirpoints of application, -- first used by Clausius in the investigationof problems in molecular physics.
A fibrous mineral occurring in tufts of a straw-yellow color.It is a hydrous silicate of alumina and manganese.
To lay on, as the hands, in the religious rites of confirmationand ordination.
A colorless, crystalline substance extracted from oil ofcloves; -- called also clove camphor.
A green micaceous mineral occurring in minute scales. It isessentially a silicate of aluminia and potash containing vanadium.
A white, crystalline, nitrogenous substance obtained by thereduction of isatin. It is a member of the indol series; -- hence itsname.
A small hammer used by marble workers and sculptors.
Notoriously, in an ill sense; infamously; impudently;shamefully. L'Estrange.
To filter; to defecate; as liquid, by straining or percolation.Arbuthnot.
The chambered sporogenous tissue forming the central mass ofthe sporophore in puff balls, stinkhorns, etc.
The lining of a mine shaft with stones or bricks to preventcaving.
Pertaining to, or resembling, coal; containing coal; of thenature of coal.
A sort of Russian isinglass, made from the air bladder of thesturgeon, and used in clarifying wine.
The body of young aspirants for knighthood. [Obs.] Chaucer.
That part of an elliptical or many-centered arch which has theshorter radius and immediately adjoins the impost.
A circumscribed swelling produced by an effusion of bloodbeneath the skin.
The operation, art, or practice of cutting for stone in thebladder.
Having hairs branching out laterally, like the parts of afeather.
A work made across or in the ditch, to protect it from theenemy, or to serve as a covered passageway.
The farthest or exterior bounds; extreme limits; boundaries.Spenser.
One who, or that which, spades; specifically, a diggingmachine.
The coping of the scarp wall, which projects beyong the face ofthe wall a few inches.
Native hydrous carbonate of copper, usually occurring in greenmammillary masses with concentric fibrous structure.
A weed of the genus Lamium (L. amplexicaule) with deeplycrenate leaves.
A place where books, or other articles, are bound; abookbinder's establishment.
A small herbaceous plant growing on muddy shores (Limosellaaquatica).
A curdy white substance, obtained by the decomposition ofparillin.
To surpass in telling, counting, or reckoning. "I have outtoldthe clock." Beau. & Fl.
Any wood from which coloring matter is extracted for dyeing.
A sleight-of-hand trick played with three small cups, shapedlike thimbles, and a small ball or little pea.
The arch over the dam of a blast furnace; the tymp arch.
Accumulation in the blood of the principles of the urine,producing dangerous disease.
Public disgrace or stigma; infamy; loss of civil rights.Mitford.
Unknowing; also, unknown; unmeaning. [Obs.] Spenser.
The most northern of the English Kings-at-arms. See King-at-arms, under King.
A composition of passages detached from several differentcompositions; a potpourri.
Covered or encumbered with litter; consisting of orconstituting litter.
The habit or practice of speaking through the teeth, or withthem closed.
A remarkable genus of marine worms having tentacles around themouth. It is usually classed with the gephyreans. Its larva(Actinotrocha) undergoes a peculiar metamorphosis.
The act of measuring with a tonometer; specifically (Med.),measurement of tension, esp. the tension of the eyeball.
Making an organic or organized structure; producing anorganism; acting through, or resulting from, organs. Prof. Park.
A nematoid worm of the genus Gordius, resembling a hair. SeeGordius.
The act of giving possession of a copyhold estate. Bouvier.
Transmission of an estate by inheritance, usually, but notnecessarily, in the descending line; title to inherit an estate byreason of consanguinity. Abbott.
To ascertain the caliber of, as of a thermometer tube; also,more generally, to determine or rectify the graduation of, as of thevarious standards or graduated instruments.
A genus of Cretaceous fossil shells allied to oysters.
Something huge; a roistering blade; also, a spree. [Slang,U.S.] Bartlett.
A cruciferous herb of certain species of Dentaria; -- calledalso toothwort, tooth violet, or pepper root.
A genus of minute flagellate Infusoria of which there are manyspecies, both free and attached. See Illust. under Monad.
The hypothetical radical C2H3, regarded as the characteristicresidue of ethylene and that related series of unsaturatedhydrocarbons with which the allyl compounds are homologous.
A rope at the bow of a boat, used to fasten it to anything.Totten.
A name given to certain catechumens and penitents who werepermitted to join only in parts of church worship.
A device in an incubator for protecting the young chickens andkeeping them warm.
A certificate showing what appears upon record touching amatter in question.
bounding in, or overgrown with, furze; characterized by furze.Gay.
A tribe of Indians formerly inhabiting the valley of theDelaware River, but now mostly located in the Indian Territory.
A mistress; a wife; -- so used by the illiterate. G. Eliot.
Pertaining to, or obtained from, the rowan tree, or sorb;specifically, designating an acid, C
In an angular manner; with of at angles or corners. B. Jonson.
A European pike perch (Stizostedion lucioperca) allied to thewall-eye; -- called also sandari, sander, sannat, schill, and zant.
In a dainty manner; nicely; scrupulously; fastidiously;deliciously; prettily.
A confection made of flour, sugar, marmalade, and eggs; a sweetbiscuit.
Bright and effulgent spirits; seraphim. [Thus used by Milton.]
One who, or that which, presages; a foreteller; a foreboder.Shak.
Resembling a fan; -- specifically (Bot.), folded up like a fan,as certain leaves; plicate.
An axis or stem produced by dichotomous branching in which oneof the branches is regularly developed at the expense of the other,as in the grapevine.
A plant (Rheum Rhaponticum) the leafstalks of which are acid,and are used in making pies; the garden rhubarb.
To go astray; to diverge. [R.]Their own defective and aberrating vision. De Quincey.
A large division of Mollusca, including all except thebivalves; -- so called because the head is distinctly developed. SeeIllustration in Appendix.
To separate from the awns; -- said of barley. [Scot.]
A round and compact bed of ore, or a distinct bed, notcommunicating with a vein.
A fruit bat, especially the large species (Pieropus vulgaris)inhabiting the islands of the Indian ocean. It measures about a yardacross the expanded wings.
Am assembly or session of the Welsh bards; an annual congressof bards, minstrels and literati of Wales, -- being a patrioticrevival of the old custom.
A firm composition of emery and a certain kind of cement, usedfor making grinding wheels, slabs, etc.
One who fleeces or strips unjustly, especially by trickery orfraund. Prynne.
A mineral occurring usually in small isolated crystals, --phosphate of the cerium metals.
A kind of pleasure wagon, uncovered and with seats extendedalong the sides, designed to carry six or eight persons besides thedriver.
To slide down hill; to slide on a sled, upon snow or ice.[Local, U. S.]
That department of sanitary science which treats of thepreservation of health, esp. of households and communities; a systemof principles or rules designated for the promotion of health.
A suborder of soft-rayed fresh-water fishes of which theblackfish of Alaska (Dallia pectoralis) is the type.
Good-by; farewell; an expression of kind wishes at parting.
A suit worn under another suit; a suit of underclothes.
A transparent, colorless oil obtained from elemi resin bydistillation with water; also, a crystallizable extract from theresin.
An alkaloid found with hyoscyamine (with which it is alsoisomeric) in henbane, and extracted as a white, amorphous, semisolidsubstance.
A French Protestant of the period of the religious wars inFrance in the 16th century.
To exceed in speaking; to speak too much; to use too manywords.
Having performed wonders; able to perform wonderful things.[Obs.] Shak.
A structure, part, or organ developed independently, that is,not derived from a similar structure, part, or organ, in a preexisting form.
The deadly nightshade (Atropa Belladonna), having stupefyingqualities.
An annual grass (Eleusine coracona), cultivated in India as afood plant.
Kept in stock by apothecaries; -- said of such drugs andmedicines as may be obtained without special preparation orcompounding; not magistral.
One who foists something surreptitiously; a falsitier. Mir. forMag.
the curve traced by any point in the plane of a given curvewhen the latter rolls, without sliding, over another fixed curve. SeeCycloid, and Epycycloid.
Material which, in the process of catalysis, has diffused orpassed through the separating membrane.

A follower of Robert Brown, of England, in the 16th century,who taught that every church is complete and independent in itselfwhen organized, and consists of members meeting in one place, havingfull power to elect and depose its officers.
Rising again; -- applied to a class of roses which bloom morethan once in a season; the hybrid perpetual roses, of which theJacqueminot is a well-known example.
One who is hired; a hireling; especially, a soldier hired intoforeign service. Milman.
A gatherer of cods or peas. [Obs. or Prov.] Johnson.
A plant supposed to heal bruises, as the true daisy, thesoapwort, and the comfrey.

An instrument devised originally for measuring the diameter ofthe sun; now employed for delicate measurements of the distance andrelative direction of two stars too far apart to be easily measuredin the field of view of an ordinary telescope.

; sing. Huron. (Ethnol.) A powerful and warlike tribe of NorthAmerican Indians of the Algonquin stock. They formerly occupied thecountry between Lakes Huron, Erie, and Ontario, but were nearlyexterminated by the Five Nations about 1650.
A solemn, authentic instrument in writing, by which a persondeclares his will as to disposal of his estate and effects after hisdeath.
A fine, deep red ocher, somewhat purplish, found in Spain. Itis the sil atticum of the ancients. Under the name of Indian red itis used for polishing glass and silver.
Any bird of the genus Manucodia, of Australia and New Guinea.They are related to the bird of paradise.
Excess in eating; extravagant indulgence of the appetite forfood; voracity.Their sumptuous gluttonies, and gorgeous feasts. Milton.
One who lives in a boggy country; -- applied in derision to thelowest class of Irish. Halliwell.
Codfish cured in a particular manner, so as to be of a superiorquality.
The offspring of a mulatto woman and a negro; also, a mulatto.[Local, U. S.]
A bruise; an injury attended with more or less disorganizationof the subcutaneous tissue and effusion of blood beneath the skin,but without apparent wound.
The state or quality of being better; melioration. [Obs.]Bacon.
An exclamation used in addressing a familiar acquaintance.[Obs.] Shak.
Bearing flowers on a spadix; of the nature of a spadix.
To breathe with a rough, hoarse, nasal voice in sleep.
A supposed fourth integument of an ovule, counting from theoutside.
The hinder part, posteriors, or rump of a person or animal.
Arrangements; embellishments; trimmings; accompaniments.[Colloq. U.S.]
A short, variously distorted foot; also, the deformity, usuallycongenital, which such a foot exhibits; talipes.
Of or pertaining to papyrus, or to paper; papyraceous.
An ornament used in rich Norman doorways, resembling a headwith a beak. Parker.

A bird of Madagascar (Leptosomus discolor), the only livingtype of a family allied to the rollers. It has a pair of loralplumes. The male is glossy green above, with metallic reflections;the female is spotted with brown and black.
Having finlike appendages or flukes instead of legs, as acetacean.
One who passes for a degree, without honors. See Classman, 2.[Eng. Univ.]
Any carangoid fish of the genus Trachurus, especially T.trachurus, or T. saurus, of Europe and America, and T. picturatus ofCalifornia. Called also skipjack, and horse mackarel.
A small state, consisting of a few cities or towns; a pettycountry governed by a toparch; as, Judea was formerly divided intoten toparchies. Fuller.
To change (an adjective, verb, etc.) into a noun. Earle.
A pointed implement used to make holes in the ground in whichno set out plants or to plant seeds.
A white crystalline bitter alkaloid extracted from ipecacuanharoot, and regarded as its peculiar emetic principle.
An edict or order of the government prohibiting the departureof ships of commerce from some or all of the ports within itsdominions; a prohibition to sail.
A genus of plants,mostly herbs, with acid-tasting trifoliolateor multifoliolate leaves; -- called also wood sorrel.
Having knaps; full of protuberances or humps; knobby. [Obs.]Huloet.
An ancient stringed instrument; -- so called because, in form,it resembled the Delphic tripod.
A North Pacific salmon (Salmo Gairdneri) found from NorthernCalifornia to Siberia; -- called also hardhead, and preesil.
Ornamental work produced by inlaying steel with gold, -- avariety of damascening much used in the arts of India.
A German nobleman of a rank corresponding to that of an earl inEngland and of a count in France.
Situated in front of, or anterior to, the pubis; pertaining tothe prepubis.
Of or pertaining to hearing; auditory. [R.] Cotgrave.
A landing place; an elevated staging upon a wharf fordischarging coal, etc., as from railway cars, into vessels.
All the adjuncts of a play except the scenery and the dressesof the actors; stage requisites.I will draw a bill of properties. Shak.
Abnormal regularity; the state of certain flowers, which, beingnaturally irregular, have become regular through a symmetricalrepetition of the special irregularity.
A polishing material made of potter's clay that has failed inbaking.
A cow house, dairy house, or cow pasture. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]Wright.

An instrument for determining the strength of spirits, with ascale graduated so as to indicate the percentage of pure alcohol,either by weight or volume. It is usually a form of hydrometer with aspecial scale.
A stocking without a foot, worn by coal miners at work.
The portico, or narthex in an ancient temple or church.
Pertaining to, or caused by, a blow; sudden; abrupt. [R.] H.Bushnell.
Standing upright, with reference to the earth's surface, or tothe surface to which it is attached.
Land or region where one was cradled; hence, land of origin.
Lit., the little, or short, O, o; the fifteenth letter of theGreek alphabet.
A cam, wiper, or projecting piece which strikes another piecerepeatedly.
Rich or highly ornamented cake, to be distributed to the guestsat a wedding, or sent to friends after the wedding.
A mouse of the genus Arvicola; the meadow mouse. There are manyspecies.
A mineral of the feldspar family, commonly occurring in smallglassy crystals, also a constituent of some igneous rocks. It is alime feldspar. See Feldspar.
One devoted to the acquisition of wealth or the service ofMammon. C. Kingsley.
Too full; filled to overflowing; excessively full; surfeited.Shak.
A hard, heavy, and durable wood, which admits of a fine polishor gloss. The usual color is black, but it also occurs red or green.
A delicate person; one not inured to the hardship and rudenessof pioneer life. [Slang, Western U.S.]
To solve, to clear up; as, to soyl all other texts. [Obs.]Tyndate.
One who brews; one whose occupation is to prepare malt liquors.
A reference to decided cases, or books of authority, to prove apoint in law.
One who promotes or establishes a colony; a colonist. Bancroft.
One of locomotive appendages of an animal; a limb; a leg or anarm of man.
Not becoming electrified by friction; -- opposed toidioelectric.-- n.
