A process or fold below the tongue in some animals.
To tear up by the roots; to draw away. [Obs.] Wyatt.
The pin, or gnomon, of a dial, the shadow of which indicatesthe hour. See Gnomon. (f) Etym: [Probably fr. Gr. (Bot.)
A quality, idiom, or peculiarity characteristic of the Japaneseor their products, esp. in art.
One who, or that which, vaporizes, or converts into vapor.
The power of exciting mirth; comicalness. [R.] H. Giles.
Fruitfulness; copiousness; abundance; plenty. [Obs.] Florio.
Of or pertaining to verses; designating distinct divisions of awriting.
The act of leaning, resting, or reclining; the state of beingrecumbent.
The use of a variety of names for the same object. G. S. Faber.
A dyestuff, obtained from the Chinese croicin, which produces abrilliant yellow.
Act of enraging or state of being enraged; excitement. [Obs.]

That division of the Mollusca which includes the bivalveshells, like the clams and oysters; -- so called because they have noevident head. Formerly the group included the Tunicata, Brachiopoda,and sometimes the Bryozoa. See Mollusca.
One who, or that which, unloads; a device for unloading, as hayfrom a wagon.
One who backbites; a secret calumniator or detractor.
Any one of the derivatives of indogen, which contain that groupas a nucleus.
The wrist; the bones or cartilages between the forearm, orantibrachium, and the hand or forefoot; in man, consisting of eightshort bones disposed in two rows.
A sexual zooid produced as a medusoid bud upon a hydroid,sometimes becoming a free hydromedusa, sometimes remaining attached.See Hydroidea, and Illusts. of Athecata, Campanularian, and Gonosome.
A name applied to the amorphous or crystalline mass obtainedfrom bile by the action of alcohol and ether. It is composed of amixture of the sodium salts of the bile acids.

The act or process of rolling logs from the place where theywere felled to the stream which floats them to the sawmill or tomarket. In this labor neighboring camps of loggers combine to assisteach other in turn. Longfellow. [U.S.]
To oxidize to the utmost degree, so as to form a peroxide.
Of or pertaining to Iceland; relating to, or resembling, theIcelanders.

A beautiful evergreen shrub of the Dogbane family, havingclusters of fragrant red or white flowers. It is native of the EastIndies, but the red variety has become common in the south of Europe.Called also rosebay, rose laurel, and South-sea rose.
To subject to petty authority; -- said of a wife who thustreats her husband. Commonly used in the past participle (oftenadjectively).
Situated under, or on the ventral side of, the lumbar region ofthe vertebral column.
To leaven too much; hence, to change excessively; to spoil.[Obs.]
A wingless, bloodsucking, hemipterous insect (CimexLectularius), sometimes infesting houses and especially beds. SeeIllustration in Appendix.
One addicted to jargon; one who uses cant or slang. Macaulay.
A metal so prepared as to have the appearance of bronze.-- a.
A lemon-yellow phosphate of uranium and calcium occurring intabular crystals with basal cleavage, and in micalike scales. H., 2-2.5. Sp. gr., 3.05-3.19.
A statement by a party of what he undertakes to prove, --usually applied to each separate averment; the charge or matterundertaken to be proved.
Crude native borax, formerly imported from Thibet. It was oncethe chief source of boric compounds. Cf. Borax.
A bone near the middle of the buttock of a horse. Crabb.
One who curries and dresses leather, after it is tanned.
A temporary blindness, or impairment of sight, said to becaused by sleeping in the moonlight; -- sometimes called nyctalopia.
A rich goblet, esp. one used on state occasions. [Obs.]
The elision of a final m, with the preceding vowel, before aword beginning with a vowel.
The philosophical system of Thomas Hobbes, an Englishmaterialist (
A toll or tribute of a sextary of ale, paid to the lords ofsome manors by their tenants, for liberty to brew and sell ale.Cowell.
A chalklike concretion, consisting mainly of urate of sodium,found in and about the small joints, in the external ear, and inother situations, in those affected with gout; a tophus.
To tie or fasten beneath; to join beneath. [R.] Pope.
An Australian pigeon of the genus Phaps, of several species; --so called from its bronze plumage.
To utter suddenly a sharp, shrill sound; to screech; to creak,as a door or wheel.
A genus of leguminous plants, including the Lima bean, thekidney bean, the scarlet runner, etc. See Bean.
The quality or state of being cross; peevishness; fretfulness;ill humor.
The vascular appendage which connects the fetus with theparent, and is cast off in parturition with the afterbirth.
To order to arrange beforehand; to foreordain. Sir W. Hamilton.
Existing, or made, by the mutual consent of two or moreparties.
To make a victim of, esp. by deception; to dupe; to cheat.
To forge again or anew; hence, to fashion or fabricate anew; tomake over. Udall.
In a gross manner; greatly; coarsely; without delicacy;shamefully; disgracefully.
To annul the consecration of; to secularize; to unhellow.[Obs.] Holland.
A display, as of plate, equipage, etc.; that which isdisplayed. [Coloq.] Dickens.

An oblong or elongated seed vessel, consisting of two valveswith a dissepiment between, and opening by sutures at either margin.The seeds are attached to both edges of the dissepiment, alternatelyupon each side of it.
A microscopic form of life; an animal or vegetable organismmicroscopic size.
That of which the type pattern or representation; that which isrepresented by the type or symbol.
One who, or that which, stanches, or stops, the flowing, as ofblood.
To exercise dominion over; to lord it over. [Obs.] Shelton.
A person subjected to the influence of animal magnetism. [R.]
Rolled together downward, the tip occupying the center; -- aterm used in reference to foliation or leafing, as in ferns. Gray.
A race Hindostan, believed to be the original people whooccupied the land before the Hindoo or Aryan invasion.
That which integrates; esp., an instrument by means of whichthe area of a figure can be measured directly, or its moment ofinertia, or statical moment, etc., be determined.
A woman who performs the duties of a tutor; an instructress. E.Moore.
The large succulent and slightly acid fruit of a small tree(Anona muricata) of the West Indies; also, the tree itself. It isclosely allied to the custard apple.
Easily or clearly seen; distinctly visible; perspicuous. [Obs.]Testament of Love.
A clause in a deed by which some new thing is reserved out ofwhat had been granted before; the clause by which rent is reserved ina lease. Cruise.
The state of being a tyro, or beginner; apprenticeship. [Obs.]Blount.
The science which relates to the formation and development ofthe embryo in animals and plants; a study of the gradual developmentof the ovum until it reaches the adult stage.
A magistrate or judge in Spain and in Spanish America, etc.Prescott.
A figure by which a person really speaks of a thing while hemakes a show as if he would say nothingon the subject.
An oily liquid, resembling, and possibly identical with,furfurol, and obtained from fucus, and other seaweeds.
A machine for use in making topographical maps. It is operatedby being pushed across country, and not only records distances, likethe perambulator, but also elevations.
To hold or bind with, or as with, a strap; to entangle. [Obs.]Chapman.
The act of detorting, or the state of being detorted; atwisting or warping.
A condition of not generating or breeding freely; infertility;a form homogenesis in which the hybrids are sterile among themselves,but are fertile with members of either parent race.
More than regal; worthy of one greater than a king. Waterland.
A French fop or dandy of the time of the Directory; hence, anyfop.
One of a race inhabiting the valleys of the Pyrenees, who until1793 were political and social outcasts (Christian Pariahs). They aresupposed to be a remnant of the Visigoths.
A confection of quinces, in consistency between a sirup andmarmalade.
An old Spanish dance in moderate three-four measure, like thePassacaglia, which is slower. Both are used by classical composers asthemes for variations.
A private person at whose relation, or in whose behalf, theattorney-general allows an information in the nature of a quowarranto to be filed.
The circulation or movement of protoplasmic granules within aliving vegetable cell.
Of or pertaining to a sorites; resembling a sorites.
All right; in a good condition; also, even; square. [Slang, U.S.]
Of or pertaining to uplands; dwelling on high lands. [Obs.]Chapman.
Same as Limuloidea. Called also Xiphosura. X ray. See underRay.
A cellar beneath another story wholly or partly underground;usually, a cellar under a cellar.
A stanza, epigram, or poem, consisting of four verses or lines.Pope.
A common plant (Saponaria officinalis) of the Pink family; --so called because its bruised leaves, when agitated in water, producea lather like that from soap. Called also Bouncing Bet.
A vertical water space in a fire box or combustion chamber.
In an airy manner; lightly; gaily; jauntily; fippantly.
The larva of any one of numerous species of bombycid moths,which spins a large amount of strong silk in constructing its cocoonbefore changing to a pupa.
The state of being abject; abasement; meanness; servility.Grew.
One who believes that it is possible to realize a cognition orconcept of the absolute. Sir. W. Hamilton.
A variety of siliceous slate, of which hones are made; razorstone; Turkey stone; hone stone; whet slate.
A mammal of tropical America of the genus Nasua, allied to theraccoon, but with a longer body, tail, and nose.
Suitable to be patented; capable of being patented.
A disciple of Plotinus, a celebrated Platonic philosopher ofthe third century, who taught that the human soul emanates from thedivine Being, to whom it reunited at death.
Used also figuratively; as, his nerves were unstrung by fear.
A botching, or that which is done by botching; clumsy orcareless workmanship.
An enemy of the gods, esp. one of a race of demons and giants.
An opinion or doctrine, or a system of doctrines, contrary tosome established standard of faith, as the Scriptures, the creed orstandards of a church, etc.; heresy. Bp. Bull.
Exciting laughter; also, addicted to laughter; merry. [R.]
A special plate situated on the sides of the mesothorax andmetathorax of certain insects.
The act or proceeding of seizing personal property by distress.Abbott.
A wind instrument, sounded through a reed, and similar in shapeto the clarinet, but with a thinner tone. Now more commonly calledoboe. See Illust. of Oboe.
Having its vertical height greater than the half span; -- saidof an arch.
In a presumable manner; by, or according to, presumption.
An instrument for measuring the vital capacity of the lungs, orthe volume of air which can be expelled from the chest after thedeepest possible inspiration. Cf. Pneumatometer.
The doctrine of the final causes of things; specif. (Biol.),
The state or quality of being lax; want of tenseness,strictness, or exactness.
To render neat; to clean; to put in order. [R.] Chapman.
In a compact manner; with close union of parts; densely;tersely.
A crystallized substance of the composition C4I4NH, technicallytetra-iodo-pyrrol, used like iodoform.

One who believes in realism; esp., one who maintains thatgenerals, or the terms used to denote the genera and species ofthings, represent real existences, and are not mere names, asmaintained by the nominalists.
The Arabian name of two trees of the genus Balsamodendron,which yield a gum resin and a red aromatic wood.
Having all or many degrees of power; having a great range ofpower; -- said of an eyepiece made adjustable so as to give a varyingmagnifying power.
The state or quality of being automatic; the power of self-moving; automatic, mechanical, or involuntary action. (Metaph.) Atheory as to the activity of matter.
The piece in the interior of a gun lock, which holds in placethe timbler, sear, etc.
The worship of the generative principle in nature, symbolizedby the phallus.
Potassium carbonate, obtained by the incineration of tartar.[Obs.]
A drawing instrument, combining a protractor and scale.
The part of the plow to which the share is attached.
Hawking with staniels, -- a base kind of falconry. [Obs.]
The state of being triform, or of having a threefold shape.
A short piece of land in arable ridges and furrows, ofuncertain quantity; also, a ridge of land lying between two furrows.[Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
To blow together; to bring together; to collect;  to fusetogether; to join or weld; to consolidate.
The art of training by athletic exercises; the games and sportsof athletes.
Having four columns in front; -- said of a temple, portico, orcolonnade.-- n.
A writ issued in the third place, after two former writs havebeen disregarded. Mozley & W.
The pulverized shells of oysters used in making walks. [Eng.]Simmonds.
A treatise on, or the science which treats of, the kidneys, andtheir structure and functions.
An engraver of dies for stamping coins, medals, etc.
A bad quality or disposition in a disease; an incurable ulcer.
One who blesses; one who bestows or invokes a blessing.
To compel to perform military service; to seize for militarypurposes; -- orig. used of the Boers.
Of or pertaining to a mass of matter; -- said of the propertiesor motions of masses, as distinguished from those of molecules oratoms. Carpenter.
A genus of fossil encrinoidea, from the Mesozoic rocks.
A scent bag, or perfume cushion, to be laid amonghandkerchiefe, garments, etc., to perfume them.
A yard in front of a house or around the door of a house.
Like a buffoon; consisting in low jests or gestures. Blair.
Any one of numerous species of small limicoline game birdsbelonging to Tringa, Actodromas, Ereunetes, and various allied generaof the family Tringid\'91.
A genus of plants including the cucumber, melon, and same kindsof gourds.
Any one of three possible metameric substances, which aredimethyl derivatives of thiophene, like the xylenes from benzene.
The middle of the anterior margin of the great foramen of theskull.
A form of crystal common with quartz, consisting of two six-sided pyramids, base to base.
Deposits of earth, sand, gravel, and other transported matter,made by rivers, floods, or other causes, upon land not permanentlysubmerged beneath the waters of lakes or seas. Lyell.
Having the qualities, consistence, or appearance, of butter.
One who captures any person or thing, as a prisoner or a prize.
A compound cordial, in the form of a confection, deriving itsname from the kermes insect, its principal ingredient.
Decapitated; worn or cast off in the process of growth, as theapex of certain univalve shells.
A two-masted passenger boat or small vessel, used in the bay ofManila.
To tighten, as slack standing rigging, by bringing the oppositeshrouds nearer.
A rare metallic element of uncertain properties and identity,said to have been found in the mineral gadolinite.
A slender marine fish (Scombresox saurus) of Europe andAmerica. It has long, thin, beaklike jaws. Called also billfish,gowdnook, gawnook, skipper, skipjack, skopster, lizard fish, andEgypt herring.
A suborder of Actinaria, including Zoanthus and allied genera,which are permanently attached by their bases.
The bassoon; -- so called from being divided into parts forease of carriage, making, as it were, a small fagot.
A river tortoise; one of a group of tortoises (Potamites, orTrionychoidea) having a soft shell, webbed feet, and a sharp beak.See Trionyx.
One of the little hypogynous scales found in the flowers ofgrasses; a lodicule.
A steak of beef; a slice of beef broiled or suitable forbroiling.
(Physics) An instrument for ascertaining the specific gravityof bodies.
A local name for the igneous rocks of Derbyshire, England; --said by some to be derived from the German todter stein, meaning deadstone, that is, stone which contains no ores.
The country of one's ancestors; -- same as fatherland.
The part of a mortar extending from the chamber to thetrunnions.
Having the form of an egg; having a figure such that anysection in the direction of the shorter diameter will be circular,and any in the direction of the longer diameter will be oval.
To make a predatory incursion; to plunder or lay waste. [Obs.]Beau. & Fl.
Of or pertaining to the epigenesis; produced according to thetheory of epigenesis.
The quality or state of being dumb; muteness; silence;inability to speak.
Refuse coal, coal ashes, and cinders, used in the burning ofbricks.
Wet and soft; easily penetrated by the feet of cattle; -- saidof land
A piece of iron imbedded in the sand of a mold to keep the sandin place.
One who gauges; an officer whose business it is to ascertainthe contents of casks.

Any one of several metameric alkaloids, C5H3N.(CH3)2, of thepyridine series, obtained from bone oil as liquids, and havingpeculiar pungent odors. These alkaloids are also called respectivelydimethyl pyridine, ethyl pyridine, etc.
One of a religious order, dwelling in a convent, or acommunity, in opposition to an anchoret, or hermit, who lives insolitude. Gibbon.
A minute vesicle in a red seaweed, which contains thereproductive spores.
A colorless mobile liquid of a pleasant aromatic odor obtainedby the distillation of olibanum, or frankincense, and regarded as aterpene; -- called also conimene.
A figure of speech by which the present tense is used insteadof the past or the future, as in the animated narration of past, orin the prediction of future, events.
Resembling myrtle or myrtle berries; having the form of amyrtle leaf.
The reticular network of fine fibers, of which the nucleus of acell is in part composed; -- in opposition to kytomiton, or thenetwork in the body of the cell. W. Flemming.
Vigorous; lively; active; vegete. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A rare metallic element, of doubtful identification, said tooccur in the copper-nickel of Norway.
A Norman idiom; a custom or expression peculiar to the Normans.M. Arnold.
The ratio of the three crystallographic axes which determinesthe position of any plane; also, the fundamental axial ratio for agiven species.
The French name for concrete; hence, concrete made after theFrench fashion.
A single farmhouse; a steading. [Prov.Eng. & Scot.] Grose.Jamieson.
A West African baboon (Cynocephalus sphinx), allied to thechacma. Its color is generally chestnut, varying in tint.
Having a forked petiole, and a pair of leaflets at the end ofeach division; biconjugate; twice paired; -- said of a decompoundleaf.
Pertaining to, or resembling, the lascivious compositions ofthe Greek poet Sotades.-- n.
An order of Tunicata, including Appendicularia, and alliedgenera; -- so called because certain larval features are retained bythem through life. Called also Copelata. See Appendicularia.
The conveyance of vehicles or loads by means of electricity.Fleeming Jenkin.
A tower in which a sentinel is placed to watch for enemies, theapproach of danger, or the like.
Capable of being congealed; capable of being converted intojelly.
The character and opinions of a Jewish scribe in the time ofChrist. F. W. Robertson.
A stringed musical instrument having a head and neck like theguitar, and its body like a tambourine. It has five strings, and isplayed with the fingers and hands.
One who settles at a distance, or away, from others.
A borate of iron and magnesia, occurring in fibrous masses of ablackish green color.
A transparent crystalline substance, C6H5.CO.NH2, obtained bythe action of ammonia upon chloride of benzoyl, as also by severalother reactions with benzoyl compounds.
Firmly established by custom; formed by habit; habitual. [R.]Hammond.
The embryonic shell, or first chamber, of ammonites and othercephalopods.
The capacity, on the part of one of the parents, as comparedwith the other, to transmit more than his or her own share ofcharacteristics to their offspring.
An Egyptian deity, the conductor of departed spirits,represented by a human figure with the head of a dog or fox.
To sit, as on eggs for hatching; to brood; to brood upon, orkeep warm, as eggs, for the purpose of hatching.
The art of using the perimeter; measurement of the field ofvision.
The act of ascribing, imputing, or affirming to belong; also,that which is ascribed.
The antecedent of the ferment pepsin. A substance contained inthe form of granules in the peptic cells of the gastric glands. It isreadily convertible into pepsin. Also called propepsin.
An early larval form of a trematode worm; a redia. See Redia.
Relating to, or employed in, the cure of diseases; tending tocure. Arbuthnot.
Serving to measure distance on a road. [R.] Sydney Smith.
A secondary notch in the pulse curve, obtained in asphygmographic tracing.
Without uttering words or sounds; in a mute manner; silently.
A kind of glass of a red or ruby color, made in Bohemia.
Not numbered; not counted or estimated; innumerable. Dryden.
Characterized by annotations; of the nature of annotation.
The influence, doctrines, principles, etc., of priests or thepriesthood. [R.]
A very large red and black butterfly (Danais Plexippus); --called also milkweed butterfly.
The great muscle of the buttock in man and most mammals, andthe corresponding muscle in many lower animals.
One who seals; especially, an officer whose duty it is to sealwrits or instruments, to stamp weights and measures, or the like.
The act of overdrawing; also, the amount or sum overdrawn.
The quality of insisting, or being urgent or pressing; the actof dwelling upon as of special importance; persistence; urgency.
To render alkaline; to communicate the properties of an alkalito.
A house of prostitution; a house of ill fame; a brothel.
The quality or state of being vegetal, or exhibiting thosephysiological phenomena which are common to plants and animals. SeeVegetal, a., 2.
That part of the skeleton of the hand or forefoot between thecarpus and phalanges. In man it consists of five bones. See Illust.of Artiodactyla.
An establishment for the treatment of the sick; a resort forinvalids. See Sanitarium.
Violent and irrational excitement; delirium. See Frenzy.
A sale at second hand, or at retail; also, a second sale.Bacon.
A receptacle in which money given for the poor is placed.

An enlargement, or series of enlargements, in the anterior partof the alimentary canal, in which food is digested; any cavity inwhich digestion takes place in an animal; a digestive cavity. SeeDigestion, and Gastric juice, under Gastric.
The European garden warbler (Sylvia, or Currica, hortensis); --called also beccafico and greater pettychaps.
Resinlike, or resinform; resembling a resin without being such.
Any tooth that juts out.When he laughed, two white buckteeth protruded. Thackeray.
Three united; state of being three. [R.] H. Wharton.
The eleventh month of the year, containing thirty days.
A species of kangaroo (Macropus Brunii), inhabiting New Guinea.
The hard substratum. Same as Hard pan, under Hard, a.
An inclosure surrounding a well to prevent persons from fallinginto it; a well curb. Weale.

Moisture; dampness; a moderate degree of wetness, which isperceptible to the eye or touch; -- used especially of theatmosphere, or of anything which has absorbed moisture from theatmosphere, as clothing.
A brassicaceous plant of many varieties, cultivated for itsleaves, which are not formed into a compact head like the cabbage,but are loose, and are generally curled or wrinkled; kale.
That point of a planet's or comet's orbit which is most distantfrom the sun, the opposite point being the perihelion.
An instrument to ascertain the degree of friction in rubbingsurfaces. Brande & C.
A metal covering plate which passes over the trunnions of acannon, and holds it in place.
A companion in amusements or sports; a playmate. Shak.
To engrave. [R.] "Whose gleaming rind ingrav'n." Tennyson.
A band of sworn soldiers; a division of the Spartan armyranging from twenty-five to thirty-six men, bound together by oath.
A compound containing two amido groups united with one or morebasic or positive radicals, -- as contrasted with a diamide.
Capable of being predicated or affirmed of something;affirmable; attributable.
A long knife, or short saber, common among Mohammedan nations,usually having a double curve, sometimes nearly straight. [Writtenalso ataghan, attaghan.] Chaucer.
A small European rodent (Cricetus frumentarius). It isremarkable for having a pouch on each side of the jaw, under theskin, and for its migrations.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid produced artifically asa white crystalline substance, CH2.(CO2H)2, and so called becauseobtained by the oxidation of malic acid.
To look attentively; to consider; to notice. [Obs.] Shak.
A luminous spot occasionally seen a few degrees from the sun,supposed to be formed by the intersection of two or more halos, or ina manner similar to that of halos.
A written or printed notice to be posted, as on a wall; aposter; a placard.
On or towards the port or left side; -- said of the helm.
One of the processes along the edges of the barbs of a feather,by which adjacent barbs interlock. See Feather.
Consisting of jungles; abounding with jungles; of the nature ofa jungle.
Relating to what is to come; pertaining to futurity; future.[R.]
A white or colored wash for the ceiling or other plastering ofa room, consisting of a mixture of clear glue, Paris white or zincwhite, and water. [Also spelt kalsomine.]
One who diets; one who prescribes, or who partakes of, food,according to hygienic rules.
Any one of several species of sea birds of the genus Uria, orCatarractes; a guillemot.
A valuation by an authorized person; an appraisement.
A knobike protuberance of any part, esp. at the end of a boneor cartilage.
To urge on or incite another, as to strife; also, to informagainst a person. [Obs.]
Pertaining to an acroterium; as, ornaments. P. Cyc.
A carrier pigeon remarkable for its ability to return home froma distance.
Pertaining to, or obtained from, terbenthene (oil ofturpentine); specifically, designating an acid, C7H10O4, obtained bythe oxidation of terbenthene with nitric acid, as a white crystallinesubstance.
Any one of several species of ruminants of the genus Ovis,native of the higher mountains of both hemispheres, but most numerousin Asia.
A fabulous being of antiquity, said to have had a hundred eyes,who has placed by Juno to guard Io. His eyes were transplanted to thepeacock's tail.
One of the bones or cartilages of the carpus; esp. one of theseries articulating with the metacarpals.
The rod or handle to which the lash of a whip is fastened.
In time past, either in time immediately preceding or at anyindefinite distance; of old; heretofore.
A man employed in weighing and shipping at a staith. [Eng.]

Of or pertaining to, or designating, the older division ofgeological time during which life is known to have existed, includingthe Silurian, Devonian, and Carboniferous ages, and also to the lifeor rocks of those ages. See Chart of Geology.
The longer liver of two joint tenants, or two persons having ajoint interest in anything. Blackstone.
A compendium containing the heads of a discourse, and the like;an abstract.
A dark-colored, basic, igneous rock, composed essentially ofpyroxene and a triclinic feldspar with magnetic iron. By many authorsit is considered equivalent to a coarse-grained basalt.
Having five columns in front; -- said of a temple or portico inclassical architecture.-- n.
Pertaining to, or suitable for, the church; ecclesiastical.
A large leather bottle for liquors, etc., made of the skin of agoat or other animal. Hence: A drunkard. [Obs.]You're an absolute borachio. Congreve.
One who, or that which, disgraces, or makes ashamed. Beau & Fl.
A finding of carriages, carts, etc., for the transportation ofgoods, produce, etc. Ainsworth.
To call out or forth; to summon; to evoke. [R.] Stackhouse.
A small glass tube, often with an enlargement or bulb in themiddle, and usually graduated, -- used for transferring or deliveringmeasured quantities.
Of, pertaining to, or living in, a marsh or swamp; marshy.
A form of speech adapted to be used by all mankind; universallanguage.
Of or pertaining to simples, or a simplist. [R.] Wilkinson.
A soft fabric with a kind of basket weave and a diaperedpattern.
A dry sweetmeat; any kind of fruit, root, or seed preservedwith sugar and dried; a confection.
A seeking for or gathering of berries, esp. of such as growwild.
Having a suture or sutures; knit or united together. Pennant.
A genus of copepod Crustacea, parasitic of fishes; a fishlouse. See Branchiura.
A suborder of copepod Crustacea, including a large number ofremarkable forms, mostly parasitic on fishes. The young, however, areactive and swim freely. See Illustration in Appendix.
The operation of cutting out or removing a testicle by theknife; castration.

A single body or mass of building, contained within simplewalls and a single roof, whether insulated, as in the park or gardenof a larger edifice, or united with other parts, and forming an angleor central feature of a large pile.

One who, or that which, readjusts; in some of the States of theUnited States, one who advocates a refunding, and sometimes a partialrepudiation, of the State debt without the consent of the State'screditors.
To grain (leather) so as to produce a surface covered withsmall rounded prominences.
Bringing together or towards a given point; -- a word appliedto those muscles of the body which pull one part towards another.Opposed to abducent.
The interval by which the curtate distance of a planet is lessthan the true distance.
A longitudinal strip projecting as a fin from an object, tostrengthen it, or to enter a channel in another object and therebyprevent displacement sidwise but permit motion lengthwise; a spline.
The spirit of the time; the general intellectual and moralstate or temper characteristic of any period of time.
The state of being a father; fatherhood; paternity.
Glittering; dressed in, or overlaid with, tinsel finery. [Obs.]Shak.
A pigment of a green color, the chief constituent of which isoxide of chromium.
A follower of Robert Owen, who tried to reorganize society on asocialistic basis, and established an industrial community on theClyde, Scotland, and, later, a similar one in Indiana.
The very thin transparent and apparently homogenous sheathwhich incloses a striated muscular fiber; the myolemma.
That department of the science of metaphysics whichinvestigates and explains the nature and essential properties andrelations of all beings, as such, or the principles and causes ofbeing.
One of the senior and governing members of an Inn of Court.
To furnish or inclose with a border; to form a border of.Milton.
One who uses or interprets figurative expressions. Waterland.
An assumption of a possible thing as a fact, irrespective ofthe question of its truth. Wharton.
One who delivers goods or money to another in trust.
A place galled or excoriated by much using of the spur.
An instrument similar to a mariner's compass, but withoutmagnetic needles, and having two sight vanes by which bearings aretaken, esp. such as cannot be taken by the compass.
That part of a boltrope which is sewed to the upper edge orhead of a sail.
One nominated in conjunction with another; a joint nominee.Kirby.
A kind of small fern, the wall rue. See under Wall.
A kind of campion; according to Gerarde, the Lychnis Flos-cuculi.

A certificate of interest due, printed at the bottom oftransferable bonds (state, railroad, etc.), given for a term ofyears, designed to be cut off and presented for payment when theinterest is due; an interest warrant.
To render more violent or bitter; to irriate; to exasperate; toimbitter, as passions or disease. Broughman.
The state of being feracious or fruitful. [Obs.] Beattie.
To surpass in giving rede, or counsel. [Obs.] See Atrede.Chaucer.
The impure residue, consisting of cocoons, propolis, etc.,remaining after the wax is extracted from honeycombs.
A supposed rare metallic element, with a characteristicspectrum, found associated with yttrium and other rare metals. Itsindividuality and properties have not yet been determined.
Cerium oxide, CeO2, a white infusible substance constitutingabout one per cent of the material of the common incandescent mantle.
A lesser kind of triumph allowed to a commander for an easy,bloodless victory, or a victory over slaves.
Incapable of being tasted; tasteless; unsavory. [R.] Grew.
The opening through the bulwarks of a vessel by which personsenter or leave it.
A Franciscan; -- so called in France from the girdle of knottedcord worn by all Franciscans.

A sensation of cold with convulsive shaking of the body,pinched face, pale skin, and blue lips, caused by undue cooling ofthe body or by nervous excitement, or forming the precursor of someconstitutional disturbance, as of a fever.
A plant of the genus Glycyrrhiza (G. glabra), the root of whichabounds with a juice, and is much used in demulcent compositions.
The action by which the parts of the body are drawn towards itsaxis]; -- opposed to abduction. Dunglison.
To persuade, or to gain, by entreaty. [Obs.] Cockeram.
Of or pertaining to Sir Thomas Bodley, or to the celebratedlibrary at Oxford, founded by him in the sixteenth century.
Measurement (of cloth) by the ell; also, a duty for suchmeasurement.
A scientific account or discussion of rivers; a treatise onrivers; potamography.
Situated around the radii, or radial tubes, of a radiate.
A problem of more than usual difficulty added to another on anexamination paper.
To render void or useless; to vacate or annul. [Obs.]
To behave wantonly; to frolic; to wanton. [R.] Lamb.

A mill worked by persons treading upon steps on the peripheryof a wide wheel having a horizontal axis. It is used principally as ameans of prison discipline. Also, a mill worked by horses, dogs,etc., treading an endless belt.
The metamorphosis of other floral organs into sepals orsepaloid bodies.
An orange-colored dyestuff, of artificial production.
A place in which a collection of rare trees and shrubs iscultivated for scientific or educational purposes.
Affected by presbyopia; also, remedying presbyopia; farsighted.
Diversified by squares; done in mosaic; tessellated. [Obs.] SirR. Atkyns (1712).
a white crystalline substance, resembling oxanilamide, obtainedby heating aniline oxalate, and regarded as a double anilide ofoxalic acid; -- called also diphenyl oxamide.
A red dyestuff, used as a substitute for cochineal, archil,etc. It consists of the sodium salt of a complex azo derivative ofnaphtol.
A short bat for beating clothes in washing them; -- called alsobatler, batling staff, batting staff. Shak.
A kind of scissors used for opening the intestinal canal, as inpost-mortem examinations.
To walk proudly; to sweep along. [Prov. Eng.] Todd.
Full of bricks; formed of bricks; resembling bricks or brickdust. [R.] Spenser.
A session, as of some public body; especially, a meeting ofspiritualists to receive spirit communication, so called.
A measure of area, the tenth part of an are; ten square meters.
One who promulges or publishes what was before unknown.Atterbury.
The Manila-hemp plant (Musa textilis); also, its fiber. SeeManila hemp under Manila.
My lord; -- an ecclesiastical dignity bestowed by the pope,entitling the bearer to social and domestic rank at the papal court.(Abbrev. Mgr.)
A fan; especially, the fan carried before the pope on stateoccasions, made in ostrich and peacock feathers. Shipley.
A white crystalline substance obtained by oxidation of pipericacid, and regarded as a complex aldehyde.
A fine cotton fabric, having a linen finish, and often printedon one side, -- used for women's and children's wear.
A landlord's right, independently of stipulation, over thestocking (cattle, implements, etc.), and crops of his tenant, assecurity for payment of rent.
One that commingles; specif., a device for noiseless heating ofwater by steam, in a vessel filled with a porous mass, as of pebbles.
Colored a prevailing red, bay, or black, with flecks of whiteor gray especially on the flanks; -- said of horses. Smart.
Compliance; disposition to yield to others. Goldsmith.
The state of widows or of widowhood; also, widows,collectively.
Having the right forefoot lifted, the others remaining on theground, as if he were trotting; trippant; -- said of an animal, as ahart, buck, and the like, used as a bearing.
One who courts; one who plays the lover, or who solicits inmarriage; one who flatters and cajoles. Sherwood.
A contrivance for affording a copious stream of water to theheated surface of an object of large bulk, as an anvil or die.Knight.
To purge of faults; to make better; to correct; esp., to makecorrections in (a literary work); to alter for the better by textualcriticism, generally verbal.
A genus of polished marine gastropod shells, chiefly tropical,and often beautifully colored.
The act of uniting, or an agreement to unite, an aggregation ofproperties belonging to different persons, with a view to commonliabilities or profits.
To divest of the title or privilege of an esquire. Swift.
A morbid swelling, prominence, or growth, on any part of thebody; especially, a growth produced by deposition of new tissue; aneoplasm.
A term applied to the centrifugal, or efferent course of thenervous infuence. Marshall Hall.
A seamstress.Two hundred sepstress were employed to make me shirts. Swift.
To make lean or to become lean; to emaciate. [Obs.] Bullokar.
An explosive compound; a preparation of gun cotton.
A widely dispersed genus of shrubs and trees, usually witharomatic foliage. It includes the bayberry or wax myrtle, the sweetgale, and the North American sweet fern, so called.
Of or pertaining to Renard, the fox, or the tales in whichRenard is mentioned.
Scraping; that which is scraped off. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
The act of entering, or becoming a member of, a religiousorder.
in the gugue style, but not strictly like a fugue.-- n.
That part of the vertebral column which is directly connectedwith, or forms a part of, the pelvis.
On the beam, that is, on a line which forms a right angle withthe ship's keel; opposite to the center of the ship's side.
Having flowers and leaves which appear at the same time; --said of certain plants.
A siliceous variety of calcite, or carbonate of lime, having asilvery-white, pearly luster, and a waving or curved lamellarstructure.
One who is related to another on the female side. Wharton.

A sauce compounded of raw yolks of eggs beaten up with oliveoil to the consistency of a sirup, and seasoned with vinegar, pepper,salt, etc.; -- used in dressing salads, fish, etc. Also, a dishdressed with this sauce.
A small copper coin of Germany. It is the hundredth part of amark, or about a quarter of a cent in United States currency.
An individual cell, differing greatly from its neighbours inregard to size, structure, or contents.
Not aware; not noticing; giving no heed; thoughtless;inattentive. Swift.
In european geology, a name given to the middle division of theUpper Cretaceous formation.
A work in the Persian tongue, being a summary of the Zend-Avesta, or sacred books.
A perfumed unguent or composition, chiefly used in dressing thehair; pomade. Wiseman.
To rise, or tend to rise, as if lighter than the surroundingmedium; to become buoyant; -- opposed to gravitate. Sir. J. Herschel.
A former officer in the English Court of Common Pleas; -- socalled because he filed the writs on which he made out process.[Obs.] Burrill.
The act of disjoining, or the state of being disjoined. [Obs.]Bp. Pearson.
One who has the care of game, especially in a park or preserve.Blackstone.
A tenure by which houses or lands are held of the king or otherlord of a borough or city; at a certain yearly rent, or by servicesrelating to trade or handicraft. Burrill.
A smith who makes jacks. See 2d Jack, 4, c. Dryden.
Having or producing scurf; covered with scurf; resemblingscurf.
An oily substance, C10H16, extracted from oil caraway.
Having, or characterized by, reliance; confident; trusting.
A retort, used in the Bessemer process, in which molten castiron is decarburized and converted into steel by a blast of airforced through the liquid metal.
A large and swift Asiatic falcon (Falco pregrinator) highlyvalued in falconry.
Past the flowering state; having shed its pollen. Gray.
Having the mandible suspended by the hyomandibular, or upperpart of the hyoid arch, as in fishes, instead of directly articulatedwith the skull as in mammals; -- said of the skull.
Inability to transmit radiant; impermeability to heat. Tyndall.
Intercalated with slate; -- said of a seam of coal. Raymond.
A tense in the Greek language, which expresses an action ascompleted in past time, but leaves it, in other respects, whollyindeterminate.
With boiling or ebullition.And lakes of bitumen rise boiling higher. Byron.
The separation of the parts of a compound word by theintervention of one or more words; as, in what place soever, forwhatsoever place.
The people of a town; especially, the inhabitants of a city, indistinction from country people; townspeople.
The subterraneous portion of a building, as in amphitheaters,for the service of the games; also, subterranean galleries, as thecatacombs.
The estimated reparation in money for detriment or injurysustained; a compensation, recompense, or satisfaction to one party,for a wrong or injury actually done to him by another.
Pertaining to, or resembling, a crater. [R.] R. Browning.
Having a curved projection or spine on the inner side of a legjoint; -- said of insects.
Supplying or aiding; auxiliary; suppletory. [Obs.] Shak.
To beautify; to dandify.I employed three good hours at least in adjusting and adonozingmyself. Smollett.
A supposed alkaloid obtained from croton oil by boiling it withwater and magnesia, since found to be merely a magnesia soap of theoil. Watts.
One of the thoracic legs of a crustacean. See Illust. ofCrustacea.
A massive mineral of tin-white or steel-gray color, an arsenideof copper.
The chief magistrate of a city or borough; the chief officer ofa municipal corporation. In some American cities there is a citycourt of which the major is chief judge.
A high explosive similar to lyddite, consisting principally ofpicric acid, used in the French military service.
A kind of fine sand from the banks of the Trent, used as apolishing powder. [Eng.]
The homology of parts arranged on transverse axes. Haeckel.
The outward opening of a river, of a valley, or of a strait.
One who uses dynamite; esp., one who uses it for thedestruction of life and property.
A childish play, in which one covers his eyes, and guesses whostrikes him or his hand placed behind him.
A large and tall glass, or drinking cup. [Obs.] J. Philips.
One who writes a parody; one who parodies. Coleridge.
Relating to or expressing admiration or wonder. [R.] Earle.
A borough or incorporated town, especially, one in Scotland.See Borough.
A common appellation for a North American Indian; -- so calledfrom the color of the skin. Cooper.
Humble condition or estate; humility. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A judge in the Isle of Man who decides controversies withoutprocess. Cowell.
A sweetmeat of boiled brown sugar or molasses made withalmonds, and flavored with orange or lemon juice, etc. Thackeray.
A man of elevated rank or station; a nobleman. In Spain, anobleman of the first rank, who may be covered in the king'spresence.
The enforcement of methods of correction against one guilty ofecclesiastical offenses; reformatory or penal action toward a churchmember.
One of a Gnostic sect of the second century, so called fromMarcus, an Egyptian, who was reputed to be a margician.
Full of, or covered with, patches; abounding in patches.
One's acts considered as fixing one's lot in the futureexistence. (Theos.) The doctrine of fate as the inflexible result ofcause and effect; the theory of inevitable consequence.
A kind of coccolith, which in shape resembles a minute cupwidened at the top, and varies in size from
A large noxious fly of Abyssinia, which like the tsetse fly, isdestructive to cattle.
A genus of crustaceans, containing the crawfish of fresh-waterlobster of Europe, and allied species of western North America. SeeCrawfish.
One who furnishes outfits for a voyage, a journey, or abusiness.
Leisure; indolence; idleness; ease. [R.] Thackeray.
A drug useful in neuralgia, derived from a Fijian plantsupposed to be of the aroid genus Epipremnum.
Having a part displaced, as if broken; -- said of an ordinary.Macaulay.
The office or occupation of a tutor; tutorship; guardianship.
An alkaloid constituting the active principle of ergot; -- sonamed from its power of producing abortion.
That part of the bottom of a vessel on each side of the keelsonwhich is most nearly horizontal.
Work turned on a lathe; turnery.[Obs.] See Turnery. Evelyn.
A liquor composed of vegetable acid, especially lemon juice,and sugar, with spirit to preserve it.
A variety of pyroxene, usually of a black or dark green color,occurring in igneous rocks, such as basalt; -- also used instead ofthe general term pyroxene.
An extinct genus of large herbivorous dinosaurs, found inJurassic strata in America.
One of the suckerlike rootlets of such plants as the dodder andivy. R. Brown.
A coarse, narrow cloth, like frieze, used by the lower classesin the sixteenth century. Halliwell.
The act or process of reducing. See Reduce, v. t., 6. and Toreduce an equation, To reduce an expression, under Reduce, v. t.
A genus of plants of the Cactus family. They are natives ofAmerica, from California to Chili.
To make a victim of; to sacrifice; to immolate. [Obs.]Bullokar.
A wind instrument made of reeds tied together; -- called alsopandean pipes.
One of a series of artificial blue or red dyes obtained fromquinoline and lepidine and used in calico printing.
A surcingle, or strap of leather, used for binding a load uponthe back of a beast; also, a leather tie; a short wagon rope. [Prov.Eng.]
A plane for shaving or dressing the concave or inside faces ofbarrel staves.
The Evil Principle or Being of the ancient Persians; the Princeof Darkness as opposer to Ormuzd, the King of Light.
Want of civism; want of patriotism or love to one's country;unfriendliness to one's state or government. [R.] Macaulay.
A poem in which the final letters of the lines, takenconsequently, make a name. Cf. Acrostic.
Like the sky, or approaching the sky; lofty; ethereal. [R.]Shak.
an ovum composed entirely of germinal matter. See Meroblast.
A pattern produced by arranging the warp threads in sets ofalternating colors, or in sets presenting some other contrast ofappearance.
Of or relating to a dynasty or line of kings. Motley.
Any one of numerous species of singing birds belonging toTurdus and allied genera. They are noted for the sweetness of theirsongs.
The practice of begging; the life of a beggar; mendicancy. Rom.of R.
A period during which an obligor has a legal right to delaymeeting an obligation, esp. such a period granted, as to a bank, by amoratory law.
Description or comparative study of the customs of savage oruncivilized tribes.
The preaching or promulgation of the gospel. Bacon.
A genus of fossil whales belonging to the Phocodontia; -- socalled because their are serrated, like a shark's.
A genus of ferns with twining or climbing fronds, bearingstalked and variously-lobed divisions in pairs.
The interior or central region of a country; -- usually in theplural. Drayton.
The Mexican pocket gopher (Geomys Mexicanus). It resembles thecommon pocket gopher of the Western United States, but is larger.Called also tugan, and tuza.
A plant of the genus Artemisa (A. dracunculus), much used inFrance for flavoring vinegar.
A limpid, colorless oil with a peculiar odor, obtained frombeech tar. Watts.
A diminution in the normal amount of fibrin present in theblood.
To besprinkle or scatter over with, or as with, flowers.Hobbes.
A large species of barbel (Barbus bynni), found in the Nile,and much esteemed for food.
An acid containing oxygen, as chloric acid or sulphuric acid; -- contrasted with the hydracids, which contain no oxygen, ashydrochloric acid. See Acid, and Hydroxy-.
Having no spleen; hence, kind; gentle; mild. [Obs.] Chapman.
An amorphous nitrogenous substance found in the spermatic fluidof salmon. It is soluble in water, which an alkaline reaction, andunites with acids and metallic bases.
A projecting block worked under the corona of the Doric corice,in the same situation as the modillion of the Corinthian andComposite orders. See Illust. of Gutta. Oxf. Gloss.
The falling down of a part through the orifice with which it isnaturally connected, especially of the uterus or the rectum.Dunglison.
To subject to the process of vapor galvanizing (which see,below).
A rake for collecting hay; especially, a large rake drawn by ahorse or horses.
The process of pointing, edging, or overlaying with steel;specifically, acierage. See Steel, v.
A whim, or burst of ill-humor; an affected air. [Colloq.]Thackeray.
The California poison oak (Rhus diversiloba). See under Poison,a.
To be convereted into a powder or friable substance, or into acalx, by the action of heat. "Calcining without fusion" Newton.
The radical PO, regarded as the typical nucleus of certaincompounds.
Lit., May you live ten thousand years; -- used in salutation ofthe emperor and as a battle cry. [Japan]
Suitableness of one thing to another; agreement; consistency.Holland.
The throstle, or song thrust. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]When he heard the thrustel sing. Chaucer.
A hydrous sulphate of alumina occurring in white reniformmasses.
To deprive of the character or authority of a prince; to divestof principality of sovereignty. [R.] Swift.
The running together of the matter of an ore into a mass, whenthe ore is only heated for calcination.
Of or pert. to the German physicist Heinrich Hertz.
A cartilaginous fish of several species, belonging to the orderHolocephali. The teeth are few and large. The head is furnished withappendages, and the tail terminates in a point.
The acrid principle of Monesia, sometimes used as a medicine.
A small house or building at a little distance from the mainhouse; an outbuilding.
To fright or terrify. See Gally, v. t. [Obs.] Shak.
Situated under a zone, or zona; -- applied to a membranebetween the zona radiata and the umbilical vesicle in the mammalembryo.
Waste or misapplication of the assets of a deceased person byan executor or an administrator. Bouvier.
To be nourished or trained up together. [Obs.] Spenser.
The doctrines, principles, or practice of a mystagogue;interpretation of mysteries.
An allowance of wood to a tenant for repairing his hedges orfences; hedgebote. See Bote. Blackstone.
The quality or state or dividing in a forklike manner.
The right of presentation to church or ecclesiastical benefice;advowson. Blackstone.
The introductory or subordinate member of a sentence, generallyof a conditional sentence; -- opposed to apodosis. See Apodosis.
Love of country; devotion to the welfare of one's country; thevirtues and actions of a patriot; the passion which inspires one toserve one's country. Berkley.
A genus of flowerless plants, having articulated stems andwhorled branches. They flourish in wet places.
Formerly, a local judge among miners; now, an officer of thebarmote. [Eng.]
One who is skilled in the art of anatomy, or dissection.
Art of preparing sections (transverse, tangential, or radial)of wood, esp. by means of a microtome, for microscopic examination.

A South African shrub (Barosma) with small leaves that aredotted with oil dlands; also, the leaves themselves, which are usedin medicine for diseases of the urinary organs, etc. Several speciesfurnish the leaves.
An elastic band worn around the wrist, as for the purpose ofsecuring the upper part of a glove.
The legislative assembly, composed of nobility, clergy, andrepresentatives of cities, which in Spain and in Portugal answers, insome measure, to the Parliament of Great Britain.
A hairlike feather; a father with a slender scape and without aweb in most or all of its length.
The court of a sovereign or of a feudal lord; also; hisresidence or his household. Burrill.
A man's coat to be worn over his other garments; an overcoat,especially when long, and fitting closely like a body coat. Gay.
The flight of Mohammed from Mecca, September 13, A. D. 622(subsequently established as the first year of the Moslem era);hence, any flight or exodus regarded as like that of Mohammed.
The act of annexing, or the thing annexed; appendage. [R.]Shak.
A hood-shaped bandage for the head, the shoulder, or the stumpof an amputated limb.
Of or pertaining to paranoia; affected with, or characteristicof, paranoia.
A countryman; a rustic; especially, one of the lowest class oftillers of the soil in European countries.
To rear, or bring up; to nurse. "Upbred in a foreign country."Holinshed.
To ward off, evade, or turn aside something, as a blow,argument, etc. Locke.
Of or pertaining to the country of the ancient Silures; -- aterm applied to the earliest of the Paleozoic eras, and also to thestrata of the era, because most plainly developed in that country.
The use of a word of common or general signification for thename of a particular thing; as, "He has gone to town," for, "He hasgone to London."
One who writes epistles; a correspondent. Mary Cowden Clarke.
The action of a horse, when, to get rid of his rider, he rears,plunges, and kicks furiously.
Of or pertaining to Paphos, an ancient city of Cyprus, having acelebrated temple of Venus; hence, pertaining to Venus, or her rites.
A disease of plants caused by fungi, commonly called the rust,from its resemblance to iron rust in color.
To throw off impurities in spume; to work off in foam or scum;to foam.
That may be calculated or ascertained by calculation.
The hypothetical radical of certain quinone derivatives relatedto rhodizonic acid.
To suffocate or stifle; to smother. [Scot. & Prov. Eng.]
A genus of large marine gastropods having a thick heavy shellwith conspicuous folds on the columella.
An extinct quaternary mammal, of great size, allied to thesloth.
The chemical basis of ordinary connective tissue, as of tendonsor sinews and of bone. On being boiled in water it becomes gelatin orglue.
The office, dignity, or government of a caliph or of thecaliphs.
To mark by bounds; to set the limits of; to separate; todiscriminate. Wilkinson.
A photographic picture copied from the negative on glass; aphotographic transparency. R. Hunt.
A tool used for applying a fresh percussion cap or primer to acartridge shell in reloading it.
An officer in Scotland, whose office formerly corresponded tothat of sheriff, but now corresponds to that of an English alderman.
That portion of an anthocarpous fruit which is not derived fromthe ovary, as the soft part of a strawberry or of a fig.
The middle part; half; moiety. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A person who dies without making a valid will. Blackstone.
A collection of traditions received by the orthodox Mohammedansas of equal authority with the Koran.
One of the higher alcohols of the methane series, homologouswith ethal, and found in small quantities as an ethereal salt ofstearic acid in spermaceti.
A contrivence used in a loom for keeping the web stretchedtransversely.
One who keeps accounts; one who has the charge of keeping thebooks and accounts in an office.
A ferruginous variety of shalerite or zinc blende, nearly blackin color.

A deed, bond, or other written engagement, delivered to a thirdperson, to be held by him till some act is done or some condition isperformed, and then to be by him delivered to the grantee.Blackstone.
Resting upon columns; constructed by means of columns; --especially applied to the great hall at Karnak.
A cutaneous affection characterized by yellow or yellowishbrown pigmented spots.
Abounding in money; wealthy; rich. [Obs.] Sherwood.
A brick or stone laid with its longer dimension in the line ofdirection of the wall. Gwilt.
One's birth, or the circumstances attending it. [Obs.] Fitz-Geffry.
A half-vill, consisting of five freemen or frankpledges.Blackstone.
The science which treats of vocal sounds. J. Peile.
Anything crescent-shaped; a crescent-shaped part or mark; alunula, a lune.
The disciple who betrayed Christ. Hence: A treacherous person;one who betrays under the semblance of friendship.-- a.
Shaped like an arrowhead; triangular, with the two basal anglesprolonged downward.
The art or practice of curing the deformities of children, or,by extension, any deformities of the human body.
To withdraw, or take out, as a rope from a block, thimble, orthe like.
A machine generating more than one pressure wave; amultiphaser.
A place of nether darkness, being the gloomy space throughwhich the souls passed to Hades. See Milton's "Paradise Lost," BookII., line 883.
Bodily condition or constitution, esp. a morbid habit whichpredisposes to a particular disease, or class of diseases.
A medicine which destroys intestinal worms; a worm killer.Pereira.
A dance performed by two persons in circular figures with awhirling motion; also, a piece of music composed in triple measurefor this kind of dance.
A heavy gaseous hydrocarbon, C3H8, of the paraffin series,occurring naturally dissolved in crude petroleum, and also madeartificially; -- called also propyl hydride.
One who perceives (in any of the senses of the verb). Milton.
Low, fertile land; a river valley. [Scot.] Jomieson.
Of or pertaining to an office or an officer; official. [R.]Heylin.
The act or management of one who jockeys; trickery.Beaconsfield.
A hydrocarbon obtained from coal-tar residues, and remarkablefor its intense yellowish green fluorescence.
A writer on feuds; a person versed in feudal law. Spelman.
The increase of a variable quantity or fraction from itspresent value to its next ascending value; the finite quantity,generally variable, by which a variable quantity is increased.
To act upon, in any way, so as to cause change of form orvolume, as forces on a beam to bend it.
Grass-green; clear, lively green, without any mixture. Lindley.
A place for children's dolls and dolls' furniture. Swift.
Breaking out; -- said of certain fungi which burst through thetexture of leaves.
An officer who assigned to each his rank and place in publicshows and ceremonies.
The quality of being averse; opposition of mind; unwillingness.
The unsymmetrical hypothetical hydrocarbon radical, CH3.CH2.CH,analogous to ethylidene, and regarded as the type of certainderivatives of propane; -- called also propylidene.
A brownish green pigment found in human gallstones and in oldbile. It is a derivative of bilirubin.
The returning of a thing purchased to the seller, on the groundof defect or frand.
To touch gently, as with the elbow, in order to call attentionor convey intimation.
A church road (e. g., a path across fields) for funerals.[Obs.] Homilies.
To melt and become liquid by absorbing water from the air; todeliquesce. Fourcroy.
An apparatus for the production of sound by the action ofluminous or thermal rays. It is essentially the same as thephotophone.
The rod used in ramming home the charge in a muzzle-loadingfirearm.
One who cleaves, or that which cleaves; especially, a butcher'sinstrument for cutting animal bodies into joints or pieces.

The bark of several trees, esp. of Bowdichia virgilioides ofBrazil, used as a remedy for consumption; of Byrsonima crassifolia,used in tanning; of Alchornea latifolia, used medicinally; or ofQuercus ilex, the cork tree.
Placed in apposition; mutually fitting, as the mandibles of abird's beak.
An implement for reducing a stiff soil, resembling a harrow,but running upon wheels. Hebert.
Capable of being deluded; liable to be imposed on gullible. SirT. Browne.
A dark-colored substance obtained from empyreumatic animal oil.[R.]
A mulct or fine imposed on a person for making a fight orquarrel to the disturbance of the peace.
An instrument attached to a locomotive for recording its speedand the number and duration of its stops.
The act of praying; supplication; entreaty. Cotton.
The act of scoffing; scoffing conduct; mockery. Holinshed.
Having the whorls of the spire revolving or rising to the left;reversed; -- said of certain spiral shells.
The beam which supports the spindle socket of the runner in agrinding mill. Knight.
One who, or that which, retracts. Specifically:(a) In breech-loading firearms, a device for withdrawing a cartridgeshell from the barrel. (b) (Surg.)
To loose from shackles or bonds; to set free from restraint; tounfetter. Addison.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling asbestus; inconsumable;asbestine.
The science which treats of the cultivation of the cinchona,and of its use in medicine.
A rope used in hoisting the anchor to the cathead. Totten.
Pertaining to, or having the character of, a jubilee. [R.] Bp.Hall.
A tumor consisting mainly of fibrous tissue, or of samemodification of such tissue.
A curl of hair or silk; a pad of frizzed hair or silk worn bywomen under the hair to stuff it out.
A tree from which the branches have been cut; a pollard.
A Spanish silver coin, and money of account, equal to aboutnineteen cents, and divided into 100 centesimos.
The first sketch of a picture or model of a statue.
Becoming hard and thorny; tapering gradually to a rigid,leafless point; armed with spines. Gray.
A soldier of the ancient Muscovite guard or Russian standingarmy; also, the guard itself.
A patent anodyne medicine, containing opium, chloroform, Indianhemp, etc.
A cart so constructed that the body can be easily tipped, inorder to dump the load.
A piece of timber placed across the stem, to unite the bows andstrengthen the fore part of the ship; a breast hook.
A European lake whitefish (Coregonus Willughbii, or C.Vandesius) native of certain lakes in Scotland and England. It isregarded as a delicate food fish. Called also vendis.
A genus of moths, which includes the silkworm moth. SeeSilkworm.
The large, hard-shelled nut of the cocoa palm. It yields anagreeable milky liquid and a white meat or albumen much used as foodand in making oil.
Any fish whose scales yield a pearl-like pigment used inmanufacturing artificial pearls, as the bleak, and whitebait.

The art or process of making a kind of hard, stereotypeplate,by pressing into a mold, taken from a page of type or other matter, acomposition of gum shell-lac and sand of a fine quality, togetherwith a little tar and linseed oil, all in a heated state.
The lowest title of nobility in Portugal, corresponding to thatof Hidalgo in Spain.
Pertaining to, or resembling, youth; youthful. [Obs.] Spenser.
A bivalve mollusk, with radiating ribs, of the genus Cardium,especially C. edule, used in Europe for food; -- sometimes applied tosimilar shells of other genera.
A description or definition contrary to that which is given bythe adverse party. [R.]
Covered with a fine bloom or fine white powder easily rubbedoff, as that on a blue plum, or on a cabbage leaf. Gray.
A name locally applied to various wild plants, as dandelion,bluet, oxeye daisy, etc.
Pertaining to, consisting of, or containing, blende.
A crystalline nitrogenous base, C10H8N2, obtained by thereduction of pyridine.
A general name for organ stops in which the sound is caused bywind passing through a flue or fissure and striking an edge above; --in distinction from reedwork.

In certain Sporozoa, a cell formed by the growth of asporozoite or merozoite (in a cell or corpuscle of the host) whichsegment by superficial cleavage, without encystment or conjugation,into  merozoites.
A small appendage situated above the base of the wings ofHymenoptera and attached to the mesonotum.
A genus of spiders, including the common garden spider (E.diadema). They spin geometrical webs. See Garden spider.
The process of sending any matter, for inquiry in a cause, to amaster or other officer, in order that he may ascertain facts andreport to the court.
To cause to be disbelieved; to discredit. [Obs.] Fuller.

Two small, concave shells of ivory or hard wood, shaped likespoons, fastened to the thumb, and beaten together with the middlefinger; -- used by the Spaniards and Moors as an accompaniment totheir dance and guitars.
Any one of several of South African lizards of the genusZonura, common in rocky situations.

Orig., an officer appointed to look to the goodness of ale andbeer; also, one of the officers chosen by the liverymen of London toinspect the measures used in public houses. But the office is asinecure. [Also called aletaster.] [Eng.]
The rim which encompasses and fastens a jewel or other object,as the crystal of a watch, in the cavity in which it is set.
A genus of large oceanic Siphonophora which includes thePortuguese man-of-war.
To catch or entangle in, or as in, the meshes of a net. or in aweb; to insnare.
The solid contents of a body; volume; amount of inclosed space.
A papular disease of the skin, of which intense itching is thechief symptom, the eruption scarcely differing from the healthycuticle in color.
Of, pertaining to, or like, Trachinus, a genus of fishes whichincludes the weevers. See Weever.
The thickened posterior border of the corpus callosum; -- socalled in allusion to its shape.
A genus of biennial, poisonous, white-flowered, umbelliferousplants, bearing ribbed fruit ("seeds") and decompound leaves.

To bear up; to raise aloft; to support in an elevatedsituation; to sustain. Spenser.One short sigh of breath, upbore Even to the seat of God. Milton.A monstrous wave upbore The chief, and dashed him on the craggyshore. Pope.
To implant a portion of (living flesh or akin) in a lesion soas to form an organic union.
Not using words; not speaking; silent; speechless. Shak.
A foliar part of a plant; any organ homologous with a leaf, orproduced by metamorphosis of a leaf.
The bow or arch in the front part of a saddle, or the pieceswhich form the front.
The lowest division of rhizopods, including those whichresemble the amoebas, but are destitute of a nucleus.
To unwind, unfold, or untie; hence, to undo; to ruin. Shak.
A dark green igneous rock, consisting largely of chrysolite,with hornblende, augite, biotite, etc.
A week day, esp. a day which is neither a festival nor a fast.Shipley.
Of or pertaining to a vestige or remnant; like a vestige.
Toward the inside or central part; away from the surface; --opposed to ectad. B. G. Wilder.
The quality or state of being tumulous; hilliness. [R.] Bailey.
Balancing; moving like a balance, as it tends to an equipoiseor level.
The free-swimming, hat-shaped larva of certain nemertean worms.It has no resemblance to its parent, and the young worm develops inits interior.
Bad address; an awkward, tactless, or offensive way ofaccosting one or talking with one. W. D. Howells.
Having the shape of an egg, or of the longitudinal sectior ofan egg, with the broader end basal. Gray.
To sound wrongly; to utter or pronounce incorrectly. E,Hall.
A sea bird of the Atlantic (Rhynchops nigra); -- called alsoblack skimmer, scissorsbill, and razorbill. See Skimmer.
One who deputes, or makes a deputation. [R.] Locke.
A small arch thrown across the corner of a square room tosupport a superimposed mass, as where an octagonal spire or drumrests upon a square tower; -- called also sconce, and sconcheon.
One who conforms to or inculcates Judaism; specifically, pl.(Ch. Hist.), those Jews who accepted Christianity but still adheredto the law of Moses and worshiped in the temple at Jerusalem.
A thickened glandular portion of the body of the adultearthworm, consisting of several united segments modified forreproductive purposes.
An oval lobe beneath each of the optic lobes in many fishes;one of the inferior lobes. Owen.
The pressure of one dyne per square centimeter; -- used as aunit of pressure.
Of or pertaining to the Fiji islands or their inhabitants.-- n.
The condition of certain species of plants, in which thestamens and pistil do not mature simultaneously, so that these plantscan never fertilize themselves.
One who upholds or supports that which props; one who, or thatwhich, stays, stops, or restrains; also, colloquially, a horse, man,etc., that has endurance, an a race.
A small marine isopod crustacean (Limnoria lignorum or L.terebrans), which burrows into and rapidly destroys submerged timber,such as the piles of wharves, both in Europe and America.
The act or process of making and applying rands for shoes.

The European golden-crested kinglet (Regulus cristatus, or R.regulus); -- called also golden-crested wren, and golden wren. Thename is also sometimes applied to the American golden-crestedkinglet. See Kinglet.
A small coin, and money of account, in England, equivalent totwo pennies, -- minted to a fixed annual amount, for almsgiving bythe sovereign on Maundy Thursday.
Anything in three parts or leaves. Specifically: --(a) A writing tablet in three parts, two of which fold over on themiddle part.(b) A picture or altarpiece in three compartments.
A large cup or deep saucer, containing fatty matter in which awick is placed, -- used for public illuminations, as at St. Peter's,in Rome. Called also padelle.
An order of Merostomata, including among living animals thegenus Limulus, with various allied fossil genera, mostly of theCarboniferous period. Called also Xiphosura.
A machine for spreading out cotton cloths to prepare them forprinting.
The quality or state of being pallid; paleness; pallor;wanness.
Over; above; before; also, beyond; besides; -- much used as aprefix.
The order of amphibians which includes the frogs and toads; theAnura. Sometimes the word is used in a wider sense as equivalent toAmphibia.
Similar. [Obs.]Rhyming cadences of similarly words. South.
The nobility or aristocracy of ancient Rome, as opposed to thepopulares.
Rubbish. Specifically: (a) Dross or refuse of metals. [Obs.](b) Light, dry wood, or stuff used for fuel. [Prov. Eng.]
The quality or condition of having strong reproductive powers;generation with full fertility between different species or races,specif. between hybrids of the first generation.
An instrument for estimating the purity or richness of milk, asa measuring glass, a specific gravity bulb, or other apparatus.

An elementary substance found combined in the mineralsmanaccanite, rutile, sphene, etc., and isolated as an infusible iron-gray amorphous powder, having a metallic luster. It burns when heatedin the air. Symbol Ti. Atomic weight 48.1.
A transparent, extensible membrane of extreme tenuity, whichforms the innermost coating of grains of pollen.
The name of Vishnu in his tenth and last avatar. Whitworth.
One who gives birth to twins; a breeder of twins. Tusser.
To make drunk; to intoxicate; to fuddle. [Obs.] Burton.
A medicinal plant, the thoroughwort (Eupatorium perfoliatum).Its properties are diaphoretic and tonic.
A sign or memorial of a victory raised on the field of battle,or, in case of a naval victory, on the nearest land. Sometimestrophies were erected in the chief city of the conquered people.
A word from the vocabulary of Mrs. Quickly, the hostess inShakespeare's Henry IV., probably meaning terror.
The rough surface of a congealed lava stream. [Southwestern U.S.]
A member of a club; a frequenter of clubs. [R.] Burke.
Considered as having done sufficient public service, andtherefore honorably discharged. [Obs.] Evelyn.
The black-backed gull (Larus marinus); -- called also swarbie.[Prov. Eng.]
A genus of showy flowering shrubs, mostly natives of China orof North America; false honeysuckle. The genus is scarcely distinctfrom Rhododendron.
To distill, as spirit from molasses or some saccharinepreparation.
A spherulitic cavity often with concentric chambers, observedin some volcanic rocks, as in rhyolitic lavas. It is supposed to beproduced by expanding gas, whence the name.
To supply with provender or provisions; to provide for. [Obs.]Nash.
A contrivance in some of the ealier steam engines for movingthe valves for the alternate admission and shutting off of the steam.
Loss of the power of speaking, while retaining the power ofwriting; -- a disorder of cerebral origin.
A sweet amorphous deliquescent substance obtained indirectlyfrom benzene, and isometric with, and resembling, dextrose.
A black, granular, explosive substance, consisting of anintimate mechanical mixture of niter, charcoal, and sulphur. It isused in gunnery and blasting.
A subdivision of a regiment of troops under the command of acaptain, numbering in the United States (full strength) 100 men.
A kind of narrow braid, usually of silk; -- also known asRussian braid.
Of or pertaining to sound; of the nature of sound; acoustic.Tyndall.
The absence or loss of the power of expressing ideas by writtensigns. It is one form of aphasia.
The quality of having similar sexual zooids or gonophores anddissimilar hydrants; -- said of certain hydroids.
A whisk to keep off files, used in the East Indies. Malcom.
An endemic disease occurring in the Andes in Peru,characterized by warty tumors which ulcerate and bleed. It isprobably due to a special bacillus, and is often fatal.
Of or pertaining to a relic or relics; of the nature of arelic. [R.]
Full of trade; busy in traffic; commercial. Spenser.
One who, or that which; sounds; specifically, an instrumentused in telegraphy in place of a register, the communications beingread by sound.
Plumes, collectively or in general; plumage. [R.] Southey.
In a naked manner; without covering or disguise; manifestly;simply; barely.
An animal, not truly parasitic, which lives in with, or on,another, partaking usually of the same food. Both species may bebenefited by the association.
Having the planes arranged spirally, so that they incline allto the right (or left) of a vertical line; -- said of certainhemihedral forms.
To make red or somewhat red; to give a red color to.
The peculiar character, manners, tenets, etc., of the Quakers.
To feed with eagerness or voracity; to stuff one's self withfood. Beaumont.
A long, winding constellation extending southward from Taurusand containing the bright star Achernar.
A mineral occurring in hexagonal crystals, also massive,generally of a yellow color, containing silica, alumina, lime, soda,and carbon dioxide.
That part of arithmetic which treats of adding numbers.
A substance of a resinous nature, obtained from the outer barkof the common European birch (Betula alba), or from the tar preparedtherefrom; -- called also birch camphor. Watts.
A variety of rhodonite, from Franklin Furnace, New Jersey,containing some zinc.
A florid style of ornamentation which prevailed in Europe inthe latter part of the eighteenth century.

Production of decorative designs by scratching them through asurface of layer plaster, glazing, etc., revealing a different-colored ground; also, pottery or ware so decorated; -- chiefly usedattributively.
Loathsome; disgusting; hateful. [Obs.]Murder is . . . wlatsom and abhominable to God. Chaucer.
One who engraves; a person whose business it is to produceengraved work, especially on metal or wood.
First brought forth; first in the order of nativity; eldest;hence, most excellent; most distinguished or exalted.
Absence or lack of peace. [Obs.] Testament of Love.
Alternating transparent and opaque white rings which are seenoutside the blastoderm, on the surface of the developing egg of thehen and other birds.
A person excluded from the benefit of the law, or deprived ofits protection. Blackstone.
To make smooth or plane, as a metallic surface; to condense,toughen, and polish by light blows with a hammer.
A frame or support for holding something in place, as journalboxes, etc.
The fragrant flowers of the Chloranthus inconspicuus, used inChina for perfuming tea.
A strip of wood or iron fastened on transversely to somethingin order to give strength, prevent warping, hold position, etc.
One of the sweet spices used by the ancient Jews in thepreparation of incense. It was perhaps an oil or other form of myrrhor cinnamon, or a kind of storax. Ex. xxx. 34.
Six times ten; fifty-nine and one more; threescore.
Termination a disease; indicating the end of a disease.
The act or manner of binding up; bandage; also, the conditionof being fasciated.
To follow closely; to endeavor to overtake; to pursue. [Obs.]Bp. Burnet.
The act of resulting; that which results; a result. Donne.
Hydrous carbonate of lanthanum, found in tabular whilecrystals.
A genus of herbaceous prickly plants, found in the south ofEurope, Asia Minor, and India; bear's-breech.
Those birds whose young are covered with down when hatched.
A cone-shaped piece of wood on the point of the spindle abovethe vane, on the mast-head.
A small cone or mass made of paste of gum, benzoin, cinnamon,and other aromatics, -- used for fumigating or scenting the air of aroom.
A mineral consisting of sulphate of lead, occurring eithermassive or in long slender prisms, of a greenish white or gray color.
One who sells rum; one who deals in intoxicating liquors;especially, one who sells spirituous beverages at retail.
A curious colubriform snake of the genus Xyphorhynchus, fromMadagascar. It is brownish red, and its hose is prolonged in the formof a sharp blade.
A bearing representing the head of a dart or javelin, with longbarbs which are engrailed on the inner edge.
To make efficacious; to give virtue of efficacy. [Obs.] Harvey.
The great extensor muscle of the knee, divided above into fourparts which unite in a single tendon at the knee.
One of the bones or cartilages of the carpus, which articulateswith the ulna and corresponds to the cuneiform in man.
Deprived of the faculty of will or volition. Mrs. Browning.
A sentence, phrase, or word, forming part of an heraldicachievment.
The root of a leguminous plant (Psoralea esculenta), found nearthe Rocky Mountains. It is usually oval in form, and abounds infarinaceous matter, affording sweet and palatable food.
A shelter to protect from snow, esp. a long roof over anexposed part of a railroad.
A genus of fishes, including the fresh-water perch.

A genus of herbaceous composite plants, having the achenes two-horned and remotely resembling some insect; tickseed. C. tinctoria,of the Western plains, the commonest plant of the genus, has beenused in dyeing.
One of the terminal branches or divisions of the beam of theantler of the stag or other large deer.
A thick plain silk, generally black, and used for clerical.Simmonds.
One who frequents playhouses, or attends dramatic performances.
The collective lighter equipments or outfit of a bride,including clothes, jewelry, and the like; especially, that which isprovided for her by her family.
A morbid condition in which the urine contains chyle or fattymatter, giving it a milky appearance.
Situated under, or on the ventral side of, the eye.
Having all the parts or organs which belong to it or to thetypical form; having calyx, corolla, stamens, and pistil.
An organ of the Ctenophora, supposed to be sensory.
Curved somewhat in the form of the letter S. Cussans.
A kind of rich, sweet cake; -- so called from the ingredientsbeing used by pounds, or in equal quantities.
The system or theory that denies the existence of materialbodies, and teaches that we have no rational grounds to believe inthe reality of anything but ideas and their relations.
An instrument used for measuring the distance of an object froman observer; as, a telescope with a micrometer for measuring theapparent diameter of an object whose real dimensions are known.
Madeira mahogany; the coarse, dark-colored wood of the PerseaIndica.
Not liable to sin; exempt from the possibility of doing wrong.-- n.
Any of several isomeric iodine derivatives of the cresols,C6H3I(CH3)OH, esp. one, an odorless amorphous powder, used inmedicine as a substitute for iodoform.
To challenge or discredit the credibility of, as of a witness,or the validity of, as of commercial paper.
To impregnate with azote, or nitrogen; to nitrogenize.
