Destructive or downward metabolism; regressive metamorphism; --opposed to anabolism. See Disassimilation.
The reducing of anything to ashes by combustion; cinefaction.
Pertaining to an army marching, or to a train. [R.]
A subordinate officer on an extensive estate, who acts as anassistant to the steward.

A heavy, brilliant red pigment, consisting of an oxide of lead,Pb3O4, obtained by exposing lead or massicot to a gentle andcontinued heat in the air. It is used as a cement, as a paint, and inthe manufacture of flint glass. Called also red lead.
An herb used in medicine (Plantago Psyllium), named from theshape of its seeds. Loudon.
Of or pertaining to Clement, esp. to St.Clement of Rome and thespurious homilies attributed to him, or to Pope Clement V. and hiscompilations of canon law.
A harmless lizard of the Gecko family (PlatydactylusMauritianicus) found in Southern Europe and adjacent countries,especially among old walls and ruins.
A suborder of corals including many reef-building species,having round, starlike calicles.
Of or pertaining to silver; resembling, containing, or combinedwith, silver.
Anything scattered, as flowers for decoration. [Obs.] Shak.
A mineral of a brownish black color, related to titanite inform. It consists chiefly of silica, titanium dioxide, lime, andyttria.
To unite with glue; to cement; to stick together. Bailey.
Cloth, specifically cotton cloth, suitable for making shirts.
The quality or state of being vivid; vividness. [R.]
A genus of Branchiopoda, having a disklike shell, attached byone valve, which is perforated by the peduncle.
The edible fruit of an East Indian tree (Baccaurea Malayana) ofthe Spurge family. It somewhat resembles an apple.
An American endogenous plant (Tradescantia Virginica), withlong linear leaves and ephemeral blue flowers. The name is sometimesextended to other species of the same genus.
A tract of low land reclaimed from the sea by of highembankments. [Holland & Belgium]
One who, or a vessel that, cruises; -- usually an armed vessel.
Having the two main flexor tendons of the toes blendedtogether.
A movement or phase in post-impressionism (which see, below). -- Cu"bist (#), n.
Sullenness; silent displeasure; the sulks. Skinner.
The state of being stormy; tempestuousness; biosteruousness;impetuousness.
A marsupial of Australia (Dasyurus macrurus), about the size ofa cat.
A nitrogenous organic base, C8H6N2, analogous to quinoline,obtained from certain complex diazo compounds.
Full of news; abounding in information as to current events.[Colloq.]
The pains which succeed childbirth, as in expelling theafterbirth.
To withdraw from fellowship, communion, or association; toseparate one's self by a solemn act; to draw off; to retire;especially, to withdraw from a political or religious body.
As much as a vessel will hold; enough to fill a vessel.
A building in which vessels' masts are shaped, fitted, etc.
Grief for sin arising only from fear of punishment or feelingsof shame. See Contrition. Wallis.
A book, or a list, of lections, for reading in divine service.
One who opposes; an opponent; an antagonist; an adversary.
A female heir who inherits with other heiresses; a jointheiress.
The quality of being costy; expensiveness; sumptuousness.
A complex nitrogenous compound obtained as a scarletcrystalline substance, and regarded as related to murexide.
A canopy usually standing free and supported on four columns,covering the high altar, or, very rarely, a secondary altar.
The principal bone of the shoulder girdle in mammals; theshoulder blade.

The larva of a small, hymenopterous fly (Eurytoma hordei),which is found in gall-like swellings on the stalks of wheat, usuallyat or just above the first joint. In some parts of America it doesgreat damage to the crop.
The outfit of clothing, blankets, etc., prepared for a newborninfant, and placed ready for used.
The larva of any species of geometrid moths. See Geometrid.

The dramatic practice or purpose characteristic of the writingsof Henrik Ibsen (1828-1906), Norwegian poet and dramatist, whosebest-known plays deal with conventional hypocrisies, the story ineach play thus developing a definite moral problem.

Of or pertaining to a region of the earth's surface includingall of temperate and arctic North America and Greenland. In thegeographical distribution of animals, this region is marked off asthe habitat certain species.
Having all the teeth similar in front, as in the porpoises; --opposed to heterodont.
One of a group of arachnids, including the mites and ticks.
An advocate of, or believer in, solidism. Dunglison.
A kind of oven, or reverberatory furnace, used for thecalcination of sand and potash, and converting them into frit. Ure.

The system of the Quietists, who maintained that religionconsists in the withdrawal of the mind from worldly interests andanxieties and its constant employment in the passive contemplation ofGod and his attributes.
The trade or work of an engraver. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
A small molding, carved into beads, pearls, olives, etc.
A variety of lignin or cellulose found in the medulla, or pith,of certain plants. Cf. Lignin, and Cellulose.

A cylindrical bundle of small sticks of wood, bound together,used in raising batteries, filling ditches, strengthening ramparts,and making parapets; also in revetments for river banks, and in matsfor dams, jetties, etc.
A severe beating with a stick, cudgel, or the fist.
Tired or sore of foot from travel; lamed. [Obs.] Nares.
Hollow and cylindrical, like a pipe or reed. Johnson.
The quality of having a nap; abundance of nap, as on cloth.
One who pays; specifically, the person by whom a bill or notehas been, or should be, paid.
In every place; in all places; hence, in every part; throughly;altogether.
To unwind; to disentangle; to loose. [Obs.] Spenser.
A hydrocarbon (C13H10) obtained in white fluorescent crystals,in the distillation products of the needles of the California "bigtree" (Sequoia gigantea).

The matter secreted by any of the sebaceous glands.Specifically:(a) The soapy substance covering the skin of newborn infants.(b) The cheesy, sebaceous matter which collects between the glanspenis and the foreskin.
Any one of the Fungi, a large and very complex group ofthallophytes of low organization, -- the molds, mildews, rusts,smuts, mushrooms, toadstools, puff balls, and the allies of each.
A translation or paraphrase of some portion of the OldTestament Scriptures in the Chaldee or Aramaic language or dialect.
A public assembly of the Roman people for electing officers orpassing laws.
Belonging to, or constituted by, timocracy. Sir G. C. Lewis.
An ethereal fluid that supplied the place of blood in the veinsof the gods.
Alack the day; alas; -- an expression of sorrow, regret,dissatisfaction, or surprise.
To prepare, treat, impregnate, or coat with bitumen.
Separated or broken up; -- said of the crest of birds when thefeathers are divergent.
A native of India employed as a soldier in the service of aEuropean power, esp. of Great Britain; an Oriental soldierdisciplined in the European manner.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, copper; containing copper;-- said of those compounds of copper in which this element is presentin its lowest proportion.
A noun which has no distinction of cases; an indeclinable noun.
A kind of coarse grass growing in wet grounds, and supposed tobe injurious to sheep. [Prov. Eng.]
The berrylike drupe of the elder. That of the Old World elder(Sambucus nigra) and that of the American sweet elder (S. Canadensis)are sweetish acid, and are eaten as a berry or made into wine.
The hypothetical principle of fire, or inflammability, regardedby Stahl as a chemical element.
To flow over the brim; to be so full as to overflow. [R.]

The thick, brown or dark colored, viscid, uncrystallizablesirup which drains from sugar, in the process of manufacture; anythick, viscid, sweet sirup made from vegetable juice or sap, as ofthe sorghum or maple. See Treacle.
A person competent to serve on a jury, in an action for land inthe hundred to which he belongs.
A low public house; especially, a place where spirits and otherexcisable liquors are illegally and privately sold. [Ireland]
Capable of being, or fit to be, pursued, followed, orprosecuted. Sherwood.
Of or pertaining to the movement of the eye; -- appliedespecially to the common motor nerves (or third pair of cranialnerves) which supply many of the muscles of the orbit.-- n.
An inhabitant of the more southern part of a country; formerly,a name given in Scotland to any Englishman.
A measure of length in Italy, varying from six to seven feet.See Cane, 4.
A believer in the doctrine of William Miller (d. 1849), whotaught that the end of the world and the second coming of Christ wereat hand.
Of or pertaining to dew; consisting of dew; dewy. [R.] M.Green.
A surgical instrument consisting of a slender knife, eitherstraight or curved, generally used by introducing it beneath the partto be divided, and cutting towards the surface.
The Greek letter S, or s). It originally had the form of theEnglish C.
Of or pertaining to the woodpeckers (Pici), or to thePiciformes.
A person well versed in theology; a professor of theology ordivinity; a divine.
Of or pertaining to covering; -- applied to a membraneimmediately over the organ of Corti in the internal ear.
A solid hydrocarbon, C20H42, of the paraffine series, ofartificial production, and also probably occurring in petroleum.
To intimidate by bullying; to rally contemptuously; to badger.[Low]
Aftermath; also, stubble and stubble field. See Arrish. [Eng.]
The act of solacing, or the state of being solaced; also, thatwhich solaces. [R.]
The closely matted hair or downy nap covering the leaves orstems of some plants.
The projector, manager, or conductor, of an opera or concertcompany.
The free-swimming larva of sea urchins and ophiurans, havingseveral long stiff processes inclosing calcareous rods.
Trembling or tottering, as if about to fall; un steady.[Colloq. U.S.]
An instrument for indicating and recording shocks to railwaycars occasioned by sudden stopping.
A base resembling and isomeric with conine, and obtained as acolorless liquid from butyric aldehyde and ammonia.
A nodule of flint, or a pebble, which resembles a fig. [Obs.]
The movable part of a stuffing box by which the packing iscompressed; -- sometimes called a follower. See Illust. of Stuffingbox, under Stuffing.
A colorless liquid, C6H4,OCH3.OH, resembling the phenols, foundas a constituent of woodtar creosote, aud produced by the drydistillation of guaiac resin.
An extinct genus of marine reptiles allied to Plesiosaurus, buthaving a much shorter neck.
Depression occasioned by terror; dismay. [Obs.] Bacon.

To have secretly a joint part or share in an action; to playinto each other's hands; to conspire; to act in concert.If they let things take their course, they will be represented ascolluding with sedition. Burke.

An officer whose business was to denounce or proclaim war, tochallenge to battle, to proclaim peace, and to bear messages from thecommander of an army. He was invested with a sacred and inviolablecharacter.
Seaweed; esp., coarse seaweed. See Ware, and Sea girdles.
A plant, Globularia Alypum, a violent purgative, found inAfrica.
A small due, in meal, established by usage, which is paid tothe under miller. [Scot.]
A person who is not of full age, or who has not attained theage of legal capacity; a person under the age of twenty-one years; aminor.
The condition of being flaggy; laxity; limberness. Johnson.

In the modern Olympic Games, a composite contest consisting ofa 100-meter run, a broad jump, putting the shot, a running high-jump,a 400-meter run, throwing the discus, a 100-meter hurdle race, polevaulting, throwing the javelin, and a 1500-meter run.
A contract or convention between Spain and other powers forfurnishing negro slaves for the Spanish dominions in America, esp.the contract made with Great Britain in 1713.
A celebrated Egyptian statue near Thebes, said to have theproperty of emitting a harplike sound at sunrise.
Soft material lying between the wall of a vein aud the solidvein. Raymond.
One who advocates the doctrine of pessimism; -- opposed to Ant:optimist.
To let; to hinder. See Let, to hinder. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A large stone reaching through a wall so as to appear on bothsides of it, and acting as a binder; -- called also perbend, perpendstone, and perpent stone.
Confinement within narrow limits, -- as of foreign troops, tothe interior of a country.
An unfermentable sugar, isomeric with glucose, found in theripe berries of the rowan tree, or sorb, and extracted as a sweetwhite crystalline substance; -- called also mountain-ash sugar.
To consume or reduce to ashes by burning, as a dead body; tocremate.
A package of gold beater's skins in which gold is subjected tothe second process of beating.
Up to this time; hitherto; before; in time past. Shak.
An instrument for measuring the rate of evaporation from amoist surface; an evaporometer. Huxley.

A species of the genus Bos or Bubalus (B. bubalus), originallyfrom India, but now found in most of the warmer countries of theeastern continent. It is larger and less docile than the common ox,and is fond of marshy places and rivers.
The art or process of producing or gauging a plane surface.
A tribe of sea birds comprising the petrels, shearwaters,albatrosses, hagdons, and allied birds having tubular horny nostrils.
In an initial or incipient manner or degree; at the beginning.Barrow.
A plate which supports the labrum in certain Crustacea.
To repeat the distillation of, pouring the liquor back upon thematter remaining in the vessel. Arbuthnot.
Of or pertaining to Assyria, or to its inhabitants.-- n. A native or an inhabitant of Assyria; the language of Assyria.
Counselor at law; a counsel admitted to plead at the bar, andundertake the public trial of causes, as distinguished from anattorney or solicitor. See Attorney. [Eng.]
Filled with hommocks; piled in the form of hommocks; -- said ofice.
A public establishment for the storage, or for the manufactureand storage, of arms and all military equipments, whether for land ornaval service.
The finishing of any face of a wall with material differentfrom that of which it is chiefly composed, or the coating or materialso used.
The right or duty of a patron; patronage. [R.] Westm. Rev.
To open the seam or seams of; to rip; to cut; to cut open.Shak.
A lifting or rising; a swell; a panting or deep sighing.Addison. Shak.
An affected elegance or euphuism of style, for which theSpanish poet Gongora y Argote (1561-1627), among others of his time,was noted.
The act of softening by mixing with a thinner substance; theformation of ingredients into a mass for pills or plasters. [R.]
A golf club like the iron, but with a shorter head, slightlymore lofted, used chiefly for short approaches.
To divide into two branches; to cause to branch apart.
The root of Spigelia Marilandica, used as a powerful vermifuge;also, that of S. Anthelmia. See definition 2 (below).
A slattern; an idle, sluttish, or untidy woman. [Obs. orColloq.]
Hanging down at the side; limp; drooping; without firmness orshapeliness; moving in an ungainly manner.
Divination by serpents, as by their manner of eating, or bytheir coils.
A tasteless, yellow, crystalline substance, obtained from thegentian; -- called also gentianin.
The pore or opening leading into the cavity of invagination, orarchenteron.
The cob or axis on which the kernels of Indian corn grow.[U.S.]
Absence or closure of a natural passage or channel of the body;imperforation.
Producing decomposition, as diseases which are supposed to beaccompanied or caused by decomposition.
Careful consideration; pondering. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
To go back; to retrograde, as the apsis of a planet's orbit.[R.] Todhunter.
A muslin wrapper for the head and the lower part of the face,worn by Turkish and Armenian women when they go abroad.
A plant growing entirely in the air, and receiving itsnourishment from it; an air plant or epiphyte.
A solution of alkaline salts extracted from wood ashes; hence,any solution obtained by lixiviation.
An instrument for ascertaining the weight and purity of oil; anelaiometer.
One who has the use of anything in trust for another. [Obs.]Daniel.
To graft by cutting the scion and stock in a certain manner.See Whip grafting, under Grafting.
An imaginary speech or discussion between two or more;dialogue. Fulke.
One who obscures; one who prevents enlightenment or hinders theprogress of knowledge and wisdom. Coleridge.
An openwork frame on which vessels are placed for examination,cleaning, and repairs. 3. (Sport)
A fine kind of French cotton goods, usually of one color.
An organic base obtained from quinoline. It is used as afebrifuge, and resembles kairine.
To stop (a leak in a ship at sea) by drawing under its bottom athrummed sail, so that the pressure of the water may force it intothe crack. Totten.
A genus of violaceous plants, chiefly found in tropicalAmerica, some species of which are used as substitutes foripecacuanha.
A piece of ground between the wall of a place and the moat.Farrow.
A mass or stratum of fragments or rock lying under thealluvium, and derived from the neighboring rock. Lyell.
To refurnish with a voice; to refit, as an organ pipe, so as torestore its tone.
Twisted; bent; -- said of a dolphin haurient, which forms afigure like the letter S.
To make like an angel; to angelize. [Obs.] Farindon (1647).
Of or pertaining to roads; happening on roads. [Obs.]
Heathy; abounding in heather; of the nature of heath.
(a) One who abates a nuisance. (b) A person who, without right,enters into a freehold on the death of the last possessor, before theheir or devisee. Blackstone.
Generally or popularly admitted or received. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
A trifoliate plant used as a national emblem by the Irish. Thelegend is that St. Patrick once plucked a leaf of it for use inillustrating the doctrine of the trinity.
A peculiar rounded granule of some mineral, usually enstatiteor chrysolite, found imdedded more or less aboundantly in the mass ofmany meteoric stones, which are hence called chondrites.
A dark resinous substance, polymeric with indol, and obtainedby the reduction of indigo white.
Equality of condition, blood, or dignity; also, equality in thepartition of an inheritance. Spelman.
A duty or tax paid by merchants for the protection of theirconnerce by means of a consul in a foreign place.
A joint of the cirri of the Crinoidea; a joint or segment of anarthropod appendage.
A mineral occurring in small, green, transparent, monocliniccrystals. It is a hydrous phosphate of iron.
That part of the alimentary canal between the stomach and theanus. See Illust. of Digestive apparatus.
One who fakes something, as a thief, a peddler of petty things,a workman who dresses things up, etc. [Slang]
A kind of Italian pressed milk cheese; -- so called from avillage near Milan.
A Chinese provincial tax levied at many inland stations uponimports or articles in transit.
A genus of Infusoria which form minute vaselike or tubularcases in which they dwell.
One of the two ecclesiastics allowed to attend a cardinal inthe conclave.
Native sulphide of manganese a reddish brown or brownish blackmineral.
Divination by observing the objects offered in sacrifice.
An instrument for cutting into the urethra so as to enlarge itsorifice.
An instrument resembling the organ in tine and the uprightpiano in form. It is characterized by great strength and sweetness oftone.

a small thrush (Turdus pilaris) which breeds in northern Europeand winters in Great Britain. The head, nape, and lower part of theback are ash-colored; the upper part of the back and wing coverts,chestnut; -- called also fellfare.
Containing more alcohol than proof spirit; stronger than proofspirit; that is, containing more than 49.3 per cent by weight ofalcohol.
The subclass of Mammalia which includes the marsupials. SeeMarsupialia.
A digression in which a person is introduced speaking his ownwords.
An arrow or bolt for a crossbow having feathers or brass placedat an angle with the shaft to make it spin in flying.
Sudden diminution or loss of consciousness, sensation, andvoluntary motion, usually caused by pressure on the brain.
The posterior horn of each lateral ventricle of the brain. B.G. Wilder.
The quality or condition of being salable; salableness. Duke ofArgyll.
Depopulation; destruction of population. [R.] Chapman.
A publication issued once in seven days, or appearing once aweek.
A term suggested by Haeckel to be instead of serial homology.See Homotype.
An instrument for measuring the variations in size of theinternal organs of the body, as the kidney, spleen, etc.
Of or pertaining to the gallows, or to execution. [R.] Carlyle.
Tears; also, lachrymal feelings or organs. [Colloq.]
Having a downcast countenance; dejected; gloomy; sullen. [R.]Dryden.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the plant acanthus.
Sorrowful; wretched; full of trouble. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To link together; to join, as one chain to another. Dryden.
In Holland, and, until the 19th century, also in Cape Colony, acouncil to assist a local magistrate in the government of ruraldistricts; hence, also, a member of such a council.
A genus of American and Asiatic trees, with aromatic bark andlarge sweet-scented whitish or reddish flowers.
A contrivance for recording the revolutions of a wheel, as of abicycle.
Any one of a series of artificial ethereal salts derived fromthe alkaloidal base tropine.
Of or pertaining to a natural order of plants, of which theviolet is the type. It contains about twenty genera and two hundredand fifty species.
A woman who practices unlawful sexual commerce with men,especially one who prostitutes her body for hire; a prostitute; aharlot. Wyclif.
A blue coloring matter found in some stentors. See Stentor, 2.
A relater of stories; an historian. [Obs.] Bp. Peacock.
One who, or that which, cleanses; a detergent. Arbuthnot.
The satirical or ribald poetry of the Goliards. Milman.
That which serves as a reminder; a remembrancer; a memento; akeepsake.
Charged with vair; variegated with shield-shaped figures. SeeVair.
Bastardlike; baseborn; spuripous; corrupt. [Obs.] -- adv.
The plain semidome of an apse; sometimes used for the entireapse.
An opening made in the interior walls of a cruciform church toafford a view of the altar to those in the transepts; -- called, inarchitecture, a squint. Hook.
A circular ornament, resembling a dish, often worked in reliefon friezes, and the like.
A cutaneous, pustular eruption, not attended with fever;usually, a kind of eczema with pustulation.

A leader of a choir; a directing singer. Specifically:(a) The leader of the choir in a cathedral; -- called also thechanter or master of the choir. Hook.(b) The leader of the congregational singing in Scottish and otherchurches.
To unfold; to undo; to ravel, as what has been woven.
The siliceous shell of a diatom. It is composed of two valves,one overlapping the other, like a pill box and its cover.
The business of one who spins; spinning. [Obs.] Milton.
An extensive group of echinoderms, comprising the starfishesand ophiurans.
The bindings of a hedge. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
The business of a housewife; female domestic economy and skill.Tusser.
Divination by the letters of a name; nomancy. [R.] Camden.
To release from a charm, fascination, or secret power; todisenchant. Beau. & Fl.
An American shrub (Symphoricarpus occidentalis) which bearssoft white berries.
The matter of which the philosopher's stone was believed to becomposed.

A genus of flowering plants having elegant drooping flowers,with four sepals, four petals, eight stamens, and a single pistil.They are natives of Mexico and South America. Double-floweredvarieties are now common in cultivation.
The nutritive zooids of a hydroid, collectively, asdistinguished from the gonosome, or reproductive zooids.
One who vents; one who utters, reports, or publishes. [R.]Barrow.
Being of the nature of soap; soapy; cleansing; detersive.
A genus of leguminous shrubby plants and herbs, mostly found intropical countries, a few herbaceous species being North American.The foliage is often ashy-pubescent, whence the name.
One who makes a trust; -- the correlative of trustee.
Plaiting or joining together; -- said of a bone next above thequadrate in the mandibular suspensorium of many fishes, which unitestogether the other bones of the suspensorium.-- n.
Pertaining to the Cimbri, an ancient tribe inhabiting NorthernGermany.-- n.
A warming cathartic medicine, made of aloes and canella bark.Dunglison.
A wagon or cart, usually heavy and without springs, and oftencovered. [Oriental]
A genus of monkeys, found in Asia and the East Indies. Theyhave short tails and prominent eyebrows.
One who gropes; one who feels his way in the dark, or searchesby feeling.
Act of bringing down; depravation; deterioration. South.
Of or pertaining to ancient Idumea, or Edom, in Western Asia.-- n.
An unfermentable sugar of the pentose class, C5H10O5, formed bythe hydrolysis of xylan; wood sugar.
A rare mineral, occurring crystallized and in cleavable masses,usually white, or nearly so, in color. It is a silicate of aluminiaand lithia.
A movable parapet, serving to support fascines to coverpioneers. [Obs.]
That which is to supply what is wanted.Invent suppletories to excuse an evil man. Jer. Taylor.

Any small square or quadrangular member; as:(a) A square of glass, esp. when set diagonally.(b) A small opening in window tracery, of which the cusps, etc., makethe form nearly square.(c) A square or lozenge-shaped paving tile.
A phenol derivative of anthracene obtained as a whitecrystalline substance, which on oxidation produces a red dyestuffrelated to anthraquinone.
Of or pertaining to Hibernia, now Ireland; Irish.-- n.
A lazy or cowardly person; a rascal. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The skin of a deer, or the leather which is made from it.Hakluyt. Longfellow.
A marine European fish (Crenilabrus melops); also, the relatedAmerican cunner. See Cunner.
To deaden the sound of (bells) by muffling the clapper.
Pertaining to oratorical expression. [Obs.] Feltham.

The path by which electricity is conveyed into or from asolution or other conducting medium; esp., the ends of the wires orconductors, leading from source of electricity, and terminating inthe medium traversed by the current.
The acid amide derived from malic acid, as a white crystallinesubstance metameric with asparagine.
To celebrate loudly; to extol; to praise. [Obs.]In fable, hymn, or song so personating Their gods ridiculous. Milton.
Not swearing allegiance; -- applied to the party in GreatBritain that would not swear allegiance to William and Mary, or theirsuccessors.
The giant cactus (Cereus giganteus); -- so named by the Indiansof Arizona. Called also saguaro.
Pertaining to, or derived from, fat. The word was formerly usedspecifically to designate a supposed acid obtained by the oxidationof oleic acid, tallow, wax, etc.
Hatred of argument or discussion; hatred of enlightenment. G.H. Lewes.
To leap over or across; hence, to omit; to ignore. "Let meo'erleap that custom." Shak.
A district or local division, as of a province. [India]
A white, bitter, crystallizable substance, obtained fromcoffee. It is identical with the alkaloid theine from tea leaves, andwith guaranine from guarana.
A skullcap covering the tonsure, worn under the berretta. Thepope's is white; a cardinal's red; a bishop's purple; a priest'sblack.
A European composite herb (Centaurea nigra); -- so called fromthe resemblance of its knobbed head to an iron ball fixed on a longhandle. Dr. Prior.
Capable of living; born alive and with such form anddevelopment of organs as to be capable of living; -- said of anewborn, or a prematurely born, infant.
A small South American species of tiger cat (Felis mitis).
Soft; -- a direction to the performer to execute a certainpassage softly, and with diminished volume of tone. (Abbrev. p.)
A device for saving power in stopping and starting a railroadcar, by means of a heavy fly wheel.
That branch of botanical science which relates to the musgroomsand other fungi.
One who propagates; one who continues or multiplies.
In the form of a globe or sphere; -- applied to nebulous mattercollected into a sphere by the force of gravitation.
A split of a sheepskin; one of the thin sections made bysplitting a sheepskin with a cutting knife or machine.

An alkaline salt of fluorescein, obtained as a brownish redsubstance, which is used as a dye; -- so called from the peculiaryellowish green fluorescence (resembling that of uranium glass) ofits solutions. See Fluorescein.
To remove the dullness of; to clear. [Obs.] Whitlock.
An odd thing, or one that is left over, disconnected,fragmentary, or the like; something that is separated or disconnectedfrom its fellows; esp. (in pl.),
A defect in pronouncing the letter m, or a too frequent use ofit.
A clear soup or bouillion boiled down so as to be very rich.
Pertaining to, or designating, a variety of tannin or tannicacid found in Acacia, Mimosa, etc.
The quality or state of being unwary; carelessness;heedlessness.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained by thedistillation of terebic acid, and homologous with citraconic acid.
A queer old fellow; an old chap; an old woman. [Contemptuous,Slang or Dial.]
As much or as many as a ship will hold; enough to fill a ship.
One of the ropes or chains serving as stays for the dolphinstriker or the bowsprit; -- called also gobrope and gaubline.
A product of gastric digestion intermediate between albumin andpeptone, identical with hemialbumose.
A cuirassier or cuirassiers; also, hardy veteran soldiers; --applied specifically to Cromwell's cavalry.
A young German noble or squire; esp., a member of thearistocratic party in Prussia.
One who favors the use or establishment of silver as a monetarystandard; -- so called by those who favor the gold standard. [Colloq.or Cant]
A brush of feathers, bristles, or hair, for removing dust fromfurniture.
A glass show case for displaying fine wares, specimens, etc.
The common title of honor in Persia, prefixed to the surname ofan individual. When appended to the surname, it signifies Prince.
One who gilds; one whose occupation is to overlay with gold.
A light, spongy, cylindrical cake, used for breakfast and tea.
To become thinner; to make excuses; to advance palliatingconsiderations. Burke.
The act of turning or diverting any disease from one part ofthe body to another. It resembles derivation, but is usually appliedto a more active form of counter irritation.
A raised way or foot bank, running along the inside of aparapet, on which musketeers stand to fire upon the enemy.
To adorn; to grace; to honor; to make becoming, appropriate, orhonorable. [Obs.] Abp. Sandys.
A genus of mollusks, including the cowries. See Cowrie.

That branch of logic which teaches the rules and modes ofreasoning; the application of logical principles to discursivereasoning; the science or art of discriminating truth from error;logical discussion.
The quality of being sanguine; sanguineness. Swift.
An earthwork; a mound; a raised work. [Obs.] Hearne.
Chopped meat stuffed into small bags of tripe. They are cut inslices and fried. [Local, New York]
A machine of great antiquity, used in Bengal for raising waterto irrigate land. Knight.
A white variety of amphibole, or hornblende, occurring in long,bladelike crystals, and coarsely fibrous masses.
A genus of plants of the Ranunculus or Crowfoot family;windflower. Some of the species are cultivated in gardens.
A traversing base frame, or movable railway, along which thecarriage of a barbette or casemate gum moves backward and forward.[See Gun carriage.]
An instrument for measuring in volts the differences ofpotential between different points of an electrical circuit.
A genus of birds that comprises the white-eyes. See White-eye.

A Spanish mode of execution by strangulation, with an ironcollar affixed to a post and tightened by a screw until life becomeextinct; also, the instrument by means of which the punishment isinflicted.
A divinity of the modern Hindoo trimurti, or trinity. He isregarded as the preserver, while Brahma is the creator, and Siva thedestroyer of the creation.
A bunch of odorous and showy flowers; a bouquet; a posy. Pope.
The state of being absent; withdrawal. [R.] Barrow.
The skin or coat of a seed, especially the outer coat. SeeTesta.
A household servant; also, one of the bodyguard of King Canute.
Any one of several species of large, long-legged sandpipersbelonging to the genus Totanus.
Such as may be presumed or supposed to be true; that seemsentitled to belief without direct evidence.
Relating to the foot, or to a metrical foot; pedal. [R.]Maunder.

A wheel with a broad rim, or grooved rim, for transmittingpower from, or imparting power to, the different parts of machinery,or for changing the direction of motion, by means of a belt, cord,rope, or chain.
Having two teeth or two toothlike processes; two-toothed.
Situated under, or on the ventral side of, the cranium; facial.
A follower of Henry Barrowe, one of the founders ofIndependency or Congregationalism in England. Barrowe was executedfor nonconformity in 1953.
An incorrect union of parties or of causes of action in aprocedure, criminal or civil. Wharton.
A woodpecker; -- called also specht, spekt, spight. [Obs. orProv. Eng.]
A plug introduced into a natural or artificial cavity of thebody in order to arrest hemorrhage, or for the application ofmedicine.
A clergyman; -- familiarly so called, as a soldier is sometimescalled a redcoat or a bluecoat.
A cincture, girdle, or belt; -- chiefly used in English as adressmaking term.
To flatten (metal) by hammering, so as to compress it inwardlyand spread it outwardly.
Scarcely distinct; -- applied to the markings of insects.
A chimney board or screen to close a fireplace when not in use.
The quality or state of being seminal. Sir T. Browne.
The part of a sleeve nearest the hand; a cuff or wristband.[Obs.] Shak.
A magnificent assemblage of buildings at Rome, near the churchof St. Peter, including the pope's palace, a museum, a library, afamous chapel, etc.
A genus of parasitic shrubs, including the mistletoe of Europe.
A cordial of brandy, etc., flavored with the kernel of thebitter almond, or of the peach stone, etc.
Pertaining to a draught, or current of air; as, a draughtly,comfortless room.
A vine or climbing shrub, of the genus Vitis, having smallgreen flowers and lobed leaves, and bearing the fruit called grapes.
One to whom anything is allotted; one to whom an allotment ismade.
The space, at one end, between opposite trusses when these areterminated by inclined braces.
The quality or state of being penal; lability to punishment.Sir T. Browne.
A crooked back; one who has a crooked or deformed back; ahunchback.
An alkaloid resembing physostigmine and occurring with it inthe calabar bean.
A manikin, or image, representing an animal, especially man,with the skin removed so that the muscles are exposed for purposes ofstudy.
One who advocates adheres to new laws; esp. one who holds orbelieves that the gospel is a new law.
The method in which the parts of a plant are arranged; also,the position of the parts. Henslow.
A low wall, especially one serving to protect the edge of aplatform, roof, bridge, or the like.
To cause to waste gradually, to emaciate. [R.]  Harvey.
To lie in front of. [Obs.]Which forelay Athwart her snowy breast. Spenser.
A bird tied by the foot, to serve as decoy to other birds byits fluttering.
A fruit bat, esp. the Indian edible fruit bat (Pteropusedulis).
A measure of land in India, varying from a third of an acre toan acre.
The quality or state of being useful; utility; serviceableness;advantage. Addison.
A genus of fishes comprising the archer fishes. See Archerfish.
Stout, coarse cloth of which sacks, bags, etc., are made.
To arrange in a file or rank; to place in order. [Obs.]Holland.

A genus of airbreathing mollusks, including the common gardenslugs. They have a small rudimentary shell. The breathing pore is onthe right side of the neck. Several species are troublesome ingardens. See Slug.
One of the organs, as the brain, heart, or stomach, in thegreat cavities of the body of an animal; -- especially used in theplural, and applied to the organs contained in the abdomen.
To separate the strands of; to undo, as a braid; to unravel; todisentangle.
A rough, knotted woolen cloth, used chiefly for men'sovercoats; also, a coat of that material.
A name given to several very different kinds of grapes, but inAmerica used chiefly for the scuppernong, or southern fox grape,which is said to be the parent stock of the Catawba. See Grapevine.
Like a thief; thievish; thievishly. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Strength; firmness; stability. [Obs.] Chillingworth.
Of or pertaining to a certain school of Greek philosophers whotaught that the only certain science is that which owes nothing tothe senses, and all to the reason.-- n.
A white, crystalline, tasteless substance, found in the milkysap of species of Lactuca, and constituting an essential ingredientof lactucarium.
A white crystalline substance obtained by the decomposition ofsaponin.
A disused generic name for mustard; -- now called Brassica.
The science which treats of the heart and its functions.
One who writes tracts; specif., a Tractarian. [R.] C. Kingsley.
A staff or pole on which a vessel is supported between twopersons. Suckling.
A bearing like a chevron, but of only half its width.
To perform by proxy; to employ as a proxy. [Obs.] Shak.
Minute membranous scales on the surface of some leaves, as inthe goosefoot. Gray.
An early Latin version of the Scriptures (the Old Testament wastranslated from the Septuagint, and was also called the Italicversion).
An important genus of reef-building corals having small twelve-rayed calicles, and a very porous coral. Some species are branched,others grow in large massive or globular forms.
To convert into an alkali; to give alkaline properties to.
One who makes a bargain, or contracts with another; esp., onewho sells, or contracts to sell, property to another. Blackstone.
A place where bees are kept; a stand or shed for bees; abeehouse.
Capable of being required; proper to be required. Sir M. Hale.
One whose occupation is to make or repair sails.-- Sail"mak`ing, n.
To contend with; to oppose actively; to counteract.
A striped variety of hornstone, resembling wood in appearance.
A penurious person; a miser; a niggard. Sir W. Scott.
To let loose from prison, to set all liberty. [R.] Bulwer.
Like a ruffian; bold in crimes; characteristic of a ruffian;violent; brutal.
The quality or state of being merry; merriment; mirth; gayety,with laughter.
A sort of petticoat worn by both sexes in Java and the MalayArchipelago. Balfour (Cyc. of India)
One who intercedes; an intercessor; a mediator. Johnson.
A collection of serous fluid in the cavity of the abdomen;dropsy of the peritoneum. Dunglison.
A smooth coat of brown mortar, usually the second coat, and thepreparation for the finishing coat of plaster.
A tool, hooked at the end, for enlarging or clearing seams forthe reception of oakum.
1. One who grades, or that by means of which grading is done orfacilitate.
One who swaggers; a blusterer; a bully; a boastful, noisyfellow. Shak.
A rollicking French dance, accompanied by indecorous orextravagant postures and gestures.
A basic amido derivative of phloroglucin, having an astringenttaste.
The region surrounding the anus, particularly of echinoderms.
An elementary substance, resembling a metal in its appearanceand physical properties, but in its chemical relations belonging tothe class of nonmetallic substances. Atomic weight, 120. Symbol, Sb.

The prostration made by mandarins and others to theirsuperiors, either as homage or worship, by knocking the forehead onthe ground. There are degrees in the rite, the highest beingexpressed by three knockings. [China]kowtow S. W. Williams.
The fine, hard parts of wheat, rounded by the attrition of themillstones, -- used in cookery.
Mystical interpretations or studies, esp. of the Scriptures. L.Addison.
A small African hyracoid mammal (Dendrohyrax arboreus)resembling the daman.
A narrow board nailed against the wall of a room next to thefloor; skirting board; baseboard. See Baseboard.
Full of weeping or lamentation; grieving. [Obs.] Wyclif.
To exhibit mental activity; to have the brain in action.
Constriction or contraction of some natural passage, as inconstipation from inflammation.
Refraining from indulgence, especially from the indulgence ofappetite; abstemious; continent; temperate. Beau. & Fl.
A substance obtained from the volatile oils of anise, fennel,etc., in the form of soft shining scales; -- called also anisecamphor. Watts.
A yellow crystalline substance extracted from crude anthracene.
Not a true or noble falcon; -- said of certain hawks, as thegoshawk.
One who meddles; one who interferes or busies himself withthings in which he has no concern; an officious person; a busybody.
A mineral of blackish lead-gray color and metallic luster,generally of a foliated massive structure; foliated tellurium. It isa telluride of lead and gold.
In Turkey, an administrative authority of any of certainsanjaks. They are appointed directly by the Sultan.
A kind of transparent reliquary with an ornamental top.
A Mohammedan church or place of religious worship. [Writtenalso mosk.]
A construction in which adherence to some element in the sensecauses a departure from strict syntax, as in "Philip went down toSamaria and preached Christ unto them."
A taste beforehand; enjoyment in advance; anticipation.
The metamorphism of limestone, that is, its conversion intomarble. Geikie.
A scrutinizer; specifically, an examiner of votes, as at anelection.

A small anchor, with four or five flukes or claws, used to holdboats or small vessels; hence, any instrument designed to grapple orhold; a grappling iron; a grab; -- written also grapline, andcrapnel.
The European pollack; -- called also laith, and leet. [Scot.]
One who pastures; one who takes cattle to graze. See Agister.
The act of expiring; passage from life to death; loss of life.
The act of obviating, or the state of being obviated.

The Roman divinity who presided over boundaries, whose statuewas properly a short pillar terminating in the bust of a man, woman,satyr, or the like, but often merely a post or stone stuck in theground on a boundary line.
That minces; characterized by primness or affected nicety.
A kind of Swiss cheese, of a greenish color, flavored withmelilot.
One who sells distilled liquors by the dram or glass.
The application of a lever to move any weighty body, as a cask,anchor, cannon, car, etc. See Prize, n., 5.
A South American bird (heliornis fulica) allied to the grebes.The name is also applied to several related species of the genusPodica.
A variety of sandstone, usually imperfectly consolidated,consisting largely of glauconite, a silicate of iron and potash of agreen color, mixed with sand and a trace of phosphate of lime.
A rope used for hauling out a sail upon a spar; -- opposite ofinhaul.
A revolving buddle or sieve for separating, or sizing, ores.Raymond.
The tissue of young cells which produces cork cells.
To cause to sink deeply; to cause to dive or penetrate fardown. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A turning point; the principal or highest point; top; summit;crown; apex. Specifically: --(a) (Anat.)
In a safe manner; danger, injury, loss, or evil consequences.
A celebrated marble temple of Athene, on the Acropolis atAthens. It was of the pure Doric order, and has had an importantinfluence on art.
The act or shock of striking a vessel's stern by a followingwave or vessel.

A bitter, brownish yellow, amorphous substance, extracted fromvegetable mold, and also produced by the action of acids on certainsugars and carbohydrates; -- called also humic acid, ulmin, gein,ulmic or geic acid, etc.
Excessive enthusiasm, unreasoning zeal, or wild and extravagantnotions, on any subject, especially religion; religious frenzy.
A kind of warm drink for sick persons, being a mixture of winewith eggs, bread, sugar, and spices.
A web or fold of skin which extends between the legs of certainmammals, as the flying squirrels, colugo, and phalangister.
A destroyer. [R.]Fire, the destructive and the artificial death of things. Boyle.
Resembling a monster; abnormal; of a pathological growth,exceedingly complex or highly organized. S. D. Gross.
One of the proprietors of certain tracts of land with manorialprivileges and right of entail, under the old Dutch governments ofNew York and New Jersey.
One who suborns or procures another to take, a false oath; onewho procures another to do a bad action.
The part of a solid next the base, formed by cutting off the,top; or the part of any solid, as of a cone, pyramid, etc., betweentwo planes, which may be either parallel or inclined to each other.
One of the lower segments in the hyoid arch, often consolidatedwith the body of the hyoid bone and forming one of its great horns,as in man.
The writer, or one of the writers, of the passages of the OldTestament, notably those of Elohim instead of Jehovah, as the name ofthe Supreme Being; -- distinguished from Jehovist. S. Davidson.
The condition or quality of being secure; exemption from fear;want of vigilance; security.
A pendulous process of the skin on the throat of a bird, as inthe turkey; a dewlap.
To cause to be mongrel; to cross breeds, so as to producemongrels.
Pertaining to gems; of the nature of gems; resembling gems.Pennant.
One who piks or chooses; esp., an inspector who select waressuitable for market.
An earth abounding in pyrites, used by the ancients to killinsects, etc., on vines; -- applied by Brongniart to a carbonaceousalum schist.
Manipulation applied to a hernial tumor, or to an intestinalobstruction, for the purpose of reducing it. Dunglison.
Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, calcium or lime.
Some kind of stinging or biting insect, as a flea, a gnat, asandly, or the like. Ex. viii. 17 (Douay version).
Want or neglect of cultivation or culture. [Obs.] Feltham.
A St. Andrew's cross, or cross in the form of an X, -- one ofthe honorable ordinaries.
The regurgitation of food from the stomach after it has beenswallowed, -- occasionally oberved as a morbid phenomenon in man.
That stage in the development of the ovum in which the outercells of the morula become more defined and form the blastoderm.
One of the divisions of Crinoidea found fossil in paleozoicrocks; pentremites. They are so named on account of their budlikeform.
Opposition to the body politic of citizens. [Obs.] Carlyle.
To beat; to break, as flax or hemp. [Obs.] Mortimer.
Originally, one of the national cavalry of Hungary and Croatia;now, one of the light cavalry of European armies.
Rising; -- applied to a bird in the attitude of rising; also,sometmes, to a bird in profile with wings addorsed.
A boat or vessel propelled by steam power; -- generally used ofriver or coasting craft, as distinguished from ocean steamers.

Formerly, an armor bearer, as of a knight, an esquire who borehis shield and rendered other services. In later use, one next indegree to a knight, and entitled to armorial bearings. The term isnow superseded by esquire. Jacob.
An ancient kind of cap worn by horsemen or huntsmen. Bacon.
A piece of rubber, felt, or woolen cloth, used in the tympan tomake it soft and elastic.
One who, or that which, dilutes or makes thin, more liquid, orweaker.
The title of the eldest son of the king of France, and heir tothe crown. Since the revolution of 1830, the title has beendiscontinued.
Estimable according to quantity; quantitative. Sir K. Digby.
Pertaining to, or derived from, or designating, a complexorganic acid found in the products of different members of the Pepperfamily, and extracted as a yellowish crystalline substance.
A genus of plants, mostly perennial, having succulent leavesand cymose flowers; orpine; stonecrop. Gray.
A jeweled chain, necklace, or collar. [Also written carkenetand carcant.] Shak.
A variety of winter apple of medium size, deep red color, andyellowish flesh of a rich, rather subacid flavor.
Length of stroke, as of a piston; stroke. [An awkward use ofthe word.]
Of or pertaining to tenesmus; characterized by tenesmus.
An alkaloid found in small quantity in opium. It is identicalwith narcotine.
In Guam and the Philippines, an idol, fetich, or spirit.
The European long-tailed titmouse; -- called also poke-pudding.[Prov. Eng.]
One who vindicates; one who justifies or maintains. Locke.
A hollow tile used in making drains; -- called also drainingtile.
One whose business is to tap or draw ale or other liquor.
The officer who officiates or performs an office, as the burialoffice. Shipley.
To deflour; to deprive of virginity. [Obs.] Bailey.
The system of arranging the scale by the names do, re, mi, fa,sol, la, si, by which singing is taught; a singing exercise uponthese syllables.
Grooves or furrows formed in snow by the action of the wind,and running parallel with the direction of the wind. This formationresults from the erosion of transverse waves previously formed.
Serving to measure or ascertain chemical equivalents;stoichiometric. [R.]
Any North American river chub of the genus Hybopsis, esp. H.biguttatus.
The quality of being refulgent; brilliancy; splender; radiance.
That part of an embryo which represents the young stem; thecaulicle or radicle.
An overflowing of land by river; an inundation; a freshet.Clarendon.
Infinite; perpetual, as a canon whose end leads back to thebeginning. See Infinite, a., 5.
Formed like a cirrus or tendril; -- said of appendages of bothanimals and plants.
A small sailboat, with a single mast placed as far forward aspossible, carring a sail extended by a graff and long boom. SeeIllustration in Appendix.
A varicose enlargement of the veins of the spermatic cord;also, a like enlargement of the veins of the scrotum.
The state of being carnal; carnality; sensualism. [R.]
A bird confined in a cage; esp. a young bird. [Poetic]Tennyson.
The science of the understanding; intellectual science.
An instrument (chisel or shears) to cut the ribs and open thethoracic cavity, in post-mortem examinations and dissections. Knight.
A person who steals or kidnaps a human being or beings.
Majestic or majestically; -- a direction to perform a passageor piece of music in a dignified manner.
The person to whom a feoffment is made; the person enfeoffed.
To intimidate; to restrain or coerce by intimidation orviolence; -- used originally of the intimidation of negro voters, inLouisiana. [Slang, U.S.]
An order of sponges having a skeleton composed of hornlikefibers. It includes the commercial sponges.
A large fish of Florida and the W. Indies (Caulolatiluschrysops). It is red, marked with yellow.
An overfall, or weir, for the escape, or overflow, ofsuperfluous water from a canal, reservoir, pond, or the like.
Having a mouth; -- applied to certain Protozoa.-- n.

Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid, C4H7CO2H (calledalso methyl crotonic acid), homologous with crotonic acid, andobtained from croton oil (from Croton Tiglium) as a white crystallinesubstance.
Having the surface closely covered with hairs, like a brush.
A letter, syllable, or word, added to the end of another word;a suffix. Parkhurst.
Start modified by heat so as to become a transparent mass, likehorn. It is soluble in cold water.
Of or pertaining to a matron; suitable to an elderly lady or toa married woman; grave; motherly.
An extensive group of insects which are parasitic on birds andmammals, and feed on the feathers and hair; -- called also bird lice.See Bird louse, under Bird.
The base of a window casing, on which the elbows may rest.
To produce again by means of seed. [Obs.] Sir. T. Browne.
Having the odor, taste, or appearance of fruit; also, fruitful.Dickens.
A treatise on laws; an exposition of the form proper for laws.
A South American monkey of the genus Callithrix, esp. C.Moloch.
A smooth woolen stuff, generally black, used for making shoes;a kind of lasting; -- formerly used also for clergymen's gowns.
A partial, secondary, or small involucre. See Illust. ofInvolucre.
A genus of marine amphipod crustacea, which bore into andsometimes destroy timber.
A movement, or part of a figure, in the contradance. Dickens.
A fish of the genus Aulostoma, having a much elongated tubularsnout.

A self-acting apparatus for regulating temperature by theunequal expansion of different metals, liquids, or gases by heat, asin opening or closing the damper of a stove, or the like, as the heatbecomes greater or less than is desired.
To take the spars, stakes, or bars from. [R.] Sir W. Scott.
The land of one's birth; one's inheritance. [R.] Shak.
A descendant of Benjamin; one of the tribe of Benjamin. Judg.iii. 15.
A winning of all the tricks at the game of piquet. It countsfor forty points. Hoyle.
To thrive poorly; to be not thrifty or prosperous. [Obs.]
To season with spice, or with some spicy drug. Shak.
A medicine that promotes alvine discharges; a purge; apurgative of moderate activity.
Anything which is required to be done; as, in geometry, tobisect a line, to draw a perpendicular; or, in algebra, to find anunknown quantity.

Tissue in which the cell or partition walls are wholly wantingand the cell bodies fused together, so that the tissue consists of acontinuous mass of protoplasm in which nuclei are imbedded, as inordinary striped muscle.
A size of type next smaller than minion and next larger thanagate (or ruby).
Sulphide of silver; -- also called vitreous silver, or silverglance. It has a metallic luster, a lead-gray color, and is sectilelike lead.
A signal telegraph; an apparatus for giving signals by thedisposition of lanterns, flags, oscillating arms, etc.
To damage, impair, or injure, as an estate, voluntarily, or bysuffering the buildings, fences, etc., to go to decay.
To cause to be no longer pastor; to deprive of pastorship. [R.]Fuller.
A genus of ground squirrels, including the chipmunk.
A dynamometer for measuring the force required to draw wheelcarriages on roads of different constructions. G. Francis.
A genus of endogenous herbs with grassy leaves and small yellowflowers in short, scaly-bracted spikes; yellow-eyed grass. There areabout seventeen species in the Atlantic United States.
A fish of the genus Upeneus, inhabiting the Gulf of Mexico. Itis allied to the surmullet.
The character or act of a separatist; disposition to withdrawfrom a church; the practice of so withdrawing.
The art or act of rendering the letters of the alphabet of onelanguage into the possible equivalents of another; transliteration.Stormonth.
To cook, as macaroni, in a savory juice or sauce until juice isabsorbed and a crisp surface forms.
The Pleiades or seven stars, fabled to have been the daughtersof Atlas.
To make profit of; to convert to one's own profit; said esp. ofwaste or common land appropriated by the lord of the manor.
A group of the Carnivora, which includes the cats, civets, andhyenas.
A pin used to prevent the wheel of a vehicle from sliding offthe axletree.
A machine in which strips of metal are drawn through adrawplate; especially, one in which wire is thus made; -- also calleddrawing bench.
A compound formed by the union of cyanogen with an element orradical.

A boat made by covering a wicker frame with leather oroilcloth. It was used by the ancient Britons, and is still used byfisherman in Wales and some parts of Ireland. Also, a similar boatused in Thibet and in Egypt.
A genus of herbs with compound white or bluish flowers;starwort; Michaelmas daisy.
The downy seed head of a dandelion, which children delight toblow away. B. Jonson.
A rhetorical mode of speech, including tropes, or changes fromthe original import of the word. Sir T. Browne.
The defendant's answer to the plaintiff's replication.

A rare element of the vanadium group, first found in a varietyof the mineral columbite occurring in Connecticut, probably atHaddam. Atomic weight 94.2. Symbol Cb or Nb. Now more commonly calledniobium.
A head or leading man, especially of a village community.
An aspect of two planets with regard to the earth when they arethree octants, or three eighths of a circle, that is, 135 degrees,distant from each other. Hutton.
The first word in certain mnemonic lines which represent thevarious forms of the syllogism. It indicates a syllogism whose threepropositions are universal affirmatives. Whately.
A group of ciliated Infusoria, having cilia all over the body.
An autographic stencil copying device invented by Edison.
An order of sessile-eyed Crustacea, usually having seven pairsof legs, which are all similar in structure.
The middle segment of the brain; the mesencephalon. See Brain.
A substance extracted from mustard seed and probably identicalwith sinalbin. [Obs.]
A tissue of growing cells, or cells capable of furtherdivision.

The act of respiring through the open mouth so that thecurrents of inspired and expired air cause a vibration of the uvulaand soft palate, thus giving rise to a sound more or less harsh. Itis usually unvoluntary, but may be produced voluntarily.
The act or process of filtering; the mechanical separation of aliquid from the undissolved particles floating in it.
To cast off or down; hence, to abase; to degrade; to lower; todebase. [Obs.] Donne.
The pendent fleshy lobe in the middle of the posterior borderof the soft palate.
Gentle or friendly reproof; counseling against a fault orerror; expression of authoritative advice; friendly caution orwarning.

A thick plank, used for several mechanical purposes;especially:(a) A plank to receive the mouth of a petard, with which it isapplied to anything intended to be broken down.(b) A plank or beam used for supporting the earth in mines orfortifications.
An example of a conjugation or declension, showing a word inall its different forms of inflection.
One who deals in wine; a wine seller, or wine merchant.
An appendage; something dependent on another; an appurtenance;a pendant. Sir W. Scott.
A fossil tooth colored a bright blue by phosphate of iron. Itis used as an imitation of turquoise, and hence called boneturquoise.
A limpid, colorless, inflammable liquid from the slow oxidationof alcohol under the influence of platinum black.
Repentant from fear of punishment; having attrition of grieffor sin; -- opposed to contrite.
Not capable of being exactly expressed by an integral number,or by a vulgar fraction; surd; -- said especially of roots. See Surd.
Beneath the sky; in the open air; specifically (Geol.), takingplace on the earth's surface, as opposed to subaqueous.
A common American tyrant flycatcher (Sayornis phoebe, or S.fuscus). Called also pewit, and phoebe.
A kind of field spaniel, with short legs and stout body, which,unlike other spaniels, hunts silently.
One who frotes; one who rubs or chafes. [Obs.] Marston.
One who considers; a man of reflection; a thinker. Milton.
To inoculate with the cowpox by means of a virus, calledvaccine, taken either directly or indirectly from cows.
Anything which alleviates or compensates for suffering or loss;a compensation; esp., an additional allowance, as for injuredfeelings.
The general term for the Hebrew oral or traditional law; one oftwo branches of exposition in the Midrash. See Midrash.
Failing or diminishing trust; want of trust or confidence;distrust. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Of or pertaining to a climax; forming, or of the nature of, aclimax, or ascending series.
Suggestion; incitement; prompting. [R.] Shak. Coleridge.
Of or pertaining to the black-haired races. Prichard.
Relating to the art of carving, enchasing, or embossing in lowrelief.
To make little or less in a moral sense; to speak of in adepreciatory or contemptuous way. T. Jefferson.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid (commonly calledchrysophanic acid) found in rhubarb (Rheum). [Obsoles.]
To render like heaven or fit for heaven. [R.] Bp. Hall.
A person devoted to luxury and pleasure; a voluptuary.
An incubator for sickly infants, esp. those prematurely born.
A room for conversation; especially, a room in monasteries,where the monks were allowed to converse.
Tending to a pole; having a direction toward a pole. [R.] SirT. Browne.
Pinnately cut with the lobes pointing downwards, as the leaf ofthe dandelion.
A division of Crustacea, which, in some its characteristics, isintermediate between Amphipoda and Isopoda.
A colorless liquid hydrocarbon, C7H14, of the ethylene series;also, any one of its isomers. Called also heptene.
Too much or too frequent change; fickleness. [R.] Beau. & Fl.
The player who stands behind the batsman to catch the ball.

A white crystalline substance with a sweet taste, found incertain animal tissues and fluids, particularly in the muscles of theheart and lungs, also in some plants, as in unripe pease, beans,potato sprouts, etc. Called also phaseomannite.
A layer of green parenchimatous cells formed on the inner sideof the phellogen.
Of or pertaining to a zeolite; consisting of, or resembling, azeolite.
A fish allied to the turbot (Rhombus levis), much esteemed inEngland for food; -- called also bret, pearl, prill. See Bret.
A cylindrical glass vessel, with a large and short neck.
A collection of pus or purulent matter in any part of an animalbody; an abscess.
A minute spherical crystalline body having a radiatedstructure, observed in some vitreous volcanic rocks, as obsidian andpearlstone.
Disturbed state; uneasiness either of body or mind;restlessness; disquietude. Sir H. Wotton.
The period during which the presidency of the senate belongedto the prytanes of the section.
A member of one of certain ascetic sects which at various timesprofessed to imitate the practice of the apostles.
The tendency of a body to remain in a given state, either ofmotion or rest, till disturbed by another body; inertia. Cheyne.
Evil name; bad reputation; defamation. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Of or pertaining to the art of preparing and preserving theskins of animals.
Fondness for women; uxoriousness; -- opposed to Ant: misogyny.[R.] Byron.
The quality or state of being greasy, oiliness; unctuousness;grossness.
A good for nothing fellow; a vagabond. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A translucent mineral of a green color and micaceous structure,belonging to the chlorite group; a hydrous silicate of alumina,magnesia, and iron; -- called also clinochlore.
One who ranks, or disposes in ranks; one who arranges.
Liveliness; vigor in action; quickness; gayety; vivacity;effervescence.
An officer on the bishop, who exercises ecclesiasticaljurisdiction in parts of the diocese at a distance from the residenceof the bishop. Ayliffe.
To infer from an inference already made. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
A concave molding used especially in classical architecture.
A muscle which serves to retain an organ or part in place, esp.when retracted. See Illust. of Phylactolemata.
To alight, or to cause to alight, from a railway train. [Eng.]London Graphic.
The act of recreating, or the state of being recreated;refreshment of the strength and spirits after toil; amusement;diversion; sport; pastime.
The disposal or relative arrangement of figures or objects, asin, drawing, painting, and sculpture, or in ornamental design.
An organic base, C6H6N4, produced artificially as a white,crystalline powder, by the action of ammonia on glyoxal.
A genus of shrubby plants, including the heaths, many of themproducing beautiful flowers.
A cultivator of the soil; an agriculturist. Dodsley.
A thermometer for the measurement of low temperatures, esp.such an instrument containing alcohol or some other liquid of a lowerfreezing point than mercury.
A large roundish variety of the cultivated hazelnut.
A work or artificial watercourse for throwing water on landsthat lie on the slopes of hills; a catchdrain.
A median ossification back of the lophosteon in the sternum ofsome birds.
A silicate of zinc, usually occurring massive and of a greenishyellow color, also in reddish crystals (troostite) containingmanganese.
Left uncovered, as land by recession of water. Bouvier.
More than perfect; past perfect; -- said of the tense whichdenotes that an action or event was completed at or before the timeof another past action or event.-- n.
An instrument for recording automatically the variations of thehumidity of the atmosphere.
A genus of herbs and shrubs (Aristolochia), reputed to havemedicinal properties.
The process of cleavage, or segmentation, of the ovum, by whicha morula is formed.
To be spread in disorder or hang negligently, as the hair. [R.]Sir T. Herbert.
The nostril, or one of the nostrils, of whales, porpoises, andallied animals.
Dropsy of the subcutaneous cellular tissue; an effusion ofserum into the cellular substance, occasioning a soft, pale,inelastic swelling of the skin.
A little hood or veil, resembling an extinguisher in form andposition, covering each of the small flaskike capsules which containthe spores of mosses; also, any similar covering body.
A fossil shell of, or similar to, the genus Miliola.

In bats, an expansion of the integument uniting the fore limbwith the body and extending between the elongated fingers to form thewing; in birds, the similar fold of integument uniting the fore limbwith the body.
(Chem.) A prefix or combining form (also used adjectively)indicating the presence of three methyl groups.
Christmas time; Christmastide; the season of Christmas.
To free from a witch or witches; to fee from witchcraft. [R.]B. Jonson.
Toward, or on the side toward, the mesial plane; mesially; --opposed to laterad.
The doctrine or practice of the iconoclasts; image breaking.
The act or process of rendering impervious to sound, as a flooror wall; also, the material with which the spaces are filled in thisprocess; pugging.
Widening into a lamina or into lateral winglike appendages.
knot which slips along the rope or line around which it ismade.
Inhabiting the somewhat high slopes and summits of mountains,but considerably below the snow line.
A transparent body found in the chromatophores of certainInfusoria.
An affected woman of polite society, esp. one of the literarywomen of the French salons of the 17th century.
A slender stem by which certain of the lower animals or theireggs are attached. See Illust. of Aphis lion.
Things so unequal or unlike that they can not be compared witheach other.
A name given to several different species of plants having blueflowers, as the Houstonia coerulea, the Centaurea cyanus orbluebottle, and the Vaccinium angustifolium.
An immense field or stream of ice, formed in the region ofperpetual snow, and moving slowly down a mountain slope or valley, asin the Alps, or over an extended area, as in Greenland.
The cuckoopint, the tubers of which yield a fine quality ofstarch.
To find harbor or safety in; to dwell in or inhabit. W. Browne.
A sort of electroscope, invented by Rousseau, in which the drypile is employed to measure the amount of electricity transmitted bydifferent bodies, or to determine their conducting power. Nichol.
A priming of size mixed with whiting or white lead, used inhouse painting, etc.; also, a size upon which gold leaf is applied ingilding.
Any one of the several species of large antarctic petrels whichfeed on blubber and carrion and have an offensive odor, as the giantfulmar.
The region or home of cockneys; cockneys, collectively.Thackeray.
The dominion or authority of a suzerain; paramount authority.

A genus of New Zealand birds about the size of a hen, with onlyshort rudiments of wings, armed with a claw and without a tail; thekiwi. It is allied to the gigantic extinct moas of the same country.Five species are known.

A genus of transparent marine annelids which swim actively atthe surface of the sea. They have deeply divided or forked finlikeorgans (parapodia). This genus is the type of the order, or suborder,Gymnocopa.
Unfit for a feast; hence, jaded; worn. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A remora, -- fabled to stop ships by attaching itself to them.
A lead-gray sectile mineral. It is a telluride of silver.
Having a dry and contracted hoof, which occasions pain andlameness.
A person who breeds or trains hawks for taking birds or game;one who follows the sport of fowling with hawks. Johnson.
A close four-wheeled carriage, with one seat inside, and a seatfor the driver.
A kind of wild goose, by a flock of which a virtuoso was fabledto be carried to the lunar world. [Also gansa.] Johnson.
The preparation of the back of a book with glue, etc., beforeputting on the cover.
A plane figure consisting of seven sides and having sevenangles.
To reduce in altitude or magnitude, as hills and mountains; towear down.
A water-tight inclosure, as of piles packed with clay, fromwhich the water is pumped to expose the bottom (of a river, etc.) andpermit the laying of foundations, building of piers, etc.
Flaming; blazing; flamelike; flame-colored; composed of flame.Pope.
Producing ova only; -- said of the ovaries of certain insectswhich do not produce vitelligenous cells.
An alkaloid, found in the rootstock of the golden seal(Hydrastis Canadensis), and extracted as a bitter, white, crystallinesubstance. It is used as a tonic and febrifuge.
One who encourages and propagates error; one who holds toerror.
A thin leaf of metal, as for use in gilding or enameling, or toshow through a translucent medium.

A poem set to music; a musical composition comprising choruses,solos, interludes, etc., arranged in a somewhat dramatic manner;originally, a composition for a single noise, consisting of bothrecitative and melody.
A kind of coarse blanket or garment used by the North AmericanIndians.
Pertaining to, or designating, certain derivatives ofphosphorous acid containing a hydrocarbon radical, and analogous tothe sulphonic acid.
The active principle of the water hemlock (Cicuta) extracted asa poisonous gummy substance.
Denoting the final end or purpose, as distinguished fromecbatic. See Ecbatic. Gibbs.
Toward the side; away from the mesial plane; -- opposed tomesiad.
One who prates in a weak and silly manner, like one whosefaculties are decayed.
The act or process by which articulate sounds are uttered; theutterance of articulate sounds; articulate speech.
A kind of sugar confection which dissolves easily in the mouth.Thackeray.
The male corresponding to mermaid; a sea man, or man fish.
A young squire, or knight's attendant; a page. [Obs.] Beau. &Fl.
The state or condition of one under age, or under the age oftwenty-one years; nonage; minority.
Furnished with an awn, or long bristle-shaped tip; bearded.Gray.
Granular; pertaining to, or having the granular structurecharacteristic of, the class of meteorites called chondrites.
The act of cutting down, as of trees; the act of cutting off.[R.]
A catkin or ament; the flower cluster of the hazel, pine,willow, and the like.
The quality or state of being spiny or thorny; spininess.
A dull, lusterless surface in certain of the arts, as gilding,metal work, glassmaking, etc.
A room or place where meat and other articles of food are keptbefore they are cooked. Shak.
Any plant of the umbelliferous genus Sanicula, reputed to havehealing powers.
One who lays slates, or whose occupation is to slate buildings.
A bitter principle obtained from the dogbane (Apocynumcannabinum).
A German cavalry soldier of the fourteenth and fifteenthcenturies.

A volatile liquid hydrocarbon, C5H6, related to ethylene andacetylene, but possessing the property of unsaturation in the thirddegree. It is the only known member of a distinct series ofcompounds. It has a garlic odor.
A small British marine fish (Motella tricirrata); -- calledalso whistler and three-bearded rockling. [Prov. Eng.]
One of the subdivisions into which the Upper Cretaceousformation of Europe is divided.
The third canonical book of the Old Testament, containing thelaws and regulations relating to the priests and Levites among theHebrews, or the body of the ceremonial law.
A simple podlike pericarp which contains several seeds andopens along the inner or ventral suture, as in the peony, larkspurand milkweed.
A compendious and rapid method or writing by substitutingcharacters, abbreviations, or symbols, for letters, words, etc.;short writing; stenography. See Illust. under Phonography.
A boat intended for use in heavy surf. It is built with apronounced sheer, and with a view to resist the shock of waves and ofcontact with the beach.
Condition of a client; state of being under the protection of apatron. Dryden.

Originally, a part of the palestra, or gymnasium among theGreeks; either the place where sand was stored for use in sprinklingthe wrestlers, or the wrestling ground itself. Hence, a part of theorchestra of the Greek theater.
An ancient Latin version of the Scripture, and the only versionwhich the Roman Church admits to be authentic; -- so called from itscommon use in the Latin Church.
Purple, -- represented in engraving by diagonal lines decliningfrom the right top to the left base of the escutcheon (or fromsinister chief to dexter base).
One employed to inspect yarn, to see that it is well spun, andfit for the loom. [Prov. Eng.]

Either one of two species of singular West Indian insectivores,allied to the tenrec. One species (Solendon paradoxus), native of St.Domingo, is called also agouta; the other (S. Cubanus), found inCuba, is called almique.
The institution, government, or authority of a church. [R.] Bp.Pearson.
Capable of being prorated, or divided proportionately. [U.S.]
A small, deep-centered ulcer of the transparent cornea.
One who makes an offering as an act worship or reverence. Dr.H. More.
To daub or smear, as with lime; to make or finish in a slipshodway. [Scot.]
In the East Indies, a princess or lady of high rank. Malcom.
To depart to, or be at, a distance; esp., to recede apparentlyfrom the sun, as a planet in its orbit. [R.]
Formerly, one of the administrative divisions or provinces ofthe Ottoman Empire; -- now called a vilayet.
To transfer, as blood, from the veins or arteries of one man oranimal to those of another.
To divest or deprive of deity or of a deific rank or condition.Feltham.

A constituent of the nuclei of all cells. It is a colorlessamorphous substance, readily soluble in alkaline fluids andespecially characterized by its comparatively large content ofphosphorus. It also contains nitrogen and sulphur.
A tree, the top of which has been lopped off. [Eng.]
The placing of two or more nouns in the same case; apposition.
The restitution of an outlawed person to the protection of thelaw; inlawing. Bouvier.
One who, or that which, singes. Specifically:(a) One employed to singe cloth.(b) A machine for singeing cloth.
The act of withdrawing; withdrawment; retreat; retraction.Fielding.
Of or pertaining to Ogyges, a mythical king of ancient Attica,or to a great deluge in Attica in his days; hence, primeval; ofobscure antiquity.
The care of a foster child; the charge of nursing. Sir W.Raleigh.
To importune; to demand fiercely or with passion. [Archaic]Carcyle.
A loding room; esp., a sleeping place partitioned off from alarge dormitory.
The action of the elements on a rock in altering its color,texture, or composition, or in rounding off its edges.
A term formerly restricted to mortification of the soft tissueswhich has not advanced so far as to produce complete loss ofvitality; but now applied to mortification of the soft parts in anystage.
The early part of the day, from morning to meridian, or noon.
The Rocky Mountain sheep (Ovis or Caprovis montana).

Of or pertaining to fat; derived from, or resembling, fat;specifically, designating an acid (formerly called also sebic, andpyroleic, acid), obtained by the distillation or saponification ofcertain oils (as castor oil) as a white crystalline substance.
A stub, like soft horn, about the size of a chestnut, situatedbehind and below the pastern joint.
One who makes an epitome; one who abridges; an epitomizer.Milton.
The quantity of being addible; capability of addition. Locke.
So tightly fitted as to preclude the escape of gas; imperviousto gas.
Turmeric oil, a brownish yellow, oily substance extracted fromturmeric by ligroin.
Not assented; -- said specif. of stocks or bonds the holders ofwhich refuse to deposit them by way of assent to an agreementaltering their status, as in a readjustment.
The variety of sugar (glucose) obtained from the glucosideindican. It is unfermentable, but reduces Fehling's solution.
Any deviation from the essential characteristics of a specifictype.
A primer; the first principle or rudiment of anything. [R.]Fuller.
The relation of an object to number. Krauth-Fleming.
A kind of persimmon tree (Diospyros discolor) from thePhilippine Islands, now introduced into the East and West Indies. Itbears an edible fruit as large as a quince.
An original or primary word; a word not derived from another; -- opposed to derivative.
A street remote from the center of a town. Johnson.
A foot that is abnormally flattened and spread out; flat foot.
An African bird of the genus Buphaga; the beefeater.
A reformed branch of the Bernardines, founded in 1577 atFeuillans, near Toulouse, in France.
A morphological term signifying development, in the case ofmulticellular organisms, from the same unit deme or unit of theinferior orders of individuality.
A bitter crystalline substance constituting the essentialprinciple of Natal aloes. Cf. Aloon.
A small dam to prevent free passage of water in an adit orlevel.
Of the nature of tallow; resembling tallow; greasy.
A large food fish (Diagramma lineatum), native of the EastIndies.
Having two hydrogen atoms which can be replaced by negativeatoms or radicals to form salts; -- said of bases. See Diacid.
A strong, liquid, organic base, C3H7.C6H4.NH2, homologous withaniline.
Having power, or tending, to take away. [R.] Harris.
An oily hydrocarbon regarded as a polymeric variety ofethylene, produced with etherin.
To whirl; to eddy. [R.]The waters went wirbling above and around. Owen. Meredith.
The act, practice, or art of singing psalms or sacred songs;also, psalms collectively, or a collection of psalms.
A Silurian fossil, formerly supposed to consist of eggs.

The act of baptizing; the application of water to a person, asa sacrament or religious ceremony, by which he is initiated into thevisible church of Christ. This is performed by immersion, sprinkling,or pouring.
The falling of dew; the time when dew begins to fall.
A granular crystalline rock consisting essentially of atriclinic feldspar (as labradorite) and hypersthene.
A benefice conferred on a person by the founder or patron,without either presentation or institution by the ordinary, orinduction by his orders. See the Note under Benefice, n.,
That group of vertebrates which develops in its embryonic lifethe envelope called the amnion. It comprises the reptiles, the birds,and the mammals.

The right of an author or his assignee, under statute, to printand publish his literary or artistic work, exclusively of all otherpersons. This right may be had in maps, charts, engravings, plays,and musical compositions, as well as in books.
Composed of clumps; massive; shapeless. Leigh Hunt.
A ball payer who stands out in the field to catch or stopballs.
An excitant containing opium, much used by the Turks.Dunglison.
A beautiful South American humming bird (Gouldia Popelairii),having the six outer tail feathers long, slender, and pointed. Thehead is ornamented with a long, pointed crest.
The depression, or mark, in the median line of the abdomen,which indicates the point where the umbilical cord separated from thefetus; the navel.
A small European flycatcher (Muscicapa gricola), so calledbecause it often nests on a beam in a building.
