A west Indian plant of the genus Maranta, esp. M. arundinacea,now cultivated in many hot countries. It said that the Indians usedthe roots to neutralize the venom in wounds made by poisoned arrows.
A subclass of Gastropoda, in which the body is symmetrical, theright and left sides being equal.
Any wheel worked by hand; esp., one the rim of which serves asthe handle by which a valve, car brake, or other part is adjusted.
A long dress, trailing on the floor, worn by tragic actors inGreek and Roman theaters.
The acquisition of the title or right to property by theuninterrupted possession of it for a certain term prescribed by law;-- the same as prescription in common law.
A mournful or plaintive poem; a funereal song; a poem oflamentation. Shak.
An acute and rugged crest of a mountain range or a subsidiaryridge between two mountain gorges.
A small marine fish of the Pacific coast of North America(Trichodon trichodon) which buries itself in the sand.
A green pigment present in the bile, formed from bilirubin byoxidation.
A provocative; an incitant; a stimulant. [R.] Jervas.
In old writers, the operations concerned in the removal ofparts of the body.
A cast taken in plaster of Paris, or in white lime.
To rouse up; to rouse from sleep; to awake; to arouse. Shak.
To settle, as the estate of one who dies without a will, orwhose will fails of an executor.
Pertaining to, or of the nature of, steatite; containing orresembling steatite.

A colorless, amorphous, nitrogenous substance, tasteless andodorless, formed from cartilaginous tissue by long-continued actionof boiling water. It is similar to gelatin, and is a large ingredientof commercial gelatin.
Of or pertaining to the smallpox; having pits, or sunkenimpressions, like those of the smallpox; variolar; variolic.
To cover with some protecting substance, as with lute, a crust,coating, or plates.

A process used in preparing certain kinds of leather, whichconsists in frizzing the skin, and working oil into it to supply theplace of the astringent (tannin, alum, or the like) ordinarily usedin tanning.
Growing black; changing to a black color; approaching toblackness. Johnson.
Going upon the sea; especially, sailing upon the deep sea; --used in distinction from coasting or river, as applied to vessels.
A mineral of a white or gray color occurring massive and inisometric crystals; in composition it is a magnesium borate withmagnesium chloride.
The state or quality of being ample; largeness; fullness;completeness.
The mere ranging of propositions one after another, withoutindicating their connection or interdependence; -- opposed to syntax.Brande & C.
an instrument for measuring the intensity of light; aphotometer.
Any construction, whether a temporary breastwork or permanentfortification, for attack or defense, the material of which ischiefly earth.
A bacterial disease of silkworms, supposed to be due to eatingcontaminated mulberry leaves.
A depositary, often a small box or casket, in which relics arekept.
One who complies, yields, or obeys; one of an easy, yieldytemper. Swift.
Accoutered with defensive armor; -- said of a horse. See Barded( which is the proper form.) Sir W. Raleigh.
A force acting on a body in the direction of its motion.Rankine.
The tribal history of cells, a division of morphophyly.Haeckel.
Pertaining to, or derived from, amber; specif., designating adibasic acid, C
A theorem or proposition so easy of demonstration as to bealmost self-evident. [R.] Crabb.
Act of plowing; also, act of writing. [Obs.] Bailey.
In a precious manner; expensively; extremely; dearly. Also usedironically.
A shingle; also, a slate for roofing. [Obs.] Holland.
A male red deer two years old; -- sometimes called brock.
A genus of marine univalve shells; the harp shells; -- socalled from the form of the shells, and their ornamental ribs.
The conveyance or transfer of an estate, either in fee for lifeor for years, most commonly the latter. Bouvier.
A kind of long trumpet, used among the Persians. Moore (Encyc.of Music).
Something sent by God; an unexpected acquisiton or piece ofgood fortune.
A disease of the mind; especially, a functional mentaldisorder, that is, one unattended with evident organic changes.
One who plagiarizes; or purloins the words, writings, or ideasof another, and passes them off as his own; a literary thief; aplagiary.
A Portuguese gold coin of the value of eight dollars, namedfrom the figure of King John which it bears;- often contracted intojoe; as, a joe, or a half joe.
By design; purposely; intentionally; -- opposed toaccidentally, ignorantly, or inadvertently.
A large purse or pouch made of skin with the hair or fur on,worn in front of the kilt by Highlanders when in full dress.
Having the sexes united in one individual, as when male andfemale flowers grow upon the same individual plant; hermaphrodite; --opposed to Ant: dioecious.
An unfledged or young male sparrow hawk. [Obs.] Shak.
The power or act of discovering ships or land at considerabledistances.
The relationship of cousins; state of being cousins;cousinhood. G. Eliot.
A small line of three strands used for seizing; -- called alsohousing. Totten.
A house of religious retirement, or of secusion from ordinarytemporal concerns, especially for monks; -- more rarely applied tosuch a house for females.
To remove the outer surface of, as of an old hewn stone, so asto give it a fresh appearance.
An instrument for observing or showing the positions of thestars. It is now disused.
A mode of speech peculiar to the Turks; a Turkish idiom orexpression; also, in general, a Turkish mode or custom.
A hydrocarbon obtained by decomposition of certain piperidinederivatives.
A surety; one bound for another, conjointly with him; aguarantor. Blackstone.
The spore-bearing surface of certain fungi, as that on thegills of a mushroom.
One who, or that which, paces; especially, a horse that paces.
To drain, as land; by means of wells, or pits, which receivethe water, and from which it is discharged by machinery.
An order of birds, formerly established to include the perchingbirds, but now generally regarded as an artificial group.
Pertaining to, or situated near, the surface; outer; -- opposedto ental. B. G. Wilder.
An order of holothurians, including those that have ambulacralsuckers, or feet, and an internal gill.
One who wears a mask; one who appears in disguise at amasquerade.
The art of giving birth (i. e., clearness and conviction) toideas, which are conceived as struggling for birth. Payne.
A substance found in madder root, and probably identical withruberythrinic acid.
The gum resin of the hemp plant (Cannabis sativa). Same asChurrus. Balfour.
An iron bar, with the end bent, used in stirring or skimmingmolten iron in the process of puddling.
A ketone derivative of thiophene obtained as a whitecrystalline substance, (C4H3S)2.CO, by the action of aluminiumchloride and carbonyl chloride on thiophene.
To play the sovereign; to act the monarch. [R.] Shak.
Hair matted, or twisted into a knot, as if by elves.
A part of a circle comprehended between two radii and theincluded arc.
Appearing or blossoming later in the season than is customarywith allied species.
A mania for, or an inordinate attachment to, English customs,institutions, etc.
To deprive of status as a church, or of membership in a church.Bp. Hall.
The administration of medicine in doses; specif., a scheme orsystem of grading doses of medicine according to age, etc.
One skilled in subjective philosophy; a subjectivist.
One accustomed to climb rocks or crags; esp., one who makes abusiness of climbing the cliffs overhanging the sea to get the eggsof sea birds or the birds themselves.
Caloric; heat; regarded as a material but imponderablesubstance.
The molecular attraction exerted between bodies in contact. SeeCohesion.
To mar the figure of; to render less complete, perfect, orbeautiful in appearance; to deface; to deform.Disfiguring not God's likeness, but their own. Milton.
One who, or that which, grubs; especially, a machine or tool ofthe nature of a grub ax, .grub hook, etc.
A cover or protection for an advanced trench or approach,formed of fascines and earth supported by a framework.
To treat cruelly or improperly; to ill use; to maltreat.
One who asperses; especially, one who vilifies another.
The ancient Latin name of Scotland; -- still used in poetry.
Money paid at fairs for leave to break ground for booths.Ainsworth.
A collective name for reviews, magazines, and all kinds ofperiodical literature. Brande & C.
To draw back, or cause to draw back. [Obs.] Spenser.
Produced by crushing or bruising; resembling, or consisting of,a mash.
A small muff worn over the wrist. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
Wrong understanding; misconstruction. [Obs.] Spenser.
A variety of hone slate, or whetstone, used for whetting toolswhen lubricated with oil.
A thin piece of wood, or other substance, used to keep inplace, or protect, an injured part, especially a broken bone whenset.
The quality of being legible; legibleness. Sir. D. Brewster.
An argument which presents an antagonist with two or morealternatives, but is equally conclusive against him, whicheveralternative he chooses.
Capable of being cut; specifically (Min.), capable of beingsevered by the knife with a smooth cut; -- said of minerals.
A stopper, as in a wind instrument of music. [Obs.] Bacon.
The formation of a new individual, either animal or vegetable,by a process of budding; an asexual method of reproduction;gemmulation; gemmiparity. See Budding.
A European sandpiper or snipe (Totanus canescens); -- calledalso greater plover.
A subscript mark, number, or letter. See Subscript, a.
A wind instrument, blown by a single reed, of richer and fullertone than the oboe, which has a double reed. It is the leadinginstrument in a military band.
A conflict by persons on foot; -- distinguished from a fight onhorseback. Sir P. Sidney.
An oxysulphide of lead occurring in implanted sphericalglobules of a yellowish or brownish color; -- called also voltzine.
The arrangement of the leaves within the leaf bud, as regardstheir folding, coiling, rolling, etc.; prefoliation.
. Capable of being exculpated; deserving exculpation. Sir G.Buck.
Lame; disabled; in a crippled condition. [R.] Mrs. Trollope.
Having a resemblance in structure, due to descent from a commonprogenitor with subsequent modification; homogenetic; -- applied bothto animals and plants. See Homoplastic.
The act of dividing with an instrument having a sharp edge.Wiseman.
To rouse; to excite; to call into life and action. [Obs.]
Two signs or characters combined to express a singlearticulated sound; as ea in head, or th in bath.
To display, or spread to view, as a flag, or the colors of amilitary body.
To eject the contents of the stomach by the mouth; to puke; tospew.
A condition of vegetation in which there is too abundant growthof the stem and leaves, accompanied by deficiency of flowers andfruit.
To come into contact with (an ovum or egg) so as to causeimpregnation; to fertilize; to fecundate.
The quality or state of being sensuous; sensuousness. [R.]
One of the elder and principal deities, the son of Coelus andTerra (Heaven and Earth), anf the father of Jupiter. Thecorresponding Greek divinity was Kro`nos, later CHro`nos, Time.
An implement consisting of a broad scythe for cutting grain,with a set of long fingers parallel to the scythe, designed toreceive the grain, and to lay it eventlyin a swath.

A crystalline, granular rock, consisting of quartz, feldspar,and mica, and usually of a whitish, grayish, or flesh-red color. Itdiffers from gneiss in not having the mica in planes, and therefor inbeing destitute of a schistose structure.
The act or practice of crimping; money paid to a crimp forshipping or enlisting men.
To or in the rear; behind; backwards. [Obs.] Spenser.
Having a brilliantly polished surface, as some leaves.
An East Indian stony coral now known to belong to theAlcyonaria; -- called also blue coral.
One of the special zooids, or cells, of Bryozoa, destined toreceive and develop ova; an ovicell. See Bryozoa.
The science or knowledge of the stars, esp. the fixed stars.Bouvier.
A fluophosphate of magnesia, occurring in yellowish crystals,and also in massive forms.
One who, or that which, repairs, restores, or makes amends.
A system of universal writing, or a manner of writing that maybe understood and used by all nations. Good.
A single and continuous vegetable axis; -- opposed tosympodium.
The process of fertilization in plants by an indirect orcircuitous method; -- opposed to orthogamy.
Watered or wet beneath; well-watered. [Obs.] Blount.
A solid whose bases or ends are any similar, equal, andparallel plane figures, and whose sides are parallelograms.
An igneous, crystalline in structure, consisting essentially ofa triclinic feldspar and hornblende. It includes part of what wascalled greenstone.
A slice; a skimmer; a spatula; a pudding stick. [Obs. or Prov.Eng.] Ainsworth.
Having no hard and sharp projections, as spines, prickles,spurs, claws, etc.
Covered or set with spherules; having one or more rows ofspherules, or minute tubercles.
A species of clover with pinkish or white flowers; Trifoliumhybridum.
A term applied to a lady's long, close-fitting dress made withwaist and skirt in one.
A large ganoid fish (Polyodon spathula) found in the rivers ofthe Mississippi Valley. It has a long spatula-shaped snout. Calledalso duck-billed cat, and spoonbill sturgeon.
Any one of several large spiny-tailed lizards of the genusUromastix. They inhabit Southern Asia and North Africa.
A hired mourner at a funeral. [Scot.] Sir W. Scott.
A mineral of a brown to black color, or, as in the varietyorangite, orange-yellow. It is essentially a silicate of thorium.

A mineral of a steel-gray to black color and metallic luster,occurring crystallized, often in twin crystals shaped like cogwheels(wheel ore), also massive. It is a sulphide of antimony, lead, andcopper.
A reserved rent in corn, formerly paid to religious houses bytheir tenants or farmers. Kennet.
A salt having two equivalents of oxalic acid to one of thebase; an acid oxalate.
One of an ancient religious sect, so called fron Cerinthus, aJew, who attempted to unite the doctrines of Christ with the opinionsof the Jews and Gnostics. Hook.
The name of the Supreme Being, in use among the Arabs and theMohammedans generally.
The three-banded armadillo (Tolypeutis tricinctus). See Illust.under Loricata.
A vessel for conveying passengers, merchandise, etc., acrossstreams and other narrow waters.
A store where books are kept for sale; -- called in England abookseller's shop.
One of the barbs of the hypoptilum, or aftershaft of a feather.See Feather.
A framework of timber covered with boards to support rubbish;also, a framework of boards to protect miners from falling stones.[Prov. Eng.]
Consisting of clay; abounding with clay; partaking of clay;like clay.
The various relations of animals and plants to one another andto the outer world.
A red or crimson pigment obtained from certain feathers ofseveral species of turacou; whence the name. It contains nearly sixper cent of copper.
The long-tailed, or resplendent, trogon (Pharomachus mocinno,formerly Trogon resplendens), native of Southern Mexico and CentralAmerica. Called alsoquetzal, and golden trogon.
Resembling sponge; having the nature or qualities of sponge.
A European plant of the genus Cerinthe, whose flowers are veryattractive to bees. Loudon.
To weave in or together; to intermix or intertwine by weaving;to interlace.Down they cast Their crowns, inwove with amaranth and gold. Milton.
A defect of vision consequent upon advancing age. It is due torigidity of the crystalline lens, which producepresbytia.
A rootlike filament or hair growing from the stems of mosses oron lichens; a rhizoid.
A convoluted ridge between grooves; a convolution; as, the gyriof the brain; the gyri of brain coral. See Brain.

Having one sex only, as plants which have the male and femaleflowers on separate individuals, or animals in which the sexes are inseparate individuals; dioecious; -- distinguished from bisexual, orhermaphrodite. See Dioecious.
One who eulogizes or praises; panegyrist; encomiast. Buckle.
One who is disgruntled by a failure in politics, or the like.[Slang, U.S.]
An orangered coloring substance resembling alizarin, found inthe root of an East Indian species of madder (Rubia munjista).
A compound medicinal powder, used by the ancients to sprinkleon ulcers, to absorb perspiration, etc. Dunglison.
A mineral of a honey color, found in brown coal, and partly theresult of vegetable decomposition; honeystone. It is a mellitate ofalumina.
A person named, or designated, by another, to any office, duty,or position; one nominated, or proposed, by others for office or forelection to office.
A traffic in bills of exchange (see Arbitration of Exchange);also, a traffic in stocks which bear differing values at the sametime in different markets.
The persons or interest formerly representing slaverypolitically, or wielding political power for the preservation oradvancement of slavery. [U. S.]
A kind of German biscuit or cake in the form of a twisted ring,salted on the outside.
Of, pertaining to, or containing, selenium; specifically,designating those compounds in which the element has a lower valenceas contrasted with selenic compounds.
To act as an officer in performing a duty; to transact thebusiness of an office or public trust; to conduct a public service.Bp. Stillingfleet.
The art or practice of cozening; artifice; fraud. Shak.

A viscid fluid secreted by mucous membranes, which it serves tomoisten and protect. It covers the lining membranes of all thecavities which open externally, such as those of the mouth, nose,lungs, intestinal canal, urinary passages, etc.
To free from blindness; to give or restore sight to; to openthe eyes of. [R.] J. Webster (1607).
A group of Entomostraca, with suctorial mouths, includingspecies parasitic on fishes, as the carp lice (Argulus).
An order of aquatic amphibians having prominent external gillsand four legs. It includes Proteus and Menobranchus (Necturus).Called also Proteoidea, and Proteida.
A disaccharide present in glycosides. Prepared from rutin byhydrolysis with rhamnodiastase. 6-O-a-L-rhamnosyl-D-glucose;C12H22O10.
A relation or correspondence in function, between organs orparts which are decidedly different.
To render the latent power of (anything) available. Dunglison.
A plant of the Rubia (R. tinctorum). The root is much used indyeing red, and formerly was used in medicine. It is cultivated inFrance and Holland. See Rubiaceous.
One who practices rope dancing, high vaulting, or other daringgymnastic feats.
Like, or suitable to, a zealot; ardently zealous. [R.] Strype.
One of the essential principles of the hedge hyssop (Gratiolaofficinalis).
To spread out; to expand; -- usually as a past part. or adj.
A genus of cactaceous plants; the prickly pear, or Indian fig.
Wholly solid; -- said of a barometer constructed of solidmaterials to show the variations of atmospheric pressure without theuse of liquids, as the aneroid.
One of a fanatical sect which flourished in Europe in the 13thand 14th centuries, and maintained that flagellation was of equalvirtue with baptism and the sacrament; -- called also disciplinant.
Peculiarity of constitution; that temperament, or state ofconstitution, which is peculiar to a person; idiosyncrasy.
Prepared for battle; combatant; warlike. Spenser.-- n.

With the lower focal points all in the same plane; -- said ofsets of eyepieces so mounted that they may be interchanged withoutvarying the focus of the instrument (as a microscope or telescope)with which they are used.
The Brazilian kite (Polyborus Brasiliensis); -- so called inimitation of its notes.
The tube by which food and drink are carried from the pharynxto the stomach; the esophagus.
A group of acalephs, including most of the larger jellyfishes;the Discophora.
A cartilage or bone in front of the pubis in some amphibiansand other animals.
The apartment, in a church or temple, where the vestments,etc., are kept; -- now contracted into vestry.
One who slanders; a defamer; a calumniator. Jer. Taylor.
A Dutch silver coin worth about forty cents; -- called alsoflorin and gulden.

An opposition or contrast of words or sentiments occurring inthe same sentence; as, "The prodigal robs his heir; the miser robshimself." "He had covertly shot at Cromwell; he how openly aimed atthe Queen."
One versed in the Gemara, or adhering to its teachings.
To form into an island; to surround. [Obs.] Drayton.
Furnished with an arbor; lined with trees. "An arboreal walk."Pollok.
One who maintains that faith alone, without works, issufficient for justification; -- opposed to nullifidian. Hammond.
The act, art, or practice, of riding a cycle, esp. a bicycle ortricycle.
A solid consisting of a double twelve-sided pyramid; -- socalled because the planes of this form occur on crystals of beryl.
Movables; furniture; -- also used in the singular (moeble).[Obs.] Chaucer.
A way or road dug through a hill, or sunk below the surface ofthe land. [U.S.]
Of the nature of, or containing, whey; resembling whey;wheyish. Bacon.
A hydraulic device by which the movement of the wheel on thebridge operates the steering gear at the stern.
The sodium salt of a sulphonic acid of a naphthol,C10H5(OH)(NH2)SO3Na used as a developer.
A South American bird of the genus Nyctibius, allied to thegoatsuckers.
The common bistort or snakeweed (Polygonum bistorta).
The money or price paid for fulling or cleansing cloth.Johnson.
A small California food fish (Heterostichus rostratus), livingamong kelp. The name is also applied to species of the genusPlatyglossus.
A hydrous phosphate of iron of a blue to green color, growingdarker on exposure. It occurs in monoclinic crystals, also fibrous,massive, and earthy.
The part of the axis contained between the ordinate and tangentdrawn to the same point in a curve.
A dweller in Flam (or Susiana), an ancient kingdom ofSouthwestern Asia, afterwards a province of Persia.
To free from the influence of a charm or spell; to disenchant.[R.] Jer. Taylor.
A yellowish white, amorphous, nitrogenous substance found inwheat, rye, etc., and resembling gluten; -- formerly called alsomucin.
A member of a group of South American blood-sucking bats, ofthe genera Desmodus and Diphylla. See Vampire.
Having that cloudiness or dimness of surface that is called"blooming."
A part of male dress in front of the breeches, formerly madevery conspicuous. Shak. Fosbroke.
The quality of attending or accompanying; attendance; anattendant. [Obs.]
A compound or twin crystal consisting of five individuals.
One who grasps or seizes; one who catches or holds.
In an abortive or untimely manner; immaturely; fruitlessly.
the life estate which a husband has in the lands of hisdeceased wife, which by the common law takes effect where he has hadissue by her, born alive, and capable of inheriting the lands. Mozley& W.

Relating to harmony, -- as melodic relates to melody;harmonious; esp., relating to the accessory sounds or overtones whichaccompany the predominant and apparent single tone of any string orsonorous body.

The first motion of the fetus in the womb felt by the mother,occurring usually about the middle of the term of pregnancy. It hasbeen popularly supposed to be due to the fetus becoming possessed ofindependent life.
A division of Ctenophora including those which have a long,ribbonlike body. The Venus's girdle is the most familiar example.
Gradual cessation of use or custom; neglect of use; disuse.[R.] Hooker.
A lawyer of the highest rank, answering to the doctor of thecivil law; -- called also serjeant at law. [Eng.] Blackstone.
Of or pertaining to a suborder of urticaceous plants, of whichthe elm is the type.
A large genus of plants bearing bell-shaped flowers, often ofgreat beauty; -- also called bellflower.
The substance or body that insulates; a nonconductor.
A kind of silk thread less glossy than floss, and spun fromcoarser material. It is much used in embroidery instead of floss.
A flat tablet or ledge of any material set horizontally at adistance from the floor, to hold objects of use or ornament.
Having three sorts of flowers in the same head, -- male,female, and hermaphrodite, or perfect, flowers.

To attack by words or arguments; to contradict; to assail; tocall in question; to make insinuations against; to gainsay; tooppose.The truth hereof I will net rashly pugn, or overboldly affirm.Peacham.
To convert into, or to impregnate with, silica, or with thecompounds of silicon.The specimens found . . . are completely silicified. Say.
To record in or as history. [R.] Lamb.Thy conquest meet to be historified. Sir P. Sidney.
In a melodious, flowing style; in a singing style, as opposedto bravura, recitativo, or parlando.
To deceive; to entice; to lure. [Obs.]The devil insnareth the souls of many men, by illuring them with themuck and dung of this world. Fuller.
A kind of cigar of large size and superior quality; also, thesize in which such cigars are classed.
The art of measuring degrees of heat, or the expansion ofbodies by heat.
Land appendant to a cot or cottage, or held by a cottager orcotter.
The patrician class; the aristocracy; also, the office ofpatriarch. Milman.

That which polarizes; especially, the part of a polariscopewhich receives and polarizes the light. It is usually a reflectingplate, or a plate of some crystal, as tourmaline, or a doublyrefracting crystal.
One who machinates, or forms a scheme with evil designs; aplotter or artful schemer. Glanvill. Sir W. Scott.
To kindle amiss; to inflame to a bad purpose; to excitewrongly.
To deal in; to make merchandise of; to traffic in; -- usedchiefly of discreditable traffic.
A French cordial or liqueur flavored with anise seeds. DeColange.
That branch of medical science which treats of the hygiene anddiseases of children.
To put (a vessel) on the other tack by veering her short roundon her heel; -- so called from the circumstance of bracing the headyards abox (i. e., sharp aback, on the wind). Totten.
A large revolving platform, for turning railroad cars,locomotives, etc., in a different direction; -- called alsoturnplate.
Like or pertaining to the butterflies of the genus Heliconius.
Of or pertaining to scandium; derived from, or containing,scandium.
An abnormal prolongation of the axis of inflorescence.
Indentation; an impression like that made by a tooth.
The keeper and driver of an elephant. [East Indies]
The smallest of regular sizes of portrait photographs.
Those things which pertain to the practical part of an art,science, or profession; technical terms; technics.
Disposition to willful wrongdoing; malignity; perversity;cantankerousness; obstinacy. [Slang or Colloq., U. S.]
Of or pertaining to ancient Troy or its inhabitants.-- n.
A place of shelter for cattle. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
A kind of granite or gneiss containing a silvery talcosemineral.
In a textual manner; in the text or body of a work; inaccordance with the text.
Appearing as if a part were cut off at the extremity.
The embryonic sac of an ovule, sometimes regarded as aninnermost fifth integument. Cf. Quartine, and Tercine.
A white, crystalline base, obtained indirectly from furfurol.
The stock or wood to which the barrel of a hand gun isfastened.
A medicine or substance that expels worms from animal bodies;an anthelmintic.
One of the inhabitants of the llanos of South America.

An ornament, gem, or scroll, or a package containing a relic,etc., worn as a charm or preservative against evils or mischief, suchas diseases and witchcraft, and generally inscribed with mystic formsor characters.

Of or pertaining to Michael Faraday, the distinguishedelectrician; -- applied especially to induced currents ofelectricity, as produced by certain forms of inductive apparatus, onaccount of Faraday's investigations of their laws.
Of or pertaining to the poppy; of the nature of the poppy. SirT. Browne.
(Astron.) A northern constellation near the pole. Its head,which is in the Milky Way, is marked by a triangle formed by threestars of the fourth magnitude. See Cassiopeia.
The quality or state of being moody; specifically, liability tostrange or violent moods.
A rare mineral having a velvet-black color and submetallicluster. It is a niobate of uranium, iron, and the yttrium and ceriummetals.
One who makes signals; one who communicates intelligence bymeans of signals.
In a minute manner; with minuteness; exactly; nicely.
Situated upon or over the colon; -- applied to the region ofthe abdomen adjacent to the colon.
Having vague outlines, and colors and shades so mingled as togive a misty appearance; -- said of a painting.
A somewhat riotous parade, accompanied with the blowing of tinhorus, and other discordant noises; also, a burlesque serenade; acharivari. [U. S.]
A hypothetical radical (C8H15O), regarded as the essentialresidue of octoic acid.
A tropical fish of the Atlantic ocean (Dutes auriga); -- calledalso charioteer. The name refers to a long, lashlike spine of thedorsal fin.
A medicine designed to be snuffed up the nose, to promotedischarges of mucus; a sternutatory. Coxe.-- a.
The quality or state of being unchaste; lewdness; incontinence.
Pertaining to polymathy; acquainted with many branches oflearning.
The act of mutilating, or the state of being mutilated;deprivation of a limb or of an essential part.
One who bolts; esp.: (a) A horse which starts suddenly aside.(b) A man who breaks away from his party.
To confine as in a cloister; to cloister. Lovelace.
A branch of inflorescence; the zigzag axis on which the floretsare arranged in the spikelets of grasses.
An officer of the forest, whose duty it was to guard the woods.
Opposition or resistance of matter to force. [R.] Sir W.Hamilton.
The inspissated juice of a tree of the genus Artocarpus (A.incisa, or breadfruit tree), sometimes used in making birdlime, onaccount of its glutinous quality.
A narrow space between the foot of the rampart and the scarp ofthe ditch, serving to receive the earth that may crumble off or bewashed down, and prevent its falling into the ditch. Wilhelm.
Small splinters of stone inserted into the joints of coarsemasonry. Weale.
Connection by birth; natural union. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
To make or become tepid, or moderately warm. Goldsmith.
A European whitefish (Coregonus laveretus), found in themountain lakes of Sweden, Germany, and Switzerland.
An instrument that discloses objects in the dark or in a faintlight. [Obs.] Pepys.
Laborious drudgery; esp., the acting as a drudge for another atan English school.
Pertaining to, or designating, a nitrogenous acid which isobtained by the oxidation of uric acid, as a white crystallinesubstance (C3N2H2O3); -- also called oxalyl urea.
Pain in the stomach or epigastrium, as in gastric disorders.
The quality or state of being distinguished by sex. Lindley.

The sovereignty of reason in the sphere of morals; or man'spower, as possessed of reason, to give law to himself. In this,according to Kant, consist the true nature and only possible proof ofliberty. Fleming.
To remove the shroud from; to uncover. P. Fletcher.
A tank containing pipes through which circulates steam, water,air, or the like, for heating or cooling; -- used in some heating andventilation systems.
A spiral cam, or a flat piece of metal of spirally curvedoutline, used for giving motion to, or changing the position of,another part, as the hammer tail of a striking clock.
A soft, sweet stop, or set of open wood pipes in an organ.
A structure which overlaps the mouth of certain insects.
A substance formerly supposed to give to soup and broth theircharacteristic odor, and probably consisting of one or several of theclass of nitrogenous substances which are called extractives.
A foreign substance, either liquid or solid, usually of minutesize, inclosed in the mass of a mineral.
An umpire; a third arbiter, appointed when two arbiters,previously selected, disagree.
Easily broken through; boggy; marshy; swampy. [Prov. Eng. &Colloq. U.S.] Bartlett.
As much as a tumbler will hold; enough to fill a tumbler.
A genus of small beetles, one species of which (E. viti) isvery injurious to the vines in the wine countries of Europe.
To close eyes of; to seel; -- said in reference to a hawk.[Obs.]
The quality or state of being limber; flexibleness. Boyle.
A yellow amorphous mineral, essentially a hydrated oxide ofuranium derived from the alteration of uraninite.
The act or process of heaping or drawing earth around plants.
One who steals purses or other articles from pockets. Bentley.
A collection of blood, pus, or other fluid, in some cavity ofthe body, especially that of the pleura. Dunglison.
The evening preceding Allhallows or All Saints' Day. [Scot.]Burns.
The quality or state of being seemly: comeliness; propriety.
A colorless oily liquid, (C2H5)2S2, having a strong garlicodor; -- called also ethyl disulphide. By extension, any one of theseries of related compounds.
Local oscillations in level observed in the case of some lakes,as Lake Geneva.
Fierceness of look; sternness; crabbedness; forbiddingness.

The official staff or wand of Hermes or Mercury, the messengerof the gods. It was originally said to be a herald's staff of olivewood, but was afterwards fabled to have two serpents coiled about it,and two wings at the top.
A fluoride of alumina and soda occurring with the Greenlandcryolite in octahedral crystals.
A low story between two higher ones, usually between the groundfloor and the first story; mezzanine. Parker.
A ferment, resembling diastase, found in mustard seeds.
To go on an excursion for observing and collecting minerals; tomineralogize.
A genus of elongated bivalve shells, allied to the mussels, andremarkable for their ability to bore holes for shelter, in solidlimestone, shells, etc. Called also Lithophagus.
Twentieth; divided into, or consisting of, twenties or twentyparts. Tylor.
One of the transparent lenslike cells in the ocelli of certainarthropods.
Any part of a mathematical instrument that moves or slidesbackward and forward upon another part.
A little one; -- used as a term of endearment. [Obs.] Skelton.
A large squirrel fish (Holocentrus ascensionis) of Florida andthe West Indies.
Any one of the several species of Kneiffia, esp. K. fruticosa(syn. Onothera fruticosa), of the Evening-primrose family, havingflowers that open by daylight.
A system of philosophy among the Hindoos, founded on scatteredtexts of the Vedas, and thence termed the "Anta," or end orsubstance. Balfour (Cyc. of India.)
Inclined to keep silent; reserved; uncommunicative.
One who sews well, or whose occupation is to sew. [Obs.]
To beat or reduce to powder or dust; to pulverize. [R.]

The digest, or abridgment, in fifty books, of the decisions,writings, and opinions of the old Roman jurists, made in the sixthcentury by direction of the emperor Justinian, and forming theleading compilation of the Roman civil law. Kent.
One in charge of the performances (as of horses) within thering in a circus.
The brain and spinal cord; the cerebro-spinal axis;myelencephalon. B. G. Wilder.
A genus of spiral gastropod shells, often of large size,characteristic of the lower Silurian rocks.
Careless; heedless; indifferent; unconcerned. J. S. Mill.
A solution of a medicinal substance in water; -- distinguishedfrom tincture and aqua.
To make a speech; to harangue. [Used derisively or humorously.]
Of or pertaining to a furuncle; marked by the presence offuruncles.
The doctrines of the Molinists, somewhat resembling the tenetsof the Arminians.
To stand in dread of; to regard with fear; to dread. [R.]
To land again; to put on land, as that which had been shippedor embarked.
A place where tiles are made or burned; a tile kiln.
Any bird of the genus Flatyrynchus. They belong to the familyof flycatchers.
The quality possessed by some crystals of presenting differentcolors in three different directions.
A female waiter or attendant; a waiting maid or waiting woman.
To deprive of wonted usage; to disaccustom. [R.] Bp. Hall.
A segmental tubule; one of the tubules of the primitiveurinogenital organs; a segmental organ. See Illust. under Loeven'slarva.
A sort of dog, noted for quick scent and eager pursuit of game.[Obs.] Wase (1654).
One of two straps, chains, or ropes of a harness, extendingfrom the collar or breastplate to a whiffletree attached to a vehicleor thing to be drawn; a tug.
A temporary structure sometimes used in the funeral solemnitiesof eminent persons, for the public exhibition of the remains, ortheir conveyance to the place of burial.
A kind of herpes (Herpes zoster) which spreads half way aroundthe body like a girdle, and is usually attended with violentneuralgic pain.
Sloping upward; rising as a hillside; -- opposed to declivous.
The quality or state of being a youth; the period of youth.Cheyne.
A dyestuff resembling alizarin, found in madder root, andextracted as an orange or red crystalline substance.
The spirit or conduct of the Vandals; ferocious cruelty;hostility to the arts and literature, or willful destruction ordefacement of their monuments.
Open; -- used synonymously with perforate, as applied to thenostrils or birds.
Of or pertaining to Philippi, a city of ancient Macedonia.-- n.
Having the quality of nonage; being a minor; immature. W.Browne.
The quotient of a unit divided by thirty; one of thirty equalparts.
The calcined ashes of any coarse seaweed used for themanufacture of soda and iodine; also, the seaweed itself; fucus;wrack.
Indented with small concave curves, as the edge of a bordure,bend, or the like.
Airy; showy; finical; hence, characterized by an affected orfantastical manner.
Ardently desired or longed for; earnestly coveted. [Obs.] SirH. Wotton.
Tending to descend; tending downwards; descending. Smart.
The upper division of the Permian (Dyas) of Europe. Theprevailing rock is a magnesian limestone.
Long-established practice, considered as unwritten law, andresting for authority on long consent; usage. See Usage, andPrescription.
The science of colors; that part of optics which treats of theproperties of colors.
To excel in walking; to leave behind in walking. B. Jonson.
One who fights with his fists; esp., a professional prizefighter; a boxer.
A small armed vessel, with sails and oars, -- used on theMalabar coast. A. Chalmers.
A division of bivalve mollusks of which the common clam (Mya)is the type.
One who is younger; an inferior in age; a junior. "The eldershall serve the younger." Rom. ix. 12.
One carpel of an umbelliferous fruit. See Cremocarp.
A shop or room where strong liquors are sold and drunk; adramshop.
A plant (Veronica Beccabunga), with flowers, usually blue, inaxillary racemes. The American species is V. Americana. [Formerlywritten broklempe or broklympe.]
One of a kind of minute, calcareous bodies, probably vegetable,often abundant in deep-sea mud.
A place and apparatus for boiling, as for evaporating brine insalt making.
An American species of rockrose (Helianthemum Canadense),sometimes used in medicine as an astringent or aromatic tonic.
A detached work with two embankments with make a salient angle.It is raised before the curtain on the counterscarp of the place.Formerly called demilune and half-moon.
A rounded tooth or notch of a crenate leaf, or any part that iscrenate; -- called also crenelle.
To run between parties and intercept without right theadvantage that one should gain from the other; to traffic without aproper license; to intrude; to forestall others; to intermeddle.
Relating to, or composed of, cotton; cottony. [Obs.]Cottomary and woolly pillows. Sir T. Browne.
One who punts; specifically, one who plays against the bankeror dealer, as in baccara and faro. Hoyle.
A mineral of the Zeolite family, often occurring in amygdaloid,in foliated masses, and also in monoclinic crystals with pearlyluster on the cleavage face. It is a hydrous silicate of alumina andlime.
One who practices or pretends to divination; a diviner. [R.]Burton.
A solid having many summits or angular points; a polyhedron.
A device for raising water by the direct action of steam; apulsometer.
A biennial umbelliferous plant (Apium graveolens) native of theseacoats of Europe and Asia. When deprived of its acrid and evenpoisonous properties by cultivation, it becomes celery.
Having a lyre-shaped shoulder girdle, as certain fishes.
A bony scale of a reptile or fish; a large horny scale on theleg of a bird, or on the belly of a snake.
A genus of American and Asiatic solanaceous herbs, with viscidfoliage and funnel-shaped blossoms. Several species yield tobacco.See Tobacco.
Inflames; glowing with light or passion; ablaze. G. Eliot.

An angle in the south transept of Westminster Abbey, London; --so called because it contains the tombs of Chaucer, Spenser, Dryden,Ben Jonson, Gray, Tennyson, Browning, and other English poets, andmemorials to many buried elsewhere.
A fish resembling the trout. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Garew.
Of or pertaining to iridium; -- applied specifically tocompounds in which iridium has a low valence.
A complex nitrogenous substance C3N3H5O3 obtained from alloxan(or when urea is fused with ethyl oxamate), as a stable whitecrystalline powder; -- called also oxaluramide.
A maker or vender of clocks and watches; one skilled inhorology.
To walk fast; to go quickly; to run hastily away. [Colloq. &Humorous, U.S.]
Any caterpillar which has the general appearance of a slug, asdo those of certain moths belonging to Limacodes and allied genera,and those of certain sawflies.
The articles usually sold by stationers, as paper, pens, ink,quills, blank books, etc.
A long, heavy, two-handed and two-edged sword, formerly used bySpanish foot soldiers and by executioners. Wilhelm.

A trussed frame extending fore and aft, usually above deck, andintended to increase the longitudinal strength and stiffness. Usedchiefly in American river and lake steamers. Called also hoggingframe, and hogback.
A silvered aromatic pill, used to correct the odor of thebreath.
The dense calcified substance of which teeth are largelycomposed. It contains less animal matter than bone, and in the teethof man is situated beneath the enamel.
The articles kept by a drysalter; also, the business of adrysalter.
Similar in texture or appearance to felt or woolen cloth.
The knowledge of many arts and sciences; variety of learning.Johnson.
Any one of several species of long-billed limicoline birdsbelonging to the genera Scolopax and Philohela. They are mostlynocturnal in their habits, and are highly esteemed as game birds.
To unlink; to disunite; to separate. [R.] Tennyson.
A crystalline derivative of salicylic acid, used as anantiseptic and antirheumatic.
To divest of the quality of wonder or mystery; to interpret; toexplain. [R.] Fuller.
Not bashful or modest; bold; impudent; shameless. Shak.
Of or pertaining to spots upon a surface; spotted; maculate.
A small composite plant with cottony or silky stem and leaves,primarily a species of Gnaphalium, but the name is now given to manyplants of different genera, as Filago, Antennaria, etc.; cottonweed.
A kind of catchfly of the genus Silene; also, a poisonousmushroom (Agaricus muscarius); fly agaric.
An expression of frolic and exultation, and sometimes ofwonder. B. Jonson.
A large genus of tropical American trees and shrubs, nearlyrelated to the true myrtles (Myrtus), from which they differ inhaving very few seeds in each berry.
A worthless woman; also, a worthless horse. [Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
An aquatic plant (Ceratophyllum), with finely divided leaves.
To take satisfaction; to live in happiness. [R.] Milton.
A tierce or cask for dried fruits, etc., usually about 700 lbs.Simmonds.

A genus of marine mollusks of the order Tectibranchiata; thesea hare. Some of the species when disturbed throw out a deep purpleliquor, which colors the water to some distance. See Illust. inAppendix.
To rub or wear by rubbing; to chafe. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A relative whose relationship can be traced exclusively throughmales.
A sort of cake or sausage, made of the salted roes of themullet, much used on the coast of the Mediterranean as an incentiveto drink.
A performer, esp. a skilled performer, on the piano.
A game in which the object is to toss a ring so that it willcatch upon an upright stick.
Having the base, or end next the attachment, narrower than thetop, as a leaf.
A proteolytic ferment, like trypsin, present in the juice ofthe green fruit of the papaw (Carica Papaya) of tropical America.
A peduncle rising from the ground or from a subterranean stem,as in the stemless violets, the bloodroot, and the like.
The palm (or great black) cockatoo, of Australia (Microglossusaterrimus).

Any one of numerous species of finchlike birds belonging toEstrelda and allied genera, native of Asia, Africa, and Australia.The bill is large, conical, and usually red in color, resemblingsealing wax. Several of the species are often kept as cage birds.
The red-breasted or gray snipe (Macrorhamphus griseus); --called also brownback, and grayback.
Any stone or material that has been borne away from itsoriginal site by natural agencies; esp., a large block or fragment ofrock; a bowlder.
The common perch. See 1st Bass. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
a large West African baboon (Cynocephalus, or Papio, mormon).The adult male has, on the sides of the nose, large, naked, groovedswellings, conspicuously striped with blue and red.
Forced feeding (as of poultry or infants) by means of a tubepassed through the mouth down to the stomach.
The sale of commodities in small quantities or parcels; --opposed to wholesale; sometimes, the sale of commodities at secondhand.
One who works in lead; esp., one who furnishes, fits, andrepairs lead, iron, or glass pipes, and other apparatus for theconveyance of water, gas, or drainage in buildings.
The act amputating; esp. the operation of cutting of a limb orprojecting part of the body.
One who wishes or desires; one who expresses a wish. Shak.
A small telescope for viewing distant terrestrial objects.
A mixture of volatile hydrocarbons intermediate between gsoleneand cymogene. It is obtained in the purification of crude petroleum,and is used as a refregerant.
A genus of Silurian fossil corals; the chain corals. See Chaincoral, under Chain.
The ecclesiastic who reads the epistle at the communionservice.
A hospital, or place where the infirm or sick are lodged andnursed gratuitously, or where out-patients are treated.
To reverse. [Obs.]Whose shield he bears renverst. Spenser.
A West Indian tree (Calliandra latifolia) with showy, crimsonblossoms.
A portion of a country which is separated from the main partand surrounded by politically alien territory. [Recent.]
Given to vaunting or boasting; vainly ostentatious; boastful;vainglorious.

One of several swimming birds or divers, of the genus Colymbus(formerly Podiceps), aud allied genera, found in the northern partsof America, Europe, and Asia. They have strong, sharp bills, andlobate toes.
The act, or occupation, of one who launders; washing andironing.
A silicate containing a large amount of cerium. It is usuallyblack in color, opaque, and is related to epidote in form andcomposition.
To cover or dress with lard or grease; to fatten. Shak.
To place in close connection or contiguity; to juxtapose.Derham.
A furnace for producing combustible gas which is used for fuel.
Fellowship; association; companionship. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Mixed with copper; containing copper, or made of copper; likecopper.
A rounded hillock; a rounded elevation or protuberance.Westmin. Rev.
An apparatus for measuring the capacity of condensers, or theinductive capacity of dielectrics.
A state of aroused or increased vital activity in an organism,or any of its organs or tissues.
The lesser whitethroat of Europe; -- called also babblingwarbler.
Proceeding by the smaller intervals (half steps or semitones)of the scale, instead of the regular intervals of the diatonic scale.
The act of uniting, or the state of being united; junction.[Obs.] Wiseman.
A cavity into which, in certain bryozoans, the esophagus andanus open.
An East Indian carnivorous mammal (Prionodon gracilis),resembling the civets, but without scent pouches. It is handsomelyspotted.
To analyse, or determine the strength of, by means of standardsolutions. Cf. Standardized solution, under Solution.
One who swindles, or defrauds grossly; one who makes a practiceof defrauding others by imposition or deliberate artifice; a cheat.
An internal process of the sternal plates in the thorax ofinsects.
An uproar; a noisy quarrel; a disturbance; a brawl.
An object to be tilted at; -- called also quintel. [Writtenalso quintin.]
To root with the snout. See 1st Root. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Sour, bitter, and harsh to the taste, as unripe fruit; sharpand harsh.
The germ history of the functions, or the history of thedevelopment of vital activities, in the individual, being one of thebranches of ontogeny. See Morphogeny. Haeckel.
A kind of gilt leather. See Checklaton. [Obs.] Spenser.
To unite by twining one with another; to entangle; tointerlace. Milton.
A coarse grass found on sandy beaches (Ammophila arundinacea).See Beach grass, under Beach.
The act or process of separating mingled gases of unequaldiffusibility by transmission through porous substances.

A Malayan fruit produced by the tree Nephelium lappaceum, andclosely related to the litchi nut. It is bright red, oval in shape,covered with coarse hairs (whence the name), and contains a pleasantacid pulp. Called also ramboostan.
A white, amorphous, tenacious substance resembling caoutchouc,and obtained as an insoluble residue of mastic.
For the greatest part; for the most part; chiefly; in the main.

A case containing powder to be exploded, esp. a conical orcylindrical case of metal filled with powder and attached to a plank,to be exploded against and break down gates, barricades, drawbridges,etc. It has been superseded.
To wander about; to saunter; to talk incoherently. [Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
Having an undivided, horny, bootlike covering; -- said of thetarsus of some birds.
One who is lord over another or others; a superior lord; amaster. Freeman.
An herbaceous or woody stem which bears leaves, and may bearflowers.
A textualist; a textman. [Obs.]The crabbed textualists of his time. Milton.
To wrench; to tear; to sprain; to injure by violent strainingor contortion. [R.] Dryden. "Hasting to raunch the arrow out."Spenser.
A toxic alkaloid (ptomaine) obtained from putrid flesh and fromherring brines. As a poison it is said to execute profuse diarrhoea,vomiting, and intestinal inflammation. Brieger.
A coating or covering resembling ice, as of sugar and milk orwhite of egg; frosting.
A foot of three syllables, the middle one short and the otherslong, as in cast. Andrews.
A large Mediterranean food fish (Umbrina cirrhosa): -- calledalso umbra, and umbrine.
A boy's play, called also fivepenny morris. See Morris.
A shop where any manufacture or handiwork is carried on.
A small membranous bladder or tube in which are inclosed theseedlike reproductive particles or sporules of lichens and certainfungi.
A kind of laminated shale or sandstone belonging to some of thelayers of the Upper Silurian.
To render capable; to enable; to qualify.By thih instruction we may be capaciated to observe those errors.Dryden.
The process of becoming white, or developing white patches, orstreaks.

Formerly, a man hired to work by the day; now, commonly, onewho has mastered a handicraft or trade; -- distinguished fromapprentice and from master workman.I have thought some of nature's journeymen had made men, and not madethem well. Shak.
The Oregon grape, a species of barberry (Berberis Aquifolium),often cultivated for its hollylike foliage.
An assistant to the ship's cook in washing, steeping, andshifting the salt provisions.
A prominence on the lower posterior portion of the concha ofthe external ear, opposite the tragus. See Ear.
An improvement of an estate which renders it better than mererepairing would do; -- generally used in the plural. [U. S.] Bouvier.
Having undulations like waves; -- said of one of the lines inheraldry which serve as outlines to the ordinaries, etc.

A disease, characterized by difficulty of breathing (due to aspasmodic contraction of the bronchi), recurring at intervals,accompanied with a wheezing sound, a sense of constriction in thechest, a cough, and expectoration.
A quantity greater than any assignable quantity of the samekind.
A large flatboat, used in the West Indies for taking freightfrom shore to ship.
A large heart-shaped cherry, either black, red, or white.
A genus of cetaceans having a long, pointed, bony beak, usuallytwo tusklike teeth in the lower jaw, but no teeth in the upper jaw.
One to, or for, whom anything is reserved; -- contrasted withreservor.
An attendant at a theater who has charge of the boxes.
With the flat side downward, or next to another object; notedgewise.
The act or process of portraying; description; delineation.
An architectural member, plain or ornamental, projecting from awall or pier, to support weight falling outside of the same; also, adecorative feature seeming to discharge such an office.
A heathlike plant of the genus Empetrum, and its fruit, ablack, scarcely edible berry; -- also called crakeberry.
Derived from wood by distillation; -- formerly used indesignating crude wood spirit.
A line connecting points on the earth's surface having the samemean summer temperature.
One who derides, or laughs at, another in contempt; a mocker; ascoffer.

An arctic sea bird Fratercula arctica) allied to the auks, andhaving a short, thick, swollen beak, whence the name; -- called alsobottle nose, cockandy, coulterneb, marrot, mormon, pope, and seaparrot.
Of or pertaining to Tahiti, an island in the Pacific Ocean.-- n.
An officer who has authority to direct in the extinguishing offires, or to order what precautions shall be taken against fires; --called also fireward.
To melt or be dissolved; to deliquesce. [Obs.] Boyle.
Copied, reproduced as a molding or cast, in contradistinctionfrom the original model.
A woman's headband (sometimes of metal), for binding the fronthair.
a creator of great skill in the manual arts.Syn. -- craftsman.[WordNet 1.5]
A yellow dye obtained from the leaves of the holly.
Producing but one kind of spore, as the ferns and Equiseta. Cf.Heterosporic.
Was, should be, or would be, able, capable, or susceptible.Used as an auxiliary, in the past tense or in the conditionalpresent.
Having power to excite; tending or serving to excite;excitatory. Barrow.
The upper part, or the citadel, of a Grecian city; especially,the citadel of Athens.
Broken or strained so as to have an upward curve between theends. See Hog, v. i.

A mineral of the pyroxene group, orthorhombic incrystallization; often fibrous and massive; color grayish white orgreenish. It is a silicate of magnesia with some iron. Bronzite is aferriferous variety.
The condition or quality of being glossy; the luster orbrightness of a smooth surface. Boyle.
A natural occurrence of a useful mineral under the conditionsto invite exploitation. Raymond.
A poem of fourteen lines; a sonnet. R. H. Stoddard.
One who uses, or fights with, a sword; a swordsman; a soldier;a cutthroat. [Obs.] Shak.
A series of short, convulsive inspirations, the glottis beingsuddenly closed so that little or no air enters into the lungs.
Having the inner part cut away, or left vacant, a narrow borderbeing left at the sides, the tincture of the field being seen in thevacant space; -- said of a charge.
Any one of six metameric phenol derivatives of xylene, obtainedas crystalline substances, (CH3)2.C6H3.OH.
The bone or cartilage of the tarsus, which articulates with thefibula, and corresponds to the calcaneum in man and most mammals.
The state of being intestate, or of dying without having made avalid will. Blackstone.
The time during which there is daylight, as distinguished fromthe night.
A supposed metal, said by Phipson to be contained in commercialzinc; -- so called because certain of its compounds are darkened byexposure to light.
Want of equity or uprightness; injustice; wickedness; iniquity.[Obs.] Wyclif.
To cause to shrink or shrivel with cold; to benumb. [Prov.Eng.]
A temporary and incomplete subsidence of the force or violenceof a disease or of pain, as destinguished from intermission, in whichthe disease completely leaves the patient for a time; abatement.
An igneous rock,usually light gray in color and breaking with arough surface. It consists chiefly of orthoclase feldspar withsometimes hornblende and mica.
A glazed earthen pot or vessel, used by druggists andapothecaries for containing medicines, etc.
A large toadfish the Southern United States and the Gulf ofMexico (Batrachus tau, var. pardus).
An officer who presides over the academic senate of a Germanuniversity. Heyse.
To adjust or settle again; to put in a different order orrelation; to rearrange.
That part of geology which treats of the materials of theearth's structure, and its general exterior and interiorconstitution.
A decomposed granite, forming a mass of gravel, as in tin lodesin Cornwall.
Having great tension, or exaggerated action. Dunglison.
The act or art of taking off the top soil of land before anexcavation or embankment is begun.
A permanent colony of cells or plastids which may remainisolated, like Rotifer, or may multiply by gemmation to form higheraggregates, termed zoides. Perrier.
Lit., my lady; hence (as used on the Continent), an Englishnoblewoman or gentlewoman.
Tabular parenchyma, a form of cellular tissue in which thecells are broad and flat, as in some kinds of epidermis.
To spend time in trifling employments, or to attend to usefulsubjects in an indifferent or superficial manner; to dawdle.
A beautiful North American butterfly (Basilarchia, orLimenitis, astyanax). Its wings are nearly black with red and bluespots and blotches. Called also red-spotted purple.
Having the shape or appearance of a julus or catkin.
A grocer; -- formerly so called because he sold pepper. [Obs.]
A white crystalline compound of piperidine and piperic acid. Itis obtained from the black pepper (Piper nigrum) and other species.
A slip from a plant; a scion; a cutting. [R.] Holished.
An extensive plain with or without vegetation. [SpanishAmerica]
A division of swimming birds which includes the grebes, divers,auks, etc., in which the legs are placed far back.

A process of extracting perfumes by exposing absorbents, asfixed oils or fats, to the exhalations of the flowers. It is used forplants whose volatile oils are too delicate to be separated bydistillation.

A picture (as of a slice of wood) obtained by first wetting theobject slightly with hydrochloric or dilute sulphuric acid, thentaking an impression with a press, and next strongly heating thisimpression.
Of or pertaining to phlogiston, or to belief in its existence.
Self-fertilization, the fertilizing pollen being derived fromthe same blossom as the pistil acted upon.
Any long-legged bird that wades in the water in search of food,especially any species of limicoline or grallatorial birds; -- calledalso wading bird. See Illust. g, under Aves.
A tool for lifting loose sand from the mold; also, acontrivance attached to a cope, to hold the sand together when thecope is lifted.
A small kind of onion (Allium Ascalonicum) growing in clusters,and ready for gathering in spring; a scallion, or eschalot.
To stand on the price or conditions of, so as to lose a sale;to lose by an extravagant price or hard conditions. [Obs.]What madman would o'erstand his market twice Dryden.
A small isolated mass of ore, as distinguished from acontinuous vein. Page.
A room occupied as a messroom by the commissioned officers of awar vessel. See Gunroom. Totten.
One who, or that which, sets type; a compositor; a machine forsetting type.
The inner, or preaxial, and usually the larger, of the twobones of the leg or hind limb below the knee.
Of or pertaining to Geneva, in Switzerland; Genevan.-- n. sing. & pl.
Having power to transmit light; transparent; diaphanous.
The amphitheater of Vespasian in Rome. [Also written Coliseum.]
Small or portable articles for dress, furniture, or use; goods;luggage; things. [Colloq.]
One who exchanges; one who practices exchange. Matt.
Suppressed or concealed mirth. [Obs.] The Coronation.
To cast about; to consider; to ponder. [Obs.] Sir T. Malory.
A cloth for carrying bread, so as not to touch it with thehands. [Obs.]
The name given to one the cultivated Dravidian languages,closely related to the Tamil. Yule.
A pale green mineral occurring in crystalline aggregates havinga botryoidal or mammillary structure, and rarely in distinctcrystals. It is a hydrous silicate of alumina and lime.
An instrument of eight strings; a system of eight tones. [Alsowritten octochord.]
A mode of opening the game, in which a pawn is sacrificed togain an attacking position.
To restore after hunger or fatique; to refresh. [Archaic] SirT. Browne.
To grow turgid as by effusion of liquid in the cellular tissue;to puff out; to swell. Arbuthnot.
Exposing linen to the sun, on the grass, in the process ofbleaching.
A feasting or feast; banquet. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
The science which treats of the properties of the air, and ofthe part it plays in nature. Craig.
One of a class of plants, so called by Lindley, because theovules are fertilized by direct contact of the pollen. Same asGymnosperm.
One of the spaces between the septa in the Anthozoa.
A tetrahexahedron; -- so called because it is a common form offluorite.
A count or earl who presided in the domestic court, and had thesuperintendence, of a royal household in Germany.
The opening from the pharynx into the larynx or into thetrachea. See Larynx.
A piece of hard wood loaded at one end with lead, and used tostrike the fleam into the vein. Youatt.
An instrument in which are combined the characteristic tones ofthe organ and various other instruments. [R.]

A mineral occurring in transparent crystals, usually of awhite, sometimes of a reddish gray, or lemon-yellow, color; nativesodium nitrate. It is used in making nitric acid and for manure.Called also soda niter.
Forked or branched like a pair of forceps; constructed so as toopen and shut like a pair of forceps. Sir T. Browne.
Of or pertaining to Augeus, king of Elis, whose stablecontained 3000 oxen, and had not been cleaned for 30 years. Herculescleansed it in a single day.
An ornamental casing for a flowerpot, of porcelain, metal,paper, etc.
An instrument like a guitar. "Harps, lutes, and giternes."Chaucer.

Composition in mutually related, equally important parts whichshare the melody among them; contrapuntal composition; -- opposed tohomophony, in which the melody is given to one part only, the othersfilling out the harmony. See Counterpoint.
An intermediate depot or station between one commercial city orcountry and another. Mitford.
The act of producing excitement (stimulation); also, theexcitement produced.
The man who rows the aftermost oar, and whose stroke is to befollowed by the rest. Totten.
A South American armadillo (Dasypus sexcinctus). Called alsosixbanded armadillo.
A tough, horny animal substance entering into the compositionof the skeleton of sponges, and other invertebrates; -- called alsokeratode.
A long-tailed monkey (Semnopithecus schislaceus), from themountainous districts of India.
A liquid hydrocarbon, C7H10, of the valylene series.
A group of chelonians which comprises many species of fresh-water tortoises and terrapins.
A composition adapted to sacred words in the elaboratepolyphonic church style; an anthem.
Having a space equal to two diameters or four modules betweentwo columns; -- said of a portico or building. See Intercolumniation.-- n.
Combined with fluorine; subjected to the action of fluoride.[R.]
Lead chromate occuring in crystals of a bright hyacinth redcolor; -- called also red lead ore.
A treatise on demons; a supposititious science which treats ofdemons and their manifestations. Sir W. Scott.
Tending to calm, moderate, or tranquilize; specifically (Med.),allaying irritability and irritation; assuaging pain.
Sculptured ornaments, used in classical architecture,representing rams' heads or skulls.
A group of transparent, free-swimming Annelida, having setaeonly in the cephalic appendages.
A compound of antimonious acid and a base or basic radical.

A name given to several different fishes, in allusion to theirslippery coating of mucus, as the Stromateus triacanthus of theAtlantic coast, the Epinephelus punctatus of the southern coast, therock eel, and the kelpfish of New Zealand.
One of the first three Gospels of the New Testament. SeeSynoptist.

Groups of small shining spots on the surface of the sun whichare brighter than the other parts of the photosphere. They aregenerally seen in the neighborhood of the dark spots, and aresupposed to be elevated portions of the photosphere. Newcomb.
The modern, or true, Crustacea, as distinguished from theMerostomata.
The act of asperating; a making or becoming rough. Bailey.
To stretch; to extend; hence, to lay out, as a dead body. [Obs.or Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
Intended for voices of one kind only, either all male or allfemale; -- opposed to mixed. [R.]
The process of straining; the matter strained; a strainer. [R.]
One who is garnished; a person upon whom garnishment has beenserved in a suit by a creditor against a debtor, such person holdingproperty belonging to the debtor, or owing him money.
The rootstock or decumbent stem by which a hydroid is attachedto other objects. See Illust. under Hydroidea.
An instrument used by masons and others to trace and formangles.
To poke or stir up a fire; hence, to tend the fires offurnaces, steamers, etc.
An engine somewhat resembling a massive crossbow, used by theancient Greeks and Romans for throwing stones, arrows, spears, etc.

A small landlocked variety of the Atlantic salmon (Salmo salarounaniche) of Lake St. John, Canada, and neighboring waters, notedfor its vigor and activity, and habit of leaping from the water whenhooked.
The state or condition of being an albino: abinoism;leucopathy.
One who is deficient in understanding; a witless person. Shak.
The dried hemp plant, used in India for smoking. It isextremely narcotic and intoxicating.
One who commits a trespass; as:(a) (Law) One who enters upon another's land, or violates his rights.(b) A transgressor of the moral law; an offender; a sinner.
One who swerves from and is unfaithful to the marriage vow.[Poetic] Shak.
Of or pertaining to Laodicea, a city in Phrygia Major; like theChristians of Laodicea; lukewarm in religion. Rev. iii. 14-16.
Antidotal.-- n. Antidote; also, a book of antidotes.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling the style of, Richard Wagner,the German musical composer.

A tenure by which land descended from the father to all hissons in equal portions, and the land of a brother, dying withoutissue, descended equally to his brothers. It still prevails in thecounty of Kent. Cowell.
A wind from the north; esp., a strong and cold north wind inTexas and the vicinity of the Gulf of Mexico.
An instrument for measuring the rain that falls; a rain gauge.
Act of leaning upon something; incumbency. [Obs.] Derham.
Containing, or derived from, tartar; combined with tartaricacid.
State of being within; interiority. [R.] H. Brooke.
Of or pertaining to Trophonius, his architecture, or his caveand oracle.
A kind of thin translucent paper with a glossy finish.
The unlawful beating of another. It includes every willful,angry and violent, or negligent touching of another's person orclothes, or anything attached to his person or held by him.

A province, prefecture, or territory, under the jurisdiction ofan eparch or governor; esp., in modern Greece, one of the largersubdivisions of a monarchy or province of the kingdom; in Russia, adiocese or archdiocese.
A wind instrument nearly identical with the bagpipe. Drayton.
A easy and concise method of applying the rules of arithmeticto questions which occur in trade and business.
A worker in cordwain, or cordovan leather; a shoemaker.[Archaic.]
An unexpected subsequent event; something disagreeablehappening after an affair is supposed to be at an end. Spenser.

A form of the possessive case of the pronoun thou, nowsuperseded in common discourse by your, the possessive of you, butmaintaining a place in solemn discourse, in poetry, and in the usuallanguage of the Friends, or Quakers.
Pertaining to, or derived from, the locust; -- formerly used todesignate a supposed acid.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid obtained bythe oxidation of narcotine.
A nocturnal bird of South America and Trinidad (SteatornisCaripensis, or S. steatornis); -- called also oilbird.
The throwing overboard of goods from necessity, in order tolighten a vessel in danger of wreck.
To check (an adversary's king) in such a manner that escape inimpossible; to defeat (an adversary) by putting his king in checkfrom which there is no escape.
The husks and other refuse of rice mills, used to adulterateoil cake, or linseed cake.
Of or pertaining to the Pontus, Euxine, or Black Sea.
An alloy of copper, invented by the Japanese, having a verydark blue color approaching black.
A mucilage obtained from, or containing, gun tragacanth.

Pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid which isobtained from several varieties of lichen (Lecanora, Roccella, etc.),as a white, crystalline substance, and is called also orsellic, ordiorsellinic acid, lecanorin, etc.
A maker of gowns, or similar garments; a mantuamaker.
A toga of purple, or ornamented with purple horizontal stripes.-- worn by kings, consuls, and augurs. Dr. W. Smith.
Having the ovule inverted at an early period in itsdevelopment, so that the chalaza is as the apparent apex; -- opposedto orthotropous. Gray.
A scaly parasitic plant (Conopholis Americana) found in oakwoods in the United States; -- called also cancer root.
A term at omber, signifying that the game is won. Pope.
To interpose; to insert or place between. [R.] Cudworth.
Having the flesh attached closely to the stone, as in somekinds of peaches.-- n.
Condition of being a mulier; position of one born in lawfulwedlock.
To lie or sail along the coast or side of; to accost. [Obs.]Whether high towering or accosting low. Spenser.
The neck; also, the necklike portion of any part, as of thewomb. See Illust. of Bird.
The position, distribution, and order of persons and propertieson the stage of a theater, as determined by the stage manager inrehearsal.
Having all the flowers alike; -- said of such composite plantsas Eupatorium, and the thistels.
Navigation along the coast; the details of coast pilotage.
Having lost the power of development, and become rotten, aseggs; putrid. Hence: Unfruitful or confused, as brains; muddled.Dryden.
A large tree of the genus Swietenia (S. Mahogoni), found intropical America.
A small stick or rod used as a spike in thatching; a splinter.[Prov. Eng.] Grose.
Making a clang, or a ringing metallic sound. [Obs.]
Several times compounded or divided, as a leaf or stem;decomposite.
A hawker; specifically, one who travels about selling anddistributing religious tracts and books.
A mineral of a dark brown color, generally with a fibrous,massive structure. It is a fluophosphate of iron and manganese.
The property of two curves, or surfaces, which meet, and at thepoint of meeting have a common direction.
Incapable of being moved; immovable; fixed; stable. Prof.Shedd.
Enough to fill a sheet; as much as a sheet can hold.
A genus of cruciferous plants, containing the lady's-smock,cuckooflower, bitter cress, meadow cress, etc.
A room before, or forming an entrance to, another; a waitingroom.
Having the power of giving life or spirit. Johnson.
Thrusting with the foil; fencing with the point, asdistinguished from broadsword play. [Obs.] Marston.
A treatise on sacred things; especially, the science whichtreats of the ancient writings and inscriptions of the Egyptians, ora treatise on that science.
The homology of metameres. See Metamere. Gegenbaur.
To deprive of the position or office a vicar. [R.] Strype.
The act or process of salivating; an excessive secretion ofsaliva, often accompained with soreness of the mouth and gums;ptyalism.
To cause to cease to be pagan; to divest of pagan character.[R.] Cudworth.

A white, crystalline sugar, C6H12O6, isomeric with dextrose,obtained by the decomposition of milk sugar, and also from certaingums. When oxidized it forms mucic acid. Called also lactose (thoughit is not lactose proper).
Resembling or becoming a wizard; wizardlike; weird.
One who has charge of cattle, horses, etc.; a herdsman.[Southwestern U. S.]
A peculiar tackle, formed of two or more blocks, or pulleys,the weight being suspended of a hook block in the bight of therunning part.
To rove or wander stealthily, esp. for prey, as a wild beast;hence, to prey; to plunder.
A member of a secret association (esp. in Russia), which isdevoted to the destruction of the present political, religious, andsocial institutions.
Consisting of a network of veins, without intermediateparenchyma, as the leaves of certain plant; latticelike.
Act, or state, of being twice married; deuterogamy. [R.]
Rubbish or refuse consisting of broken rock containing littleor no ore. Weale.
A gummy or gelatinous substance produced in certain plants bythe action of water on the cell wall, as in the seeds of quinces, offlax, etc.
Lowness in price, considering the usual price, or real value.
A part of a man's beard on the chin or lower lip which isallowed to grow, and trimmed so as to resemble the beard of a goat.
One eminently studious of symmetry of parts. Sir H. Wotton.
A genus of coarse biennial herbs (Lappa), bearing small burswhich adhere tenaciously to clothes, or to the fur or wool ofanimals.
An additional piece of canvas laced to the foot of a jib orforesail in moderate winds. Hakluyt.
A concave molding; -- used chiefly in classical architecture.See Illust. of Calumn.
The triad, or trinity, of Hindoo gods, consisting of Brahma,the Creator, Vishnu, the Preserver, and Siva, the Destroyer. [Spelledalso Trimurtti.]
A single particle of ice falling from a cloud; a frozenraindrop; a pellet of hail.
The art or process of making barometrical measurements.
To fix by the root; to fix fast; to implant deep. Shak.
To deprive of the qualities of a woman; to unsex. [R.] R.Browning.
Government by a single person; undivided rule. Sydney Smith.
The region which is included within the outlet of the pelvis,and is traversed by the urinogenital canal and the rectum.
A substance allied to alkali albumin and to mucin, present insemen, to which it is said to impart the mucilaginous character.
One who studies by night; also, one who produces lucubrations.
The quality or state of being touchy peevishness; irritability;irascibility.
The substance from which attraction spheres develop in mitoticcell division, and of which they consist.
A red, gummy, coloring matter, extracted from the colorlessjuice of the Otaheite chestnut (Inocarpus edulis).
The wooden boarding used in supporting the roofs and walls ofcoal mines. See Brattice.
A harbor or port at some distance from the chief town or seatof trade. Macaulay.
Informal talk or discussion, as about literary matters; lightconversation; chat.
One who, or that which, connects; as:(a) A flexible tube for connecting the ends of glass tubes inpneumatic experiments.(b) A device for holding two parts of an electrical conductor incontact.

A flat, narrow molding, used chiefly to separate the parts ormembers of compartments or panels from one another, or doubled,turned, and interlaced so as to form knots, frets, or otherornaments. See Illust. (12) of Column.
One who labors with another; an associate in labor.
To salt or pickle, as fish, and then preserve in oil orvinegar; to prepare by the use of marinade.
A painful discharge of urine, drop by drop, produced byspasmodic muscular contraction.
A layer or mass of cellular tissue, especially that part of thethallus of certain fungi which incloses the perithecia.
To signal by means of a flag waved from side to side accordingto a code adopted for the purpose. [Colloq.]
In a half-raised position, as if about to spring on prey.
A strong shutter, made to fit open ports and keep out water ina storm.
Derived from the name of a country, and designating aninhabitant of the country; gentile; -- said of a noun.-- n.
A sweet-scented herb; ambrosia. See Ambrosia, 3. Turner.
To meet. [Obs.]Our very loving sister, well bemet. Shak.
The iron lap used by diamond polishers in finishing the facetsof the gem.
A carnivorous animal of the Weasel family (Mustela Canadensis);the pekan; the "black cat."
The doctrine that matter possesses a species of life andsensation, or that matter and life are inseparable. [R.] Cudworth.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, plants of the genus Musa.
That part of optics which explants the properties and phenomenaof reflected light, and particularly that which is reflected frommirrors or polished bodies; --- formerly caled anacamptics.
Pertaining to a second marriage, that is, one after the deathof the first wife or the first husband.
A figure oMust I give way and room to your rash choler Shall I be frighted whena madman stares Shak.
One who seeks for things which gratify merely himself; aselfish person; a selfist. [R.] Whitlock.
A whitish mineral occurring in radiated or fibrous crystallinemasses. It is a hydrous silicate of lime and soda.
The channel in which tailings, suspended in water, areconducted away.
A sharing among brothers, or brothers' kin. [Obs.] Crabb.
The action of the vital principle, or of the instinctivepowers, toward the preservation of the individual; also, the vitalprinciple. [In this sense, written also autocrasy.] Dunglison.
A decorative cabinet, of a form originating in Spain, the bodybeing rectangular and supported on legs or an ornamental frameworkand the front opening downwards on hinges to serve as a writing desk.
Of or pertaining to the west; toward the west; coming from thewest; western.
A shallow iron pan to hold glass ware while being annealed.
One of two oval bodies hanging from the interior walls of thebody in the Acanthocephala.
A white, crystalline substance obtained as an anhydride ofalanine, and regarded as an imido derivative of lactic acid.
The state of being doubtful; a doubtful statement or thing.[R.]Men often swallow falsities for truths, dubiosities for certainties,possibilities for feasibilities. Sir T. Browne.
The state or quality of being icy or very cold; frigidity.
A warrior of great force and courage. [R. & Obs.] 1 Chron. xi.12.
A color mixed of white, and red, or a gray violet. [Writtenalso gredaline, grizelin.] Dryden.
A bolt used by shipwrights, to bend and secure the planksagainst the timbers till they are fastened by bolts, spikes, ortreenails; -- not to be confounded with ringbolt.
The sakti or wife of Brahma; the Hindoo goddess of learning,music, and poetry.
A kind of pack saddle used in the American military service andamong the Spanish Americans. It is made of leather stuffed with hay,moss, or the like.
Produced increased vital action in the organism, or in any ofits parts.
An instrument for ascertaining the weight or density of air andgases.
Capable of being deduced; derivable. [R.] Bp. Warburton.
Bent downward or aside; (Bot.) bending downward in a curve;declined.
Having the effect of loosening or opening the intestines, andrelieving from constipation; -- opposed to astringent.-- n. (Med.)
A small species of titmouse, with a black head; the coletit.
The husk covering an ear of Indian corn. [Colloq. U.S.]
Supplying amendment; corrective; emendatory. Bancroft.
Growing white, or assuming a color approaching to white.
