Tenderness or stiffness in the foot of a horse, which causeshim to move in a hobbling manner.
A liquid measure formerly used in France and Great Britain,varying from half a pint to a wine quart.
The sum or number to be subtracted, or taken from another.
A suborder of Hemiptera, in which both pairs of wings aresimilar in texture, and do not overlap when folded, as in the cicada.See Hemiptera.
Being without veins or nerves, as the leaves of certain plants.
To befall, as ill luck; to happen to unluckily. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who passes his life on land; -- so called among seamen incontempt or ridicule.

To send or address (by bill of lading or otherwise) to an agentor correspondent in another place, to be cared for or sold, or forthe use of such correspondent; as, to cosign a cargo or a ship; toset apart.
One who, or that which, preys; a plunderer; a waster; adevourer. Hooker.
That which is given under the doctrine of administering apatient's own virus.
The passage of the corpuscular elements of the blood from theblood vessels into the surrounding tissues, without rupture of thewalls of the blood vessels.
To affict with pestilence; to infect, as with plague. [Obs.]
The insertion of a scion in a stock; ingraftment. Ray.
A room containing a bar or counter at which liquors are sold.
The rule or practices of bosses, esp. political bosses. [Slang,U. S.]
A plant of the Parsley family (Apium graveolens), of which theblanched leafstalks are used as a salad.
A hybrid between the tangerine orange and the grapefruit, orpomelo; also, the fruit.
The quality or state of succession in a series; sequence. H.Spenser.
The operation or work of cutting grass and curing it for hay.
A mineral of a black color, submetallic luster, and highspecific specific gravity. It is a niobate (or columbate) of iron andmanganese, containing tantalate of iron; -- first found in NewEngland.
An annual composite plant (Carthamus tinctorius), the flowersof which are used as a dyestuff and in making rouge; bastard, orfalse, saffron.
To plow, or fallow, a second time (land that has been oncefallowed).
Serving for example or pattern; exemplary. [Obs.] Hooker.
Protected by an external coat, or covering, of scales orplates.
The act of abstaining; a holding aloof. Jer. Taylor.
The European mountain finch (Fringilla montifringilla); --called also bramble finch and bramble.
To open, as the eyes of a hawk that have been seeled; hence, togive light to; to enlighten. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A yard or storage place for all sorts of naval stores andtimber for shipbuilding.
a box, or vase with a perforated cover to emit perfumes.
A kind of embryo of certain hydroids (Tubularia), having astellate form.
The state or quality of being literal. Sir T. Browne.
The hypothetical radical, C5H11, of pentane and certain of itsderivatives. Same as Amyl.
A fatlike substance in certain marine animals, to which theyowe their phosphorescent properties.
Want or difference of belief; disbelief. [Obs.] Bp. Reynolds.
The larva or young of the mussel, formerly thought to be aparasite upon the parent's gills.
The first coating of color, size, or the like, laid on canvas,or on a building, or other surface.
An aspect of the planets when they are distant from each otherby twice the fifth part of a great circle -- that is, twice 72degrees.
One who confers a benefit; -- also, one who receives a benefit.
An Algonquin tribe of Indians, inhabiting a large part ofBritish America east of the Rocky Mountains and south of Hudson'sBay.
Like a rasp, or the sound made by a rasp; grating. R. D.Blackmore.
A chemical process involving the addition of the elements ofwater.

An equilateral parallelogram, or quadrilateral figure whosesides are equal and the opposite sides parallel. The angles may beunequal, two being obtuse and two acute, as in the cut, or the anglesmay be equal, in which case it is usually called a square.
One of the single eyes forming the compound eyes ofcrustaceans, insects, and other invertebrates.
A wind instrument of brass, containing a reed, and partaking ofthe qualities both of a brass instrument and of a clarinet.
A broad-leaved species of garlic (Allium ursinum), common inEuropean gardens; -- called also buckram.
To lament in an elegy; to celebrate in elegiac verse; tobewail. Carlyle.
The memorandum or certificate at the end of an asffidavit, or abill or answer in chancery, showing when, before whom, and (inEnglish practice), where, it was sworn or affirmed. Wharton. Bouvier.
The hypothetical homogeneous cosmic material of the originaluniverse, supposed to have been differentiated into what arerecognized as distinct chemical elements.
Relating to a dialect; dialectical; as, a dialectical variant.
An instrument for ascertaining the amount of ozone in theatmosphere, or in any gaseous mixture. Faraday.
The color or incrustation which age gives to works of art;especially, the green rust which covers ancient bronzes, coins, andmedals. Fairholt.
In a clever manner.Never was man so clever absurd. C. Smart.
Having the power of seeing visions; inspired; also, seen invisions. [R.] Shelley.
A figure in which several things are mentioned that seem tomake against the argument, or in favor of the opposite side, each ofthem being refuted in order.
a nontoxic base, C5H14N2, found in the putrescent matters offlesh, fish, decaying cheese, etc.
To have the effect of a Gorgon upon; to turn into stone; topetrify. [R.]

One of a sect or party among the Jews, noted for a strict andformal observance of rites and ceremonies and of the traditions ofthe elders, and whose pretensions to superior sanctity led them toseparate themselves from the other Jews.
Divination by inspection of entrails of victims offered insacrifice.
The state or condition of being faulted; the process by which afault is produced.
A white, crystalline, nitrogenous substance, C2O2N3H5, formedby heating urea. It is intermediate between urea and cyanuric acid.
A large South African tree snake (Bucephalus Capensis).Although considered venomous by natives, it has no poison fangs.
The skin which a deer frays from his horns. B. Jonson.
Master; sir; -- a title of a Turkish state official and man oflearning, especially one learned in the law.
A slut; a vagabond wench. Same as Drossel. [Obs.] Hudibras.
Want of urbanity or courtesy; unpolished manners or deportment;inurbaneness; rudeness. Bp. Hall.
To thicken or bring to greater consistence, as fluids byevaporation.
An old game of ball played with a trap. See 4th Trap, 4.
A hymn with no regular meter, sometimes introduced into theMass. See Sequence.
One who dispends or expends; a steward. [Obs.] Wyclif (1 Cor.iv. 1).
Pertaining to, or possessing the properties of, a species ofcaustic curves formed by refraction. See Caustic surface, underCaustic.
An old crafty fox or beguiler -- a word of contempt. [Obs.]Cotgrave.
A genus of plants containing some of the most popular ofcultivated flowers, including the pink, carnation, and Sweet William.
An extinct genus of large, fossil, bivalve shells,allied to themussels. The genus is characteristic of the Cretaceous period.
The jurisdiction of a mill, or that extent of ground astrictedto it, the tenants of which are bound to bring their grain thither tobe ground.
A bout, or turn, as at fencing; a thrust; a hit; a veney.[Obs.] Fuller.
Direct fertilization in plants, as when the pollen fertilizingthe ovules comes from the stamens of the same blossom; -- opposed toheterogamy.
The Japanese warrior gentry or middle class, formerly calledsamurai; also, any member of this class.
A genus of American perrenial herbs growing in bogs; theAmerican pitcher plant.
The quality or state of being taxable; taxableness.
A plaster or poultice composed principally of powdered mustardseed, or containing the volatile oil of mustard seed. It is apowerful irritant.
A nonnucleated mass of protoplasm, the supposed simplest formof independent life differing from the amoeba, in which nuclei arepresent.
The three-beared rocking, or whistlefish. [Prov. Eng.]
In an orthodox manner; with soundness of faith. Sir W.Hamilton.
A floral ornament, common in Greek and other ancientarchitecture; -- often called the honeysuckle ornament.
A composite plant (Aster Tripolium) growing along the seacoastof Europe.
Relatingto, emanating from or resembling, the poet Dante or hiswritings.
Powdered aromatic herbs, sometimes made into little balls andstrung together. [Obs.]
To order ill; to manage erroneously; to conduct badly. [Obs.]Shak.
To deprive of worship or due honor; to dishonor. [Obs.] Wyclif.
Genteel irony; a polite and ingenious manner of deridinganother.
To madden; to rave. [Obs.]An infatuating and delirating spirit in it. Holland.
A four-wheeled pleasure carriage, (commonly two-seated)somewhat like a phaeton, but having a straight bottom.
Ignorant, unlearned; belonging to the laity. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A substance employed as a hypnotic, produced by the union ofmercaptan and acetone.
To rate too low; to rate below the value; to undervalue. Burke.
The butting or boundary of land, particularly at the end; aheadland. Spelman.
An agreement between two or more persons to defraud a person ofhis rights, by the forms of law, or to obtain an object forbidden bylaw. Bouvier. Abbott.
A white crystalline neutral substance (C2O2(NH2)2) obtained bytreating ethyl oxalate with ammonia. It is the acid amide of oxalicacid. Formerly called also oxalamide.
A crystalline vari ety of fruit sugar obtained from dambonite.
The art or practice of measuring gases; also, the science whichtreats of the nature and properties of these elastic fluids. Coxe.
The division of Mollusca which includes the land snails andslugs.
A yellow crystalline substance, C6Cl4.O2, regarded as aderivative of quinone, obtained by the action of chlorine on certainbenzene derivatives, as aniline.
A soft crayon for use in stump drawing or in shading with thestump.
Having much heat in the constitution and little serum in theblood. [Obs.] Hence: Atrabilious; sallow; gloomy.
A table stove or small furnace, usually a cylindrical box ofsheet iron, with a grate at the bottem, and an open top.
An accumulation of earth and stones carried forward anddeposited by a glacier. Lyell.
An instrument for measuring thickness, as of the glass of amirror, or of paper; a pachymeter.
That part of medicine which treats of regimen for old people.
Belonging to, or like, the family of plants of which theprickly pear is a common example.
The doctrine of the Cynics; the quality of being cynical; themental state, opnions, or conduct, of a cynic; morose andcontemptuous views and opinions.
A youth; especially, a student in a german university.
Mortar or the like, laid between the joists under the boards ofa floor, or within a partition, to deaden sound; -- in the UnitedStates usually called deafening.
An amorphous, gummy carbohydrate, found in Gelidium, agar-agar,and other seaweeds.
Lack of sympathy; want of passion; apathy. [R.]Many discrepancies and some dispathies between us. Southey.
The point on the side of the skull where the lambdoid, parieto-mastoid and occipito-mastoid sutures.
Having much beef; of the nature of beef; resembling beef;fleshy.
A nitrogenous base, CO.(NH.C3H5)2, related to urea, extractedfrom mustard oil, and also produced artifically, as a whitecrystalline substance; -- called also diallyl urea.
A paste prepared from tobacco, and smoked in hookahs in WesternIndia.
The powder of aloes with canella, formerly officinal, employedas a cathartic.
An unnatural, violent, and unvoluntary contraction of themuscular parts of an animal body.
One of the filaments on the inner surface of the gastric cavityof certain jellyfishes.
A sudden breaking off; a violent separation of bodies.Woodward.
A kind of small reed organ; -- a portable form of theseraphine.
The science of worship; history, doctrine, and interpretationof liturgies.
A native of Sind, India, esp. one of the native Hindoo stock.
One who makes a business of lending money on the security ofpersonal property pledged or deposited in his keeping.
[Fraise a kind of defense; also Friz.) A kind of small ruffle.Halliwell.
Up, or ahead, as many holes as remain to be played; -- said ofa player or side.
One who favors a form of government in which the unintelligentpopulace rules without restraint. Bayne.
A colloquial or humorous appelation for a negro; sometimes, theoffspring of a black person and a mulatto; a zambo.
A quantity of oats paid by a tenant to a landlord in lieu ofrent. Jacob.
A believer in the theory of vitalism; -- opposed to physicist.
Lit., an eggshell; hence, an eggshell filled with confetti tobe thrown during balls, carnivals, etc. [Western U. S.]
A small dipterous fly of the genus Oscinis, esp. O. vastator,injurious to grain in Europe, and O. Trifole, injurious to clover inAmerica.
The quality or state of being stable, or firmly established;stability.
A bowman, one skilled in the use of the bow and arrow.
A support or column on which stamens are raised. Gray.

A right formerly belonging to an archbishop to select any onedignity or benefice in the gift of a suffragan bishop consecrated orconfirmed by him, for bestowal by himself when next vacant; --annulled by Parliament in 1845.
As much as a wagon will hold; enough to fill a wagon; awagonload.
The process of becoming solid by cooling; a cooling andsolidifying.
A defensive garment formerly in use for the body, made of clothstuffed and quilted.
The act of opening an academical disputation; the propositionof objections to a tenet, as an exercise for a degree. [Eng.] Todd.
A double-edged, sharp-pointed dismembering knife. [Spelt alsocatlin.] Crobb.
The meridian, or middle line of the heavens; the point of theecliptic on the meridian.
A venomous snake of India, of the genus Bungarus, allied to thecobras, but without a hood.
A bladderlike vessel; a membranous cavity; a cyst; a cell.Specifically: --(a) (Bot.)
One of a kind of light cavalry of Tartaric origin, firstintroduced into European armies in Poland. They are armed withlances, pistols, and sabers, and are employed chiefly as skirmishers.
A mode of speech peculiar to the French; a French idiom; also,in general, a French mode or custom.
A yard, place, or inclosure where ships are built or repaired.
Of or pertaining to the malleolus; in the region of themalleoli of the ankle joint.
The stomach of a calf, prepared for rennet. Halliwell.
The state or quality of being ordinal. [R.] Latham.
An old game in England, played by throwing pieces of wood at astake set in the ground. [Obs.] Shak.
Incombustible; capable of sustaining a strong heat withoutalteration of form or properties.

One who forms theories; one given to theory and speculation; aspeculatist. Cowper.The greatest theoretists have given the preference to such agovernment as that which obtains in this kingdom. Addison.
To perplex with scruples; to regard with scruples. [Obs.] Bp.Montagu.
To nerve again; to give new vigor to; to reinvigorate.
Serving to initiate; inceptive; initiatory; introductory;preliminary.
Sledge runners on which a skip is dragged in a mine.
The operation of putting down or displacing the opaque lens incataract.
A coheir, or one of two or more persons to whom an estate ofinheritance descends jointly, and by whom it is held as one estate.
A white amorphous substance obtained as a polymericmodification of acrolein.
A third person, who is to decide a controversy or questionsubmitted to arbitrators in case of their disagreement. Blackstone.
The germinal membrane in an ovum, from which the embryo isdeveloped.
A royal charter confirming to a subject all his possessions.[Obs.] Holinshed.
Lead protoxide, PbO, obtained as a yellow amorphous powder, thefused and crystalline form of which is called litharge; lead ocher.It is used as a pigment.
Reaping peas, beans, wheat, etc., with a chopping stroke.[Eng.]
The fillet, listel, or band next to the apophyge at theextremity of the shaft of a column.
Having the qualities or manners of a ruffian; ruffianly.
Goods which, after shipwreck, appear floating on the waves, orsea.
A straight wind without apparent cyclonic tendency, usuallyaccompanied with rain and often destructive, common in the prairieregions of the United States.
Pertaining to, or involving, taxonomy, or the laws andprinciples of classification; classificatory.
A form of voltaic, or galvanic, battery suitable for useelectrotyping. G. Francis.

; sing. Choctaw. (Ethnol.) A tribe of North American Indians(Southern Appalachian), in early times noted for their pursuit ofagriculture, and for living at peace with the white settlers. Theyare now one of the civilized tribes of the Indian Territory.
Of or pertaining to Lima, or to the inhabitants of Lima, inPeru.-- n.
One who, or that which, backs; especially one who backs aperson or thing in a contest.
Of, or relating to, Confucius, the great Chinese philosopherand teacher. -- n.
One who, or that which, preludes; one who plays a prelude.Mason.

An upright pivot pin; as:(a) The pivot pin of a hinge.(b) A hook or pin on which a rudder hangs and turns.(c) A pivot about which the chassis swings, in some kinds of guncarriages.(d) A kingbolt of a wagon.
The spirit of religious revivals; the methods of revivalists.
The act of induing, or state of being indued; investment;endowment. W. Montagu.
A stand, as for casks or vats in a brewery, or for potterywhile drying.
Of or pertaining to the day before, or yesterday. [R.]Thackeray.
The religion of the Roman Catholic Church, comprehendingdoctrines and practices; -- generally used in an opprobrious sense.

An extinct order of Mammalia found in the South AmericanTertiary formation. The incisor teeth were long and curved andprovided with a persistent pulp. They are supposed to be related bothto the rodents and ungulates. Called also Toxodontia.
Shaped like a fern or like the parts of a fern leaf. Smart.
A warlike South African people of the Bantu stock, divided intomany tribes, subject to the English. They formerly practicedcannibalism, but have now adopted many European customs.
An instrument for indicating directly resistance in ohms.
A hawk which is of proper age and training to be carried on thehand; a hawk in its first year. Booth.
A species of musical recitation in which the words aredelivered in manner resembling that of ordinary declamation; also, apiece of music intended for such recitation; -- opposed to melisma.
A four-wheeled truck, having a certain amount of play around avertical axis, used to support in part a locomotive on a railwaytrack.
A star of the first magnitude, in the constellation PiscisAustralis, or Southern Fish.
One of a class of strongly basic substances derived fromammonia by replacement of one or more hydrogen atoms by a basic atomor radical.
Work done as a task; also, work done by the job; piecework.
A close or inclosure; the compass of a manor. Bacon.
Thin iron sheets coated with an alloy of lead and tin; -- socalled because made up of three metals.
Anterior in age to the lowest rocks which contain organicremains. Lyell.
Done, as pitching, with the hand lower than the shoulder, or,as bowling, with the hand lower than elbow.
One who nullifies or makes void; one who maintains the right tonullify a contract by one of the parties.
A shovel-like utensil for conveying away dust brushed from thefloor.
Not explicit; not clearly stated; indefinite; vague.
A name given to a numerous family of brass wind instrumentswith valves, invented by Antoine Joseph Sax (known as Adolphe Sax),of Belgium and Paris, and much used in military bands and inorchestras.
A species of fern (Lomaria borealis), growing in Europe andNorthwestern America.
The transparent part of the coat of the eyeball which coversthe iris and pupil and admits light to the interior. See Eye.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from molassesor glucose, and probably identical with saccharic acid. SeeSaccharic.
Purchased; not obtained or produced at home. Coleridge.
The act or state of becoming green through the formation ofchlorophyll.
A composition in verse, in which all the lines end with thesame rhyme.
The principles or practices of the Whigs; Whiggism.
To sell again; to sell what has been bought or sold; to retail.
Furnishing or giving two colors; -- said of defective vision,in which all the compound colors are resolvable into two elementsinstead of three. Sir J. Herschel.
A light, close carriage, with seats inside for two or four, andthe fore wheels so arranged as to turn short.
Having two atoms or equivalents of calcium to the molecule.
A figure which omits the connective; as, I came, I saw, Iconquered. It stands opposed to polysyndeton.
One who travels a circuit, as a circuit judge. [R.] R.Whitlock.
Wood coal, or charcoal; -- so called in distinction frommineral coal.
A scombroid food fish of Maderia (Cybium Commersonii).
The union of two men in the same office; or the office,dignity, or government of two men thus associated, as in ancientRome.
Without a distinct head; -- a term applied to bivalve mollusks.
One who marries a second time; a deuterogamist. Hammond.
One of the teeth in front of the canines in either jaw; anincisive tooth. See Tooth.
Like a quack; boasting; characterized by quackery. Burke.
In an improper manner; not properly; unsuitably; unbecomingly.
A kind of rubblework. In the United States, any rubblework ofthin and small stones.
One who takes part in a folkmote, or local court. [Obs.]Milton.
To cause to clonk, or make small, sharp, quick sounds.
A sac which surrounds the generative bodies in the gonophore ofa hydroid.
A contribution toward the building or repairing of castles orwalls for the defense of a city or town.
Any bird of the genus Turnix. Various species inhabit Asia,Africa, and Australia.
The act or business of making mines or of working them.
One of the tannic acids, extracted from catechu as a white,crystaline substance; -- called also catechuic acid, and catechuin.
A perfume derived from, or imitating the odor of, the flower ofthe red jasmine, a West Indian tree of the genus Plumeria.
A pictorial suggestion on a coat of arms of the name of theperson to whom it belongs. See Canting arms, under Canting.
A carving in relief, esp. one on a small scale used as a jewelfor personal adornment, or like.
Pertaining to homicide; tending to homicide; murderous.
To quicken anew; to reanimate; to give new life to. Shak.
Of a texture resembling horn; horny; hard. Sir T. Browne.
An explosive of great destructive power; -- so called from itscolor, which resembles honey.
An unsaturated hydrocarbon, C30H60, of the ethylene series,obtained from beeswax as a white, scaly, crystalline wax; -- calledalso melissene, and melissylene.
A compound radical, or unsaturated group, HO, consisting of oneatom of hydrogen and one of oxygen. It is a characteristic part ofthe hydrates, the alcohols, the oxygen acids, etc.
One who favors the humoral pathology or believes in humoralism.
A genus of American monkeys with prehensile tails, and havingthe thumb wanting or rudimentary. See Spider monkey, and Coaita.
A Sprengel explosive consisting of potassium chlorate and mono-nitrobenzene.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, hydrogen sulphide, which isregarded as an acid, especially when in solution.
An accession of land gradually washed to the shore or bank bythe flowing of water. See Accretion.
A double eight-sided pyramid, a form common with tetragonalcrystals; -- so called because this form often occurs in crystals ofzircon.
Rectified oil of turpentine, used for burning in lamps, and asa common solvent in varnishes.
A cotquean; a man who intermeddles with women's concerns.
To excrete matter through the skin; esp., to excrete fluidsthrough the pores of the skin; to sweat.
One of a breed of dogs trained to accompany carriages; theDalmatian dog.
A measure for fresh herrings, -- as many as will fill a barrel.[Scot.] H. Miller.
A bronze-yellow massive mineral with metallic luster; atelluride of gold; -- first found in Calaveras County California.
Noting the region of foothills near the base of a mountainchain.
A sauce made of small fish. It was prized by the ancients.

The act or process of measuring, at the various distances fromthe surface of a block of marble, the surface of a future piece ofstatuary; also, a process used in cutting the statue from theartist's model.
Journeying; itinerant; -- formerly applied to judges who wenton circuit and to bailiffs at large. Mozley & W.
A kind of lively dance, in 2-4 time; also, the music to thedance.
A wading bird of the genus Botaurus, allied to the herons, ofvarious species.
Of the nature of execration; imprecatory; denunciatory. C.Kingsley.-- n.
A European perennial succulent herb (Cotyledon umbilicus),having round, peltate leaves with a central depression; -- alsocalled pennywort, and kidneywort.
A genus of polypetalous herbaceous plants, including all kindsof violets.
To move in a circle; to go round; to circulate. [Obs.] J.Philips.
To emit a harsh or discordant sound. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
The edible fruit of a passion flower, especially that of theNorth American Passiflora incarnata, an oval yellowish berry as largeas a small apple.
The panel for the name, between the bands of the back of abook.
The gentlemen, or gentry, of a country, collectively. [Writtenalso squirearchy.]
Bonbons; sweetmeats; confections; also, plaster or paperimitations of, or substitutes for, bonbons, often used by carnivalrevelers, at weddings, etc.
A red crystalline dyestuff, obtained by heating togetherpyrogallic and phthalic acids.
Anything producing torment, annoyance, or pain. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The art of conducting state affairs; state management;statesmanship.
A man at draughts; a piece used in playing games at tables. SeeTable, n., 10. [R.] Bacon.
A yellow crystalline substance, (C6H5.C2H2)2CO, the ketone ofcinnamic acid.
A body so suspended from a fixed point as to swing freely toand fro by the alternate action of gravity and momentum. It is usedto regulate the movements of clockwork and other machinery.
Not fleshy; specifically, not made flesh; not incarnate. [R.]Sir T. Browne.
One of a number of persons, before the revolution of 1789,chiefly of the higher orders, appointed by the king to constitute arepresentative body.
A spore case in the cryptogamous plants, as in ferns, etc.
The insertion of a letter or a sound in the body of a word; as,the b in "nimble" from AS. nemol.
A military headdress or cap, used in the British army. It is offur, with a bag, of the same color as the facings of the regiment,hanging from the top over the right shoulder.
An altered form of a toxin, possessing little or no toxicpower.
Old rope or iron chains wound around a cable. See Keckle, v. t.
Not favorable; unlucky; unpropitious; sinister. [R.] Ld.Lytton.
To free from perversion; to deliver from being perverted; toreconvert. [Obs.]
A place in a pagan temple in which the images of the deitieswere inclosed.
A species of sandpiper (Tringa alpina); -- called also churr,dorbie, grass bird, and red-backed sandpiper. It is found both inEurope and America.
A genus of a large naked mollusks having a very large, broad,fringed cephalic disk, and branched dorsal gills. Some of the speciesbecome a foot long and are brilliantly colored.
Inflammation of external parts of the body; erysipelatousinflammation.
A slender bony or cartilaginous process developed from the heelbone of bats. It helps to support the wing membranes. See Illust. ofCheiropter.
Margaric; -- formerly designating a supposed acid. [Obs.]
Sharp-edged and pointed; shaped like a pruning knife, as thebeak of certain birds.
A unit of resistance equal to one billion ohms, or one thousandmegohms.
A barbed dart carrying a banderole which the banderillerothrusts into the neck or shoulder of the bull in a bullfight.
One who fletches of feathers arrows; a manufacturer of bows andarrows. [Obs.] Mortimer.
Fondness for forest scenery; love of the woods. [R.]
To make a blow with, or as with, a hammer. [Obs.] Spenser.
One who lives in accordance with prescribed rules for diet; adieter.

An American marine fish of the Herring familt (Brevoortiatyrannus), chiefly valuable for its oil and as a component offertilizers; -- called also mossbunker, bony fish, chebog, pogy,hardhead, whitefish, etc.
A member of a college, particularly of a literary institutionso called; a student in a college.
An atom or radical which has a valence of eight, or isoctavalent.
A piece of lively dance music, in two strains which arerepeated; also, the dance.
To walk in a wavering, unsteady manner; to toddle; to topple.[Colloq.]
Not fledged; not feathered; hence, not fully developed;immature. Dryden.
Inflammation of the stomach, esp. of its mucuos membrane.
One who attributes diseases of the state of the humors.
The state or quality of being withered or lean. [R.]
One who steals anything in a shop, or takes goods privatelyfrom a shop; one who, under pretense of buying goods, takes occasionto steal.
To outgo; to move faster than; to leave behind. [R.] Lamb.
An oily substance prepared by the dry distillation of abituminous mineral containing fossil fishes. It is used in medicineas a remedy in some forms of skin diseases.
An appendage of the labyrinth of the internal ear, which iselongated and coiled into a spiral in mammals. See Ear.
Of or pertaining to alloxan; -- applied to an acid obtained bythe action of soluble alkalies on alloxan.
A mineral consisting of titanic oxide, and hence identical withrutile and octahedrite in composition, but crystallizing in theorthorhombic system.
An ammoniated compound of phenyl and acetamide, used as ananalgesic and antipyretic. It resembles phenacetin in its therapeuticaction.
To move irregularly or awkwardly; to wamble, or wabble. [Prov.Eng.]
In China, the official headquarters or residence of a mandarin,including court rooms, offices, gardens, prisons, etc.; the placewhere the business of any public department is transcated.
Abounding in stems, or mixed with stems; -- said of tea, driedcurrants, etc. [Colloq.]
Lasting during three nights; comprising three nights.
To thrust forward (at a venture), as a spear. [Obs.] Spenser.
A lady; madam; mistress; -- the title given a lady in Italy.
To invent, compose, or relate fables or fictions. G. S. Faber.
A metallic element separated from ytterbium in 1907, by Urbainin Paris and by von Welsbach in Vienna. Symbol, Lu; at. wt. 174.0.
The plant comfrey; -- so called from its use as a restorative.Dr. Prier.
A genus of sea urchins, similar to Spatangus, abounding in thechalk formation; -- from the starlike disposal of the ambulacralfurrows.
A South American striped frog (Pseudis paradoxa), remarkablefor having a tadpole larger than the adult, and hence called alsoparadoxical frog.
The political doctrines advocated by the People's party.
Having, or partaking of the properties of, fibrin; as, fibriousexudation.
A liquid obtained from fat, or fat fish, by pressure.
Preciousness; something precious. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
The peculiar smell and taste arising from products ofdecomposition of animal or vegetable substances when burnt in closevessels.
The wood of two small tropical American trees (Hameliaventricosa, and Cordia gerascanthoides). It is brownish, veined withlighter color.
A native or a Mexican horse of small size. [Western U.S.]
; sing. Catawba. (Ethnol.) An appalachian tribe of Indianswhich originally inhabited the regions near the Catawba river and thehead waters of the Santee.
The state of being amazed, or confounded with fear, surprise,or wonder. Bp. Hall.
To turn upside down; to subvert; to upset. [Obs.] Wyclif.
One of several alkaloids found in the leaves of the oleander.
To vex; to annoy; to startle. [Obs. or Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
Placed in paradise; enjoying delights as of paradise.
To subject to, or cause to undergo, volcanic heat, and to beaffected by its action.
To render nasal, as sound; to insert a nasal or sound in.
The middle layer of a pericarp which consists of three distinctor dissimilar layers. Gray.
The bitter principle of wormwood (Artemisia absinthium). Watts.
The branch of science which treats of the nervous system.
A dark blue substance obtained from wood tar. It consists ofhydrocarbons which when oxidized form the orange-yellow eupittoniccompounds, the salts of which are dark blue.
The Charioteer, or Wagoner, a constellation in the northernhemisphere, situated between Perseus and Gemini. It contains thebright star Capella.
The arrest of a person, or the seizure of his effects; esp., aprocess by which money or movables in the possession of a third partyare attached.
Capable of being moved, aroused, or excited; capable ofspontaneous movement.
To confront; to oppose; to withstand. [Obs.] Milton.
To wriggle or frisk about; to move awkwardly; to shake up anddown.
In certain fungi, a flask-shaped cavity from the surface of theinner walls of which spores are produced.
In Russia, a published proclamation or imperial order, havingthe force of law.
A boat shell (Crepidula fornicata) of the American coast.[Local, U.S.]
Eagerness for plunder; rapacity; extortion. Luke xi. 39.
Of or pertaining to mustard oil; specifically, designating anacid of the oleic acid series said to occur in mistard oil.
The act of expunging or erasing; the condition of beingexpunged. Milton.
A short, stout post used for any purpose, a to mark a boundary.[Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
One who, or that which, finds; specifically (Astron.), a smalltelescope of low power and large field of view, attached to a largertelescope, for the purpose of finding an object more readily.
A complex, nitrogenous radical, C8H5NO, regarded as theessential nucleus of indigo.
The lock of a gun, for producing the discharge. See Lock.
Demureness; also, one who is demure. Sir T. Browne.
To buy back or again; to regain by purchase. Sir M. Hale.
A name given to several malvaceous trees (species of Hibiscus,Ochroma, etc.), and to their strong fibrous inner bark, which is usedfor strings and cordage.

The situation of planets or stars with respect to one another,or the angle formed by the rays of light proceeding from them andmeeting at the eye; the joint look of planets or stars upon eachother or upon the earth. Milton.
A toll or tax paid by passengers, entitling them to safe-conduct and protection. [Obs.] Spelman.
A form of redan, so named from its shape; -- called alsoswallowtail.
A dome-shaped structure built over relics of Buddha or someBuddhist saint. [East Indies]
That which annoys or gives trouble and vexation; that which isoffensive or noxious.
The act or process of whipping or stinging with nettles; --sometimes used in the treatment of paralysis.

Any one of the three metameric hydrocarbons, C5H12, of themethane or paraffin series. They are colorless, volatile liquids, twoof which occur in petroleum. So called because of the five carbonatoms in the molecule.
An instrument or machine for comparing anything to be measuredwith a standard measure; -- applied especially to a machine forcomparing standards of length.

A New Zealand lizard, which, in anatomical character, differswidely from all other existing lizards. It is the only livingrepresentative of the order Rhynchocephala, of which many Mesozoicfossil species are known; -- called also Sphenodon, and Tuatera.
A disused word or phrase; an archaism. Fitzed. Hall.
A state of being amorphous; esp. a state of being withoutcrystallization even in the minutest particles, as in glass, opal,etc.
Taking root on, or above, the ground; rooting from the stem, asthe trumpet creeper and the ivy.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid amide, analogous tosuccinamic acid, which is obtained as a white crystalline substanceby heating urea with succinic anhydride. It is known also in itssalts.
Viscous; glutinous; of the nature of, or like, glue.
A small wooden vessel made of staves and hoops, like a tub.[Prov. Eng.]
A fluid containing the products formed by the growth of thetubercle bacillus in a suitable culture medium.
An oriental shrub (Lawsonia inermis) from which henna isobtained.
Of or pertaining to a bubo or buboes; characterized by buboes.
A glucoside found in the bark of the lilac (Syringa) andextracted as a white crystalline substance; -- formerly called alsolilacin.
A genus of leguminous shrubs, having long clusters of purpleflowers; false or bastard indigo. Longfellow.
A combination of meat with vegetables, bread, etc., usuallystewed, sometimes baked; an olio.
The language or dialect of the rabbins; the later Hebrew.
The act of evincing or proving, or the state of being evinced.
Of or pertaining to phthisis; affected with phthisis; wasting;consumptive.

A member or follower of the "liberal" party, headed by EliasHicks, which, because of a change of views respecting the divinity ofChrist and the Atonement, seceded from the conservative portion ofthe Society of Friends in the United States, in 1827.
A silicified stem of tree fern, found in abundance in theTriassic sandstone.

The act of dividing; the singling or severing of two or morethat join, or are joined, in one writ; the putting in several orseparate pleas or answers by two or more disjointly; the destructionof the unity of interest in a joint estate. Bouvier.
Having the form of a straight rod; wand-shaped; straight andslender.
A distraining or levying of a distress; an impounding. Burrill.
To soil or encumber with mire and dirt. [Obs.] Shak.
The game of hockey; -- so called because of the liability ofthe players to receive blows on the shin. Halliwell.
A tree (Terminalia latifolia) of Jamaica, the wood of which isused for boards, scantling, shingles, etc; -- sometimes called thealmond tree, from the shape of its fruit.
Something which takes place or appears once in three years.
A solid crystalline substance, C5H13NO2, found in the toadstool(Agaricus muscarius), and in putrid fish. It is a typical ptomaine,and a violent poison.
An albuminoid substance which occurs in minute grains ("proteingranules") in maturing seeds and tubers; -- supposed to be amodification of protoplasm.
A frightful goblin; an imp; a bugaboo; also, a name formerlygiven to the household spirit, Robin Goodfellow. Macaulay.
One who pules; one who whines or complains; a weak person.
A genus of rosaceous trees and shrubs having pomes for fruit.It includes the apple, crab apple, pear, chokeberry, sorb, andmountain ash.
A retrograde metamorphosis of the floral organs to thecondition of leaves.
Land that is overflowed by tide water; hence, land near thesea.
One who procures or receives a papal provision. See Provision,6.
An instrument carried by a pedestrian for automatically makinga topographical record of the ground covered during a journey.
Consisting of sod; covered with sod; turfy. Cotgrave.
The principles of those adhering to the house of Bourbon;obstinate conservatism.
One who flatters.The most abject flaterers degenerate into the greatest tyrants.Addison.
A shered; a fragment; a strip of wood. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Facing toward the axis of the flower, as in the introrseanthers of the water lily.
Intermission of labor, as upon the Sabbath; rest. Dr. H. More.
Of or pertaining to a semitone; consisting of a semitone, or ofsemitones.
To extort; to draw from or forth by violence. [Obs.] Spenser.

An organized being; a living body, either vegetable or animal,compozed of different organs or parts with functions which areseparate, but mutually dependent, and essential to the life of theindividual.
A man of the same race or family; one related by blood.
To traffic or trade, by exchanging one commodity for another,in distinction from a sale and purchase, in which money is paid forthe commodities transferred; to truck.
A wandering about with evil intentions; a rioting. [Obs. & R.]Feltham.
A projecting molding round a panel. Same as Bilection. Gwilt.
The act of plundering, despoiling, or snatching away. [R.]Speed.
To cause to run off from the rails of a railroad, as alocomotive. Lardner.
The cudweed (Gnaphalium), used to prevent or cure chafing.
Turning the head towards the spectator, but not the body; --said of a lion or other beast.
A noisy or unrestrained carousal or frolic; a spree. [Slang]Kipling.
A concession to an adversary in order to strengthen one's ownargument.
(Photog.) An assisting instrument for focusing an object in orbefore a camera. Knight.
A variety of the domestic pigeon remarkable for the extent towhich it is able to dilate its throat and breast.
A prolate spheroid. See Ellipsoid of revolution, underEllipsoid.
A four-wheeled pleasure carriage with two inside seats, calashtop, and seats for driver and footman.
The lowest square sail, or the lower yard of the mizzenmast.
A plaited or gathered flounce on a woman's garment.
A steel cutting instrument, with a long bent shank set in ahandle which rests against the shoulder of the operator. It isoperated by a thrust movement, and used in paring the hoofs ofhorses.
Work or wall consisting of stone; mason's work of stone.Mortimer.
A place fit only for dogs; a vile, mean habitation orapartment. Dryden.
A fold of the peritoneum connecting the liver with the dorsalwall of the abdominal cavity.
The doctrine of innate ideas, or that the mind possesses formsof thought independent of sensation.
Any insect of the genus Forticula and related genera, belongingto the order Euplexoptera.
A kind of golf stick used to lift the ball out of holes, ruts,etc.
A crystallized variety of pyroxene, of a clear, grayish greencolor; mussite.
Solemn; grand; stately; splendid; magnificent. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A name given to several inconspicuous plants having leaves inwhorls of four, as species of Crucianella, Valantia, etc.
An indefinite feeling of uneasiness, or of being sick or ill atease.
Vexatious; causing bother; causing trouble or perplexity;troublesome.
The country ruled by a soldan, or sultan. [Poet.] Sir W. Scott.
An Asiatic burrowing rodent (Siphneus aspalax) resembling themole rat. It is native of the Altai Mountains.
A manifestation of God to man by actual appearance, usually asan incarnation.
A south American tick of the genus Amblyamma. There are severalspecies, very troublesome to man and beast.
The wax-covered fruit of the wax myrtle, or bayberry. SeeBayberry, and Candleberry tree.
A very venomous snake of India (Bungarus coeruleus), allied tothe cobra. Its upper parts are bluish or brownish black, often withnarrow white streaks; the belly is whitish.
Odd in manner or appearance; fantastic; whimsical; extravagant;grotesque. C. Kingsley.
A narrow-sterned boat formerly much used in the Newfoundlandfisheries; -- called also pinkstern and chebec. Bartlett.
A genus of ericaceous shrubs including the various kinds ofblueberries and the true cranberries.
To surprise or astonish; to be startled or astonished. [Prov.Eng.] Halliwell.
A word having an acute accent on the penultimate syllable.
The chamber of a mine in which the powder is placed.
Capable of passing through animal membranes by osmosis.
One well versed in the Arabic language or literature; also,formerly, one who followed the Arabic system of surgery.
Of or pertaining to dolphin oil or porpoise oil; -- said of anacid (called also delphinic acid) subsequently found to be identicalwith valeric acid. Watts.
The stalk of a leaf or of flower; a petiole, pedicel, orreduncle.
One who exports; the person who sends goods or commodities to aforeign country, in the way of commerce; -- opposed to importer.
The reach or distance to which a gun will shoot; gunshot.
A coin, either of gold or silver, of several countries inEurope; originally, one struck in the dominions of a duke.
A governor or viceroy; -- a title granted in 1867 by the sultanof Turkey to the ruler of Egypt.
The chain of micrococci formed by the division of themicrococci in multiplication.
One who drives or uses a cart; a teamster; a carter.
A mound formed of fragments of rock, earth, etc., and set withplants.
To twist in and out; to twine; to wreathe; to wind; to wring.Pope.
Of or pertaining to Lethe; resembling in effect the water ofLethe. Milton. Barrow.
The condition of being numb; that state of a living body inwhich it loses, wholly or in part, the power of feeling or motion.
One of the clergy of first rank in the lower order of secularclergy; an archpriest; -- called also protopapas.
An acute disease occurring in India, characterized by multipleinflammatory changes in the nerves, producing great musculardebility, a painful rigidity of the limbs, and cachexy.
A genus of American shrubs containing several species, calledsnowdrop trees, or silver-bell trees. They have showy, white flowers,drooping on slender pedicels.
The worship of images as symbols; -- distinguished fromidolatry, the worship of images themselves.
A name of many different kinds of apples. Cf. Reinette.Mortimer.
The hunting spiders, which run after, or leap upon, their prey.
A paste made by mixing powdered charcoal, coal, or coke withclay, molasses, tar, or other suitable substance. It is used forlining hearths, crucibles, etc. Called also steep.
A medicine to check the secretion of milk, or to dispel asupposed accumulation of milk in any part of the body.
A genus of tropical orchidaceous plants, the flower of onespecies of which (O. Papilio) resembles a butterfly.
A large conical brick structure around which the firing kilnsare grouped. Knight.
One of the clews or lower corners of a course or a topsail whenthe middle part or the rest of the sail is furled.
A blowing machine for separating the flour from the bran.
A flying off in small particles, as heated iron or fermentingliquors; a sparkling; scintillation. Sir T. Browne.
Containing dregs or lees; muddy; foul; feculent. Boyle.
A clear, viscous, tasteless substance extracted from themucilaginous sap of the mistletoe (Viscum album), holly, etc., andconstituting an essential ingredient of birdlime.
The division or defective coherence of an organ that is usuallyentire.
The jaws between which the hinder end of a carriage tongue isinserted. Knight.
A weapon, used in discharging arrows, formed by placing a bowcrosswise on a stock.
A Latin god of commerce and gain; -- treated by the poets asidentical with the Greek Hermes, messenger of the gods, conductor ofsouls to the lower world, and god of eloquence.
A form of government in which the supreme power is lodged inthe hands of the wealthy classes; government by the rich; also, acontrolling or influential class of rich men.
Flesh-colored tights, worn by actors dancers. D. Jerrold.
One to whom anything is resigned, or in whose favor aresignation is made.
Any small kangaroo belonging to Hypsiprymnus, Bettongia, andallied genera, native of Australia and Tasmania. Called also kangaroorat.

Formed or crystallized at depths the earth's surface; -- saidof granite, gneiss, and other rocks, whose crystallization isbelieved of have taken place beneath a great thickness of overlyingrocks. Opposed to epigene.
The trick of a shopkeeper; deception. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A simple or compound principle, whose presence is necessary toproduce acidity, as oxygen, chlorine, bromine, iodine, etc.
Able to decide or determine; having a tendency to decide. [R.]
A crying down; a clamorous censure; condemnation by censure.
The European bearded titmouse (Panurus biarmicus); -- calledalso reed bunting, bearded pinnock, and lesser butcher bird.
A horizontal member spanning an opening, and carrying thesuperincumbent weight by means of its strength in resisting crosswisefracture.
A painting all of one color, as a sepia painting, or an Indiapainting.
The condition of being poisoned by the excessive use ofabsinth.
The act of cajoling; the state of being cajoled; cajolery.Coleridge.
The upper end of the rudderpost, to which the tiller isattashed.
To spit out; to discharge from the throat by hawking andspitting. [Obs.] Cockeram.
One of the orders of Infusoria, characterized by having cilia.In some species the cilia cover the body generally, in others theyform a band around the mouth.
A rowdy street loafer; a rowdyish or noisy ill-bred fellow; --variously applied, as to a street blackguard, a street Arab, a youthgiven to horse-play, etc. [Australia & Eng.] -- a.
Even; not odd; -- said of elementary substances and of radicalsthe valence of which is divisible by two without a remainder.
The lower faceted portion of a brilliant-cut diamond.
A frame, like a balcony, projecting from the stern or quarterof a ship, and hence called stern galery or quarter gallry, -- seldomfound in vessels built since 1850.
A willful contempt of, and disobedience to, any lawful summons,or to the rules and orders of court, as a refusal to appear in courtwhen legally summoned.
The acid amide of mucic acid, obtained as a white crystallinesubstance.
An alteration of, or subtraction from, a contract for a sale ofstocks.
A light vehicle having two wheels one behind the other. It hasa saddle seat and is propelled by the rider's feet acting on cranksor levers.
A fitting, usually having a plug, applied to a cistern, tub,sink, or the like, and forming the outlet opening.
A genus of rodents, including the beaver. See Beaver.

A name given to various roots, tubers, or pods grown under oron the ground; as to:(a) The esculent tubers of the umbelliferous plants Bunium flexuosumand Carum Bulbocastanum.(b) The peanut. See Peanut.
The scale, or exopodite, of an antenna of a crustacean.
Any plectognath fish of the genera Monacanthus, Alutera,balistes, and allied genera; -- so called on account of the roughlygranulated skin, which is sometimes used in place of sandpaper.
A medicine in the form of a roll, a esp. a roll of plaster.
Any one of several species of Australian singing birds of thegenus Pachycephala. The males of some of the species are bright-colored. Some of the species are popularly called thrushes.
A wiseacre; a person deficient in wisdom; -- so called fromGotham, in Nottinghamshire, England, noted for some pleasantblunders. Bp. Morton.
A silicate of alumina, of fibrous or columnar structure. It islike andalusite in composition; -- called also sillimanite, andbucholizite.

The material of repair in fractures of bone; a substance exudedat the site of fracture, which is at first soft or cartilaginous inconsistence, but is ultimately converted into true bone and unitesthe fragments into a single piece.
The state, condition, or quality, of being light or not heavy;buoyancy; levity; fickleness; delicacy; grace.
A numbering of the people, and valuation of their estate, forthe purpose of imposing taxes, etc.; -- usually made once in fiveyears.
Combined or impregnated with muriatic or hydrochloric acid.
One of the exceedingly minute spores found in certainflowerless plants, as Selaginella and Isoetes, which bear two kindsof spores, one very much smaller than the other. Cf. Macrospore.
An iron needle for piercing the cartridge of a cannon beforepriming.
Any operation for the removal of varices by incision.Dunglison.
A rude apparatus for pulverizing ores, esp. those containingfree gold.
That part of the treadboard of a stair which projects over theriser; hence, any like projection, as the projecting edge of amolding.
One of the granular masses which constitute a racemose orcompound gland, as the pancreas; also, one of the saccular recessesin the lobules of a racemose gland. Quain.
Long and flexible, like a wand. [Prov. Eng.] Brockett.
The state or practice of having several wives at the same time;marriage to several wives. H. Spenser.
A South American bird, of the genus Pleroglossius, allied tothe toucans. There are several species.
To form a theory or theories; to form opinions solely bytheory; to speculate.
Of or pertaining to that division of the Celtic languages,which includes the Irish, Gaelic, and Manx. J. Peile.
Bacchanalian; fond of drunken revelry; wine-loving; reveling;carousing. Byron.
In a glancing manner; transiently; incidentally; indirectly.Hakewill.
Having a taste or flavorl savory; sapid. [Obs.] Cockeram.
To apply carbonic acid to; to wash or treat with carbolic acid.
An instrument with a graduated disk by means of which theangles of gems are measured in the process of cutting and polishing.

The washing out or away of earth, etc., especially of a portionof the bed of a road or railroad by a fall of rain or a freshet;also, a place, especially in the bed of a road or railroad, where theearth has been washed away.
Of or relating to Morpheus, to dreams, or to sleep. Keats.
To deprive of odor, especially of such as results fromimpurities.
A minute calcareous rodlike structure found both at the surfaceand the bottom of the ocean; -- supposed by some to be a calcareousalga.
A kind of liquid medicine made up of many ingredients; esp., asopposed to solution, a liquid preparation in which the solidingredients are not completely dissolved.
A West Indian name for the prickly pear (Opuntia); -- calledalso pimploes.

Resembling salt; -- said of certain binary compounds consistingof a metal united to a negative element or radical, and now chieflyapplied to the chlorides, bromides, iodides, and sometimes also tothe fluorides and cyanides.-- n.
Proceeding by sixes; sextuple; -- applied especially to asystem of arithmetical computation in which the base is six.
A rescript of the pope, commanding an ordinary collator to putthe person therein named in possession of the first vacant beneficein his collation.
To swathe; to envelop, as in swaddling clothes. Shak.
The district under a Roman tetrarch; the office or jurisdictionof a tetrarch; a tetrarchate.
A vegetable jelly, resembling pectin, found in gooseberries(Ribes Grossularia) and other fruits.
The act of refitting, or the state of being refitted.
A pole or beam used in Scottish games for tossing as a trial ofstrength.
That part of a pistil which has no epidermis, and is fitted toreceive the pollen. It is usually the terminal portion, and iscommonly somewhat glutinous or viscid. See Illust. of Stamen and ofFlower.
A poisonous plant (Aconitum Lycoctonum), a kind of monkshood;also, by extension, any plant or species of the genus Aconitum. SeeAconite.
A substance characterizing wood cells and differing fromcellulose in its conduct with certain chemical reagents.
Uttered or done again; repeated. [Obs.] Bp. Gardiner.
One who is born or bred in a city; a citizen. [Obs.] Champan.
Any apparatus by which an electrical current is originated.[R.]
Fate-bringing; deadly; mortal; destructive. [R.] Johnson.
Of or pertaining to monks or a monastic life; monastic.
An abnormal sound of several kinds, heard on auscultation.
The production of artificial membranes by contact of twofluids, as albumin and fat, by which the globules of the latter aresurrounded by a thin film of the former.
The principles and practices of the Ribbonmen. See RibbonSociety, under Ribbon.
The wife of an earl in the British peerage, or of a count inthe Continental nobility; also, a lady possessed of the same dignityin her own right. See the Note under Count.
In Ireland, a tenure of family lands by which the proprietorhad only a life estate, to which he was admitted by election.
Greater than any assignable quantity of the same kind; -- saidof certain quantities.
A theory which regards matter as the original principle ofevil.
A perpendicular shaft sunk to cut the lode at any requireddepth. Weale.
A piece attached to, or forming part of, the hammer of agunlock, upon which the mainspring acts and in which are the notchesfor sear point to enter.
Double location; the state or power of being in two places atthe same instant; -- a miraculous power attributed to some of thesaints. Tylor.
A matter of doctrine; also, a system of doctrines. T. Goodwin.Sir T. Elyot.
Stone-inhabiting; pertaining to, or having the characteristicsof, the stonechats.
An arch, or ceiling, of boards, placed over the men's heads ina mine.
A celebrated collection of tales, supposed to be related in tendays; -- written in the 14th century, by Boccaccio, an Italian.
A name given to several plants because they were thought to bea cure for warts, as a kind of spurge (Euphorbia Helioscopia), andthe nipplewort (Lampsana communis).
The art or habit of making rhymes; rhyming; -- in contempt.
A firm, elastic substance resembling horn, taken from the upperjaw of the right whale; baleen. It is used as a stiffening in stays,fans, screens, and for various other purposes. See Baleen.
To reel, sway, or move from side to side; to move with awagging motion; to waddle.Why do you go nodding and waggling so L'Estrange.
Infectious particles or germs floating in the air; air madenoxious by the presence of such particles or germs; noxious effluvia;malaria.
Porcelain impressed with figures which are made distinct bytransmitted light, -- as when hung in a window, or used as a lampshade.
The art or the science of drawing; esp. of drawing according tomathematical rules, as in perspective, projection, and the like.
The state of being siderated, or planet-struck; esp., blast inplants; also, a sudden and apparently causeless stroke of disease, asin apoplexy or paralysis. [Obs.] Ray.
The act of warping; also, a charge per ton made on shipping insome harbors.
A thin, pointed nail, with a heavy flaring head, for securing ahorsehoe to the hoof; a horsehoe nail.
A weight used in certain parts of the East Indies, varyingconsiderably in different localities, the range being from 223 to 625pounds.
A moving picture or a moving picture show; -- commonly used inpl. [Slang or Colloq.]
One who serves in a surfboat in the life-saving service.
One who dishonors or disgraces; one who treats anotherindignity. Milton.
One who denies the doctrine of the Trinity, believing that Godexists only in one person; a unipersonalist; also, one of adenomination of Christians holding this belief.
To deprive of buds or shoots, as for training, or economizingthe vital strength of a tree.
A light cape, usually of lace, worn by women, to cover the neckand throat, and extending to the shoulders.
The science of grafting, including the various methods ofpractice and details of operation.
The five lines and the spaces on which music is written; --formerly called stave.
A gallstone, or biliary calculus. See Biliary. E. Darwin.
The anterior horn of each lateral ventricle of the brain. B. G.Wilder.
A morphological individual, characterized by definiteness ofform bion, a physiological individual. See Tectology. Haeckel.
Resembling an ass; asinine; stupid or obstinate.Such . . . appear to be of the assich kind . . . Udall.
A selenide containing two atoms of selenium in each molecule.
The act of precluding, or the state of being precluded; ashutting out.
Any comprehensive group of animals or plants including severalsubordinate related groups.
To perform inefficiently, as a play; to act feebly.
A peculiar starchy matter contained in barley. It is complexmixture. [R.]
The missel thrush; -- so called from its harsh alarm note.[Prev. Eng.]
In a needy condition or manner; necessarily. Chaucer.
Handily; readily; dexterously; advantageously. [Obs.] Dr. H.More.
The process of pulling out and elongating the sliver from thecarding machine, by revolving rollers, to prepare it for spinning.
Consisting of acini, or minute granular concretions; as,acinose or acinous glands. Kirwan.
An inhabitant of highlands, especially of the Highlands ofScotland.
One of a series of organic bases obtained by the reduction ofcertain isonitroso compounds of the ketones. In general they areunstable oily substances having a pungent aromatic odor.
A private circle or assembly at a private house; a circle.[Obs.] Dryden.
A morbid condition resembling tetanus, but distinguished fromit by being less severe and having intermittent spasms.
A female steward; specifically, a woman employed in passengervessels to attend to the wants of female passengers.
To relieve from perspiration; to ease or cool after exercise ortoil. [R.] Milton.
A soft, earthy, clayey mineral, of whitish or grayish color.
A yard or inclosure for the interment of the dead; a cemetery.
The doctrine that animals of the same species have sprung frommore than one original pair.
Soaring too high for safety, like Icarus; adventurous inflight.
Like the motion of the hands of a clock; -- said of thatdirection of a rotation about an axis, or about a point in a plane,which is ordinarily reckoned negative.
A rhizopod. common in fresh water, capable of undergoing manychanges of form at will. See Rhizopoda.
One to whom a debt is due; creditor; -- correlative to debtor.Blackstone.
The unit of heat according to the Frensc standard; the amountof heat requires to raise the temperature of one kilogram (sometimes,one gram) of water one degree centigrade, or from 0Foot pound.
Giving a previous narrative or explanation, as of the plot orpersonages of a play; introductory. = 32,500 yrs.) Also calledbrevium, Uranium X2 and UX2.

A venereal sore, resembling a chancre in its seat and someexternal characters, but differing from it in being the startingpoint of a purely local process and never of a systemic disease; --called also soft chancre.
A division of Carnivora, including the dogs, wolves, and foxes.
That which incubates, especially, an apparatus by means ofwhich eggs are hatched by artificial heat.
One in subjection to a demon, or to demons. [R.] Sir T.Herbert.
A sudden or unexpected coming or stepping on. [Obs.]
To refuse or reject, as a judge; to challenge that the judgeshall not try the cause. [Obs.] Sir K. Digby.
The young, either larva or pupa, of the mosquito; -- calledalso wiggletail.
A bitter, crystallizable substance obtained from gentian.
An alkaloid found in opium, and extracted as a yellow amorphoussubstance which is easily decomposed.
Like, or imitative of, anything archaic; pertaining to anarchaism.
The station or government of a despot; also, the domain of adespot. Freeman.
Sloping gradually; shelving.The shore was shelving and shallow. Shak.
Any passage having the entrance represented as wider than theexit, so as to give the appearance of length.
Turned upside down from its proper position; inverted;reversed.
A minute yellowish body present in the interior of certainrhizopods.
A collusive agreement between two or more persons to prejudicea third.
A genus of fungi having the under side of the pileus or capcomposed of a multitude of fine separate tubes. A few are edible, andothers very poisonous.
A kind of ear trumpet for the deaf, or the partially deaf.
A public hall or building, belonging to a town, where thepublic offices are established, the town council meets, the peopleassemble in town meeting, etc.
Having large, full eyes, like those of an ox. Burton.
An explosive substance consisting essentially of sawdust orwood pulp, saturated with nitroglycerin and other similar nitrocompounds. It is inferior to dynamite, and is more liable toexplosion.
A genus of phyllopod Crustacea found in salt lakes and brines;the brine shrimp. See Brine shrimp.
Time characterized by syncopation, as in many negro melodies.[Colloq.]
A careless or inaccurate delineation of anything. Etym: [R.]
To impart metallic properties to; to impregnate with a metal.[R.]
Art of producing metal decorative work other than statuary, asreliefs, intaglios, engraving, chasing, etc.
The bone or cartilage of the carpus which articulates with theradius and corresponds to the scaphoid bone in man.
A wandering of the mind; a crazy fancy. [Obs.] Heywood.
A broad, shallow basket, for displaying fruit or flowers.
In the army, a soldier who feigns himself sick, or who inducesor protracts an illness, in order to avoid doing his duty; hence, ingeneral, one who shirks his duty by pretending illness or inability.
Radiating to or from the same point. [R.] Coleridge.
Characterized by fullness, clearness, strength, and smoothness;ringing and musical; -- said of the voice or manner of utterance.-- n.
The act or method of weaving a cover for a ring, rope end, etc.
A kind of open sedan used in Ceylon, carried by a single poleon men's shoulders.
To strip of glass; to remove the glazing, or glass, from, as awindow.
That part of a flail which strikes the grain. Knight.
Becoming a skillful workman; skillful; well performed;workmanlike.
The science which treats of motions considered in themselves,or apart from their causes; the comparison and relation of motions.
Capable of being deposed or deprived of office. Howell.
Having a glazed appearance; -- said of the fractured surface ofsome kinds of pin iron.
Moving in a circle, or spirally; revolving; whirling around.
A general or comprehensive statement; an abridged account; anabstract, abridgment, or compendium, containing the sum or substanceof a fuller account.
A species of English granite, used as a building stone.
An early form of hand gun, variety of the arquebus; originallya gun having a regular size of bore. [Obs.] Shak.
One who practices polygamy, or maintains its lawfulness.
Full of contention; contentious; quarrelsome. [Obs.] Spenser.
A viceroy; a governor of a subah; also, a native captain in theBritish native army. [India]
A curve traced by a point in the circumference of a circlewhich rolls on the convex side of a fixed circle.

Any one of numerous edible, marine, spiny-finned fishes of thegenus Labrus, of which several species are found in the Mediterraneanand on the Atlantic coast of Europe. Many of the species are bright-colored.

A poisonous base (ptomaine) formed in meat broth through theagency of a peculiar microbe from the wound of a person who has diedof tetanus; -- so called because it produces tetanus as one of itsprominent effects.
A heavy wind; a wind that brings a storm; the blast of a storm.Longfellow.
A gladiator armed with a net for entangling his adversary and atrident for despatching him.
The act of addressing or directing one's course. [Rare & Obs.]Chapman.
To coil up; to make into a coil, or to be made into a coil.
A casting or throwing seed in all directions, as from the handin sowing.
A yellow crystalline substance, having a geraniumlike odor,regarded as a complex derivative of acetone, and obtained fromcertain camphor compounds.
A kind of larkspur (Delphinium Staphysagria), and its seeds,which are violently purgative and emetic. They are used as aparasiticide, and in the East for poisoning fish.
To play upon by artifice; to deceive; to mock; to excite anddisappoint the hopes of.
A fastening or knitting together; the state of being closelyjointed; close union. [R.] Coleridge.
Inserted in the corner of the eye; -- said of the antenn
An inside range of ceiling planks, corresponding to the sheerstrake on the outside and bolted to it.
Consisting of corymbs, or resembling them in form. [Writtenalso corymbous.]
To view subjects from certain premises given or assumed, andinfer conclusions respecting them a priori.
One who sends goods from one place to another not in the samecity or town, esp. one who sends goods by water.
A strong, long stake, one end of which is set firmly in theground, and the other is sharpened; also, a fence formed of suchstakes set in the ground as a means of defense.
A silicate of alumina, iron, and magnesia, having a bright bluecolor and vitreous luster; cordierite. It is remarkable for itsdichroism, and is also called dichroite.
One who sells slops, or ready-made clothes. See 4th Slop, 3.
The state or condition of being an orphan; orphanage.
Enlargement or extension of business transaction; esp.,increase of the circulation of bank notes.
A division of Echini which includes the circular, or regular,sea urchins.
Divided into many narrow parts or segments by sharp incisions;laciniate.
Of or pertaining to the czar or the czarina; czarish.
A fieldwork consisting of two faces, forming a salient angle,and two parallel flanks. See Bastion.
An insect characterized by having but four perfect legs, ascertain of the butterflies.
A collection of serous fluid in the areolar texture of thescrotum or in the coverings, especially in the serous sac, investingthe testicle or the spermatic cord; dropsy of the testicle.
One who reefs; -- a name often given to midshipmen. Marryat.
A toggle joint; -- so called because consisting of two piecesjointed to each other end to end, making an angle like the knee whenbent.
The charge made by innkeepers for drawing the cork and takingcare of bottles of wine bought elsewhere by a guest.
Having the appearance of being labiate; -- said of certainpolypetalous corollas.
The organ of a female mammal in which the young are developedprevious to birth; the womb.
A person born of relations between whom marriage was forbiddenby the Mosaic law; a bastard. Deut. xxiii. 2 (Douay version).
To fill with rage; to provoke to frenzy or madness; to makefurious.
Anything which prevents sleep, or produces wakefulness, asstrong tea or coffee.
Act of eluding; adroit escape, as by artifice; a mockery; acheat; trickery.
A prime mover; a machine by means of which a source of power,as steam, moving water, electricity, etc., is made available fordoing mechanical work.
A master of arts whose regency has ceased. See Regent.
Of or pertaining to a cognomen; of the nature of a surname.
A Hindoo system of philosophy which refers all things to souland a rootless germ called prakriti, consisting of three elements,goodness, passion, and darkness. Whitworth.
A kind of large, coarse, short trousers formerly worn. [Local,U. S.] Bartlett.
A yellow or brown amorphous substance, of indifferent nature,found in cod-liver oil.
Two small, pointed rods of metal, formerly used in thetreatment called Perkinism.
A band of rich embroidery, wholly or in part of gold, affixedto vestments, especially those of ecclesiastics. Pugin.
A bitter white crystalline alkaloid extracted from the seeds ofthe castor-oil plant.
Pertaining to, containing, or consisting of, strophes.
A crown-saw or cylindrical saw for perforating the skull,turned, when used, like a bit or gimlet. See Trephine.
Wise after the event; wise or knowing, when it is too late.
Any one of a series of amido compounds obtained by treatingsulphuryl chloride with various amines.
A woman who is a prelate; the wife of a prelate. Milton.
The neck or line of junction between the root of a plant andits stem. Gray.
Out of condition; not in good condition; -- said of a hawk.
A stone for scouring or rubbing; a whetstone; a rub.

An order of small apterous insects having an elongated body,with three pairs of thoracic and about nine pairs of abdominal legs.They are, in many respects, intermediate between myriapods and trueinsects.
One of the orders of Nemertina, characterized by the presenceof a peculiar armature of spines or plates in the proboscis.
Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acid(C4H5N3O4) not known in the free state, but obtained, in combinationwith its salts, by a slow oxidation of uric acid, to which it isrelated.
In German mythology, the children of the mist, a race of dwarfsor demonic beings, the original possessors of the famous hoard andring won by Siegfrid; also, the Burgundian kings in theNibelungenlied.
A variety of garnet, of a poppy or blood-red color, frequentlywith a tinge of orange. It is used as a gem. See the Note underGarnet.
A method of working in which the waste is packed into the spaceformed by excavating the vein.
To guard as a churchwarden does. [Obs.] J. Gregory.
The quotient of a unit divided by a thousand; one of a thousandequal parts into which a unit is divided.
A small coin of the value of six and a quarter cents. SeeFippenny bit. [Local, U.S.]
The European small-spotted dogfish, or houndfish. See the Noteunder Houndfish.
To give nervous energy or power to; to give increasedenergy,force,or courage to; to invigorate; to stimulate.
Benne (Sesamum orientale); also, its seeds; -- so called in theWest Indies.
The kiang, a wild horse or wild ass of Thibet (Asinushemionus).
One who, or that which, occasions, causes, or produces. Bp.Sanderson.
The art of making baskets; also, baskets, taken collectively.
A soluble poison (ptomaine) present in putrid blood. It is alsoformed in the putrefaction of proteid matter in general.
A colorless corpuscle, as one of the white blood corpuscles, orthose found in lymph, marrow of hone, connective tissue, etc.
The difference between the approximate result and the trueresult; -- used particularly in the rule of double position.
A projecting turret for a sentry, as at the salient angles ofworks, or the acute angles of bastions.
One who rents or leases an estate; -- usually said of a lesseeor tenant.
A genus of small marine bivalve shells, having a pearlyinterior.
Plaster as used in Persian architecture and decorative art.
Narrowed at the forward end; -- said of an automobile framewhen the side members are closer together at the forward end than atthe rear.
One who systemizes, or reduces to system; a systematizer.
A contemptuous nickname for a timid, yielding politician, orone who is easily molded. [Political cant, U. S.]
A stunted shrub, bush, or branch. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
The space between the columns and the wall of the cella, in aGreek or a Roman temple.
Fetid feldspar, a mineral which, when struck, exhales a fetidodor.
A canonical term for regular induction into a benefice,comprehending nomination, collation, and installation.
The general outward form of any solid object, as of a column ora vase.
A lovely maiden, daughter of a king and mistress of Eros, orCupid. She is regarded as the personification of the soul.
To affect excessive refinement in language; to be overnice inexpression.
One fond of his own notions, or unduly attached to his ownopinions. Glanvill.
An apparent right; as where the defendant in trespass gave tothe plaintiff an appearance of title, by stating his title specially,thus removing the cause from the jury to the court. Blackstone.
The art of preaching; that branch of theology which treats ofhomilies or sermons, and the best method of preparing and deliveringthem.
Honorably discharged from the performance of public duty onaccount of age, infirmity, or long and faithful services; -- said ofan officer of a college or pastor of a church.
Sewed or knit together; united by a suture; stitched.
A Roman measure of land, measuring 28,800 square feet, or 240feet in length by 120 in breadth.
A long, covered walk, or a low, level building, where ropes aremanufactured.
A yellow coloring matter, soluble in ether, contained in thesmall round fat drops in the retinal epithelium cells. It is bestobtained from the eyes of frogs.
Turned back; reversed. Specifically: (Her.) Bent or curvedtwice, in opposite directions, or in the form of an S.
To fight with the fists; to box.Bruising was considered a fine, manly, old English custom. Thackeray.
A kind of coarse upper coat, or overcoat, formerly worn.
The apart or practice of measuring the diameters of heavenlybodies, their relative distances, etc. See Heliometer.
To change (one proposition) into another, so that what was thesubject of the first becomes the predicate of the second.
To make melodious; to form into, or set to, melody.
Having no radiating processes; -- applied particularly tocertain nerve cells.
A class of Mollusca in which the anterior lobes of the foot aredeveloped in the form of broad, thin, winglike organs, with whichthey swim at near the surface of the sea.
Speedily; with haste or celerity; soon; without delay; quick.
Ascending rivers from the sea, at certain seasons, forbreeding, as the salmon, shad, etc.
An alkaloid found in small quantities in opium, and extractedas a white crystalline substance of a bitter astringent taste. It isa narcotic. Called also narceia.
One who adheres to the letter of the Koran, rejecting alltraditions.
A slender European weed (Galium Cruciata); -- called alsocrossweed.

A thick, circular disk of wood, to which the cartridge bag andprojectile are attached, in fixed ammunition for cannon; also, apiece of soft metal attached to a projectile to take the groove ofthe rifling.
A machine for pressing the water from skins in tanning. Knight.
A telluride of silver and gold, related to hessite.
Universal wisdom; esp., a system of universal knowledgeproposed by Comenius (1592 -- 1671), a Moravian educator. [R.]Hartlib.
Comely or decent appearance. [Obs.] Rom. of R. Spenser.
An extinct order of reptiles which stood erect on the hindlegs, and resembled birds in the structure of the feet, pelvis, andother parts.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the plant spinach, or thefamily of plants to which it belongs.
One whose occupation is to make and repair watches.
The sum allowed to a sheriff or other officer upon the amountrealized by an execution; -- estimated in England, and formerly inthe United States, at so much of the pound. Burrill. Bouvier.
Inherent baseness or vileness of principle, words, or actions;shameful wickedness; depravity. Shak.
A sportsman who pursues wild fowl, or takes or kills for food.
To unite in compact, as different States; to confederate forpolitical purposes; to unite by or under the Federal Constitution.Barlow.
Same as Cordwain. in England the name is applied to leathermade from horsehide.
The bar, or crosspiece, of a carriage, to which the singletreesare attached.
The radical KO, derived from, and supposed to exist in,potassium hydroxide and other compounds.
The fiery cross, used as a rallying signal in the Highlands ofScotland.
An instrument for measuring the voltaic electricity passingthrough it, by its effect in decomposing water or some other chemicalcompound acting as an electrolyte.

An advocate of confederation; specifically (Amer. Hist.), afriend of the Constitution of the United States at its formation andadoption; a member of the political party which favored theadministration of president Washington.
Hopelessly insensible or stupid; not easily aroused or excited;dull; impassive; foolish.
Transparent, or semitransparent, colors passed thinly overother colors, to modify the effect.
A reddish fleshy herb of the genus Monotropa (M. hypopitys),formerly thought to be parasitic on the roots of pine trees, but moreprobably saprophytic.
Departing from the main subject; partaking of the nature ofdigression. Johnson.
To comb; also, to beat; to worry. [Obs. or Local] See Feaze, v.
A game of chance, in which four sea shells, each called a prop,are used instead of dice.
To merge again. "Remerging in the general Soul." Tennyson.
The part of a polariscope which receives the light afterpolarization, and exhibits its properties.
An acid amide derived from lactic acid, and obtained as a whitecrystalline substance having a neutral reaction. It is metameric withalanine.
The fourth joint of a typical appendage of Crustacea.
One learned in the classics; an advocate for the classics.
One who rides a bicycle or tricycle; a cycler, or cyclist.
The back part of the neck; the scruff. [Prov. Eng.] Ld. Lytton.

The three divisions, or "baskets" (pitakas), of buddhistscriptures, -- the Vinayapitaka [Skr. Vinayapitsaka] , or Basket ofDiscipline; Suttapitaka [Pali] , or Basket of Discourses; andAbhidhammapitaka [Pali] , or Basket of Metaphysics.
To ascend or creep upward by twining about a support, or byattaching itself by tendrills, rootlets, etc., to a support orupright surface.
A small South African antelope (Cephalous mergens); -- calledalso impoon, and deloo.
A place or an establishment where bleaching is done.
The business, the place of business, or the goods, of a makerof, or dealer in, oils.
The triangular middle part of each segment of the shell of abarnacle.
A dish made of fowls, veal, or other meat of small animals cutinto pieces, and stewed in a gravy.
One of a sect in the early Christian church which rejected thedoctrine of the Trinity; -- called also patripassian.
The chipmunk; also, the chickaree or red squirrel. [U.S.]
A small spoon used in stirring and sipping tea, coffee, etc.,and for other purposes.
To force; to constrain; to compel to yield. [Obs.] Spenser.
