An instrument which shows whether there is more or lessmoisture in the atmosphere, without indicating its amount.
The arrangement or system of veins, as in the wing of aninsect, or in the leaves of a plant. See Illust. in Appendix.
Capable of having an oath administered to. [Obs.] Shak.
To import or export in violation of the customs laws.
A child born of a white father and Indian mother. [S. Amer.]
With that violation of law called a rout. See 5th Rout, 4.
Having more than one axis; developing in more than a singleline or plain; -- opposed to Ant: monoaxial.
A laboring man; a man who earns his daily support by manuallabor.
The lower or apparently anterior petal of an orchidaceousflower, often of a very curious shape.
A newspaper; a printed sheet published periodically; esp., theofficial journal published by the British government, and containinglegal and state notices.

A style of ornamentation either painted, inlaid, or carved inlow relief. It consists of a pattern in which plants, fruits,foliage, etc., as well as figures of men and animals, real orimaginary, are fantastically interlaced or put together.
Imitation parchment, made by soaking unsized paper in dilutesulphuric acid.
One who pronounces, utters, or declares; also, a pronouncingbook.
Belonging to, or in the style of, Tully (Marcus TulliusCicero).
The first month of the year, containing thirty-one days.
A handsaw with coarse teeth which have but a slight set, usedfor cutting wood in the direction of the fiber; -- called alsoripping saw.
A fleshy-leaved herb (Rhodiola rosea); rosewort; -- so calledbecause the roots have the odor of roses.
A piece of ground taken out of any regular ground plot orfloor, so as to make a court, yard, etc.; -- sometimes written quink.Gwilt.
To bring back a metal to the metallic form, as from an oxide orsolution; to reduce. [Obs.]

The art or practice of using the manual alphabet or ofcommunicating thoughts by sings made by the hands and fingers; asubstitute for spoken or written language in intercourse with thedeaf and dumb. See Dactylalogy.
One who makes or enacts a law or system of laws; a legislator.
A vain or blustering boaster; a braggart; a braggadocio. Sir T.Herbert.
A crinoid of the genus Antedon and related genera. When youngthey are fixed by a stem. When adult they become detached and clingto seaweeds, etc., by their dorsal cirri; -- called also featherstars.
An accessory plume arising from the posterior side of the stemof the contour feathers of many birds; -- called also aftershaft. SeeIllust. of Feather.
An exchange, or place where merchants, bankers, etc., meet forbusiness at certain hours; esp., the Stock Exchange of Paris.
Having greater length than breadth, esp. when rectangular.
The laying of the first courses of stone in a foundation.[Eng.]
One of the larger measures of force, amounting to one milliondynes.
Of or pertaining to physic nuts, the seeds of plants of thegenus Jatropha.
Distance of any heavenly body south of the equator; southdeclination; south latitude.
The arch or rib which crosses a Gothic vault diagonally.
A photographic picture taken on an iron plate by a collodionprocess; -- familiarly called tintype.
The region of the skull, in the temporal fossa back of theorbit, where the great wing of the sphenoid, the temporal, theparietal, and the frontal hones approach each other.
Any grouse of the genus Lagopus, of which numerous species areknown. The feet are completely feathered. Most of the species arebrown in summer, but turn white, or nearly white, in winter.
A whitish, granular rock, consisting of feldspar and quartzintimately mixed; -- sometimes called whitestone, and leptynite.
A lining of planks or boards (rarely of metal) for protectingan embankment.
A species of merganser (M. merganser) of Northern Europe andAmerica; -- called also merganser, dundiver, sawbill, sawneb,shelduck, and sheldrake. See Merganser.
To give strength or support to; to confirm. [Obs.] Fuller.
Not having good repute; disreputable; disgraceful; inglorius.[R.] Shak.
The first month of the jewish ecclesiastical year, formerlyanswering nearly to the month of April, now to March, of theChristian calendar. See Abib.
To cleanse, as open drains which are entered by the tide, bystirring up the sediment when the tide ebbs.
A yellow crystalline substance having a peculiar unpleasantodor, resembling the quinones, and obtained from beechwood tar andcoal tar, as also by the oxidation of xylidine; -- called alsoxyloquinone.
An instrument for dividing lines, describing circles, etc.,compasses. See Compasses.
A mineral identical in composition with calcite or carbonate oflime, but differing from it in its crystalline form and some of itsphysical characters.
An igneous rock of semiglassy nature, having a luster likepitch.
One of several shores used to hold a ship firmly and preventher moving while the blocks are knocked away before launching.
An outbuilding for washing, esp. one for washing clothes; alaundry.

An albuminous body present in dead muscle, being formed in theprocess of coagulation which takes place in rigor mortis; the clotformed in the coagulation of muscle plasma. See Muscle plasma, underPlasma.
The omission of some person who ought to have been made aplaintiff or defendant in a suit, or of some cause of action whichought to be joined.
A winding and circuitous way; a roundabout course; a shift.
The precincts within which a bailiff has jurisdiction; thelimits of a bailiff's authority.
Private grudge or quarrel; as, domestic simulties. [Obs.] B.Jonson.
A species of figwort or Scrophularia (S. vernalis), and otherspecies of the same genus, mostly perennials with inconspicuouscoarse flowers.
One who, or that which, blusters; a noisy swaggerer.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a nitrogenous acid ofosmium, H2N2Os2O5, forming a well-known series of yellow salts.
Attachment to the system or doctrines of Moses; that which ispeculiar to the Mosaic system or doctrines.
Defamatory by denial of desert; derogatory; calumnious. Sir T.Browne.
Wearing a helmet; furnished with or having a helmet or helmet-shaped part; galeate.
The repetition of a word or phrase at the beginning and anotherat the end of successive clauses; as, Justice came down from heavento view the earth; Justice returned to heaven, and left the earth.
A well or opening, through the successive floors of a warehouseor manufactory, through which goods are raised or lowered. [U.S.]Bartlett.
A salt of fungic acid. [Formerly written also fungiate.]
The privileges, prerogatives, or retinue of a court. [Obs.]Bacon.
A strap placed across a man's forehead to assist him incarrying a pack on his back. [Local, U. S.] Bartlett.
Bowed in the form of an arch; -- called also arched.
To be guilty of; to offend; to sin against; to wrong. [Obs.]Chaucer.
The act of marrying, or the state of being married, threetimes; also, the offense of having three husbands or three wives atthe same time.
Lydian stone; basanite; -- so called because used to test thepurity of gold and silver by the streak which is left upon the stonewhen it is rubbed by the metal. See Basanite.
To bedeck; to array or equip; to adorn. [Archaic] Milton.
Shaped like a boat; (Bot.) elongated and having the uppersurface decidedly concave, as the glumes of many grasses.
One of a coterie who exclude others; one who from real ofaffected fastidiousness limits his acquaintance to a select few.
Bent or turned abruptly inwards, or toward the axis, as thepetals of a flower.
Inflammation of the vagina, or the genital canal, usually ofits mucous living membrane.
The Muse that presides over eloquence and heroic poetry; motherof Orpheus, and chief of the nine Muses.
To deprive of soul, spirit, or principle. [R.] Shelton.
A muscle that serves to raise some part, as the lip or theeyelid.
Consisting of four; requiring four participants. [Scot. orGolf]
A provisional group in which are placed a number of lowmicroscopic organisms of doubtful nature. Some are probably plants,others animals.
Resembling, or covered with a substance resembling, rust;affected with rust; rubiginous.
Full of dislike; disaffected; malign; disagreeable. [Obs.]Spenser.
Relating to what is now called the Plutonic theory of theearth, first advanced by Dr. James Hutton. Lyell.
To vote or vote with. [Obs.] "Suffragating tribes." Dryden.
A metamere of the vertebrate skeleton; an osteomere; avertebra. Owen.
The act of interposing; interposition; intervention.
A tumultuous crowd of low people; a rabble. "Rude rablement."Spenser.
A kind of goggles, used to protect the eyes form glare, etc.
In consideration that; seeing that; since; because that; --followed by as. See under For, prep.
One who, or that which, stiffens anything, as a piece of stiffcloth in a cravat.
A thick piece of timber in the form of a knee, placed acrossthe stem of a ship to strengthen the fore part and unite the bows oneach side. Totten.
One of the series of boilers in which the cane juice is treatedin making sugar; especially, the last boiler of the series. Ure.
One to whom a fine of land was ackowledged. Blackstone.
The concluding part of an oration; especially, a final summingup and enforcement of an argument. Burke.
A small tree of the genus Citrus (C. Japonica) growing in Chinaand Japan; also, its small acid, orange-colored fruit used forpreserves.
Of or pertaining to photogeny; producing or generating light.
In general, that which is set off, from, before, or against,something; as: --
The land belonging, or yielding revenue, to a parish church orecclesiastical benefice.
A part of a machine or instrument which directs its motion oraction.
In plate armor, a suspended plate in from of the thigh. SeeIllust. of Tasses.
A raft or float, used principally on the Pacific coast of SouthAmerica.
The plant costmary, which was formerly much used for flavoringale.
The small apple-shaped or pear-shaped fruit of an Americanshrub (Pyrus arbutifolia) growing in damp thickets; also, the shrub.
Being of the first production; primitive; original. [Obs.]Ainsworth.
A species of flea (Sarcopsylla, or Pulex, penetrans), whichburrows beneath the skin. See Chigoe.
Of or pertaining to the Glaucium or horned poppy; -- formerlyapplied to an acid derived from it, now known to be fumaric acid.
The seigniory, dignity, or lordship of a marquis; the territorygoverned by a marquis.
A European species of lavender (Lavandula spica), whichproduces a volatile oil. See Spike.
The space between two axes. See Axis, 6.The doors, windows, niches, and the like, are then placed centrallyin the interaxes. Gwilt.
Fit for plowing or tillage; -- hence, often applied to landwhich has been plowed or tilled.
To sprout; to bud; to shoot; to begin to vegetate, as a plantor its seed; to begin to develop, as a germ. Bacon.
A substance found in the pollen of certain plants. [R.]
The state or quality of being heavy in its various senses;weight; sadness; sluggishness; oppression; thickness.
Producing cells; -- applied esp. to lymphatic, or adenoid,tissue.
A moaning or sighing sound or noise; a sough. [Obs.] Chaucer.
An unexplained epithet used by Chaucer in reference to ships.By some it is defined as "dancing (on the wave)"; by others as"opposing," "warlike." T. R. Lounsbury.
Lying down; -- used of beasts of the chase, as couchant is ofbeasts of prey.
A South African antelope (Alcelaphus albifrons), having a largewhite spot on the forehead.
To yoke or harness, as oxen to a vehicle. [South Africa]
A portion of dead bone which becomes separated from the soundportion, as in necrosis.
A union, association, or society; -- used in names of Germanorganizations.
A wind instrument or pipe, with a horn at each end, -- used inWales.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, emotion or suffering. [R.]Chalmers.
A kind of latch whose bolt may be so locked by a detent that itcan not be opened from the inside by the handle, or from the outsideby the latch key. Knight.
Once more; again; -- used by the auditors and spectators ofplays, concerts, and other entertainments, to call for a repetitionof a particular part.
The spasmodic ejection of matter from the stomach through themouth.
The Diet, or House of Representatives, of the German empire,which is composed of members elected for a term of three years by thedirect vote of the people. See Bundesrath.
To send in; to inject; to infuse; -- the correlative of emit.[R.] Boyle.
A small shield, especially one of an approximately ellipticform, or crescent-shaped.
The main part of either auricle of the heart as distinct fromthe auricular appendix. Also, the whole articular portion of theheart.
A distinct articulation given in playing quick notes on theflute, by striking the tongue against the roof of the mouth; double-tonguing.
A liquid or semiliquid preparation of a consistence thinnerthan an ointment, applied to the skin by friction, esp. one used as asedative or a stimulant.
A diffusible substance formed from albumin by the action ofnatural or artificial gastric juice. See Peptone.
Cell-like; -- applied to the corpuscles of lymph, blood, chyle,etc.
The tonic or first tone of the scale in which a piece orpassage is written; the fundamental tone of the chord, to which allthe modulations of the piece are referred; -- called also key tone.
An animal or plant which is much below the ordinary size of itsspecies or kind; especially, a diminutive human being.
A petition; esp., a written one, with a certificate that theconditions have been complied with.
An Australian honeysucker (Myzomela sanguineolata); -- socalled from the bright red color of the male bird.
Having a margin distinct in appearance or structure.
The condition of being nebulated; also, a clouded, or ill-defined, color mark.
Ethane; -- sometimes so called because regarded as consistingof two methyl radicals. See Ethane.
A gaseous hydrocarbon, C3H4, homologous with acetylene;propine. CH3.C.CH
The quality or state of being prim; affected formality orniceness; preciseness; stiffness.
In a bibulous manner; with profuse imbibition or absorption. DeQuincey.
Originally, a solid exterior angle, as of a building; now,commonly, one of the selected pieces of material by which the corneris marked.
A kind of ocher which is used in some parts of England inmarking sheep. [Prov. Eng.]
An instrument signaling the correct time to distant points byelectricity.
The science of the determination of the density of vapors andgases.
The decimal point; the dot placed at the left of a decimalfraction, to separate it from the whole number which it follows. Theterm is sometimes also applied to other marks of separation.
The murder of one's sister; also, one who murders or killsone's own sister. Johnson.
Greater, in respect to scales, intervals, etc., when used inopposition to minor; major. Moore (Encyc. of Music).
The tenets of the Church of Rome; the Roman Catholic religion.
A breed of sheep originally from Spain, noted for the finenessof its wool.
A hydrocarbon radical, CH2.(CO)2, from malonic acid.
One who vamps; one who pieces an old thing with something new;a cobbler.
One who, or that which, proscribes, denounces, or prohibits.
Capable of being moved by entreaty; pitiful; tender. Milton.
An officer who has charge of a ballot box. [Obs.] Harrington.
A genus of ground beetles, including numerous species. Theydevour many injurious insects.
Any one of numerous species of elasmobranch fishes of the orderPlagiostomi, found in all seas.
Containing glands; consisting of glands; pertaining to glands;resembling glands.
The state or quality of being isostatic. Specif. (Geol.),

An American bird of the genus Cassicus, allied to the starlingsand orioles, remarkable for its skillfully constructed and suspendednest; the crested oriole. The name is also sometimes given to thepiping crow, an Australian bird.
An offset where a wall or bank of earth, etc., retreats,leaving a shelf or footing.
One skilled in simples, or medicinal plants; a simpler. Sir T.Browne.

Any Old Word rodent of the genus Hystrix, having the backcovered with long, sharp, erectile spines or quills, sometimes a footlong. The common species of Europe and Asia (Hystrix cristata) is thebest known.
The connective tissue sheath which surrounds a muscle, andsends partitions inwards between the bundles of muscular fibers.
The principles, purposes, and methods of the Fenians.
To sweep over or across; to pass over rapidly. [R.] Thomson.
The segment of the body of an insect to which the wings areattached; the thorax. Kirby.
A genus of marine gastropod mollusks, having a conical orlimpetlike shell, with an opening at the apex; -- called also keyholelimpet.
Having no weight; imponderable; hence, light. Shak.
An instrument of torture for compressing the thumb; athumbscrew.
Great anxiety accompanied by painful constriction at the upperpart of the belly, often with palpitation and oppression.
A parish lying without the walls of, or in a remote part of, atown. Graunt.
A European mountain trout (Salvelinus alpinus); -- called alsoBavarian charr.
A lamp with lenses or reflectors to collect the rays of lightand throw them in a given direction; -- used in lighthouses.
A key used to raise, or throw back, the latch of a door, esp. anight latch.
A movable part of a rail; or of opposite rails, fortransferring cars from one track to another.

The projected spot or circle of light used to illuminatebrilliantly a single person or object or group on the stage; leavingthe rest of the stage more or less unilluminated; hence, conspicuouspublic notice. [Cant or Colloq.]
A little shoot; a twig; a sucker. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
To furnish with a fringe; to form a fringe upon; to adorn aswith fringe. Fuller.
A dwarf supposed to dwell in rocks and hills and to be skillfulin working metals.
Upraised; erect; -- said of the ears of an animal. Mason.
A broken gait of a horse, between an amble and a gallop; --commonly called a Canterbury gallop.
Arrest of development of any organ, so that it remains animperfect formation or is absorbed.
The office, jurisdiction, or duty, of a pastor; pastorate.
Putting the whole foot upon the ground in walking, as somemammals.
To have an opinion; to judge; to think; to suppose. South.
Situated in front of the back; immediately in front, or on theventral side the dorsal part of the vertebral column.
That portion of fibrovascular bundles which corresponds to theinner bark; the liber tissue; -- distinguished from xylem.
The surface of the sand of one section of a mold where it meetsthat of another section.
The daisy (Bellis perennis). The name is often applied also tothe ox-eye daisy and to the China aster. Longfellow.
One who chooses; one who has the power or right of choosing; anelector. Burke.
A stated meeting of preachers and others, invested withauthority to take cognizance of ecclesiastical matters.
A unit of force equal to the force which, acting for onesecond, will give a pound a velocity of one foot per second; --proposed by J.D.Everett, an English physicist.
An iron attachment on one end of a mast or boom, with a ring,through which another mast or boom is rigged out and secured; awythe. R. H. Dana, Jr.
A mineral of a grayish-green or bluish color, consisting of thephosphates of iron, manganese, and lithia.
That portion of the soil formed by the decomposition of animalor vegetable matter. It is a valuable constituent of soils. Graham.
To make search; to try to find something. [Obs.] -- v. t.
Of or pertaining to spasm; spasmodic; especially, pertaining totonic spasm; tetanic.
To stick over, as with sharp points pressed in; to mark byinfixing points or spots here and there; to pierce.Truth shall retire Bestuck with slanderous darts. Milton.

A sort of riddle in which it is required to discover a chosenword from various combinations of its letters, or of some of itsletters, which form other words; -- thus, to discover the chosen wordchatter form cat, hat, rat, hate, rate, etc. B. Jonson.
Any species of very small woodpeckers of the genus Picumnus andallied genera. Their tail feathers are not stiff and sharp at thetips, as in ordinary woodpeckers.

A contrivance for carrying objects from place to place; esp.,one for conveying grain, coal, etc., -- as a spiral or screw turningin a pipe or trough, an endless belt with buckets, or a truck runningalong a rope.

One of the Moravians; -- so called from the settlement ofHerrnhut (the Lord's watch) made, about 1722, by the Moravians at theinvitation of Nicholas Lewis, count of Zinzendorf, upon his estate inthe circle of Bautzen.
The second mast, or that which is next above the lower mast,and below the topgallant mast.
A plant of the family of grasses, and genus Bambusa, growing intropical countries.
A tribe of North American Indians, which formerly occupied theregion between the Wabash and Mississippi rivers.
The person to whom any property is legally conveyed.
Bread baked in a mold, and scooped out, to serve minces upon.Bishop.
The octave, or interval which includes all the tones of thediatonic scale.
A follower of the opinions of Molina, a Spanish Jesuit (inrespect to grace); an opposer of the Jansenists.
Not broken or fractured; unharmed; whole. [Obs.] Chapman.
The demandant in a common recovery after judgment. Wharton.
An American genus of perennial herbs with delicate blossoms; --sometimes called spring beauty.
A bird having a distinct band of color across the tail, as thehen harrier.
A number of sheaves set together in the field; a stook.
A perspective representation or general view of an object.
Having a rostellum, or small beak; terminating in a beak.
An old form of gunlock, as the flintlock, which ignites thepriming by a spark; perhaps originally, a matchlock. Hence, a gunhaving such a lock.
Any one of the small branches on a stag's head. [Obs.] Howell.
A vessel for holding or conveying water, or for sprinklingwater on cloth, plants, etc.
The root of a plant which penetrates the earth directlydownward to a considerable depth without dividing.
The quality or state of being utter, or extreme; extremity;utmost; uttermost. [R.]
The war cry, or gathering word, of a Highland clan in Scotland;hence, any rallying cry. Sir W. Scott.
One of the hereditary nobility among the Tatars, esp. one ofthe second class.
The examination or study of the soft palate, posterior nares,etc., by means of a laryngoscopic mirror introduced into the pharynx.
An instrument for copying drawings on the same or a differentscale; a form of the pantograph.
A kind of stone containing native vitriol or subphate of iron,used in making ink.
A stone erected over a grave, to preserve the memory of thedeceased.
A Chinese alloy of nickel, zinc, and copper, resembling Germansilver.
To free from ballast; to discharge ballast from. Totten.
One who, or that which, cools or freezes, as a refrigerator, orthe tub and can used in the process of freezing ice cream.
In Greenland, an insular hill or mountain surrounded by an icesheet.
Same as Drawbar (b). Called also draglink, and drawlink. [U.S.]
An amorphous carbohydrate found in the vegetable kingdom, esp.in unripe fruits. It is associated with cellulose, and is convertedinto substances of the pectin group.
A short musical dramatic piece, of a light and pleasing,sometimes a burlesque, character; an interlude introduced between theacts of a play or an opera.
A written confession of faith; a formal statement of foctrines.
To honor, as some day, person, or nation, by a discharge ofcannon or small arms, by dipping colors, by cheers, etc.
An alkaloid associated with cocaine in coca leaves(Erythroxylon coca), and extracted as a thick, yellow oil, having apungent taste and odor.
A large, dark-colored, South American monkey, of the genusLagothrix, having a long prehensile tail.
One who boozes; a toper; a guzzler of alcoholic liquors; abouser.
Trusting beforehand; hence, overconfident. [Obs.] Baxter.
An advocate for a metallic currency, or a paper currency alwaysconvertible into gold.
A pitcher-shaped, or flask-shaped, organ or appendage of aplant, as the leaves of the pitcher plant, or the little bladderliketraps of the bladderwort (Utricularia).
A returning ascent or ascension; acclivity. Cowper.
To make indefinite; to obliterate or confuse the definition orlimitations of.
A genus of Lower Silurian trilobites in which the glabella andcheeks form three rounded elevations on the head.
Wearing, or entitled to wear, a coronet; of noble birth orrank.
The curve which on a given surface and with a given perimetercontains the greatest area. Tait.
An inversion of the natural order of words; as, echoed thehills, for, the hills echoed.
That part of a testeator's estate wwhich is not disposed of inhis will by particular and special legacies and devises, and whichremains after payment of debts and legacies.
The person who selects the appointee. See Appointee, 2.
The government or jurisdiction of a satrap; a principality.Milton.
A kind of pad worn on the leg under the boot. [Obs.] Nares.
A substance which prevents or retards putrefaction, ordestroys, or protects from, putrefactive organisms; as, salt,carbolic acid, alcohol, cinchona.
A little lady; -- applied by the writers of Queen Elizabeth'stime, in the abbreviated form Lakin, to the Virgin Mary.
A genus of aroideous plants, of which some species arecultivated for their immense leaves (which are often curiouslyblotched with white and red), and others (in Polynesia) for food.
A substitution, as of one part of speech for another, of onegender, number, case, person, tense, mode, or voice, of the sameword, for another.
Having no drift or direction; without aim; purposeless.
Living upon the exterior of another animal; ectozoic; -- saidof external parasites.
To please; -- chiefly used impersonally. [Obs.] " Sith itlyketh you." Chaucer.
A muscle having three heads; specif., the great extensor of theforearm, arising by three heads and inserted into the olecranon atthe elbow.
Any one of three metameric hydrocarbons, C4H8, of the ethyleneseries. They are gaseous or easily liquefiable.
A present given to a guest or stranger, or to a foreignambassador.
A blood feud; private revenge for the murder of a kinsman.
To raise the anchor of, as a ship; to weigh anchor. [Obs.]Heywood.
Moderately cold; cold and raw or damp so as to cause shivering;causing or feeling a disagreeable sensation of cold, or a shivering.
To consign beforehand; to make a previous consignment of.
Cleft or separated into eight segments, as a calyx.
A fetter for horses, or cattle, when turned out to graze; --chiefly used in the plural.
The last syllable but one of a word; the syllable preceding thefinal one.
A long rope or chain by which an animal is fastened, as to astake, so that it can range or feed only within certain limits.
A large antelope (Alcelaphus bubalis) of Egypt and the Desertof Sahara, supposed by some to be the fallow deer of the Bible.
Formed with different shapes; having various forms; variform.
The principles of painting introduced by Raphael, the Italianpainter.
The finest and whitest bread made in the Middle Ages; -- calledalso paynemain, payman. [Obs.]
That refractive condition of the eye in which the rays of lightare all brought accurately and without undue effort to a focus uponthe retina; -- opposed to hypermetropia, myopia, an astigmatism.
A tax or toll paid for building or repairing the walls of afortified town.

A morbid condition produced by exhalations from decayingvegetable matter in contact with moisture, giving rise to fever andague and many other symptoms characterized by their tendency to recurat definite and usually uniform intervals.
Reflecting a milky or pearly light from the interior; having anopaline play of colors.
To act secretly, or in an underhand way; to tamper. [Obs.]Wright.
One who acknowledges no head or superior. Dr. Gauden.
A dissertation or digression appended to a work, and containinga more extended exposition of some important point or topic.
An instrument of iron, with sharp prongs, attached to a boot orshoe to enable the wearer to walk securely upon ice; a creeper. Kane.
A house in which tender plants are cultivated and shelteredfrom the weather.
Among Spanish Americans, a foreigner, esp. an Englishman orAmerican; -- often used as a term of reproach.
A light skiff or rowboat used on the Bosporus; also, aLevantine vessel of larger size.
One of the oxides of manganese; -- called also gray manganeseore. It occurs in brilliant steel-gray or iron-black crystals, alsomassive.

A poweful vegetable alkaloid, found, associated withstrychnine, in the seeds of different species of Strychnos,especially in the Nux vomica. It is less powerful than strychnine.Called also brucia and brucina.
Having the surface appearing as if dusty, or covered with finedew.
A number of animals or plants living or growing together,beyond their usual range.
The liver of the lobster, which becomes green when boiled; --called also tomalline.
An instrument for measuring the size of the womb. Knight.
To go ashore from a ship or boat; to disembark; to put ashore.
A yellow crystalline substance allied to pyrrol, obtained bythe distillation of gelatin.
Having a sting; covered with prickles; sharp like a prickle.
Resembling trachyte; -- used to define the structure of certainrocks.
Spars or timbers set up as a support against the side of abuilding.
Promoting uterine contractions, or parturition.-- n.
An Englishman; a subject or inhabitant of Great Britain, esp.one in the British military or naval service. [Now used jocosely]
Apt to start; skittish; shy; -- said especially of a horse.[Colloq.]
A copious gummy secretion of the humor of the eyelids, inconsequence of some disorder; blearedness; lippitude.
Of or pertaining to Napoleon I., or his family; resembling, orhaving the qualities of, Napoleon I. Lowell.
The larva of any geometrid moth, as the cankeworm; a geometer;a measuring worm.
A scaly multiple fruit resulting from the ripening of an amentin certain plants, as the hop or pine; a cone. See Cone, n., 3.
One of numerous species of marine gastropod shells, belongingto Ranella and allied genera.
A list of passengers in a public vehicle, or of the baggage orgods transported by a common carrier on a land route. When the goodsare transported by water, the list is called a bill of lading.
A liquid hydrocarbon, C10H18, of the acetylene series. It isproduced artificially.
A prickle growing on the bark, as in some brambles and roses.Lindley.
A figure of speech employed when a speaker having begun to saya thing stops abruptly: thus, "He is a man of so much honor andcandor, and of such generosity -- but I need say no more."
The act of reshipping; also, that which is reshippped.
Pertaining to ancient France, or Gaul; Gallic. [R.]
Befitting a church or a churchman; becoming to a clergyman.Shak.
A kind of antidote for poisons; a counter poison formerly invogue. [Obs.]
A little intoxicated; fuddled; stupid with liquor; bousy.[Colloq.] C. Kingsley.
One of the two bodies or nuclei (called male and femalepronuclei) which unite to form the first segmentation nucleus of animpregnated ovum.
A reckless, furious man; a person urged by furious passions,and regardless of consequence; a wild ruffian.
The act of entombing or burying, or state of being entombed;burial. Barrow.
To free from a gage or pledge; to disengage. [Obs.] Holland.
The removal by operation of a portion of a limb; particularly,the removal of a portion of a bone in the vicinity of a joint; theact or process of cutting out.
The act of discoursing or reasoning; range, as from thought tothought. Coleridge.
A partner or associate in some civil or ecclesiastical officeor employment. It is never used of partners in trade or manufactures.
A morbid state produced by the use of iodine and its compounds,and characterized by palpitation, depression, and general emaciation,with a pustular eruption upon the skin.
The person in whose hands is the property attached byarrestment.
A brownish black native hydrocarbon occurring in elastic orjellylike masses.
Leadership; preponderant influence or authority; -- usuallyapplied to the relation of a government or state to its neighbors orconfederates. Lieber.
Affording pabulum, or food; alimental. [R.]  Sir T. Browne.
Destruction; -- opposed to creation. [R.] Cudworth.
A ravine caused by heavy rains or a watercourse. [Texas & N.Mex.]

A large Asiatic antelope (Budorcas taxicolor) native of thehigher parts of the Himalayas and other lofty mountains. Its head andneck resemble those of the ox, and its tail is like that of the goat.Called also budorcas.
The common feeling and interest of the Slavonic race.
A substance isomeric with, and resembling, indigo blue, andaccompanying it as a side product, in its artificial production.
To thrust oakum into (seams or chinks) with a chisel , thepoint of a knife, or a chinsing iron; to calk slightly. Chinsingiron, a light calking iron.
The top stone of the gable end of a house. Halliwell.
A stout silk having satin stripes, -- used for furniture.
In a natural manner or way; according to the usual course ofthings; spontaneously.
A hero, fabled to have been the son of Jupiter and Alcmena, andcelebrated for great strength, esp. for the accomplishment of histwelve great tasks or "labors."
A soft, whitish, coral-like stone, formed of broken shells andcorals, found in the southern United States, and used for roadbedsand for building material, as in the fort at St. Augustine, Florida.
Chopped meat, bread, etc., used to stuff legs of veal or otherjoints; stuffing; farce. Bacon.
A pot containing melted tin into which the plates are dipped tobe coated.
One who crucifies; one who subjects himself or another to apainful trial.
Of or pertaining to the tribe of ruminants of which the goat,or genus Capra, is the type.
To turn, or transfer homage and service, from one lord toanother. This is the act of feudatories, vassals, or tenants, uponthe alienation of the estate. Blackstone.
A portion ofthe printed sheet, in certain sizes of books, thatis cut off before folding.
A white, crystalline substance, obtained from also, byextension, any similar substance.
Pertaining to charcoal, or partaking of its qualities.
The inward part of a building; the interior. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The framework of some pods, as the cress, which remains afterthe valves drop off. Gray.
Animals having two hands; -- a term applied by Cuvier to man asa special order of Mammalia.
Promoting the discharge of bile from the system.-- n.
Of, pertaining to, or in the region of, the backbone, orvertebral column; rachidian; vertebral.
Destitute of life; lacking animation; unanimated. Pope.
One of a special breed of hounds used for chasing foxes.
The twisting of a rope or cable, as it is running out. [Eng.]
A liquid hydrocarbon, C10H22, of the paraffin series, includingseveral isomeric modifications.
Omission; a figure of syntax, by which one or more words, whichare obviously understood, are omitted; as, the virtues I admire, for,the virtues which I admire.
The stipe when developed into an internode between calyx andcorolla, as in the Pink family. Gray.
The grand division of the animal kingdom which includes thesponges; -- called also Spongida, Spongiaria, Spongiozoa, andPorifera.
A thin, sour beer, made by pouring warm water on rye or barleymeal and letting it ferment, -- much used by the Russians. [writtenalso quas.]
A plant that bears naked seeds (i. e., seeds not inclosed in anovary), as the common pine and hemlock. Cf. Angiosperm.
An ammonite; -- so called from its form, which resembles thatof a coiled snake.
The long jump, with weights in the hands, -- the most importantof the exercises of the Pentathlon.
An instrument for making very thin sections for microscopicalexamination.
An interpreter; -- so called in the Levant and other parts ofthe East.
A kind of striped cotton fabric, usually of superior qualityand striped with blue or red on white.
The quality or state of being jovial. Sir T. Herbert.
A rumbling or gurgling noise produced by wind in the bowels.Dunglison.
To attack with heavy artillery; to batter with cannon shot.
A variety of dog, of remarkable ferocity, courage, and tenacityof grip; -- so named, probably, from being formerly employed inbaiting bulls.

A long, slender rope made of hemp or strips of hide, esp. onewith a noose; -- used as a lasso for catching cattle, horses, etc.,and for picketing a horse so that he can graze without wandering.[Mexico & Western U.S.]
A follower of Eudoxius, patriarch of Antioch and Constantinoplein the 4th century, and a celebrated defender of the doctrines ofArius.

The force exerted between the atoms of elementary substancewhereby they unite to form chemical compounds; chemical attaction;affinity; -- sometimes used as a general expression for chemicalactivity or relationship.
Pertaining to pot herbs; of the nature or having the qualitiesof herbs for cookery; esculent. Sir T. Browne.
Adhesion of the tail of a sheep to the wool from excoriationproduced by contact with the feces; -- called also tagbelt. [Obs.]
superl. Most remote; most in advance; farthest. See Further, a.
To make ready; -- often used reflexively. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The goddess of wisdom, of war, of the arts and sciences, ofpoetry, and of spinning and weaving; -- identified with the GrecianPallas Athene.
A dangerous inflammatory swelling of a horse's breast, justopposite the heart.
Any one of a series of nitro derivatives of phenol. They areyellow oily or crystalline substances and have well-defined acidproperties, as picric acid.
A European fish (Pagellus centrodontus); the sea bream orbraise.

A Highland air, suited to the particular passion which themusician would either excite or assuage; generally applied to thoseairs that are played on the bagpipe before the Highlanders when theygo out to battle. Jamieson.
The aggregate value of the different stocks in which a loan togovernment is now usually funded. M'Culloch.
Containing or supporting glands; consisting of glands;pertaining to glands.
Overcome by some foolish passion or desire; affected byinfatuation.
A gobioid fish (Eleotris gyrinus) of the Southern UnitedStates; -- called also sleeper.
The weight when the tare has been deducted, and tret is yet tobe allowed. M
To afflict with, or perish from, hunger. [Obs.] Spenser.
A skein or hank of rope yarns wound round with yarns ormarline, -- used for stoppers, straps, etc.
Reclined, as a leaf; bent downward, so that the point, as of astem or leaf, is lower than the base.
Any one of numerous species of the genus Pica and relatedgenera, allied to the jays, but having a long graduated tail.
Pertaining to the peculiar species of rhyme called assonance;not consonant.
A religious house presided over by a prior or prioress; --sometimes an offshoot of, an subordinate to, an abbey, and calledalso cell, and obedience. See Cell, 2.
A kind of Muscovite, or potash mica, containing water.
A man who ascends or flies in an aircraft; a flying machinepilot.
God with us; -- an appellation of the Christ. Is. vii. 14.Matt. i. 23.
The most westerly branch of the great Slavic family of nations,numbering now more than 6,000,000, and found principally in Bohemiaand Moravia.
A name given to four of the twelve astrological "houses."[Obs.] Chaucer.
Buoys, taken collectively; a series of buoys, as for theguidance of vessels into or out of port; the providing of buoys.
The quality or state of being pertinent; pertinence. [Obs.]
A small bird. (Silvia hortensis), which is highly prized by theItalians for the delicacy of its flesh in the autumn, when it has fedon figs, grapes, etc.
Having the orbital index relatively large; having the orbitsnarrow transversely; -- opposed to microseme.
A kind of openwork edging made of serpentine braid.
An artificial dyestuff obtained as an orange-yellow powder, andregarded as a phenyl hydrazine derivative of tartaric and sulphonicacids.
A hydrocarbon radical regarded as an essential residue ofpropine and allied compounds.
To cause to flow together, as water drawn from several streams.[Obs.] Burton.
A white or flesh-red mineral, of the zeolite, occurring inisometric crystals. By friction, it acquires a weak electricity;hence its name.
The resistance which a body meets with from the surface onwhich it moves. It may be resistance to sliding motion, or to rollingmotion.
A certain reed stop in the organ, of a quality of toneresembling that of the oboe. [Corruptly written cromona.]
A playfellow. [Obs.] [Also, playfeer, playphere.] Holinsheld.
The first word of ancient charters in England, confirming agrant made by a former king; hence, a royal grant.
To loose from pinions or manacles; to free from restraint.Goldsmith.
In a cursed manner; miserably; in a manner to be detested;enormously. [Low]
One who, or that which, macerates; an apparatus for convertingpaper or fibrous matter into pulp.
A variety of spinel, of a dark color, found at Candy, inCeylon.
A genus of trees including the mangrove. See Mangrove.

The state of compulsion or necessity in which a person isinfluenced, whether by the unlawful restrain of his liberty or byactual or threatened physical violence, to incur a civil liability orto commit an offense.
Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an acid obtainedas a white crystalline substance by the distillation of mucic acid,or by the oxidation of furfurol.
A kind of linen cloth made in Normandy, the thread of which ispartly blanches before it is woven.

The handle by which the bed of a hand press, holding the formof type, etc., is run in under the platen and out again; -- sometimesapplied to the whole apparatus by which the form is moved under theplaten.
A wading bird of the genus Grus, and allied genera, of variousspecies, having a long, straight bill, and long legs and neck.
A South American ant bird of the genus Hylactes; -- called alsobarking bird.
Consisting of or containing matter like honey; -- said ofcertain encysted tumors.
Having superior influence or power; prevailing; predominant.[R.] Boyle.
Pertaining to, or obtained from, hops; specifically,designating an acid obtained by the decomposition of lupulin.
A contradiction between any words or passages in an author. SirW. Hamilton.
A large African antelope (Alcelaphus Lichtensteini), allied tothe hartbeest, but having shorter and flatter horns, and lacking ablack patch on the face.
A peculiar species of poetry, for the most part devoted tomoral and religious topics, and commonly satirical, -- often used bythe troubadours of the Middle Ages.
A flat member of an order or building, like a flat band orbroad fillet; especially, one of the three bands which make up thearchitrave, in the Ionic order. See Illust. of Column.
A toper; one habitually given to strong drink; a drunkard.Shak.
A rapid dance in six-eight time in which a large number joinhands and dance in various figures, sometimes moving from room toroom. It originated in Provence.
Sword-shaped; resembling a sword in form, as the leaf of theiris, or of the gladiolus.
An insect that deposits its eggs in plants, and occasionsgalls, esp. any small hymenopteran of the genus Cynips and alliedgenera. See Illust. of Gall.
A monk of the Greek Church; a cenobite, anchoret, or recluse ofthe rule of St. Basil, especially, one on or near Mt. Athos.
A figure by which permission is either seriously or ironicallygranted to some one, to do what he proposes to do; e. g., "He that isunjust, let him be unjust still."
Knowledge of the earth, ground, or soil, obtained byinspection. Chambers.
A large silk-and-cotton kerchief, usually of bright colors,such as those often used by negroes for turbans.
One who, or that which, extends or stretches anything.
A kind of card or comb having rows of metallic teeth orserrated ridges, used in curryng a horse.
A glandular organ which excretes urea and other waste productsfrom the animal body; a urinary gland.
Using the left hand in pitching; said of a pitcher. [Cant]
A group of five notes to be played or sung in the time of fourof the same species.
To revoke or annul by prayer, as something previously prayedfor. [R.] Sir M. Hale.
A whaler's name for a whale more than two years old.
As if dead; lifeless; spiritless; dejected; depressed. Shak.
In amazement; with confusion or astonishment. Shak.
A work of more that ordinary heigh, rising from the levelground of a bastion, etc., and overlooking surrounding parts.
That branch of political economy which relates to theproduction of wealth.
The worship of the earth. G. W. Cox. The Geological Series.
Belonging to the euphuists, or euphuism; affectedly refined.
Joining subject and predicate; copulative. F. A. March.
To insert in a catalogue; to register; to catalogue. [R.]Coles.
To degrade from the rank of a martyr. [Obs.] Fuller.
Enough to fill a plate; as much as a plate will hold.
A staff by means of which a burden is borne by two persons ontheir shoulders.
A second breaking (as of a badly set bone) by the surgeon.
A silky, crystalline, waxy substance, forming the less solublepart of beeswax, and regarded as a palmitate of a higher alcohol ofthe paraffin series; -- called also myricyl alcohol.
One who holds the principles of Puseyism; -- often usedopprobriously.
Brushwood and thorns for making and repairing hedges. [Obs.Eng.]
A beam or bar armed with iron spikes, and turning on a pivot; -- used to block up a passage.
The office or position of an usher; ushership; also, ushers,collectively. [R.]
Having delegated power, as a vicar; vicarious. Barrow.
Becoming turgid or inflated; swelling; growing big.
A small, clear space in the segments of the ovum, the precursorof the nucleus.
The enlargement of a molt caused by rapping the pattern.
A commercial preparation of garancin, yielding fine violettints.
A stone or thick lump of glass, or kind of pestle, flat at thebottom, used for grinding pigments or drugs, etc., upon a slab ofsimilar material.
One who exacts or demands by authority or right; hence, anextortioner; also, one unreasonably severe in injunctions or demands.Jer. Taylor.
To put into disorder; to tumble; to touse. [Colloq.]
Lying or being beyond the mountains; coming from the other sideof the mountains; hence, foreign; barbarous.
A pod dehiscent into two pieces or valves, and having the seedattached at one suture, as that of the pea.
A vessel which receives the wort as it flows from the mashingtub.
A form of government in which the supreme power is vested intwo persons.

The production of an optogram on the retina by thephotochemical action of light on the visual purple; the fixation ofan image in the eye. The object so photographed shows white on apurple or red background. See Visual purple, under Visual.
A colorless variety of chabazite; the original was from Leipa,in Bohemia.
The person or cause that produces or effects a divorce.Drummond.
Containing twelve; twelvefold; increasing by twelves;duodecimal.
A kind of silk lace originally of the color of raw silk, nowsometimes dyed; -- called also blond lace.
Having sense or sensibility; sensitive. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
A genus of yellow-flowered composite perennial herbs; golden-rod.
A leucocyte which plays a part in retrogressive processes bytaking up (eating), in the form of fine granules, the parts to beremoved.
Naturally growing in groups or masses; -- said of manyindividual plants of the same species.
To fortify beforehand; to guard against objection. [Obs.]Fotherby.
A smoothly running passage of short notes (as semiquavers, orsixteenths) uniformly grouped, sung upon one long syllable, as inHandel's oratorios.
A kind of blowgun for discharging arrows, -- used by thesavages of Borneo and adjacent islands.
A West African antelope (Cephalophus rufilotus) of a deep baycolor, with a broad dorsal stripe of black; -- called alsoconquetoon.
Any one of several species of beautiful birds of Australia andNew Guinea, of the genera Ptiloris and Craspidophora, allied to theparadise birds.
A soft grass (Pennisetum typhoideum) found in all tropicalregions, used as food for men and cattle in Central Africa.
A strong, buoyant boat especially designed for saving the livesof shipwrecked people.
To separate, as things cemented or luted; to take the lute orthe clay from. Boyle.
To fill to satiety; to stuff full; to clog; to overload; toburden. See Cloy. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who roams, or hides, among the bushes; especially, inAustralia, an escaped criminal living in the bush.
Tengmalm's or Richardson's owl (Nyctale Tengmalmi); -- socalled from a superstition of the North American Indians that itsnote presages death.
A blackish fish (Hypoplectrus nigricans), of the Sea-bassfamily. It is a native of the West Indies and Florida.
Dressed in a toga or gown; wearing a gown; gowned. [R.] Sir M.Sandys.
To refine in argument; to make very nice distinctions. Milner.
An arctic seal (Lobodon carcinophaga), having the molarsserrated; -- called also crabeating seal.
The mouth of a river, or place where its waters are discharged.[R.]
The quality of a body by which it excites the sensation oftaste.

The doctrine that refers all diseases to morbid changes of thesolid parts of the body. It rests on the view that the solids aloneare endowed with vital properties, and can receive the impression ofagents tending to produce disease.
Pertaining to regicide, or to one committing it; having thenature of, or resembling, regicide. Bp. Warburton.
The half of a lens divided along a plane passing through itsaxis.
A light sword used for thrusting only; especially, the swordworn by civilians of rank in the eighteenth century.
To draggle; to soil, as garments which, in walking, aresuffered to drag in dust, mud, etc. Swift.
Quality of being sterile; infecundity; also, the state of beingfree from germs or spores.
To expurgate, as a book, by omitting or modifying the partsconsidered offensive.
A disturbance; noise and confusion; a quarrel. [Colloq.]
The quality or state of being pompous; pompousness. Thackeray.
An English warbler (Melizophilus provincialis); -- called alsofurze wren, and Dartford warbler.
Relating to objects situated within the eye; esp., relating tothe perception of objects in one's own eye.
An addition to, or a paraphrase of, some part of the Latinservice in the vernacular; -- common in English before theReformation.
A gaseous element found in the atmospheres of the sun and earthand in some rare minerals.
An auxiliary part of a machine which supplies or leads alongthe material operated upon.
To supply with an organ or organs having a special function orfunctions.
Of or pertaining to Albania, a province of Turkey.-- n.
Raving with madness; raging with disordered intellect; affectedwith mania; mad.
Tending to excite; containing excitement; excitative.
The act, method, or process of laying a groundwork orfoundation; hence, elementary instruction; the act or process ofapplying a ground, as of color, to wall paper, cotton cloth, etc.; abasis.
(Dredging, Pile Driving, etc.) A pointed timber attached to aboat and sliding vertically, to thrust into the ground as a means ofanchorage.
A variety of chalcedony, of a clear, deep red, flesh red, orreddish white color. It is moderately hard, capable of a good polish,and often used for seals.
Set between two cottises, -- said of a bend; or between twobarrulets, -- said of a bar or fess.
A sovereign prince in India; -- a title given also to otherpersons of high rank.
The act of process of applying manure; also, the manureapplied.
To thrash in the chaff; also, to cleanse or sift, as barley.[Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
A supporter of extreme doctrines or practice; one who holdsextreme opinions.
An alkaloid produced by the decomposition of solanine, as awhite crystalline substance having a harsh bitter taste.
A musket-proof shield of rope, wood, or metal, which issometimes used for the protection of sappers or riflemen whileattacking a fortress, or of gunners at embrasures; -- now commonlywritten mantlet.
On the hither side of the river Po with reference to Rome; thatis, on the south side.
One who, or that which, polishes; also, that which is used inpolishing. Addison.
A class of Coelenterata, commonly ellipsoidal in shape,swimming by means of eight longitudinal rows of paddles. The separatepaddles somewhat resemble combs.
A machine formerly employed for reducing dislocations of thehumerus.
A frame or fender of rope or junk, laid out at the sides orbows of a vessel to secure it from injury by floating ice.
The process of the first growth of teeth, or the phenomenaattending their issue through the gums; dentition.
The science which treats of diseases, their nature, causes,progress, symptoms, etc.
A division of Tunicata including the common attached ascidians,both simple and compound. Called also Tethioidea.
A genus of grasses including Indian rice. See Indian rice,under Rice.
A liquid hydrocarbon, C6H8, of the valylene series, obtainedfrom distillation products of certain fats and gums.
An alkaloid found in the leaves of the walnut (Juglans regia).
A bladder growing on the root of the tongue of a horse, againstthe windpipe, and stopping the breath.
A remarkable meteorological phenomenon, of the nature of atornado or whirlwind, usually observed over the sea, but sometimesover the land.
To draw again; to make a second draft or copy of; to redraft.
A substance regarded as an element, contained in the atmosphereand remarkable for its chemical inertness. Rayleigh and Ramsay.
An animal of Peru (Lama paco), having long, fine, wooly hair,supposed by some to be a domesticated variety of the llama.
A genus of fungi, remarkable for the great quantity of spores,forming a fine dust, which is thrown out like smoke when the plant iscompressed or burst; puffball.
To frighten; to worry. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] T. Brown.
A new formation or tissue, the product of morbid action.
A colorless crystalline substance, isomeric with piperonal, buthaving weak acid properties. It is extracted from sandalwood.
Of maximum fusibility; -- said of an alloy or mixture which hasthe lowest melting point which it is possible to obtain by thecombination of the given components.
The line of works which forms the main inclosure of a fortressor place; -- called also body of the place.
The manners and dress of a dandy; foppishness. Byron.
A spot or mark on the skin of children when born; a birthmark;-- usually applied to vascular tumors, i. e., those consisting mainlyof blood vessels, as dilated arteries, veins, or capillaries.
One of afanatical Antinomian sect originating in Holland, andexisting in England about 1580, called the Family of Love, who heldthat religion consists wholly in love.
Want of loyalty; lack of fidelity; violation of allegiance.
A soldier enlisted for home service only; -- usually in the pl.
A genus of tubiculous annelids having a circle of plumose gillsaround head.

A net for leading fish into a pound, weir, etc. ; also, a lineof gut, to which the snell of a fly hook is attached.(i) (Mining) A branch or small vein, not important in itself, butindicating the proximity of a better one.
Of or pertaining to a lobe; characterized by, or like, a lobeor lobes.
A second crop or harvest in the same year. Mortimer.
Tending to ordain; directing; giving order. [R.] Gauden.
In a curved or crooked manner; in a perverse or untowardmanner.

A colorless, tasteless, odorless, gaseous element occurring inthe free state in the atmosphere, of which it forms about 23 per centby weight and about 21 per cent by volume, being slightly heavierthan nitrogen. Symbol O. Atomic weight 15.96.
to look intently; to stare angrily or with a scowl. Thackeray.
A poem in which persons are represented at speakingalternately; as the third and seventh eclogues of Virgil.
A European fresh-water cyprinoid fish of the genus Abramis,little valued as food. Several species are known.
An order of Crinoidea, mostly fossils of the Paleozoic rocks.They were usually roundish or egg-shaped, and often unsymmetrical;some were sessile, others had short stems.
The delicate membrane by which the back part of the globe ofthe eye is lined, and in which the fibers of the optic nerveterminate. See Eye.
Of or pertaining to Aragon, in Spain, or to its inhabitants.-- n. sing. & pl.
The coloring matter within the cells of plants, whether green,red, yellow, or any other color.
Pertaining to, or containing, uranium; designating thosecompounds in which uranium has a lower valence as contrasted with theuranic compounds.
Fruitful; copious; abundant; plentiful. [Obs.] Sir T. Herbert.

The "falling sickness," so called because the patient fallssuddenly to the ground; a disease characterized by paroxysms (orfits) occurring at interval and attended by sudden loss ofconsciousness, and convulsive motions of the muscles. Dunglison.
To stand out, or project, from a surface or mass; hence, toremain standing out.
Vegetable fiber, as jute or ramie, prepared for manufacture.
Containing, or resembling, quartz; partaking of the nature orqualities of quartz.

An inodorous exudation, usually in the form of yellow tears,produced chiefly by the African Euphorbia resinifrea. It was formerlyemployed medicinally, but was found so violent in its effects thatits use is nearly abandoned.
The quantity of motion in a moving body, being alwaysproportioned to the quantity of matter multiplied into the velocity;impetus.
To load with too great a cargo; to overburden; to overload.Spenser.
A short, close-fitting vestment worn by bishops under thedalmatic, and by subdeacons.
To put upon the back or outside of anything; -- the olderspelling of endorse. [Obs.] Spenser.
Of, pertaining to, or like, opal in appearance; havingchangeable colors like those of the opal.
One of the external openings of the nose, which give passage tothe air breathed and to secretions from the nose and eyes; one of theanterior nares.
To deprive or strip, as a house of furniture, or a barn ofstock. [Scot.]
Any plectognath fish that dilates itself, as the bur fish,puffer, or diodon.
The ketone of myristic acid, obtained as a white crystallinesubstance.
To seek after plants for botanical investigation; to studyplants.
Quickness of scent; hence, nice discernment; acuteness. [Obs.]Dr. H. More.
An alkaloid found in several species of lupine (Lupinus luteus,L. albus, etc.), and extracted as a bitter crystalline substance.
A young full trout during its second season. [Prov. Eng.]
A genus of ferns, the leaves of which shed water; maidenhair.Also, the black maidenhair, a species of spleenwort.
In a vexing manner; so as to vex, tease, or irritate. Tatler.
A figure or polygon bounded by twelve sides and containingtwelve angles.
A board on which pastry dough is rolled; a molding board.
A period of six months; especially, a term in a college oruneversity which divides the year into two terms.
A swelling, like a wen, on the point of the elbow (or the heelof the hock) of a horse, caused probably by bruises in lying dowm.
A hydrocarbon radical, C6H4.(CH2)2, regarded as characteristicof certain toluene derivatives.
To make a park of; to inclose, as with a fence; to impark.[Obs.]
The coloring matter of the blood; the clotted portion ofcoagulated blood, containing the coloring matter; gore.
A presbyter appointed by the bishop to institute a rector orassistant minister over a parish church.
One who uses an abacus in casting accounts; a calculator.
Without a fence; uninclosed; open; unguarded; defenseless.Milton.
A large, strong clasp knife for the pocket; a pocket knife.
A yellowness of the parts of plants which are normally green;yellows.
Quality of being earthy; earthiness. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
To offer incense to or upon; to burn incense. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The act of advocating, defending, or supporting, a cause byarguments.
A apartment in a church where the sacred utensils, vestments,etc., are kept; a vestry.
To bear fruit or offspring to excess; to be too prolific.
An ax with an edge or blade on each side of the handle.
Partaking of the nature of clay, or containing particles of it.
The anterior part of the alimentary canal, from the mouth tothe intestine, o
The six-legged young, or larva, of certain mites; -- sometimesused as a generic name. See Harvest mite, under Harvest.
Full of small hills or mounds; hilly; tumulose. [R.] Bailey.
The practice of illustrating a particular book by engravingscollected from other books.
One who, when indicted for crime, confessed it, and accusedothers, his accomplices, in order to obtain pardon; a state'sevidence.

A genus of coniferous trees of the northen hemisphere,including the Norway spruce and the American black and white spruces.These trees have pendent cones, which do not readily fall to pieces,in this and other respects differing from the firs.
That which renders pastry short or friable, as butter, lard,etc.
State of being in doubt; uncertainty; doubt. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Growing immediately on a caulis; of or pertaining to a caulis.
A little world; a miniature universe. Hence (so called byParacelsus), a man, as a supposed epitome of the exterior universe orgreat world. Opposed to macrocosm. Shak.

In ascomycetous fungi, the spherical, discoid, or cup-shapedbody within which the asci are collected, and which constitutes themature fructification. The different forms are known in mycologyunder distinct names. Called also spore fruit.
The allowance given to a factor, as a compensation for hisservices; -- called also a commission.
A mineral of a white to blue or gray color, occuring commonlyin dodecahedrons, also massive. It is a silicate of alumina and sodawith some chlorine.
A South Africa genus of Carnivora, allied to the hyenas, butsmaller and having weaker jaws and teeth. It includes the aard-wolf.

One of an order of priests established in France in 1642 toeducate men for the ministry. The order was introduced soonafterwards into Canada, and in 1791 into the United States. [Writtenalso Sulpitian.]
One of the clergy who reads the epistle at the communionservice; an epistler.
One who meanly shrinks from danger; an arrant coward; apoltroon.You are all recreants and dashtards, and delight to live in slaveryto the nobility. Shak.
A low, bushy, nearly leafless herb (Hypericum Sarothra), commonin sandy soil in the Eastern United States.
A tribe of Indians inhabiting the pampas of South America.
Of or pertaining to a professor; professorial. [R.] Bacon.
Considerable debility of the vital powers, as in typhoid fever.Dunglison.
That branch of physics which treats of the laws of motion, orof moving bodies.
The act or process of depurating or freeing from foreign orimpure matter, as a liquid or wound.
A mixture of wheat and rye, or other species of grain. [ProvEng.]
The science which treats of the teeth, their structure anddevelopment.
To smile in an affected or conceited manner; to smile withaffected complaisance; to simper.
To convert from a solid form to that of a liquid; to melt; todissolve; and technically, to melt by the sole agency of heat.
A mode of treating certain diseases, as obesity, by gymnastics;-- proposed by Pehr Henrik Ling, a Swede. See Kinesiatrics.
The part of the field beyond the diamond, or infield. It isoccupied by the fielders.
The upper arm; the segment of the fore limb between theshoulder and the elbow.
The quality or state of being hasty; haste; precipitation;rashness; quickness of temper.
The fruit bate; a group of the Cheiroptera, comprising the batswhich live on fruits. See Eruit bat, under Fruit.
Of or pertaining to Verona, in Italy.-- n. sing. & pl.
A bright green variety of amphibole occurring usually infibrous or columnar masses.
An exemplar; also, a copy of a book or writing. [Obs.] Donne.

A plant of the genus Viola (V. tricolor) and its blossom,originally purple and yellow. Cultivated varieties have very largeflowers of a great diversity of colors. Called also heart's-ease,love-in-idleness, and many other quaint names.
A hole in the ground, or hiding place, for concealing andpreserving provisions which it is inconvenient to carry. Kane.
A stuffed jacket worn under the mail, or (later) a jacketplated with mail. [Spelled also hacqueton.] [Obs.] Halliwell. Sir W.Scott.
The act of immitting, or of sending or thrusting in; injection;-- the correlative of emission.
An American fresh-water fish (Ictiobus, or Carpiodes,cyprinus); -- called also carp sucker, sailfish, spearfish, andskimback.
A large theorbo, or double-necked lute, formerly in use, havingthe bass strings doubled with an octave, and the higher strings witha unison.
Belonging to the table; transacted at table; as, mensaconversation.
The folds of integument at the opening of the vulva.
Formerly, a soldier who was taught and armed to serve either onhorseback or on foot; now, a mounted soldier; a cavalry man.
The act of crowning with laurel; the act of conferring anacademic degree, or honorary title.

A tuft of long, tough filaments which are formed in a groove ofthe foot, and issue from between the valves of certain bivalvemollusks, as the Pinna and Mytilus, by which they attach themselvesto rocks, etc.
One of a species of aromatic oils, resembling carvacrol.
A volatile liquid obtained by boiling sulphur with linseed oil.It has an unpleasant garlic odor.
The scoria on the surface of molten metal in the ladle.
The act of forming a groove or grooves; a groove, or collectionof grooves.
The act of relegating, or the state of being relegated;removal; banishment; exile.
Peevish; tettish; fretful; -- said of a child. See Tettish.[Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
Having the ovary free, but the petals and stamens borne on thecalyx; -- said of flower such as that of the cherry or peach.
To fish for eels by thrusting the baited hook into their holesor hiding places. Walton.
A liquid hydrocarbon, C8H18, of the marsh-gas series, being oneof several octanes, and consisting of two butyl radicals. Cf. Octane.
Having to hydrogen atoms which can be replaced by positive orbasic atoms or radicals to form salts; -- said of acids. See Dibasic.
A variety of vegetable casein, resembling legumin, and found inalmonds, rye, wheat, etc.
An exclamation expressive of sorrow. [Archaic. or Poet.] Shak.
Any one of numerous species of elegant, usually white, marineshells of the genus Scalaria, especially Scalaria pretiosa, which wasformerly highly valued; -- called also staircase shell. See Scalaria.
A small mine, sometimes formed in the wall or side of anenemy's gallery, to blow in the earth and cut off the retreat of theminers. Farrow.
One of the largest African antelopes (Hippotragus, or Oryx,nasomaculatus).
A prerogative given to the eldest coparcener to choose firstafter an inheritance is divide. Mozley & W.
A kind of banjo, with a short neck, tuned a fourth higher thanthe common banjo; -- popularly so called.
To draw aside or open; to draw back.Angels undrew the curtain of the throne. Young.

To cover lighty, as a painting, or a drawing, with a thin washof opaque color, or with color-crayon dust rubbed on with the stump,or to make any similar additions to the work, so as to produce asoftened effect.
The general aspect or habit of a species, or group of species,esp. with reference to its adaptation to its environment.

A sheet of paper printed and distributed, at stated intervals,for conveying intelligence of passing events, advocating opinions,etc.; a public print that circulates news, advertisements,proceedings of legislative bodies, public announcements, etc.
A membrane extending between the toes of a bird, and unitingthem more or less closely together.
To make sour or acid in a moderate degree; to sour somewhat.Arbuthnot.
The European spotted goby (Gobius minutus); -- called alsopollybait. [Prov. Eng.]
Relating to wheels or to rotary motion; rotary. [R.]
An overhead rail forming a track on which a trolley runs toconvey a load, as in a shop.
To take into the hand; to take up; to help. [Obs.] Wyclif.Spenser.
The state of being falcate; a bend in the form of a sickle. SirT. Browne.
The forearm; the ulna, a bone of the arm extending from elbowto wrist. [Obs.]
Any species of Australian birds of the genus Acanthorhynchus.They are related to the honey eaters.
A native of Cathay or China; a foreigner; -- formerly a term ofreproach. Shak.
Something unimportant, incidental, or superfluous. [Obs.] SirT. Browne.
The lapping of chamfered edges of planks to make a smoothsurface, as for a bulkhead.
A yellow, crystalline substance, obtained from anthraquinone,and regarded as a hydroxyl derivative of it.
In the organ, a small wooden rod which connects (in part) a keyand a pallet, so as to communicate motion by pushing.
To intersect or penetrate with mines. [Obs.] Drayton.
A mixture of honey, water, vinegar, and spice, boiled to asirup. Sir T. Elyot.

A cavity, or one of the cavities, of an organ, as of the larynxor the brain; specifically, the posterior chamber, or one of the twoposterior chambers, of the heart, which receives the blood from theauricle and forces it out from the heart. See Heart.

Formerly, an entertainment at which each person contributedsome dish to a common table; now, an excursion or pleasure party inwhich the members partake of a collation or repast (usually in theopen air, and from food carried by themselves).
An umbelliferous plant (Levisticum officinale), sometimes usedin medicine as an aromatic stimulant.
An official of a bureau; esp. an official confirmed in a narrowand arbitrary routine. C. Kingsley.
The science which treats of the fluids of the body.
To rate or chide vehemently; to scold. Holland. Motley.
To connote; to suggest or designate (something) as additional;to include; to imply. Hammond.
A cloth dipped in a liquid for washing a sore. Crabb.
One of the classes of Arthropoda. See Illustration in Appendix.
An exception taken against a plaintiff in a cause, when he isunable legally to commence a suit.
It is silent; -- a direction for a vocal or instrumental partto be silent during a whole movement.
The fruit or nut of any tree of the genus Juglans; also, thetree, and its timber. The seven or eight known species are allnatives of the north temperate zone.

An official diviner who foretold events by the singing,chattering, flight, and feeding of birds, or by signs or omensderived from celestial phenomena, certain appearances of quadrupeds,or unusual occurrences.
To outrun or outwalk; hence, of a vessel, to outsail. [Colloq.]
The act of offering for sale to the highest bidder. [R.]
Any one of a family of bivalves, of which the oyster is thetype.
Of or pertaining to zeugma; characterized by zeugma.
To make hungry; to whet the appetite of. Sir W. Scott.
A person employed to ascertain the bulk or size of goods, inorder to fix the amount of freight or dues payable on them.
A linear apothecium furrowed along the middle; the fruit ofcertain lichens.
One who walks about in a shop as an overseer and director. Cf.Floorwalker.
Of or pertaining to optimism; tending, or conforming, to theopinion that all events are ordered for the best.
A name formerly applied rather loosely to certain dark-coloredigneous rocks, including diorite, diabase, etc.

A rare metallic element associated with several other rareelements in the mineral gadolinite from Ytterby in Sweden. Symbol Er.Atomic weight 165.9. Its salts are rose-colored and givecharacteristic spectra. Its sesquioxide is called erbia.
Serving to dissolve or attenuate viscid matter, and so toremove obstructions; deobstruent.-- n.
Having a head like that of a bull. Fig.: Headstrong; obstinate;dogged.
An opinion opposed to some accepted standard. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
A genus of pretty spring flowers closely related to Anemone;squirrel cup.
The giving up or vacating a benefice by accepting anotherwithout a proper dispensation.
A depilatory made of orpiment and quicklime, and used by theTurks. See Rhusma.
Pelts or skins, collectively; skins with the fur on them; furs.
A transverse drain or waterway of masonry under a road,railroad, canal, etc.; a small bridge.
Brigands in bands, who, about 1793, pillaged, burned, andkilled in parts of France; -- so called because they used to burn thefeet of their victims to extort money.
The anterior segment of the thorax in insects. See Insect.
A fleet of armed ships; a squadron. Specifically, the Spanishfleet which was sent to assail England, a. d. 1558.
The triangular space under the beak of many brachiopod shells.
An instrument for measuring the forms and angles of salts andcrystals; a goniometer.
To associate, or hold fellowship, as sisters; to have sisterlyfeelings; -- analogous to fraternize. [Recent & R.]

A group of decapod Crustacea, including the common crabs,characterized by a small and short abdomen, which is bent up beneaththe large cephalo-thorax. [Also spelt Brachyoura.] See Crab, andIllustration in Appendix.
Productive of fruit, or causing fruit to be developed.
Pertaining to, or derived from, fatty or oily substances; --applied to certain acids obtained from fats by the action of nitricacid.
A slight withdrawal from view or knowledge. Sir W. Hamilton.
Consisting of, or containing, calcareous matter or lime salts;calcareous.
A plane on a door, giving the name, and sometimes theemployment, of the occupant.
A journal of accounts; a primary record book in which arerecorded the debts and credits, or accounts of the day, in theirorder, and from which they are transferred to the journal.
A dich or drain along the side of a hill to catch the surfacewater; also, a ditch at the side of a canal to catch the surpluswater.
A collegian of inferior rank or position, corresponding to thesizar at Cambridge. [Oxford Univ., Eng.]
The principal church in a diocese, so called because in it thebishop has his official chair (Cathedra) or throne.
Of or pertaining to the island anciently called Lesbos, nowMitylene, in the Grecian Archipelago.
A ruddy eruption upon the nose caused by drinking ardentspirits; a grog blossom.
The state or quality of being gemmy; spruceness; smartness.
One of the ropes by which the mainsail is hauled aft andtrimmed.
A small sailing vessel, commonly rigged as a sloop, usedchiefly in the coasting and fishing trade.
One of a class of theologians who maintain that God has fixed acertain term for the probation of individual persons, during whichperiod, and no longer, they have the offer to grace. Murdock.
A saw (as a tenon saw) whose blade is stiffened by an addedmetallic back.
A genus of large arenaceous fossil Foraminifera found in theCretaceous rocks. The species are globular, or nearly so, and are ofall sizes up to that of a tennis ball.
An instrument for measuring the force or velocity of the wind;a wind gauge.
Of or pertaining to negroes; composed of negroes. Keary.
To imbue with, or subject to the influence of, a narcotic; toput into a state of narcosis.
A small Brazilian monkey (Callithrix torquatus), -- called alsocollared teetee.
The mode of using the pencil or brush, etc.; style of touch.Fairholt.
A green seaweed (Cladophora rupestris) growing in dense tufts.
A genus of marine bivalve shells, including the common mussel.See Illust. under Byssus.
A little sac; specifically, the sacculus of the ear.
Having the ends forked or branched, and the ends of thebranches terminating abruptly as if cut off; -- said of an ordinary,especially of a cross.
In a manner not exact or precise; inaccurately. R. A. Proctor.
A white fibrous mineral frequently found on the walls of minesand quarries, chiefly hydrous sulphate of alumina; -- also calledfeather alum, and hair salt.
The process of coating the surface of a metal plate (as astereotype plate) with steellike iron by means of voltaicelectricity; steeling.
One who deals in hose or stocking, or in goods knit or wovenlike hose.
The part of a mast below the hounds and above the deck.
One who adheres to the house of Bourbon; a legitimist.
Furnished with a leaflike appendage, as the fruit of the elmand the ash, or the stem in certain plants; alate.

The sunlight reflected from the earth to the moon, by which wesee faintly, when the moon is near the sun (either before or afternew moon), that part of the moon's disk unillumined by directsunlight, or "the old moon in the arms of the new."
One of a sect of mystics originated in the seventeenth centuryby Molinos, a Spanish priest living in Rome. See Quietism.
A strong piece of plank used in applying wringbolts.
To forge on an anvil.The forge that stithied Mars his helm. Shak.
A glucoside found in the seeds of white mustard (Brassica alba,formerly Sinapis alba), and extracted as a white crystallinesubstance.
The state of being frigid; want of heat, vigor, or affection;coldness; dullness.
To bear down with a brazen face; to surpass in impudence. T.Brown.
Same as Cartographer, Cartographic, Cartography, etc.
One of a non-Jewish nation; one neither a Jew nor a Christian;a worshiper of false gods; a heathen.
One of the red dye products extracted from madder root, andprobably identical with ruberythrinic acid.
To restore vitality to; to bring back to life. L. S. Beale.

A paragraph added to a letter after it is concluded and signedby the writer; an addition made to a book or composition after themain body of the work has been finished, containing somethingomitted, or something new occurring to the writer. [Abbrev. P. S.]
Pilotage; skill of a pilot or loadsman. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A person whose business is marriage brokage; a marriage broker,esp. among certain Jews.
A napkin or handkerchief. [Obs. or R.] Wyclif. R. Browning.
The name given by Europeans to that form of the Hindustanilanguage which is chiefly spoken by native Hindoos. In employs theDevanagari character, in which Sanskrit is written. Whitworth.
A part turned or folded back so as to show the inside, or apiece put on in imitation of such a part, as the lapel of a coat.
To bind up,as in a knot; to include. [Obs.] Fuller.

A relation between two figures, such that to any point of theone corresponds one and but one point in the other, and vise versa.Thus, a tangent line rolling on a circle cuts two fixed tangents ofthe circle in two sets of points that are homographic.
A fur esteemed in the Middle Ages as a part of costume. It isuncertain whether it was the fur of one animal only or of differentanimals.
A general morbid condition induced by the crowding together ofmany persons, esp. sick persons, under one roof. G. Gregory.
Excess of acetone in the urine, as in starvation or diabetes.

Pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid (called alsopropargylic acid) of the acetylene or tetrolic series, analogous topropionic acid, and obtained as a white crystalline substance.C3H2O2,CH.C.COOH
The chief tower, also called the keep; a massive tower inancient castles, forming the strongest part of the fortifications.See Illust. of Castle.
A poisonous alkaloid, C19H21NO3, found in opium in smallquantities, having a sharp, astringent taste, and a tetanic actionresembling that of strychnine.
Flint or pebble stone, used in building walls, etc. Haliwell.
Not arrayed in the dress of a morris dancer. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
Any one of several plants of different genera and species, mostof which are (or were formerly) reputed to be efficacious as remediesfor the bites of serpents; also, the roots of any of these.
A region or tract of land; esp., the open field; grass country.[South Africa]
A large spiral East Indian marine shell (Turbinella rapha); --so called because used by native priests to hold the oil foranointing.
Being three in one; -- an epithet used to express the unity ofa trinity of persons in the Godhead.
A grand division of birds, including all existing flying birds;-- So called from the carina or keel on the breastbone.
Bending gradually toward the axis or center, as branches orpetals.
To be silent, as a letter; to have no sound. M. Stuart.
A sense organ found in certain sponges. It consists of severalfilaments, each of which arises from a single cell.
The collection of staves which form a full score. See Score, n.
The process of accruing, or that which has accrued; increase.Jer. Taylor.
