Any thorny shrub of the genus Ribes; also, the edible berriesof such shrub. There are several species, of which Ribes Grossulariais the one commonly cultivated.
One who refuses to join, or withdraws from, a trades union.[Cant, Eng.]
One who, or that which, hulls; especially, an agriculturalmachine for removing the hulls from grain; a hulling machine.
A yellow crystalline substance extracted from fustet, andregarded as its essential coloring principle; -- called also fiseticacid.
An account of deaths, or of the dead; a register of deaths; acollection of obituary notices.
Fully; roundly; plainly; without reserve. [Colloq.]
An earthy carbonate of iron containing considerablecarbonaceous matter; -- valuable as an iron ore.
The middle portion of the foot in the Gastropoda and Pteropoda.
A stupid person. [Colloq.] C. Reade.-- Mud"dle-head`ed, a. [Colloq.] Dickens.
To separate the constituent parts of; to resolve into originalelements; to set free from previously existing forms of chemicalcombination; to bring to dissolution; to rot or decay.
One of those who conspired for constitutional governmentagainst the Emperor Nicholas on his accession to the throne at thedeath of Alexander I., in December, 1825; -- called also Dekabrist.
Situated in front of the frontal bone, or the frontal region ofthe skull; ectethmoid, as a certain bone in the nasal capsule of manyanimals, and certain scales of reptiles and fishes.-- n.
The quality of being arch; cleverness; sly humor free frommalice; waggishness. Goldsmith.
The texan guan (Ortalis vetula). [written also chiacalaca.]
To rise with a curling motion; to curl upward, as smoke.Longfellow.
A narrow-necked vessel having two handles and bellying out likea jug.
A musical wind instrument, now used chiefly in the Highlands ofScotland.
Having grooves or furrows broader than the intervening ridges;furrowed.
To place in a tomb; to bury; to entomb. See Entomb.

An imitation of any veined and ornamental stone, as marble,formed by a substratum of finely ground gypsum mixed with glue, thesurface of which, while soft, is variegated with splinters of marble,spar, granite, etc., and subsequently colored and polished.
To pronounce with a hissing sound, like that of the letter s;to mark with a character indicating such pronunciation.
The use of concetti or affected conceits. [R.] C. Kingsley.
A public house where travelers and other transient guests areaccomodated with rooms and meals; an inn; a hotel; especially, inmodern times, a public house licensed to sell liquor in smallquantities.
A bird of the genus Pyrrhula and other related genera,especially the P. vulgaris or rubicilla, a bird of Europe allied tothe grosbeak, having the breast, cheeks, and neck, red.

A coarsely granular substance obtained by heating, and thuspartly changing, the moistened starch obtained from the roots of thecassava. It is much used in puddings and as a thickening for soups.See Cassava.
After the manner of a court; elegant; polite; courtly.
A patient who receives lodging and food, as well as treatment,in a hospital or an infirmary; -- distinguished from outpatient.
To cover, as a road, or street, with small, broken stones, soas to form a smooth, hard, convex surface.
A red African antelope (Kobus Vardoni) allied to the waterbuck.
A shareholder of the Assiento company; one of the parties tothe Assiento contract. Bancroft.
Odd; not even; -- said of elementary substances and of radicalswhose valence is not divisible by two without a remainder. Contrastedwith artiad.
One who is versed in, or makes a study of, pyrology.
By natural or original condition; naturally; originally.
A boat sent to make discoveries and bring intelligence.Arbuthnot.
A regiment, or two or more companies of a regiment, esp. whenassembled for drill or battle.

A substance, in the form of reddish brown, microscopic,prismatic crystals, formed from dried blood by the action of strongacetic acid and common salt; -- called also Teichmann's crystals.Chemically, it is a hydrochloride of hematin.
The production of the tones of a chord in rapid succession, asin playing the harp, and not simultaneously; a strain thus played.
A figure representation which has a meaning beyond notiondirectly conveyed by the object painted or sculptured.
A division of bivalve mollusks including the oysters and alliedshells.
A kind of Bohemian earthenware resembling the Wedgwood ware.
A crystalline hydrocarbon derivative, metameric with orcin, butproduced artificially; -- called also cresorcin.
One of the movable, slender, spinelike organs or parts withwhich certain bryozoans are furnished. They are regarded as speciallymodified zooids, of nearly the same nature as Avicularia.
To grace or honor exceedingly or beyond desert. [R.] Beau. &Fl.
Distance northward from any point of departure or of reckoning,measured on a meridian; -- opposed to Ant: southing.
A polymeric modification of terpene, obtained as a whitecrystalline camphorlike substance; -- called also camphene. Byextension, any one of a group of related substances.

One of a sect of peripatetic philosophers, who appeared inItaly before the restoration of learning; so denominated fromAverroes, or Averrhoes, a celebrated Arabian philosopher. He held thedoctrine of monopsychism.
The internal or principal branch of the locomotive appendagesof Crustacea. See Maxilliped.
That point, in the real or apparent orbit of one star revolvingaround another, at which the former is nearest to the latter.
A large bee of the genus Bombus, sometimes called humblebee; --so named from its sound.
One who repeals; one who seeks a repeal; specifically, anadvocate for the repeal of the Articles of Union between GreatBritain and Ireland.
A woman who is negligent of her dress or house; one who is notneat and nice.
A person invested with a title, in virtue of which he holds anoffice or benefice, whether he performs the duties of it or not.
A micaceous mineral occurring in small scales. It ischaracteristic of certain crystalline schists.
Deck sweepings, refuse of cordage, canvas, etc. Ham. Nav.Encyc.
Arising from the pleurapophysis of a vertebra. Owen.
One who explores; one who examines closely; a searcher.
An Australian tree (Acacia Doratoxylon), and its tough wood,used by the natives for spears.
A complex nitrogenous substance, which, by Hermann'shypothesis, is continually decomposed and reproduced in the muscles,during their life.
Quality of being due; debt; what is due or becoming. T.Goodwin.
A quantity of wares, as raw silk, etc., from one hundredweight.
The under side of the subordinate parts and members ofbuildings, such as staircases, entablatures, archways, cornices, orthe like. See Illust. of Lintel.
The act of treating with ozone; also, the act of convertinginto, or producing, ozone; ozonization.
A genus of decapod Crustacea, including some of the most commonshore crabs of Europe and North America, as the rock crab, Jonahcrab, etc. See Crab.
A genus of small oceanic fishes, remarkable for the largeconical tubercles which cover the under surface.
Having the frames, stem, and sternpost adjusted; -- said of aship on the stocks.
A plant (Anthriscus cerefolium) with pinnately divided aromaticleaves, of which several curled varieties are used in soups andsalads.
Not prepared or mediated beforehand; extemporaneous. [Obs.]Jonhson.
The quality or state of being wordy, or abounding with words;verboseness. Jeffrey.
A characteristic of Londoners; a mode of speaking peculiar toLondon.
One who prepares or deals in ornamental plumes or feathers.
A process by which ores are washed on a shovel, or in a vanner.
One who, or that which, whitens; a bleacher; a blancher; awhitewasher.
Filling up; supplementary; supernumerary; -- a term applied tothose instruments which only swell the mass or tutti of an orchestra,but are not obbligato.
A species of deer (Elaphurus Davidianus) found in china. Itabout four feet high at the shoulder and has peculiar antlers.
imp. & p. p. of Wind to twist, and Wind to sound by blowing.
A protecting ruffle or frill, as of silk or lace, sewed closeto the lower edge of a skirt on the inside.
A man who carries or takes care of a light. T. Brown.
The state of being fleshy; plumpness; corpulence; grossness.Milton.
Roundish pearl-colored specks or flakes in the mouth, on thelips, etc., terminating in white sloughs. They are commonlycharacteristic of thrush.
An order of worms, having a long, round, and generally smoothbody; the roundworms. they are mostly parasites. Called alsoNematodea, and Nematoda.
A case or box containing paper and materials for writing.
The office, position, or station of a chaplain. Swift.
An instrument used by the ancients in driving piles.
Vested with all due formalities, and legally attested.

One not of noble blood; a plebeian; a roturier. [R.]The exclusion of the French ruptuaries ("roturiers," for history mustfind a word for this class when it speaks of other nations) from theorder of nobility. Chenevix.
One who, or that which, loads; a mechanical contrivance forloading, as a gun.
In an American college, an optional study or course of study.[Colloq.]
A genus of small Insectivora, including the common shrews.
Fat; grease; esp. the fat of pigs or geese; usually (Pharm.),lard prepared for medical use.
Any member of a group of sugars containing six carbon atoms inthe molecule. Some are widely distributed in nature, esp. in ripefruits.
A vertebral rudiment in front of the atlas in some reptiles.
A fabulous being, represented as half man and half horse.
One of those adherents of James II. who refused to take theoath of allegiance to William and Mary, or to their successors, afterthe revolution of 1688; a Jacobite.
Any one of several species of northern sea ducks of the genusOidemia.
A genus of small hemipterous insects which injure trees bysucking the sap from the leaves. See Illustration in Appendix.
A small silver coin of three times the value of a penny. [Eng.]
A supposed new metal found in columbite, afterwards shown to beidentical with columbium, or niobium.
Relating to Elohim as a name of God; -- said of passages in theOld Testament.
Liable to slip, err, fall, or apostatize. [Obs.] Cheyne.
A native sulphate of lead. It occurs in white or yellowishtransparent, prismatic crystals.
A leafless plant, with hollow and rushlike stems. It is of thegenus Equisetum, and is allied to the ferns. See Illust. ofEquisetum.
To free from the bonds of marriage; to divorce. [Obs.] Ld.Berners.

A poisonous glucoside found in several species of hellebore,and extracted as a white crystalline substance with a sharp tinglingtaste. It possesses the essential virtues of the plant; -- calledalso elleborin.
Having a color somewhat like saffron; yellowish. Lord (1630).
Freedom from passion; an undisturbed state; apathy. Sir W.Temple.
One of the solemn religious ordinances enjoined by Christ, thehead of the Christian church, to be observed by his followers; hence,specifically, the eucharist; the Lord's Supper.
Having a slightly undulating margin; -- said of leaves.
The right or privilege of fishing in another man's waters.Blackstone.
Something to be done; some transformation to be made uponquantities, the transformation being indicated either by rules orsymbols.
The top sheaf of a stack of grain: (fig.) the crowning orfinishing part of a thing.
A French mode or characteristic; an idiom peculiar to theFrench language. Earle.
Of or relating to modern Greece, and especially to itslanguage.-- n.
One of the digestive ferments of the pancreatic juice; also, apreparation containing such a ferment, made from the pancreas ofanimals, and used in medicine as an aid to digestion.
To injure by too long exposure to the light of the sun in thecamera; to burn.
Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acid ofthe alloxan group, obtained as a honey-yellow powder. Its solutionshave a gelatinous consistency.
The act of nauseating, or the state of being nauseated.
A pad or ball of rags, covered over with canvas, for inkingplates; a dabber.
A species of whitefish (Coregonus nigripinnis) found in LakeMichigan.
To prance ostentatiously; -- said of a horse or his rider.[Local slang U. S.]
One who, or that which, diverts, turns off, or pleases.
A name popularly given to the officinal valerian, and to someother plants.
A fever accompanied by an eruption of small, isolated, redpimples, resembling a millet seed in form or size; miliary fever.
A chitinous piece between the metasternum and the pleuron ofcertain insects.
To utter ejaculations; to make short and hasty exclamations.[R.] "Ejaculating to himself." Sir W. Scott.
An iron-black ore of silver, consisting of silver, sulphur, andantimony, with some copper and arsenic.
A blanket or shawl worn as an outer garment by the SpanishAmericans, as in Mexico.
An instrument for registering the changes observable with anoncometer.
One in a flight of steps which are curved in plan, so that eachtread is broader at one end than at the other; -- distinguished fromflyer.
A tribe of Indians distantly related to the Shoshones. Theyformerly inhabited the region about the head waters of the NorthPlatte.
A tall umbelliferous plant (Ferula communis). See Giant fennel,under Fennel.
A plant affording a blue dye; the woad (Isatis tinctoria);also, the dye itself.
A low rhamnaceous shrub (Karwinskia humboldtiana) of thesouthwestern United States and Mexico. Its berries are said to bepoisonous to the coyote.
One of the orders of Anthozoa. It includes the Alcyonacea,Pennatulacea, and Gorgonacea.
A contrivance for turning a spit by means of a fly or wheelmoved by the current of ascending air in a chimney.
Hoofed, or bearing hoofs; -- used only when these are of atincture different from the body.
To post over; to pass over swiftly, as by post. Shak.
A very large glandular and vascular organ in the visceralcavity of all vertebrates.
To outvote; to outnumber in votes given. [R.] Eikon Basilike.
A clinic in which diseases of many sorts are treated;especially, an institution in which clinical instruction is given inall kinds of disease.

Any one of several substances or mixtures which phosphoresce orignite spontaneously on exposure to air, as a heated mixture of alum,potash, and charcoal, or a mixture of charcoal and finely dividedlead.
The sliding block or support, in a lathe, which carries thedead spindle, or adjustable center. The headstock supports the livespindle.

Close; termination; as:(a) (Mus.) The last movement of a symphony, sonata, concerto, or anyinstrumental composition.(b) The last composition performed in any act of an opera.(c) The closing part, piece, or scene in any public performance orexhibition.
A breed of dogs having curly hair, and often showing remarkableintelligence in the performance of tricks.
To deprive of features; to mar the features of. [R.]
Capable of being indorsed; transferable; convertible.
The formation of an involute by unwrapping a thread from acurve as an evolute. Hutton.
Any lamellirostral bird, as a duck or goose; -- so calledbecause it sifts or strains its food from the water and mud by meansof the lamell
A process in the nature of a summons to appear and answer.
One of the two halves of bilaterally symmetrical animals; oneof any opposite symmetrical or homotypic parts in animals and plants.
Rendered blue, as the surface of the body, from cyanosis ordeficient a
A plant having a woody, durable stem, but less than a tree; ashrub.
A fierce, wild dog (Canis Dukhunensis), found in the mountainsof India. It is remarkable for its propensity to hunt the tiger andother wild animals in packs.
A plantation of the nopal for raising the cochineal insect.
A form of decay seen in fleshy, overripe fruit. Lindley.
A variety of opal occuring in the cavities of volcanic tufa, insmooth and shining globular and botryoidal masses, having a pearlyluster; -- so called from Fiora, in Ischia.
One who believes or maintains that the fulfillment of theprophecies of the Bible is to be in the future.
The leaves of several leguminous plants of the genus Cassia.(C. acutifolia. C. angustifolia, etc.). They constitute a valuablebut nauseous cathartic medicine.
A metallic strengthening band or thimble on the wooden arm ofan axle. Knight.
The art or practice of combining different colors, especiallybrilliant ones, in an artistic way.
Having no petals, or flower leaves. [See Illust. under Anther].
Resembling Quakers; Quakerlike; Quakerish. Macaulay.
Belonging to the Danes, or to their language or country.-- n.
A small wheel carriage, so constructed that a person sitting init may move it.
To crush with the teeth; to chew with violence and noise; tocrunch. Swift.
The time of the first appearance of light in the morning.
Like, or pertaining to, Lagena, a genus of Foraminifera havinga straight, chambered shell.
Bread-gainer; -- a term applied in the Middle Ages to the swordof a hired soldier.
Pertaining to the blood or blood vessels; also, ventral. SeeHemal.
A bird (Nyctidromus albicollis) ranging from Texas to SouthAmerica. It is allied to the night hawk and goatsucker.
A top; a platform at a masthead; -- so called because formerlyround in shape.
A hollow globe on the inner surface of which a map of the worldis depicted, to be examined by one standing inside.
The state of dwelling or residing; occupancy as a dwellingplace. [Obs.] Shak.

Foul matter; excretion; dregs; filthy, useless, or rejectedmatter of any kind; specifically (Med.), the foul matter thatcollects on the teeth and tongue in low fevers and other conditionsattended with great vital depression.
One of the receptacles on the rim of a water wheel into whichthe water rushes, causing the wheel to revolve; also, a float of apaddle wheel.
An apparatus or agent for the production or application ofozone.
A passage through a fence or wall; a gate; also, a frame, arch,etc., in which a gate in hung, or a structure at an entrance or gatedesigned for ornament or defense.
To buy at less than the real value or worth; to buy cheaperthan. [R.] J. Fletcher.
A long, thin fish of the arctic seas (Trachypterus arcticus).
A village composed of Arab tents arranged in streets.
To involve one within another; to twist or coil together.Milton.
Any one of numerous species of small bark-boring beetles of thegenus Scolytus and allied genera. Also used adjectively.
Power, or command, over a certain district; chieftainship.[Obs.]
Pertaining to, or situated near, central or deep parts; inner;-- opposed to ectal. B. G. Wilder.
Dust or small fragments of wood 9or of stone, etc.) made by thecutting of a saw.
Any matter which makes land productive; a fertilizingsubstance, as the contents of stables and barnyards, dung, decayinganimal or vegetable substances, etc. Dryden.
A small California surf fish (Micrometrus aggregatus); --called also shiner.
Time beyond, or in excess of, a limit; esp., extra workingtime.
One who believes in, or conforms to, the theory of naturism.Boyle.
The state of being queasy; nausea; qualmishness; squeamishness.Shak.
One of the testicles of a hart or stag. [Spelt also doucet.] B.Jonson.
An extemporaneous funeral song, composed and sung by a woman onthe death of a friend. [Modern Greece]
The common tissue which unites the various zooids of abryozoan.
Probably from "saintes" saints, or from sanctities; -- used asan oath. [Obs.] Shak.
Of or pertaining to a demesne; of the nature of a demesne.
A triple alliance; specif., the alliance of Germany, Austria,and Italy, formed in 1882.
An ornament often resembling curved and bent foliage,projecting from the sloping edge of a gable, spire, etc.
An arrangement of parallel bars for lifting the hooked wireswhich raise the warp threads in a loom for weaving figured goods.Knight.
The earth. [Obs.] "Is my son dead or hurt or on the yerthefelled" Ld. Berners.
A group of fishes including the sharks and rays; theElasmobranchii; -- called also Placoidei.
In a manner admitting of pardon; excusably. Dryden.
A term applied to the stipes or stalks of certain fungi whichare covered with a woolly substance which at length becomes powdery.Henslow.
Any character used to represent a quantity, an operation, arelation, or an abbreviation.
To explode, or cause to explode; to burn with an explosion; todetonate.
A speculum for examining a natural passage, as the urethra.
A bundle of rods, having among them an ax with the bladeprojecting, borne before the Roman magistrates as a badge of theirauthority.
To separate, as threads; to divide, as a collection of threads;to sley; -- a weaver's term.
An oblate spheroid; a figure described by the revolution of anellipse about its minor axis. Cf. Oblongum.
Anything that floors or upsets a person, as a blow that knockshim down; a conclusive answer or retort; a task that exceeds one'sabilities. [Colloq.]

A group of ganoid fishes, including the living genera Ceratodusand Lepidosiren, which present the closest approximation to theAmphibia. The air bladder acts as a lung, and the nostrils openinside the mouth. See Ceratodus, and Illustration in Appendix.
A quaking or trembling of the flesh; a quiver. [Obs.] B.Jonson.
A longing; a desire; especially an ardent desire; appetite;appetency.
Pertaining to, of the nature of, or resembling, a phantasm;spectral; illusive.
A thick, strong stuff, somewhat like camlet; -- still used forouter garments in the Levant.
The obtaining gifts of escheat by fraud or surprise. Bell.
Expression of the passions; the science of the signs by whichhuman passions are indicated.
Sticky and foul; muddy; filthy; dirty. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
An instrument for dilating certain passages of the body, andthrowing light within them, thus facilitating examination or surgicaloperations.
That division of the Rhizopoda which includes the amoeba andsimilar forms.
A dragon fly. See Darning needle, under Darn, v. t.
Irregularity of form; diversity of form; want of uniformity.[Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
The quality or state of being slight; slenderness; feebleness;superficiality; also, formerly, negligence; indifference; disregard.
A post on which a sign hangs, or on which papers are placed togive public notice of anything.
Of, pertaining to, or like, mud; living in mud. [Obs.] Grew.
A circle around whose circumference a planet or the center ofann epicycle was conceived to move uniformly; -- called alsoeccentric equator.
A contribution or a tax for paving streets or highways.Bouvier.
An artifical red nitrogenous dyestuff, called also redcoralline.
Having columns on all sides; -- said of an edifice. SeeApteral.
Of or pertaining to syphilis; of the nature of syphilis;affected with syphilis.-- n.
Unfruitful; not producing young; barren; infertile. [Obs.]Evelyn.
Pertaining to, or resembling, a grove; situated in, orfrequenting, groves. Dampier.
An ornament produced by notching or carving a rounded molding.
A person employed in the express business; also, the driver ofa job wagon. W. D. Howells.
A dark brown powder containing iron, prepared by the action ofzinc dust as a reducing agent upon the coloring matter of the blood,used medicinally as a hematinic.
To howl, as a dog or a wolf; to wail; as, ululating jackals.Sir T. Herbert.
The observation of the state and variations of the atmosphere.
Quickness of perception or discernment; penetration of mind;the faculty of nice discrimination. Selden.
The pellicle which forms over a wound or breach of continuityand completes the process of healing in the latter, and whichsubsequently contracts and becomes white, forming the scar.
An assembly room in dwelling of the Pueblo Indians. L. H.Morgan.
To fry lightly and quickly, as meat, by turning ot tossing itover frequently in a hot pan greased with a little fat.
The state of being intimate; close familiarity or association;nearness in friendship.
A long pole with a spike at the end, used in climbingmountains; an alpenstock.
The quality of being mordacious; biting severity, or sarcasticquality. Bacon.
Clay, or potter's earth; sometimes pure clay, or alumina. SeeClay.
The quality or state of being venial; venialness. Jer. Taylor.
A fillet between the flutes of columns, pilasters, or the like.Oxf. Gloss.
A pen for animals; esp., an inclosure made with wagons, byemigrants in the vicinity of hostile Indians, as a place of securityfor horses, cattle, etc.
Under the feet; underneath; below. See Under foot, under Foot,n.
The young tissue of a fibrovascular bundle before its componentcells have begun to be differentiated. Sachs.
The lucern (Medicago sativa); -- so called in California,Texas, etc.
The practice of exciting and encouraging lawsuits and quarrels.[Also spelt barretry.] Coke. Blackstone.
An ill habit or state of the constitution; -- formerly regardedas dependent on a morbid condition of the blood and humors.
Inscriptions, figure drawings, etc., found on the walls ofancient sepulchers or ruins, as in the Catacombs, or at Pompeii.
A giving suck; the secretion and yielding of milk by themammary gland.
The place on an ovule, or seed, where its outer coats coherewith each other and the nucleus.
Derangement of the mind in regard of a single subject only;also, such a concentration of interest upon one particular subject ortrain of ideas to show mental derangement.
A large British fluke, or flounder (Rhombus megastoma); --called also carter, and whiff. marchpane.
A cornice, or series of moldings, on the top of the base of apedestal, podium, etc. See Illust. of Column.
Having the ventral fins beneath the throat; -- said of certainfishes.
The science of athletic combats, or contests in public games.
A lively, spirited march; also, a lively style of dancing.
A long staff, pointed with iron, used in climbing the Alps.Cheever.
A form of phonographic recorder and reproducer adapted for usein dictation, as in business.
A plant of the genus Aconitum; aconite. See Aconite.
The indistinct and magnified appearance of objects seen inparticular states of the atmosphere. See Mirage.
Downward convexity, or convexity of the inferior surface.
A kind of soup containing thin slices or shreds of carrots,onions, etc.
An appendage of the vestibular ear sac of fishes. Owen.
a New Zealand tree, the Cypress cedar (Libocedrus Doniana),having a valuable, fine-grained, reddish wood.
Of or pertaining to Livonia, a district of Russia near theBaltic Sea.
A preliminary or auxiliary proposition demonstrated or acceptedfor immediate use in the demonstration of some other proposition, asin mathematics or logic.
A thin lamina of gray matter in each cerebral hemiphere of thebrain of man.-- Claus"tral, a.
A limpid, colorless, highly volatile liquid, obtained by thedehydration of glycerin, or the destructive distillation of neutralfats containing glycerin. Its vapors are intensely irritating. Watts.
One who intervenes; especially (Law), a person who assumes apart in a suit between others.
Calcium oxide; unslacked lime; -- so called because when wet itdevelops great heat. See 4th Lime, 2.
State of being without or beyond a thing; foreignness. [Obs.]
The common sainfoin (Onobrychis sativa), an Old Worldleguminous forage plant.
Of, pertaining to, or like, saffron; deep reddish yellow. [R.]
A brine or pickle containing wine and spices, for enriching theflavor of meat and fish.
An administrative subdivision of a fu, or department, or of anindependent chow; also, the seat of government of such a district.
One who owls; esp., one who conveys contraband goods. SeeOwling, n. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] T. Brown.
One of the inhabitants of the north of Europe; esp., one of theancient Scandinavians; a Norseman.
A magnificent tomb, or stately sepulchral monument.
The operation of excising one or more of the bones of thetarsus.
The act of making unlucky; misfortune; bad luck. [Obs.] Bacon.
To be sequeamish or delicate; hence, to act or talk triflinglyor ineffectively; to twaddle; piddle. [Dial. or Slang]
A wandering troop or gang; especially, a clan or tribe of anomadic people migrating from place to place for the sake ofpasturage, plunder, etc.; a predatory multitude. Thomson.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from atropine,and isomeric with cinnamic acid.
Of or pertaining to a division (Monocystidea) of Gregarinida,in which the body consists of one sac.
A drum made of thin copper in the form of a hemisphericalkettle, with parchment stretched over the mouth of it.
The difference between two quantities commensurable only inpower, as between sq. root2 and 1, or between the diagonal and sideof a square.
A temporary structure upon which the materials of a vault orarch are supported in position util the work becomes self-supporting.
A lodging for soldiers in garrison towns, usually near therampart; barracks. Bescherelle.
A subterraneous passage communicating between the parade andthe main ditch, or between the ditches and the interior of theoutworks. Mahan.
A kind of marble or alabaster, sometimes used for windows onaccount of its transparency.
To meet unexpectedly; to encounter in a hostile manner; to comein collision; to skirmish.
The art or science which treats of lighthouses and signallights.
Situated immediately in front of the loins;- applied to thedorsal part of the abdomen.
One who adheres to the philosophy of Plato; a follower ofPlato. Hammond.
The act of reviling; also, contemptuous language; reproach;abuse. Spenser.
To look into or within; to view the inside of. Bailey.
Allspice; -- applied both to the tree and its fruit. SeeAllspice.
The band which passes over the back of a horse and holds up theshafts of a carriage.
One who projects a scheme or design; hence, one who formsfanciful or chimerical schemes. L'Estrange.
A phylum of the vegetable kingdom consisting of the classMyxomycetes. By some botanists it is not separated from theThallophyta.
A bag filled with earth, used commonly to raise or repair aparapet.
One who monopolizes; one who has a monopoly; one who favorsmonopoly.
The state or circumstance of being testate, or of leaving avalid will, or testament, at death.
The moor cock, or red grouse. See Grouse. [Prov. Eng.]
A concussion or shock produced by a blow or other injury, in apart or region opposite to that at which the blow is received, oftencausing rupture or disorganisation of the parts affected.
Native phosphate of lime, occurring usually in six-sidedprisms, color often pale green, transparent or translucent.
Belonging to the Heath family, or resembling plants of thatfamily; consisting of heats.
That which shines at night; -- a fanciful name for phosphorus.
A shaft or gallery to drain a mine. [Local, Eng.] Bailey.
Having three sorts of flowers on the same or on differentplants, some of the flowers being staminate, others pistillate, andothers both staminate and pistillate; belonging to the orderTrioecia.
One of several isomeric organic bases of the quinoline seriesof alkaloids.
Having colors like those of the rainbow; iridescent. Holmes.
The act of stirring; stir; commotion. [Obs.] T. Granger.
Resembling mucus; having the character or appearance of mucus.
A figure by which a word is repeated in different forms, cases,numbers, genders, etc., as in Tennyson's line, -- "My own heart'sheart, and ownest own, farewell."
Stonework in which the surface is left broken and rough.
A constellation of the northern hemisphere east of, orfollowing, Lyra; the Swan.
The water pepper (Polygonum Hydropiper), an aquatic plant ofEurope and North America.
To run quickly; to scurry; to scuttle. [Prov. Eng.]
On the ground; stranded; -- a nautical term applied to a shipwhen its bottom lodges on the ground. Totten.
A small insectivorous mammal (Solenodon paradoxus), allied tothe moles, found only in Hayti.
The dress prescribed for any body of men, academical,municipal, or sacerdotal. [Obs.]The doctors attending her in their formalities as far as Shotover.Fuller.
A foundation or sustaining wall of stones thrown togetherwithout order, as in deep water or on a soft bottom.
An impure, massive, flintlike quartz or hornstone, of a dullcolor.
One who manages another's affairs, either generally or in aspecial matter; an agent; a proctor. Chaucer. Shak.
An incessant motion of a horse's head, neck, and body, fromside to side, fancied to resemble the motion of a hand weaver inthrowing the shuttle. Youatt.
A noun or verb, not modified by inflections; also, that part ofa noun or verb which remains unchanged (except by euphonicvariations) in declension or conjugation; stem.
A crystalline, transparent, colorless substance found in theallantoic liquid of the fetal calf; -- formerly called allantoic acidand amniotic acid.
A colorlees or greenish oil extracted from cajuput.
A genus of herbaceous plants, some of them having berries whichabound in intensely red juice; poke, or pokeweed.
The nest or dwelling of a swarm of ants; an ant-hill.
A West African monkey (Cercopithecus cephus). It has yellowwhiskers, and a triangular blue mark on the nose.
A series or range of columns placed at regular intervals withall the adjuncts, as entablature, stylobate, roof, etc.
A name given to the series of sandstones and schists overlyingthe true nummulitic formation in the Alps, and included in the EoceneTertiary.
An African two-horned rhinoceros (Atelodus, or Rhinoceros,simus); -- called also chukuru, and white rhinoceros.
To come between. [R.]Self-sown woodlands of birch, alder, etc., intervening the differentestates. De Quincey.
Obscuration of the field of vision due to the appearance of adark spot before the eye.
A spoon-shaped instrument, used in extracting certainsubstances or foreign bodies.
A written decision of a Turkish mufti on some point of law.Whitworth.
A kind of light passenger vehicle, carrying four persons.
Plumpness of person; -- said especially of persons somewhatcorpulent.
An instrument for examining the condition of the ear.
To give predictions; to foreshow events; to prophesy. [R.]"Prophetizing dreams." Daniel.
To pass off in the form of vapor or insensible perspiration; toexhale.
A surface of ground on which water may be caught and collectedinto a reservoir.
A complex nitrogenous substance related to urea and uric acid,produced as a white powder; -- so called because it forms yellowsalts, and because its solution forms a blue fluorescence likequinine.
Food for dogs, made from the refuse of tallow melting.
Agalmatolite; -- so called because sometimes carved by theChinese into the form of pagodas. See Agalmatolite.
Malmsey wine. See Malmsey. " A jub of malvesye." Chaucer.
Incapable of being counted; not ascertainable; innumerable.
Restoration of a part by granulation, adhesive inflammation, orautoplasty.
Any one of several South American wrens, noted for thesweetness of their song.
One of several pivoted pieces forming the throat of anadjustable die used in drawing wire, lead pipe, etc. Knight.
To separate or disunite, as what has been soldered; hence, todivide; to sunder. [Formerly written also unsoder.] Tennyson.
To emit foam; to froth; -- said of the emission of yeast frombeer in course of fermentation. [Obs.] W. Cartright.
An alloy consisting of copper, nickel, tungsten, and aluminium;-- used by jewelers.
One who reigns before another; a sovereign predecessor. [R.]Warner.
Want of sleep; inability to sleep; wakefulness; sleeplessness.
Unregardful of the Muses; disregarding the power of poetry;unpoetical. Milton.
One who sells wares by crying them in the street; hence, apeddler or a packman.
The act of kindling or the state of being kindled; ignition.Locke.
Portions of small fish used for bait on the banks ofNewfoundland.

A curious vegetable production of the Southern Atlantic UnitedStates, growing under ground like a truffle and often attainingimmense size. The real nature is unknown. Called also Indian bread,and Indian loaf.
A lightning conductor erected, as in a vineyard, for drawingoff the electricity in the atmosphere in order to prevent hailstorms.[France] Knight.
one of the side at the bat posted near first or third base todirect a base runner.
All the zooids of a hydroid colony collectively, including thenutritive and reproductive zooids, and often other kinds.
A genus of great seaweeds with long and broad fronds; kelp, ordevil's apron. The fronds commonly grow in clusters, and aresometimes from thirty to fifty feet in length. See Illust. of Kelp.
The fold of peritoneum connecting the ovary with the wall ofthe abdominal cavity.
One who acquires an estate in lands by his own act oragreement, or who takes or obtains an estate by any means other thanby descent or inheritance.
To exert one's influence secretly. [Obs.] Ld. North.
Composed of parts united according to a law of twinning. SeeTwin, n., 4.
State or character of a zany; buffoonery. Coleridge. H. Morley.
A zeolitic mineral, grayish white or yellowish, occuring indelicate groups of crystals, also fibrous massive. It is a hydroussilicate of alumina, lime, and soda.
. Capable of being excoriated.The scaly covering of fishes, . . . even in such as are excoriatable.Sir T. Browne.
A border one fifth the width of the shield, surrounding thefield. It is usually plain, but may be charged.

A native double salt, consisting of a combination of neutraland acid sodium carbonate, Na2CO3.2HNaCO3.2H2O, occurring as a whitecrystalline fibrous deposit from certain soda brine springs andlakes; -- called also urao, and by the ancients nitrum.
Cross-shaped; (Bot.) having four parts arranged in the form ofa cross.
The act or process of giving form or shape to anything; as, inshipbuilding, the exact shaping of partially shaped timbers.
The germinating point in the embryo of a seed; the point in theyolk of an egg at which development begins.
A rolling of a body; a wallowing. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
More or less extensive patches of subcutaneous extravasation ofblood.
Falling in small drops; mistling; mizzing. [Obs.] Arbuthnot.
To furnish with a title or titles; to entitle. [Obs.] Carlyle.
A brittle gem occurring in light green, transparent crystals,affording a brilliant clinodiagonal cleavage. It is a silicate ofalumina and glucina.
A genus of cretaceous fossil shells allied to the oyster.
A writ of right for a tenant in tail in case of adiscontinuance of the estate tail. This writ has been abolished.
Boscage; also, the state or quality of being bosky.
Of or pertaining to the tarsus (either of the foot or eye).-- n.
Volcanic ashes, consisting of small, angular, stony fragmentsor particles.
One who attends a market to buy or sell; one who carries goodsto market.
To transfer the title of from one to another; to alienate.
Pertaining to, or designating, certain compounds of iodine andoxygen.
One versed in pomology; one who culticvates fruit trees.
The ancient title of emperors of Germany assumed by KingWilliam of Prussia when crowned sovereign of the new German empire in1871.
Native lead molybdate occurring in tetragonal crystals, usuallytabular, and of a bright orange-yellow to red, gray, or brown color;-- also called yellow lead ore.
A variety of gelatin; the chief ingredient of raw silk,extracted as a white amorphous mass.
The monetary unit of Nicaragua, equivalent to the United Statesgold dollar.
A little flower; one of the numerous little flowers whichcompose the head or anthodium in such flowers as the daisy, thistle,and dandelion. Gray.
A conical or branching body, by which a seaweed is attached toits support, and differing from a root in that it is not speciallyabsorbent of moisture.
An instrument consisting of a fine, sharp hook attached to ahandle, and used mainly for taking up arteries, and the like.
A genus of marine mollusks belonging to the Scaphopoda, havinga tubular conical shell.
A kind of reddish, moderately acid, winter apple. [U.S.]
A trickish knave; one who carries on any business, especiallylegal business, in a mean and dishonest way. [Slang, U.S.]
An implement, with teeth like those of a comb, for removing theseeds and seed vessels from flax, broom corn, etc.
To cause to seem to be a miracle. [R.] Shaftesbury.
One who is in the same class with another, as at school orcollege.
One of fifty equal parts; the quotient of a unit divided byfifty.
The office or the province of an exarch. Jer. Taylor.
An inhabitant or burgess of a port, esp. of one of the CinquePorts.
Having the characteristic of Zoilus, a bitter, envious, unjustcritic, who lived about 270 years before Christ.
Of or pertaining to Saturn, whose age or reign, from themildness and wisdom of his government, is called the golden age.
Of or pertaining to a hare; like or characteristic of, a hare.
A small eminence of a conical form, of land or of ice; a knoll;a hillock. See Hummock. Bartram.
A piano having a mechanical attachment which enables the playerto prolong the notes at will.
Pertaining to, or affected by, aphasia; speechless.

An order, or suborder, including the kamichi, and allied SouthAmerican birds; -- called also screamers. In many anatomicalcharacters they are allied to the Anseres, but they externallyresemble the wading birds.
In a frolicsome manner; with mirth and gayety. [Obs.] Beau. &Fl.
One who has constant day duties on board ship, and keeps noregular watch. Totten.
Capable of being protruded or thrust out; protractile;protrusive.
The ninth month of the year, containing thurty days.
A system of excavating by means of gullets or channels.
One who has received the highest of the four minor orders inthe Catholic church, being ordained to carry the wine and water andthe lights at the Mass.
The decimal part of a logarithm, as distinguished from theintegral part, or characteristic.
The act of deterring; also, that which deters. Boyle.

A small packet of explosive material with wire appendagesallowing it to be conveniently attached to a railroad track. It willexplode with a loud report when run over by a train, and is used toprovide a warning signal to the engineer.
A South American bird, of the genus Aramus, allied to therails.
A woodman; especially, one who lives in the forest.
The act of adoring; adoration. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Cottagelike; suitable for a cottage; rustic. [Obs.] Jer.Taylor.
A dilated base or receptacle, supporting a multilocular ovary.
A light part song, or madrigal, with a fa la burden or chorus,-- most common with the Elizabethan madrigal composers.
The wood of trees, esp. of oaks, dug up from peat bogs. It isof a shining black or ebony color, and is largely used for makingornaments.
Very soft; -- a direction to execute a passage as softly aspossible. (Abbrev. pp.)

A small, slender European hawk (Falco alaudarius), allied tothe sparrow hawk. Its color is reddish fawn, streaked and spottedwith white and black. Also called windhover and stannel. The name isalso applied to other allied species.
A lateral cavity of the prosencephalon; a lateral ventricle ofthe brain. B. G. Wilder.
An elementary substance which forms one of the constituents ofdidymium. Symbol Nd. Atomic weight 140.8.
A pastil or troche, composed of various aromatic and otheringredients, highly celebrated in India as an antidote, and as astomachic and antispasmodic.
An instrument for measuring the dimensions of the pelvis. Coxe.
The quality or state of being potent; powerfulness; potency;efficacy.
The part inclosed within the walls of an ancient temple, asdistinguished from the open porticoes.
A bitter white crystalline nitrogenous substance, obtainedindirectly from oil of mustard and ammonia; -- called also allylmelamine.
A small breed of dogs having a long body and short crookedlegs. These dogs were formerly much used for turning a spit on whichmeat was roasting.
One of the aboriginal inhabitants of New Zealand; also, theoriginal language of New Zealand.-- a.
A genus of amphibians, inhabiting the Southern United States,having a serpentlike form, but with four minute limbs and twopersistent gill openings; the Congo snake.
One who, or that which, banishes or expels. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Having no silcver; hence, without money; impecunious. PiersPlowman.
The fossil root stem of a coal plant of the genus Sigillaria.

One of the group of shooting stars which come into the air incertain years on or about the 19th of April; -- so called because theapparent path among the stars the stars if produced back wardscrosses the constellation Lyra.
One who, or that which, inks; especially, in printing, the pador roller which inks the type.
Capable of being ordained; worthy to be ordained or appointed.Bp. Hall.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid found in galipot, andisomeric with abietic acid.
A kind of clay for making melting pots. Percy Smith.
Easily managed; obedient to the helm; -- said of a vessel.
Variability in chemical constitution without variation incrystalline form.
The art or process of measuring the specific gravity of fluids.
An iron rod used by glass makers for manipulating the hotglass; -- called also, puntil, puntel, punty, and ponty. See Fascet.
A quilted military doublet or gambeson worn in the 14th and15th centuries; also, a name for the doublet of the 16th and 17thcenturies worn by civilians.
Made of velvet, or like velvet; soft; smooth; delicate.
A determining feature; a distinguishing characteristic adifferentia.
The quality of being amorous; lovingness. [R.] Galt.
Partaking of the nature ofcalcite or calcium carbonate;consisting of, or containg, calcium carbonate or carbonate of lime.Clcareous spar. See as Calcite.
The bone or cartilage of the tarsus which articulates with thetibia and corresponds to a part of the astragalus in man and mostmammals.
The wax secreted by bees, and of which their cells areconstructed.
To move or pass (something) over a surface quickly so that ittouches only at intervals; to skip.
A religious harangue; a sermon; -- used derogatively. Shak.
To appear in court personally or by attorney. [Scot]
One who pillages; a plunderer; a pillager. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
The act of destroying a fetus in the womb; feticide.
A small dumb keyboard used by pianists for exercising thefingers; -- called also dumb piano.
Diabolical conduct; malignant mischief; devilry. C. Reade.
Pertaining to, or designating, a nitrogenous organic acid ofthe uric acid group, obtained by the decomposition of allantoin, andusually called allanturic acid.
Awful, or reverential, in an excessive degree. [R.] Milton.
Rough brick masonry used to fill in the interstices of a woodenframe, in building.
The act of fitting; that which is proper or becoming;equipment. [Obs.] Shak.
The letting of one timber into another by alternate scores orprojections, as in shipbuilding.
A kind of crossbow formerly used for shooting stones. Shak.

An apparatus, or a process, for communicating intelligencerapidly between distant points, especially by means of preconcertedvisible or audible signals representing words or ideas, or by meansof words and signs, transmitted by electrical action.

A form of French versification, sometimes imitated in English,in which three or four rhymes recur through three stanzas of eight orten lines each, the stanzas concluding with a refrain, and the wholepoem with an envoy.
A tribe of American Indians including many of the Pueblos ofNew Mexico and adjacent regions.
Money paid for transportation of goods, etc., by water. [Eng.]
The act of imbuing; the state of being imbued; hence, a deeptincture.
To tear limb from limb; to dismember. [Obs.] Bailey.
In a manner to please, or to excite love. [Obs. or R.] Tyndale.
A condition of the penis in which the prepuce can not be drawnback so as to uncover the glans penis.
Missing; wanting. [Prov. Scot. & Eng.] Sir W. Hamilton.
A hood; especialy, the hood attached to the gown of a monk.
The hundredth part of a franc; a small French copper coin andmoney of account.
Being or growing under water, as the leaves of aquatic plants.
An old astronomical instrument, formed of two cones, on whosesurface the constellations were delineated.
A suborder of carnivorous and insectivorous marsupialsincluding the dasyures and the opossums.
One of a religious order who are the regular clerks of theScuole Pie (religious schools), an institute of secondary education,founded at Rome in the last years of the 16th century. Addis &Arnold.
Divalent; -- said of a base or radical as capable of saturatingtwo acid monad radicals or a dibasic acid. Cf. Dibasic, a., andBiacid.
An American Indian game analogous to dice, probably originallya method of divination.
An amido derivative of xanthic acid obtained as a whitecrystalline substance, C2H5O.CS.NH2; -- called also xanthogen amide.
A tribe of Indians who inhabited the south side of the MissouriRiver. They are now partly civilized and occupy a reservation inNebraska.
A carnivorous animal of the Weasel family (Mustela zibellina)native of the northern latitudes of Europe, Asia, and America, --noted for its fine, soft, and valuable fur.
The long-tailed pangolin (Manis tetradactyla); -- called alsoipi.
An acetabulum; or about one eighth of a pint. [Obs.] Holland.
The act of debasing or the state of being debased. Milton.
Pertaining to, or derived from, beeswax; specif., denoting anacid obtained by oxidation of myricin.
Half the gorge, or entrance into a bastion, taken from theangle of the flank to the center of the bastion.
The act of excusing; seizure by law. [Obs.] Ayliffe.
To intervene; to come or occur in the meantime. [Obs.] Shelton.
An Australian crested insessorial bird (Sphenostoma cristatum)having a wedge-shaped bill. Its color is dull brown, like the earthof the plains where it lives.
The space at the mouth of a level next the shaft, widened topermit wagons to pass, or ore to be deposited for hoisting; -- calledalso platt. Raymond.
Inquire; question; see; -- used to signify doubt or to suggestinvestigation.
A medicinal preparation made by mixing or dissolving asubstance in glycerin.
One who, or that which, insures; the person or company thatcontracts to indemnify losses for a premium; an underwriter.
A goatsucker, esp. the European species. See Illust. ofGoatsucker.
The act of stripping, as trees, of leaves or branches; a kindof pruning. Evelyn.

Any one of several species of large Old World ducks of thegenus Tadorna and allied genera, especially the European and Asiaticspecies. (T. cornuta, or tadorna), which somewhat resembles a goosein form and habit, but breeds in burrows.
To advise or counsel before the time of action, or before theevent. Shak.
A French money of account, afterward a silver coin equal to 20sous. It is not now in use, having been superseded by the franc.
A system or method of fishing by means of a number of hooks seton snoods all on one line; -- in North America, called trawl fishing,bultow, or bultow fishing, and long-line fishing.
A proteidlike body found in the fluid from ovarian cysts andelsewhere. It is generally associated with a substance related to, ifnot identical with, glycogen.
An officer of the church who has the care of the utensils ormovables, and of the church in general; a sexton.
A salt glaze on pottery, made by adding common salt to anearthenware glaze.
Situated beyond or below the red rays; as, the ultrated rays ofthe spectrum, which are less refrangible than the red.
The building in which a State legislature holds its sessions; aState capitol. [U. S.]
Among the ancients, a two-handled vessel, tapering at thebottom, used for holding wine, oil, etc.
An elastic textile fabric imitating knitting, of whichstockings, under-garments, etc., are made.
The condition or quality of being frivolous; also, acts orhabits of trifling; unbecoming levity of disposition.
A tribe of lizards including the skinks. See Skink.
To surpass in daring; to overcome by courage; to brave. Shak.R. Browning.
One who travels over lands or countries; one who travelsoverland.
Made holy; also, made to have the air of sanctity;sanctimonious.

Pertaining to, or designating, an acid, C8H12O4, related tofumaric acid, and obtained from citraconic acid as an oily substancehaving a bittersweet taste; -- so called from its tendency to formits anhydride.
A rare metallic element of which little is known. It is said byScacchi to have been extracted from a yellowish incrustation from thecracks of a Vesuvian lava erupted in 1631.
To register; to enter, as in a register. [R.] Walsh.
An open furnace or forge, in which blooms are heated beforebeing wrought into bars.
A genus of palm trees including the palmetto of the SouthernUnited States.
Of or pertaining to Vienna, or people of Vienna.-- n. sing. & pl.
Something which excites distaste or disgust. [Obs.] Speed.
An iron block, usually bolted to a ship's deck, for controllingthe running out of a chain cable. The links of the cable tend to dropinto hollows in the block, and thus hold fast until disengaged.
Of or pertaining to John, esp. to the Apostle John or hiswritings. M. Stuart.
A cake of unleavened bread eaten by the Jews at the feast ofthe Passover.
Anancient tenure of land, which obliged the tenant to givenotice of an invasion by blowing a horn.
A warm or spicy condiment or pickle made in India, compoundedof various vegetable substances, sweets, acids, etc.
An extensive family of butterflies including the nymphs, thesatyrs, the monarchs, the heliconias, and others; -- called alsobrush-footed butterflies.
A substance resembling mannite, found in the needles of thecommon silver fir of Europe (Abies pectinata). Eng. Cyc.
A more or less subtle playing upon the meaning of words.

The curved channel in which a breast wheel turns. It is closelyadapted to the curve of the wheel through about a quarter of itscircumference, and prevents the escape of the water until it hasspent its force upon the wheel. See Breast wheel.
To affect with necrosis; to unergo necrosis. Quain.
A cavity; a depression. Specifically:(a) A cavity in a bone or other part, either closed or with a narrowopening.(b) A dilated vessel or canal.
A cuplet or little cup, as the acorn; the husk or bur of thefilbert, chestnut, etc.
A material of wool or silk used for working the figures inembroidery.
A division of birds including those whose young are able to runabout when first hatched.
A penalty inflicted by a court of justice on a convictedoffender as a just retribution, and incidentally for the purposes ofreformation and prevention.
The harvest mite; -- so called from the wheals, caused by itsbite.
A measure of capacity, equal to ten steres, or ten cubicmeters.
A pin worn of the breast for a fastening, or for ornament; abrooch.
Making thin, as fluids; diluting; rendering less dense andviscid; diluent.-- n. (Med.)
Having the form of the Greek capital letter Omega (
A rate or proportion estimated at a certain amount for eachpound; poundage.
A stairway or incline arranged like an endless belt so that thesteps or treads ascend or descend continuously, and one stepping uponit is carried up or down; -- a trade term.
Relating to, or resulting from, or resembling, cholera.
To remove a bank from; to open by, or as if by, the removal ofa bank. H. Taylor.
Advantage; gain; gain by plunder; booty. [Obs.] Sir. J.Harrington.
Of or pertaining to amitosis; karyostenotic; -- opposed tomitotic.
The influence of a star upon other stars or upon men. [Obs.]Chaucer.
Native sulphide of arsenic, including sandarach, or realgar,and orpiment.
A salt of vanadious acid, analogous to a nitrite or aphosphite.
A native or inhabitant of Paris, the capital of France.
Born free; not born in vasssalage; inheriting freedom.
A variety of epidote, of a reddish color, found in Scotland.
The name of two Mohammedan festivals, of which one is held atthe close of the fast called Ramadan, and the other seventy daysafter the fast.
A large food fish (Anoplopoma fimbria) of the north Pacificcoast; -- called also candlefish.
The posterior division of the foot in the Gastropoda andPteropoda.
One who is afficted with pellagra. Chambers's Encyc.
A speck or stain made by the excrement of a fly; hence, anyinsignificant dot.
Of or pertaining to Lithuania (formerly a principality unitedwith Poland, but now Russian and Prussian territory).
Palmate, with the divisions separated but little more thanhalfway to the common center.
An organic base, C9H6.N.CH3, metameric with quinaldine, andobtained by the distillation of cinchonine.
An outwork composed of two demibastions joined by a curtain. Itis connected with the works in rear by long wings.
An act on the part of the vassal which cost him his fee byforfeiture. Burrill.
The quality or state of being irrelative; want of connection orrelation.
A bright red pigment consisting of mercuric sulphide, obtainedeither from the mineral cinnabar or artificially. It has a fine redcolor, and is much used in coloring sealing wax, in printing, etc.
The quality or state of being viable. Specifically: --(a) (Law)
The bracteal covering of the flowers or seeds of grain andgrasses; esp., an outer husk or bract of a spikelt. Gray.
That of the pericardium which forms the outer surface of theheart; the cardiac pericardium.

A hole bored through a tenon nearer to the shoulder than theholes through the cheeks are to the edge or abutment against whichthe shoulder is to rest, so that a pin or bolt, when driven into it,will draw these parts together. Weale.

A stage in the development of certain insects, such as the Mayflies, intermediate between the pupa and imago. In this stage, theinsect is able to fly, but subsequently sheds a skin before becomingmature. Called also pseudimago.
To paint or tinge with red lead or vermilion; also, to decoratewith letters, or the like, painted red, as the page of a manuscript.T. Wharton.
In a privy manner; privately; secretly. Chaucer. 2 Pet. ii. 1.
A kind of fresh-water bass; the crappie. [Southern U.S.]
A popular name for mica, especially when in thin sheets.
To resolve beforehand; to predetermine. Sir E. Dering.
An element which forms no part of the original root; -- opposedto radical.

A milky fluid containing the fatty matter of the food in astate of emulsion, or fine mechanical division; formed from chyme bythe action of the intestinal juices. It is absorbed by the lacteals,and conveyed into the blood by the thoracic duct.
A group intermediate in importance between an order and asubclass.
A colorless gas, PH3, analogous to ammonia, and having adisagreeable odor resembling that of garlic. Called also hydrogenphosphide, and formerly, phosphureted hydrogen.
Not licked; hence, not properly formed; ungainly. Cf. To lickinto shape, under Lick, v. Shak.
A temporary substitute for a bed, as one made on the floor oron chairs; -- perhaps originally from the shaking down of straw forthis purpose. Sir W. Scott.
In an abusive manner; rudely; with abusive language.
Any species of the genus Sarcoptes and related genera of mites,comprising the itch mites and mange mites.-- a.
An instrument resembling the astrolabe, formerly used formeasuring the angles between heavenly bodies; -- called alsopantacosm.
A kind of blue color; also, anciently, a kind of cloth,generally blue.
A work consisting of two or more bastioned fronts, with theiroutworks, covering an enceinte, a bridgehead, etc., and connected bywings with the main work or the river bank.
To make total, or complete;to reduce to completeness.Coleridge.
The south America alligator. See Alligator. [Sometimes writtencaiman.]
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained as a whiteamorphous deliquescent substance, C8H10O11; -- called alsoditartaric, tartrilic, or tartrylic acid.
Resembling, or covered with, a sleeve; -- said of the chiefwhen lines are drawn from the middle point of the upper edge upperedge to the sides.
One who believes in the second coming of Christ to reign onearth a thousand years; a milllenarian.
A mineral which is opaque in its natural state, but is said tochange its color and become transparent by heat.

A fine or composition which the heir of a deceased tenant paidto the lord for the privilege of taking up the estate, which, onstrict feudal principles, had lapsed or fallen to the lord on thedeath of the tenant.
To do the first act; to perform the first rite; to take theinitiative. [R.] Pope.
Of or pertaining to Galicia, in Spain, or to Galicia, thekingdom of Austrian Poland.-- n.
Saturnian; -- applied to the North Polar Sea. [R.] Milton.
Cylindrical with alternate swellings and contractions; havingthe surface covered with rounded prominences.
Abounding in, or resembling, chips; dry and tasteless.
A flat piece of metal; especially, a disk of metal ready to bestamped as a coin.
Having three bellies; -- said of a muscle. Dunglison.
Of or pertaining to an amulet; operating as a charm.
A conspicuous wild flower (Centaurea Cyanus), growing ingrainfields.
A custom of the Celts, or an idiom of their language. Warton.
A hypothetical radical regarded as the essential residue ofmyricin; -- called also melissyl.
The middle division of the small intestine, between theduodenum and ileum; -- so called because usually found empty afterdeath.
One who, or that which, seasons, or gives a relish; aseasoning.
A colored albuminous substance in the serum from red-coloredmuscles. It is identical with hemoglobin.
The stud in which the bearing for the lower pivot of the vergeis made.
A follower of John Huss, the Bohemian reformer, who wasadjudged a heretic and burnt alive in 1415.
Having the stamens and pistils in separate flowers. Gray.
To rise in value. [See note under Rise, v. i.] J. Morse.
A kind of divination drawn from the responses of oracles amongheathen nations.
The act of bringing forth a child; travail; labor. Jer. Taylor.
A large ship of burden, in ancient Greece. Mitford.
Not purified according to the ceremonial law of Moses; unclean.
The practice of killing persons for the purpose of sellingtheir bodies for dissection.
Deprived of manly qualities; deficient in vigor, strength,courage, etc.; weak; effeminate.
A morbid state or condition not preceded or occasioned by anyother disease; a primary disease.
One of various plants, supposed to have efficacy in drivingaway fleas. They belong, for the most part, to the genera Conyza,Erigeron, and Pulicaria.
Any small book carried about for sale by chapmen or hawkers.Hence, any small book; a toy book.
The muscular and tendinous partition separating the cavity ofthe chest from that of the abdomen; the midriff.
A repetition of a word or of words at the beginning of two ormore successive clauses.
A byword; a proverb; also, a watchword. [Obs.] hak.
A ball or globe forming part of the regalia of an emperor orother sovereign. It is encircled with bands, enriched with preciousstones, and surmounted with a cross; -- called also globe.
A plant with a conspicuous, dry, unwithering involucre, as thespecies of Antennaria, Helichrysum, Gomphrena, etc. See Everlasting.
A Buddhist priest of the higher orders in Burmah. Malcom.
A genus of wingless parasitic Hemiptera, including the commonlice of man. See Louse.
The act or state of bursting forth; a bursting out. [R.] Sir T.Browne.
Destitute of leaves, as the broom rape, certain euphorbiaceousplants, etc.
One who welds, or unites pieces of iron, etc., by welding.
The state of being a cenobite; the belief or practice of acenobite. Milman.
A name sometimes applied to a member of any sect holding thatrebaptism is necessary for those baptized in infancy.
The office, or period of office, of an augur. Bacon.
One whose business it is to clean, extract, or repair naturalteeth, and to make and insert artificial ones; a dental surgeon.
Of, like, or pertaining to, a deer of the genus Rucervus, whichincludes the swamp deer of India.
A plant (Polianthes tuberosa) with a tuberous root and aliliaceous flower. It is much cultivated for its beautiful andfragrant white blossoms.

A squirrel-like animal of the genus Tamias, sometimes calledthe striped squirrel, chipping squirrel, ground squirrel, hackee. Thecommon species of the United States is the Tamias striatus. [Writtenalso chipmonk, chipmuck, and chipmuk.]
A jocosely depreciative name for a dwelling or shop.[Slang,U.S.]
Of or pertaining to the grasses which are cultivated for theiredible seeds (as wheat, maize, rice, etc.), or to their seeds orgrain.
The operation of opening the fetal head, in order to effectdelivery.
Of or pertaining to the styloid process and the hyoid bone.
One of the dilatations of the body wall of Bryozoa in which theova sometimes undegro the first stages of their development. SeeIllust. of Chilostoma.
One who visualizes or is proficient in visualization; esp.(Physiol.),
The European sand ray (Raia maculata); -- called also home,mirror ray, and rough ray.
A species of steel imported from the East Indies, valued formaking edge tools; Indian steel. It has in combination a minuteportion of alumina and silica.
A low, spreading weed (Scleranthus annuus), common in sandysoil.
An infidel; -- a term applied by Turks to disbelievers in theMohammedan religion, especially Christrians. Byron.
A cabal, intrigue, faction, contention, strife, or quarrel.[Obs.] Chesterfield.
A small bronze mortar mounted on a wooden block with handles,and light enough to be carried short distances by two men.
To make perpetual; to cause to endure, or to be continued,indefinitely; to preserve from extinction or oblivion; to eternize.Addison. Burke.
An erythematous affection of the skin, with severeconstitutional and nervous symptoms, endemic in Northern Italy.

A canticle (the Latin version of which begins with this word)which may be used in the order for morning prayer in the Church ofEngland. It is taken from an apocryphal addition to the third chapterof Daniel.
Of or pertaining to Siam, its native people, or their language.
One who treats of ideas; one who theorizes or idealizes; oneversed in the science of ideas, or who advocates the doctrines ofideology.
Having the power of uniting; causing, or tending to produce,union. Jer. Taylor.
A hole through which a man may descend or creep into a drain,sewer, steam boiler, parts of machinery, etc., for cleaning orrepairing.
A folding stool, or portable seat, made to fold up in themanner of a camo stool. It was formerly placed in the choir for abishop, when he offciated in any but his own cathedral church.Fairholt.
A kind of aggregate fruit in which the ovaries cohere in asolid mass, with a slender receptacle, as in the magnolia; also, asimilar multiple fruit, as a mulberry.
A genus of large marine gastropods. having a pear-shaped shell.It includes the fig-shells. See Illust. in Appendix.
To toot gently, repeatedly, or continuously, on a windinstrument, as a flute; also, to make a similar noise by any means."The tootling robin."  John Clare.
One who toys; one who is full of trifling tricks; a trifler.
A smith who works at the vice instead of at the anvil.
Equivalent in combining or displacing power to two atoms ofhydrogen; dyad.
The open sea supposed to surround the north pole. Kane.
A method of forming a joint at the intersection of window-sashbars, by cutting away only enough wood to show a miter.
To render parallel to a certain line or direction; to bringinto the same line, as the axes of telescopes, etc.; to renderparallel, as rays of light.
The formation situated between the Permian and Lias, and sonamed by the Germans, because consisting of three series of strata,which are called in German the Bunter sandstein, Muschelkalk, andKeuper.
The upper part of a horse's hoof, where the horn terminates inskin. James White.
A tribe of Indians native of the region between the Arkansasand Red rivers. They are related to the Pawnees. See Pawnees.
The alburnum, or part of the wood on any exogenous tree next tothe bark, being that portion of the tree through which the sap flowsmost freely; -- distinguished from Heartwood.
Apropriate to the relation of neighbors; having frequent orfamiliar intercourse; kind; civil; social; friendly.-- adv.
An American tree (Juglans cinerea) of the Walnut family, andits edible fruit; -- so called from the oil contained in the latter.Sometimes called oil nut and white walnut.
A suspension of arms by agreement of the commanders of opposingforces; a temporary cessation of hostilities, for negotiation orother purpose; an armistice.
A document, as a letter, deed, or will, wholly in thehandwriting of the person from whom it proceeds and whose act itpurports to be.
In an abominable manner; very odiously; detestably.
The science of rotary motion, or of wheel work. Wilkins.
An ornamental covering, as of carpet or leather, for a bench orform.
Belonging, or affected by, anasarca, or dropsy; dropsical.Wiseman.
Bearing silicles; pertaining to, or resembling, silicles.
An assemblage of upright stones with others placed horizontallyon their tops, on Salisbury Plain, England, -- generally supposed tobe the remains of an ancient Druidical temple.
The small, troublesome tumors or swellings about the anus andlower part of the rectum which are technically called hemorrhoids.See Hemorrhoids.
A bard, or learned man, among the ancient Goths. Sir W. Temple.
To hearten; to encourage; to incite. [Obs.] Spenser.
To change the nature of; to invest with a different or contrarynature. [Obs.]A right heavenly nature, indeed, as if were unnaturing them, doth sobridle them [the elements]. Sir P. Sidney.
A tribe of Indians formerly inhabiting the northern andweastern shores of Lake Superior; -- called also Objibways.
The defect of stammering; also, a kind of incompletepronunciation.
A carved ornament consisting of flowers, and leaves, intermixedor twisted together, wound with a ribbon, and hanging or depending ina natural curve. See Illust. of Bucranium.
Leading to sleep; -- applied to the illusions of one who ishalf asleep.
obs. 3d pers. sing. pres. of Shend, for shendeth. Chaucer.
The middle part of the alimentary canal from the stomach, orentrance of the bile duct, to, or including, the large intestine.
A salt of rhodanic acid; a sulphocyanate. [Obsoles.]
In an irresolute, undecided, or hesitating manner.I am somewhat dainty in making a resolution, because when I make it,I keep it; I don't stand shill-I-shall-I then; if I say 't, I'll do't. Congreve.
A substance capable of producing with another a reaction,especially when employed to detect the presence of other bodies; atest.
Any climbing woody vine of the tropics with the habit of aliane; in the Philippines, esp. any of various species of Calamus,the cane or rattan palm.
A mineral occurring in transparent emerald green crystals. Itis hydrous arseniate of copper.
A very large species of frog (Rana Catesbiana), found in NorthAmerica; -- so named from its loud bellowing in spring.

A close garnment with straight sleeves, and skirts reaching tothe ankles, and buttoned in front from top to bottom; especially, theblack garment of this shape worn by the clergy in France and Italy astheir daily dress; a cassock.
To disinherit; to cut off, or detain, from the possession orenjoyment of an inheritance. [Obs.] Spenser.
A fabric made in Manilla from the older leaf sheaths of theabaca (Musa textilis).
A hydrocarbon, C14H10, related both to the acetylene and thearomatic series, and produced artificially as a white crystallinesubstance; -- called also diphenyl acetylene.
A lemur; -- applied to several species, as the White-fronted,the ruffed, and the ring-tailed lemurs.
The principles of the aristocratic party in Prussia.
One addicted to egotism; one who speaks much of himself ormagnifies his own achievements or affairs.
A West Indian name for two large timber trees (Podocarpuscoriaceus, and P. Purdicanus) of the Yew family. The wood, which ismuch used, is pale brownish with darker streaks.
Resembling a ladder; formed with steps. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
To dispose in due order, as the different quarterings on anescutcheon, or the different crests when several belong to anachievement.
A plate of timber for the end of a beam or joist to rest on.Gwilt
1. One who follows; a pursuer; an attendant; a disciple; adependent associate; a retainer.
The governor of a province in ancient Persia; hence, a pettyautocrat despot.
An agreement between belligerents for the exchange ofprisoners. Wilhelm.
To moisten and rub (a diseased part) with a liquid substance,as with spirit, oil, etc., by means of a cloth or sponge.
A mixtire of caustic lime and orpiment, or tersulphide ofarsenic, -- used in the depilation of hides. Knight.
An intrusion of one vegetable cell into the cavity of another,sometimes forming there an irregular mass of cells. Goodale.
A ridge or projecting edge on a shoulder piece to turn the blowof a lance or other weapon from the joint of the armor.
A punishment sometimes used by the ancients, consisting in thebesmearing of the criminal with honey, and exposing him to insects.It is still in use among some Oriental nations.
Of pertaining to Canopus in egypt; as, the Canopic vases, usedin embalming.
A gaping after; eager desire; craving. [R.] Bp. Hall.
Possessed of the properties of chyle; consisting of chyle.
A kind of ornament consisting of a narrow fillet or bandfolded, crossed, and interlaced.
A tall weed with purplish flowers (Vernonia Noveboracensis).The name is also applied to other plants of the same genus.
In the manner of a chorus; adapted to be sung by a choir; inharmony.
To cause loss or damage to; to injure; to imparir. [R.]This work will ask as many more officials to make expurgations andexpunctions, that the commonwealth of learning be not damnified.Milton.
A doctor or teacher in the Armenian church. Members of thisorder of ecclesiastics frequently have charge of dioceses, withepiscopal functions.
A piece of woodland; a small wood. [Obs.] See Holt.
A bucket for removing mud from a bored hole; a sand pump.
The art of, or method for, assisting the memory by associatingthe thing or subject to be remembered with some place. [R.]
One of twe or more occupying the same room or rooms; one whoshares the occupancy of a room or rooms; a chum.
The conductir of a mule team; also, a head shepherd.
The act of obtaining a favor by surprise, or by unfairrepresentation through suppression or fraudulent concealment offacts. Bp. Hall.
The quality or condition of being viviparous. H. Spencer.
Of or performance to Argos, the capital of Argolis in Greece.-- n.
An instrument for exhibition or illustration of the phenomenaof halos, parhelia, and the like.
Of or pertaining to Whigs; partaking of, or characterized by,the principles of Whigs.
A style of bookbinding in which the back is plain leather, thesides paper or cloth, the top gilt-edged, but the front and bottomleft uncut.
One who takes care of baggage; a camp follower. [Obs.] Sir W.Raleigh.
The order of fishes which includes the Gymnotus or electricaleel. The dorsal fin is wanting.
One of the processes of the shell which project inwards andunite with one another, in the thorax of many Crustacea.
The quality or state of being penetrant; power of entering orpiercing; penetrating power of quality; as, the penetrancy of subtileeffluvia.
A dwelling or standing on something; fixedness; persistence.[Obs.] Shak.
An aqueous solution of formaldehyde, used as a preservative inmuseums and as a disinfectant.
One who inlays, or whose occupation it is to inlay.
A tribe of edentates comprising the sloths. They are noted forthe slowness of their movements when on the ground. See Sloth, 3.
A tender to a fleet, formerly used for conveying men, orders,or treasure. [Spain & Portugal]
To take the saddle off; to unsaddle. [Obs.] Jervas.
Dropping off or disappearing early, as the calyx of a poppy, orthe gills of a tadpole.
A saclike envelope of certain fungi, which bursts open as theplant develops.
A favorite; a paramour; an ingle. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A cetacean allied to the grampus; -- called also bottle-nosedwhale.
One who, or that which, purges or cleanses; especially, acathartic medicine.
One whose wealth gives him power or influence; one of theplutocracy.
To have time before pleading; to have delay for mutualadjustment. Blackstone.
One prone to sound or excite alarms, especially, needlessalarms. Macaulay.
To laugh boisterously. [Colloq. U. S.]We haw-haw'd, I tell you, for more than half an hour. Major JackDowning.
A lighter, or vessel for inland navigation. [Scot.] Jamieson.
One who practices or advocates strict conformity to law; intheology, one who holds to the law of works. See Legal, 2 (a).
A massive and fibrous mineral of a whitish color, chieflyhydrous silicate of lime.

The transference of the relation between one set of objects toanother set for the purpose of brief explanation; a compressedsimile; e. g., the ship plows the sea. Abbott & Seeley. "All theworld's a stage." Shak.
The outermost of the three small auditory bones, ossicles; thehammer. It is attached to the tympanic membrane by a long process,the handle or manubrium. See Illust. of Far.
The unlaid or ragged end of a rope. Ham. Nav. Encyc.
An officer whose duty it is to observe what escheats have takenplace, and to take charge of them. Burrill.
A minute jointed filament growing among the archegonia andantheridia of mosses, or with the spore cases, etc., of otherflowerless plants.
A mass of timbers built into the bow and stern of a vessel togive solidity.
To make worse; -- the opposite of improve. [R.] Jer. Taylor.
A failure to make claim within the time limited by law;omission of claim.
A collection of the Novels or New Constitutions of Justinian,by an anonymous author; -- so called on account of its authencity.Bouvier.
Of or pertaining to a dwarf tree; shrublike. Da Costa.
An inflammation of the membranes or coats of the eye or of theeyeball.
The art of treating diseases of the hands and feet.
A box of the lowest tier in a theater.  Du Maurier.
A woman who is chief; a woman who has charge of the work orworkers in a shop or other place; a head woman. Tatler. W. Besant.
A small, overhanging structure for lookout or defense, usuallyprojecting at an angle of a building or near an entrance gateway.
A petticoat; the foundation skirt of a draped dress.
To strike, as the breech, with the open hand; to slap.
An embryonic insect which has twice cast its skin previous tohatching from the egg.
That loss of character, or public disgrace, which a convictincurs, and by which he is at common law rendered incompetent as awitness.
A flounder (Symphurus plagiusa) native of the southern coast ofthe United States.
Table linen; also, linen clothing, or linen in general. [Obs.]Gayton.
To furbish up for sale; to set off to advantage. [Obs. or R.]B. Jonson.
Facing outwards, or away from the axis of growth; -- said esp.of anthers occupying the outer side of the filament.
A woolly filament sometimes occuring with the sporules ofcertain fungi.
One of the four principal forms of clouds. SeeCloud.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a sulphonic (thionic) acidderivative of methane, obtained as a stable white crystallinesubstance, CH2.(SO3H)2, which forms well defined salts.
An alkaloid found in opium, and extracted as a whitecrystalline substance, tasteless and less poisonous than morphine; --called also narcotia.

A figure by which an adjective or verb, which agrees with anearer word, is, by way of supplement, referred also to another moreremote; as, "hic illius arma, hic currus fuit;" where fuit, whichagrees directly with currus, is referred also to arma.
An inflammable mineral resin, usually of a yellowish browncolor, found in roundish masses, sometimes with coal.
A class of articulate animals, nearly equivalent to Annelida,including the marine annelids, earthworms, Gephyrea, Gymnotoma,leeches, etc. See Annelida.
A group of ruminants whose horns are hollow, and planted on abony process of the front, as the ox.
A military mechanic, as a blacksmith, carpenter, etc.; also,one who prepares the shells, fuses, grenades, etc., in a militarylaboratory.
One who rejects of renounces upon oath; one who swears a falseoath.
Causing a discharge of water; expelling serum effused into anypart of the body, as in dropsy.-- n.
Of or relating to one of the early races in Mexico thatinhabited the great plateau of that country at the time of theSpanish conquest in 1519.-- n.
